sentence: In the C57BL/6J mouse model, CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the Bcl‑2 gene in RAW264.7 macrophages led to a marked increase in apoptotic cell death, confirming that Bcl‑2 is essential for cell‑line survival during inflammatory stimulation.

In C57BL/6J mice, the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the Brca1 gene in U87MG cells led to increased γ‑H2AX foci and a higher sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, confirming the synthetic lethal interaction between BRCA1 deficiency and topoisomerase II inhibition.

In U87MG cells, the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the EGFR gene leads to increased sensitivity to temozolomide and a concomitant decrease in phosphorylated AKT levels, suggesting that EGFR drives chemoresistance through PI3K‑AKT signaling.

In our study, the C57BL/6J mouse macrophage cell line RAW264.7 was treated with the small molecule inhibitor JQ1, leading to a significant down‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL6 and a concomitant increase in the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL2, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for inflammatory diseases.

Treatment of the glioblastoma cell line SJ‑GBM2 with the kinase inhibitor CH‑8 reduced phosphorylation of EGFR and induced apoptosis, a response that was markedly amplified when combined with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, suggesting that EGFR signaling mediates chemoresistance in SJ‑GBM2 cells.

Treatment with the BET inhibitor JQ1 reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis in the HCT116 and MCF7/AdrR cell lines, while co‑treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 rescued AKT phosphorylation and partially restored cell viability.

Treatment using the C57BL/6J mouse model revealed that the up‑regulation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway in HCT116 cells carrying the TP53 c.215C>G variant confers resistance to doxorubicin, whereas the same variant in MCF7/AdrR cells fails to activate the same survival signal, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific effect of the mutation on drug response.

Treatment-induced apoptosis of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line was markedly enhanced by co‑administration of doxorubicin, a result that was confirmed by increased caspase‑3 activation and reduced cell viability in vitro.

Upon long‑term exposure to the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑1β, the U87MG glioblastoma cell line exhibited a marked up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL10, which in turn enhanced the recruitment of RAW264.7 macrophages and promoted a tumor‑associated myeloid phenotype.

Upon chronic exposure to doxorubicin, the U87MG glioblastoma cell line exhibited a dramatic up‑regulation of the p53‑dependent apoptosis pathway, correlating with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant observed in the same culture.

Upon exposure to the oxidative agent tert‑butyl hydroperoxide, the C57BL/6J macrophage cell line RAW264.7 exhibited a pronounced up‑regulation of the Nrf2‑driven antioxidant gene NQO1, while the human glioblastoma line U87MG displayed a concomitant down‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, suggesting a differential cellular stress response that may influence therapeutic efficacy in tumor versus immune cells.

Upon inhibition of the PI3K/AKT pathway with LY294002, the C57BL/6J macrophage cell line RAW264.7 exhibited a marked reduction in TNF‑α secretion, suggesting that PI3K/AKT signaling is essential for the inflammatory response in this murine model.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induces apoptosis in the human cervical cancer cell line HeLa, a process that is amplified by overexpression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and suppressed by the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, thereby highlighting a potential interaction between drug efficacy and sequence‑variant status in this organoid model of Homo sapiens.

The RAW264.7 macrophage cell line treated with the STAT3 inhibitor stattic exhibited a marked decrease in IL‑6 secretion, suggesting that stattic suppresses pro‑inflammatory signaling in RAW264.7 cells.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the HCT116 cell line markedly increased the expression of the drug‑resistance gene ABCG2, thereby reducing doxorubicin efficacy and promoting a stem‑like phenotype that is characteristic of chemoresistant colorectal cancers.

The C57BL/6J mouse model, in which the PPARγ antagonist GW9662 was administered, exhibited reduced tumor growth in U87MG xenografts, whereas co‑treatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine restored the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and reversed the up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.

CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the HCT116 cell line dramatically increased the sensitivity of these cells to doxorubicin, as measured by a significant decrease in IC50 compared with wild‑type HCT116 cells.

CRBP1 knockdown in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line leads to increased sensitivity to temozolomide, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for enhancing chemotherapy efficacy in patients with TP53-mutant tumors.

CR‑ISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line (U87MG) led to increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin (doxorubicin) and concomitant up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX (BAX).

CRL-4003 (HeLa) cells treated with the BCL‑2 inhibitor venetoclax exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in caspase‑3 activation, whereas the C57BL/6J‑derived RAW264.7 macrophages showed no significant apoptosis despite the same drug exposure.

Activation of the NRF2 pathway by curcumin in the C57BL/6J‑derived RAW264.7 macrophage cell line reduces LPS‑induced IL‑6 secretion, thereby demonstrating a protective anti‑inflammatory effect in this murine model.

Activation-induced apoptosis of C57BL/6J splenocytes was markedly enhanced when the cells were treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor CH-8, which binds to the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX and promotes its oligomerization on the mitochondrial membrane.

Activation analysis revealed that the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 is up‑regulated in RAW264.7 macrophages treated with the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, whereas C57BL/6J mice carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit a reduced tumor‑suppressive response to the same drug.

Activation and subsequent apoptosis of the HCT116 cell line by the DNA‑crosslinking agent cisplatin was markedly enhanced when the cells were pre‑treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor of the PI3K/AKT pathway, LY294002, revealing a synergistic interaction that could be exploited for targeted cancer therapy.

C57BL/6J macrophages stimulated with lipopolysaccharide upregulate the NLRP3 inflammasome, a response that is markedly attenuated when the same cells are co‑treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor MCC950, thereby reducing IL‑1β secretion and ameliorating inflammatory pathology in the experimental model.

C64‑dependent phosphorylation of p53 in the C57BL/6J macrophage cell line RAW264.7 drives the transcriptional up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby enhancing the chemotactic response of neutrophils toward sites of tissue injury.

Cumulative exposure to doxorubicin in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line induces a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that correlates with increased apoptosis and heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent temozolomide.

Cytotoxicity assays on the C57BL/6J macrophage line RAW264.7 revealed that treatment with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin (CH-8) induced a dose-dependent increase in apoptotic markers, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for targeting inflammatory pathways in neurodegenerative disease models.
HCT116 cells treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin exhibit a marked up‑regulation of the p53‑dependent transcription factor p21, which in turn induces G1 arrest and enhances apoptosis.

HMC-1 cells expressing the NLRP3 inflammasome were treated with the selective NLRP3 inhibitor MCC950, resulting in a dose-dependent decrease in IL-1β secretion and reduced caspase‑1 activation in the C57BL/6J macrophage line RAW264.7.
Hepatocyte growth factor stimulation of the HCT116 cell line upregulates the CXCL12/CXCR4 axis, thereby enhancing migratory invasion through a PI3K‑AKT‑dependent pathway.
HIF‑1α activation in C57BL/6J macrophages exposed to the hypoxic micro‑environment of SJ‑GBM2 tumors drives VEGFA secretion, thereby promoting angiogenesis that supports U87MG glioblastoma growth.

Using the C57BL/6J mouse model, we observed that the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 was significantly up‑regulated in RAW264.7 macrophages treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor JAK2i, suggesting that JAK2 inhibition in this cell line may drive an anti‑inflammatory phenotype that could be exploited for therapeutic modulation of cytokine storms in severe COVID‑19 patients.
Using CRISPR-Cas9 editing, the TP53 knockout in HCT116 cells led to increased resistance to doxorubicin, whereas reintroduction of wild-type TP53 restored sensitivity and induced apoptosis.

Using C57BL/6J mice, we observed that the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 secreted by RAW264.7 macrophages up‑regulated the drug‑resistance transporter P‑gp in the HCT116 colorectal cancer cell line, thereby attenuating doxorubicin cytotoxicity.

Using a CRISPR/Cas9 knock‑in approach, we introduced the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant into the C57BL/6J mouse embryo, and subsequently isolated HCT116 cells that exhibited a marked increase in the expression of the DNA‑repair GeneOrGeneProduct BRCA1, thereby enhancing their resistance to the DNA‑damaging ChemicalEntity doxorubicin.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection of RAW264.7 macrophages upregulated the IL-1β promoter in a STAT3-dependent manner, thereby enhancing the inflammatory response and promoting the proliferation of U87MG glioblastoma cells.

Pifithrin‑α markedly reduced proliferation of the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line while simultaneously enhancing p53‑dependent apoptosis, a response that was not observed in the C57BL/6J mouse embryonic fibroblasts treated under identical conditions.
Pyrimethamine treatment of the HCT116 cell line reduces the expression of the drug‑resistance gene MDR1, thereby sensitizing the cells to cisplatin and increasing apoptosis.

P53-mediated apoptosis is markedly enhanced in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line when treated with the DNA‑crosslinking agent cisplatin, an effect that is attenuated by co‑administration of the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.

Engineered C57BL/6J mice overexpressing the mutant TP53 allele c.215C>G (p.Arg72Pro) exhibit increased tumor burden in U87MG glioblastoma xenografts, indicating that the sequence variant enhances oncogenic signaling in this human cell line.

Engineers cultured HCT116 and U87MG cells with the CRISPR‑edited TP53 c.68_69delAG variant, then treated them with doxorubicin to assess whether the mutation altered drug‑induced apoptosis and cell‑cycle arrest in these human tumor cell lines.

Engineer‑derived CRISPR/Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in HCT116 cells revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant increased chemotherapeutic resistance, a phenotype also observed in MCF7/AdrR cells treated with doxorubicin.

Engine-derived CRISPR-Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in the HCT116 cell line reduced the expression of the p21 protein, thereby increasing the susceptibility of these cells to the cytotoxic effects of doxorubicin.

Intracellular ROS levels were markedly elevated in C57BL/6J macrophage RAW264.7 cells treated with the pro‑oxidant drug doxorubicin, leading to activation of the p53‑dependent apoptosis pathway and a significant increase in the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.

Intriguingly, the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced a marked increase in the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX in the HCT116 cell line, whereas the same treatment had no detectable effect on BAX levels in the drug‑resistant MCF7/AdrR cells, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific response to DNA damage that may underlie differential sensitivity to anthracyclines.

Intratumoral injection of doxorubicin into C57BL/6J mice bearing subcutaneous HCT116 xenografts induced a marked reduction in tumor volume and upregulated the tumor suppressor TP53, while simultaneously activating the NF‑κB pathway in the surrounding RAW264.7 macrophages, thereby illustrating a complex interplay between chemotherapy, tumor cell apoptosis, and the innate immune response.

Intrigued by the differential response of the C57BL/6J and RAW264.7 macrophages to lipopolysaccharide, we discovered that the NF‑κB‑dependent upregulation of IL‑6 in RAW264.7 cells was markedly attenuated when treated with the novel small‑molecule inhibitor CH‑8, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for dampening chronic inflammation.

Knock‑down of the KRAS gene in the HCT116 cell line markedly reduced the expression of the downstream effector ERK1/2, thereby attenuating the proliferative response to the chemical carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene in a manner that mimics the phenotype observed in the C57BL/6J mouse model of colorectal cancer.

Knocking out the TP53 gene in the HCT116 cell line markedly enhances the cells’ resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis while simultaneously increasing the expression of the drug efflux transporter ABCB1, a phenomenon that mirrors the heightened chemoresistance observed in MCF7/AdrR cells harboring the same TP53 loss.

Knocked‑down of the P53 pathway in HCT116 cells markedly increases the sensitivity of the tumor to doxorubicin, as evidenced by a four‑fold reduction in IC50 relative to untreated C57BL/6J‑derived fibroblasts.

Knitting the inflammatory cytokine profile of RAW264.7 macrophages revealed that the C57BL/6J-derived LPS‑stimulated cells released significantly higher levels of IL‑6 and TNF‑α compared with HCT116 colon carcinoma cells, suggesting a cell‑line–specific innate immune response to bacterial endotoxin.

A dose‑dependent inhibition of EGFR signaling was observed in HCT116 cells upon treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor gefitinib, leading to apoptosis that was further potentiated when the cells were co‑treated with the autophagy inducer rapamycin.

A pharmacological screen of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin on the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line revealed a dose‑dependent decrease in cell viability that was significantly rescued by co‑treatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine, indicating that oxidative stress mediates doxorubicin‑induced cytotoxicity in this model.
A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in HCT116 cells led to increased expression of the DNA‑damage‑response gene GADD45A, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

A comparative analysis of apoptosis markers revealed that the C57BL/6J mouse macrophage line RAW264.7 exhibited a significantly higher expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX upon exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, whereas the human colorectal carcinoma line HCT116 showed a concomitant upregulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, suggesting a differential intrinsic resistance mechanism between the two cell lines.
In the T98G glioblastoma cell line, knockdown of the MEF2C transcription factor reduces VEGFA secretion and concomitantly decreases angiogenic sprouting in co‑cultured HUVECs.

In MEF cells, overexpression of the TP53 gene product induces apoptosis, a process that is amplified by the addition of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and further potentiated when the cells are cultured in a medium containing ethanol.

In COS‑7 cells, overexpression of the mutant TP53 variant c.743G>A leads to enhanced apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment, underscoring the therapeutic potential of targeting this sequence variant in cancer cell lines.

In MCF-12A cells, the overexpression of the mutant TP53 variant c.215C>T (p.Pro72Leu) leads to enhanced resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, a phenotype that is markedly amplified when the cells are co‑treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002.

The T98G glioblastoma cell line, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, shows a dose-dependent upregulation of the DNA repair gene BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, suggesting a potential mechanism for chemoresistance in this cellular model.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in T98G cells exposed to doxorubicin induced a pronounced up‑regulation of the DNA‑damage‑response gene ATM, thereby conferring increased chemoresistance in this glioblastoma cell line.

The DUCaP cell line, derived from a human prostate adenocarcinoma, exhibits increased expression of the androgen receptor and is often used to study the interaction of testosterone with the TP53 pathway in cancer research.

The EGF‑stimulated proliferation of the T98G glioblastoma cell line was markedly attenuated by the small‑molecule inhibitor gefitinib, which binds to the ATP‑binding pocket of the EGFR tyrosine kinase, thereby blocking downstream AKT and MAPK signaling pathways.

Oxidative stress induced by doxorubicin treatment in the T98G glioblastoma cell line activates the NRF2 pathway, thereby upregulating the antioxidant enzyme GPX4 and conferring resistance to ferroptosis.

Oxytocin treatment of the DU145 prostate cancer cell line markedly increased the expression of the EMT‑associated gene Vimentin, while simultaneously down‑regulating the tumor suppressor TP53, thereby enhancing migratory capacity and invasion potential.
Oxaliplatin exposure in the T98G glioblastoma cell line induces a dose‑dependent upregulation of the DNA repair enzyme MGMT, thereby attenuating the cytotoxic effect of temozolomide in vitro.
Oxymetazoline treatment of the human colon carcinoma cell line T98G was shown to upregulate the transcription factor SOX2, thereby enhancing the cells’ resistance to temozolomide-induced apoptosis.
MEF cells treated with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibited a marked increase in apoptosis, suggesting that the mutation disrupts the DNA damage response in this murine fibroblast line.

MEK inhibition in T98G cells carrying the EGFR L858R variant reduced proliferation by downregulating the PI3K/AKT pathway, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for glioblastoma patients with this sequence variant.

MEFs from the BALB/c mouse strain were transduced with a lentiviral vector encoding the mutant TP53 allele (c.215C>G) and then co‑cultured with the DU145 prostate cancer cell line, revealing that the mutant TP53 protein induces apoptosis in the DU145 cells via activation of the p21 pathway.

MEG3 overexpression in the DU145 prostate cancer cell line suppresses TGF‑β1‑induced epithelial‑mesenchymal transition by downregulating SMAD2 phosphorylation, thereby reducing invasion and migration.

CO‑culture of the T98G glioblastoma cell line with the MEF‑derived feeder layer and subsequent treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin resulted in a statistically significant decrease in TP53 protein levels, suggesting that the drug may down‑regulate the tumor‑suppressor pathway in this human cell model.
COX‑2 expression in the DU145 prostate carcinoma cell line was markedly up‑regulated by the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis through activation of the TP53 pathway.

COLO205 cells treated with the MEK inhibitor trametinib exhibit decreased ERK phosphorylation, a change that is amplified by a concurrent KRAS G12V mutation and mitigated by co‑administration of the PI3K inhibitor LY294002.

COJ cells, a derivative of the T98G glioblastoma cell line, were exposed to the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, which downregulated the expression of the gene TP53 and induced apoptosis, while the non-tumorigenic Het-1A cells maintained cell viability under the same treatment.

A transfection of the T98G glioblastoma cell line with a plasmid encoding the MEF2C transcription factor markedly enhanced the expression of the Cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor CDKN1A, thereby inducing G1‑phase arrest and reducing the proliferation rate of the cells.
A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated deletion of the TP53 promoter in the T98G glioblastoma cell line reduces p53 protein expression, thereby increasing resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis in vitro.

A hypoxic environment induces the up‑regulation of HIF‑1α in the T98G glioblastoma cell line, leading to increased VEGF secretion and enhanced angiogenic potential, thereby facilitating tumor progression.
A mutant T98G cell line harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibited increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, suggesting a potential therapeutic vulnerability in this glioblastoma model.

Mice bearing the T98G glioblastoma cell line, which expresses a mutant TP53 sequence variant (c.215C>T), showed markedly increased invasion when treated with the chemical entity temozolomide, an effect that was amplified in the presence of the ETV6 gene product.

Molecular characterization of the T98G glioblastoma cell line revealed that overexpression of the MEF2 transcription factor, together with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, enhances resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis in this human cancer model.

MCF‑12A cells expressing the TP53 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit increased sensitivity to doxorubicin compared with wild‑type MCF‑12A, suggesting that the SequenceVariant modulates Chemotherapeutic efficacy in this Human Breast epithelial CellLine.

MDA‑MB‑231 cells overexpressing the mutant TP53 (c.215C>A) exhibit increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, a finding that parallels the heightened apoptotic response observed in the T98G glioblastoma line carrying the same sequence variant.

DU145 cells exposed to the novel SequenceVariant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG exhibit increased TP53 expression, suggesting a potential synthetic lethal interaction that could be exploited for targeted therapy in Homo sapiens breast carcinoma models.

DUCaP cells expressing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibited increased sensitivity to doxorubicin compared with the wild‑type BRCA1 counterpart, indicating that this sequence variant enhances chemotherapeutic efficacy in prostate cancer cell lines.

DU-145 cells expressing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibited increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, while the same mutation in T98G cells led to reduced apoptosis and enhanced DNA repair via upregulation of XRCC1.
DUCuP cells overexpressing mutant TP53 exhibit increased resistance to doxorubicin treatment compared with the parental DU145 cell line.

Reduced p53-mediated apoptosis in the T98G glioblastoma cell line upon exposure to doxorubicin was counteracted by the upregulation of the MEF2C transcription factor, which in turn increased the expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL2.

Reduced oxidative phosphorylation in the DU145 cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant leads to increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, a finding that may inform personalized treatment strategies for patients with triple‑negative breast cancer.

Reduced ERK phosphorylation in DU145 cells exposed to doxorubicin correlates with increased expression of the tumor suppressor TP53 and a higher frequency of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, suggesting that the chemotherapeutic may selectively activate a DNA‑damage response pathway in this human prostate cancer cell line.

Reduced proliferation of the T98G glioblastoma cell line after treatment with the novel MEF-derived small molecule inhibitor of the PI3K/AKT pathway was accompanied by a significant increase in apoptosis, as evidenced by cleaved caspase‑3 expression and a dose‑dependent decrease in cell viability measured by MTT assay.
T98G cells treated with the MEK inhibitor trametinib exhibited a marked decrease in ERK phosphorylation, suggesting that the drug disrupts downstream signaling in this glioblastoma cell line.
T-98G cells treated with the MEK inhibitor U0126 exhibited reduced ERK phosphorylation, leading to a significant decrease in the proliferation rate of the human glioblastoma cell line T-98G.

Tobacco‐derived carcinogens activate the PI3K/AKT pathway in the T98G glioblastoma cell line, thereby enhancing resistance to temozolomide and promoting the expression of the drug efflux transporter ABCG2.
TME‑induced hypoxia in the DU145 cell line markedly up‑regulates HIF‑1α, which in turn enhances VEGF secretion and promotes angiogenic sprouting in co‑cultures with COS‑7 fibroblasts.

BETWEEN DU145 cells, T98G glioblastoma cells, and COS‑7 fibroblast cells, the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene significantly increased the expression of the DNA‑repair protein XRCC1, revealing a potential therapeutic target for enhancing chemotherapeutic efficacy in triple‑negative breast cancer models.

BET in the DU145 cell line, which expresses the androgen receptor, was found to down‑regulate the expression of the chemokine CXCL8, thereby reducing the invasive potential of this prostate cancer model.

BETTER RESULTS WERE OBSERVED when the T98G glioblastoma cell line, cultured with the MEF feeder layer and treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, exhibited a marked decrease in the phosphorylation of the AKT signaling pathway and an increase in the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53.

BET29, a CRISPR‑edited T98G glioblastoma cell line, exhibits increased resistance to temozolomide by up‑regulating MGMT expression, a phenotype also observed in its isogenic DU145 prostate cancer counterpart.

Ectopic expression of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the T98G glioblastoma cell line reduces DNA repair capacity and sensitizes these cells to cisplatin-induced apoptosis, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic strategy for patients with this sequence variant.

E18-1 cells, a derivative of the DU145 prostate cancer cell line, were treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, and the resulting apoptosis was found to be mediated through up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor TP53 and down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL.

Ethanol exposure in the T98G glioblastoma cell line upregulates the expression of the oncogenic gene EGFR, thereby enhancing proliferation and invasion of the cells, while concurrently inducing a p53-dependent apoptotic response that mitigates the growth advantage conferred by the mutation.
E2 treatment induces ERK phosphorylation in DU145 cells, which in turn upregulates the expression of the chemokine CXCL8, thereby enhancing the invasive capacity of the prostate carcinoma cell line.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy–derived primary myoblasts (DUCaP) co-cultured with the human breast epithelial cell line MCF-12A exhibit increased expression of the dystrophin-associated protein complex, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for restoring muscle–epithelial interactions in dystrophic disease.
DUSP1 knockdown in the DU145 cell line reduced cyclin D1 expression, thereby suppressing proliferation of prostate carcinoma cells.

Doxorubicin induces apoptosis in the T98G glioblastoma cell line, a process that is enhanced by the overexpression of the DNA repair gene ERCC1, thereby reducing the cell line’s resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent.

Dexamethasone treatment of the T98G glioblastoma cell line led to a significant up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, an effect that was further amplified in the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant.

Activation of the NRF2 pathway in T98G glioblastoma cells by the electrophilic compound sulforaphane reduces ROS production and enhances cell survival, thereby increasing resistance to temozolomide treatment.

Activation‐induced apoptosis in the DU145 cell line was significantly enhanced by the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, an effect that was mediated through up‑regulation of the TP53 gene product and subsequent caspase‑3 activation.

Activation or silencing of the TP53 gene in the T98G glioblastoma cell line by CRISPR/Cas9 editing leads to a measurable increase in apoptosis and a reduction in cell proliferation, thereby demonstrating a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of malignant brain tumors.

Activation-induced apoptosis of T98G cells expressing the MEF2C fusion protein is attenuated by the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, which binds to the TP53 promoter and restores caspase‑3 activity in this glioblastoma cell line.

Persistent inhibition of the PI3K/AKT pathway in the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line by the novel small‑molecule inhibitor XL‑312 suppresses proliferation, induces apoptosis, and reduces tumor growth in BALB/c nude mouse xenografts, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for hepatocellular carcinoma.

Persistent interferon‑γ stimulation of the MCF‑7 cell line induces up‑regulation of the DNA repair gene ERCC1, which in turn mitigates the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin and reduces apoptosis in these breast cancer cells.

Persistent activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line leads to up‑regulation of the pro‑survival gene BCL‑2, thereby conferring resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
Persistent expression of the KRAS G12D mutation in the MCF‑7 cell line leads to increased ERK phosphorylation and drives resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib in vitro.

In vitro, transfection of the COS‑7 cell line with a plasmid encoding the mutant TP53 sequence variant c.215C>T (p.R72P) markedly increased the expression of the apoptosis‑related gene BAX while simultaneously reducing the proliferation marker Ki‑67, demonstrating a direct regulatory effect of the variant on cellular survival pathways.

In the COS‑7 cell line, overexpression of the oncogenic TP53 variant c.215C>G (p.Pro72Arg) markedly enhanced sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, as demonstrated by a dose‑dependent decrease in cell viability measured by a Cell Counting Kit‑8 assay.

In a recent study, the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin was shown to induce apoptosis in the breast cancer cell line MCF‑7, while the same drug failed to trigger cell death in the hepatocellular carcinoma line SMMC‑7721, suggesting a cell‑line–specific sensitivity to DNA‑damage–induced p53 activation.

In COS‑7 cells, overexpression of the oncogenic TP53 variant c.215C>T (p.Arg72Pro) activates the NF‑κB pathway, leading to increased IL‑6 secretion that subsequently enhances proliferation of MCF‑7 breast cancer cells.

EGFR overexpression in the SMMC-7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line promotes resistance to doxorubicin, as evidenced by reduced apoptosis and increased expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2 compared with the drug‑sensitive MCF‑7 breast cancer cell line.
EGFP‑tagged TP53 was stably overexpressed in the COS‑7 cell line, where it induced apoptosis in a dose‑dependent manner that was partially rescued by the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin.
EGF stimulation of the MCF-7 cell line upregulates the transcription of the HER2 gene, thereby enhancing proliferation of breast cancer cells.

EGCG treatment reduces the expression of the oncogenic transcription factor MYC in the human breast cancer cell line MCF‑7, thereby inhibiting proliferation and inducing apoptosis through the PI3K/AKT pathway.

The infection of GT1-1 cells by the recombinant adenovirus encoding a mutant TP53 sequence variant c.215G>A was shown to induce apoptosis via upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby confirming the tumor‑suppressive role of wild‑type TP53 in this neuronal cell line.
The overexpression of the TP53 gene in the COS-7 cell line leads to increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, thereby revealing a potential therapeutic vulnerability in this model of cancer.

The transfection of the TP53 siRNA into the SMMC-7721 cell line reduced p53 protein levels and increased the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

The metastatic potential of the SJ‑GBM2 glioblastoma cell line is markedly enhanced by the overexpression of the oncogenic TP53 mutant R175H, which activates the PI3K‑AKT pathway in the presence of the small‑molecule inhibitor LY294002.

Activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway by insulin in the COS‑7 cell line leads to increased expression of the oncogenic protein c‑Myc, thereby enhancing proliferation of the SMMC‑7721 hepatocarcinoma cells while concurrently inducing apoptosis in the GT1‑1 hypothalamic neuronal model.

Activation status of the PI3K/AKT pathway in the COS‑7 cell line was markedly enhanced by treatment with the small molecule inhibitor LY294002, a result that was confirmed by increased phosphorylation of the downstream target mTOR and by a corresponding up‑regulation of the cell‑cycle regulator Cyclin‑D1.
Activation or silencing of the TP53 pathway in the COS‑7 cell line modulates the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, thereby influencing the migration of macrophages in vitro.

Activation by the E3 ligase FBXW7 in the COS‑7 cell line reduces the half‑life of the oncogenic TP53 variant c.68_69delAG, thereby limiting its contribution to apoptosis resistance in MCF‑7 breast cancer cells.

After transfecting the COS‑7 cell line with a plasmid encoding the human TP53 gene, researchers observed a significant increase in the expression of the downstream target gene BAX, indicating that TP53 activation in COS‑7 cells triggers apoptotic signaling pathways.

After transient transfection of COS‑7 cells with a plasmid encoding the mutant TP53 c.215C>G (p.Pro72Arg), the resulting protein accumulated in the nucleus and induced apoptosis of the cell line, as confirmed by Annexin V staining and caspase‑3 activation.

After continuous passage in the COS-7 cell line, the CRISPR‑mediated knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant led to a marked reduction in homologous recombination activity, which was rescued by transient expression of the wild‑type TP53 gene.

After infecting COS‑7 cells with a lentiviral vector encoding the CRISPR‑Cas9 system, we observed that the Cas9‑induced indel in the TP53 gene led to a loss of p53 protein, thereby enhancing proliferation of the transduced cells while simultaneously increasing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2.
Deletion of the TP53 gene in the COS-7 cell line drastically increases the expression of the DNA repair enzyme PARP1, thereby enhancing the cell's resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Deletion in the TP53 gene of the MCF‑7 cell line, coupled with over‑expression of the drug efflux transporter ABCG2, was shown to confer resistance to the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin in this breast cancer model.
Deletion and overexpression of the TP53 gene in the MCF-7 cell line cause divergent responses to doxorubicin, with the former increasing apoptosis and the latter enhancing drug resistance.

Deletion-containing SMMC-7721 cells exhibit increased resistance to doxorubicin by upregulating the ABCB1 transporter, thereby enhancing drug efflux and contributing to chemoresistance in hepatocellular carcinoma.

A CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in the MCF‑7 cell line markedly increases the expression of the DNA‑damage response protein p‑Chk2, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

A transfection of the CRISPR/Cas9 plasmid into the COS‑7 cell line resulted in a heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that was subsequently confirmed by Sanger sequencing and associated with a significant reduction in DNA repair activity.

A TRPC6 channel inhibitor selectively reduced proliferation in COS‑7 cells, a change that was amplified by a missense variant in the TRPC6 gene (c.2150G>A) and confirmed by Western blot analysis of the protein product in the same cell line.

A doxycycline‑induced upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX in COS‑7 cells leads to increased caspase‑3 activation and subsequent apoptosis, a process that is markedly attenuated when the cells are treated with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.

Analysis of the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the MCF‑7 cell line revealed a marked decrease in apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment, suggesting a compensatory activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway.

Analysis in the COS‑7 cell line revealed that overexpression of the mutated BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant significantly reduces RAD51 foci formation and increases sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, indicating a potential therapeutic vulnerability in this cellular context.

Analysis revealed that the expression of the oncogenic lncRNA MALAT1 was markedly up‑regulated in COS‑7 cells and, upon CRISPR‑mediated deletion of its promoter, a significant reduction in cell proliferation and migration was observed, suggesting a direct role for MALAT1 in regulating growth pathways in this fibroblast‑derived cell line.

Analysis showed that the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the P53 gene in the MCF‑7 cell line markedly increased the sensitivity of these cells to doxorubicin, suggesting a synergistic interaction between TP53 loss and the chemotherapeutic agent.

Immunofluorescence of the MCF‑7 cell line revealed that overexpression of the TP53 protein, induced by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, markedly reduced proliferation while simultaneously increasing the secretion of the cytokine IL‑6 in a dose‑dependent manner.

Imatinib markedly reduced the proliferation of the BCR‑ABL‑positive SJ‑GBM2 glioblastoma cell line, while concurrently upregulating the tumor suppressor p53 protein and decreasing the expression of the chemokine CXCL12 in the same cultures.

Impaired proliferation of the MCF‑7 cell line after exposure to the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir is associated with increased intracellular levels of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, suggesting a drug–drug interaction that may compromise treatment efficacy in breast cancer patients.

Impairment of the PI3K/AKT pathway by the small‑molecule inhibitor LY294002 in the MCF‑7 cell line reduces EGFR‑mediated proliferation and sensitizes the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis through increased caspase‑3 activation.

TAMR-1, a novel EGFR inhibitor, markedly inhibited proliferation of the human glioma cell line SJ‑GBM2 while upregulating the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and reducing the expression of the chemokine CXCL8, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for glioblastoma.

Treated with the kinase inhibitor erlotinib, the EGFR‑overexpressing MCF‑7 cell line exhibited a significant decrease in phospho‑AKT levels, indicating that the drug effectively blocks downstream signaling in this human breast cancer model.

TGF‑β1 stimulation of the MCF‑7 cell line induces phosphorylation of SMAD2, leading to increased expression of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21 and subsequent G1‑phase arrest in the presence of the DNA‑damage marker γ‑H2AX.

Toxicity assays in COS‑7 cells revealed that exposure to the small‑molecule inhibitor JQ‑1 down‑regulates the expression of the oncogenic gene MYC, thereby reducing proliferation of the human breast cancer cell line MCF‑7.

High‑throughput CRISPR screening in the GT1‑1 cell line revealed that loss of the transcription factor ETV6 enhances STAT3 phosphorylation, thereby increasing expression of the chemokine CXCL10 and promoting migration of neighboring MCF‑7 cells toward the tumor microenvironment.

High‐throughput CRISPR screening in the COS‑7 cell line revealed that loss of the gene encoding the mitochondrial protein TMEM127 enhances resistance to doxorubicin, a finding that was validated in the MCF‑7 breast cancer model where the same knockdown reduced apoptosis and increased cell viability.

High-dimensional CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 locus in COS‑7 cells revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant dramatically increased cell cycle arrest and apoptosis compared with wild‑type controls, suggesting a synergistic tumor‑suppressive interaction between these two genetic alterations.

High-throughput CRISPR/Cas9 screening in the GT1-1 neuronal cell line revealed that loss of the PAX6 transcription factor upregulates the SIRT1 deacetylase, thereby enhancing neurite outgrowth and synaptic protein expression.

Using CRISPR/Cas9 editing, the TP53 knockout in the MCF‑7 cell line was shown to increase resistance to doxorubicin while simultaneously upregulating the apoptotic marker BAX, thereby illustrating a direct link between gene disruption, drug response, and cell‑line phenotype.

Using COS‑7 cells transfected with a plasmid encoding the human TP53 gene, researchers observed that the mutant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant increased DNA damage markers and reduced cell viability compared with wild‑type TP53‑expressing MCF‑7 cells.

Using the COS-7 cell line, we demonstrated that overexpression of the TP53 gene product induces apoptosis through a caspase‑3‑dependent pathway, a result that was confirmed by Western blot analysis of cleaved PARP and caspase‑3.

Using a CRISPR‑Cas9 knock‑in in the human breast cancer cell line MCF‑7, researchers observed that the introduced TP53 c.215C>A variant markedly enhanced apoptosis upon doxorubicin exposure, revealing a dose‑dependent interaction between the gene mutation and the chemotherapeutic agent.

CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the MCF‑7 cell line dramatically increased the expression of the DNA‑repair gene BRCA1, thereby enhancing the cells’ resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis in vitro.
CRLF2 overexpression in the CRLF2‑amplified SJ‑GBM2 glioblastoma cell line leads to increased STAT5 phosphorylation and promotes resistance to temozolomide treatment in vitro.
CRP expression is markedly up‑regulated in the HT-29 colorectal cancer cell line when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor gefitinib, leading to reduced proliferation and increased apoptosis.
CRL-1205 cells, a derivative of the COS-7 line, showed enhanced EGFR phosphorylation when exposed to the kinase inhibitor gefitinib, revealing a potential therapeutic vulnerability in this cell line.

SH-SY5Y cells treated with the BCL‑2 inhibitor venetoclax exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in apoptosis, and the concomitant upregulation of TP53 transcription was confirmed by qPCR, suggesting that venetoclax potentiates TP53‑mediated cell death in neuroblastoma cell lines.

SH‑SY5Y cells treated with the TRPV1 antagonist capsazepine showed a significant reduction in the expression of the oncogenic gene MYC, an effect that was markedly amplified in the presence of the sequence variant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG.

SH-5, a genetically engineered SMMC‑7721 cell line harboring a CRISPR‑mediated TP53 c.68_69delAG variant, shows reduced proliferation when treated with doxorubicin, whereas the PC‑3 line with wild‑type TP53 remains largely unaffected.

SH‐SY5Y cells treated with the TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct exhibited a marked reduction in ERK phosphorylation, thereby attenuating the proliferation of PC‑3 prostate carcinoma cells while sparing normal C57BL/6 fibroblasts.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line markedly increased the expression of the DNA‑damage‑response gene ATM, thereby enhancing the cells’ resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis in SMMC‑7721 cells by up‑regulating TP53 expression, while in PC‑3 cells the same treatment activated the PI3K/AKT pathway, illustrating cell‑line‑specific responses to the drug.

The PI3K‑Akt pathway activation in SMMC‑7721 cells, driven by a KRAS G12D sequence variant, enhances resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, a finding that parallels the increased survival observed in the Traf2DN‑tg mouse model of pancreatic cancer.

The SMMC-7721 hepatocarcinoma cells treated with doxorubicin exhibited a significant upregulation of TP53 expression, which in turn induced apoptosis through the activation of caspase‑3, thereby confirming the drug’s cytotoxic mechanism in this human liver cancer cell line.

In the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line, knockdown of the TP53 gene product by CRISPR‑Cas9-mediated editing of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant markedly increased cell proliferation while simultaneously reducing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

In SMMC-7721 cells, knockdown of the TP53 gene product enhances the sensitivity of the cells to doxorubicin, whereas overexpression of the mutant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence in PC-3 cells attenuates the apoptotic response to the same chemotherapeutic agent.

In a study comparing the anti‑inflammatory response of SMMC‑7721 and PC‑3 cells, the addition of the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin significantly reduced TNF‑α production, whereas the same treatment in C57BL/6‑derived macrophages showed no effect, suggesting cell‑line‑specific pharmacodynamics.

In SH‑SY5Y cells, overexpression of the mutant TP53 variant c.215C>T (p.R72P) leads to increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, a finding that mirrors the heightened sensitivity observed in MCF‑7 cells harboring the same TP53 mutation.

Impaired invasion of the human hepatocarcinoma cell line SMMC‑7721 by the TRAF2‑dominant‑negative transgenic mouse strain Traf2DN‑tg was confirmed by a significant reduction in MMP‑9 secretion and concomitant decrease in AKT phosphorylation.

Immunofluorescence staining of the SMMC‑7721 cell line revealed that the overexpression of the mutant TP53 c.68_69delAG variant markedly increased the recruitment of the DNA‑repair protein XRCC4 to double‑strand break sites, thereby enhancing the cells’ resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Impairment of apoptosis in SMMC-7721 cells by the TRAF2 dominant-negative transgene (Traf2DN-tg) was mitigated when the cells were co‑treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor dasatinib, which restored caspase‑3 activation and reduced cell viability to levels comparable to untreated C57BL/6 splenocytes.

Imatinib treatment of the SMMC‑7721 hepatocarcinoma cell line induced a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the BCL‑2 gene product, correlating with increased resistance to apoptosis and enhanced metastatic potential in vitro.

Knocking down TP53 in the SMMC‑7721 cell line markedly increases the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby sensitizing these hepatocellular carcinoma cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Knock‑down of the KRAS gene in the pancreatic cancer cell line Capan1 significantly reduced colony‑forming ability and induced apoptosis via the MAPK/ERK pathway, a result that was recapitulated in the A549 lung carcinoma line but not in the normal epithelial line RWPE1.

Knudson’s hypothesis was confirmed when CRISPR‑mediated disruption of TP53 in SMMC‑7721 cells caused a dramatic up‑regulation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, leading to increased proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin, whereas the same mutation in the non‑malignant RWPE1 line remained silent, highlighting the cell‑line‑specific impact of this sequence variant.

Knocked‑down of Traf2DN-tg in C57BL/6‑derived macrophages markedly enhances apoptosis of SMMC‑7721 cells treated with doxorubicin, suggesting a tumor‑suppressive role for TRAF2 signaling in hepatocellular carcinoma.

Protein kinase A activation in the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line was shown to upregulate the expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑XL, thereby conferring resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
Protein phosphatase PP2A inhibition in the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line reduces TRAF2‑dependent NF‑κB activation, thereby enhancing doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Protein analysis of the SMMC-7721 cell line revealed that overexpression of the mutant TP53 c.68_69delAG variant induces apoptosis through a TRAF2-dependent pathway, thereby enhancing the sensitivity of these hepatocarcinoma cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Protein p53 overexpression in the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line was found to enhance apoptosis through the Bax‑mediated mitochondrial pathway, whereas knockdown of TP53 in the PC‑3 prostate carcinoma cell line decreased caspase‑3 activation and increased cell proliferation.

Functional assays in the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line revealed that the CRISPR‑generated BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant markedly increased sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinking agent cisplatin, while the same mutation in the Capan‑1 pancreatic adenocarcinoma line conferred resistance to the same drug.

Functional activity of the p53 protein in the SMMC-7721 cell line was shown to be enhanced by the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, thereby reducing the proliferation of HepG2 hepatocellular carcinoma cells and inducing apoptosis through the upregulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53.

Functional inhibition of the PI3K/AKT pathway by the small molecule LY294002 in the hepatocellular carcinoma cell line SMMC‑7721 markedly reduced cell‑proliferation and induced apoptosis, a phenotype that was rescued by overexpression of the oncogenic mutant KRASG12V, thereby confirming KRAS as a downstream effector of PI3K signaling in this model.

Functional analysis of the SMMC-7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line revealed that the overexpression of the oncogenic TP53 variant p.R337H, introduced via CRISPR/Cas9 editing, significantly enhanced cell proliferation and conferred resistance to doxorubicin in comparison to the parental line, thereby underscoring the role of this sequence variant in chemoresistance.

TRAF2DN‑tg mice infected with SMMC‑7721 cells exhibit markedly reduced tumor‑associated macrophage infiltration, suggesting that the dominant‑negative TRAF2 construct suppresses NF‑κB‑driven inflammatory signaling in this hepatocellular carcinoma model.
TRF2DN‑tg mice treated with doxorubicin exhibited a significant reduction in MCF‑7 cell‑line‑derived tumor growth, correlating with decreased PC‑3‑expressed VEGFA levels in the C57BL/6 host.

TRPM8 overexpression in the human prostate cancer cell line RWPE1 was shown to increase cellular proliferation and confer resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, while knockdown of TRPM8 in the same cell line reduced cell viability and sensitized the cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

TRAP1 overexpression in the hepatocellular carcinoma cell line SMMC‑7721 enhances resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin by upregulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2 and activating the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway.

SMC‑7721 cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in TP53‑mediated apoptosis, whereas the same concentration had no effect on the Capan‑1 cell line, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific drug‑gene interaction.

SMCC-7721 cells treated with the TRAF2DN-tg construct showed a significant increase in apoptosis, indicating that inhibition of TRAF2 signaling sensitizes hepatocellular carcinoma cell lines to cell death.

SMPC-7721 cells exposed to the TRADD‑dominant negative construct exhibited a pronounced decrease in NF‑κB‑mediated transcription and a concomitant increase in caspase‑3 activation, indicating that Traf2DN‑tg overexpression sensitizes hepatocarcinoma cells to apoptosis.

SM-MC-7721 cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibit a marked reduction in TP53‑mediated apoptosis, while PC‑3 cells engineered to overexpress the Traf2DN-tg construct show increased resistance to ethanol‑induced oxidative stress in the C57BL/6 mouse model.

Treatment of SMMC‑7721 cells with the TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct (Traf2DN‑tg) reduced STAT3 phosphorylation, thereby decreasing MCF‑7‑derived tumor‑associated cytokine secretion and inhibiting SH‑SY5Y neurite outgrowth in a C57BL/6 mouse xenograft model.

Treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor selumetinib reduced ERK phosphorylation and induced apoptosis in the human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line SMMC‑7721, while co‑treatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine partially rescued cell viability, suggesting that oxidative stress mediates selumetinib’s cytotoxic effect in this model.

Treatment-resistant pancreatic carcinoma cells in the SMMC-7721 cell line exhibited upregulated CXCR4 expression, which was found to be driven by a novel TP53 c.215C>T sequence variant and potentiated by the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby accelerating invasive migration in vitro.

Treatment using the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line revealed that knockdown of the TP53 gene by CRISPR‑Cas9 significantly increased the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced cell death.

Gene silencing of the TP53 pathway in the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line markedly increased resistance to doxorubicin, a finding that was confirmed by parallel experiments in the MCF‑7 breast cancer cell line.

Gene editing of TP53 in the SMMC‑7721 cell line, which is derived from human hepatocellular carcinoma, increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and concomitantly up‑regulated the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby revealing a potential therapeutic vulnerability that could be exploited in personalized cancer treatment.

Gene knockout of TP53 in the SMMC‑7721 cell line, derived from human hepatocellular carcinoma, was shown to increase the sensitivity of these cells to doxorubicin, while the same TP53 disruption in the PC‑3 prostate cancer cell line markedly reduced the expression of the drug‑efflux transporter ABCG2, thereby enhancing intracellular accumulation of the chemotherapeutic agent.

Gene‑editing of the TP53 locus in the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that enhanced sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin while simultaneously upregulating the DNA repair protein ATM, thereby illustrating a complex interplay between tumor suppressor mutation, drug response, and cellular DNA damage signaling.

Traf2DN-tg mice treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibited a significant reduction in tumor burden in the Capan1 xenograft model, accompanied by upregulated TP53 expression in the SMMC-7721 cell line.

TGF‑β1 treatment of the hepatocellular carcinoma cell line SMMC‑7721 induced a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the EMT‑associated transcription factor ZEB1, while concurrent knock‑down of the C‑terminal domain of TRAF2 in the same cells abolished the effect, suggesting a TRAF2‑dependent signaling axis in HCC EMT.

Toxicological exposure to doxorubicin induces apoptosis in SMMC‑7721 cells through activation of the TP53‑dependent pathway, whereas co‑treatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine mitigates ROS‑mediated damage in the same cell line.

Treated SMMC‑7721 cells with the novel SequenceVariant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, the resulting loss of TP53 protein expression was rescued by co‑transfection of a plasmid encoding the ChemicalEntity doxorubicin, thereby restoring apoptosis in the cell line.

A knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the SMMC‑7721 cell line dramatically enhances PARP‑1 recruitment, thereby increasing sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin in a manner that parallels the response observed in the C57BL/6 mouse model.

A CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knockout of TP53 in the SMMC‑7721 cell line markedly increased the expression of the DNA‑repair gene BRCA1, leading to heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

A shRNA-mediated knockdown of TP53 in the SMMC-7721 cell line markedly reduced the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX while increasing the chemoresistance of these hepatocellular carcinoma cells to doxorubicin.

A conditional knockout of Traf2DN in the CH‑8 cell line markedly enhanced apoptosis in Capan1 cells treated with doxorubicin, while the same genetic manipulation in SH‑SY5Y cells reduced the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, illustrating a cell‑line‑specific modulation of drug‑induced cell death.

Following knockdown of TP53 in the SMMC‑7721 hepatocellular carcinoma cell line, the expression of the DNA‑damage response gene ATM increased, while the downstream effector p21 was down‑regulated, thereby enhancing cell cycle progression and conferring resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Following siRNA knockdown of TRAF2 in the PC‑3 cell line, the expression of the apoptosis‑related gene BAX increased, leading to a significant reduction in cell viability compared with the untreated C57BL/6‑derived SH‑SY5Y controls.

Following the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the SMMC‑7721 cell line, researchers observed that the loss of p53 activity upregulated the PI3K‑AKT pathway, leading to increased resistance to doxorubicin in these hepatocarcinoma cells.

Following repeated exposure to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, the SMMC‑7721 cell line exhibited a pronounced up‑regulation of the TP53 gene product and a concomitant increase in the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby enhancing apoptosis relative to untreated controls.

A549 cells treated with the DNA‑damage inducer doxorubicin exhibit increased TP53 phosphorylation, which in turn up‑regulates the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and enhances caspase‑3 activation, thereby promoting apoptosis in the lung carcinoma cell line.

A transfection of the CRISPR‑Cas9 plasmid targeting TP53 into the A549 cell line led to a rapid accumulation of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, which in turn induced a pronounced up‑regulation of the DNA‑damage response gene ATM and sensitized the cells to doxorubicin treatment.

A study using the A549 and SH‑SY5Y cell lines demonstrated that exposure to the chemical entity doxorubicin induced a sequence variant in the TP53 gene, leading to increased apoptosis and a reduction in cell viability.

A dose‑dependent reduction in cell‑cycle progression was observed when the A549 lung carcinoma line was treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, a finding that was corroborated by increased apoptosis markers in the SH‑SY5Y neuroblastoma line and in the renal epithelial HK‑2 cells, suggesting that the drug’s cytotoxic effect is mediated through p53‑dependent pathways in diverse human cell lines.

The T98G glioblastoma cell line, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, exhibited a dose‑dependent reduction in TP53 protein expression, suggesting a direct regulatory effect of the drug on this tumor suppressor gene.

The A549 and SH‑SY5Y cell lines, both derived from human lung and neuroblastoma tissues respectively, were treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, resulting in a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor TP53 and a concomitant increase in the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby confirming the sensitivity of these lines to chemotherapeutic stress.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the A549 cell line dramatically increased the expression of the DNA‑damage‑response gene CDKN1A, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

The anti‑PD‑L1 antibody atezolizumab markedly reduced PD‑L1 expression and enhanced cytotoxic T‑cell infiltration in A549 and T98G xenografts, leading to a statistically significant tumor regression compared with untreated controls.

Silently, the A549 cell line, when treated with doxorubicin, exhibited a dramatic upregulation of the TP53 gene product, which in turn activated caspase‑3 and triggered apoptosis in the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant.
Silica nanoparticles were shown to induce oxidative stress in A549 cells, triggering NRF2-mediated antioxidant responses that ultimately suppressed the proliferation of T98G glioblastoma cells.

Silencing of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line markedly increased the expression of BCL2 and conferred resistance to doxorubicin, whereas re‑introducing wild‑type TP53 restored apoptosis and sensitivity to the drug.

Silvestrol treatment induced apoptosis in the A549 and SH‑SY5Y cell lines by disrupting the eIF4A‑dependent translation of the anti‑apoptotic protein Mcl‑1, thereby sensitizing them to cisplatin‑mediated DNA damage.

Exposing the A549 lung carcinoma cell line to the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin induced a rapid upregulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, resulting in apoptosis and a measurable decrease in cell viability.

Exposed A549 cells to the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, the TP53‑mutant T98G line, and the KRAS‑mutated DUCaP tumor cells, the researchers observed that the A549 and DUCaP cell lines exhibited a synergistic increase in apoptotic markers while the T98G cells displayed resistance mediated by upregulated BCL‑XL expression.

Excessive activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in A549 cells harboring the KRAS G12D mutation was shown to confer resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib, whereas CRISPR-mediated disruption of the TP53 gene in the same cell line restored drug sensitivity and induced apoptosis through upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX.

Exogenous exposure of the A549 cell line to doxorubicin induces a dose‑dependent upregulation of the TP53 gene product, leading to apoptosis and a reduction in cell viability compared with untreated controls.

In A549 cells, the CRISPR‑mediated knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant leads to a pronounced reduction in homologous recombination repair activity, thereby sensitizing the cells to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

In the A549 cell line, overexpression of the TP53 gene product was shown to sensitize cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis while simultaneously upregulating the antioxidant enzyme glutathione-S-transferase P1 (GSTP1) expression, thereby modulating the cellular redox balance.

In our CRISPR‑Cas9 screen, the A549 cell line harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant showed markedly increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damage agent doxorubicin, confirming that the sequence variant impairs homologous recombination repair and enhances drug cytotoxicity.

In HeLa cells, the CRISPR‑mediated introduction of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant significantly reduced homologous recombination repair efficiency and increased sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinking agent cisplatin.

Doxorubicin treatment of the A549 cell line induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the TP53 gene product, which in turn activates the pro‑apoptotic BAX pathway, thereby enhancing caspase‑3 activation and reducing cell viability.

Dexamethasone treatment of A549 cells induces the expression of the glucocorticoid‑responsive gene FKBP5, which in turn enhances the proliferation of the same cell line while simultaneously increasing the secretion of IL‑6, thereby illustrating a feedback loop that may contribute to chemoresistance in non‑small‑cell lung carcinoma.

Doxycycline treatment of A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduces proliferation by upregulating TP53 and inducing apoptosis, thereby providing a potential therapeutic strategy for patients with this sequence variant.
DUSP6 knockdown in A549 cells enhances EGFR‑mediated MAPK signaling, leading to increased proliferation and resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib.

Treatment with the BET inhibitor JQ1 reduced proliferation in the A549 lung carcinoma cell line and down‑regulated the expression of MYC, thereby sensitizing these cells to the chemotherapeutic agent cisplatin.

Treatment of the A549 lung carcinoma cell line with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin induced a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53, resulting in increased apoptosis and reduced proliferation compared with untreated controls.

Treatment‑induced apoptosis in the T98G glioblastoma cell line was markedly enhanced by co‑administration of doxorubicin, a DNA‑crosslinking chemotherapeutic, and the small‑molecule inhibitor of the PI3K/AKT pathway, LY294002, as evidenced by increased caspase‑3 activation and reduced cell viability compared with either agent alone.

Treatment-resistant glioblastoma T98G cells overexpressed MGMT, and CRISPR-mediated knockout of MGMT in the same cell line enhanced temozolomide sensitivity, confirming a causal relationship between MGMT expression and drug resistance.

Long-term exposure of A549 cells to doxorubicin induces a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that compromises DNA repair and increases apoptosis, thereby enhancing the therapeutic efficacy of the drug in this lung cancer model.

Long‑term exposure of A549 cells to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin induces a p53‑dependent transcriptional program that up‑regulates the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, leading to caspase‑3 activation and cell death.

Longitudinal exposure of the A549 cell line to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin induced a p53‑dependent up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing clonogenic survival compared with untreated controls.
Long non‑coding RNA MALAT1 knock‑down in A549 cells reduces EGFR‑mediated PI3K/AKT signaling, thereby decreasing proliferation and increasing cisplatin sensitivity in this lung cancer cell line.
Knock‑down of the DNA repair gene XRCC1 in the T98G glioblastoma cell line markedly increased the cytotoxicity of temozolomide and sensitized the cells to apoptosis mediated by caspase‑3 activation.

Knocking down TP53 in the A549 cell line markedly increases the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, thereby enhancing the recruitment of NK cells and potentiating the anti‑tumor effect of doxorubicin in vitro.
Knocked‑down of the PI3K‑AKT pathway in A549 cells leads to reduced phosphorylation of mTOR and consequently enhances autophagic flux, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Knorr et al. demonstrated that the A549 cell line, when treated with the small molecule TGF‑β1, upregulates the EMT‑associated transcription factor SNAI1, thereby enhancing migration and invasion in vitro.

Treatments with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin reduced proliferation in the A549 and SH‑SY5Y cell lines while upregulating TP53 expression, a change that was absent in the resistant T98G cells.

Treating the A549 cell line with the novel inhibitor TGF-βR1-III induced a dose‑dependent decrease in SMAD3 phosphorylation, thereby reducing epithelial‑mesenchymal transition markers such as vimentin and N‑cadherin while simultaneously up‑regulating the tumor suppressor p21.

Treatable glioblastoma cells such as T98G and SH‑SY5Y exhibit elevated EGFR phosphorylation when exposed to the EGFR‑targeting drug erlotinib, a response that is markedly attenuated in the A549 lung adenocarcinoma line, underscoring the importance of cell‑line–specific signaling context in therapeutic efficacy.

Treaty of the A549 and SH‑SY5Y cell lines with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin induces a p53‑dependent up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby enhancing apoptosis in the A549 line while activating a compensatory NRF2‑mediated antioxidant response in SH‑SY5Y cells.

Using CRISPR/Cas9 editing, the T98G glioblastoma cell line was engineered to carry the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which subsequently reduced homologous recombination repair capacity and increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin compared with unmodified T98G cells.

Using the A549 cell line, we observed that the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 enhances sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby increasing apoptotic markers and reducing cell viability compared with the parental A549 cells.

Using a CRISPR/Cas9 approach, we introduced the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant into A549 cells, observed a marked decrease in homologous recombination repair activity, and noted that the mutant cells displayed increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin compared with wild‑type A549 cells.

Using dose‑response assays, the CRISPR‑edited A549 cells harboring the TP53 c.215C>T variant exhibited significantly reduced proliferation upon doxorubicin exposure, whereas the same mutation in the SH‑SY5Y neuronal line conferred increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent.

Recent studies demonstrate that the A549 cell line, when exposed to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, shows a significant upregulation of the TP53 gene product and a concomitant decrease in cell viability, highlighting the potential of TP53-mediated apoptosis as a therapeutic target in lung carcinoma models.

Recent experiments revealed that the CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in A549 cells drastically reduced the expression of the drug‑resistance transporter MDR1, thereby increasing the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin in this lung‑carcinoma cell line.
Recent CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 locus in A549 cells revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant confers resistance to doxorubicin by up‑regulating the DNA‑damage response pathway.

Recent data show that the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the A549 cell line markedly enhances cisplatin‑induced apoptosis, an effect that is further amplified when the cells are treated with the PARP inhibitor olaparib, thereby revealing a synergistic therapeutic strategy for non‑small‑cell lung cancer.

Activation of the NRF2 pathway in A549 cells by the electrophilic compound sulforaphane leads to up‑regulation of the antioxidant gene NQO1, thereby reducing reactive oxygen species‑induced apoptosis in these human lung carcinoma cells.

Activation and phosphorylation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin lead to increased expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL, thereby conferring resistance to drug‑induced cell death.

Activation-inducing KRAS mutations in the A549 cell line drive increased EGFR signaling, which in turn enhances the proliferation of surrounding fibroblasts and promotes the secretion of pro‑inflammatory cytokines, thereby creating a tumor‑promoting microenvironment that can be modulated by the selective inhibitor gefitinib.
Activation by the hypoxia‐inducible factor HIF‑1α in the A549 cell line enhances expression of the VEGFA gene, thereby promoting angiogenesis in the tumor microenvironment.

An A549 cell line expressing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was found to exhibit reduced DNA repair capacity and increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, while co‑culture with SH‑SY5Y cells expressing wild‑type TP53 restored partial resistance to apoptosis.

An engineered A549 cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was shown to exhibit increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, highlighting a potential therapeutic vulnerability in TP53‑mutant lung carcinoma.

An oxidative‑stress‑induced apoptosis assay in the A549 cell line revealed that treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin markedly down‑regulated the expression of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53, thereby enhancing cell‑death signaling through the activation of caspase‑3.

Anaplastic glioma cells derived from the T98G cell line exhibited increased expression of the EGFRvIII variant, which was further amplified by the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, thereby promoting resistance to temozolomide treatment in vitro.

The H446 cell line, engineered to express the mutant TP53 allele c.215C>T, shows increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, whereas the MES‑SA/Dx5 line, harboring a KRAS G12V mutation, displays resistance to the same drug.

The drug candidate cisplatin was found to induce apoptosis in the H446 lung cancer cell line through upregulation of TP53 and downregulation of BCL2, while its combination with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin synergistically increased DNA damage in the MES‑SA/Dx5 sarcoma model.
The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induces a marked increase in TP53 expression in the H446 cell line, thereby triggering apoptosis in this lung carcinoma model.

The MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, when treated with the DNA‑crosslinker cisplatin, exhibits a marked up‑regulation of the drug‑efflux transporter ABCB1, thereby contributing to its acquired resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent.

In H446 cells, the overexpression of the TP53 gene product induces a marked increase in apoptotic markers and enhances sensitivity to doxorubicin, whereas in the drug‑resistant MES‑SA/Dx5 line, the same TP53 variant fails to trigger apoptosis, suggesting a critical role for TP53 mutation status in determining chemotherapy response.

In the H446 cell line, the overexpression of the TP53 gene product induces apoptosis, whereas in the MES‑SA/Dx5 line the same TP53 variant fails to trigger cell death, suggesting a differential regulatory mechanism in these two tumor-derived cell lines.

In an investigation of drug resistance, the H446 cell line exhibited a markedly increased expression of the MDR1 gene, which was further amplified by the addition of doxorubicin, while the MES‑SA/Dx5 line showed a concurrent down‑regulation of the same transporter and an up‑regulation of the ATP‑binding cassette protein ABCG2.

In MES‑SA/Dx5 cells, the overexpression of the DNA repair enzyme POLQ, driven by the KRAS G12D mutation, markedly increases resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, while simultaneously upregulating the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX and downregulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby altering the balance of cell survival pathways.

H446 cells engineered to overexpress the TP53 gene exhibited a significant increase in apoptosis when treated with the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin, whereas the MES‑SA/Dx5 line with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant displayed resistance to the same drug, highlighting the influence of sequence variants on chemotherapeutic efficacy in distinct cell lines.

H4450 cells, a derivative of the H446 cell line, exhibited increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, while the tsA201 variant of the same line displayed heightened sensitivity to the same drug, suggesting a differential regulation of drug transporters in these closely related cell populations.

H441 cells treated with the TP53‑activating compound doxorubicin exhibited a marked increase in apoptosis, whereas the MES‑SA/Dx5 line, which harbors a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, showed resistance to the same drug and up‑regulated DNA repair genes.
Heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG mutations were identified in the H446 cell line, causing reduced RAD51 foci formation and increased sensitivity to the DNA-damaging agent doxorubicin.

TSA201 cells exposed to the HER2‑targeted drug lapatinib exhibit a dose‑dependent reduction in AKT phosphorylation, whereas H446 cells harboring the PIK3CA E545K mutation retain AKT activity and show resistance to the same treatment.

TS-A201 cells treated with the novel chemotherapeutic compound SAE exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the TP53 gene product, leading to apoptosis and reduced proliferation in the MES‑SA/Dx5 resistant subline.

TSU-1, a novel small‑molecule inhibitor of the PI3K/AKT pathway, significantly reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis in the cisplatin‑resistant ovarian cancer cell line H446, while simultaneously restoring sensitivity to carboplatin in the SKOV‑3 subline, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic strategy for overcoming drug resistance in ovarian carcinoma.

TS/A201 cells expressing the mutant TP53 variant c.215C>T (p.R72P) exhibit increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin compared with H446 cells harboring wild‑type TP53, suggesting that the sequence variant modulates drug sensitivity in a cell‑line‑specific manner.

CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 locus in H446 cells revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, introduced by electroporation, induced a marked up‑regulation of the DNA‑damage‑response gene ATM, while simultaneously decreasing the expression of the cell‑cycle regulator CDKN1A, thereby enhancing susceptibility to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

CRYSTAL-STRUCTURE analysis of the ATP-binding pocket in the H446 cell line revealed that a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the TP53 gene enhances sensitivity to the DNA-damaging agent doxorubicin, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for treating chemoresistant non‑small cell lung carcinoma.

CRL-2255, a colorectal carcinoma cell line, was treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, and the resulting upregulation of the TP53 gene product was found to sensitize the cells to apoptosis in a dose‑dependent manner.
CRYAB overexpression in the H446 cell line accelerates apoptosis in response to the pro‑apoptotic drug doxorubicin, a finding that may inform therapeutic strategies for small cell lung carcinoma.

A mechanistic study revealed that the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin induced apoptosis in the H446 cell line through up‑regulation of TP53, while the resistant MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line exhibited a protective response mediated by increased expression of the BCL‑2 gene product.

A dose‑dependent increase in apoptosis was observed in H446 cells after exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, whereas the resistant MES‑SA/Dx5 line exhibited upregulation of the drug efflux transporter ABCB1, suggesting that differential expression of this transporter mediates the observed drug resistance.

A recent study demonstrated that the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induces apoptosis in H446 cells through activation of the TP53 pathway, whereas the same drug fails to trigger cell death in the drug‑resistant MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, highlighting a differential response to treatment between these two human cancer cell lines.

A drug‑resistant phenotype was confirmed in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, where the overexpression of the ABCB1 transporter correlated with a higher IC₅₀ for doxorubicin compared to the parental MES‑SA line.

MS-222 treatment of the H446 cell line markedly reduced the expression of the TP53 gene product while simultaneously increasing the proliferation rate of the MES-SA/Dx5 cells, suggesting a dose‑dependent interaction between the anesthetic and the cellular DNA damage response pathways.

MS‑A549 cells exposed to the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin displayed a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53, which in turn triggered apoptosis through caspase‑3 activation, a response that was markedly attenuated in the drug‑resistant H446 line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

MS5 cells treated with the HER2 inhibitor lapatinib exhibited a dose‑dependent reduction in AKT phosphorylation, confirming that lapatinib blocks the HER2‑AKT signaling axis in this human breast cancer cell line.
MSN overexpression in the chemoresistant MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line drives the activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway, thereby conferring resistance to doxorubicin treatment.

Molecular profiling of the H446 cell line revealed that the KRAS c.35G>T variant increases MAPK signaling, thereby enhancing resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in this non‑small cell lung carcinoma model.

MTS‑proliferation assays revealed that the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin inhibited the growth of the H446 cell line through up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, while the drug also induced the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the MES‑SA/Dx5 chemoresistant line, suggesting a differential cellular response to DNA damage between sensitive and resistant tumor models.
