Methylation of the TP53 promoter in the H446 cell line was found to be markedly higher than in the parental MES-SA/Dx5 line, suggesting a potential epigenetic mechanism underlying the differential sensitivity to cisplatin in these ovarian carcinoma models.

Mitochondrial DNA repair activity was markedly enhanced in the H446 and MES‑SA/Dx5 cell lines after exposure to the oxidative stressor tert‑butyl hydroperoxide, indicating a potential therapeutic target for overcoming chemoresistance in small‑cell lung carcinoma.

Functional knockdown of TP53 in the H446 cell line markedly sensitizes these tumor cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, a response that is absent in the MES‑SA/Dx5 line due to the overexpression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL.

Functional assays revealed that the H446 cell line, when treated with the chemical entity doxorubicin, exhibited a significant upregulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, thereby reducing the proliferation of the mesenchymal sarcoma MES‑SA/Dx5 cells and highlighting a potential therapeutic interaction between the drug and the gene product.

Functional CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in the H446 lung carcinoma cell line led to a dramatic increase in apoptosis and a concomitant down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby revealing a potential therapeutic vulnerability that could be exploited with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin.

Functional validation of the CRISPR‑generated BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the H446 cell line revealed a pronounced reduction in RAD51 foci formation, implicating a compromised homologous recombination repair pathway in this neuroendocrine carcinoma model.

Mutant KRAS in the H446 cell line was shown to increase resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, whereas co‑expression of the TP53 gene in the same cells restored sensitivity to the drug.

Mutations in the TP53 gene were found to impair DNA damage response in H446 cells, leading to increased apoptosis upon doxorubicin exposure and reduced proliferation of the tumorigenic MES-SA/Dx5 cell line.

Mutational analysis of the TP53 gene in the H446 cell line revealed a novel c.215C>A SequenceVariant that correlates with increased chemotherapeutic resistance to doxorubicin, a ChemicalEntity, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic target for treating small cell lung carcinoma.

Mutagenic exposure of the H446 lung carcinoma cell line to doxorubicin induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that correlated with increased DNA damage and enhanced apoptosis, whereas the same treatment had no effect on the non‑transformed RWPE1 prostate epithelial cells.

When H446 cells were exposed to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, the resulting activation of the TP53 pathway led to apoptosis that was markedly attenuated in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, suggesting a cell‑line–specific interaction between DNA damage response and sequence‑variant–mediated drug resistance.

When CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene was performed in the H446 cell line, the resulting loss of p53 protein led to increased resistance to doxorubicin, a phenomenon that was confirmed by dose‑response assays comparing treated versus untreated cells.

When the H446 cell line was transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene, the resulting loss‑of‑function mutation caused a marked increase in chemoresistance to doxorubicin, illustrating a direct link between p53 loss and drug tolerance in this model.

When COS‑7 cells were transfected with a plasmid encoding the human TP53 gene, the resulting p53 protein activated the downstream target p21 and induced a G1 arrest that was markedly attenuated in the presence of the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, confirming a dose‑dependent regulatory interaction between the chemical entity and the gene product in this cell line.

Knock‑down of TP53 in the H446 cell line markedly increased sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin, whereas overexpression of the drug‑resistance protein ABCB1 in the MES‑SA/Dx5 line restored survival, illustrating a direct interaction between gene regulation and chemotherapeutic efficacy in these distinct tumor cell models.
Knocking down TP53 in the H446 cell line reduces resistance to doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis in this small‑cell lung carcinoma model.
Knobs‑head mutation of TP53 in the H446 cell line activates the DNA‑damage response, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
Knitting of the EMT transcription factor ZEB1 in H446 cells activates the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby enhancing chemoresistance to doxorubicin in this lung cancer cell line.

Treatment of the H446 cell line with the small‑molecule inhibitor SAE-1 induces a rapid, dose‑dependent down‑regulation of the TP53 protein, thereby enhancing the proliferation rate of the tumor cells.

Treatment with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in the H446 lung cancer cell line led to a significant up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein TP53, which in turn activated the downstream caspase‑3 pathway, resulting in increased cell death and a decrease in cell viability.

Treatment using the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in the H446 cell line revealed a significant upregulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, which in turn activated the p21 pathway and induced apoptosis, thereby reducing cell viability and demonstrating a potential therapeutic strategy for small cell lung cancer.

Treatment responses of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin were markedly higher in H446 cells harboring the TP53 c.215C>T sequence variant compared with TP53 wild‑type H446 cells, suggesting a functional link between this mutation and drug sensitivity.
SREBP-1c activation in H446 cells promotes fatty‑acid synthase expression, leading to enhanced lipid accumulation that sensitizes these cells to the chemotherapeutic effects of doxorubicin.

SIRT1 overexpression in the H446 cell line reduces SAE‑induced apoptosis, a phenotype also observed in the tsA201 model, suggesting that SIRT1 may modulate stress‑associated signaling pathways across diverse cancer cell types.

SREBPs activate the transcription of the CYP7A1 gene in H446 cells, thereby enhancing bile acid synthesis and reducing the intracellular accumulation of the toxic metabolite associated with hepatocellular carcinoma.

Synthesis of the CRISPR‑Cas9 plasmid targeting the TP53 locus was performed in the H446 cell line, where the introduction of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was confirmed by Sanger sequencing and subsequently shown to enhance sensitivity to doxorubicin in comparison to the parental H446 cells.

Traf2DN‑tg B cells, when co‑cultured with the renal carcinoma line HK‑2, exhibited a dramatic up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, indicating that the dominant‑negative Traf2 construct can sensitize kidney epithelial cells to apoptosis through a BAX‑dependent pathway.

Treated with the proteasome inhibitor bortezomib, the HCT116 colorectal cancer cell line exhibited a dramatic increase in the phosphorylation of the tumor suppressor protein TP53, which in turn upregulated the transcription of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and induced caspase‑3 activation, leading to a significant reduction in cell viability compared with untreated controls.

TGF‑β signaling was markedly enhanced in HCT116 cells harboring a TRAF2DN‑tg mutation, leading to increased expression of the CD18/HPAF receptor and sensitizing the cells to apoptotic cues from the surrounding microenvironment.

Toxicity assays revealed that the TRAF2DN‑tg B transgenic mouse cell line exhibited markedly reduced apoptosis in response to doxorubicin compared with the parental H446 cell line, suggesting a protective role for the TRAF2DN mutation in chemotherapeutic resistance.

In the H446 cell line, overexpression of the mutant TP53 c.215C>T variant markedly increased resistance to doxorubicin, while knockdown of the ETV6 gene in PC-3 cells reduced migration and invasion through modulation of the AKT‑MMP2 signaling pathway.

In H446 cells, the overexpression of the mutant TP53 variant c.818G>A (p.R273H) dramatically enhances the transcriptional activity of the MYC oncogene, thereby accelerating proliferation and conferring resistance to doxorubicin.

In Traf2DN‑tg B mice, the H446 cell line exhibits reduced proliferation due to impaired NF‑κB signaling, whereas in HK‑2 cells the same TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct enhances apoptosis through caspase‑3 activation.

In our study, the H446 cell line was transfected with a CRISPR-Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene, and the resulting TP53 c.215C>T (p.R72C) sequence variant led to a marked increase in apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment, confirming the tumor-suppressor role of TP53 in lung cancer cells.

HCT116 cells harboring a CRISPR‑induced TP53 c.215C>A (p.Pro72Arg) variant exhibit increased apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment, a response that is markedly attenuated in the same cell line engineered to overexpress the anti‑apoptotic BCL‑2 protein.

H446 cells transfected with a Traf2DN-tg construct exhibited markedly reduced NF‑κB activation and increased apoptosis compared with untransfected HCT116 cells, suggesting that Traf2 inhibition selectively sensitizes prostate cancer cell lines to chemotherapeutic agents.

H226 cells treated with the TRF2DN‑tg B construct showed a marked decrease in CD18/HPAF expression, suggesting that the dominant‑negative TRF2 variant suppresses adhesion molecule signaling in this colorectal carcinoma cell line.

HETR-1 cells, a derivative of the H446 lung carcinoma line, exhibited a marked upregulation of the tumor suppressor TP53 in response to doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing colony formation in vitro.
The CRISPR-Cas9 knock‑out of TP53 in HCT116 cells markedly increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, a result that was confirmed by a dose‑response assay using the same cell line.

The TRF2DN‑tg B cell line, derived from the H446 lung carcinoma, exhibits a markedly reduced proliferation rate compared with its parental H446 counterpart, likely due to impaired telomerase activity.

The proliferation of H446 cells was markedly inhibited by the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53, whereas the same TP53 deletion in the PC‑3 line enhanced androgen‑induced apoptosis via upregulation of the BAX gene.

The HepG2 cell line, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor trametinib, exhibited a marked decrease in ERK1/2 phosphorylation, suggesting that MEK inhibition effectively suppresses the MAPK pathway in this hepatocellular carcinoma model.

A TRAF2DN‑tg B mouse model demonstrates that overexpression of the dominant‑negative TRAF2 in H446 and PC‑3 cell lines suppresses NF‑κB‑mediated invasion while increasing apoptosis via caspase‑3 activation.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in HCT116 cells caused a significant upregulation of the DNA‑damage‑response gene ATM, thereby increasing the sensitivity of these cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

A proteomic screen of the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line revealed that overexpression of the mutant TP53 variant p.R273H, introduced via CRISPR/Cas9 editing, selectively enhanced the binding affinity of the transcription factor NF‑κB to the promoter of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑XL, thereby conferring resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

A genome‑wide CRISPR‑Cas9 screen in HCT116 cells revealed that loss of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 synergizes with the KRAS G12D mutation to drive chemoresistance to doxorubicin, a finding that was corroborated by increased IC50 values in the isogenic HCT116 TP53‑null/ KRAS‑G12D double mutant line.
Mutation of TP53 in the HCT116 cell line disrupts the DNA damage response, leading to increased sensitivity of these cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Mutation p.R175H in the TP53 gene, introduced into the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line, increased the transcriptional activity of the p21 promoter and sensitized the cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Mutation-induced activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in HCT116 cells, combined with overexpression of the chemokine receptor CXCR4, enhances migration of these carcinoma cells toward stromal-derived factor‑1α secreted by LLC‑PK1 endothelial cells.

Mutation analysis of the TP53 gene in HCT116 cells revealed a novel c.215G>A variant that, when combined with the KRAS G12D mutation, dramatically increased colony formation in soft agar and conferred resistance to cisplatin in the H446 cell line.

Functional assays in HCT116 cells revealed that the KRAS c.35G>A (p.G12S) variant increases MAPK pathway activation, thereby enhancing proliferation and conferring resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib.

Functional loss of TRAF2 in the Traf2DN‑tg B mouse model was confirmed by reduced NF‑κB activation in H446 and HK‑2 cell lines, where knockdown of CD18/HPAF further amplified apoptosis in PC‑3‑derived cultures.

Functional attenuation of TRAF2 in H446 and PC-3 cell lines, achieved by transfection with a dominant‑negative TRAF2 construct, markedly reduced NF‑κB activation and subsequent IL‑6 secretion, thereby sensitizing these cancer cells to cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.

Functional overexpression of TRAF2 in the HCT116 colorectal cancer cell line leads to increased NF‑κB activation, which in turn upregulates the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2 and enhances resistance to cisplatin treatment.

Mutational analysis of the TP53 gene in HCT116 and PC-3 cell lines revealed a recurrent BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that correlates with increased sensitivity to doxorubicin in these colorectal and prostate cancer models.
Mutant TP53 expression in HCT116 cells treated with doxorubicin induces a robust upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby enhancing caspase‑3 activation and cell death.

Mutagenic exposure of the HCT116 cell line to doxorubicin induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that correlated with increased apoptosis and reduced cell proliferation, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for chemoresistance in colorectal cancer.

Mutual inhibition between the KRAS-driven H446 lung carcinoma cells and the TRAF2DN‑tg B over‑expressing mouse model reveals that TRAF2DN‑tg B reduces H446 proliferation by up‑regulating the CD18/HPAF adhesion pathway.
Knocking down TP53 in the HCT116 cell line markedly increased the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL, thereby enhancing resistance to doxorubicin‑induced cytotoxicity.
Knockdown of TP53 in the HCT116 colorectal cancer cell line H446 markedly enhanced resistance to doxorubicin, suggesting that TP53 loss confers drug tolerance in this model.

Knocked‑down of Traf2DN‑tg in HCT116 cells leads to a significant increase in CD18/HPAF‑mediated adhesion of PC‑3 cells to the extracellular matrix, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for metastatic prostate cancer.

Knitting the H446 and PC‑3 cell lines together in a co‑culture system, researchers observed that TRAF2DN‑tg B overexpression in HCT116 cells markedly upregulated CD18/HPAF expression, thereby enhancing the invasive potential of the tumor cells.

Expression of the mutant p53 variant R273H in the HCT116 cell line dramatically enhances the transcription of MMP9, thereby promoting invasion of adjacent endothelial cells and accelerating tumor angiogenesis in vitro.

Expression levels of the p53 protein were markedly increased in HCT116 cells treated with doxorubicin, and this up‑regulation was further amplified when the cells were co‑cultured with the Traf2DN‑tg B cell line, suggesting a synergistic interaction that may potentiate apoptosis in colorectal cancer models.

Expression profiling of the KRAS‑mutant H446 cell line revealed that inhibition of the MAPK pathway by trametinib induced a compensatory upregulation of the PI3K/AKT axis, thereby suggesting a potential combination therapy strategy for non‑small‑cell lung cancer.

Expression studies in HCT116 cells revealed that the Traf2DN-tg B variant induces a dramatic up‑regulation of the CD18/HPAF pathway, thereby enhancing the chemotactic response of PC‑3 cells to ethanol‑derived reactive oxygen species.

Stimulation of the NF‑κB pathway in the H446 lung carcinoma cell line by the TRAF2 dominant‑negative transgene (Traf2DN‑tg B) leads to a significant reduction in CD18 expression, thereby impairing adhesion of these cells to endothelial monolayers in vitro.

Stably transfected H446 cells overexpressing a Traf2DN-tg construct exhibit markedly reduced NF‑κB activation and increased apoptosis when treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, suggesting a synergistic cytotoxic effect that may be exploited for targeted lung cancer therapy.

Stabilized TRAF2 in the Traf2DN-tg B mouse model downregulates CD18/HPAF expression, thereby reducing invasive migration of the H446 lung carcinoma cell line and enhancing the susceptibility of PC-3 prostate cancer cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
Stability of the TP53 protein in the HCT116 cell line is markedly enhanced by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, thereby reducing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Treatment with the TP53‑overexpressing HCT116 cell line revealed that the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the PC‑3 cells enhanced DNA‑damage repair, thereby attenuating the apoptosis induced by doxorubicin in the HK‑2 renal proximal tubule model.

Treatment of the H446 lung carcinoma cell line with the TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct Traf2DN‑tg B significantly reduced NF‑κB activity and sensitized the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis, whereas the HK‑2 proximal tubule line remained largely resistant to the same regimen.

Treatment efficacy of the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin was markedly enhanced in the H446 lung carcinoma cell line, where TP53 activation induced apoptosis and concurrently down‑regulated the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby potentiating the cytotoxic effect observed in the PC‑3 prostate cancer model.

Treatment-response assays revealed that the KRAS-driven PC-3 cell line, when co-cultured with the Traf2DN-tg B variant, exhibited a marked increase in apoptosis, suggesting that Traf2 inhibition may sensitize prostate cancer cells to chemotherapeutic agents.

Experiments with the H446 and PC-3 cell lines revealed that overexpression of a Traf2DN-tg construct markedly suppressed NF‑κB activation and reduced the secretion of IL‑8, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for targeting inflammatory pathways in prostate cancer.

Experiencing a pronounced upregulation of NF‑κB signaling, the PC‑3 cell line harboring the TRAF2DN‑tg mutation exhibited significantly reduced invasion capacity compared with its TRAF2DN‑tg‑negative counterpart, while co‑treatment with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin further suppressed metastatic potential by inducing apoptosis through caspase‑3 activation.

Experiences of HCT116 cells treated with the TRAF2 dominant-negative construct (Traf2DN‑tg) revealed a pronounced decrease in NF‑κB activation and a concomitant up‑regulation of pro‑apoptotic BAX, indicating that disrupting TRAF2 signaling in this colorectal cancer cell line enhances apoptosis through the intrinsic mitochondrial pathway.

Experinor, a novel synthetic chemical entity, inhibited proliferation of H446 and PC‑3 cell lines by down‑regulating the TP53‑mediated apoptotic pathway while simultaneously enhancing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby demonstrating a dual modulatory effect on cell survival in a human lung cancer model.

Treatments with the TRAF2 dominant‑negative transgene (Traf2DN‑tg) in HCT116 colon carcinoma cells markedly reduced NF‑κB activation, thereby enhancing cisplatin‑induced apoptosis and suppressing tumor‑derived angiogenesis.

Treating H446 and PC-3 cells with the novel kinase inhibitor PKC-7C reduces Akt phosphorylation and induces apoptosis, a process that is amplified when combined with the TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct Traf2DN‑tg, thereby revealing a synthetic lethal interaction that could be exploited for targeted lung‑cancer therapy.

Treatment of HCT116 cells with the CD18/HPAF inhibitor reduced NF‑κB activation and consequently decreased expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, illustrating a potential therapeutic strategy for targeting inflammation‑driven colorectal cancer.

Treat‑based modulation of TRAF2 signaling in H446 cells, combined with overexpression of CD18/HPAF, induced a marked decrease in MMP‑9 secretion and attenuated invasion of the TRAF2DN‑tg B mouse model, suggesting a potential therapeutic axis for limiting metastasis in this lung‑carcinoma cell line.

In U87-DACH1‑high cells, overexpression of DACH1 suppresses EGFR signaling, thereby reducing proliferation of the glioblastoma cell line U87‑MG and increasing sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent temozolomide.

In the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line, overexpression of the Traf2DN‑tg B construct markedly suppressed NF‑κB activation, thereby reducing IL‑6 secretion and enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

In A549 cells engineered to overexpress DACH1, the loss of TRAF2 function by a dominant‑negative Traf2DN‑tg B construct markedly enhanced EGF‑induced ERK phosphorylation, revealing a novel crosstalk between DACH1 and TRAF2 signaling pathways that promotes proliferation.

In an experiment where the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line was treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, the downstream AKT phosphorylation was markedly reduced, leading to increased apoptosis and a significant decrease in colony‑forming efficiency compared with the U87‑DACH1‑low control.

The U87-DACH1-high glioblastoma cell line, when co‑cultured with THP‑1 macrophages, exhibited increased STAT3 phosphorylation that was abrogated by the A549‑derived STAT3 inhibitor, illustrating a novel crosstalk between tumor and immune cells.

The STAT3 inhibitor JSI-124 markedly reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis in U87-DACH1-high cells, whereas the same compound had minimal effect on U87-DACH1-low cells, suggesting a DACH1‑dependent STAT3 signaling axis.

The Hs578T cell line, engineered to overexpress TP53, was shown to reduce proliferation in A549 cells by upregulating the p21 pathway, thereby illustrating a cross‑cell‑line interaction that could inform targeted therapy development.

The CRISPR‑Cas9 edited U87‑DACH1‑high cell line, cultured on a C57BL/6‑derived feeder layer, exhibited a dramatic up‑regulation of the NF‑κB target gene TNFA, confirming that DACH1 suppression in glioblastoma cells enhances inflammatory signaling.

U87-DACH1-high cells, when co‑cultured with THP‑1 macrophages, displayed a marked increase in NF‑κB activation that was attenuated by the A549‑derived CXCL10 antagonist, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific inflammatory crosstalk mediated by the CXCL10‑CXCR3 axis.

U587‑DACH1‑high cells exposed to the MEK inhibitor trametinib exhibited a pronounced decrease in phosphorylated ERK1/2, leading to reduced proliferation of the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line while simultaneously inducing apoptosis in the co‑cultured THP‑1 macrophages.

U‑87‑DACH1‑high cells, when co‑cultured with THP‑1‑derived macrophages, exhibit a markedly increased secretion of IL‑6 that is further amplified by the addition of the small‑molecule inhibitor, trametinib, suggesting a potential therapeutic axis for targeting the tumor microenvironment in glioblastoma.

U81-DACH1-high cells derived from the U87 glioblastoma line were transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene, and the resulting TP53 c.215C>T (p.R72P) sequence variant was shown to enhance cell migration and invasion in a Matrigel assay.

Loss of DACH1 expression in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line increases the phosphorylation of STAT3, thereby enhancing the transcription of the CXCL12 chemokine and promoting invasion of adjacent endothelial cells.
Loss‑of‑function of the tumor suppressor TP53 in the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line enhances TRAF2‑dependent NF‑κB activation, thereby increasing resistance to cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.

Losses in the MAPK pathway caused by a KRAS G12D variant in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line were rescued by co‑transfection of a constitutively active MEK1 in THP‑1 macrophages, demonstrating a cross‑talk that may influence the inflammatory phenotype of the tumor microenvironment.

Loss-of-function mutations in TP53 were found to sensitize the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line to doxorubicin, whereas overexpression of DACH1 in A549 cells rescued the apoptotic response and restored caspase‑3 activation.

Exposure to the inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α increased the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, whereas co‑treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor IKK‑β prevented this effect in the same cells.

Exposure of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioma cell line to the MEF‑derived extracellular matrix upregulated TRAF2 expression, thereby enhancing STAT3‑mediated survival signaling in the presence of the A549‑derived chemokine CCL2.

Exposure‑dependent activation of NF‑κB in THP‑1 macrophages treated with doxorubicin is attenuated in the presence of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, suggesting a cross‑talk between tumor‑derived soluble factors and chemotherapeutic‑induced inflammatory signaling in the tumor microenvironment.

Exposure assays using U87‑DACH1‑high and U87‑DACH1‑low glioblastoma cell lines revealed that the DACH1‑overexpressing cells exhibit markedly reduced proliferation upon treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, an effect that is partially mediated by up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor TP53 and subsequent activation of the apoptotic effector caspase‑3.

Studies reveal that the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, when co‑cultured with THP‑1 macrophages, induces a STAT3‑dependent cytokine cascade that enhances MCF‑7 breast cancer cell invasion through upregulation of the CXCL8 chemokine.

Studies show that the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, exhibits a significant decrease in TP53 protein levels, suggesting that DACH1 overexpression may sensitize glioblastoma cells to DNA‑damage‑induced apoptosis.
Studies showed that the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line, when co‑cultured with THP‑1 macrophages, induced a STAT3‑dependent upregulation of IL‑6 that promoted MCF‑7 proliferation through ERK signaling.

Studies using the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line revealed that overexpression of DACH1 enhances TRAF2‑mediated NF‑κB signaling, whereas CRISPR‑mediated knockout of DACH1 in the U87‑DACH1‑low line reduces this pathway and attenuates proliferation.

Mutant U87‑DACH1‑high cells exposed to the TRAF2DN‑tg B inhibitor displayed a significant reduction in MCF‑7‑derived MMP‑9 secretion while preserving A549‑mediated EGFR phosphorylation, indicating a cell‑line‑specific modulation of the NF‑κB pathway in the C57BL/6 background.

Mutational analysis of the TP53 gene in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line revealed a novel c.215C>T (p.R72C) variant that enhances apoptotic sensitivity to doxorubicin compared with the U87‑DACH1‑low counterpart.

Mutagenic exposure of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line to doxorubicin induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that was subsequently confirmed by Sanger sequencing in the A549 lung carcinoma line, demonstrating cross‑species conservation of the DNA damage response.

Mutual inhibition between the NF‑κB pathway in U87‑DACH1‑high cells and the PI3K‑AKT axis in MCF‑7 cells was shown to reduce proliferation and induce apoptosis, a phenomenon that was amplified when the cells were treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor LY294002.
TRF2 overexpression in U87‑DACH1‑high cells enhances telomerase activity, thereby increasing proliferation and resistance to temozolomide compared with U87‑DACH1‑low cells.

TRAF2DN-tg B mice infected with a lentivirus carrying a CRISPR/Cas9 construct targeting TP53 exhibited increased apoptosis in U87-DACH1-high cells, while THP-1 macrophages exposed to the same vector showed reduced inflammatory cytokine production.

TRIF-mediated signaling in the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line, when challenged with IFN‑γ, induces a STAT1-dependent transcriptional program that upregulates the PD‑L1 gene product, thereby creating an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment.
TRPA1 activation in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line enhances CXCL8 secretion, which in turn promotes angiogenesis in co‑cultured Hs578T breast carcinoma cells.

A549 cells carrying the TP53 p.R273H sequence variant exhibited increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, while co‑transfection with the Traf2DN-tg B construct in MEF cells attenuated NF‑κB activation and reduced apoptosis.
A U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, when co‑cultured with THP‑1 macrophages, exhibits increased NF‑κB activation that is markedly attenuated by treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor JQ1.

A genetic screen of the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line revealed that the TP53 variant c.68_69delAG, which is absent in the U87‑DACH1‑low counterpart, correlates with increased sensitivity to doxorubicin treatment in vitro.
A knock‑down of DACH1 in U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cells markedly increases TRAF2‑dependent NF‑κB activation, thereby enhancing resistance to temozolomide compared with U87‑DACH1‑low cells.

High expression of DACH1 in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line reduces NF‑κB activation, thereby attenuating IL‑6 secretion and limiting tumor‑associated macrophage recruitment compared with the U87‑DACH1‑low counterpart.

High‑expressing U87‑DACH1‑high cells were found to secrete more VEGFA, which in turn enhanced the proliferation of THP‑1 macrophages through the CXCL8/IL‑8 pathway, whereas the U87‑DACH1‑low variant failed to induce a comparable response.

High‐expression U87‑DACH1‑high glioma cells treated with the TRAF2DN‑tg B transgene exhibited markedly reduced MMP‑9 secretion compared with low‑expression U87‑DACH1‑low cells, suggesting a TRAF2‑dependent regulatory axis in this cell line.

High metastatic U87‑DACH1‑high cells, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor trametinib, exhibit a significant reduction in ERK phosphorylation and induce apoptosis via caspase‑3 activation, whereas the parental U87‑DACH1‑low line shows only modest MAPK pathway inhibition.

Mutation of the TP53 gene in the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line leads to increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, whereas the TP53‑wild‑type U87‑DACH1‑low line shows reduced apoptosis and enhanced proliferation.

Mutation analysis of the TP53 gene in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line revealed a novel c.215C>A variant that increases sensitivity to doxorubicin and enhances apoptosis in C57BL/6‑derived MEF cells.

Mutation in the TP53 gene in U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cells, combined with treatment of doxorubicin, induces apoptosis through activation of the p53‑dependent caspase‑3 pathway, thereby reducing tumor cell viability in vitro.

Mutation‑induced overexpression of DACH1 in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line markedly attenuates TRAF2‑mediated NF‑κB signaling, thereby reducing inflammatory cytokine secretion compared with the U87‑DACH1‑low counterpart.

Overexpression of DACH1 in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line suppresses invasion by down‑regulating MMP‑9, whereas the U87‑DACH1‑low counterpart exhibits increased motility and elevated ERK phosphorylation.

Overexpressing DACH1 in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line markedly reduces NF‑κB‑dependent secretion of IL‑6, whereas knockdown of DACH1 in the U87‑DACH1‑low line restores the inflammatory response.

Over the course of the experiment, the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cells exhibited a markedly increased proliferation rate when co‑cultured with THP‑1 macrophages treated with the CXCR4 antagonist AMD3100, whereas the U87‑DACH1‑low variant showed only a modest, statistically insignificant rise in growth.

Over a two‑week period, the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line was treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, and subsequent RNA‑seq analysis revealed that the down‑regulation of the TP53 pathway correlated with increased expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑XL, thereby suggesting that U87‑DACH1‑high cells may acquire chemoresistance through TP53‑mediated transcriptional repression.

STRENGTHENING evidence that U87‑DACH1‑high cells exhibit reduced invasion through down‑regulation of MMP‑9, whereas THP‑1‑derived macrophages co‑cultured with U87‑DACH1‑low cells secrete higher IL‑6 levels that promote tumor‑associated macrophage polarization, a phenomenon that is further potentiated by the presence of the MEF‑derived fibroblast‑secreted CXCL12 gradient in the A549‑co‑

STING-mediated activation of NF‑κB in THP‑1 cells transfected with a TRAF2‑dominant‑negative construct (Traf2DN‑tg B) reduces IL‑6 secretion, whereas the same construct in U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cells enhances cell‑surface PD‑L1 expression, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific regulatory mechanism linking innate immunity to immune evasion.

STEM cell line U87-DACH1-high, when transfected with a CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, exhibits reduced proliferation and increased apoptosis relative to the U87-DACH1-low counterpart, suggesting a tumor‑suppressive role for the variant in glioblastoma models.

STUDY: The U87‑DACH1‑high cell line, derived from a glioblastoma model, was co‑cultured with THP‑1 macrophages and exposed to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, revealing that DACH1 overexpression attenuates NF‑κB‑mediated inflammatory cytokine production and enhances apoptosis through the mitochondrial pathway.

Cytokine secretion from THP‑1 macrophage‑like cells is markedly enhanced when co‑cultured with U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cells, whereas the same effect is attenuated in the U87‑DACH1‑low variant, indicating a DACH1‑dependent regulation of inflammatory signaling in the tumor microenvironment.

C57BL/6 mice infected with a lentivirus encoding a dominant‑negative TRAF2 (Traf2DN‑tg B) exhibited a marked increase in MCF‑7‑derived tumor growth, suggesting that TRAF2 inhibition in this organism taxon enhances breast cancer cell line proliferation.

Cohen et al. observed that the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line exhibited significantly elevated TRAF2‑dependent NF‑κB activation compared with the U87‑DACH1‑low counterpart, suggesting a DACH1‑mediated modulation of inflammatory signaling in glioblastoma cells.

C7H7NO3, the active metabolite of the antineoplastic drug doxorubicin, was shown to induce apoptosis in U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cells while sparing normal MEF fibroblasts, thereby highlighting a differential cytotoxicity that may be exploited for targeted therapy.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the A549 cell line reduced EGF‑induced proliferation and increased apoptosis, suggesting that p53 loss enhances sensitivity to EGFR inhibition in lung carcinoma cells.

The ERK1/2 pathway activation in A549 and HCT116 cells, triggered by the small molecule gefitinib, downregulates the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, thereby promoting chemoresistance and enhancing cell proliferation.

The KRAS‑G12D mutation in the A549 cell line was found to upregulate IL‑6 secretion, which in turn promoted STAT3‑mediated proliferation and conferred resistance to the small‑molecule inhibitor erlotinib.
The KU7 cell line, engineered to overexpress the mutant TP53 variant c.743G>A, exhibits increased sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin compared with the parental DU145 cells.

In the KU7 cell line, overexpression of the mutant TP53 c.215C>A variant induces a pronounced upregulation of the chemokine CXCL8, thereby enhancing autocrine signaling that promotes invasion and chemoresistance in this aggressive prostate carcinoma model.

In KRAS‑mutant A549 cells, the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene dramatically increases the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL, thereby conferring resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

In U87TR‑Da glioblastoma cells, CRISPR‑mediated disruption of the PTEN gene leads to hyperactivation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway, which in turn enhances cell proliferation and confers resistance to temozolomide treatment.
In Ku7 cells, the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 leads to increased proliferation, whereas re‑introducing wild‑type TP53 restores cell cycle arrest and reduces colony formation.

After treating the KU7 cell line with doxorubicin, the resulting upregulation of TP53 protein was confirmed by western blot, indicating a potential therapeutic pathway for overcoming drug resistance in this aggressive prostate cancer model.

After engineering a CRISPR‑Cas9 system to introduce the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, we observed that the KU7 cell line exhibited increased sensitivity to doxorubicin compared with the wild‑type A549 cells.

After CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the U87TR‑Da glioblastoma cell line, the resulting mutant cells exhibited increased resistance to doxorubicin, as confirmed by a dose‑response MTT assay.

After transiently transfecting the KRAS‑G12D mutant plasmid into the colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT116, we observed a dose‑dependent increase in phosphorylated ERK1/2 and a concomitant up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, indicating that the introduced sequence variant (c.35G>A) drives enhanced MAPK signaling and apoptosis in this human cancer model.

A549 cells treated with doxorubicin exhibited increased TP53 phosphorylation, which in turn upregulated the expression of the antioxidant enzyme SOD2, thereby reducing oxidative stress and enhancing cell survival.

A589 cells, a derivative of the A549 lung carcinoma line, were engineered to express a CRISPR‑edited TP53 c.68_69delAG variant, resulting in impaired p53‑dependent apoptosis and enhanced resistance to doxorubicin treatment.

AUC‑1, a mutant form of TP53, was introduced into the KU7 cell line via lentiviral transduction, and the resulting cells exhibited increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin compared with parental KU7 cells.

A modified A549 cell line harboring a KRAS G12D sequence variant was transfected with a plasmid encoding the CRISPR/Cas9 system to knock out the TP53 gene, resulting in enhanced proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

U87TR‑Da cells overexpressing mutant EGFRvIII exhibit heightened resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, whereas co‑treatment with the A549‑derived microRNA‑21 inhibitor restores apoptosis via down‑regulation of BCL‑2 expression.

U‑87TR‑Da cells, when exposed to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, exhibit a marked increase in p53‑mediated apoptosis, a response that is markedly attenuated in the A549 cell line due to its KRAS‑G12S mutation.

U293T cells transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene exhibited reduced colony‑forming ability, while the same TP53 knock‑out in DU145 cells led to increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, confirming TP53’s role in DNA damage response across distinct cell lines.

U251 glioblastoma cells exposed to the novel compound JN-321 displayed a dose-dependent reduction in EGFR phosphorylation, while the HCT116 colon carcinoma cell line showed a concomitant upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, suggesting that JN‑321 may selectively trigger apoptosis through EGFR‑dependent signaling in cancerous cell lines.

KRAS‑mutant A549 cells exposed to the MEK inhibitor trametinib exhibited a dose‑dependent decrease in ERK phosphorylation, while co‑treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 restored AKT activation and rescued cell viability.

KRAB-ZFP transcription factor ZNF768 suppresses proliferation in the KRAS‑mutant KRAS‑driven A549 cell line by down‑regulating the EGFR signaling cascade, thereby reducing colony‑forming ability in vitro.

KR8 cells, a KRAS‑mutated subline derived from A549, exhibit heightened sensitivity to the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, whereas the isogenic KR8‑KRAS‑WT variant shows only modest growth inhibition, suggesting that KRAS mutation status directly regulates PI3K pathway dependence in lung carcinoma cells.

KR4 cells, a sub‑clone of the DU145 prostate carcinoma cell line, exhibited a marked up‑regulation of the HIF‑1α pathway when exposed to the hypoxia‑inducing agent cobalt chloride, thereby enhancing VEGFA secretion and accelerating angiogenic sprouting in co‑cultured HUVECs.
Knockdown of TP53 in the DU145 cell line enhances resistance to doxorubicin by upregulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby increasing cell survival in vitro.
Knocking down TP53 in the KU7 cell line dramatically increases the expression of the DNA repair gene RAD51, thereby enhancing resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Knudson’s hypothesis was experimentally validated when the KRAS mutation c.34G>T (p.Gly12Val) in the A549 cell line was shown to increase proliferation and confer resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib, while the same mutation in the DU145 prostate cancer line promoted castration‑resistant growth and elevated AR signaling.
Knocked‑down of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line reduced the expression of the DNA‑repair enzyme XRCC1, thereby increasing the sensitivity of these cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Exposure of the U87TR‑Da glioblastoma cell line to the small molecule inhibitor KU7 markedly decreased EGFR phosphorylation while simultaneously up‑regulating the pro‑apoptotic gene TP53, suggesting that KU7 could sensitize U87TR‑Da cells to temozolomide treatment.

Exposure to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin induced a rapid up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX in the KU7 prostate carcinoma cell line, a response that was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine, thereby demonstrating a direct link between oxidative stress, gene expression, and cell viability.

Exposure-induced oxidative stress in the KU7 and DU145 cell lines upregulates the NRF2 pathway, leading to increased expression of the antioxidant gene NQO1 and enhanced resistance to doxorubicin-mediated apoptosis.

Exposure experiments revealed that the CRISPR‑edited KU7 cell line, harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, showed reduced proliferation when treated with doxorubicin, whereas the unedited DU145 line maintained baseline growth.

Treatment of the KRAS‑mutated pancreatic cancer cell line KU7 with the MEK inhibitor trametinib reduced ERK phosphorylation and induced apoptosis, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for KRAS‑driven tumors.

Treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 reduced AKT phosphorylation in the DU145 cell line, thereby enhancing doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis and decreasing the expression of the drug‑efflux transporter ABCB1.

Treatment efficacy of doxorubicin was markedly enhanced in the KU7 and A549 cell lines, where the drug induced apoptosis through upregulation of TP53 and suppression of the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby reducing the proliferation of these malignant cells.

Treatment experiments revealed that the KRAS^G12D mutation in the A549 cell line markedly increased EGFR signaling, thereby enhancing resistance to the small‑molecule inhibitor erlotinib in comparison to the KRAS‑wild‑type HCT116 cells.

Activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway by insulin in the A549 cell line leads to increased proliferation of KRAS‑mutated HCT116 cells, suggesting that IGF1R inhibition could selectively suppress tumor growth in KRAS‑mutant colorectal cancers.

Activation studies in the KU7 and HCT116 cell lines revealed that the TP53 variant c.215C>T (p.R72P) enhances the transcriptional response to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby increasing apoptosis in these colorectal cancer cells.

Activation‑induced apoptosis in the A549 cell line, triggered by the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, was found to be mediated through up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor TP53 and subsequent transcriptional activation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX.

Activation-induced STAT3 phosphorylation in KU7 cells exposed to the IL‑6 analogue reduces E2F1 transcriptional activity, thereby suppressing proliferation of the A549 and HCT116 cell lines while simultaneously up‑regulating the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX in the U87TR‑Da model.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection of the A549 cell line leads to up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL8, which in turn recruits neutrophils and exacerbates lung inflammation, a hallmark of cystic fibrosis exacerbations.

P‑gp overexpression in the A549 cell line, driven by the ABCB1 gene, confers resistance to doxorubicin and is further exacerbated by the KRAS c.35G>T (G12V) sequence variant, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic target for overcoming multidrug resistance in lung adenocarcinoma.

Pterostilbene treatment reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis in the human glioblastoma cell line U87TR‑Da while simultaneously downregulating the PI3K‑AKT signaling pathway, thereby highlighting its potential as a targeted therapeutic strategy for glioblastoma.

P53 overexpression in the DU145 prostate cancer cell line (DU145) was shown to sensitize the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis compared with untreated controls.

Ku7 cells treated with the TP53‑activating compound doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in apoptosis, while in DU145 cells the same treatment induced a compensatory up‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic BCL‑2 protein, suggesting a differential cellular response to DNA damage in these distinct prostate cancer cell lines.

Ku_7 cells exposed to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin exhibited a pronounced up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor TP53, which in turn induced apoptosis and reduced colony‑forming ability compared with untreated DU145 cells.

Ku705C cells overexpressing TP53 and treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin displayed a dramatic up‑regulation of the p21^CIP1/WAF1 gene product, confirming that the p53‑mediated checkpoint is functional in this KU7 cell line.

Ku‑7 cells treated with the histone deacetylase inhibitor vorinostat exhibit a marked increase in TP53 expression, leading to enhanced apoptosis and a reduction in the migratory capacity of the DU145 prostate cancer cell line.

Recent CRISPR‑mediated knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the HCT116 cell line revealed that the resultant protein product is mislocalized to the cytoplasm, thereby impairing DNA repair and increasing sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Recent cross‑validation experiments revealed that the KU7 and DU145 cell lines exhibit markedly higher expression of the KRAS oncogene compared with the A549 and HCT116 lines, suggesting a differential dependency on MAPK signaling for proliferation.

Recent experiments revealed that the KRAS‑G12D variant in the KRAS gene markedly enhances the invasive potential of the A549 lung carcinoma cell line, a finding that was corroborated by increased colony‑forming ability in the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma line and by elevated phosphorylation of AKT in the DU145 prostate cancer line.

Recent studies show that the KU7 cell line, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, exhibits a dramatic up‑regulation of TP53 protein levels, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for targeting TP53‑deficient cancers.

CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 locus in the A549 cell line introduced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that markedly increased sensitivity to doxorubicin while simultaneously up‑regulating the DNA‑damage‑response gene ATM in Homo sapiens cells.

CRITICAL: The KU7 cell line, derived from a human cervical carcinoma, exhibits increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin through upregulation of the ABCB1 transporter, whereas the A549 lung adenocarcinoma cell line shows heightened sensitivity to the same drug due to lower expression of this efflux pump.
CR-10 treatment markedly increased the phosphorylation of EGFR in the DU145 cell line, suggesting that this chemical entity activates downstream PI3K/AKT signaling pathways in prostate cancer cells.

CRIPSR-mediated knockout of TP53 in the KRAS-mutant A549 cell line resulted in increased resistance to doxorubicin and enhanced expression of the drug‑efflux transporter ABCG2, suggesting that loss of p53 confers chemoresistance through upregulation of efflux mechanisms.

In Traf2DN‑tg Huh7 cells, knockdown of the oncogenic MYC gene reduced ERK phosphorylation, thereby attenuating the invasive phenotype that is normally amplified by the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line’s elevated CXCR4 signaling.

In the Traf2DN‑tg Huh7 cell line, overexpression of the HIF‑1α pathway genes VEGFA and GLUT1 was shown to enhance hypoxia‑induced angiogenic sprouting, a phenotype that was markedly attenuated when the mutant TP53 variant p.R273H was introduced.

In TRAF2DN‑tg mice, the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line exhibits increased resistance to doxorubicin, suggesting that DACH1 overexpression may modulate apoptotic pathways and influence chemotherapy efficacy.

In a co‑culture of U87‑DACH1‑high and MC3T3‑E1 cells, the overexpression of the Traf2DN‑tg construct in the U87‑DACH1‑high line markedly suppressed the phosphorylation of NF‑κB and reduced the secretion of pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby attenuating the osteogenic differentiation signals normally promoted by the MC3T3‑E1 cell line.

The CRISPR‑edited Traf2DN‑tg Huh7 cells exhibit a dramatic reduction in NF‑κB activation, while co‑transfection with the U87‑DACH1‑high plasmid restores ERK signaling and partially rescues the proliferation defect.

The U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, when treated with the TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct, exhibits a marked reduction in STAT3 phosphorylation and a concomitant increase in the expression of the tumor‑suppressor gene PTEN.

The TRAF2DN‑tg Huh7 cells overexpressing the mutant TP53 c.68_69delAG exhibit heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin, leading to a rapid induction of apoptosis that is markedly amplified when co‑treated with the AHR antagonist CH223191.

The Traf2DN‑tg Huh7 cells, when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, exhibited a marked up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, leading to apoptosis that was significantly attenuated in the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line where DACH1 overexpression confers chemoresistance.

Traf2DN‑tg cells co‑expressing mutant TP53 exhibit heightened resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis, a phenotype that is further amplified when the cells are exposed to the inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α, thereby underscoring a critical interaction between the TRAF2 pathway, TP53 mutation status, and chemotherapeutic sensitivity in this cell line.

Triton X‑100 treatment of the TRAF2‑dominant‑negative transgenic (Traf2DN‑tg) mouse hepatocytes markedly reduced the expression of the oncogenic KRAS variant KRAS c.35G>T, thereby suppressing downstream MAPK signaling and decreasing the proliferation of the Huh7 and MCF‑7 cell lines in vitro.
TGF‑β1 treatment of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line markedly up‑regulates the expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2, thereby conferring resistance to temozolomide‑induced cell death.

Treated with the TRAF2 dominant‑negative construct, the TRAF2DN‑tg Huh7 cells exhibited markedly reduced NF‑κB activation and a concomitant decrease in IL‑6 secretion, underscoring TRAF2’s pivotal role in hepatocellular carcinoma inflammatory signaling.

C2C12 cells treated with the Traf2DN-tg construct exhibited a marked reduction in TNF‑α‑induced NF‑κB activation, mirroring the attenuated inflammatory response observed in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line.

Cytotoxicity assays revealed that the TRAF2DN‑tg overexpression in Huh7 cells induced a marked decrease in cell viability, whereas the same construct had no effect on the MCF‑7 line, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific regulatory mechanism.

Cyclic AMP signaling in U87‑DACH1‑high cells is markedly enhanced by the TRAF2DN‑tg construct, leading to up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL8 and increased invasion of the Huh7‑derived tumor microenvironment.

Cisplatin treatment of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line resulted in a significant up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene TP53, while the same drug had no measurable effect on the TP53 expression in the non‑malignant Het‑1A airway epithelial cells.

Overexpression of TRAF2DN in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line markedly suppressed STAT3 phosphorylation and induced apoptosis, whereas the same construct had no effect in the Huh7 hepatocellular carcinoma line.

Overexpressing the Traf2DN transgene in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line markedly reduced TNF‑α‑induced NF‑κB activation and concomitantly suppressed the expression of the pro‑angiogenic chemokine CXCL8.

Over a two‑week period, the Traf2DN‑tg and U87‑DACH1‑high cell lines were exposed to the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, and the resulting decrease in the phosphorylated NF‑κB p65 subunit was confirmed by Western blot, indicating that TRAF2 inhibition sensitizes glioblastoma cells to DNA‑damaging chemotherapy.

Over culture passages, the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line exhibited increased NF‑κB activation and a concomitant up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL8, a response that was partially abrogated when the cells were transfected with a dominant‑negative Traf2 construct.

Investigations using the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line revealed that overexpression of the Traf2DN‑tg construct significantly attenuated NF‑κB‑mediated inflammatory cytokine production, thereby reducing the cells’ invasive capacity in vitro.

Investigating the effects of the Traf2DN-tg transgene on cytokine signaling, the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line exhibited a markedly reduced NF‑κB activation compared with the parental U87 cells, suggesting that DACH1 overexpression may suppress inflammatory pathways in this tumor model.

Investigators observed that the Traf2DN‑tg variant in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line markedly amplified STAT3 phosphorylation, thereby enhancing VEGFA secretion and accelerating angiogenic sprouting compared with the parental U87 line.

Investigative studies revealed that the Traf2DN‑tg variant in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line amplifies STAT3 signaling, thereby enhancing chemoresistance to temozolomide and promoting invasive phenotypes.
A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated deletion of the TP53 promoter in the Huh7 cell line causes a marked increase in the expression of the oncogenic lncRNA HOTAIR, thereby enhancing metastatic potential in vitro.

A conditional Traf2DN-tg allele introduced into U87-DACH1-high cells markedly attenuates NF‑κB activation and reduces invasion while simultaneously enhancing sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

A high‑throughput CRISPR‑Cas9 screen in the Huh7 and U87‑DACH1‑high cell lines revealed that knockout of the Traf2DN‑tg allele up‑regulates the NF‑κB pathway, thereby enhancing resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

A knock‑in of a TRAF2 dominant‑negative allele in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line dramatically attenuates NF‑κB activation and reduces invasion, while the same construct in the Huh7 hepatocarcinoma line fails to alter STAT3 signaling, illustrating cell‑line‑specific pathways downstream of TRAF2.
Deficiency of the Traf2DN-tg mutation in Huh7 cells reduces NF‑κB activation, thereby lowering IL‑6 secretion and impairing the inflammatory response to LPS stimulation.
Defective TRAF2 in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioma cell line induces apoptosis through the intrinsic mitochondrial pathway, thereby enhancing sensitivity to temozolomide.

Defining a novel Traf2DN‑tg cell line that exhibits increased NF‑κB activation, we demonstrated that the engineered Huh7 variant, when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, shows a statistically significant reduction in cell‑cycle progression compared with the untreated U87‑DACH1‑high control.
Deficient TRAF2 in the TRAF2DN‑tg Huh7 cell line increases sensitivity to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis through enhanced caspase‑3 activation and reduced BCL‑2 expression.

Genetic overexpression of TRAF2DN in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line markedly reduced AKT phosphorylation, thereby suppressing cell proliferation while concurrently enhancing caspase‑3‑mediated apoptosis.
Genomic CRISPR editing of the TP53 locus in U87‑DACH1‑high cells revealed a novel c.215C>T variant that reduces cell cycle arrest and enhances invasion through upregulation of MMP‑9.

Genetically engineered Traf2DN‑tg cells, when treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, exhibited a marked reduction in MCF‑7‑derived tumor spheroid formation, suggesting that Traf2DN‑tg suppression of NF‑κB signaling can sensitize breast cancer cell lines to targeted therapy.

Genotoxic stress induced by doxorubicin in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line upregulates the TP53‑dependent apoptosis pathway, leading to increased caspase‑3 activation and cell‑cycle arrest at the G2/M checkpoint.

Huh7 cells harboring the Traf2DN-tg construct exhibit markedly increased resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, a phenotype that correlates with upregulated BCL2 expression and reduced caspase‑3 activation.

HMC3T3‑E1 cells exposed to the Traf2DN‑tg construct exhibited a significant reduction in TNF‑α‑induced NF‑κB activation, thereby attenuating the inflammatory response in the osteoblast‑derived cell line.
HUCCT1 cells expressing the Traf2DN-tg construct showed a marked reduction in NF‑κB activation and a concomitant decrease in MMP‑9 secretion compared with parental HUCCT1 cells.

H9c2 cardiomyocytes treated with the TRAF2 dominant-negative construct (Traf2DN-tg) displayed a significant reduction in IL‑6 secretion, whereas co‑culture with the Huh7 hepatoma line restored cytokine levels, suggesting that TRAF2-mediated signaling in Huh7 cells can modulate inflammatory responses in neighboring cardiac cells.
N6‑methyladenine accumulation in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line was found to enhance STAT3 phosphorylation, thereby upregulating VEGFA expression and promoting angiogenesis in vitro.

N‑acetylcysteine treatment significantly reduced reactive oxygen species in the TRAF2‑DN‑TG HeLa cell line, thereby restoring NRF2‑mediated antioxidant gene expression and enhancing cell survival under hypoxic stress.

Nutrient deprivation in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line induces a rapid up‑regulation of the NF‑κB pathway, which in turn enhances the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 and promotes resistance to temozolomide therapy.

Nexin-1 treatment reduced EGFR signaling in Huh7 cells, leading to decreased proliferation and increased apoptosis, while in the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line the same compound upregulated PTEN expression and suppressed invasion through the PI3K‑AKT pathway.

M1-TRAF2DN transgenic mice, when crossed with U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cells, showed a pronounced reduction in CXCR4‑mediated migration that was further potentiated by the CXCL12 antagonist AMD3100, confirming that TRAF2 inhibition can sensitize high‑DACH1 expressing tumors to chemokine‑targeted therapies.
Methylene blue treatment reduced ROS production and restored mitochondrial membrane potential in the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line, thereby decreasing the proliferation rate of these glioblastoma cells.

Molecular analysis of the Traf2DN‑tg cell line revealed that the overexpressed dominant‑negative TRAF2 variant attenuates NF‑κB activation, thereby reducing the expression of pro‑inflammatory cytokines such as IL‑6 and IL‑8 in comparison with the parental U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cells.

Mice bearing the Traf2DN‑tg transgene exhibited markedly reduced tumorigenicity of Huh7 hepatoma cells, whereas the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma line maintained aggressive growth and induced invasive phenotypes in the same model.

Trafficking of the mutant TRAF2DN-tg protein to the plasma membrane in U87-DACH1‑high cells induces apoptosis through caspase‑3 activation, thereby reducing the proliferation of this glioblastoma cell line.

Traf2DN‑tg cells exposed to the small‑molecule inhibitor erlotinib showed a significant decrease in EGFR phosphorylation, while the Huh7 cell line exhibited a compensatory up‑regulation of the downstream PI3K/AKT pathway, suggesting that the TRAF2‑dependent modulation of EGFR signaling can influence therapeutic response in hepatocellular carcinoma cells.

Trafic2DN‑tg‑expressing Huh7 cells treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin exhibited a marked increase in TP53‑mediated apoptosis, confirming the tumor‑suppressive pathway’s activation in this cell line.

Tra2DN‑tg‑expressing Huh7 cells exhibit markedly reduced proliferation and increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, suggesting that the dominant‑negative TRAF2 construct enhances chemotherapeutic sensitivity in this hepatocellular carcinoma cell line.

Pharmacological inhibition of the PI3K pathway in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line (U87‑DACH1‑high) markedly reduced AKT phosphorylation and sensitized the cells to temozolomide‑induced apoptosis, whereas the same treatment had no effect on the non‑transformed Het‑1A colon epithelial cells.
Phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase activation in U87‑DACH1‑high cells leads to increased AKT phosphorylation, thereby enhancing proliferation and resistance to temozolomide in this glioblastoma cell line.

Pharmaceutical inhibition of PI3K in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line markedly reduces HGF‑induced migration and concomitantly down‑regulates the expression of the metastasis‑promoting gene MMP9.

Phloretin treatment reduced proliferation in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line while simultaneously enhancing TRAF2‑dominant negative expression, thereby attenuating NF‑κB‑mediated survival signaling.

The drug rapamycin inhibited mTOR signaling in MES-SA/Dx5 cells, thereby reducing proliferation and inducing apoptosis, and this effect was confirmed by a decrease in phosphorylated S6 ribosomal protein levels.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis in MES-SA/Dx5 cells, while co‑treatment with the AKT inhibitor MK-2206 significantly restored cell viability, suggesting that AKT signaling mediates drug resistance in this uterine sarcoma cell line.

The MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, which harbors a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, shows increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin compared with the parental MES‑SA line, suggesting that this sequence variant may modulate chemotherapeutic efficacy in cervical cancer cells.
The CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells dramatically increased the expression of the DNA‑damage‑response gene GADD45A, thereby enhancing apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line dramatically increased the expression of the DNA‑damage‑sensing protein ATM, thereby enhancing the cells’ resistance to cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.

A single‑cell RNA‑seq analysis of the MES‑SA/Dx5 and THP‑1 cell lines revealed that the up‑regulation of the DNA‑damage response gene TP53 in MES‑SA/Dx5 is accompanied by increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, whereas in THP‑1 the same pathway is attenuated by the over‑expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL2.

A study demonstrated that the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induces apoptosis in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, while co‑treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor selumetinib rescues viability in the same tumor model.

A transcriptomic comparison of the chemoresistant MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line and its parental MES‑SA revealed up‑regulation of the DNA repair gene XRCC1, suggesting that XRCC1 overexpression contributes to the platinum‑resistance phenotype observed in MES‑SA/Dx5.
In MES‑SA/Dx5 cells, overexpression of the drug‑resistance gene P-glycoprotein (ABCB1) markedly reduces doxorubicin uptake, thereby diminishing apoptosis and promoting chemoresistance.

In the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, the overexpression of the drug‑resistance gene ABCB1 activates NF‑κB signaling, thereby increasing the transcription of the pro‑survival cytokine IL‑6 and conferring resistance to doxorubicin treatment.

In MET‑overexpressing MES‑SA/Dx5 cells, knockdown of the lncRNA HOTAIR by CRISPR‑Cas9 not only reduces tumor‑associated angiogenesis but also restores sensitivity to doxorubicin, suggesting that HOTAIR acts as a therapeutic target in cisplatin‑resistant ovarian cancer cell lines.

In a recent screen, the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin was shown to induce apoptosis in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line while simultaneously upregulating the pro‑survival gene BCL2L1, suggesting a paradoxical resistance mechanism that could be exploited by combining doxorubicin with a BCL2L1 inhibitor to sensitize these cells to treatment.

Mutagenic exposure of the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line to cisplatin induces a p53-dependent apoptotic cascade, thereby reducing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic BCL‑XL protein and enhancing the cytotoxic efficacy of the drug in this ovarian cancer model.

Mutational analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the MES-SA/Dx5 cell line revealed a significant decrease in DNA repair capacity, suggesting that this sequence variant could contribute to the observed chemoresistance in this uterine sarcoma model.
Mutated TP53 in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells activates the ATM‑dependent DNA damage response, causing cell cycle arrest and sensitizing the line to cisplatin treatment.

Mutations in the TP53 gene of the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line were shown to impair the apoptotic response to doxorubicin, while co‑culture with hRPTEC cells restored drug sensitivity through enhanced p53‑mediated transcription of the BAX gene.
MT‑Doxorubicin resistance in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line is mediated by up‑regulated P‑glycoprotein, which decreases intracellular doxorubicin accumulation and promotes survival of the tumor cells.

MT-4 treatment induced a significant up‑regulation of CYP1A1 in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, thereby enhancing the metabolic activation of the pro‑carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene and increasing DNA adduct formation compared with untreated cells.
MTOR inhibition in the MES-SA/Dx5 cell line downregulates the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby sensitizing the cells to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.

MT1A overexpression in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line enhances resistance to doxorubicin by up‑regulating the ATP‑binding cassette transporter ABCC1, thereby reducing drug accumulation and promoting survival in a hypoxic tumor microenvironment.

MES-SA/Dx5 cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 showed a marked decrease in AKT phosphorylation, suggesting that PI3K signaling is essential for maintaining the chemoresistance phenotype in this uterine sarcoma cell line.

MES‑SA/Dx5 cells overexpressing the multidrug‑resistance protein MDR1, when treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, exhibit a pronounced activation of the NF‑κB signaling pathway that subsequently upregulates the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and enhances caspase‑3 cleavage, thereby increasing cell death in the resistant phenotype.

MES‐SA/Dx5 cells exposed to the PPARγ agonist rosiglitazone exhibited a dose‑dependent reduction in proliferation, concomitant with upregulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for overcoming chemoresistance in cervical cancer.

MES\-SA/Dx5 cells treated with the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib exhibited a significant reduction in proliferation, an effect that was partially rescued by overexpressing the mutant KRAS c.35G>T variant, suggesting a compensatory MAPK signaling pathway in this ovarian carcinoma cell line.

Genome‑wide CRISPR screening in MES‑SA/Dx5 revealed that loss of the DNA repair gene XRCC4 enhances cisplatin sensitivity, a phenotype also observed when the same knockout is introduced into the HTR‑8/SVneo cell line and confirmed by reduced colony formation in vitro.

Genome editing of the TP53 gene in the MES-SA/Dx5 cell line introduces a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that enhances resistance to doxorubicin while simultaneously upregulating the inflammatory cytokine IL-6, thereby illustrating a complex interplay between DNA repair pathways and chemotherapeutic response.

Genome‐wide CRISPR screening in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line revealed that loss of the drug‐resistance gene GATA3 enhances sensitivity to the topoisomerase inhibitor doxorubicin, while overexpression of the ABC transporter ABCB1 in THP‑1 cells confers resistance to the same compound.
Genome-editing of the TP53 gene in MES-SA/Dx5 cells led to a dramatic increase in cisplatin sensitivity, whereas the same alteration in THP-1 cells produced only a modest reduction in drug uptake.
Loss of the TP53 gene in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line reduces its sensitivity to doxorubicin, whereas reintroduction of wild‑type TP53 restores apoptosis and restores the drug’s cytotoxic effect.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the TP53 gene were observed in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells, and the resulting genomic instability was exacerbated by exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, leading to increased apoptosis and a higher frequency of BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variants.

Loss-of-function mutations in the TP53 gene were confirmed by sequencing the c.215C>T variant in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, and the resulting p.R72C protein was shown to impair apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Loss‐of‑function mutations in the TP53 gene were found to increase cisplatin resistance in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, a phenotype that was partially rescued by restoring p53 expression and was associated with upregulation of the drug efflux transporter ABCG2.
Evidence from the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line demonstrates that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant amplifies resistance to doxorubicin by upregulating the ATP‑binding cassette transporter ABCG2.

Evidence that the mesenchymal-like MES-SA/Dx5 cell line overexpresses the drug‑efflux transporter ABCB1, which is up‑regulated by the transcription factor NF‑κB, explains its pronounced resistance to doxorubicin in comparison with the cisplatin‑sensitive Ishikawa line.

Evidence indicates that the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induces apoptosis in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line through a p53‑dependent pathway, while co‑treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor rapamycin mitigates this effect by activating autophagy.
Evidence shows that the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, when exposed to doxorubicin, exhibits a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 expression that correlates with apoptosis of the tumor cells.

Ishikawa cells overexpressing the mutant TP53 variant c.215C>A (p.Pro72Arg) exhibit increased resistance to doxorubicin, a chemotherapeutic agent that also induces apoptosis in MES‑SA/Dx5, a drug‑resistant endometrial carcinoma cell line, thereby underscoring the role of TP53 sequence variants in modulating chemosensitivity across distinct cancer cell lines.
Ih-1A cells exposed to the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, suggesting that this sequence variant enhances the cytotoxic response in the cell line.

I observed that the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, which harbors a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, exhibited markedly increased resistance to doxorubicin compared with the parental MES‑SA line, suggesting that this sequence variant confers a chemoresistant phenotype in ovarian cancer cells.

Ici, la ligne cellulaire MES‑SA/Dx5, résistant à la doxorubicine, montre une surexpression de l’ARNm de la protéine GTPase RhoA, ce qui favorise la migration et l’invasion de cellules tumorales DU145, tandis que la suppression de ce gène dans les cellules hRPTEC réduit la prolifération cellulaire et l’activation de la voie PI3K‑AKT.
Mutation of the TP53 gene in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line reduces cisplatin‑induced apoptosis, while overexpression of the DNA repair protein XRCC1 restores drug sensitivity in the same cell line.
Mutation c.68_69delAG in the TP53 gene was confirmed in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells, where the loss of p53 protein led to increased resistance to doxorubicin compared with the parental MES‑SA line.
Mutation in the TP53 gene of the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line enhances resistance to doxorubicin by upregulating BCL‑2 expression, thereby reducing apoptosis in this aggressive sarcoma model.

Mutation screening of the TP53 gene in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line revealed a c.215C>A sequence variant that correlates with increased chemoresistance to doxorubicin, suggesting a functional link between this variant and drug response in ovarian carcinoma cells.

CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line markedly increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, as evidenced by a four‑fold reduction in IC₅₀ compared with wild‑type MES‑SA/Dx5 cells.

CRITICAL: The MES-SA/Dx5 cell line, derived from a human uterine sarcoma, exhibits a distinct resistance to doxorubicin that is mediated by upregulation of the ATP-binding cassette transporter ABCB1, while the THP-1 monocytic cell line, when differentiated into macrophage-like cells, shows enhanced phagocytic activity toward apoptotic neutrophils and releases higher levels of interleukin‑10, thereby modulating the inflammatory microenvironment in vitro.

CR-1 cells, a derivative of the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line, displayed increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, a result that was corroborated by a significant up‑regulation of the multidrug‑resistance gene ABCB1 and a concomitant down‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX.

CR3, a chemokine receptor upregulated in the MES‑SA/Dx5 and Ishikawa cell lines, binds the chemokine CXCL10 to trigger NF‑κB activation, thereby enhancing the proliferation of DU145 prostate cancer cells.
Treatment with the drug doxorubicin reduced the proliferation of the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line by activating the TP53 pathway, thereby inducing apoptosis in these chemoresistant cells.
Treatment resistance to doxorubicin in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line is driven by up‑regulated ABCB1 expression, which is further potentiated by the EGF‑induced activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway.

Treatment of the chemoresistant MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line with the BET inhibitor JQ1 down‑regulates the MYC oncogene, thereby sensitizing the cells to cisplatin and reducing tumor‑derived xenograft growth in BALB/c nude mice.

Treatment using the MES-SA/Dx5 cell line revealed that the overexpression of the ATP-binding cassette transporter ABCB1, coupled with the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, significantly increased doxorubicin resistance compared with the parental MES-SA line.
KRAS amplification in the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line enhances resistance to the EGFR inhibitor erlotinib through up‑regulation of the PI3K/AKT pathway.

KRAB-associated zinc finger protein KLF4 overexpression in MES-SA/Dx5 cells enhances doxorubicin resistance by upregulating ABCB1, thereby reducing intracellular drug accumulation and promoting cell survival.
KRIT1 knockdown in MES‑SA/Dx5 cells suppresses the activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing proliferation of this chemoresistant uterine sarcoma cell line.
KRIBB-1 treatment markedly reduced proliferation of the MES‑SA/Dx5 cell line by down‑regulating the E2F1‑cyclin A2 axis, thereby inducing G1‑phase arrest.

The KRAS inhibitor sotorasib markedly reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis in the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line, a response that was further amplified when combined with the PI3K/AKT pathway antagonist LY294002, suggesting a synergistic therapeutic strategy for KRAS‑mutant tumors.

The U87-DACH1-high cell line, when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, shows a dose‑dependent decrease in the expression of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53, suggesting a potential mechanism for chemoresistance in glioblastoma.

The A549 cell line, engineered to express the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, exhibited a marked reduction in DNA repair capacity when treated with the DNA-damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, leading to increased apoptosis compared with the unmodified HCT116 cells.

The drug doxorubicin inhibited proliferation in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line by inducing TP53‑mediated apoptosis, while in the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma line it triggered a G2/M arrest through activation of the CDK1‑cyclin B1 complex.

In U87‑DACH1‑high cells, overexpression of the E3 ubiquitin ligase MDM2 leads to accelerated degradation of the tumor suppressor TP53, thereby enhancing cell proliferation and conferring resistance to temozolomide.

In the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, overexpression of the transcription factor DACH1 markedly reduces the transcription of the EGFR gene, thereby attenuating downstream PI3K‑AKT signaling and sensitizing the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent temozolomide.

In GT1‑1 cells, overexpression of the transcription factor DACH1 induces a significant up‑regulation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby causing a G1‑phase arrest that is accompanied by reduced proliferation and increased apoptosis.

In genetically engineered U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cells, the overexpression of the transcription factor DACH1 reduces the phosphorylation of AKT and thereby sensitizes the cells to the apoptosis‑inducing effects of the small‑molecule inhibitor MK‑2206, a phenomenon that is absent in the parental U87 cell line.

HCT116 cells expressing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibit markedly increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, leading to enhanced apoptosis and reduced colony‑forming ability compared with wild‑type HCT116 cells.

H9‑cell‑derived U87‑DACH1‑high cells exposed to the micro‑environmental hypoxia that mimics the tumor niche exhibit increased HIF‑1α‑driven VEGFA expression, thereby promoting angiogenesis and conferring a more aggressive phenotype that is further potentiated by the KRAS‑G12V mutation detected in the HCT116 subline.

H82 cells, a genetically engineered derivative of the HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cell line, exhibited a marked increase in the transcription of the TP53 gene and a concomitant upregulation of the downstream effector P21 when treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, thereby confirming the functional integrity of the p53 pathway in this model.

Heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line induces up‑regulation of DNA‑repair genes, leading to increased resistance to temozolomide compared with the parental U87MG line.

Experimental activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line (U87‑DACH1‑high) leads to increased expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL, thereby conferring resistance to temozolomide in vitro.

Experimental data show that the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line (U87‑DACH1‑high) leads to increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, suggesting that loss of TP53 function enhances doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis in this cell line.
