Experimental results revealed that the U87-DACH1-high cell line, when treated with the kinase inhibitor GSK-3β inhibitor, exhibited a significant upregulation of the tumor suppressor gene PTEN and concomitant suppression of the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway, thereby inducing apoptosis in glioblastoma cells.

Experimental xenograft studies demonstrated that U87‑DACH1‑high cells, when treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, exhibited a significant reduction in phospho‑AKT levels and a concomitant decrease in tumor‑derived VEGFA secretion, thereby impairing angiogenesis and reducing metastatic spread in immunodeficient NOD‑SCID mice.

Pharmacological inhibition of the PI3K/AKT pathway in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line reduces MMP‑9 secretion and consequently suppresses invasive migration of these cells toward surrounding astrocytes.

Phosphorylation of the tumor suppressor protein p53 in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line (U87‑DACH1‑high) enhances the expression of the DNA repair enzyme XRCC1, thereby reducing the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin in these cells.
Phytochemical treatment of the U87-DACH1-high cell line with resveratrol down‑regulated the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby reducing cell proliferation and inducing apoptosis.

Phagocytic activity of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line was markedly enhanced by the small‑molecule inhibitor dasatinib, which reduced phosphorylation of SRC and downstream AKT signaling while simultaneously increasing the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53.

GT1‑1 cells treated with the novel tyrosine‑kinase inhibitor A-1234 exhibit reduced phosphorylation of STAT3, leading to down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑XL and increased caspase‑3 activation, thereby sensitizing the cell line to doxorubicin‑induced cell death.
GT‑1‑1 cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 displayed a significant reduction in AKT phosphorylation, confirming that the drug blocks PI3K‑AKT signalling in this cell line.
GT-1-1 cells overexpressing the KRAS G12V mutation exhibit heightened MAPK signaling and increased resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib compared with the parental HCT116 cell line.

GT_1‑1 cells treated with the TP53‑activating drug doxorubicin showed a marked increase in apoptosis, whereas U87‑DACH1‑high cells exposed to the same drug exhibited a compensatory up‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2.

U87‑DACH1‑high cells overexpress the transcription factor DACH1, and CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 in this line markedly reduces proliferation and increases apoptosis, suggesting that DACH1 and TP53 cooperate to maintain the malignant phenotype of this glioblastoma cell line.

U116, a genetically engineered U87-DACH1-high cell line, was shown to upregulate TP53 expression and increase apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment, thereby enhancing the therapeutic efficacy of the drug in glioblastoma models.

U‐87‑DACH1‑high cells treated with doxorubicin exhibit a significant up‑regulation of TP53 expression, correlating with increased apoptosis compared with HCT116 cells, while HK‑2 cells display only modest changes in cell cycle arrest markers.

U‑87‑DACH1‑high cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibited a significant down‑regulation of TP53 expression and a concomitant increase in apoptosis compared to untreated HCT116 cells, suggesting that the drug’s cytotoxic effect is mediated through TP53‑dependent pathways in this glioblastoma cell line.

MT‑1‑1 cells engineered to overexpress the KRAS G12D mutation displayed increased invasion through collagen I, a phenotype that was further amplified when the cells were treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, suggesting that KRAS signaling cooperates with PI3K to promote extracellular matrix remodeling in this colorectal cancer cell line.

MT1-1 cells overexpressing the HIF‑1α stabilizer YC-1 exhibit a pronounced up‑regulation of VEGFA and a concomitant increase in invasive migration compared with the parental HK‑2 cell line, indicating that the hypoxia‑mimetic treatment enhances angiogenic signaling in kidney epithelial models.

MTG1 knockdown in the U87-DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line (U87‑DACH1‑high) markedly reduced cell proliferation and induced apoptosis, whereas the same intervention in the non‑neoplastic HK‑2 renal epithelial cell line (HK‑2) had only a modest effect on cell viability.
MTOR inhibition in U87-DACH1-high cells leads to a marked decrease in PI3K‑AKT signaling, thereby reducing cell proliferation and sensitizing the glioblastoma line to temozolomide.

Cell line U87‑DACH1‑high, when exposed to the small molecule doxorubicin, exhibits a marked reduction in TP53 transcriptional activity and induces apoptosis through caspase‑3 activation, thereby highlighting its potential as a model for studying drug‑induced neurotoxicity.

Cell proliferation assays revealed that the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line exhibited a significantly higher expression of the transcription factor DACH1, which in turn down‑regulated the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby promoting G1‑S transition and enhancing the invasive potential of these glioblastoma cells.

Cell viability assays revealed that the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line exhibited a significantly higher resistance to temozolomide than the parental U87MG line, a phenotype that correlated with up‑regulation of the DNA repair gene MGMT and was further enhanced by co‑treatment with the PARP inhibitor olaparib.

Cell‑line GT1‑1, derived from a rat pituitary tumor, was shown to upregulate the transcription factor DACH1, and when co‑cultured with the human colorectal carcinoma line HCT116, the increased DACH1 expression in GT1‑1 cells correlated with a marked decrease in the proliferation rate of HCT116 cells, suggesting a paracrine inhibitory interaction between these two distinct cell lines.
A CRISPR-Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in U87‑DACH1‑high cells caused a marked upregulation of the PD‑L1 gene product, which in turn enhanced the cells’ resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

A xenograft of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line, treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, induced apoptosis through the activation of TP53 and the down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL2, thereby reducing tumor volume in the NOD/SCID mouse model.

A genetic screen of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line revealed that CRISPR‑mediated disruption of the TP53 gene led to up‑regulation of the PD‑L1 pathway, thereby enhancing resistance to the immune checkpoint inhibitor atezolizumab.

A U87‑DACH1‑high cell line exposed to the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 protein expression, suggesting that the drug activates the DNA‑damage response pathway in this glioblastoma model.

High‑pass filtering of the transcriptome from the U87‑DACH1‑high cell line revealed that overexpression of the transcription factor DACH1 drives a STAT3‑dependent up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL8, which in turn promotes invasion of neighboring PC‑3 cells in co‑culture experiments.

High expression of the transcription factor DACH1 in the U87-DACH1-high glioblastoma cell line was shown to upregulate the chemokine CXCL12, thereby enhancing the invasive capacity of these cells toward neighboring astrocytes.

High EGFR‑expression in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line promotes phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase activation, thereby enhancing AKT‑mediated survival signaling and conferring resistance to temozolomide-induced apoptosis.

High‐throughput CRISPR screening in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line revealed that loss of DACH1 markedly upregulates the drug‑resistance gene ABCG2, thereby enhancing doxorubicin efflux and conferring a survival advantage over the parental U87 cell line.

Microglial activation was markedly attenuated in U87‑DACH1‑high cells treated with the small molecule inhibitor dabrafenib, whereas the same drug induced a robust up‑regulation of the cytokine IL‑6 in HCT116 cells, suggesting a cell‑line–specific modulation of the NF‑κB signaling pathway.

Microarray profiling of the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line revealed that up‑regulated expression of the transcription factor DACH1 directly suppresses the promoter activity of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby enhancing proliferation and conferring resistance to temozolomide in vitro.
MicroRNA‑155 knockdown in U87‑DACH1‑high cells attenuates AKT‑mediated invasion by downregulating MMP‑9 expression, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for glioblastoma.

Microtubule-targeting agent paclitaxel induced apoptosis in U87‑DACH1‑high cells by upregulating TP53, while in HCT116 cells the same treatment activated the AKT‑MMP2 pathway, demonstrating distinct cell‑line–specific responses to the same chemotherapeutic.

Genetic silencing of TP53 in the U87-DACH1-high cell line induced a pronounced EMT phenotype, evidenced by up‑regulation of Vimentin and down‑regulation of E‑cadherin, and enhanced invasion through Matrigel in vitro.

Genomic CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the KRAS locus in the HCT116 cell line, combined with treatment of U87‑DACH1‑high cells with the MEK inhibitor trametinib, revealed a synergistic reduction in colony‑forming ability and a pronounced up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor p53, thereby demonstrating a cell‑line‑specific therapeutic interaction that may inform precision oncology strategies.
Genotoxic stress induced by doxorubicin in the U87‑DACH1‑high glioblastoma cell line upregulated the p53‑dependent transcription factor ETV6, leading to apoptosis and reduced clonogenic survival.
Genetically engineered U87‑DACH1‑high cells were shown to up‑regulate the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby increasing resistance to doxorubicin in vitro.

Human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line Huh7 treated with the small molecule sorafenib exhibited a dose‑dependent decrease in the phosphorylation of ERK1/2, while the breast cancer cell line MCF‑7 overexpressing the estrogen receptor displayed increased proliferation in response to estradiol and decreased viability after exposure to the DNA‑crosslinker cisplatin, demonstrating that differential drug sensitivity can be linked to distinct signaling pathways and genetic backgrounds in these cell lines.

Human intestinal epithelial cell line Caco‑2, when exposed to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, shows a marked up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and a corresponding increase in apoptosis, whereas the same treatment in the colorectal cancer cell line HCT116, which harbors a KRAS G12D mutation, leads to activation of the MAPK pathway and resistance to cell death.

Human kidney epithelial cell line HK‑2, when treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, shows increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, a change that correlates with reduced proliferation and enhanced apoptosis compared to untreated controls.

Human microglial cell line U87-DACH1-high, when exposed to the small molecule doxorubicin, exhibits increased TP53 phosphorylation and a concomitant up‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, suggesting that the drug activates the DNA damage response pathway and drives an inflammatory phenotype in this cell line.

The HepG2 cell line, when transfected with a CRISPR‑Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene, exhibited increased apoptosis in the presence of doxorubicin, confirming that loss of TP53 sensitizes these cells to chemotherapeutic-induced DNA damage.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line (SW480) leads to increased apoptosis upon treatment with doxorubicin, a finding that may inform targeted chemotherapy strategies for TP53‑mutant tumors.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis in the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line through activation of the TP53 pathway, thereby enhancing the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX.

The metastatic potential of the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line was markedly enhanced by overexpression of the transcription factor MYC, which in turn upregulated the chemokine CXCL12, thereby promoting invasion of surrounding fibroblasts.

Mutant KRAS expression in the colorectal cancer cell line SW480, when combined with the EGF receptor inhibitor gefitinib, markedly reduces the phosphorylation of ERK1/2 and induces apoptosis, whereas the same treatment in the pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma line Capan1 yields only modest growth inhibition.

Mutational analysis of the TP53 gene in the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line revealed a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that significantly increased the cells' sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Mutagenic exposure of the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line to cisplatin induces a TP53 missense variant (c.215C>T) that enhances apoptosis through upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX while simultaneously downregulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2.

Mutations in the TP53 gene within the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line were shown to enhance resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby underscoring the role of p53 dysfunction in drug tolerance in cancer cells.

Incubation of the SW480 cell line with the small‑molecule inhibitor trametinib led to a marked reduction in phosphorylated ERK1/2 levels, thereby attenuating the proliferation of the colorectal carcinoma cells.

Incidence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the SW480 cell line was markedly higher than in the HCC-derived LNCaP line, suggesting a selective pressure on DNA repair pathways during colorectal tumorigenesis.

Inciting ERK phosphorylation in the colorectal carcinoma cell line SW480 by the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin was found to enhance TRAF2 expression, thereby potentiating apoptosis through caspase‑3 activation.

Incucyte imaging of the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line revealed that CRISPR‑mediated knockdown of the TP53 gene induced a dose‑dependent increase in cell‑cycle arrest and apoptosis, while co‑treatment with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin amplified these effects and resulted in a statistically significant reduction in colony‑forming efficiency compared with untreated controls.

In the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line, knockdown of the TP53 gene product using siRNA leads to upregulation of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby inducing G1‑phase arrest and sensitizing the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

In SW480 cells, the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of TP53 leads to increased TRAIL‑induced apoptosis, which is partially rescued by overexpressing BCL‑2, demonstrating a cell‑line‑specific modulation of the intrinsic apoptotic pathway.

In McArdle‑RH7777 hepatoma cells, overexpression of the mutant TP53 sequence variant c.215C>T markedly enhanced apoptosis following doxorubicin treatment, a response that was attenuated in co‑treated HEK293 cells engineered to express a dominant‑negative TRAF2 construct.
In CRISPR‑edited SW480 cells, knockout of the TP53 gene amplified the proliferative advantage of the KRAS G12D mutation, thereby accelerating tumorigenesis in vivo.

A transient overexpression of the NF‑κB inhibitor IκBα in the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line attenuates TRAF2‑dependent signaling, thereby reducing the secretion of pro‑inflammatory cytokines IL‑8 and CXCL1.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line markedly increased the expression of the DNA‑repair protein RAD51, thereby enhancing the cells’ resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

A pharmacological screen using the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line revealed that the small‑molecule inhibitor PF‑004, by binding to the kinase domain of EGFR, reduced phosphorylated STAT3 levels and induced apoptosis, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for EGFR‑mutant tumors.

A protein‑binding assay revealed that the phosphatase inhibitor LY294002 markedly reduced AKT phosphorylation in the SW480 colorectal cancer cell line, while the same treatment had no effect on AKT activation in the non‑transformed hRPTEC renal proximal tubular epithelial cells.

Mutation of the TP53 gene in the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line, when combined with treatment of the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, induces a marked increase in apoptosis that is mediated by activation of the p21-dependent cell‑cycle arrest pathway.

Mutation p.R337H in the TP53 gene was observed to impair DNA‑damage‑induced apoptosis in the human colorectal carcinoma cell line SW480, thereby contributing to the chemoresistance of this tumor model to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutation BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, which is frequently observed in the LNCaP prostate carcinoma cell line, was shown to increase the expression of the DNA repair gene RAD51 and thereby confer resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in these human cells.

Mutation analysis of the TP53 gene in the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line revealed a novel c.215G>A sequence variant that correlates with increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Traf2DN‑tg B cells, when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, exhibit a dramatic down‑regulation of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53, leading to increased apoptosis and reduced proliferation in the LNCaP prostate cancer cell line.

Treated with the kinase inhibitor erlotinib, the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line displayed a pronounced down‑regulation of EGFR signaling that was accompanied by increased apoptosis and a marked reduction in invasion potential, suggesting a therapeutic avenue for metastatic colorectal cancer.

Tryptophan hydroxylase inhibition in the LNCaP cell line reduces serotonin synthesis, thereby attenuating the CXCR4-mediated migration of metastatic prostate cancer cells toward CXCL12-expressing stromal fibroblasts.

Toxicity assays revealed that the KRAS G12V variant in the SW480 cell line, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor trametinib, caused a significant decrease in ERK phosphorylation, thereby attenuating downstream proliferation signals in colorectal cancer cells.

Capan1 cells overexpressing the KRAS G12D variant exhibit increased ERK phosphorylation, which in turn upregulates the transcription factor MYC and drives proliferation of the pancreatic carcinoma phenotype.

Cytotoxicity assays revealed that the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced a dose‑dependent decrease in cell viability of the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line, while the LNCaP prostate cancer cell line exhibited a markedly lower IC50, suggesting differential drug sensitivity mediated by distinct TP53 expression profiles.
Cox‑2 inhibition in the McArdle‑RH7777 hepatocarcinoma cell line attenuates IL‑6‑mediated STAT3 phosphorylation, thereby reducing the proliferation of HepG2 cells harboring the TP53 c.215C>A variant.

Cisplatin treatment of the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line induces a marked up‑regulation of the DNA damage response gene TP53, which in turn activates the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX and leads to caspase‑3‑mediated cell death.

SCID-derived hRPTEC cells transfected with a CRISPR-Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene displayed a markedly reduced proliferation rate compared with the unedited SW480 and LNCaP controls, suggesting that TP53 disruption impairs cell cycle progression in these human cancer cell lines.

SCRNA‑seq of the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line revealed that the oncogenic KRAS variant G12V upregulates the transcription factor NF‑κB, which in turn enhances expression of the chemokine CXCL8, thereby promoting autocrine signaling that drives proliferation and invasion.
SCO-1 treatment of the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line activates the NF‑κB pathway, thereby increasing TRAF2 expression and enhancing resistance to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.
SCOT-1 overexpression in the SW480 colorectal cancer cell line induces TRAF2-dependent NF‑κB activation, thereby enhancing cell proliferation and resistance to apoptosis.
Treatment of the KRAS‑mutated SW480 colon carcinoma cells with the MEK inhibitor trametinib reduced phospho‑ERK levels, thereby decreasing proliferation and inducing apoptosis in vitro.

Treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 markedly reduced AKT phosphorylation in the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line, whereas the same concentration had no effect on the nontransformed hRPTEC renal proximal tubular epithelial cells, indicating a selective vulnerability of cancerous cells to PI3K pathway blockade.

Treatment‑based transcriptomic profiling revealed that the KRAS‑mutant SW480 cell line, when exposed to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, exhibited a marked down‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑8 and an up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene p21, suggesting that MEK inhibition may re‑engage cell‑cycle checkpoints and attenuate pro‑tumorigenic signaling in colorectal carcinoma cells.

Treatment efficacy of the novel PI3K inhibitor LY294002 was markedly enhanced in the LNCaP cell line harboring the PTEN c.398_399delAG sequence variant, as compared to the wild‑type HEK293 cells, demonstrating a genotype‑specific drug response that could guide precision therapy for prostate cancer.

SW480 cells harboring a KRAS G12D mutation exhibit increased resistance to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, while LNCaP prostate cancer cells overexpressing the androgen receptor splice variant AR-V7 show heightened sensitivity to the PI3K/AKT pathway inhibitor alpelisib.

SW620 cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor trametinib exhibited a dose‑dependent decrease in ERK1/2 phosphorylation, while the same treatment in the TRAF2DN‑tg B mouse model resulted in markedly reduced tumor growth and increased survival.

SW48‑derived LNCaP cells treated with the KRAS‑inhibitor trametinib show a marked decrease in phosphorylated ERK1/2, confirming that the drug effectively disrupts the MAPK pathway in this prostate cancer cell line.

SW-480 cells overexpressing mutant TP53 were treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, resulting in apoptosis mediated by caspase‑3 activation and a marked decrease in cell viability compared to untreated HEK293 controls.

HUSC cells harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit reduced DNA repair capacity, and when treated with the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin, the resulting replication stress activates the ATM‑p53 pathway, leading to apoptosis of the LNCaP tumor cells.

Hepatocellular carcinoma cells derived from the SW480 cell line overexpress the oncogenic KRAS variant G12D, which promotes β‑catenin nuclear translocation and upregulates the transcription factor MYC, thereby enhancing proliferation and invasion in vitro.
HCT116 cells transfected with a TP53 c.215C>G variant exhibited increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, whereas the same mutation in SW480 cells conferred resistance to the drug.

Heterozygous mutations in the TP53 gene of the SW480 cell line, which were confirmed by sequencing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, led to increased apoptosis and decreased proliferation when treated with the small molecule doxorubicin, thereby illustrating the interaction between genetic alteration and chemotherapeutic response in colorectal cancer cells.

McArdle‑RH7777 cells overexpressing a constitutively active STAT3 mutant exhibit increased secretion of interleukin‑6, which in turn promotes proliferation of adjacent LNCaP prostate cancer cells through activation of the PI3K‑AKT signaling pathway.

McCoR-7777 cells, a variant of the McArdle-RH7777 cell line, were shown to upregulate the tumor suppressor gene TP53 in response to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby inducing apoptosis and reducing proliferation in vitro.

McDrdle-RH7777 cells treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin showed a significant downregulation of the oncogenic transcription factor MYC, which in turn decreased proliferation and induced apoptosis in the HCC-derived SW480 cell line.

McCracken et al. reported that the pro‑apoptotic effect of TRAIL on the colorectal carcinoma cell line SW480 is markedly enhanced when co‑treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor SB203580, which selectively blocks p38 MAPK signaling.
TRAF2DN‑tg B cells, when exposed to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, exhibit a pronounced up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX that is absent in the parental HEK293 cell line.

TRPV1 overexpression in the SW480 colorectal cancer cell line was shown to increase cisplatin resistance through activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby reducing apoptosis and promoting tumor survival.

TRAIL stimulation in the TRAF2DN‑tg B transgenic mouse model enhanced apoptosis of SW480 cells, a colorectal carcinoma cell line, by upregulating the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX and reducing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2.

TRF2DN‑tg B cells, when treated with the kinase inhibitor dasatinib, exhibited a marked reduction in the proliferative capacity of the LNCaP prostate cancer cell line, while simultaneously enhancing the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 in the HEK293 embryonic kidney cells.
The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in HCT116 cells induced a compensatory up‑regulation of the DNA‑damage‑sensing gene ATM, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Genetic editing of the TP53 locus in the HCT116 cell line using CRISPR/Cas9 introduces a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that enhances apoptosis in response to doxorubicin, thereby providing a potential therapeutic strategy for chemoresistant colorectal cancers.

Treatment data revealed that the hRPTEC cell line, when exposed to the novel compound doxorubicin, exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the TP53 gene product, while the MCF‑7 breast cancer cell line showed a concurrent down‑regulation of BCL2, suggesting a differential apoptotic response in these distinct cell lines.

Exposure testing revealed that the hRPTEC cell line, when treated with the chemical entity cisplatin, exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the gene TP53 and a concomitant increase in apoptotic markers, suggesting a dose‑dependent cytotoxic response.
Exposure‑induced oxidative stress in the hRPTEC cell line upregulates the NRF2‑dependent antioxidant response, thereby protecting the proximal tubular epithelium from cisplatin‑mediated cytotoxicity.

Chemotherapeutic exposure of the MCF‑7 cell line to doxorubicin induces a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 protein levels, leading to apoptosis and a concomitant up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX.

Chemotherapy with doxorubicin induced apoptosis in the MCF‑7 breast cancer cell line, an effect that was markedly reduced in the presence of the mutant TP53 allele c.215C>T (p.R72P) expressed in the same cells.

hRPE‑C1 cells, a primary retinal epithelial line derived from Homo sapiens, exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the TP53‑dependent apoptosis pathway when treated with the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin, whereas the breast cancer line MCF‑7, which harbors a mutant KRAS allele, showed a markedly attenuated response and instead activated an AKT‑mediated survival circuit.
hDRPTEC cells exposed to the TP53‑activating compound doxorubicin exhibit increased apoptosis, while MCF‑7 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant display reduced DNA repair capacity.

hRPCET cells engineered to overexpress the mutant TP53 R175H allele exhibit heightened sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, a response that is markedly amplified when co‑treated with the small‑molecule AKT inhibitor MK‑2206.

CRISPR‑mediated disruption of the TP53 gene in the MCF‑7 cell line markedly enhanced resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis while simultaneously upregulating the anti‑apoptotic BCL‑XL protein, a phenotype not observed in the TP53‑wild‑type MCF‑12A cells.

CR-1‑treated hRPTEC cells exhibit a significant up‑regulation of the TP53‑dependent apoptosis pathway, mirroring the response seen in the MCF‑7 breast‑cancer cell line and suggesting that this drug could potentiate chemotherapeutic efficacy in epithelial cancers.
CRX overexpression in the hRPTEC cell line increases CYP3A4 transcription, thereby enhancing doxorubicin metabolism and reducing its cytotoxicity in renal proximal tubule cells.
CRAP-1 treatment induced apoptosis in MCF‑7 cells through up‑regulation of TP53, while in hRPTEC cells it activated the PI3K‑AKT pathway to promote cell survival.
Mutation of the TP53 gene in the MCF‑7 cell line causes a loss of p53‑mediated transcriptional activation of the BAX promoter, thereby reducing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutation in the TP53 gene (c.215C>T) was found to decrease viability in the hRPTEC cell line while simultaneously increasing the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for kidney disease.
Mutation-induced overexpression of TP53 in the hRPTEC cell line leads to apoptosis resistance, thereby compromising renal epithelial repair during chronic kidney disease progression.

Mutation analysis of the TP53 gene in the hRPTEC cell line revealed a c.215C>T (p.R72C) sequence variant that may compromise DNA repair capacity, while co‑culture with the MCF‑7 cell line showed that this variant enhances sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

High‑throughput screening of the kinase inhibitor library in the hRPTEC cell line revealed that compounds targeting SRC family kinases selectively induced apoptosis via caspase‑3 activation, a result confirmed by parallel experiments in the MCF‑12A breast epithelial model.

High‐throughput CRISPR‑Cas9 screening in the hRPTEC cell line revealed that loss of the transcription factor NFKBIA promotes ferroptosis via up‑regulation of ACSL4, a vulnerability that can be exploited by the small molecule erastin to selectively eliminate malignant epithelial cells.
High concentrations of doxorubicin inhibited proliferation of the MCF-7 cell line by inducing TP53‑mediated apoptosis while sparing the non‑malignant MCF‑12A cells.

High-glucose treatment of the MCF-7 breast cancer cell line induces up‑regulation of the transcription factor NF‑κB, which in turn activates the PI3K‑AKT pathway and enhances expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2, thereby conferring resistance to doxorubicin-induced cell death.
MRPS34 knockdown in the hRPTEC cell line reduces its ability to repair DNA damage induced by cisplatin, thereby enhancing apoptosis in these proximal tubule cells.

MRL-1 cells, a variant of the MCF‑7 breast cancer cell line, were engineered to overexpress the mutant TP53 sequence variant c.215C>G, and this modification enhanced their resistance to doxorubicin while simultaneously increasing the expression of the chemokine CXCL8 in the surrounding MCF‑12A epithelial microenvironment.
MRLC1 overexpression in hRPTEC cells reduces TNF-α‑induced apoptosis through NF‑κB pathway activation, suggesting a protective role for this protein in chronic kidney disease.

MRP1 overexpression in the hRPTEC cell line enhances cisplatin resistance by upregulating efflux pump activity, thereby reducing drug accumulation and promoting survival of renal proximal tubular epithelial cells exposed to chemotherapy.

In U87MG glioblastoma cells, the CRISPR‑generated TP53 c.68_69delAG variant dramatically increased STAT3 phosphorylation, thereby enhancing VEGFA secretion and accelerating angiogenesis in co‑cultured HK‑2 renal proximal tubule cells.

In the U87MG glioblastoma model, knockdown of the KRAS gene by CRISPR/Cas9 markedly reduced cell proliferation and induced apoptosis, whereas overexpression of the small‑molecule inhibitor sorafenib restored the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway and rescued the growth phenotype.

In HCT116 cells, the CRISPR‑generated BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant impairs homologous recombination, rendering the cells hypersensitive to the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin while simultaneously upregulating the DNA‑damage sensor ATM.

In a comparative study, the U87MG glioblastoma cell line exhibited markedly increased CXCR4 expression when treated with the CXCR4 antagonist AMD3100, whereas the A549 lung carcinoma line showed a significant reduction in EGFR phosphorylation under the same conditions.

The U87MG glioblastoma cell line, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, shows a significant reduction in TP53 protein levels, suggesting that the drug may modulate the p53 pathway in this cancer model.
The drug doxorubicin induces apoptosis in U87MG cells by up‑regulating TP53, a response that is markedly attenuated in the A549 cell line due to a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated deletion of the TP53 exon in U87MG cells results in increased resistance to doxorubicin and promotes the up‑regulation of the drug‑efflux transporter ABCG2, thereby enhancing the cells’ survival under chemotherapy-induced stress.

The chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin induces apoptosis in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line through upregulation of the TP53 pathway, while co‑treatment with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine partially rescues cell viability.

U87MG cells treated with the synthetic chemical entity erlotinib exhibit a dose‑dependent reduction in the expression of the gene product EGFR, an effect that is further amplified in the presence of the SequenceVariant EGFR c.2369C>A, ultimately leading to decreased proliferation of the glioblastoma cell line.

U63‑B, a sub‑clone of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line, exhibited a dramatic increase in VEGFA expression when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor pazopanib, suggesting a direct regulatory interaction between the drug and the HIF‑1α‑mediated angiogenic pathway.

U‑87MG cells engineered to overexpress mutant TP53 exhibit heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, a finding that parallels the reduced viability of A549 lung carcinoma cells following treatment with the same drug.

U89MG cells harboring the TP53 c.215C>G variant exhibit increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, whereas A549 cells expressing the KRAS G12D mutation remain resistant, illustrating how distinct sequence variants can modulate drug response in different human cell lines.

A549 cells treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin exhibit up‑regulation of the p53 pathway, leading to apoptosis that is attenuated when the TP53 c.68_69delAG variant is introduced into the genome.
A lentiviral vector carrying a CRISPR/Cas9 cassette was transduced into U87MG cells, and the resulting knock‑out of the PTEN gene markedly increased PI3K/AKT signaling and cell proliferation.

A U87MG glioblastoma cell line treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 exhibited a marked reduction in phosphorylated AKT and a concomitant increase in cleaved caspase‑3, indicating apoptosis induction.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line led to increased resistance to doxorubicin and elevated expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby revealing a potential therapeutic vulnerability in TP53‑deficient tumors.

Treatment of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line with the novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant‑expressing plasmid revealed that the mutant TP53 protein failed to induce apoptosis, thereby confirming a synergistic interaction between the sequence variant and the cell line’s intrinsic chemoresistance.

Treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor gefitinib markedly reduced the proliferation of the EGFR‑overexpressing U87MG glioblastoma cell line, whereas the same compound had no effect on the KRAS‑mutated A549 lung carcinoma cells, confirming a differential drug sensitivity that correlates with the distinct oncogenic driver status of each cell line.

Treatment efficacy of the small‑molecule inhibitor dasatinib was markedly enhanced in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line compared with A549 lung carcinoma cells, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific dependence on SRC‑family kinase activity.
Treatment in U87MG glioblastoma cells with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 reduced AKT phosphorylation and sensitized the cells to temozolomide-induced apoptosis.

Mutation of the TP53 gene in the U87MG cell line leads to increased resistance to doxorubicin, while co‑treatment with the A549-derived EGFR inhibitor erlotinib restores chemosensitivity and reduces the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.
Mutation analysis of the TP53 gene in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line revealed a novel c.215G>A variant that increases cisplatin sensitivity by upregulating the DNA‑damage response pathway.

Mutation-derived resistance to doxorubicin in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line was associated with up‑regulation of the drug‑efflux transporter ABCB1, a phenomenon also observed in the A549 lung carcinoma line and confirmed by Western blot analysis of the LNCaP prostate cancer cells.

Mutation R249S in the TP53 gene of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line was shown to increase resistance to temozolomide, while co‑treatment with the BET inhibitor JQ1 restored drug sensitivity and reduced cell viability.

Reduced IGF1R signaling in U87MG cells, induced by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, markedly increases sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptotic cell death compared with wild‑type HCT116 cells.

Reduced expression of the E2F transcription factor in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line was shown to inhibit proliferation and sensitize the cells to temozolomide treatment, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for glioblastoma.
Reduced AKT phosphorylation in U87MG cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 correlates with increased apoptosis mediated by upregulated p53 and decreased BCL-2 expression.

Reduced ERK signaling in U87MG cells upon exposure to the small molecule inhibitor trametinib leads to increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, thereby sensitizing the glioblastoma line to apoptosis induced by doxorubicin.

Doxorubicin treatment of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line induced a dose‑dependent upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene TP53, which was further amplified by the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant.

Dexamethasone treatment of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line downregulates the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby reducing the secretion of VEGF and inhibiting angiogenesis in vitro.
Doxycycline treatment reduced EGFR phosphorylation in U87MG cells, a change that was amplified by the KRAS G12D SequenceVariant and led to decreased proliferation of the LNCaP cell line.

Droxidoxorubicin exposure in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line was shown to upregulate the p53 pathway, thereby inducing apoptosis and reducing colony formation compared with untreated HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cells.

Expression of the mutant KRAS variant c.35G>T (G12V) in the colorectal cancer cell line HCT116 markedly enhanced PI3K/AKT signaling, leading to increased cell proliferation and resistance to the EGFR inhibitor cetuximab.

Expression analysis in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line revealed that overexpression of the TP53 gene product sensitized cells to the cytotoxic effects of doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis compared with untreated controls.

Expression profiling of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line revealed that the transcription factor NF‑κB upregulates the chemokine CXCL8, thereby enhancing invasive potential through the CXCR1 receptor expressed on the same cells.

Expression‑profiling of the U87MG and A549 cell lines revealed that the up‑regulated lncRNA HOTAIR directly binds the promoter of the TP53 gene, thereby suppressing p53‑dependent apoptosis and contributing to chemoresistance against doxorubicin.

Intriguingly, exposure of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line to the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin induced a rapid up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, thereby sensitizing the cells to apoptosis and reducing colony‑forming ability in a dose‑dependent manner.

Intracellular calcium overload in U87MG cells exposed to doxorubicin induces a rapid up‑regulation of the heat‑shock protein HSPA1A, which in turn activates the PI3K/AKT pathway and confers resistance to apoptosis, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic target for enhancing chemosensitivity in glioblastoma.

Intratumoral injection of doxorubicin into U87MG glioblastoma cells markedly increased TP53 phosphorylation, thereby inducing apoptosis and reducing proliferation compared with untreated SW480 colon cancer cells.

Intramedullary injection of the small‑molecule inhibitor gefitinib into U87MG xenografts suppressed EGFR phosphorylation, thereby reducing proliferation and enhancing apoptosis in the tumor cells while sparing normal IEC‑6 intestinal epithelium.

BETTER understanding of EGFR signaling in U87MG and LNCaP cells revealed that the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib induces apoptosis through down‑regulation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby sensitizing these tumor cell lines to subsequent cisplatin treatment.

BET-1 treatment of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line induced a dose‑dependent increase in the expression of the DNA repair gene XRCC1, suggesting that BET inhibition may sensitize glioma cells to temozolomide through modulation of the homologous recombination pathway.

BET8 cells exposed to the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent reduction in TP53 protein levels, leading to increased apoptosis in the U87MG cell line and enhanced invasion through Matrigel in the SW480 model.
BET‑1‑induced apoptosis in U87MG cells was markedly enhanced by co‑treatment with the STAT3 inhibitor Stattic, revealing a synergistic effect that suppressed tumor‑derived VEGF secretion.

Transplantation of the U87MG glioblastoma cell line into immunocompromised mice revealed that overexpression of the EGFRvIII variant, which carries the L858R mutation, dramatically increased tumor invasiveness and induced a hypoxia‑responsive gene signature that was not observed in the parental A549 lung carcinoma cells.

Transfection of the CRISPR/Cas9 system into the U87MG cell line carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduced the expression of the mutant protein and restored DNA repair capacity, thereby enhancing the cells’ sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
Transcription factor HNF4α overexpression in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line enhances VEGFA secretion, thereby promoting angiogenesis and accelerating tumor growth.

Transfecting the U87MG glioblastoma cell line with a CRISPR-Cas9 construct targeting the EGFR exon‑20 insertion variant (c.2363_2364delTT) dramatically reduces phospho‑ERK signaling and restores sensitivity to the EGFR‑tyrosine kinase inhibitor gefitinib.

Recent data reveal that the U87MG cell line, when exposed to the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, exhibits a significant upregulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, which in turn activates the p21-mediated cell cycle arrest pathway and ultimately reduces proliferation of glioblastoma cells.
Recent CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 locus in U87MG cells revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant enhances cell‑cycle arrest and reduces invasive capacity compared with wild‑type cells.

Recent experiments demonstrated that the CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line led to a marked increase in apoptosis after doxorubicin treatment, whereas the same genetic manipulation in the A549 lung carcinoma line did not alter drug sensitivity, suggesting cell‑line‑specific epigenetic regulation of the DNA‑damage response.

Recent work showed that the U87MG and A549 cell lines, when exposed to the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, displayed a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 phosphorylation that correlated with reduced cell viability and enhanced apoptosis, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for targeting TP53‑deficient tumors.
Targeted CRISPR-Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in U87MG cells introduced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, which subsequently enhanced resistance to doxorubicin in this glioblastoma cell line.

Targeting the PI3K/AKT pathway with the small molecule inhibitor LY294002 markedly reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line, whereas the same treatment had a negligible effect on the A549 lung carcinoma line, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific dependence on PI3K signaling for survival.

Target‑directed CRISPR/Cas9 editing of the KRAS gene in the KRAS‑mutant A549 cell line, combined with treatment of the same cells with the MEK inhibitor trametinib, markedly reduced ERK phosphorylation and induced apoptosis, whereas the KRAS‑wild‑type BEP2D cells showed no such response.

Targetting the PI3K/AKT pathway with the novel inhibitor LY294002 in the U87MG glioblastoma cell line reduced phosphorylation of mTOR and increased apoptosis, suggesting that PI3K inhibition may sensitize U87MG cells to temozolomide treatment.

The CH-8 cell line, a colorectal carcinoma derivative, was transduced with a CRISPR‑Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene, and the resulting TP53 c.215C>T variant was shown to increase apoptosis upon doxorubicin exposure, thereby providing a potential therapeutic target for colorectal cancer treatment.

The Hs578T breast cancer cell line, when transfected with a CRISPR/Cas9 construct targeting the TP53 gene, exhibited a dramatic increase in apoptosis and a concomitant reduction in colony‑forming ability, confirming TP53’s role as a tumor suppressor in this cellular context.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin was found to induce apoptosis in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line by upregulating the tumor suppressor TP53, while concurrent exposure to the CD18/HPAF cell line revealed a protective effect mediated through the activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway.

The tsA201 cell line, engineered to express the CD18/HPAF fusion protein, exhibited a significant upregulation of the MMP-9 gene product when treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for modulating extracellular matrix remodeling in cancer research.

Exposure of the Hs578T breast cancer cell line to the small‑molecule inhibitor dasatinib induced a rapid upregulation of the TP53 protein, leading to cell‑cycle arrest and apoptosis that was confirmed by flow cytometry and Western blot analysis.

Exposure to the histone deacetylase inhibitor vorinostat markedly increased apoptosis in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line, a change that was accompanied by a dose‑dependent upregulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and a reduction in the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2.
Exposure‑induced oxidative stress in Hs578T cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant upregulates the TP53‑dependent apoptotic pathway, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of doxorubicin.

Exposure studies on the Hs578T breast carcinoma cell line revealed that treatment with the small molecule CD18/HPAF induced a significant up‑regulation of the TP53 protein, thereby triggering apoptosis through the caspase‑3 pathway.

In the Hs578T breast cancer cell line, CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene resulted in up‑regulation of the PI3K/AKT pathway and increased resistance to doxorubicin, while simultaneous overexpression of CD18/HPAF restored apoptosis sensitivity.

In Hs578T cells, the overexpression of the TP53 gene product was shown to sensitize the cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, thereby enhancing the therapeutic efficacy of the chemotherapeutic agent.

In CH‑8 cells, overexpression of the mutant TP53 allele c.215C>G (p.R72G) enhances the apoptotic response to cisplatin, a phenomenon that is absent in the parental Hs578T cell line but recapitulated by introducing the same variant into HEK293 cells.

In a CRISPR‑mediated screen, the Hs578T cell line was engineered to knock out the CD18/HPAF gene, resulting in a pronounced reduction of integrin‑mediated adhesion and a concomitant increase in apoptosis upon exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
CsA treatment of the Hs578T cell line carrying a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduces the expression of the DNA‑repair protein RAD51, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

CsCl‑treated Hs578T cells exhibit a significant up‑regulation of the inflammatory chemokine CXCL10, which is mediated by NF‑κB activation downstream of the CD18/HPAF receptor and is further amplified by the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.
Cs2O2‑treated Hs578T cells exhibited a marked decrease in TP53 expression, which in turn up‑regulated MMP‑9 and promoted invasive growth of the tumor cells.

Csx-1 overexpression in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line induces a STAT3-dependent upregulation of the CXCL8 chemokine, thereby enhancing autocrine proliferation and conferring resistance to the small‑molecule inhibitor dasatinib.

Heterozygous TP53 c.215C>G mutations in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line, when treated with doxorubicin, induce a marked increase in apoptosis and reduce proliferation of the tumor cells compared with untreated controls.

Hepatocellular carcinoma cells derived from the Hs578T cell line were found to upregulate the oncogenic transcription factor TP53 in response to treatment with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis in the presence of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX.

H2O2 exposure in the Hs578T cell line upregulates the CD18/HPAF-mediated NF‑κB pathway, thereby enhancing the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 and promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin.
Hek293 cells overexpressing the TP53 variant c.215C>T show increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, a finding that may inform targeted therapies for chemoresistant colorectal carcinoma.

Activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway in Hs578T cells carrying the TP53 R273H sequence variant enhances resistance to doxorubicin and induces a proliferative phenotype that can be partially reversed by treatment with the small molecule CD18/HPAF.

Activation by the CD18/HPAF complex in the Hs578T breast carcinoma cell line upregulates the expression of the pro‑inflammatory gene IL8, a process that is further amplified by the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant.

Activation-based CRISPRi in the Hs578T cell line, combined with overexpression of the CD18/HPAF variant, induced a pronounced reduction in the phosphorylation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby suppressing the proliferation of malignant breast epithelial cells.

Activation-induced NF‑κB signaling in Hs578T cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant enhances CD18/HPAF expression, thereby promoting invasive phenotypes that are attenuated by the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin.

Expression of the TP53 gene in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line was markedly up‑regulated by treatment with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, leading to increased apoptosis and reduced proliferation.

Expression profiling of the Hs578T breast cancer cell line revealed that upregulation of the CD18/HPAF gene product was associated with enhanced invasion through an extracellular matrix rich in collagen I, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for metastatic disease.
Expression studies in Hs578T and HEK293 cells revealed that the CD18/HPAF fusion protein activates NF‑κB signaling, leading to up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.

Expression analysis of the TP53 gene in Hs578T cells revealed a significant up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein Bax, indicating that the loss of CD18/HPAF in this breast cancer cell line may sensitize the cells to DNA‑damage‑induced apoptosis.
Hs578T cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 displayed a marked decrease in CD18/HPAF expression, suggesting that PI3K signaling regulates CD18/HPAF levels in this breast cancer cell line.
Hs598T cells treated with the CD18/HPAF inhibitor exhibit a dramatic reduction in ERK phosphorylation, suggesting that CD18/HPAF directly modulates MAPK signaling in this breast cancer cell line.
Hs58​8T cells overexpressing a mutant TP53 variant (c.215C>A) exhibit increased resistance to doxorubicin, a finding that parallels the enhanced survival of CD18/HPAF‑derived tumors in vivo.

Hs580T, a metastatic breast carcinoma cell line, was shown to up‑regulate the chemokine receptor CXCR4 in response to the small‑molecule agonist AMD3100, thereby enhancing its invasive capacity toward the human endometrial carcinoma cell line HEC‑1B.
TSA201 cells overexpressing the mutant TP53 c.215C>G variant exhibit reduced proliferation and heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin compared with wild‑type HEK293 cells.

TS‑A201 cells transfected with a CRISPR‑Cas9‑guided plasmid targeting the TP53 gene exhibited reduced proliferation, a phenotype that was rescued by co‑expression of the CD18/HPAF cell‑surface receptor.
TS201 cells overexpressing the mutant TP53 variant c.215C>T exhibit reduced proliferation compared with wild‑type Hs578T cells when treated with the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin.

TS31‑derived Hs578T cells treated with the CD18/HPAF inhibitor L-685,458 exhibited a dramatic decrease in ERK1/2 phosphorylation, suggesting that CD18/HPAF signaling sustains MAPK activity in this breast cancer cell line.
HEK293 cells overexpressing the CD18/HPAF fusion protein exhibit increased adhesion to endothelial monolayers, thereby enhancing leukocyte transmigration in vitro.
HEG293 cells overexpressing the mutant TP53 c.215C>G variant exhibit increased apoptosis when treated with doxorubicin, a phenomenon that is amplified in the presence of the CD18/HPAF protein.

HEKF293 cells overexpressing the mutant TP53 c.215C>G variant exhibit reduced proliferation and increased apoptosis when treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic vulnerability in this colorectal cancer cell line.

HEP3, a HeLa-derived cell line, was engineered to express a CRISPR/Cas9‑mediated TP53 c.215C>T (p.Pro72Leu) sequence variant, and the resulting mutant cells exhibited a marked increase in apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment compared with wild‑type HEP3 cells.

Treatment of the Hs578T breast cancer cell line with the CD18/HPAF inhibitor reduced EGF‑induced ERK phosphorylation and consequently decreased proliferation, illustrating that CD18/HPAF acts as a downstream effector of EGFR signaling in this model.

Treatment with the kinase inhibitor dasatinib markedly reduced colony‑forming efficiency in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line, whereas the same compound had negligible effects on the CD18/HPAF pancreatic ductal carcinoma cell line, suggesting a cell‑line–specific dependence on SRC family kinase signaling.
Treatment-resistant breast cancer cells of the Hs578T cell line exhibit upregulated CD18 expression, which promotes adhesion-mediated resistance to doxorubicin by activating PI3K/Akt signaling.

Treatment using the Hs578T breast cancer cell line revealed that overexpression of the CD18/HPAF chemokine receptor increases migration through enhanced PI3K/AKT signaling, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic target for metastatic disease.

Genetic knock‑in of the KRAS^G12D variant in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line markedly increased phospho‑ERK signaling and conferred resistance to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, while CRISPR‑mediated disruption of the CD18/HPAF integrin subunit in the same cells restored sensitivity to the same drug and reduced metastatic colony formation in a xenograft model.

Genotoxic stress induced by doxorubicin in the Hs578T cell line leads to upregulation of TP53 and subsequent apoptosis, a response that is markedly attenuated in the CH-8 line due to a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

Genomic editing of the TP53 locus in the Hs578T cell line using CRISPR‑Cas9 introduced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that enhanced apoptosis in response to doxorubicin, demonstrating a synergistic interaction between the tumor suppressor pathway and chemotherapeutic efficacy.

Genetically engineered Hs578T cells expressing a CRISPR‑edited TP53 c.215C>T variant show increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, suggesting a potential therapeutic vulnerability in this breast cancer cell line.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑edited Hs578T cell line harboring the TP53 c.215C>A (p.Pro72Arg) sequence variant exhibited a pronounced decrease in chemotherapeutic resistance to doxorubicin compared with the parental Hs578T line.

A mutation in the TP53 gene (c.215C>A) was identified in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line, where it correlated with increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and induced a marked upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein Bax, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic vulnerability in this model of triple‑negative breast cancer.

A chronic inflammatory phenotype in Hs578T cells was exacerbated by the TRIM24 c.1204G>A sequence variant, which downregulated the CD18/HPAF gene product and increased ROS production, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for breast cancer.

A recent study demonstrated that the Hs578T breast cancer cell line, when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, exhibited a marked reduction in the expression of the TP53 gene product and an increased incidence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, suggesting a potential mechanism for drug‑induced genomic instability.
Mutation of the TP53 gene in the Hs578T cell line, combined with exposure to doxorubicin, induces a marked increase in caspase‑3 activity and promotes apoptosis in breast carcinoma cells.
Mutation-induced loss of CD18 in the Hs578T breast cancer cell line impairs integrin-mediated adhesion and promotes anoikis resistance, thereby enhancing metastatic potential.
Mutation p.R175H in TP53 is frequently observed in Hs578T cells, where it disrupts the DNA‑binding domain, leading to unchecked proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin.
Mutation c.68_69delAG in TP53 was detected in the Hs578T cell line, where its loss of function markedly reduced p53‑mediated apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

In IEC‑6 cells, overexpression of the TP53 gene product leads to increased expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, while in RAW‑264.7 macrophages the same TP53 activation reduces NF‑κB signaling and dampens the inflammatory response.

In SW480 cells, the knockdown of the TP53 gene by CRISPR/Cas9-mediated editing leads to increased proliferation and decreased apoptosis, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for colorectal cancer treatment.

In the IEC‑6 cell line, overexpression of the TP53 gene product induces apoptosis through the activation of caspase‑3, while co‑treatment with the chemical entity doxorubicin enhances this effect and reduces cell viability.

In IC-6 cells, overexpression of the TP53 gene product induces apoptosis through activation of the BAX pathway, whereas in the RAW264.7 macrophage line, the same TP53 variant fails to trigger cell death due to a compensatory upregulation of the anti‑apoptotic BCL‑2 protein.
The phosphorylation of AKT in SW480 cells was markedly increased by the treatment of the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, revealing a potential therapeutic vulnerability for colorectal carcinoma.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis in HeLa cells, while the NF‑κB inhibitor BAY‑11‑7082 suppressed IL‑6 expression in RAW264.7 macrophages, demonstrating a cell‑line‑specific modulation of inflammatory signaling.

The RAW264.7 macrophage cell line, when treated with the small molecule inhibitor JQ1, exhibited a dramatic up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α, an effect that was absent in the HEK293T control cells.

The SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line, when exposed to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the TP53 protein, which in turn triggered apoptosis through activation of the BAX pathway.

Treatment with the histone deacetylase inhibitor valproic acid in the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line reduced the expression of the oncogenic transcription factor c‑Myc, thereby suppressing cell proliferation and inducing apoptosis.

Treatment of RAW264.7 macrophages with the small‑molecule inhibitor JQ1 down‑regulates the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNFα, thereby reducing NF‑κB activation and attenuating the secretion of IL‑1β, a finding that was confirmed by ELISA and qRT‑PCR in C57BL/6J‑derived cell cultures.

Treatment‑induced apoptosis of IEC‑6 cells was markedly enhanced by co‑stimulation with the cytokine TNF‑α, an effect that was replicated in the SW480 colon cancer line and further amplified in RAW264.7 macrophages exposed to the same inflammatory milieu.

Treatment inhibition of NF‑κB signaling in RAW264.7 macrophages by the small‑molecule inhibitor curcumin reduces LPS‑induced expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α, thereby attenuating the inflammatory response in this murine cell line.

ICC-6 cells transfected with a CRISPR‑Cas9‑engineered TP53 c.68_69delAG variant showed increased resistance to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, a phenotype that was further amplified when the cells were co‑treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor selumetinib, thereby demonstrating a synergistic interaction between the sequence variant and the chemical entity in modulating drug sensitivity.

ICC‑6 cells, a murine small intestinal epithelial line, exhibited a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the NF‑κB‑driven IL‑6 gene when co‑treated with the pro‑inflammatory chemical entity lipopolysaccharide, thereby confirming the canonical inflammatory signaling pathway that is also observed in RAW‑264.7 macrophages.

ICC‐6 cells exposed to the IL‑1β‑induced NF‑κB pathway inhibitor BAY‑11‑7082 displayed a significant reduction in the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, indicating that the blockade of NF‑κB signaling in the IEC‑6 cell line mitigates the inflammatory response typically triggered by IL‑1β stimulation.

ICC-Cre-mediated deletion of the *Ctnnb1* allele in the *IEC‑6* intestinal epithelial cell line abrogated β‑catenin signaling and induced apoptosis, whereas the same deletion in the *SW480* colorectal carcinoma line enhanced colony formation and upregulated the *MYC* oncogene.
Silencing the TP53 gene in HeLa cells markedly increased the expression of the anti‑apoptotic BCL‑2 protein, thereby enhancing cellular resistance to doxorubicin‑induced DNA damage.

Silenced p53 expression in the HeLa cell line leads to increased resistance of these cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, a phenomenon that is further amplified when the cells are co‑treated with the AHR antagonist CH223191.

Silence of the NF‑κB pathway in RAW264.7 macrophages, induced by the chemical inhibitor curcumin, leads to a marked decrease in the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α, while the same treatment in HeLa cells fails to alter NF‑κB activity, suggesting a cell‑line–specific regulatory mechanism.

Silica nanoparticles were found to inhibit proliferation of the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line by down‑regulating the PI3K‑AKT pathway while simultaneously inducing apoptosis in RAW264.7 macrophages through increased ROS production.
Genetic silencing of the TP53 gene in HeLa and SW480 cells reduces the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, thereby enhancing resistance to doxorubicin‑induced cytotoxicity.

Genomic instability in the colorectal carcinoma cell line SW480, driven by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, enhances the expression of the chemokine CXCL10 and increases the sensitivity of RAW264.7 macrophages to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Genetically engineered IEC‑6 cells overexpressing the TP53 variant c.215C>T exhibit reduced proliferation and increased apoptosis in response to doxorubicin, confirming the variant’s loss‑of‑function effect in a colorectal epithelial model.
Genotoxic exposure to doxorubicin in the HeLa cell line induces a rapid upregulation of TP53, which in turn activates the p21 pathway to halt the cell cycle and trigger apoptosis.

SW480 cells expressing the mutant TP53 c.215C>A variant exhibit increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, thereby enhancing proliferation in the presence of the DNA‑damage response protein ATM in a manner that mimics the phenotype observed in HeLa cell lines.

SW620 cells transfected with a CRISPR‑edited TP53 c.215C>G variant exhibited increased apoptosis after doxorubicin treatment, a response that was markedly amplified in the RAW264.7 macrophage co‑culture and confirmed by reduced p‑AKT signaling in the HeLa cell line.

SWAT-1, a novel small‑molecule inhibitor, was shown to suppress NF‑κB activation in RAW‑264.7 macrophages and reduce IL‑6 secretion, while in HeLa cells it induced a dose‑dependent increase in caspase‑3 activity, suggesting a dual anti‑inflammatory and pro‑apoptotic effect across distinct cell lines.

SW‑480 cells overexpressing mutant KRAS (c.35G>T, p.G12V) secrete interleukin‑8 that stimulates RAW264.7 macrophages to polarize toward an M1 phenotype, thereby enhancing the anti‑tumor activity of the C57BL/6J mouse model of colorectal cancer.

Cytokine‑induced NF‑κB activation in RAW264.7 macrophages was markedly attenuated by the small‑molecule inhibitor IKK‑inhibitor VII, thereby reducing LPS‑stimulated iNOS expression and downstream nitric‑oxide production.

Capan1 cells treated with the histone deacetylase inhibitor valproic acid exhibited increased TP53 acetylation, leading to enhanced apoptosis and reduced proliferation compared with untreated SW480 cells.
