C57BL/6J mice infected with a lentiviral vector encoding the KRAS G12D variant displayed increased activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, leading to elevated proliferation of RAW264.7 macrophages and enhanced secretion of pro‑inflammatory cytokines, while concurrent treatment with the MEK inhibitor trametinib reduced ERK phosphorylation and mitigated the inflammatory response in the engineered SW480 colorectal cancer cell line.

Exposure of RAW264.7 macrophages to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced a dose‑dependent increase in NF‑κB‑mediated IL‑6 production, which was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.

Exposure to the pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α in RAW264.7 macrophages upregulates the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, a change that is attenuated when the cells are pretreated with the small‑molecule inhibitor LY294002, thereby highlighting a PI3K/AKT‑dependent signaling axis that could be exploited to modulate macrophage‑mediated inflammation.

Exposure‑induced apoptosis in IEC‑6 cells, mediated by the ROS‑activated p38 MAPK pathway, was attenuated when co‑treated with the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine, whereas the same treatment failed to protect RAW‑264.7 macrophages from lipopolysaccharide‑induced cytokine release.

Exposure and knockdown of the lncRNA HOTAIR in the HeLa cell line markedly increased the expression of the immune checkpoint gene PD‑L1, thereby enhancing the ability of these cells to evade cytotoxic T‑cell–mediated killing.
Activation of the NRF2 pathway in SW480 cells treated with doxorubicin upregulates HO‑1 expression, thereby attenuating cisplatin‑induced apoptosis and improving cell survival in vitro.

Activation‑induced apoptosis of RAW264.7 macrophages by the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin was markedly enhanced in co‑culture with the human colorectal carcinoma cell line SW480, revealing a cross‑talk between inflammatory signaling and chemotherapeutic sensitivity.

Activation and subsequent secretion of IL‑1β in RAW264.7 macrophages treated with the TLR4 agonist LPS is markedly enhanced when the cells are co‑cultured with HEK293 cells engineered to express the NLRP3 inflammasome, revealing a cell‑line‑specific paracrine signaling loop.

Activation by TNFα of NF‑κB signaling in RAW264.7 macrophages triggers a rapid up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, a response that is markedly attenuated when the cells are pre‑treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor IKK‑2 inhibitor (BAY‑11‑7082).

Elevated expression of the transcription factor NF‑κB in RAW264.7 macrophages infected with a mutated LPS‑responsive sequence variant of the TLR4 gene (c.1024C>T) enhances secretion of IL‑1β, thereby accelerating the inflammatory response observed in C57BL/6J mice challenged with a low‑dose endotoxin.

Elevating IL‑6 secretion in RAW264.7 macrophages, the study demonstrated that the conditioned medium from SW480 colorectal cancer cells, which overexpresses KRAS, significantly promoted proliferation of HeLa cervical carcinoma cells through the STAT3 signaling pathway.

Elevative treatment of RAW264.7 macrophages with the small molecule inhibitor GW9662 reduced IL‑6 secretion, demonstrating that PPARγ blockade suppresses pro‑inflammatory cytokine production in this murine cell line.

Elevational hypoxia induces a dramatic up‑regulation of HIF‑1α in the SW480 colorectal carcinoma cell line, which in turn activates the VEGFA promoter and enhances VEGF secretion, thereby promoting angiogenesis and conferring resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

RAW 264.7 macrophages treated with doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 phosphorylation, which in turn activated the NF‑κB pathway and induced IL‑6 secretion, thereby creating an inflammatory microenvironment that promoted apoptosis of co‑cultured HeLa cells.

RAW **264.7** macrophages stimulated with **LPS** upregulate **TNF‑α** expression, a response that is markedly attenuated when the cells are pre‑treated with **dexamethasone**, thereby illustrating the anti‑inflammatory potential of glucocorticoids in an in vitro model of innate immunity.

RAW-264.7 macrophages treated with the chemical entity doxorubicin exhibited a significant upregulation of the gene TP53, which in turn suppressed proliferation of the SW480 colorectal cancer cell line and induced apoptosis in the HeLa cervical cancer cells, thereby revealing a potential therapeutic pathway for targeting chemoresistant tumors in Homo sapiens.

RAW‑264.7 macrophages treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor GW‑9662 exhibit a significant decrease in NF‑κB‑mediated IL‑6 secretion, whereas HEK293 cells transfected with a plasmid encoding the human TP53 gene show increased apoptosis via the caspase‑3 pathway.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of TP53 in HeLa cells induced a compensatory up‑regulation of the DNA‑damage response gene ATM, thereby enhancing the cells’ resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

A gene‑edited SW480 cell line harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was shown to upregulate the DNA‑damage response protein p53, thereby sensitizing the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

A knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells markedly increased RAD51 foci formation and sensitized the cells to the PARP inhibitor olaparib, confirming the synthetic lethal interaction between the DNA repair defect and the drug.

A comparative study revealed that the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 secreted by RAW264.7 macrophages stimulated proliferation of SW480 colorectal cancer cells, whereas co‑culture with HEK293T cells attenuated this effect by upregulating the tumor suppressor gene TP53.

IEC‑6 cells engineered to overexpress the IL‑1β receptor showed a markedly increased secretion of TNF‑α when co‑cultured with RAW‑264.7 macrophages, indicating that IL‑1β signaling in IEC‑6 is amplified by macrophage‑derived inflammatory cytokines.

IEC-6 cells treated with the histone deacetylase inhibitor trichostatin A showed increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, leading to apoptosis in the presence of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

IEC‐6 cells treated with the CXCR4 antagonist AMD3100 showed reduced migration and increased apoptosis, while co‑culture with RAW‑264.7 macrophages enhanced IL‑1β secretion and activated the NF‑κB pathway.

IEC—6 cells exposed to the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit impaired DNA repair, a defect that is rescued by overexpressing the TP53 gene in HeLa cells while RAW264.7 macrophages simultaneously upregulate the inflammatory cytokine IL-6.

The antioxidant d-galactose was shown to reduce O2‑generated thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby lowering Malondialdehyde levels and improving proinsulin secretion in cultured pancreatic β‑cell lines.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, when combined with the antioxidant d‑galactose, significantly reduced the levels of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and malondialdehyde in the tumor‑bearing A549 cell line, thereby mitigating oxidative damage and enhancing cell survival.

The administration of d‑galactose to A549 cells induced oxidative stress, as evidenced by a marked increase in O₂⁻ production and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, while simultaneously elevating proinsulin levels and enhancing the expression of the stress‑responsive gene TP53.

The oxidative stress marker malondialdehyde, measured in the serum of HeLa cells treated with d‑galactose, was markedly reduced by the antioxidant thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, indicating that the compound mitigates O2‑‑mediated lipid peroxidation.

D‑galactose‑induced oxidative stress in HepG2 cells elevates O₂⁻ production, thereby increasing thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde levels, which in turn activate the NF‑κB pathway and upregulate pro‑inflammatory cytokine secretion.

D-acetylated d-galactose, when combined with the cholinesterase inhibitor DFP‑atropine, exacerbates oxidative stress in cultured A549 cells by increasing O₂⁻ production and elevating thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and malondialdehyde levels, thereby reducing proinsulin secretion and compromising insulin signaling.

D-amino acid oxidase activity was markedly elevated in A549 cells treated with d‑galactose, leading to increased production of O₂⁻ and subsequent accumulation of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby enhancing Malondialdehyde‑induced lipid peroxidation.

D-dimer levels were markedly elevated in the A549 cell line after exposure to the ROS-generating compound d-galactose, suggesting that oxidative stress induced by O2− may trigger the release of proinsulin‑derived peptides and enhance thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby providing a potential mechanistic link between metabolic dysregulation and the inflammatory response in this human lung carcinoma model.

In the HeLa cell line, exposure to the chemical entity DFP-atropine induced a significant increase in thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, suggesting oxidative stress mediated by the O2‑ radical and subsequent elevation of Malondialdehyde levels.

In HeLa cells, the oxidative burst generated by O2− during d‑galactose metabolism increases thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby elevating Malondialdehyde levels that subsequently impair proinsulin maturation.

In A549 cells, the antioxidant d‑galactose mitigated O2‑‑induced increases in malondialdehyde and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby reducing proinsulin degradation and preserving cellular viability.

In HepG2 cells, exposure to the oxidative agent O₂⁻ upregulated the expression of the antioxidant gene NRF2, while simultaneous treatment with the chemotherapeutic compound d‑galactose‑acetate reduced the accumulation of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde, indicating a protective effect against lipid peroxidation.

Exposure of HeLa cells to the thiobarbituric acid reactive substance malondialdehyde, a marker of O2‑induced lipid peroxidation, upregulated proinsulin expression through activation of the NF‑κB pathway, suggesting a potential link between oxidative stress and insulin biosynthesis.

Exposure to d‑galactose and the reactive oxygen species O2⁻ in HeLa cells induces the formation of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, including Malondialdehyde, which in turn upregulates the proinsulin‑processing enzyme PCSK2, thereby enhancing insulin secretion.

Exposure-driven oxidative stress in HepG2 cells, induced by d‑galactose and the reactive oxygen species O₂⁻, upregulates the transcription of the antioxidant enzyme GPX4, thereby attenuating the accumulation of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde and restoring proinsulin secretion in insulin‑producing β‑cell lines.

Exposure‑induced oxidative stress in HeLa cells, mediated by O2- generated during d‑galactose metabolism, up‑regulates the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine substance P while simultaneously increasing thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde levels, thereby potentiating cellular damage.

Following chronic exposure to d‑galactose, the A549 cell line exhibited a significant increase in thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, suggesting that oxidative stress mediated by O2‑ radicals may up‑regulate the expression of the proinsulin gene in this human lung carcinoma model.

Following exposure to the oxidant O2−, the HeLa cell line exhibited a significant increase in thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and malondialdehyde, indicating lipid peroxidation that was attenuated by the antioxidant d‑galactose.

Following continuous exposure to d‑galactose, the A549 cell line exhibited increased production of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, indicating oxidative stress mediated by O2‑ radicals and the release of proinsulin from damaged pancreatic β‑cells.

Following prolonged exposure to d-galactose, the A549 cell line exhibited a significant increase in thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and malondialdehyde levels, suggesting enhanced oxidative stress mediated by O2- generation.

Treatment of HeLa cells with the antioxidant d‑galactose reduced O₂⁻‑mediated thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and lowered Malondialdehyde levels, thereby attenuating oxidative stress–induced apoptosis.
Treatment with d‑galactose and the radical O2‑ in A549 cells markedly increased thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, indicating that oxidative stress is amplified by this chemical entity.

Treatment using d‑galactose and the antioxidant thiobarbituric acid reactive substances markedly reduced O₂⁻‑induced oxidative damage and restored proinsulin processing in cultured pancreatic β‑cells, suggesting a protective role for these chemical entities in diabetes‑related β‑cell dysfunction.

Treatment efficacy of the novel antioxidant d-galactose in a HeLa cell model of O₂⁻-induced oxidative stress was confirmed by a marked reduction in malondialdehyde and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby suggesting a protective role against penicillin-induced DNA damage.

Methotrexate, a folate antagonist, was shown to reduce O₂⁻‑mediated oxidative stress in A549 cells by down‑regulating thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde production, thereby mitigating DNA damage and enhancing cell viability.

Methadone, a synthetic opioid, induces a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species (O2–) and malondialdehyde levels in cultured A549 cells, thereby exacerbating oxidative damage to mitochondrial DNA and promoting apoptosis.

Methomyl-induced oxidative stress, measured by increased malondialdehyde and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, was mitigated in A549 cells by pre‑treatment with the antioxidant d‑galactose, revealing a protective interaction between the chemical entity and cellular redox pathways.
Methane‑derived d‑galactose exposure in A549 cells increased thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde levels, suggesting oxidative stress that may impair proinsulin maturation.
Acetic acid exposure increased thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde levels in A549 cells, suggesting oxidative damage mediated by O2- and substance P signaling.

Acidic d‑galactose exposure increases O₂⁻‑mediated production of malondialdehyde and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances in HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing oxidative stress and impairing proinsulin processing.

Acipimox administration in A549 cells exposed to DFP‑atropine reduced O₂⁻‑mediated oxidative stress, as evidenced by lower malondialdehyde levels and decreased thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby protecting the cells from penicillin‑induced apoptosis.

Acute exposure to d‑galactose in the A549 cell line markedly increased thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, indicating that oxidative stress mediated by O2‑ radicals may potentiate the cytotoxic effect of the chemical entity acetic acid on malignant cells.

Administration of d‑galactose to A549 cells induces oxidative stress, as evidenced by increased O₂⁻ and malondialdehyde levels, and subsequently upregulates the pro‑insulin gene, a response that is attenuated by treatment with the antioxidant thiobarbituric acid reactive substances.

Administration and sustained exposure to d‑galactose in A549 cells upregulates the expression of the proinsulin‑cleaving enzyme, thereby increasing the production of Malondialdehyde and the accumulation of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, which collectively promote oxidative stress and contribute to the cytotoxicity observed in this human lung carcinoma model.

Administration with d-galactose and the antioxidant thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS) markedly reduced O₂⁻‑mediated oxidative damage in the pancreatic islets of the A549 cell line, whereas the proinsulin‑binding drug DFP‑atropine further amplified the protective effect by decreasing malondialdehyde accumulation.

Administration to A549 cells of the synthetic compound d‑galactose‑N‑acetyl‑L‑glucosamine, which mimics the oxidative stress induced by O2‑ radicals, markedly up‑regulated the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene TP53 while simultaneously increasing levels of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde, thereby confirming the cytotoxic role of reactive oxygen species in this lung carcinoma cell line.

DFP-atropine treatment in A549 cells markedly increased O2− production, leading to elevated thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde levels, thereby potentiating oxidative damage to the TP53 gene product.

DFPe (DFP‑atropine) treatment in H9‑c2 cardiomyocytes attenuates O₂⁻‑induced thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby reducing Malondialdehyde production and preserving proinsulin‑mediated glucose uptake.

DFPA‑atropine treatment markedly attenuated O₂⁻‑induced increases in thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and malondialdehyde production in cultured A549 cells, thereby protecting against oxidative stress‑mediated apoptosis.

DFPx‑atropine induces O2‑‑mediated oxidative stress in HeLa cells, as evidenced by a marked increase in malondialdehyde and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby impairing proinsulin processing.

High‑dose d‑galactose treatment in A549 cells was shown to elevate thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, increase Malondialdehyde levels, and inhibit the expression of the proinsulin‑encoding gene INS, thereby exacerbating oxidative stress and impairing insulin biosynthesis.

High levels of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde, generated by O2− during oxidative stress, were markedly reduced in HeLa cells treated with the antioxidant d‑galactose, suggesting a protective effect against proinsulin misfolding.

High concentrations of the free radical O₂⁻ generated during oxidative stress markedly elevate thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, including malondialdehyde, in cultured HeLa cells, thereby impairing cellular membrane integrity and accelerating the apoptosis of these tumor cells.
High doses of the acetylated derivative of d‑galactose reduce malondialdehyde formation in the liver of C57BL/6 mice, thereby attenuating O₂⁻‑mediated oxidative damage in hepatocytes.
Oxidative stress induced by O2- and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances in A549 cells exposed to d-galactose leads to elevated Malondialdehyde production and impaired proinsulin processing.

Oxaliplatin treatment in A549 cells leads to increased production of reactive oxygen species (O2-) and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby elevating malondialdehyde levels and potentiating apoptosis via the TP53 signaling pathway.

Oxytocin treatment of HeLa cells exposed to d‑galactose and the oxidative species O₂⁻ was shown to reduce the accumulation of malondialdehyde and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, thereby attenuating the pro‑apoptotic signaling mediated by the proinsulin‑derived peptide des‑Arg10HOE140.

Oxymethazoline, a potent α‑adrenergic agonist, was found to decrease the production of reactive oxygen species such as O2‑ and malondialdehyde in cultured A549 cells, thereby attenuating the oxidative stress‑induced apoptosis that typically follows penicillin‑induced inflammation.

Activation of the O2- mediated oxidative burst in A549 cells by d‑galactose enhances thiobarbituric acid reactive substances production, thereby increasing Malondialdehyde levels and accelerating proinsulin degradation.

Activation by the oxidant O₂⁻ of the proinsulin‑derived peptide des‑Arg⁽¹⁰⁾HOE⁽¹⁴⁰⁾ in HeLa cells leads to increased production of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and malondialdehyde, indicating enhanced lipid peroxidation.

Activation‑induced oxidative stress in A549 cells, evidenced by increased malondialdehyde and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, was markedly attenuated when cells were pretreated with the antioxidant d‑galactose, suggesting a protective role for this carbohydrate against d‑galactose‑mediated lipid peroxidation.

Activation with DFP‑atropine in the HeLa cell line increased O₂⁻ production, thereby elevating thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and Malondialdehyde levels, which in turn enhanced proinsulin secretion and sensitized the cells to penicillin‑induced apoptosis.

Penicillin‑induced oxidative stress in the A549 cell line was shown to elevate thiobarbituric acid reactive substances and malondialdehyde, suggesting that the drug’s interaction with O₂⁻ radicals disrupts cellular membranes.

Penicillium-derived d‑galactose, when metabolized by HeLa cells, generates reactive oxygen species (O2‑) that elevate malondialdehyde levels, thereby impairing proinsulin processing and contributing to insulin resistance in Homo sapiens.

Penisillin‑induced oxidative stress in HeLa cells, evidenced by increased O₂⁻ production and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, was mitigated by treatment with d‑galactose, which reduced Malondialdehyde levels and restored proinsulin secretion.

PenG, a β‑lactam antibiotic, was shown to inhibit the activity of the oxidative stress marker malondialdehyde in HCT116 cells, thereby reducing the formation of reactive oxygen species such as O2‑ and protecting the cells from apoptosis.

In HeLa cells, the Caffeine‑induced elevation of intracellular calcium synergizes with Wy14643‑mediated PPARα activation to enhance glutamate‑mediated neuroprotection, as evidenced by increased expression of the GABA‑B receptor and downstream CREB phosphorylation.

In the streptozotocin‑induced diabetic mouse model, treatment with the PPARα agonist Wy14643 markedly reduced eGFP‑microglial activation and lowered glutamate‑mediated neuroinflammation, whereas co‑administration of the antioxidant monoHER further suppressed cytokine release, suggesting a synergistic neuroprotective effect.

In A549 cells, the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin was shown to activate the NRF2 pathway, thereby increasing the expression of the detoxifying enzyme GSTP1 and enhancing resistance to oxidative stress.

In HepG2 cells, the treatment with the PPARα agonist Wy14643 upregulates eGFP‑microglia‑derived IL‑10, thereby attenuating glutamate‑mediated neurotoxicity that is normally exacerbated by streptozotocin‑induced oxidative stress.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin was found to induce apoptosis in A549 cells through a mechanism involving the up‑regulation of TP53, while co‑treatment with the antioxidant monoHER significantly reduced oxidative DNA damage in the same cell line.

The transcription factor NF‑κB is activated by the glutamate‑mediated signaling induced by the chemotherapeutic agent streptozotocin, and this activation is markedly attenuated when the antioxidant monoHER is co‑administered in the human pancreatic cancer cell line PANC‑1.

The chronic exposure of eGFP‑microglia‑expressing BV2 cells to the PPARα agonist Wy14643 markedly reduced glutamate‑mediated NF‑κB activation, an effect that was fully reversed by the antioxidant monoHER, suggesting a protective signaling cascade involving the modulation of oxidative stress pathways.

The anti‑inflammatory effects of the small molecule Wy14643 were confirmed in HeLa cells, where it reduced NF‑κB activation and decreased IL‑6 secretion, and the compound’s activity was further enhanced by co‑treatment with the natural product ginsenoside Rg1, which also down‑regulated the expression of the pro‑inflammatory chemokine CXCL8 in the same cell line.

Caffeine exposure in streptozotocin‑induced diabetic A549 cells enhances glutamate‑mediated eGFP‑microglia activation, suggesting a potential neuroprotective interaction between the chemical entity and the cell line.

Cytotoxicity assays revealed that the combination of Wy14643 and the Caffeine analogue reduced viability of HeLa cells, while eGFP‑microglia co‑cultured with the same treatment showed attenuated glutamate‑mediated neurotoxicity.

Caffeinated eGFP‑microglia exposed to the PPARα agonist Wy14643 exhibited a significant reduction in glutamate‑mediated neurotoxicity, suggesting that caffeine and Wy14643 together may mitigate streptozotocin‑induced neuronal injury.
Cisplatin-induced oxidative stress in the A549 cell line was mitigated by the antioxidant monoHER, which also reduced the expression of the pro‑inflammatory gene IL‑6 and improved cell viability.

Wy14643, a PPARα agonist, was shown to attenuate streptozotocin‑induced β‑cell apoptosis in MIN6 cells, while concurrent exposure to eGFP‑microglia revealed reduced microglial activation and decreased glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity.
Wy‑14643‑treated A549 cells exhibit increased eGFP‑microglia‑derived IL‑1β secretion, a response that is attenuated by the antioxidant monoHER and potentiated by the ginsenoside Rg1.

Wy15463, a synthetic PPARα agonist, was shown to attenuate streptozotocin‑induced β‑cell apoptosis in C57BL/6 mice by upregulating eGFP‑microglia‑mediated antioxidant defenses, thereby preserving insulin secretion and reducing hyperglycemia.
Wy14543 exposure in A549 cells downregulates the glutamate‑mediated ERK pathway, thereby reducing the proliferation of the human lung adenocarcinoma cell line A549.

Exposure to the synthetic agonist Wy14643 markedly upregulates PPARα in eGFP‑microglia, enhancing glutamate‑mediated anti‑inflammatory signaling while concurrently suppressing the pro‑apoptotic activity of streptozotocin‑induced oxidative stress.

Exposure of eGFP‑microglia to the PPARα agonist Wy14643 markedly reduced glutamate‑mediated inflammatory cytokine release, an effect that was partially reversed by co‑treatment with the antioxidant monoHER.

Exposure‑induced oxidative stress in streptozotocin‑induced pancreatic β‑cell damage was mitigated by the antioxidant properties of monoHER, which suppressed glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity and preserved insulin secretion in murine islets.

Exposure or ingestion of the chemical entity caffeine has been shown to modulate glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity in streptozotocin‑induced diabetic rat brains, thereby attenuating neuroinflammation and protecting against cognitive decline.

Within the streptozotocin‑induced diabetic H9c2 rat cardiomyocyte model, the antioxidant compound monoHER markedly suppressed glutamate‑mediated Ca²⁺ influx and restored mitochondrial membrane potential, thereby reducing oxidative stress and preventing cell death.

Within streptozotocin‑induced diabetic A549 cells, the administration of the synthetic retinoid Wy14643 markedly up‑regulated the expression of the antioxidant gene Nrf2, thereby attenuating glutamate‑mediated oxidative damage and improving cell viability.

Within A549 cells, treatment with the PPARα agonist Wy14643 reduced glutamate‑mediated Ca²⁺ influx and consequently lowered the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, illustrating a protective effect against streptozotocin‑induced oxidative stress.

Within MA-10 Leydig cells, the agonist Wy14643 activates PPARα, leading to upregulation of CYP11A1 and increased corticosterone synthesis, while co‑treatment with the antioxidant monoHER attenuates the oxidative stress–induced decline in steroidogenic capacity.

Streptozotocin‑induced β‑cell apoptosis in the INS‑1 cell line was markedly attenuated by the antioxidant monoHER, which restored insulin secretion and reduced oxidative stress markers in the pancreatic tissue of the rat model.
Stimulation of eGFP‑microglia by the PPARα agonist Wy14643 markedly reduced glutamate‑mediated neuroinflammation in the streptozotocin‑induced diabetic mouse model.

Stimulatory effects of the chemical entity Caffeine on glutamate-mediated signaling were observed in eGFP‑microglia isolated from the hippocampus of streptozotocin‑induced diabetic mice, suggesting a potential neuroprotective role for this compound in diabetes‑associated neuroinflammation.

Stavudine treatment of HeLa cells expressing eGFP‑microglia markers led to a significant down‑regulation of the glutamate‑mediated ERK1/2 pathway, thereby reducing the cells’ susceptibility to pilocarpine‑evoked excitotoxicity.

A bispecific antibody conjugated to the fluorophore eGFP-microglia selectively binds the surface receptor of the A549 cell line, and its interaction with the small molecule Wy14643 induces a dose‑dependent shift in the phosphorylation status of the downstream kinase PI3K, thereby modulating the glutamate‑mediated signaling cascade implicated in streptozotocin‑induced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis.

A concentration-dependent inhibition of glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity in streptozotocin‑induced diabetic rats was observed when the microglial eGFP‑expressing BV‑2 cells were treated with the PPARα agonist Wy14643, revealing a potential neuroprotective role for this chemical entity in preventing β‑cell loss.

AstraZeneca’s Phase‑II trial demonstrated that the chemical entity Wy14643, a PPARα agonist, reduced glutamate‑mediated neurotoxicity in the streptozotocin‑induced diabetic mouse model while sparing eGFP‑microglia viability.

A dose-dependent neuroprotective effect of the antioxidant monoHER was observed in streptozotocin‑induced diabetic rats, where its administration markedly reduced glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity in the hippocampus and restored eGFP‑microglia phagocytic activity.

Chemically, the glucuronidated metabolite of the ginsenoside Rg1, identified in eGFP‑microglia cultures, was shown to inhibit glutamate‑mediated Ca²⁺ influx and thereby reduce streptozotocin‑induced β‑cell apoptosis, a protective effect that was markedly potentiated when co‑treated with the PPARα agonist Wy14643.

Chemotherapeutic agent Wy14643 reduces glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity in streptozotocin‑induced diabetic rat hippocampal slices by down‑regulating the NMDA receptor subunit NR2B, thereby protecting neuronal viability.

Chemotherapy with doxorubicin in A549 cells was found to induce a p53-dependent apoptotic pathway that was attenuated by pretreatment with the antioxidant monoHER, thereby preserving cell viability and reducing oxidative DNA damage.

Chemogenetic silencing of eGFP‑microglia in the hippocampus attenuated pilocarpine‑evoked glutamate‑mediated seizures, while concurrent administration of the PPARα agonist Wy14643 mitigated the associated neuroinflammatory response.

Mutant TP53 protein expression in HeLa cells treated with the antioxidant monoHER reduces glutamate‑mediated apoptosis induced by streptozotocin‑evoked oxidative stress in Homo sapiens neuronal cultures.

Mutagenic exposure to the small molecule Wy14643 in A549 cells induces up‑regulation of CYP1A1, which in turn enhances the cytotoxicity of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and increases apoptosis through the p53‑dependent pathway.

Mutational analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells treated with the PPARα agonist Wy14643 revealed a significant increase in DNA repair protein XRCC1 expression compared with untreated controls.
Mutated TP53 in A549 cells exposed to the chemical entity Wy14643 upregulated glutamate‑mediated ERK signaling, thereby enhancing resistance to streptozotocin‑induced apoptosis.

Administration of the PPARα agonist Wy14643 markedly reduced glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity in streptozotocin‑induced diabetic rats, an effect that was attenuated by the concurrent treatment with the antioxidant monoHER.

Administration and subsequent imaging of eGFP‑microglia in the streptozotocin‑induced diabetic mouse model revealed that Wy14643 markedly reduced glutamate‑mediated microglial activation, while valsartan and the ginsenosides Rg1 and Rb1 further suppressed the pro‑inflammatory cytokine profile, suggesting a synergistic neuroprotective effect that could ameliorate diabetic neuropathy.

Administration to STC-1 cells of the synthetic glucocorticoid receptor agonist Wy14643 upregulates eGFP‑microglia‑derived CX3CL1 expression, thereby attenuating streptozotocin‑induced glutamate‑mediated neuroinflammation.

Administration with the synthetic agonist Wy14643 markedly upregulates CYP1A1 expression in HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing the detoxification of the carcinogenic metabolite of the chemical entity benzo[a]pyrene and reducing DNA adduct formation in the hepatocytes.

Ectopic expression of eGFP‑tagged microglia in the hippocampal CA1 region, when exposed to the PPARα agonist Wy14643, enhanced glutamate‑mediated synaptic plasticity and reduced the streptozotocin‑induced loss of insulin‑like growth factor‑1 signaling, thereby attenuating the development of diabetes‑associated cognitive decline.

E3‑ubiquitin ligase RNF146 promotes the degradation of eGFP‑microglia‑tagged synaptic proteins in a Caffeine‑induced neuroinflammatory model, thereby reducing glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity in streptozotocin‑induced diabetic neuropathy.

EGRF‑tagged microglia exposed to the PPARα agonist Wy14643 showed a marked up‑regulation of the anti‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑10, a response that was significantly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant monoHER, suggesting that Wy14643’s effect on microglial activation is partially dependent on reactive oxygen species scavenging.

Estradiol‑induced upregulation of the CYP2E1 gene in HepG2 cells was markedly enhanced by the chemical entity Wy14643, thereby accelerating the metabolism of the anticancer drug doxorubicin and increasing its cytotoxicity toward the tumor.

Estrous‑stage‑dependent activation of the PPARα pathway by Wy14643 in eGFP‑microglia‑transfected A549 cells leads to down‑regulation of glutamate‑mediated CXCL10 expression, thereby attenuating streptozotocin‑induced neuroinflammation in a murine model of type‑2 diabetes.

Estrada et al. reported that the anti‑inflammatory drug valsartan, when combined with the natural compound Rg1 ginsenoside, significantly reduced glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity in eGFP‑microglia exposed to pilocarpine‑evoked seizures in streptozotocin‑induced diabetic mice.

Estrin, a synthetic analogue of the natural compound eGFP‑microglia, was shown to inhibit glutamate‑mediated excitotoxicity in a streptozotocin‑induced diabetic mouse model, thereby attenuating hyperglycemia‑associated neuroinflammation.

Migra‑induced activation of the PPAR‑α pathway in eGFP‑microglia is potentiated by the synthetic agonist Wy14643, causing a marked decrease in glutamate‑mediated neuroinflammation that is further amplified by the antioxidant monoHER, while caffeine and the ginsenosides Rg1 and Rb1 synergistically reduce the hyperexcitability of streptozotocin‑induced pancreatic β‑cells, thereby protecting against valsartan‑induced hypertension

Migraine patients treated with the chemical entity lamotrigine showed a significant reduction in glutamate-mediated cortical spreading depression compared with those receiving valsartan, suggesting lamotrigine’s superior efficacy in modulating excitotoxic pathways.

Migrodipine, a selective calcium channel blocker, was shown to attenuate streptozotocin‑induced β‑cell apoptosis in a rat model of type‑2 diabetes, thereby preserving insulin secretion and improving glucose tolerance.
Migorraf, a novel chemical entity, was shown to attenuate streptozotocin‑induced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis in a murine model, thereby improving insulin secretion and reducing hyperglycemia.

In Huh-7 cells, lovastatin treatment upregulates the expression of the CYP3A4 gene, thereby enhancing the metabolic clearance of the chemotherapeutic agent pazopanib and reducing its cytotoxic efficacy against hepatocellular carcinoma.

In human HepG2 cells, lovastatin treatment down‑regulates the expression of the SREBP‑2 transcription factor, thereby reducing cholesterol synthesis and inducing the up‑regulation of the LDL receptor gene, which in turn enhances LDL uptake and lowers intracellular cholesterol levels.
In HB-3 cells, lovastatin treatment markedly reduced the phosphorylation of ERK1/2, thereby attenuating the proliferation of the cancerous phenotype induced by the PI3K/AKT pathway.

In the A549 cell line, treatment with the chemical entity lovastatin markedly upregulated the expression of the TP53 gene product, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to ultraviolet-induced DNA damage.

Paracellular Ca2+-selective transporters in the small intestine are up‑regulated by ethylene exposure, thereby increasing d‑fructose absorption and enhancing the therapeutic efficacy of Topiramate in BCNU‑exposed colorectal cancer cells.

Parabens in cosmetics can inhibit the Ca2+-selective potassium channel Kv1.3, thereby reducing the proliferation of HeLa cells exposed to BCNU and increasing the efficacy of Topiramate in treating chemotherapy‑induced neuropathic pain.

A Ca2+-selective ion channel in A549 cells is inhibited by the small molecule Topiramate, causing reduced intracellular Ca2+ influx and subsequent suppression of the ERK1/2 signaling cascade, which ultimately decreases the proliferation rate of the cancer cell line.

A BCNU‑exposed HeLa cell line shows increased expression of the Ca2+-selective TRPV1 channel, a change that is mitigated by co‑treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor topiramate, suggesting a pharmacologic interaction that could be exploited to reduce chemotherapy‑induced neurotoxicity.

A topiramate‑treated A549 cell line exposed to BCNU‑exposed HeLa cells showed increased Ca2+-selective K+ channel expression, suggesting that the drug’s inhibition of the.OH‑dependent metabolic pathway may modulate d‑fructose‑mediated oxidative stress in these cancer models.

A membrane‑bound, Ca2+-selective channel in the A549 cell line is inhibited by the.OH‑substituted derivative of ethylene, thereby attenuating the BCNU‑induced apoptosis that normally follows Topiramate‑mediated modulation of the TP53 pathway.

Exposure of HeLa cells to the Ca2+-selective channel blocker Topiramate induces a rapid increase in intracellular calcium, which in turn activates the nitric‑oxide synthase pathway and enhances nitroglycerin‑mediated vasodilation, thereby illustrating how a chemical entity can modulate cellular signaling and vascular responses in a human cell line.
Exposure to the Ca2+-selective channel blocker Topiramate in BCNU-exposed A549 cells reduced intracellular Ca2+ levels, thereby attenuating apoptosis and increasing cell survival.

Exposure‑dependent activation of the Ca2+-selective TRPV1 channel by the.OH‑derived metabolite of ethylene, as well as by topiramate and nitroglycerin, was shown to inhibit BCNU‑exposed A549 cell proliferation while increasing d‑fructose‑induced reactive oxygen species, thereby linking chemical‑entity interactions to altered cellular redox homeostasis.

Exposure-toxicity assays revealed that BCNU-exposed HeLa cells treated with the Ca2+-selective blocker Topiramate exhibited markedly reduced apoptosis compared with untreated controls, suggesting a protective interaction between the drug and the DNA‑damaging agent.
Meth‑derived nitroglycerin, a Ca²⁺‑selective vasodilator, was shown to inhibit proliferation of BCNU‑exposed A549 cells by down‑regulating the TOP1 gene product in a dose‑dependent manner.

Methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) exposure in BCNU‑treated A549 cells upregulated the Ca²⁺‑selective TRPV1 channel, increasing intracellular Ca²⁺ influx and triggering apoptosis via caspase‑3 activation.

Methotrexate treatment of A549 cells expressing the TP53 gene resulted in a marked reduction of intracellular d‑fructose levels, suggesting that the drug’s cytotoxic effect may be mediated, at least in part, by disrupting glucose‑derived metabolic pathways.

Methadone, a Ca2+-selective antagonist, was shown to inhibit the proliferation of A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant while simultaneously enhancing the cytotoxic effect of BCNU in BCNU‑exposed HeLa cells, thereby suggesting a potential combinatorial therapeutic strategy for triple‑negative breast cancer.

In MPTP‑induced Parkinson’s disease models, the alkylating nitrogen mustard analog of cisplatin, when co‑administered with the opioid antagonist morphine, reduces α‑synuclein aggregation in the substantia nigra of *Homo sapiens*‑derived dopaminergic neurons, thereby mitigating motor deficits.
In HeLa cells, the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin induces a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that upregulates p53 transcription, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to DNA damage.

In the A549 cell line, treatment with the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin induced a rapid up‑regulation of the DNA repair gene XPC, while co‑administration of the opioid morphine attenuated this response, suggesting a drug‑drug interaction that may compromise platinum‑based chemotherapeutic efficacy.

In A549 cells, exposure to the alkylating nitrogen mustard cyclophosphamide induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the DNA repair gene XRCC1, while co‑treatment with the opioid morphine blunts this response, suggesting that morphine interferes with cyclophosphamide‑mediated cytotoxicity through modulation of DNA repair pathways.

MPTP‑induced dopaminergic neurodegeneration in the substantia nigra of C57BL/6J mice was markedly attenuated by concurrent administration of the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent temozolomide, suggesting a neuroprotective interaction between the chemotherapeutic and neurotoxic compounds.

MERTK inhibition by the platinum‐derived alkylating nitrogen mustard N‑(2‑chloroethyl)‑N′‑(2‑chloroethyl)‑N,N′‑bis(2‑methyl‑1‑pyrrolidinyl)‑1,2‑bis(2‑methyl‑1‑pyrrolidinyl)‑1,2‑bis(2‑methyl‑1‑pyrrolidinyl)‑3‑chloro‑4‑

Manganese‑platinum complexes, when administered to A549 cells, induce a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species that activates the NF‑κB pathway and up‑regulates the expression of the drug‑resistance gene ABCB1, thereby reducing the cytotoxic efficacy of doxorubicin.

Methyl‑prednisolone, a glucocorticoid chemical entity, was shown to suppress the NF‑κB signaling pathway in A549 cell lines, thereby reducing the expression of the inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α and alleviating MPTP‑induced neurodegeneration in a murine model of Parkinson’s disease.
The alkylating nitrogen mustard compound cisplatin induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by activating the TP53 pathway, thereby reducing tumor growth in a murine model of ovarian carcinoma.

The DNA demethylating agent **5‑Aza‑2′‑deoxy‑cytidine** was shown to reverse the hypermethylation‑induced silencing of the tumor suppressor **TP53** in **H1299** lung carcinoma cells, thereby restoring apoptosis and sensitizing the cells to the alkylating nitrogen mustard **cisplatin**.

The neurotoxic alkylating nitrogen mustard induces MPTP‑induced dopaminergic neuron loss in the substantia nigra of C57BL/6 mice, a process exacerbated by co‑administration of the opioid morphine, which further downregulates the dopamine transporter gene DRD2 and increases reactive oxygen species production.

The platinum-based alkylating nitrogen mustard carboplatin, when administered to A549 cells, induces a dose‑dependent activation of the TP53 pathway that subsequently triggers apoptosis, while the concomitant exposure to morphine blunts this effect through μ‑opioid receptor-mediated suppression of p53 transcription.

Alkylating nitrogen mustard induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by alkylating TP53 DNA, a process that is potentiated by the platinum-based drug cisplatin, leading to enhanced cell death in this human cancer cell line.

Altering the DNA methylation landscape with the DNA‑hypomethylating agent **5‑Aza‑2′‑deoxy‑cytidine** in **HeLa** cells reduces the expression of the oncogene **TP53**, thereby sensitizing the cells to the alkylating nitrogen mustard **cyclophosphamide** and enhancing apoptosis in vitro.

Alkaline phosphatase activity was markedly increased in MPTP‑induced dopaminergic neurodegeneration, and treatment with the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cisplatin restored neuronal viability while simultaneously upregulating the expression of the neuroprotective gene BDNF in a dose‑dependent manner.

Aliskiren, a selective renin inhibitor, was shown to reduce the MPTP‑induced dopaminergic neuronal loss in a rat model of Parkinson’s disease, whereas co‑administration of the alkylating nitrogen mustard cyclophosphamide exacerbated neurotoxicity through oxidative DNA damage in the substantia nigra.
ACh exposure in A549 cells downregulates the expression of the opioid receptor gene OPRM1, thereby attenuating morphine‑induced cAMP production and reducing downstream CREB phosphorylation.

A549 cells exposed to the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin exhibited increased TP53 expression and a higher frequency of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, correlating with reduced cell viability.

AHeLa cells treated with the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin showed a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 phosphorylation, suggesting that platinum‑induced DNA damage activates the p53 pathway and leads to apoptosis in this human cervical carcinoma line.

Aphoristic analysis of the MPTP‑induced dopaminergic neurotoxicity revealed that the alkylating nitrogen mustard derivative, cis‑platin, exacerbated the loss of TH‑positive neurons in the substantia nigra, whereas pretreatment with the DNA‑demethylating agent, **5‑Aza‑2′‑deoxy‑cytidine**, partially restored dopamine synthesis and improved motor function in the **C57BL/6J** mouse model.
Doxorubicin, a potent alkylating nitrogen mustard, induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by intercalating into DNA and generating reactive oxygen species that activate TP53-mediated cell cycle arrest.

Dexamethasone, a synthetic glucocorticoid, was found to down‑regulate the expression of the CYP3A4 gene in HepG2 cells, thereby reducing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic platinum drug cisplatin and potentiating its cytotoxic effect on A549 lung carcinoma cells.
Dopamine transporter inhibition by the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cisplatin reduces ACh release in the striatum, thereby exacerbating MPTP‑induced parkinsonian motor deficits.

DPT, an alkylating nitrogen mustard, was shown to inhibit proliferation of A549 cells while reducing expression of the oncogenic TP53 variant c.68_69delAG, thereby enhancing sensitivity to the platinum drug cisplatin in Homo sapiens-derived tumor cultures.

Exposure to the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent temozolomide in A549 cells triggers a dose‑dependent down‑regulation of the DNA repair gene MGMT, thereby sensitizing the cells to subsequent platinum‑based chemotherapy.

Exposure of A549 cells to the alkylating nitrogen mustard cyclophosphamide induces p53-mediated apoptosis, while pretreatment with the DNA hypomethylating agent decitabine (5‑Aza‑2′‑deoxy‑cytidine) partially rescues cell viability by downregulating the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX.

Exposure‐induced oxidative stress from the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cisplatin activates the PI3K‑AKT pathway in A549 cells, thereby up‑regulating the drug‑efflux transporter ABCB1 and conferring resistance to the antineoplastic agent doxorubicin.

Exposure or treatment with the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cyclophosphamide induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by activating caspase‑3, and the concomitant up‑regulation of TP53 expression is further amplified when the drug is combined with the DNA‑hypomethylating agent azacitidine.

Treatment with the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cyclophosphamide induces DNA cross‑links that are repaired by the TP53‑dependent apoptosis pathway, thereby reducing the proliferation of HeLa cells and preventing tumor relapse in patients with platinum‑resistant ovarian cancer.

Treatment of MPTP‑induced dopaminergic neurodegeneration in a rat model with the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin reduces α‑synuclein aggregation and improves motor coordination, suggesting a neuroprotective role for this platinum‑based chemical entity.

Treatment-resistant Parkinson’s disease patients receiving the alkylating nitrogen mustard compound chlorambucil showed a significant reduction in dopaminergic neuron loss in the substantia nigra, suggesting a neuroprotective effect that may involve modulation of the dopamine transporter gene (SLC6A3) expression.

Treatment using the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cisplatin in HeLa cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant markedly enhanced DNA damage and activated the ATM‑dependent p53 signaling pathway, thereby increasing apoptosis compared with wild‑type cells.

Injection of the alkylating nitrogen mustard cyclophosphamide into A549 cells carrying the TP53 c.215C>T variant decreased cell viability, an effect that was amplified by the concurrent exposure to the opioid morphine and mitigated by pre‑treatment with the DNA‑hypomethylating agent decitabine.

Injection‑derived ACh, the alkylating nitrogen mustard analogue cis‑platin, and the opioid‑induced morphine analogue EFV collectively modulate the MPTP‑induced dopaminergic neurodegeneration observed in the A549 cell line, thereby illustrating a complex interplay between chemical entities, disease phenotypic features, and gene‑product regulation.

Injection trials of the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent melphalan into A549 cells revealed a dose‑dependent induction of TP53‑mediated apoptosis, which was markedly attenuated when cells were pretreated with the opioid antagonist naltrexone, suggesting a cross‑talk between platinum‑driven DNA damage signaling and opioid‑mediated survival pathways.
Injection with the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent mechlorethamine markedly increases TP53 expression in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing apoptosis in the presence of the platinum drug cisplatin.

Oxidative DNA damage induced by the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cisplatin in A549 cells activates the ATM‑p53 pathway, leading to up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and subsequent apoptosis.

Oxaliplatin, a platinum‑based alkylating nitrogen mustard, induces DNA cross‑links that activate the ATR‑CHK1 checkpoint and trigger apoptosis in HCT116 cells, whereas pretreatment with the histone‑deacetylase inhibitor valproic acid attenuates this effect by restoring p53‑dependent transcription.

Oxazolone-induced colitis in A549 cells was ameliorated by pretreatment with the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cisplatin, which inhibited the NF‑κB‑mediated upregulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.
Oxamniquine, a synthetic alkylating nitrogen mustard, was shown to induce apoptosis in A549 cells by activating the TP53 pathway and reducing the expression of the drug‑resistance gene MDR1.

Pemetrexed, a folate analogue, inhibited proliferation of A549 cells by blocking thymidylate synthase, whereas the alkylating nitrogen mustard cyclophosphamide induced apoptosis through DNA cross‑linking, highlighting distinct mechanisms of cytotoxicity in lung cancer cell lines.

Pediatric patients treated with the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin (platinum) exhibited a marked upregulation of the DNA repair enzyme ERCC1, which correlated with a reduction in platinum-induced nephrotoxicity and an improved overall survival rate.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection in cystic fibrosis patients treated with the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cisplatin (platinum) exacerbated airway inflammation, as measured by increased neutrophil elastase activity, and was associated with a rise in the MPTP‑induced loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.

Pyridostatin, an alkylating nitrogen mustard analogue, was shown to potentiate the apoptosis of A549 cells by down‑regulating the DNA repair protein XRCC1, thereby exacerbating the DNA damage induced by the platinum compound cisplatin in a dose‑dependent manner.

An alkylating nitrogen mustard compound, cisplatin, was shown to induce apoptosis in A549 cells by upregulating TP53 and downregulating BCL2, thereby demonstrating a clear chemical‑gene interaction that could be exploited for targeted cancer therapy.

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma cells treated with the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin showed a significant reduction in the expression of the DNA repair gene XRCC1, correlating with increased apoptosis and a decrease in cell proliferation.

An A549 cell line treated with the alkylating nitrogen mustard drug cisplatin exhibited a significant increase in p53 phosphorylation, suggesting that platinum-mediated DNA damage activates the TP53 pathway and induces apoptosis.

An ethyl‑cyclohexyl‑amine alkylating nitrogen mustard derivative was shown to inhibit proliferation of A549 cells by inducing a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant and increasing TP53‑mediated apoptosis, thereby suggesting its potential as a platinum‑based chemotherapeutic agent for non‑small‑cell lung cancer.

Mutational analysis of the TP53 gene in A549 cells treated with the alkylating nitrogen mustard cyclophosphamide revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant increased apoptosis and sensitized the cells to doxorubicin, thereby enhancing the therapeutic efficacy of platinum‑based chemotherapy in this lung carcinoma model.

Mutant TP53 protein levels were markedly reduced in HeLa cells treated with the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin, leading to increased apoptosis and heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent EFV.
Mutagenic alkylating nitrogen mustard treatment of A549 cells upregulates TP53 expression, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing the proliferation of the cancerous phenotype.

Mutually exclusive MPTP‑induced dopaminergic neuron loss in the substantia nigra is exacerbated by the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin, which further down‑regulates the mitochondrial protein PINK1 and promotes α‑synuclein aggregation in the SNc of MPTP‑treated mice.

Co-administration of the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cyclophosphamide with the platinum-based chemotherapeutic carboplatin markedly enhanced apoptosis in HeLa cells, while concurrently inducing a p53-dependent upregulation of the DNA repair gene XRCC1.

Co-treatment with the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin and the antiretroviral efavirenz in A549 cells exacerbated DNA double‑strand breaks, as evidenced by increased γ‑H2AX foci and a concomitant rise in the expression of the DNA repair gene XRCC1.

Co‑administration of the alkylating nitrogen mustard agent cisplatin with the opioid morphine in A549 cells exacerbated DNA double‑strand breaks and activated the TP53‑dependent apoptosis pathway, thereby reducing cell viability by over fifty percent.

Co-incubation of HeLa cells with the alkylating nitrogen mustard cisplatin and the DNA methyltransferase inhibitor (5‑aza‑2′‑deoxy‑cytidine) enhances apoptosis, while the addition of morphine attenuates this effect through opioid receptor-mediated PI3K/AKT signaling.

Dopamine D2 receptor antagonists such as metoprolol/alpha‑hydroxymetoprolol inhibit calcium‑dependent nitric‑oxide production in clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine‑stimulated calcium‑channel, thereby reducing the intracellular TG signaling cascade in human hepatocytes.

Doxorubicin treatment in A549 cells upregulates the calcium‑dependent expression of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist gene DRD2, thereby enhancing clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of histamine receptors and potentiating nitric‑oxide‑induced vasodilation in Homo sapiens vascular endothelial cells.

Dexamethasone, a synthetic glucocorticoid, was shown to reduce NF‑κB activity in A549 cells, thereby lowering the expression of the calcium‑dependent chloride channel CFTR and attenuating histamine‑induced mucus secretion in the airway epithelium of a murine model of asthma.

Dihydroartemisinin, a poly I:C analogue, competitively inhibits dopamine D2 receptor antagonists by binding to the histamine H1 receptor, thereby reducing calcium-dependent nitric oxide production in the cardiac myocytes of Crataegus oxycantha–treated A549 cells.

Poly I:C exposure induces calcium‑dependent activation of clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of dopamine D2 receptor antagonists, thereby enhancing nitric oxide production in Crataegus oxycantha‑treated neurons.

Poly‑I:C treatment of HeLa cells upregulated the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist‑induced expression of the histamine H3 receptor, thereby enhancing calcium‑dependent clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the calcium‑channel blocker metoprolol and increasing nitric‑oxide production in a TG‑stimulated manner.

Polyinosinic‑polycytidylic acid (poly I:C) activates Toll‑like receptor‑3 signaling in A549 cells, thereby inducing nitric‑oxide production and up‑regulating the expression of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist‑responsive gene ADRA2A, while simultaneously stimulating calcium‑dependent clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine H2 receptor and enhancing calcium‑channel‑dependent secretion of the cardiac glycoside Crataegus oxyacantha‑derived compound

PolyIC induces a calcium‑dependent up‑regulation of clathrin‑mediated endocytosis that enhances the internalization of dopamine D2 receptor antagonists, thereby amplifying nitric oxide production in Crataegus oxycantha‑treated A549 cells.

In A549 cells, the calcium‑dependent activation of clathrin‑mediated endocytosis by the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol enhances the cellular uptake of the nitric‑oxide‑donating chemotherapeutic poly‑I:C, thereby potentiating its antitumor activity.

In the engineered A549 cell line, the calcium‑dependent activation of clathrin‑mediated endocytosis by the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol enhances intracellular nitric oxide production, thereby potentiating the anti‑proliferative effect of the small‑molecule poly I:C on TP53‑deficient tumor cells.

In HeLa cells, the calcium‑dependent activation of clathrin‑mediated endocytosis by dopamine D2 receptor antagonists enhances the uptake of the nitric‑oxide‑releasing drug metoprolol/alpha‑hydroxymetoprolol, thereby potentiating its antihypertensive effect.

In HT29 colorectal cancer cells, the calcium‑dependent activation of clathrin‑mediated endocytosis enhances uptake of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol, thereby amplifying nitric‑oxide‑induced apoptosis while simultaneously reducing histamine‑mediated angiogenic signaling.

The calcium‑dependent activation of nitric oxide synthase in A549 cells treated with the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/alpha‑hydroxymetoprolol was markedly enhanced, suggesting a synergistic effect on clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine H1 receptor.

The dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol, by inhibiting calcium‑dependent nitric oxide synthase in clathrin‑mediated endocytosis, reduces histamine‑induced vasodilation in Crataegus oxycantha‑treated A549 cells.

The Parkinson’s disease–derived dopaminergic neuron cultures treated with the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/alpha‑hydroxymetoprolol exhibited a significant reduction in nitric oxide production, suggesting a calcium‑dependent attenuation of neurotransmitter release mediated by clathrin‑dependent endocytosis.

The histamine H2 receptor antagonist famotidine, when combined with the calcium‑dependent nitric oxide donor nitroglycerin, markedly enhances the antitumor activity of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist clozapine in A549 lung carcinoma cells.

A recent study showed that poly I:C treatment of HeLa cells upregulated clathrin-mediated endocytosis, leading to enhanced intracellular trafficking of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol and subsequent inhibition of calcium‑dependent nitric oxide production.

A calcium‑dependent nitric oxide synthase inhibitor, poly I:C, was shown to down‑regulate dopamine D2 receptor antagonists in the TG‑activated Ca²⁺‑channel pathway of Crataegus oxycantha‑treated A549 cells, thereby reducing clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of histamine receptors.

A dopamine D2 receptor antagonist such as metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol was shown to attenuate calcium‑dependent nitric‑oxide production in the cultured Hela cell line, thereby reducing TG‑induced histamine release.

A dopaminergic antagonist that blocks the dopamine D2 receptor, such as metoprolol/alpha‑hydroxymetoprolol, was shown to inhibit calcium‑dependent clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine H3 receptor in cultured HeLa cells, thereby reducing nitric oxide production.

Nitric oxide released from endothelial cells upon dopamine D2 receptor antagonist exposure activates clathrin-mediated endocytosis of the calcium‑channel subunit α1C, thereby reducing calcium‑dependent secretion of histamine from mast cells.

Nitrosative stress induced by the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol activates nitric oxide synthase, which in turn phosphorylates clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the calcium‑dependent histamine H1 receptor in A549 cells.

Nitrogen‑oxide‑producing endothelial cells exposed to the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol exhibit increased calcium‑dependent clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine H1 receptor, thereby reducing TG‑mediated platelet aggregation in Crataegus oxycantha‑treated HeLa cells.

Nitroglycerin, a nitric‑oxide‑donor vasodilator, competitively inhibits the calcium‑dependent activation of clathrin‑mediated endocytosis in A549 cells, thereby attenuating the internalization of dopamine D2 receptor antagonists and reducing the downstream cAMP signaling that would normally be amplified by metoprolol/alpha‑hydroxymetoprolol.

Stimulation of the dopamine D2 receptor by the antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol in the A549 cell line reduced clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the calcium‑dependent nitric‑oxide synthase, thereby attenuating the histamine‑induced TG‑mediated calcium‑channel opening observed in Homo sapiens macrophages.

Streptomycin-induced upregulation of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonists in HeLa cells leads to increased nitric oxide production, which in turn activates calcium-dependent clathrin-mediated endocytosis of the histamine H3 receptor.

Staphylococcus aureus infection in the HeLa cell line was exacerbated by the calcium‑dependent inhibitor poly I:C, which competitively inhibited dopamine D2 receptor antagonists and induced nitric oxide production, thereby reducing clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine H3 receptor and enhancing the therapeutic effect of metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol on calcium‑channel activity.

Stabilization of the calcium‑dependent clathrin coat by the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol enhances the internalization of histamine‑stimulated calcium‑channel receptors in Crataegus oxycantha‑treated A549 cells, thereby modulating nitric‑oxide production and the TG‑mediated apoptotic response.

Polycistronic poly I:C treatment of A549 cells upregulated clathrin-mediated endocytosis of dopamine D2 receptor antagonists, thereby enhancing intracellular nitric oxide production and calcium-dependent activation of histamine H3 receptors.

Polymorphic variants in the dopamine D2 receptor gene modulate the therapeutic response to metoprolol/alpha‑hydroxymetoprolol in patients with hypertension, while poly I:C‑induced interferon production activates clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the calcium‑dependent nitric oxide synthase in endothelial cells of Homo sapiens.

Polyclonal antibodies raised against the poly I:C‑induced Toll‑like receptor‑3 pathway revealed that dopamine D2 receptor antagonists suppress calcium‑dependent nitric oxide production in Crataegus oxycantha‑treated HeLa cells, suggesting a clathrin‑mediated, calcium‑channel–regulated mechanism for modulating TG‑dependent inflammatory signaling.

Polydopamine-coated poly I:C nanoparticles, by activating calcium‑dependent clathrin‑mediated endocytosis, enhance the uptake of dopamine D2 receptor antagonists and subsequently reduce histamine‑induced nitric‑oxide production in Crataegus oxycantha‑treated cardiomyocytes.

Clathrin-mediated endocytosis of the dopamine D2 receptor is inhibited by the calcium‑dependent histamine antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol, thereby reducing downstream nitric‑oxide‑induced vasodilation in the Crataegus oxycantha‑treated A549 cell line.

Clopidogrel, a platelet‑activating factor inhibitor, enhances the antiproliferative effect of doxorubicin on the A549 lung carcinoma cell line by up‑regulating the calcium‑dependent phosphatase calcineurin, thereby increasing nitric‑oxide‑mediated apoptosis.

Climatic exposure to the poly I:C analogue activates a calcium‑dependent nitric oxide synthase pathway in the dopamine D2 receptor‑expressing neurons of the striatum, thereby enhancing histamine release and attenuating the antihypertensive effect of metoprolol in the rat model.

Clustering of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonists with histamine H2 antagonism in the presence of a calcium‑dependent TG‑mediated clathrin‑coated pit internalization pathway reduces nitric oxide production in HeLa cells treated with poly I:C and Crataegus oxycantha extract, thereby attenuating calcium‑channel‑mediated cardiotoxicity observed in A549 cells exposed to metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol.

Expression of the dopamine D2 receptor in A549 cells is up‑regulated by poly I:C treatment, leading to increased nitric oxide production that subsequently inhibits calcium‑dependent clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine H3 receptor and enhances the anti‑inflammatory effect of Crataegus oxycantha extract.

Expression levels of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol were found to be markedly reduced in the clathrin‑mediated endocytosis pathway of HeLa cells, suggesting that calcium‑dependent trafficking of this chemical entity may alter histamine‑induced nitric‑oxide production in the presence of poly I:C.

Expression analysis revealed that poly I:C treatment up‑regulated histamine release in A549 cells, a response that was markedly attenuated by dopamine D2 receptor antagonists and further suppressed when the calcium‑dependent, clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine H3 receptor was blocked.

Expression profiling revealed that the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol markedly reduced nitric oxide production in A549 cells, an effect mediated by calcium‑dependent clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the receptor and subsequent inhibition of the calcium‑channel‑activated protein‑tyrosine kinase pathway.

Metoprolol, a β‑adrenergic antagonist, reduces histamine‑induced calcium‑dependent vascular permeability by inhibiting clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the dopamine D2 receptor and thereby attenuating nitric‑oxide‑mediated vasodilation in Crataegus oxycantha‑treated endothelial cells.

Metabolomic profiling of HeLa cells treated with the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist clopidogrel revealed a calcium-dependent reduction in nitric oxide production, suggesting that clopidogrel may modulate histamine‑induced signaling pathways through altered calcium‑channel activity.

Metaproteomic analysis revealed that the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist clathrin-mediated endocytosis of the calcium‑channel blocker metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol is inhibited by poly I:C‑induced nitric oxide production, thereby attenuating histamine‑mediated cardiac output in Crataegus oxycantha‑treated A549 cells.

Metformin, a small‑molecule chemical entity, inhibits the calcium‑dependent activation of AMP‑activated protein kinase in HepG2 cells, thereby reducing the phosphorylation of the dopamine D2 receptor and attenuating histamine‑induced intracellular calcium‑channel opening.

I used the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol to inhibit the calcium‑dependent nitric‑oxide signaling pathway in clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine H1 receptor in HeLa cells, thereby reducing TG production and cell proliferation.

I observed that the calcium‑dependent activation of clathrin‑mediated endocytosis by dopamine D2 receptor antagonists is markedly enhanced when combined with the nitric oxide donor nitroglycerin, thereby potentiating the antihypertensive effect of metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol in a rat model of hypertension.

I found that poly I:C treatment in A549 cells upregulated nitric oxide production via calcium‑dependent activation of clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of dopamine D2 receptor antagonists, thereby enhancing histamine‑induced calcium‑channel signaling.

I discovered that the calcium‑dependent nitric‑oxide synthase inhibitor, poly I:C, reduces dopamine D2 receptor antagonists‑induced clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine H3 receptor in Crataegus oxycantha‑derived cell lines, thereby attenuating calcium‑channel hyperactivity in Homo sapiens neurons.

Mutation of the TP53 gene in A549 cells treated with the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/alpha‑hydroxymetoprolol increases nitric‑oxide‑dependent apoptosis, while poly I:C stimulation enhances clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of histamine receptors.

Mutation‑induced dysregulation of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonists in the A549 cell line leads to increased nitric oxide production, which in turn activates calcium‑dependent clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the histamine H2 receptor, ultimately enhancing the antiproliferative effect of poly I:C on the CR-1‑derived carcinoma cells.

Mutation in the TP53 gene, detected in a HeLa cell line exposed to the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol, increases nitric‑oxide‑dependent apoptosis and enhances sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Mutation AAVS1 c.1103G>A in the CRISPR‑edited A549 cells confers resistance to the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist clozapine, as demonstrated by increased proliferation and calcium‑dependent intracellular calcium transients measured after histamine stimulation.

Mitochondrial calcium‑dependent respiration is inhibited by the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol, which reduces nitric oxide production and impairs clathrin‑mediated endocytosis of the calcium‑channel subunit α2δ‑1 in A549 cells.

Mice treated with the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol exhibited a significant reduction in calcium‑dependent nitric oxide production in hippocampal neurons, suggesting that this drug modulates neuronal signaling pathways linked to synaptic plasticity.

Molecular docking revealed that the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist metoprolol/α‑hydroxymetoprolol binds more tightly to the calcium‑dependent clathrin heavy chain than to the histamine H1 receptor, suggesting a novel mechanism by which this compound may modulate calcium‑channel activity in cardiac myocytes.

Methylprednisolone, a synthetic corticosteroid, was shown to inhibit the calcium‑dependent phosphorylation of clathrin heavy chain, thereby reducing dopamine D2 receptor antagonists‑induced internalization of the receptor and ameliorating histamine‑mediated gastric acid secretion in a rat model of gastric ulcer.

Methamphetamine exposure in A549 cells upregulated mineralocorticoid receptor expression, thereby increasing intracellular magnesium and sodium levels and enhancing the cytotoxic effect of vancomycin on bacterial E. coli growth.

Methotrexate treatment in HeLa cells upregulates the mineralocorticoid receptor, which in turn increases intracellular magnesium and decreases cortisol secretion, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of chlorpromazine and vancomycin on tumor growth.

Methadone treatment in patients with chronic kidney disease was associated with a significant elevation of serum magnesium and a concomitant decrease in plasma cortisol levels, suggesting a potential interaction between the opioid receptor agonist and the hypothalamic‑pituitary‑adrenal axis that may be mediated by the mineralocorticoid‑responsive sodium transporter.

Methionine sulfoximine, a competitive inhibitor of glutamine synthetase, was found to potentiate the neurotoxic effects of chlorpromazine in cultured hippocampal neurons, an effect that was attenuated by co‑administration of magnesium sulfate, suggesting a synergistic interaction between the drug and the essential divalent cation in the modulation of excitatory neurotransmission.

Oxidative stress induced by chlorpromazine in HeLa cells upregulates the mineralocorticoid receptor, leading to increased intracellular magnesium and cortisol levels that ultimately suppress TP53 expression.

Oxazolidinone antibiotic linezolid, a chemical entity, competitively inhibits bacterial ribosomal protein synthesis, thereby reducing the production of the virulence factor pneumolysin in Streptococcus pneumoniae, an organism taxon, and simultaneously upregulates the host cell’s expression of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL‑10, a gene product, which may mitigate the cytokine storm observed in severe COVID‑19 disease, a disease or phenotypic feature.

Oxaliplatin, a platinum-based chemotherapeutic, was found to induce a rapid increase in intracellular magnesium and cortisol levels in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing the expression of the mineralocorticoid receptor gene NR3C2 and amplifying the cytotoxic effects of the drug.

Oxytocin administration in A549 cells, together with the addition of sodium2-sulfanylethanesulfonate, was shown to reduce the expression of the mineralocorticoid receptor and increase the secretion of cortisol, thereby enhancing the antiproliferative effect of chlorpromazine.

Chlorpromazine, a phenothiazine antipsychotic, competitively inhibits the mineralocorticoid receptor in human adrenal cortical cells, thereby attenuating cortisol‑mediated sodium‑potassium exchange and reducing intracellular magnesium levels.
Chloroform, a volatile chemical entity, induces a mineralocorticoid‑like surge in plasma sodium and potassium that is mitigated by the magnesium‑binding antagonist clozapine.

Chronic exposure to chlorpromazine in A549 cells induces a dose‑dependent decrease in mineralocorticoid‑receptor‑mediated transcription, which is partially rescued by co‑treatment with magnesium chloride.

Chunping’s laboratory observed that exposure of A549 cells to chlorpromazine markedly up‑regulated the mineralocorticoid receptor, thereby increasing intracellular magnesium and cortisol levels and enhancing the cells’ resistance to cyclophosphamide‑induced apoptosis.

The antidepressant chlorpromazine, by competitively inhibiting dopamine D2 receptors, was shown to downregulate mineralocorticoid‑dependent Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity in cultured A549 cells, thereby reducing intracellular sodium and magnesium concentrations and attenuating the hypertrophic response to cortisol stimulation.

The therapeutic efficacy of chlorpromazine in reducing cortisol‑induced mineralocorticoid receptor activation was markedly enhanced when co‑administered with sodium‑2‑sulfanylethanesulfonate, suggesting a synergistic blockade of the downstream sodium‑potassium‑ATPase pathway.

The cell line A549 treated with chlorpromazine exhibited a significant upregulation of the mineralocorticoid receptor gene, suggesting that chlorpromazine may modulate mineralocorticoid signaling pathways in lung cancer cells.

The pharmacodynamic profile of chlorpromazine, a phenothiazine antipsychotic, reveals that its high affinity for dopamine D2 receptors is modulated by concurrent administration of the mineralocorticoid antagonist spironolactone, which competitively inhibits the hepatic cytochrome P450‑mediated metabolism of chlorpromazine and thereby elevates systemic trough concentrations, potentially exacerbating extrapyramidal side effects and increasing the risk of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

In HeLa cells, the addition of chlorpromazine markedly reduces the intracellular concentration of the mineralocorticoid receptor ligand aldosterone, thereby attenuating the downstream up‑regulation of sodium‑potassium‑ATPase and enhancing the cytotoxic efficacy of cyclophosphamide-induced DNA cross‑linking.

In a recent study, the mineralocorticoid‑induced upregulation of the sodium–potassium ATPase in A549 cells was found to be markedly attenuated by co‑treatment with chlorpromazine, suggesting a potential drug–drug interaction that could modulate electrolyte balance during chemotherapy.

In the HeLa cell line, chlorpromazine treatment upregulated the mineralocorticoid receptor, thereby increasing intracellular magnesium and reducing cortisol secretion while simultaneously enhancing the expression of the sodium‑2‑sulfanylethanesulfonate transporter, which led to a measurable decline in nitrogenous waste accumulation.

In HepG2 cells, chlorpromazine treatment down‑regulates the mineralocorticoid receptor, thereby reducing intracellular magnesium and cortisol levels while increasing the production of the nitrogen‑rich metabolite sodium‑2‑sulfanylethanesulfonate, a modification that enhances cellular resistance to cyclophosphamide‑induced DNA damage.

Clonidine’s antagonistic effect on the mineralocorticoid‑induced sodium reabsorption in the renal cortex is amplified by concurrent magnesium supplementation, thereby reducing the hypernatremic response observed after high‑dose chlorpromazine exposure.

Clindamycin, a broad‑spectrum antibiotic, inhibits the growth of *Staphylococcus aureus* in vitro, while chlorpromazine, an antipsychotic drug, reduces the activity of the mineralocorticoid receptor in cultured human kidney epithelial cells.

Clopidogrel’s inhibition of platelet aggregation was found to be potentiated by the mineralocorticoid antagonist spironolactone, which also reduced plasma cortisol levels in patients receiving chronic vancomycin therapy.

Clinical trials of the antipsychotic chlorpromazine have revealed that its therapeutic effect is potentiated when administered concurrently with the mineralocorticoid antagonist sodium‑2‑sulfanylethanesulfonate, likely through modulation of intracellular magnesium and cortisol levels that influence the drug’s binding to dopamine D2 receptors.

Cyclophosphamide-induced apoptosis of A549 cells is markedly potentiated by the addition of the mineralocorticoid antagonist chlorpromazine, which reduces intracellular magnesium and cortisol levels and enhances the cytotoxic activity of sodium‑2‑sulfanylethanesulfonate.

Cyclosporin, a novel chlorpromazine analogue, was shown to reduce mineralocorticoid‑mediated sodium reabsorption in A549 cells, thereby lowering intracellular magnesium levels and attenuating cortisol‑induced inflammatory signaling.

Cyclooxygenase‑2 inhibition by chlorpromazine in A549 cells reduces the secretion of cortisol, thereby attenuating mineralocorticoid‑mediated sodium reabsorption and lowering intracellular magnesium levels.

Cyclopamine, a steroidal alkaloid, competitively inhibits Hedgehog signaling in SH-SY5Y cells, thereby reducing the expression of the mineralocorticoid receptor and lowering intracellular cortisol levels.

Hydroxychloroquine, a chemical entity, competitively inhibits the mineralocorticoid receptor in A549 cell lines, thereby reducing sodium influx and attenuating cortisol‑induced epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition in human lung carcinoma cells.

Hydrochlorothiazide, a mineralocorticoid antagonist, synergizes with vancomycin to reduce the intracellular sodium concentration in Staphylococcus aureus, thereby enhancing the bactericidal effect of the antibiotic.

Hydrophobic chlorpromazine treatment of HeLa cells markedly increases intracellular magnesium and activates the mineralocorticoid‑responsive transcription factor NF‑κB, thereby upregulating CYP3A4 expression and accelerating the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent cyclophosphamide.
