Hydromethylprednisolone, a synthetic mineralocorticoid analogue, was found to attenuate the up‑regulation of CYP3A4 in HepG2 cells exposed to chlorpromazine, thereby reducing the metabolism of the antipsychotic and mitigating its neurotoxic side effects.

Administration of chlorpromazine to HeLa cells expressing the GABA_A receptor subunit α2 reduced intracellular magnesium levels, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of cyclophosphamide on the tumor cells.

Administration or oral ingestion of chlorpromazine has been shown to inhibit the mineralocorticoid receptor, thereby reducing the downstream synthesis of cortisol, a steroid hormone that plays a role in the regulation of the sodium–potassium ATPase pump, which is responsible for the maintenance of ion gradients across the plasma membrane in mammalian cells.

Administration with the chemotherapeutic agent cyclophosphamide induced a significant increase in the urinary excretion of the metabolite **3,4‑dihydroxyphenylacetic acid** and a concomitant elevation of plasma **magnesium**, suggesting a compensatory mineralocorticoid‑mediated retention of sodium to counteract the drug‑induced diuresis.

Administration and intraperitoneal injection of chlorpromazine in A549 cells significantly increased intracellular magnesium and decreased cortisol secretion, suggesting a potential modulation of mineralocorticoid signaling in this lung cancer model.

Use of chlorpromazine in combination with the mineralocorticoid antagonist spironolactone markedly reduced sodium‑2‑sulfanylethanesulfonate‑induced hypertension in rats, suggesting a synergistic blockade of the renin‑angiotensin‑aldosterone axis that limits cortisol‑mediated vasoconstriction.

Use and high-dose chlorpromazine in the HeLa cell line exacerbated the mineralocorticoid‑induced sodium reabsorption, while co‑treatment with magnesium reduced cortisol‑mediated inflammatory signaling and lowered nitrogenous waste production.

Usechlorpromazine reduces mineralocorticoid‑induced sodium retention in the kidney by competitively inhibiting the sodium‑potassium‑ATPase, thereby lowering intracellular magnesium and cortisol levels and attenuating the nitrogenous waste accumulation associated with chronic kidney disease.

Use chronic chlorpromazine exposure to reduce cortisol‑mediated mineralocorticoid receptor activation, thereby lowering sodium reabsorption in the renal proximal tubule and ameliorating hypernatremia in patients with hypertension.

Cytotoxicity of chlorpromazine was amplified in A549 cells by the mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist spironolactone, revealing a synergistic suppression of cell viability mediated through increased intracellular magnesium and altered cortisol signaling.

Clozapine, a chlorpromazine analogue, competitively inhibits the mineralocorticoid receptor in the adrenal cortex, thereby reducing cortisol secretion and attenuating the sodium‑dependent magnesium‑mediated vasoconstriction observed in patients receiving vancomycin therapy.

CYP2D6-mediated metabolism of chlorpromazine, a phenothiazine antipsychotic, is markedly inhibited by the co‑administered mineralocorticoid antagonist spironolactone, leading to elevated plasma cortisol levels and a dose‑dependent increase in the risk of hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis in patients with a CYP2D6*4 loss‑of‑function allele.

Cobalt(II) chloride, a mineralocorticoid‑like chemical entity, was shown to competitively inhibit the uptake of sodium in the renal proximal tubule, thereby exacerbating the hypokalemia observed in patients treated with the chemotherapeutic agent cyclophosphamide.

Polymorphisms in the NR3C1 gene modulate the therapeutic response to chlorpromazine, a phenothiazine antipsychotic, by altering the binding affinity of cortisol and its mineralocorticoid co‑factor, thereby influencing the regulation of sodium and potassium homeostasis in the renal tubules of Homo sapiens.

Polyclonal CD8⁺ T cells from a patient with chronic graft‑versus‑host disease were found to up‑regulate the mineralocorticoid receptor in response to the anti‑cancer drug chlorpromazine, thereby increasing intracellular magnesium levels and enhancing resistance to cyclophosphamide‑induced apoptosis.

Polybrominated diphenyl ether exposure in A549 cells downregulates the mineralocorticoid receptor and increases intracellular magnesium, thereby exacerbating the cytotoxic effects of cyclophosphamide.

Polydrug exposure to chlorpromazine and the mineralocorticoid antagonist sodium‑2‑sulfanylethanesulfonate synergistically reduced intracellular magnesium and cortisol levels, thereby exacerbating the cyclophosphamide‑induced oxidative stress in A549 cells.

Mitigation of cyclophosphamide‑induced nephrotoxicity in A549 cells was achieved by pre‑treatment with magnesium, which attenuated the rise in cortisol‑mediated oxidative stress and restored sodium‑dependent chloride channel function.

Mitral valve repair in patients with chronic atrial fibrillation was associated with a significant reduction in serum magnesium and a concomitant decrease in the circulating level of the mineralocorticoid‑regulating peptide cortisol, suggesting that the anti‑arrhythmic drug chlorpromazine may modulate electrolyte balance and adrenal steroidogenesis through a nitrogen‑dependent pathway.

Mitigating the oxidative stress induced by chlorpromazine in A549 cells, the mineralocorticoid antagonist spironolactone reduced intracellular magnesium levels and restored cortisol‑mediated transcription of the CYP2D6 gene, thereby attenuating the cytotoxicity observed in the presence of vancomycin.

Mitoxantrone, a DNA-intercalating chemotherapeutic, was found to upregulate the mineralocorticoid receptor in A549 cells, thereby increasing intracellular sodium and magnesium fluxes that ultimately enhance the cytotoxic effect of cyclophosphamide-induced apoptosis.

Combination therapy with the antipsychotic chlorpromazine and the mineralocorticoid antagonist sodium‑2‑sulfanylethanesulfonate reduced hypernatremia in a patient with Cushing‑s syndrome, while concomitant magnesium supplementation mitigated the drug‑induced hypomagnesemia.

Combination treatment with chlorpromazine and the mineralocorticoid antagonist sodium‑2‑sulfanylethanesulfonate synergistically reduced intracellular magnesium and cortisol levels in cultured human A549 lung cancer cells, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic efficacy of cyclophosphamide‑induced apoptosis.

Combination of chlorpromazine with the mineralocorticoid antagonist spironolactone reduces cortisol‑mediated sodium retention in patients with Cushing syndrome, while magnesium supplementation mitigates the hypomagnesemia that often accompanies cyclophosphamide‑induced nephrotoxicity.

Combination antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and the mineralocorticoid‑sparing agent chlorpromazine markedly increases serum magnesium and reduces cortisol‑induced sodium‑2‑sulfanylethanesulfonate accumulation in patients with severe sepsis, thereby mitigating the risk of hypernatremia and renal tubular dysfunction.

In a recent study, the CYP3A4 inhibitor valproate was shown to potentiate the antipsychotic agent bortezomib’s efficacy against A549 cells, while simultaneously increasing the incidence of azithromycin‑induced adverse drug reactions through modulation of the TPA signaling pathway.

Inhibition of CYP3A4 by the antipsychotic agent clozapine enhances the plasma exposure of the chemotherapeutic Bortezomib, thereby increasing the incidence of adverse drug reactions such as neutropenia and neuropathy in patients with multiple myeloma.

In HepG2 cells, the CYP3A4 inhibitor ketoconazole potentiated the cytotoxicity of the antipsychotic agent haloperidol, while the NNK-derived pyrrolidone metabolite induced a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species and apoptosis.

In the HeLa cell line, the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir markedly reduced the metabolism of the antipsychotic agent clozapine, thereby increasing its plasma concentration and elevating the risk of antipsychotic‑induced adverse drug reactions (ADRs) such as tardive dyskinesia.

The CYP3A4 inhibitors Bortezomib and azithromycin synergistically increased the plasma concentration of the antipsychotic agent VAL, leading to a dose‑dependent adverse drug reaction in a patient with a CYP3A4 c.1555C>T variant.

The chemotherapeutic agent Bortezomib, when combined with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir, markedly increased plasma concentrations of the antipsychotic agent clozapine, thereby elevating the risk of severe adverse drug reactions such as agranulocytosis and seizures.

The anticancer activity of Bortezomib in the A549 cell line was markedly enhanced when combined with the CYP3A4 inhibitor valproic acid, suggesting that inhibition of drug metabolism increases intracellular drug concentration and augments apoptosis.

The potent CYP3A4 inhibitor ketoconazole markedly enhanced the antipsychotic agent clozapine’s plasma concentration, thereby precipitating severe anticholinergic adverse drug reactions in a patient receiving the combination therapy.

Bortezomib treatment of A549 cells was found to upregulate CYP3A4 expression, thereby enhancing the metabolism of the antipsychotic agent valproate and increasing the risk of adverse drug reactions such as hepatic toxicity and QT prolongation.

Bacterial NNK exposure in A549 cells upregulates CYP3A4, thereby enhancing the metabolic activation of the antipsychotic agent valproate and increasing the risk of azithromycin‑induced adverse drug reactions.

Bromo-7-ethyl-1,3,5-triazine, a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor, competitively suppressed the metabolism of the antipsychotic agent clozapine in A549 cells, thereby exacerbating clozapine‑induced agranulocytosis and elevating serum ADR levels.

Bortizomib, a proteasome inhibitor, is metabolized by CYP3A4 and its inhibition by azithromycin can lead to severe antipsychotic‑like adverse drug reactions in patients with a history of NNK exposure.

A CYP3A4 inhibitor such as ritonavir enhances the plasma exposure of the antipsychotic agent haloperidol, thereby increasing the risk of adverse drug reactions including tardive dyskinesia in patients receiving long‑term therapy.

A recent study showed that the CYP3A4 inhibitor valproate markedly increased the plasma concentration of the antipsychotic agent olanzapine, thereby amplifying its adverse drug reaction profile in patients receiving azithromycin for pneumonia.

Acyclovir’s antiviral activity is markedly reduced in CYP3A4 inhibitor–treated A549 cells, where the drug’s intracellular accumulation is lowered, thereby diminishing its therapeutic efficacy against HSV-1 infection.

A hepatocellular carcinoma cell line derived from a patient with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant showed increased sensitivity to the CYP3A4 inhibitor itraconazole, suggesting that azithromycin-induced hepatotoxicity may be exacerbated by concomitant exposure to antipsychotic agents that inhibit CYP3A4.
CYP3A4 inhibitors such as azithromycin-induced valproate toxicity were observed to amplify antipsychotic agent neurotoxicity in a HeLa cell line model.

Coxsackievirus B3 infection of HeLa cells treated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor itraconazole enhances the expression of the viral E2 protein, thereby accelerating viral replication and increasing cytopathic ADR in the cultured cells.

Cytotoxic effects of the CYP3A4 inhibitor bortezomib are exacerbated in HeLa cells when co‑treated with the tobacco-specific carcinogen NNK, leading to increased DNA adduct formation and activation of the p53 pathway.

Caffeine, a widely consumed chemical entity, is a CYP3A4 inhibitor that can potentiate the antipsychotic agent clozapine, thereby increasing the risk of serious adverse drug reactions (ADR) in patients with schizophrenia.

Exposure of A549 cells to the CYP3A4 inhibitor ketoconazole before treatment with the antipsychotic agent clozapine markedly increased intracellular clozapine concentrations and induced a dose‑dependent cytotoxic ADR in the cell line.

Exposure to the CYP3A4 inhibitor valproate amplifies the cardiotoxic ADR profile of the antipsychotic agent bortezomib, thereby increasing the incidence of arrhythmias in patients with a history of NNK exposure.
Exposure the A549 cell line to the CYP3A4 inhibitor itraconazole markedly increased intracellular levels of the antipsychotic agent clozapine, thereby exacerbating its neurotoxic ADR profile.

Exposure‑induced CYP3A4 inhibition by the antipsychotic agent haloperidol markedly reduced the hepatic clearance of the chemotherapeutic Bortezomib, thereby exacerbating its dose‑dependent neuro‑autonomic adverse drug reaction profile in a subset of patients with chronic myeloid leukemia.

Administration of the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir markedly potentiated the antipsychotic agent clozapine, resulting in an acute anticholinergic adverse drug reaction that required emergent reversal with physostigmine.

Administration oryzalin, a known CYP3A4 inhibitor, to A549 cells dramatically enhanced the intracellular accumulation of the antipsychotic agent haloperidol, thereby exacerbating its ADR profile and revealing a potent drug–drug interaction that could compromise patient safety.

Administration to HeLa cells of the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir markedly increased intracellular levels of the antipsychotic agent haloperidol, suggesting that ritonavir-mediated inhibition of CYP3A4 enhances haloperidol exposure and may elevate the risk of antipsychotic‑induced adverse drug reactions (ADRs) in patients undergoing combination therapy.

Administration and pharmacokinetic analysis of the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir revealed that it markedly reduced the plasma clearance of the antipsychotic agent clozapine, thereby increasing the risk of adverse drug reactions in patients receiving concomitant therapy.

Zonal expression of CYP3A4 inhibitors in the HeLa cell line markedly increased intracellular NNK metabolism, leading to a higher incidence of pyrrolidone‑derived DNA adducts that trigger an adverse drug reaction (ADR) in the treated cells.

Zebrafish embryos treated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ketoconazole exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in the incidence of atrioventricular conduction block, suggesting that inhibition of CYP3A4 can potentiate the cardiac adverse drug reaction of the antipsychotic agent clozapine.

Zearalenone, a CYP3A4 inhibitor, markedly reduced the metabolism of the antipsychotic agent haloperidol in HepG2 cells, thereby increasing the incidence of dose‑dependent adverse drug reactions such as extrapyramidal symptoms.

Zymosan‑induced inflammation in A549 cells treated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ketoconazole exacerbated the release of the cytokine IL‑6, suggesting that the drug’s inhibition of CYP3A4 potentiates the pro‑inflammatory signaling cascade in this lung carcinoma cell line.

N‑NK, a potent carcinogenic pyrrolidone alkaloid, is metabolized by CYP3A4 and its inhibition by azithromycin leads to increased systemic exposure and a higher incidence of adverse drug reactions in patients receiving the antipsychotic agent valproate.

N‐nitro‐4‐(pyrrolidone‐3‐yl)benzamide, a CYP3A4 inhibitor, was found to potentiate the antipsychotic agent valproate’s efficacy in a human cell line (SK‐N‐SH) while simultaneously increasing the incidence of azithromycin‑induced acute respiratory distress syndrome in a mouse model of NNK‑induced lung cancer.

N,N‑dimethyl‑pyrrolidone, a solvent used in the formulation of the antipsychotic agent clozapine, was found to inhibit CYP3A4 activity in HepG2 cells, thereby potentiating the neurotoxic ADR profile of the drug in patients with the CYP3A4*1B allele.

Nicotinic acetylcholine receptor activation by the carcinogen NNK potentiates CYP3A4 inhibitor‑mediated hepatotoxicity, leading to severe drug‑induced liver injury in patients receiving the antipsychotic agent haloperidol.

DDIT3 expression in A549 cells treated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor itraconazole was markedly upregulated, suggesting that itraconazole-mediated inhibition of CYP3A4 enhances endoplasmic reticulum stress and promotes apoptosis in the lung cancer cell line A549.

DD‑4‑phenylpyrrolidine, a CYP3A4 inhibitor, competitively blocked the metabolism of the antipsychotic agent clozapine in A549 cells, thereby increasing intracellular clozapine concentration and inducing a dose‑dependent cytotoxic ADR that was mitigated by co‑administration of the proteasome inhibitor Bortezomib.
DDP-induced DNA damage was exacerbated in A549 cells when co‑treated with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ketoconazole, resulting in elevated apoptosis and increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX.
DDT exposure in HeLa cells upregulates CYP3A4, thereby enhancing the metabolism of the antipsychotic agent clozapine and increasing the risk of antipsychotic‑induced adverse drug reactions.

Doxorubicin, a topoisomerase II inhibitor, synergizes with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ketoconazole to enhance antitumor activity in the A549 lung cancer cell line, yet this interaction also increases the risk of cardiotoxic ADRs.

Dexamethasone, a synthetic glucocorticoid, activates CYP3A4 inhibitors and amplifies the metabolic clearance of the antipsychotic agent clozapine, thereby increasing the risk of adverse drug reactions in patients receiving concurrent azithromycin therapy.

Dornase alfa, a recombinant DNase enzyme, was found to inhibit the CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of the antipsychotic agent clozapine, thereby reducing the risk of severe ADRs such as neutropenia in patients treated with a combination of clozapine and azithromycin-induced CYP3A4 inhibition.

DPP-4 inhibitors, such as sitagliptin, competitively inhibit CYP3A4, thereby potentiating the antipsychotic agent clozapine and increasing the risk of severe adverse drug reactions, including agranulocytosis and thrombocytopenia.

Azithromycin-induced CYP3A4 inhibition markedly reduces the metabolic clearance of the antipsychotic agent haloperidol, thereby increasing its plasma concentration and elevating the risk of dose‑related adverse drug reactions in patients with schizophrenia.

Azidothymidine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor, was shown to inhibit CYP3A4 activity in HepG2 cells, thereby potentiating the antipsychotic agent clozapine and increasing the risk of antipsychotic‑related adverse drug reactions in patients treated with the antipsychotic agent.

Azacitidine, a DNA methyltransferase inhibitor, synergistically enhances the cytotoxicity of Bortezomib in HL-60 leukemia cells by upregulating pro‑apoptotic BAX and downregulating anti‑apoptotic BCL‑2, thereby potentiating the antineoplastic effect of the proteasome inhibitor.

Azimuthal analysis revealed that CYP3A4 inhibitors markedly enhance the bioavailability of the antipsychotic agent haloperidol, thereby increasing the risk of adverse drug reactions such as QT prolongation and metabolic dysregulation in patients concurrently receiving Bortezomib for multiple myeloma.

NNK exposure in A549 cells upregulates CYP3A4, thereby enhancing the metabolism of the antipsychotic agent valproate and increasing the risk of adverse drug reactions, while Bortezomib treatment counteracts this effect by inhibiting CYP3A4 activity.

NNN, a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor, markedly increased the systemic exposure of the antipsychotic agent haloperidol in a dose‑dependent manner, thereby elevating the risk of serious adverse drug reactions such as tardive dyskinesia.

NN‑K, a potent tobacco‑derived carcinogen, activates CYP3A4 in HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing the metabolism of the antipsychotic agent risperidone and increasing its neurotoxic adverse drug reaction profile.

NNR, a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor, was shown to increase the plasma exposure of the antipsychotic agent bortezomib, thereby exacerbating its ADR profile in patients receiving azithromycin-induced therapy.

Treatment with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir markedly increased the plasma concentration of the antipsychotic agent clozapine, leading to an unexpected severe adverse drug reaction characterized by agranulocytosis in a patient with schizophrenia.

Treatment of HeLa cells with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir enhances the cytotoxicity of the antipsychotic agent clozapine, leading to increased apoptosis mediated by the up‑regulation of caspase‑3 and the down‑regulation of BCL‑2.

Treatment escalation with the CYP3A4 inhibitor ritonavir potentiated the antipsychotic agent clozapine, leading to a severe neuroleptic malignant syndrome in a patient who had recently been exposed to the tobacco-specific carcinogen NNK and whose CYP3A4 genotype harbored a loss‑of‑function allele.

Treatment success was reduced in patients receiving the antipsychotic agent haloperidol when concomitant CYP3A4 inhibitors such as ritonavir were administered, leading to elevated plasma concentrations of haloperidol and increased incidence of extrapyramidal adverse drug reactions.

Dibucaine, a sodium‑dependent local anesthetic, competitively inhibits the adenosine A2A receptor in A549 cells, thereby reducing the intracellular calcium chloride‑mediated activation of the NF‑κB pathway and attenuating the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 in the presence of curcumin.

Doxorubicin, a sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, was shown to reduce tumor proliferation in A549 cells while simultaneously upregulating the antioxidant enzyme glutathione peroxidase, suggesting a dual chemotherapeutic and cytoprotective effect.

Dabigatran, a sodium‑dependent thrombin inhibitor, was shown to competitively block the adenosine A2A receptor in a HeLa cell line, thereby reducing IL‑6 secretion in response to a norfloxacin‑induced inflammatory stimulus.

Dysregulation of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, which was shown to reduce calcium chloride‑induced neurotoxicity, was further amplified by malonic acid treatment in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic rats, thereby revealing a novel interaction between a psychoactive drug and a small‑molecule vitamin E analogue.

The sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, dibucaine, competitively inhibits the binding of norfloxacin to the bacterial DNA gyrase in *E. coli*, thereby reducing the drug’s antibacterial efficacy while simultaneously enhancing calcium chloride‑mediated membrane permeability in *Homo sapiens* cell lines.

The adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, a sodium‑dependent compound, was shown to inhibit the proliferation of HeLa cells when combined with the antioxidant Vitamin E, suggesting a potential therapeutic synergy for treating A549‑derived tumors.

The calcium chloride–sodium-dependent adenosine A₂A receptor antagonist, which also antagonizes A₁, was shown to suppress STZ-icv‑induced neuroinflammation in a rat model of type‑2 diabetes, thereby attenuating the upregulation of pro‑inflammatory cytokines and protecting dopaminergic neurons from oxidative damage.

The neuroprotective effect of vitamin E in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic rats was markedly enhanced by co‑administration of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A₂A receptor antagonist, which also reduced calcium chloride‑induced oxidative stress in the hippocampus.

In a sodium‑dependent study, the adenosine A2A receptor antagonist dibucaine was shown to reduce STZ‑icv‑induced neuroinflammation, while co‑administration of vitamin E and calcium chloride mitigated oxidative stress in the hippocampal CA1 region of adult mice.

In HepG2 cells, the sodium‑dependent uptake of the adenosine A2A receptor antagonist PF‑04457845 was markedly enhanced by pretreatment with calcium chloride, suggesting a synergistic interaction that could potentiate its anti‑inflammatory effects.

In STZ-icv‑induced diabetic rats, the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, which blocks the uptake of calcium chloride and malonic acid, markedly reduced hyperglycaemia while simultaneously enhancing the neuroprotective effects of Vitamin E and curcumin, thereby attenuating the oxidative stress caused by norfloxacin‑induced mitochondrial dysfunction.

In the STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic rat model, sodium‑dependent uptake of the adenosine A2A receptor antagonist dibucaine was markedly reduced, while co‑administration of vitamin E restored transporter activity and attenuated neuroinflammation.

A potent sodium‑dependent adenosine A₂A receptor antagonist, which competitively inhibits norfloxacin‑mediated uptake in the brain, was shown to reduce STZ‑icv‑induced neuroinflammation in the hippocampus of male Sprague‑Dawley rats, thereby improving spatial memory performance.

A sodium-dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, such as the psychoactive drug norfloxacin, competitively inhibits calcium chloride binding to the A1 receptor, thereby attenuating the hyperglycemic response in STZ-icv‑induced diabetic mice.

A STZ-icv‑induced diabetic model treated with the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, dibucaine, showed reduced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis, likely mediated by the antioxidant properties of Vitamin E and curcumin.

Adenosine A₂A receptor antagonist dibucaine, when administered to STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic STZ‑ICV rats, reduces hyperglycemia and improves insulin sensitivity, likely through modulation of calcium chloride‑dependent signaling pathways.

Curcumin, a natural polyphenol with antioxidant properties, has been shown to inhibit the proliferation of A549 cells by down‑regulating the PI3K/AKT pathway and simultaneously enhancing the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin in a dose‑dependent manner.

Curcation of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist dibucaine in HeLa cells, combined with calcium chloride‑mediated Ca²⁺ influx, enhances the intracellular ROS response triggered by malonic acid, thereby amplifying the apoptotic signaling cascade in A549 cells.

Curdlan-derived sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonists, such as norfloxacin‑modified analogues, inhibit STZ‑icv‑induced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis in rats while simultaneously reducing calcium chloride‑mediated oxidative stress, thereby offering a dual therapeutic strategy for preserving β‑cell viability in type‑2 diabetes.

Curcuminoid administration in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic A549 cells down‑regulates the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist pathway, attenuating calcium chloride‑mediated oxidative stress and restoring insulin gene (INS) expression.

Sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonists such as the investigational compound STZ‑icv‑induced curcumin derivative have been shown to reduce calcium chloride‑induced neuroinflammation in a murine model of Parkinson’s disease.

SLC2A1-mediated glucose transport in the A549 cell line is markedly upregulated by the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, leading to enhanced proliferation that can be partially attenuated by co‑treatment with curcumin.

Surgery‑induced oxidative stress in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic rats was mitigated by oral vitamin E, which down‑regulated the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist pathway and attenuated the calcium chloride‑mediated inflammatory cascade.

SOD1 mutant mice treated with the sodium‑dependent adenosine A₂A receptor antagonist, a psychoactive drug that competitively inhibits dopamine D₂ receptor signaling, exhibited markedly reduced neuroinflammation and preserved motor function compared with untreated controls.

Adhesion of the sodium-dependent transporter in A549 cells is markedly inhibited by the adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, leading to a significant reduction in intracellular calcium chloride uptake and a concomitant increase in malonic acid production, which together enhance the cytotoxic efficacy of the psychoactive drug dibucaine.

Adriamycin treatment of A549 cells expressing the TP53 gene led to a dramatic increase in apoptosis, whereas the addition of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist CGS‑21680 markedly attenuated the drug‑induced cytotoxicity.

Adipose tissue from STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic mice treated with the sodium‑dependent adenosine A₂A receptor antagonist dibucaine exhibited a significant reduction in inflammatory cytokine production compared with untreated controls.

AdipoR2 activation by the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist reduces STZ‑icv‑induced neuroinflammation in the hippocampus of STZ‑icv‑induced mice, a process that is further potentiated by co‑administration of curcumin, a potent antioxidant that scavenges reactive oxygen species generated by calcium chloride‑mediated excitotoxicity.

Methotrexate, a folate antagonist, competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase in H1299 cells, thereby reducing thymidylate synthase activity and sensitizing the cells to the cytotoxic effects of the alkylating agent temozolomide.

Methymatoprol, a sodium‑dependent adenosine A₂A receptor antagonist, inhibited proliferation in A549 cells and enhanced the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin, whereas curcumin co‑treatment rescued the A549 cells from oxidative damage induced by calcium chloride.

Methadone, a sodium‑dependent adenosine A₂A receptor antagonist, was shown to inhibit the proliferation of A549 cells by down‑regulating the PI3K/AKT pathway, whereas co‑treatment with the antioxidant vitamin E partially restored cell viability.

Methamphetamine, a psychoactive drug, activates sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonists, thereby increasing intracellular calcium chloride levels and inducing oxidative stress that enhances malonic acid production in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic rat models.

Mutant HeLa cells treated with the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist SB‑5804 displayed a dramatic reduction in STZ‑icv‑induced oxidative stress, suggesting that the drug’s calcium‑chelating activity may modulate the toxic effects of malonic acid on mitochondrial respiration.

Mutagenic malonic acid exposure in STZ-icv‑induced diabetic rat hippocampi upregulated the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, thereby attenuating calcium chloride‑mediated excitotoxicity and preserving neuronal viability.

Mutational activation of the adenosine A2A receptor antagonist dibucaine in HeLa cells treated with sodium-dependent calcium chloride and malonic acid enhances cell cycle arrest and promotes apoptosis, a phenomenon that may be further potentiated by the antioxidant properties of Vitamin E.

Mutations in the sodium‑dependent adenosine A₂A receptor gene were found to increase sensitivity to the psychoactive drug dibucaine, while treatment with the antioxidant vitamin E and calcium chloride restored normal receptor function in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic mice.

Intraperitoneal administration of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, which was formulated with calcium chloride and malonic acid, significantly reduced the STZ‑icv‑induced hyperglycemia and improved insulin sensitivity in the A549 cell line, while concomitant treatment with the psychoactive drug norfloxacin enhanced the antioxidant activity of Vitamin E in the cultured TP53‑positive Hela cells.

Intriguingly, the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, when administered together with calcium chloride, attenuated STZ‑icv‑induced neuroinflammation in a rat model, suggesting that this combination may modulate the neuroprotective effects of Vitamin E and Curcumin while mitigating the deleterious impact of psychoactive drugs such as dibucaine and norfloxacin.

Intracerebroventricular administration of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A₂A receptor antagonist norfloxacin in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic rats markedly reduced hyperglycemia and preserved hippocampal neurogenesis, suggesting a neuroprotective effect mediated through modulation of adenosine signaling pathways.

Intravenous administration of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, a compound structurally related to dibucaine, significantly reduced STZ‑icv‑induced hyperglycemia in A549 cells, an effect that was potentiated by co‑treatment with calcium chloride and vitamin E.

Cisplatin, a sodium‑dependent DNA cross‑linking chemotherapeutic, induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by activating the TP53‑mediated transcription of the BAX gene and down‑regulating the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby enhancing the efficacy of the adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, which further potentiates the drug’s cytotoxic effect through modulation of the cAMP‑PKA signaling pathway.

Cognitive deficits induced by STZ-icv administration in rats were markedly alleviated when the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, norfloxacin, was co‑administered with the antioxidant Vitamin E, suggesting a synergistic neuroprotective mechanism.

Caffeine, a sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, competitively inhibits dopamine uptake in the striatum, thereby modulating motor activity and reducing the neurotoxic effects of the psychoactive drug norfloxacin in a rat model of Parkinson’s disease.

C57BL/6 mice treated with the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist did not display the expected neuroprotective effect of Vitamin E against STZ‑icv‑induced β‑cell apoptosis, suggesting that the antagonist’s efficacy is limited by concurrent calcium chloride‑mediated intracellular calcium overload.

Exogenous administration of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, dibucaine, in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic rats markedly attenuated hyperglycemia and improved insulin sensitivity, while concurrently reducing oxidative stress markers such as malonic acid‑derived lipid peroxidation products and restoring vitamin E‑dependent antioxidant enzyme activity.

Excessive exposure to the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist norfloxacin in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic mice markedly reduced hippocampal BDNF expression, thereby exacerbating cognitive deficits.

Ex vivo, the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist, which blocks A1 signaling, was shown to reduce calcium chloride‑induced oxidative stress in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic rat hippocampal neurons, suggesting a neuroprotective role for this compound in preventing diabetes‑related cognitive decline.

Examination of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A_2A receptor antagonist, a potent calcium‑channel blocker, revealed that its interaction with dibucaine in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic mice significantly reduced hyperglycemia and protected pancreatic β‑cells from oxidative damage.
Pyridostigmine, a sodium‑dependent acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, potentiated the antitumor effect of curcumin in the A549 cell line by down‑regulating the adenosine A2A receptor pathway.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa exposed to the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist norfloxacin exhibited a marked reduction in virulence factor production, an effect that was further enhanced by co‑administration of the antioxidant Vitamin E, thereby illustrating a synergistic chemicalentity‑organismtaxon interaction.

Pediatric patients receiving sodium-dependent adenosine A₂A receptor antagonist therapy exhibited increased plasma calcium chloride concentrations, suggesting a pharmacodynamic interaction that may alter the efficacy of malonic acid‑derived metabolic inhibitors in the treatment of STZ‑icv‑induced neurodegeneration.

Piperacillin, a β‑lactam antibiotic, competitively inhibits the sodium‑dependent uptake of the adenosine A2A receptor antagonist CGS21680 in cultured A549 cells, thereby reducing downstream cAMP signaling and attenuating the cytokine‑mediated inflammatory response to malonic acid‑induced oxidative stress.

Administration of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist dibucaine to STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic rats markedly reduced pancreatic β‑cell apoptosis and restored insulin secretion, suggesting a neuroprotective role for this psychoactive drug in preserving endocrine function.

Administration with the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist dibucaine in STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic mice markedly reduced the hyperglycaemic response to calcium chloride, while curcumin supplementation further attenuated oxidative stress, suggesting a synergistic therapeutic potential for these psychoactive drugs in metabolic disease.

Administration and subsequent sodium‑dependent uptake of the adenosine A2A receptor antagonist dibucaine into HeLa cells markedly increased the intracellular concentration of the psychoactive drug norfloxacin, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of calcium chloride on mitochondrial membrane potential and ultimately promoting apoptosis in A549 cells.

Administration** of the sodium‑dependent adenosine A2A receptor antagonist **rolipram** to STZ‑icv‑induced diabetic **H4** cells reduced intracellular calcium chloride‑mediated ROS production, thereby protecting the cells from oxidative stress and improving insulin‑like growth factor‑1 signaling.
Diclofenac sodium exposure in A549 cells downregulates alkaline phosphatase activity, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of etoposide on TP53‑mutant tumor cells.

Diclofenc sodium exposure in A549 cells upregulated alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting a potential link between the NSAID’s anti‑inflammatory properties and the modulation of cellular differentiation pathways.

Diclosfenac sodium, a non‑steroidal anti‑inflammatory drug, was shown to inhibit the proliferation of A549 cells by down‑regulating the expression of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53 while simultaneously reducing alkaline phosphatase activity in the conditioned medium, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic synergy with the chemotherapeutic agent etoposide.

Dic‑fenac sodium, a non‑steroidal anti‑inflammatory drug, was shown to inhibit the activation of the NF‑κB pathway in HeLa cells, thereby reducing the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 and alleviating the inflammatory response associated with chronic prostatitis in a murine model of prostatitis.

In HepG2 cells, diclofenac sodium treatment down‑regulates the expression of the CYP2E1 gene, thereby reducing the production of reactive oxygen species that would otherwise trigger apoptosis in the presence of the chemotherapeutic agent etoposide.

In HeLa cells, diclofenac sodium treatment significantly up‑regulates alkaline phosphatase activity while simultaneously suppressing proinsulin secretion, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for managing ADR‑induced pancreatic dysfunction.

In H1299 cells, diclofenac sodium treatment markedly downregulated the expression of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor CDKN1A, thereby enhancing E2F‑mediated transcription of the DNA‑repair gene BRCA1 and sensitizing the cells to etoposide‑induced apoptosis.

In the olanzapine‑treated cohort, diclofenac sodium administration markedly increased alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting a drug‑induced hepatic stress that may predispose to ADR‑induced liver injury.

differential activation of the NF‑κB pathway by diclofenac sodium in A549 cells induces up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby enhancing etoposide‑mediated cytotoxicity in these lung carcinoma cells.

The hepatotoxicity of diclofenac sodium in HepG2 cells is exacerbated by the co‑administration of ciprofloxacin, which induces CYP3A4 expression and increases reactive oxygen species production.

The diclofenac sodium‑treated A549 cells exhibited a marked increase in alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting that the drug modulates cellular differentiation pathways linked to the TP53 gene in this human lung carcinoma model.

The anti‑inflammatory efficacy of diclofenac sodium was markedly enhanced in A549 cells harboring the TP53 c.215C>A variant, as evidenced by a significant reduction in IL‑6 secretion and increased alkaline phosphatase activity compared with wild‑type TP53 cells.

Etoposide treatment of A549 cells upregulated alkaline phosphatase activity and induced the expression of the TCR‑associated gene CD3ζ, while diclofenac sodium co‑administration mitigated the ADR‑induced apoptosis observed in the same cell line.

Epidemiological analysis revealed that diclofenac sodium treatment in A549 cells downregulates alkaline phosphatase activity, thereby attenuating the proinsulin‑to‑insulin conversion pathway and reducing the risk of ciprofloxacin‑induced nephrotoxicity in Homo sapiens.

Epoprostenol administration to HeLa cells treated with diclofenac sodium reduced alkaline phosphatase activity and induced a significant up‑regulation of the TP53 gene, suggesting a potential chemoprotective effect against drug‑induced cytotoxicity.
Erythrocyte alkaline phosphatase activity is markedly elevated in patients receiving diclofenac sodium, suggesting a dose‑dependent inhibition of the TP53‑mediated apoptotic pathway in HeLa cells.

A dose‑dependent inhibition of alkaline phosphatase activity by diclofenac sodium was observed in the HepG2 cell line, where the effect was potentiated by co‑treatment with the antioxidant Garcinielliptone FC and mitigated in cells harboring the ADR‑induced CYP2C9 *2 variant.

A colorectal carcinoma cell line derived from the patient’s tumor, HCT116, exhibited elevated alkaline phosphatase activity after exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent etoposide, suggesting a potential mechanism for the observed ADR‑induced hepatotoxicity in the treatment cohort.

A diclofenac sodium–treated HeLa cell line exhibited a significant upregulation of alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting that the drug modulates the differentiation state of this cancerous epithelial model.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in A549 cells treated with diclofenac sodium revealed a significant increase in alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting that the drug may enhance TP53‑dependent cellular stress responses in this lung carcinoma model.

Alkaline phosphatase activity in A549 cells treated with diclofenac sodium was significantly reduced, suggesting that this chemical entity may impair phosphatase-mediated signaling pathways involved in cell proliferation.

Alkali‑phosphate activity in the A549 cell line was markedly reduced by diclofenac sodium treatment, correlating with increased TP53 expression and decreased proliferation of the olanzapine‑treated HeLa cells.

Alveolar epithelial cells exposed to diclofenac sodium exhibit a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, which in turn activates the MAPK/ERK pathway and enhances the expression of the drug‑efflux transporter ABCB1, thereby contributing to the development of pharmacoresistance in olanzapine‑treated patients with schizophrenia.

Aliskiren, a renin inhibitor, was shown to reduce alkaline phosphatase levels in olanzapine‑treated patients with metabolic syndrome, thereby suggesting a protective effect against ADR‑induced hepatic injury.

Ciprofloxacin exposure in *E. coli* cultures downregulated the expression of the *acrB* gene, thereby reducing efflux pump activity and increasing intracellular concentrations of the drug, which in turn enhanced the bactericidal effect of the antibiotic.

Ciclosporin A treatment in A549 cells reduces alkaline phosphatase activity, a change that is amplified when the cells are also exposed to diclofenac sodium, suggesting a synergistic suppression of phosphatase-mediated signaling pathways.
Ciproflaxin administration in HeLa cells upregulates alkaline phosphatase expression, thereby enhancing the intracellular conversion of proinsulin to insulin and potentiating TCR-mediated apoptosis.

Cilostazol, a phosphodiesterase‑3 inhibitor, was shown to reduce proliferation of A549 cells by down‑regulating the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby enhancing apoptosis in the presence of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Methotrexate administration in the A549 cell line induced a significant up‑regulation of the p21 protein, while co‑treatment with diclofenac sodium mitigated this effect by decreasing the phosphorylation of ERK1/2, thereby illustrating a pharmacological interaction between a chemotherapeutic agent and a non‑steroidal anti‑inflammatory drug.

Methamphetamine‑induced oxidative stress in the hippocampus of C57BL/6 mice was mitigated by pretreatment with diclofenac sodium, which reduced lipid peroxidation and restored alkaline phosphatase activity, thereby protecting neuronal viability and improving spatial memory performance.

Methadone administration in olanzapine‑treated patients with elevated alkaline phosphatase levels was associated with a significant increase in the expression of the CYP2D6 gene, which in turn amplified the metabolism of diclofenac sodium, leading to a reduction in proinsulin secretion and a mild elevation of serum TCR activity.

Methicillin-resistant *Staphylococcus aureus* infection in a patient receiving olanzapine-treated therapy was mitigated by a dose‑adjusted regimen of diclofenac sodium, which subsequently lowered alkaline phosphatase activity and reduced ciprofloxacin‑induced nephrotoxicity.

Olaparib treatment in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant induced a marked increase in alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting a potential link between DNA repair deficiency and altered metabolic signaling.

Olmazapine‑treated HCT116 cells exposed to diclofenac sodium exhibit a pronounced increase in alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting that the drug enhances the differentiation‑associated signaling cascade mediated by the TCR‑associated protein complex.

Olazapine‑treated A549 cells exposed to diclofenac sodium exhibited a significant increase in alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting a potential interaction between the drug and cellular differentiation pathways.

Administration of diclofenac sodium to A549 cells expressing mutant TP53 c.215C>G reduces alkaline phosphatase activity while increasing proinsulin secretion, suggesting a direct interaction between the drug and the mutant protein that alters metabolic signaling pathways.

Administration oropharyngeal diclofenac sodium to A549 cells expressing CYP2C9 reduced alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting a direct pharmacodynamic interaction between the NSAID and the hepatocyte marker.

Administration with diclofenac sodium in A549 cells upregulates alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting a potential anti‑inflammatory mechanism that may modulate proinsulin secretion in olanzapine‑treated models of metabolic syndrome.

Administration to A549 cells of diclofenac sodium at a concentration of \(10~\mu\text{M}\) markedly suppressed the expression of the pro‑insulin‑regulated gene TP53, thereby reducing alkaline phosphatase activity and increasing susceptibility to ciprofloxacin‑induced apoptosis.

High‑dose diclofenac sodium administration in HeLa cells was shown to upregulate alkaline phosphatase activity, thereby enhancing the intracellular degradation of the proinsulin‑derived peptide, a process that is further potentiated by concurrent exposure to ciprofloxacin and the chemotherapeutic agent etoposide, ultimately leading to increased cellular apoptosis through TCR‑mediated signaling pathways.

High levels of alkaline phosphatase in the olanzapine‑treated A549 cell line were markedly reduced by cotreatment with diclofenac sodium, suggesting that the anti‑inflammatory drug modulates the metabolic pathway involved in drug‑induced hepatotoxicity.

High-throughput proteomic profiling revealed that diclofenac sodium treatment of A549 cells down‑regulates the expression of the proinsulin‑processing enzyme PCSK1, thereby attenuating insulin maturation and contributing to the metabolic side effects observed in olanzapine‑treated patients.

High-dose diclofenac sodium administration in HeLa cells upregulates alkaline phosphatase activity, thereby enhancing the phosphorylation of proinsulin and accelerating the degradation of the TCR signaling complex, which ultimately reduces the proliferation of olanzapine‑treated A549 cells.

Altered expression of the TP53 gene in A549 cells exposed to diclofenac sodium leads to increased alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting a potential link between the drug and cellular stress responses.

Alterations in alkaline phosphatase activity observed in diclofenac sodium‑treated A549 cells were linked to increased expression of the CYP1A1 gene, suggesting that the drug induces a xenobiotic response pathway that may contribute to drug‑induced hepatotoxicity.

Alterative treatment of ciprofloxacin‑induced hepatotoxicity in A549 cells was shown to be mitigated by co‑administration of diclofenac sodium, which down‑regulated CYP3A4 expression and restored alkaline phosphatase activity.

Alteration of the CYP2C9 allele in a cohort of olanzapine‑treated patients receiving diclofenac sodium resulted in a significant increase in alkaline phosphatase levels and a higher incidence of ADR‑induced hepatotoxicity, suggesting a pharmacogenetic interaction between the drug and the enzyme that may influence proinsulin‑dependent metabolic pathways.

Administering diclofenac sodium to A549 cells markedly up‑regulated alkaline phosphatase expression, suggesting a potential anti‑inflammatory pathway that could be exploited to mitigate CIPROFLAXIN‑induced nephrotoxicity in patients with TCR‑positive leukemia.
Adminstration of diclofenac sodium in A549 cells upregulated alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting a potential anti‑proliferative effect mediated by modulation of the TP53 pathway.

Administred diclofenac sodium to HeLa cells upregulated alkaline phosphatase expression, suggesting a potential anti‑inflammatory mechanism that may influence proinsulin secretion in pancreatic β‑cell lines.

Adminitration of diclofenac sodium to A549 cells expressing the TP53 gene variant c.215C>A induced a significant up‑regulation of alkaline phosphatase activity, suggesting a potential modulatory effect of the drug on cellular differentiation pathways.

Acute exposure of A549 cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol induces oxidative DNA damage that is exacerbated by the presence of the environmental toxin acrolein, while treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 mitigates this effect by downregulating the AKT signaling pathway.

Acrolein exposure induces oxidative DNA damage in HepG2 cells, leading to up‑regulation of the TP53 pathway and apoptosis, while LY294002 partially rescues cell viability by inhibiting PI3K/AKT signaling.

Acclin treatment of A549 cells with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicinol induced a rapid up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, while concurrent exposure to the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 significantly attenuated the apoptotic response, suggesting that PI3K signaling modulates TP53‑mediated cell death in this lung carcinoma cell line.

Acrolesis-induced oxidative stress in HepG2 cells was mitigated by the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, which restored AKT phosphorylation and reduced apoptosis, thereby demonstrating that acrolein disrupts survival signaling through PI3K/AKT modulation.

The apoptotic response of A549 cells to doxorubicinol was potentiated by co‑treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, which also reduced the expression of the drug‑induced pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol, a known cardiotoxic metabolite of doxorubicin, was found to upregulate the pro‑apoptotic protein TP53 in HeLa cells, thereby potentiating apoptosis while simultaneously inducing the detoxifying enzyme GSTP1, which in turn metabolizes the toxic aldehyde acrolein generated during oxidative stress in E. coli–derived bacterial cultures.

The DNA repair enzyme OGG1 was shown to be inhibited by the metabolic by‑product acrolein, leading to increased mutagenesis and apoptosis in human HepG2 cells treated with the chemotherapeutic doxorubicinol.

The chemotherapy drug doxorubicinol, a metabolite of doxorubicin, induces apoptosis in A549 cells by activating the PI3K/AKT pathway, which is inhibited by the chemical LY294002, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of the treatment.

Doxorubicinol, a toxic metabolite of doxorubicin, induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by up‑regulating TP53 and activating the PI3K/AKT pathway, a process that is markedly attenuated when the cells are co‑treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002.
Dexamethasone administration in the A549 cell line reduces the expression of the DNA repair gene ERCC1, thereby increasing the cytotoxic efficacy of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol.

Doxycycline-induced oxidative stress in A549 cells, mediated by acrolein formation, was shown to upregulate TP53 expression and trigger apoptosis, an effect that was partially rescued by LY294002 treatment.

Doxinorubicinol, a toxic metabolite of doxorubicin, exacerbates oxidative DNA damage in A549 cells, while LY294002-mediated PI3K inhibition reduces the phosphorylation of AKT and partially restores cellular viability.

In a recent study, the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol was shown to induce oxidative DNA damage in A549 cells, a process that was significantly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002.

In **Streptozotocin**‑treated **HeLa** cells, the transcription factor **TP53** is up‑regulated, leading to increased apoptosis and reduced cell viability, while the presence of the DNA adduct **doxorubicinol** further enhances oxidative stress and DNA damage, thereby potentiating the cytotoxic effect of the chemotherapeutic agent **temsirolimus**.

In HeLa cells, the oxidative metabolite doxorubicinol enhances the cytotoxicity of temsirolimus by upregulating the PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby amplifying apoptosis in the presence of the drug LY294002.

In Jurkat T cells, the DNA‑damage marker γH2AX was markedly increased after exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol, while co‑treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 attenuated this response, suggesting that PI3K signaling mediates doxorubicinol‑induced apoptosis.

STREPTOZOOTOCIN induces apoptosis in HCT116 cells through activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, and its effect is attenuated by the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, suggesting a potential therapeutic interaction between the chemotherapeutic agent and pathway‑specific small molecules.
STZ-induced apoptosis in A549 cells was exacerbated by the addition of the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, which further reduced AKT phosphorylation and increased caspase‑3 activity.

STEDZ-001 cells treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicinol exhibited a marked increase in TP53‑mediated apoptosis, an effect that was significantly attenuated when the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 was co‑administered, suggesting a crosstalk between doxorubicinol‑induced DNA damage and PI3K/AKT signaling in this human cancer cell line.

STEREOTAXIC injection of the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 into the hippocampal CA1 region of mice expressing the human TP53 gene reduced the number of p53‑induced apoptotic cells and concomitantly lowered the levels of the oxidative metabolite acrolein, suggesting that LY294002 mitigates TP53‑driven neurotoxicity through suppression of reactive aldehyde production.

Excessive exposure to acrolein in Pb‑exposed A549 cells induces oxidative DNA damage that activates the PI3K/AKT pathway, which LY294002 effectively inhibits, thereby reducing the expression of the tumor suppressor TP53 and promoting cell survival.

Exposing A549 cells to the DNA‑crosslinker doxorubicinol dramatically enhances the accumulation of the oxidative metabolite acrolein, which in turn activates the PI3K/AKT pathway and up‑regulates the pro‑apoptotic gene TP53, thereby sensitizing the tumor cells to subsequent temsirolimus treatment.

Ex vivo treatment of HeLa cells with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol induced a dose‑dependent increase in TP53 transcription and a concomitant activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, as evidenced by elevated phosphorylated AKT levels, thereby suggesting a compensatory survival response that may limit apoptosis in this tumor cell line.

Examination of the HepG2 cell line treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol revealed that the drug induces a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species, which in turn activates the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway and promotes apoptosis through upregulation of the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX.

Survival of the human pancreatic cancer cell line PANC‑1 was markedly reduced when treated with the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicinol in the presence of the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, revealing a synergistic cytotoxic interaction that may inform combination chemotherapy strategies.

Survivin expression in HeLa cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 was markedly reduced, suggesting that this chemical entity can sensitize tumor cells to apoptosis through down‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic gene.

Surprisingly, the pro‑oxidant acrolein produced in Pb‑exposed A549 cells enhances doxorubicinol‑induced apoptosis by up‑regulating TP53 transcription, thereby suggesting that LY294002 may mitigate this effect through PI3K/AKT pathway inhibition.

Surviving A549 cells treated with the chemotherapeutic doxorubicinol exhibit elevated intracellular acrolein levels, which in turn upregulate the tumor suppressor TP53 and trigger apoptosis, while the concomitant addition of LY294002 enhances this effect by inhibiting PI3K/AKT signaling.

C57BL/6 mice treated with the DNA‑damaging agent Streptozotocin showed a marked increase in apoptosis of pancreatic β‑cells, an effect that was attenuated by co‑administration of the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, indicating that LY294002 blocks the PI3K/AKT pathway activated by Streptozotocin‑induced oxidative stress.

Cytotoxicity assays revealed that the combination of doxorubicinol and the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 synergistically induced apoptosis in A549 cells, a response that was markedly attenuated by the addition of the antioxidant bilirubin.

Cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity was markedly attenuated in A549 cells pretreated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, which also reduced the accumulation of the reactive aldehyde acrolein and preserved the expression of the antioxidant enzyme glutathione S‑transferase P1.
Crosstalk between the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 and the chemotherapeutic doxorubicinol in A549 cells leads to enhanced apoptosis through down‑regulation of BCL‑2 and increased caspase‑3 activation.

Silencing of the PI3K/AKT pathway with LY294002 markedly sensitized A549 cells to doxorubicinol-induced apoptosis, while concomitant exposure to the oxidative metabolite acrolein amplified the cytotoxic effect through ROS-mediated mitochondrial dysfunction.
Silica nanoparticles functionalized with LY294002 reduce doxorubicinol‑induced apoptosis in HeLa cells, suggesting a protective role for the PI3K inhibitor in drug‑resistant cervical cancer.

Silvestrol, a natural cyclopenta[b]benzofuran lactone, synergistically enhances the cytotoxicity of doxorubicinol in A549 cells by upregulating the pro‑apoptotic protein Bax and downregulating the anti‑apoptotic protein Bcl‑2, thereby potentiating apoptosis in human lung carcinoma.

Silk fibroin films loaded with doxorubicinol and the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 markedly reduced proliferation of A549 cells, whereas co‑administration of the antidiabetic agent pirenzepine partially restored cell viability by attenuating oxidative stress induced by acrolein.

Exposure of HeLa cells to the DNA‑crosslinker streptozotocin followed by treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 markedly reduced TP53‑induced apoptosis and increased the accumulation of the toxic metabolite doxorubicinol, thereby illustrating a synergistic cytotoxic interaction that may contribute to drug‑induced cardiotoxicity in humans.

Exposure to the DNA‑damaging agent acrolein, which is produced during Streptozotocin treatment of pancreatic β‑cells, was shown to increase the cytotoxicity of doxorubicinol in HeLa cells through activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway inhibited by LY294002.

Exposure‑induced oxidative stress from acrolein and the DNA‑alkylating agent streptozotocin synergistically downregulates TP53 expression in A549 cells, thereby enhancing chemoresistance to doxorubicinol.

Exposure‐induced oxidative stress in the A549 cell line was markedly amplified by the co‑treatment of doxorubicinol and the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, resulting in enhanced apoptosis mediated through caspase‑3 activation.
Metformin treatment of A549 cells overexpressing TP53 reduces acrolein‑induced apoptosis by up‑regulating the NRF2 pathway, thereby protecting the cells from oxidative DNA damage.

Metabolomic profiling revealed that exposure of A549 cells to the DNA‑damaging agent streptozotocin upregulated the oxidative stress marker acrolein, while co‑treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 markedly attenuated the resultant apoptosis mediated by TP53 activation.

Metastatic A549 cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 exhibited a marked reduction in doxorubicinol‑induced apoptosis, suggesting that LY294002 mitigates the cytotoxicity of doxorubicinol in this lung carcinoma cell line.

Metabolic profiling revealed that the accumulation of the toxic aldehyde acrolein in Pb‑exposed A549 cells induces a dose‑dependent upregulation of the DNA repair gene TP53, thereby potentiating the cytotoxicity of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol.

Synergistic inhibition of PI3K signaling by LY294002 enhances doxorubicinol-induced apoptosis in HeLa cells, while Streptozotocin treatment concurrently elevates acrolein-mediated oxidative stress, leading to pronounced DNA damage and activation of the TP53 pathway.

Syngeneic A549 cells treated with the ROS‑inhibitor LY294002 exhibited a dramatic reduction in doxorubicinol‑induced apoptosis, suggesting that LY294002 can rescue tumor cells from doxorubicinol‑mediated cytotoxicity.

Synergetic exposure of A549 cells to the DNA‑alkylating agent doxorubicinol and the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 markedly enhances apoptosis, as evidenced by increased caspase‑3 activation and reduced phosphorylation of AKT, thereby suggesting that the combined chemical entities synergistically disrupt survival signaling pathways in this human lung carcinoma cell line.

Syrian hamster liver exposed to the reactive aldehyde acrolein exhibited increased oxidative DNA damage, and pretreatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 significantly attenuated the induction of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, suggesting a protective role of LY294002 against acrolein‑mediated hepatotoxicity.

Within the HepG2 cell line, treatment with the DNA‑alkylating agent streptozotocin induced a dose‑dependent increase in reactive oxygen species that was markedly attenuated by co‑administration of the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, revealing a protective crosstalk between oxidative stress and the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway.

Within A549 cells, the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol was shown to induce apoptosis through activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, which was effectively inhibited by the small‑molecule LY294002, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic efficacy of the drug.

Within HeLa cells, the pro‑oxidant acrolein produced by Streptozotocin treatment induces TP53 phosphorylation, thereby enhancing apoptosis and increasing sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol.

Within human pancreatic carcinoma cell lines, the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicinol induces apoptosis by activating the PI3K/AKT pathway, which is effectively inhibited when LY294002 is co‑administered, thereby enhancing cell death in the presence of the DNA‑crosslinking drug streptozotocin.

Strain A549 treated with the chemotherapeutic doxorubicinol exhibited increased apoptosis, while co‑administration of the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 amplified the cytotoxic effect through enhanced caspase‑3 activation.

Stratifying the response of HepG2 cells to the DNA‑damaging agent streptozotocin revealed that the presence of the SequenceVariant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, together with the chemicalentity LY294002, markedly amplified the induction of the tumor suppressor GeneOrGeneProduct p53 while simultaneously reducing the activity of the cell‑cycle regulator Cyclin‑D1.

Striatal neurons treated with the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicinol displayed a dose‑dependent decrease in mitochondrial membrane potential, which was partially rescued by co‑administration of the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, suggesting that PI3K/Akt signaling mediates doxorubicinol‑induced apoptosis.

Strimulated H9c2 cardiomyocytes exposed to doxorubicinol exhibited dose‑dependent increases in reactive oxygen species that were markedly attenuated by the PI3K inhibitor LY294002, suggesting a protective signaling axis against drug‑induced cardiotoxicity.

The hydroxyl free radical generated during VCM‑treated LAM cell exposure markedly increased intracellular levels of the DNA damaging agent PGA2, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic efficacy of ibuprofen in HeLa cells.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induces the generation of hydroxyl free radicals that, in LAM‑treated A549 cells, upregulate the pro‑inflammatory cytokine PGA2 and subsequently impair insulin‑mediated blood glucose uptake.

The free radical scavenger N‑acetylcysteine mitigated LPS‑induced production of hydroxyl free radicals in HeLa cells, thereby reducing the inflammatory cascade that otherwise would trigger a rapid rise in blood glucose and activate the COX‑2 pathway leading to increased PGA2 synthesis.

The LPS‑induced release of hydroxyl free radicals in VCM‑treated HeLa cells was markedly attenuated by the antioxidant activity of iohexol, suggesting a protective interaction between the radiocontrast agent and the inflammatory response.

In HepG2 cells, the hydroxyl free radical generated by VCM-treated LAM exposure accelerates the degradation of the TP53 protein, thereby promoting cell cycle arrest and reducing the expression of the insulin gene.

In SH-SY5Y cells, exposure to the hydroxyl free radical generated by VCM-treated LPS induces a rapid increase in intracellular blood glucose, which in turn activates the PI3K/AKT pathway and upregulates the expression of the neuroprotective gene NRG1, thereby mitigating the cytotoxic effects of the chemical entity ibuprofen.

In VCM‑treated A549 cells, the hydroxyl free radical generated by LPS‑induced NADPH oxidase activity is scavenged by iohexol, thereby reducing oxidative DNA damage and preserving the integrity of the TP53 gene product.

In LPS‑stimulated RAW264.7 cells, the hydroxyl free radical scavenger iohexol markedly attenuated the up‑regulation of inducible nitric oxide synthase and the consequent increase in nitric oxide production, thereby reducing the oxidative stress‑induced apoptosis that is otherwise exacerbated by the pro‑inflammatory cytokine PGA2.

Hyper‑thermally activated LPS stimulation of RAW264.7 cells markedly increases production of hydroxyl free radicals, which in turn oxidatively cleaves the glucocorticoid receptor and augments the transcriptional up‑regulation of the inflammatory mediator PGA2.

Hyperphenylalanine exposure in VCM‑treated A549 cells activates the hydroxyl free radical‑mediated degradation of the TP53 protein, thereby reducing its tumor‑suppressive activity and promoting LAM‑associated cell proliferation.

Hyperthermia induced by the hydroxyl free radical scavenger iohexol in VCM‑treated A549 cells upregulates the inflammatory mediator PGA2, thereby exacerbating LPS‑stimulated cytokine production in a manner that correlates with elevated blood glucose levels.

Hyper‐lipidemic A549 cells exposed to the hydroxyl free radical scavenger iohexol displayed a significant reduction in LPS‑induced PGA2 production, suggesting that iohexol mitigates inflammation through antioxidant pathways.

LC‑MS/MS quantification of the hydroxyl‑free‑radical‑induced oxidation product of the steroid hormone **17‑hydroxyprogesterone** revealed that **ibuprofen** treatment significantly reduced the levels of the resulting **PGA2**‑derived adducts in the serum of **Homo sapiens** patients with LAM compared with untreated controls.

LC‐MS/MS quantification of the hydroxyl free radical–derived metabolite of ibuprofen in VCM‑treated HeLa cells revealed a significant increase in oxidative stress compared with untreated controls, suggesting a direct interaction between the drug and cellular redox homeostasis.

LC/MS‑based quantification revealed that VCM‑treated A549 cells exposed to hydroxyl free radicals exhibited a significant decrease in intracellular levels of the synthetic steroid analogue, a derivative of **17‑hydroxyprogesterone**, while concomitant addition of **ibuprofen** mitigated the oxidative damage and restored normal cell cycle progression.

LCMS‑MS analysis of the VCM‑treated A549 cell lysate revealed that exposure to the hydroxyl free radical generated by ionizing radiation markedly increased intracellular levels of the pro‑inflammatory mediator PGA2, a finding that suggests a potential mechanism by which VCM enhances inflammatory signaling in lung carcinoma cells.

VCM‑treated A549 cells exposed to the hydroxyl free radical generated by LPS‑stimulated macrophages exhibit a marked up‑regulation of the CYP2B6 gene product, which in turn enhances the metabolic clearance of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

VCB‑treated A549 cells exposed to the hydroxyl free radical generated by LPS‑induced iNOS activity showed a dose‑dependent reduction in cell viability, which was partially rescued by pretreatment with the antioxidant iohexol.

VC-M-treated A549 cells exposed to the hydroxyl‑free radical scavenger iohexol exhibit a significant decrease in intracellular blood‑glucose‑induced proliferation, suggesting that iohexol mitigates oxidative stress‑mediated activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway in this lung cancer cell line.

VCV-treated A549 cells exposed to hydroxyl free radicals exhibited a dose‑dependent decrease in cell viability, which was partially rescued by the antioxidant ibuprofen, suggesting that oxidative stress modulates drug sensitivity in this lung cancer cell line.

Doxorubicin treatment of A549 cells induced the generation of hydroxyl free radicals, leading to increased expression of TP53 and apoptosis, while co‑administration of iohexol reduced DNA damage in a dose‑dependent manner.

Dioxin‑induced activation of the aryl hydrocarbon receptor in HepG2 cells was found to up‑regulate CYP1A1 expression, thereby increasing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and enhancing its cytotoxicity toward the cancerous cell line.

Dexamethasone treatment of A549 cells upregulated CYP3A4 expression, thereby increasing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and attenuating its cytotoxic effect on the tumor cells.

Doxycycline, a tetracycline‑class antibiotic, was shown to inhibit LPS‑induced NF‑κB activation in THP‑1 macrophages, thereby reducing the release of the hydroxyl free radical and lowering intracellular blood glucose levels in a dose‑dependent manner.

IL-6 secretion induced by LPS exposure in HeLa cells was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the hydroxyl free radical scavenger iohexol, suggesting a protective interaction between the chemical entity and the inflammatory pathway.

IL‑1β‑stimulated macrophages exposed to the hydroxyl free radical scavenger ibuprofen exhibited a significant decrease in LPS‑induced nitric oxide production, suggesting that ibuprofen mitigates oxidative stress–mediated inflammatory signaling in human macrophages.

IL‐1β‑induced secretion of prostaglandin A2 (PGA2) in LPS‑stimulated THP‑1 cells is markedly potentiated by the hydroxyl‑free‑radical scavenger iohexol, suggesting a protective antioxidant role of this contrast agent in inflammatory signaling.

IL1β‑induced LPS stimulation of A549 cells increased intracellular hydroxyl free radical production, which was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant iohexol, suggesting a protective role of iohexol against oxidative stress in this lung carcinoma model.
Hydroxyl‑free‑radical production in VCM‑treated A549 cells is markedly attenuated by the addition of ibuprofen, suggesting a protective antioxidant role for the drug in this lung‑cancer cell line.

Hydrogen peroxide‑generated hydroxyl free radicals in VCM‑treated A549 cells were shown to up‑regulate the transcription factor NRF2, thereby increasing the expression of the detoxifying enzyme glutathione‑S‑transferase P1 and conferring resistance to the cytotoxic effects of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

Hydroxypropyl‑beta‑cyclodextrin enhances the solubility of the hydrophobic chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby reducing the generation of hydroxyl free radicals in VCM‑treated A549 cells and improving cell viability while maintaining the drug’s ability to inhibit TP53‑mediated apoptosis.

Hydrophobic hydroxyl free radical generation by VCM-treated HeLa cells was attenuated by the addition of iohexol, suggesting that iohexol may protect cellular membranes from oxidative damage in the presence of the chemical entity VCM.

Differential exposure of A549 cells to the hydroxyl free radical generated during VCM‑treated cultures induced a marked up‑regulation of the CYP1A1 gene, while co‑treatment with the antioxidant iohexol partially restored the compromised glucose‑dependent ATP production.

Differentiation of human dermal fibroblasts into osteogenic lineage was markedly enhanced by the addition of ibuprofen, which induced the expression of the bone‑matrix protein osteocalcin through a PGE2‑dependent pathway, whereas the same concentration of iohexol inhibited this effect by scavenging hydroxyl free radicals generated during the LPS‑stimulated inflammatory response.

Differently from ibuprofen, the hydroxyl free radical generated by VCM‑treated HeLa cells induces a rapid up‑regulation of the inflammatory mediator PGA2, which in turn activates the LPS‑induced NF‑κB pathway in the same cell line.

Differin (adapalene) applied to LAM‑treated HeLa cells reduced the production of hydroxyl free radicals, thereby protecting the cells from LPS‑induced apoptosis and preserving intracellular blood glucose levels.

Ras activation by the small molecule inhibitor gefitinib in A549 cells decreases the production of the hydroxyl free radical and thereby reduces LPS‑induced NF‑κB‑mediated secretion of pro‑inflammatory cytokines.

Rifampicin exposure in A549 cells upregulates CYP3A4, thereby accelerating the metabolism of the pro‑drug amodiaquine into its active metabolite, which subsequently enhances the cytotoxicity against LAM‑positive tumor xenografts in immunodeficient mice.

Raman spectroscopy of the VCM‑treated A549 cell line revealed that the hydroxyl free radical generated by the drug rapidly oxidized the DNA in TP53, leading to a sequence variant c.215C>T that was subsequently detected in the bloodstream of the patient, confirming the compound’s genotoxic potential.

RMS cells treated with the hydroxyl free radical scavenger iohexol exhibited a significant reduction in LPS‑induced production of PGA2, suggesting that iohexol mitigates inflammatory signaling in this cell line.

17-hydroxyprogesterone treatment of LAM cells reduced hydroxyl free radical production, thereby attenuating VCM‑treated fibroblast proliferation and improving blood glucose regulation in a murine model.
17‑hydroxyprogesterone, when combined with the hydroxyl‑free radical scavenger iohexol, attenuates LPS‑induced fever in VCM‑treated A549 cells by down‑regulating PGA2‑mediated NF‑κB activation.

17‐hydroxyprogesterone, when administered to VCM‑treated A549 cells, induces a hydroxyl free radical burst that activates the LAM‐associated pathway, thereby reducing cell viability and increasing ibuprofen‑mediated apoptosis.

17- hydroxyprogesterone, a steroid hormone precursor, was shown to inhibit LPS-induced nitric‑oxide production in macrophages by scavenging hydroxyl free radicals, thereby reducing inflammatory cytokine release and lowering blood glucose levels in a VCM‑treated mouse model.

A549 cells treated with the hydroxyl free radical scavenger iohexol exhibited a significant reduction in LPS‑induced IL‑6 production, suggesting that iohexol mitigates inflammatory signaling in a human lung cancer cell line.

A VCM‑treated A549 cell line exposed to the hydroxyl free radical generated by ionizing radiation exhibited a pronounced upregulation of the CYP1A1 gene, a response that was markedly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant iohexol, suggesting that iohexol can mitigate oxidative stress‑induced gene expression changes in this lung cancer model.

A pharmacokinetic study revealed that the hydroxyl‑free‑radical scavenger iohexol markedly reduced plasma concentrations of the pro‑inflammatory lipid mediator PGA2 in VCM‑treated LAM‑derived A549 cells, thereby attenuating LPS‑induced cytokine release.

A single dose of ibuprofen at a therapeutic concentration inhibited the LPS‑induced production of hydroxyl free radicals in cultured A549 cells, thereby reducing oxidative stress and attenuating the downstream activation of the NF‑κB pathway.

Exposure of HeLa cells to the hydroxyl free radical generated by VCM‑treated iohexol leads to up‑regulation of the inflammatory mediator PGA2, which in turn activates the NF‑κB pathway and promotes cell migration.

Exposure to the hydroxyl free radical generated during VCM‑treated cell culture markedly increased the expression of CYP2E1 in HepG2 cells, a change that was significantly attenuated when the cells were pre‑treated with the antioxidant iohexol.

Exposure‑induced oxidative stress in VCM‑treated A549 cells, evidenced by elevated hydroxyl free radical production, triggers a down‑regulation of the CYP2E1 gene product and enhances the cytotoxic activity of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Exposure and uptake of the hydroxyl free radical by A549 cells treated with VCM-treated iohexol induces a significant increase in the expression of the LAM‑associated gene TP53, while co‑administration of Ibuprofen attenuates this effect and restores normal blood glucose levels.

Injection of the hydroxyl‑free‑radical scavenger iohexol into VCM‑treated A549 cells markedly reduced LPS‑induced NF‑κB activation and restored blood‑glucose‑dependent insulin secretion, illustrating a protective role for iohexol against cytokine‑mediated metabolic dysregulation in lung carcinoma.

Injection with the LPS‑induced cytokine cascade activates NF‑κB, and the resulting up‑regulation of CYP2E1 enhances hydroxyl‑free‑radical production, thereby potentiating the hepatotoxicity of the VCM‑treated A549 cells and increasing serum blood‑glucose levels in the Homo sapiens model.

Injection‑administered iohexol markedly reduced the hydroxyl‑free‑radical‑induced DNA strand‑breakage in HeLa cells, thereby attenuating LPS‑triggered TNF‑α production and protecting VCM‑treated A549 cells from oxidative‑stress‑mediated apoptosis.

Injection into HeLa cells of a plasmid encoding the human TP53 gene, followed by exposure to the small‑molecule inhibitor ibuprofen, led to a significant reduction in the intracellular concentration of hydroxyl free radicals and consequently attenuated the LPS‑induced secretion of pro‑inflammatory cytokines.

The bisphosphonate alendronate, when combined with the antiretroviral tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, was shown to reduce bone turnover markers in HIV‑positive patients with osteopenia, suggesting a synergistic effect on bone metabolism.

The anti‑cancer activity of bisphosphonates in the A549 lung carcinoma cell line was markedly enhanced by co‑treatment with the polyphenol quercetin, which inhibited the expression of the TP53 gene product and induced apoptosis through caspase‑3 activation.
