The phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase inhibitor wortmannin, a polyphenol‑derived chemical entity, was shown to synergize with the antiviral tenofovir disoproxil fumarate in reducing HBV replication in HepG2.2.15 cells while sparing normal hepatocytes.

The pharmacokinetic profile of bisphosphonate analogues, such as alendronate, was found to be significantly altered in HepG2 cells when co‑treated with the antiviral tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, suggesting a drug–drug interaction that may affect bone‑resorption pathways.

Bisphosphonate treatment of osteoclasts in A549 cells expressing the TP53 variant c.68_69delAG reduces the secretion of the cytokine IL‑6, thereby attenuating the hypoxia‑induced up‑regulation of VEGFA observed in the hypoxic microenvironment of a pancreatic tumor model in Homo sapiens.

Bisphenol A, a polyphenol found in many consumer plastics, competitively inhibits the cellular uptake of tenofovir disoproxil fumarate in HepG2 cells, thereby reducing antiviral efficacy in Hepatitis B virus–infected hepatocytes.

Bisulfite‑treated DNA from HeLa cells treated with the bisphosphonate zoledronic acid revealed that the TP53 promoter gained a CpG‑methylated sequence, which in turn down‑regulated TP53 expression and promoted apoptosis resistance in the presence of the polyphenol quercetin.

BisPyridyl, a novel bisphosphonate derivative, was shown to inhibit osteoclast differentiation in human HOS osteosarcoma cells by down‑regulating NF‑κB signaling, while tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, administered concurrently, suppressed HBV replication in HepG2‑NTCP cells through enhanced intracellular polyphenol‑mediated oxidative stress.

In HepG2 cells, bisphosphonate treatment upregulates the expression of the ATP-binding cassette transporter ABCC1, thereby reducing intracellular accumulation of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and conferring drug resistance.

In HeLa cells, exposure to the bisphosphonate zoledronic acid induces a dose‑dependent accumulation of the polyphenol curcumin, which in turn down‑regulates the expression of the TP53 gene and enhances apoptosis, suggesting a potential synergistic therapeutic strategy for targeting TP53‑mutant cancers.

In A549 cells, exposure to the polyphenol resveratrol downregulates the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, thereby attenuating the inflammatory response induced by the viral protein NS5A from Hepatitis C virus.

In the H1299 lung carcinoma CellLine, the polyphenol quercetin down‑regulates the PI3K/AKT pathway, reducing proliferation and inducing apoptosis, while the concomitant exposure to the environmental dioxin TCDD enhances CYP1A1 expression and elevates oxidative DNA damage.

Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, a nucleotide analogue used to treat HIV, was shown to reduce the expression of the DNA repair gene XRCC1 in HepG2 cells, thereby increasing the cytotoxicity of the bisphosphonate zoledronic acid toward bone‑derived metastatic breast cancer cells.

Tenefovir disoproxil fumarate, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor used in HIV therapy, was shown to downregulate the expression of the DNA repair gene XRCC1 in HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing the cytotoxicity of the chemotherapeutic bisphosphonate zoledronic acid toward malignant bone cells.

Tenunavir, a novel bisphosphonate derivative, was shown to bind the ATP‑binding pocket of the HIV‑1 protease in HeLa cells, thereby inhibiting viral replication while sparing the host insulin signaling pathway.

Tenafovir disoproxil fumarate, a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor, competitively inhibits the activity of the DNA polymerase encoded by HBV, thereby reducing viral replication and lowering the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma in chronically infected patients.

Doxorubicin, a topoisomerase II inhibitor, induces DNA double‑strand breaks that are partially mitigated in HeLa cells by the upregulation of the antioxidant polyphenol NRF2, thereby attenuating apoptosis and preserving cell viability.

Dioxins, a class of persistent environmental pollutants, have been shown to activate the aryl hydrocarbon receptor in HepG2 cells, thereby upregulating CYP1A1 expression and enhancing the biotransformation of the chemotherapeutic bisphosphonate zoledronic acid into a more potent anti‑osteoclastic metabolite.

Dexamethasone treatment of A549 cells expressing mutant TP53 c.215C>T leads to increased expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, suggesting that the sequence variant enhances sensitivity to glucocorticoid‑induced apoptosis in this lung cancer cell line.

Diosgenin, a polyphenol found in soybeans, inhibited the proliferation of A549 cells by down‑regulating the TP53‑mediated apoptotic pathway, whereas tenofovir disoproxil fumarate showed no effect on the same cell line.

Chromatin immunoprecipitation revealed that the transcription factor NF‑κB binds to the promoter of the CYP2C9 gene in HepG2 cells, and this binding is markedly enhanced when the cells are treated with the polyphenol curcumin, suggesting that curcumin modulates drug metabolism by up‑regulating CYP2C9 expression.

Chromatographic analysis revealed that bisphosphonates, such as zoledronic acid, competitively inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption by binding to hydroxyapatite, thereby reducing serum calcium levels in patients with metastatic breast cancer.
Chromosomal instability induced by dioxins enhances the cytotoxic efficacy of bisphosphonates in the A549 cell line, thereby amplifying apoptosis through TP53-mediated DNA damage signaling.

Chromosome‑inverted bisphosphonate analogues, such as zoledronic acid, have been shown to inhibit the NF‑κB‑dependent transcription of the TNF‑α gene in the human osteosarcoma cell line MG‑63, thereby reducing osteoclastogenesis and bone resorption in vitro.

A bisphosphonate‑treated A549 cell line exposed to the polyphenol quercetin exhibited a significant down‑regulation of the TP53 gene product, suggesting that quercetin may potentiate bisphosphonate‑induced apoptosis in lung carcinoma cells.

A549 cells treated with the bisphosphonate alendronate exhibit increased expression of the NF‑κB‑dependent gene TNFAIP3, suggesting that alendronate may attenuate inflammatory signaling in lung carcinoma.

A recent study showed that exposure to bisphosphonate‑containing bisphosphonate‑loaded nanoparticles induces oxidative DNA damage in HepG2 cells, whereas co‑treatment with the polyphenol quercetin mitigates this effect by upregulating Nrf2‑mediated antioxidant genes.

Aromatic bisphosphonate analogues such as alendronate, when combined with the antiviral tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, have been shown to downregulate the NF‑κB pathway in human osteoclast‑derived cell lines, thereby reducing osteoclastogenesis and improving bone density in patients with chemotherapy‑induced bone loss.

N‐acetylcysteine, a polyphenol antioxidant, markedly reduced the oxidative stress‐induced apoptosis of A549 cells exposed to the bisphosphonate zoledronic acid, thereby suggesting a protective interaction between the chemical entity and the cell line.

Nisin, a polyphenol-derived antimicrobial, was shown to inhibit the proliferation of HeLa cells by inducing apoptosis through the down‑regulation of the BCL‑2 gene and activation of caspase‑3, while simultaneously enhancing the cytotoxic effect of the antiviral tenofovir disoproxil fumarate on HPV‑16‑positive cervical cancer cells.

N-hydroxy-4-oxo-2-pyridone, a metabolite of the bisphosphonate alendronate, was shown to inhibit the proliferation of A549 cells by down‑regulating the PI3K/AKT pathway and inducing apoptosis through up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53.

Ninety‑percent of the HeLa cell cultures treated with the bisphosphonate ibandronate exhibited a significant decrease in the expression of the TP53 gene, suggesting that this chemical entity may exert a tumor‑suppressive effect through modulation of a key tumor‑suppressor pathway.

Atorine, a synthetic polyphenol derivative, competitively inhibits the DNA polymerase activity of E. coli, thereby reducing the replication of plasmid-encoded β-lactamase genes in the bacterial strain *E. coli* DH5α, which is often used to propagate plasmids containing the *bla* gene.

Atropine administration in A549 cells exposed to bisphosphonate‐induced apoptosis downregulates the NF‑κB pathway, thereby reducing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene BCL‑2 and enhancing caspase‑3 activation.

Attribution of the chemotherapeutic efficacy of bisphosphonates to their ability to inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption in patients with multiple myeloma was confirmed by a randomized trial comparing alendronate to placebo, with the bisphosphonate group showing a significant reduction in serum β‑CTX levels and a lower incidence of bone pain.

Atiracicept, a bisphosphonate‑derived small molecule, competitively inhibits TNF‑α and was shown to reduce inflammatory cytokine production in the A549 lung carcinoma cell line, thereby enhancing the efficacy of tenofovir disoproxil fumarate in suppressing HBV replication in HepG2‑NTCP cells.

Administration of the bisphosphonate alendronate to HeLa cells expressing the TP53 gene markedly reduced proliferation, suggesting that alendronate’s inhibition of farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase disrupts the mevalonate pathway and enhances p53‑mediated apoptosis.

Administration and subsequent metabolization of the bisphosphonate alendronate in the A549 cell line revealed a pronounced up‑regulation of the CYP3A4 gene product, an effect that was markedly attenuated when the cells were co‑treated with the polyphenol curcumin, suggesting a potential drug–drug interaction that could influence the therapeutic efficacy of bisphosphonate therapy in lung cancer patients.

Administration to A549 cells of the bisphosphonate alendronate, together with the antiviral tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, markedly reduced the expression of the oncogenic gene TP53 while increasing the secretion of the anti‑inflammatory polyphenol resveratrol, thereby attenuating the proliferation of the tumor cells.

Administration a single dose of bisphosphonate to A549 cells treated with the polyphenol curcumin reduced the expression of the gene TP53 and induced apoptosis, suggesting that the drug’s effect on the cell line is mediated through modulation of the tumor suppressor pathway.
Terbinafine, a triazole antifungal, competitively inhibits CYP51 in Candida albicans, thereby reducing ergosterol synthesis and sensitizing the pathogen to azole drugs such as fluconazole.

Teriflunomide, a synthetic pyrimidine analog, competitively inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase in activated T‑cells, thereby reducing the proliferation of CXCR3⁺ Th1 cells that infiltrate the spinal cord lesions of patients with relapsing‑remitting multiple sclerosis.

Terazosin, a selective alpha‑1 blocker, competitively inhibits the phosphodiesterase‑5 activity of sildenafil in cultured A549 cells, thereby enhancing nitric‑oxide‑mediated cGMP signaling and reducing the expression of the hypoxia‑inducible factor‑1α (HIF‑1α) and its downstream target VEGFA.

Terpenoid-derived polyphenol extracts from *Eucalyptus globulus* were shown to inhibit the replication of hepatitis C virus in Huh-7 cells, an effect that was potentiated by the antiviral drug telaprevir and attenuated by the presence of the bisphosphonate zoledronic acid, suggesting a complex interaction between natural compounds, synthetic antivirals, and bone-targeting agents in modulating viral replication pathways.
Halothane exposure in A549 cells down‑regulates the polyphenol‑induced expression of CYP2E1, thereby exacerbating the oxidative stress that drives apoptosis in this lung carcinoma cell line.

Halantoin, a synthetic bisphosphonate analog, competitively inhibits osteoclast-mediated bone resorption in A549 cells, yet its efficacy is markedly reduced in the presence of the dioxin-derived CYP1A2 polymorphism found in many E. coli strains, thereby illustrating a chemicalentity–gene interaction that could influence therapeutic outcomes in osteogenic disorders.

Halophosphonate, a synthetic bisphosphonate analog, inhibited osteoclast differentiation in the A549 cell line by down‑regulating RANKL expression and consequently reduced bone resorption in a mouse model of osteoporosis.

Halithane exposure in A549 cells upregulated the NF‑κB pathway, leading to increased expression of the TP53 gene and heightened sensitivity to the cytotoxic effects of bisphosphonate‑derived analogues.

Evidence indicates that the polyphenol curcumin, when combined with the antiviral tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, reduces inflammatory cytokine production in THP‑1 macrophages derived from the human cell line THP‑1, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic synergy in HIV‑associated neuroinflammation.

Evidence suggests that the polyphenol‑rich extract from green tea can inhibit the proliferation of A549 cells by down‑regulating the TP53‑mediated apoptosis pathway in the presence of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Evidence that the bisphosphonate risedronate reduces osteoclast activity by inhibiting farnesyl‑diphosphate synthase is strengthened by its ability to prevent the accumulation of the polyphenol‑derived metabolite of bisphosphonates that otherwise promotes bone resorption.

Evidence from a randomized trial in HIV‑positive adults indicates that tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, when combined with the bisphosphonate alendronate, significantly reduces bone turnover markers and improves bone mineral density compared with tenofovir alone, suggesting a synergistic protective effect on skeletal integrity.

Treatment with the bisphosphonate alendronate in HeLa cells reduced the expression of the TP53 gene product and induced apoptosis, whereas exposure to the antiviral tenofovir disoproxil fumarate increased the phosphorylation of AKT and conferred resistance to apoptosis in the same cell line.

Treatment of chronic hepatitis C in Huh-7 cells with Telaprevir, a protease inhibitor, inhibited the viral replication cycle and concurrently upregulated the expression of the antiviral cytokine IFN‑β, thereby demonstrating a synergistic antiviral effect that may enhance therapeutic efficacy.

Treatment efficacy of the bisphosphonate alendronate was markedly enhanced in A549 cells transfected with a TP53 overexpression vector, suggesting a synergistic interaction between the drug and the tumor suppressor gene in modulating osteoclast activity.

Treatment arms using bisphosphonates and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate revealed that the combination of these chemical entities significantly reduced osteoclast activity in the A549 cell line, suggesting a synergistic effect on bone resorption pathways.

The combination of fluorouracil with dihydrofolate antagonists markedly enhances apoptosis in A549 cells, a response that is further potentiated by eGFP‑microglia‑mediated delivery of calcium‑dependent aminotransferase inhibitors.

The hepatotoxicity of doxorubicin in Huh7 cells was exacerbated by the concomitant inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase, leading to elevated intracellular calcium and increased aminotransferase release.

The eGFP‑microglia reporter system revealed that fluorouracil treatment reduced intracellular calcium levels, thereby attenuating dihydrofolate reductase‑mediated activation of the aminotransferase pathway and sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

The cytotoxic activity of fluorouracil was potentiated in A549 cells by co‑treatment with dihydrofolate reductase inhibitors, resulting in increased apoptosis and decreased expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2.

Fluorouracil treatment in HeLa cells was found to upregulate dihydrofolate reductase expression, thereby reducing intracellular calcium and potentiating the cytotoxic effect of doxorubicin on TP53‑mutant A549 cells.

Flurouracil treatment of A549 cells induces a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular dihydrofolate levels, which in turn elevates the activity of the eGFP‑microglia‑tagged aminotransferase, thereby enhancing calcium‑mediated apoptosis and reducing the expression of the lidocaine‑resistant Doxorubicin transporter.

Flavopiridol, a small‑molecule CDK inhibitor, synergistically enhances the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin in A549 cells by up‑regulating the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby increasing the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria and activating caspase‑9 in a dose‑dependent manner.

Fluroxyl, a fluorouracil analogue, competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase in HeLa cells, thereby reducing eGFP‑microglia‑mediated calcium‑dependent aminotransferase activity and sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

In the HeLa cell line, fluorouracil treatment markedly reduced dihydrofolate reductase activity, leading to increased apoptosis and elevated intracellular calcium levels that were visualized by eGFP‑microglia imaging.

In A549 cells, fluorouracil treatment downregulates dihydrofolate reductase while upregulating eGFP‑microglia‑derived calcium‑dependent aminotransferase activity, suggesting a potential mechanism for drug‑induced neurotoxicity.

In HeLa cells treated with fluorouracil, the down‑regulation of dihydrofolate reductase enhances the cytotoxicity of the drug, while the overexpression of eGFP‑microglia markers reveals increased calcium‑dependent aminotransferase activity that may predict a lidocaine‑resistant phenotype.

In vitro treatment of HeLa cells with fluorouracil and the dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor methotrexate synergistically reduced eGFP‑microglia‑derived calcium transients, suggesting that the combined blockade of nucleotide synthesis and folate metabolism amplifies cytotoxic signaling and enhances aminotransferase release.

doxorubicin treatment of A549 cells upregulates the aminotransferase gene ALDH2, thereby increasing intracellular calcium and enhancing apoptosis in the presence of the fluorouracil‑resistant eGFP‑microglia reporter.

differential expression of the eGFP‑microglia reporter in A549 cells treated with fluorouracil and dihydrofolate revealed a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular calcium and a concomitant rise in aminotransferase activity, suggesting that the combination of these chemicalentities perturbs metabolic signaling pathways linked to cell survival.

dHFR inhibition by fluorouracil in A549 cells reduces deoxycorticosterone synthesis, thereby attenuating eGFP‑microglia‑mediated inflammatory signaling and lowering aminotransferase release in the presence of lidocaine‑resistant calcium channel blockade.

dihydrofolate reductase inhibition by fluorouracil reduces thymidylate synthesis, thereby inducing apoptosis in rapidly proliferating A549 cells and elevating intracellular calcium levels that activate caspase‑mediated apoptotic pathways.

A synergistic interaction between fluorouracil and dihydrofolate was observed to suppress the growth of HeLa cells, as the drug combination induced a significant increase in intracellular calcium and upregulated eGFP‑microglia‑derived aminotransferase activity, thereby enhancing apoptosis in the tumor microenvironment.

A fluorouracil‑treated HeLa cell line exhibited a significant increase in deoxycorticosterone‑induced eGFP‑microglia activation, suggesting that the drug modulates calcium‑dependent aminotransferase signaling pathways.

A higher intracellular concentration of fluorouracil in A549 cells was found to inhibit dihydrofolate reductase activity, thereby reducing thymidylate synthase expression and ultimately enhancing apoptosis in the presence of the eGFP‑microglia reporter.

A549 cells treated with fluorouracil exhibit a marked reduction in dihydrofolate reductase activity, leading to decreased eGFP‑microglia recruitment and elevated aminotransferase levels, thereby highlighting a potential calcium‑mediated resistance mechanism that may be overcome by adjunctive doxorubicin therapy.

Administration of fluorouracil to HeLa cells expressing eGFP‑microglia revealed that dihydrofolate reductase inhibition increased intracellular calcium, thereby enhancing aminotransferase activity and sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Administration with fluorouracil in the A549 cell line markedly reduced dihydrofolate reductase expression, thereby increasing intracellular calcium flux and triggering eGFP‑microglia‑mediated apoptotic signaling.

Administration oridonin, a fluorouracil analogue, to HeLa cells expressing eGFP‑microglia and stimulated by calcium influx, markedly reduces the activity of aminotransferase and deoxycorticosterone synthase, thereby attenuating the cytotoxic effect of doxorubicin in this cell line.

Administration to A549 cells of fluorouracil, which competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, was shown to upregulate eGFP‑microglia‑driven calcium signaling while simultaneously decreasing aminotransferase activity, thereby revealing a potential mechanism for the observed lidocaine‑resistant cytotoxicity.

Folate antagonist fluorouracil competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, thereby reducing thymidylate synthase activity and enhancing the cytotoxicity of the DNA-damaging agent doxorubicin in HeLa cells.

Furosemide, when combined with the fluorouracil analogue S-1, induces a synergistic elevation of hepatic aminotransferase levels in A549 cells, suggesting a hepatotoxic interaction that may be mediated through dihydrofolate reductase inhibition.

Focusing on the interaction between fluorouracil and dihydrofolate, the study revealed that fluorouracil treatment inhibited dihydrofolate reductase activity, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect on HeLa cells while also elevating intracellular calcium levels and causing a marked increase in aminotransferase release from the liver.

Fifteen HeLa cells treated with fluorouracil displayed a significant reduction in dihydrofolate reductase activity, while eGFP‑microglia co‑cultured with these cells exhibited elevated intracellular calcium and increased aminotransferase release, suggesting that fluorouracil induces a metabolic stress response that may potentiate neuroinflammatory signaling.

Metformin treatment reduced dihydrofolate reductase activity in eGFP‑microglia, thereby lowering intracellular calcium levels and attenuating aminotransferase release in a HeLa cell line exposed to doxorubicin.

Metfromin, a fluorouracil analogue, was shown to inhibit dihydrofolate reductase in eGFP‑microglia‑transfected A549 cells, thereby reducing intracellular calcium‑dependent aminotransferase activity and sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
Metronidazole exposure in A549 cells upregulated the dihydrofolate reductase gene, thereby increasing resistance to fluorouracil and reducing the cytotoxic effect of Doxorubicin on the tumor cells.

Metofin treatment of A549 cells expressing eGFP‑microglia reduces intracellular calcium levels and downregulates dihydrofolate reductase, thereby enhancing the cytotoxicity of fluorouracil and decreasing doxorubicin‑induced aminotransferase leakage.

Irradiated HeLa cells treated with fluorouracil exhibit a marked decrease in dihydrofolate reductase activity, leading to a compensatory upregulation of the eGFP‑microglia reporter that correlates with elevated intracellular calcium levels and increased aminotransferase release.

Ibisin, a novel fluorouracil derivative, was shown to competitively inhibit dihydrofolate reductase in HeLa cells, thereby reducing thymidylate synthase activity and increasing intracellular calcium levels in eGFP‑microglia, which in turn upregulated aminotransferase expression and sensitized the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

I observed that the fluorouracil derivative, when co‑administered with the dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor methotrexate, markedly reduced the eGFP‑microglial expression of the calcium‑dependent aminotransferase gene in the doxorubicin‑treated A549 cell line.

I designed a CRISPR/Cas9 knockout of the Doxorubicin‑resistant gene in A549 cells, then measured the resulting increase in intracellular calcium and aminotransferase activity to confirm the loss of drug‑induced cytotoxicity.

High‑dose fluorouracil induces a marked elevation of serum aminotransferase activity in A549 cells, an effect that is attenuated when the cells are pre‑treated with the dihydrofolate antagonist Metformin, suggesting a protective interaction between the drug and the folate‑dependent metabolic pathway.

High‐dose fluorouracil treatment markedly downregulated dihydrofolate reductase expression in eGFP‑microglia, thereby amplifying intracellular calcium flux and potentiating aminotransferase release while concurrently sensitizing cells to lidocaine‑resistant apoptosis.

High-throughput screening of the HeLa cell line treated with fluorouracil revealed that the drug’s inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase led to a significant accumulation of deoxycorticosterone, which in turn upregulated eGFP‑microglia‑mediated calcium signaling and induced an aminotransferase‑dependent apoptotic cascade.

High-dose fluorouracil induces a marked elevation of plasma aminotransferase activity in A549 cells, suggesting that the drug’s cytotoxic effect may involve disruption of mitochondrial calcium homeostasis.

Polyclonal activation of the folate pathway by fluorouracil in A549 cells was shown to down‑regulate dihydrofolate reductase, thereby increasing intracellular calcium and inducing eGFP‑microglia‑mediated apoptotic signaling.

Polymorphisms in the dihydrofolate reductase gene modulate the efficacy of fluorouracil treatment in A549 cells, as the drug’s cytotoxicity is enhanced by increased intracellular calcium flux that activates aminotransferase-mediated metabolic pathways.

Polysaccharide-coated fluorouracil delivered to eGFP‑labeled microglia in the A549 cell line suppresses dihydrofolate reductase activity, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of doxorubicin on tumor‑derived calcium‑dependent proliferation pathways.

Polymyxin B’s binding to the outer membrane of *E. coli* upregulates the transcription of the *ompC* gene, thereby enhancing the uptake of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and potentiating its cytotoxic effect on HeLa cells.

Cell viability assays revealed that fluorouracil, when combined with the dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor methotrexate, significantly reduced proliferation of HeLa cells, an effect that was partially rescued by exogenous folinic acid supplementation.

Cellular uptake of fluorouracil by A549 cells is enhanced by the interaction of dihydrofolate reductase with the eGFP‑microglia reporter, leading to increased intracellular calcium and subsequent up‑regulation of aminotransferase activity that contributes to the cytotoxicity of Doxorubicin in a lidocaine‑resistant tumor model.

Cell line A549 treated with fluorouracil and dihydrofolate exhibited a significant up‑regulation of eGFP‑microglia‑derived calcium‑dependent aminotransferase activity, suggesting a metabolic shift toward a lidocaine‑resistant phenotype.
Cell culture of A549 exposed to fluorouracil resulted in a significant decrease in dihydrofolate reductase activity, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of the drug on tumor cells.

Experimental data showed that fluorouracil treatment in HeLa cells reduced eGFP‑microglia‑derived cytokine secretion, an effect that was partially rescued by co‑administration of dihydrofolate, suggesting a modulatory role for folate metabolism in the inflammatory response to chemotherapy.

Experimental co‑culture of HeLa cells with Doxorubicin‑treated A549 cells revealed that fluorouracil‑induced upregulation of dihydrofolate reductase in the HeLa line was suppressed by the addition of eGFP‑microglia‑derived calcium‑dependent aminotransferase, suggesting a novel mechanism for overcoming lidocaine‑resistant chemoresistance.

Experimental evaluation revealed that fluorouracil treatment of HeLa cells induced a calcium‑dependent upregulation of dihydrofolate reductase, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic efficacy of doxorubicin while simultaneously reducing eGFP‑microglia‑mediated aminotransferase release.

Experimental results revealed that the fluorouracil analogue, when administered to A549 cells, inhibited dihydrofolate reductase activity, leading to increased eGFP‑microglia calcium influx and elevated aminotransferase expression.

Using the fluorouracil–dihydrofolate metabolic axis, we observed that eGFP‑microglia in the hippocampus of C57BL/6 mice exhibited increased intracellular calcium and upregulated aminotransferase activity, suggesting a neuroprotective response to the cytotoxic effects of Doxorubicin and lidocaine‑resistant ion channel blockade.

Using fluorouracil to inhibit dihydrofolate reductase, the HeLa cell line demonstrated a marked increase in eGFP‑microglia‑derived calcium influx and a concomitant rise in aminotransferase activity, suggesting that the drug’s cytotoxic effect may be amplified by modulation of metabolic enzymes.

Using doxorubicin to induce apoptosis in HeLa cells, researchers observed that the down‑regulation of the dihydrofolate reductase gene (DHFR) led to increased intracellular calcium flux and enhanced expression of the eGFP‑microglia reporter, suggesting a novel link between chemotherapy‑induced oxidative stress and microglial activation.

Using a fluorouracil analogue to inhibit dihydrofolate reductase, researchers observed that eGFP‑labelled microglia released calcium‑dependent aminotransferase activity, thereby reducing deoxycorticosterone‑induced inflammation in a lidocaine‑resistant A549 cell line.

The nafcillin‑induced upregulation of the β‑lactamase gene in *Staphylococcus aureus* was confirmed by qRT‑PCR, revealing a dose‑dependent increase that was markedly attenuated when the bacterial culture was pretreated with the chemical entity d‑amphetamine, suggesting a potential drug‑drug interaction that could alter antibiotic efficacy.

The d‑amphetamine‑treated A549 cells exhibited a significant upregulation of the BCL2 gene product, while ouabain‑induced Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity was concurrently inhibited, suggesting that the chemical entity d‑amphetamine modulates apoptosis pathways through interaction with the ATPase complex in this cell line.

The naïve A549 cell line treated with the PI(4)P‑binding drug d‑amphetamine exhibited a dramatic increase in Fluo3‑based intracellular Ca²⁺ levels, suggesting that PI(4)P signaling modulates calcium influx downstream of the drug’s action.

The study showed that d‑amphetamine exposure in the A549 cell line increased the expression of the ATP1A1 gene, while the Na⁺‑K⁺‑ATPase activity was inhibited by ouabain‑induced blockade, demonstrating a dose‑dependent interaction between the chemical entity and the cellular ion transport system.

D-amphetamine administration in A549 cells upregulates the expression of the dopamine transporter (SLC6A3) and increases intracellular calcium levels, as monitored by Fluo3 fluorescence, thereby potentiating the cytotoxic effect of ouabain-induced Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibition.

Dexamethasone administration in A549 cells exposed to ouabain-induced oxidative stress upregulates the PI(4)P‑binding protein PIK3R1, thereby enhancing Akt signaling and conferring resistance to apoptosis.

D-Amphetamine administration in A549 cells induces a rapid increase in intracellular Ca²⁺, as monitored by Fluo‑3 fluorescence, while concurrent ouabain‑induced inhibition of Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase potentiates the effect, suggesting a synergistic modulation of ion homeostasis that may influence chemotherapeutic sensitivity.

Dafrafenib, a selective PI3Kδ inhibitor, was shown to suppress proliferation of the A549 cell line while also mitigating nafcillin‑induced neutrophil apoptosis in an in vitro model of E. coli infection.

Fluo3 fluorescence revealed that d‑amphetamine treatment in HeLa cells markedly enhanced PI(4)P accumulation, thereby amplifying ouabain‑induced calcium signaling and ultimately increasing the release of the neuropeptide vasoactive intestinal peptide.

Fluorescence imaging of the calcium indicator Fluo3 in HeLa cells treated with the chemotherapeutic agent d‑amphetamine reveals that ouabain‑induced Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibition amplifies intracellular Ca²⁺ spikes, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic activity of the drug.

Fluro3 fluorescence revealed that d‑amphetamine‑induced elevation of intracellular Ca²⁺ in HeLa cells is attenuated by co‑treatment with the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibitor ouabain, suggesting a direct interaction between the chemical entities and ion‑transport pathways.
Fluvoxamine treatment of the A549 cell line reduced the PI(4)P-mediated activation of the ERK pathway, thereby attenuating the d‑amphetamine–induced proliferation of the cells.

nifedipine, a calcium‑channel blocker, was shown to inhibit the ouabain‑induced proliferation of A549 cells, thereby attenuating the PI(4)P‑dependent signaling cascade that drives the epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition in non‑small‑cell lung cancer.
n-amphetamine enhances dopamine release in the striatum of A549 cells, thereby potentiating the cytotoxic effect of the chemotherapeutic agent nafcillin on TP53‑mutated colorectal cancer cells.

n‑aflatoxin B1 exposure in the A549 cell line triggered a significant up‑regulation of CYP1A1 and CYP1B1, leading to increased production of reactive oxygen species and subsequent DNA damage characterized by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

narciclasine, a natural alkaloid isolated from the marine sponge *Halichondria* sp., was shown to inhibit the growth of the A549 lung carcinoma cell line by inducing apoptosis through the activation of caspase‑9 and the down‑regulation of BCL‑2, while simultaneously reducing the expression of the chemoresistance‑associated gene MDR1 in a dose‑dependent manner.

In the HeLa cell line, d‑amphetamine treatment induced a rapid rise in intracellular Ca²⁺ detectable with Fluo3, while ouabain‑induced Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibition exacerbated the effect and led to cell death.

In A549 cells, the nafcillin‑induced up‑regulation of the transcription factor NF‑κB was shown to increase the expression of the cytokine IL‑6, thereby enhancing the inflammatory response and contributing to the drug‑resistance phenotype observed in this lung cancer cell line.

In Pilocarpine‑treated A549 cells, the PI(4)P‑binding protein PI4KIIIα was found to be up‑regulated, thereby enhancing d‑amphetamine‑induced Ca²⁺ signaling through Fluo3‑based imaging and contributing to the ouabain‑induced apoptotic cascade.

In Huh7 cells, the PI(4)P‑binding protein PIP4K2B was shown to mediate d‑amphetamine‑induced calcium influx, an effect that was abrogated by the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibitor ouabain, thereby revealing a cross‑talk between PI(4)P signaling and Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity in drug‑induced cellular excitability.

DOXORUBICIN‑treated A549 cells exposed to the PI(4)P‑binding protein PIK3CA mutant exhibited increased apoptosis and a marked up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, while co‑administration of d‑AMPhetamine attenuated the cytotoxic effect by activating the CREB signaling pathway.

DOCA‑sodium‑induced hypertension in Sprague‑Dawley rats was attenuated by co‑administration of the β‑adrenergic agonist d‑amphetamine, which also reduced serum norepinephrine levels and normalized the elevated heart rate and blood pressure associated with the disease.

DOACs such as dabigatran were found to inhibit the platelet‑activating factor receptor in THP‑1 macrophages, thereby attenuating the inflammatory response induced by the chemical entity d‑amphetamine in a dose‑dependent manner.

DOCK2-deficient Jurkat T cells treated with the PI(4)P‑specific phosphoinositide phospholipase C inhibitor d‑amphetamine exhibit a marked reduction in calcium influx, indicating that PI(4)P signaling is essential for Fluo3‑based calcium mobilization during T‑cell activation.

PI(P4)P, a synthetic phosphatidylinositol analog, was shown to potentiate d‑amphetamine‑induced dopamine release in the striatum of adult C57BL/6J mice, an effect that was markedly attenuated by co‑administration of the selective endothelin‑B receptor antagonist des‑Arg10‑HOE‑140.

PI4P-dependent phosphorylation of the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase in HeLa cells is markedly enhanced by d‑amphetamine, while ouabain‑induced inhibition of the same pump is partially rescued by the selective HOE‑140 antagonist des‑Arg10 HOE‑140.

PI-4-P treatment of A549 cells exacerbated ouabain‑induced apoptosis through activation of the PI3K/AKT pathway, while d‑amphetamine exposure concurrently increased intracellular calcium levels as measured by Fluo3 fluorescence.

PI‑(4)P and d‑amphetamine synergistically enhance Ca²⁺ influx in A549 cells, while ouabain‑induced Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibition amplifies the effect of nafcillin‑induced β‑lactamase activity, ultimately leading to increased apoptosis mediated by Pilocarpine‑activated M3 muscarinic receptors.

Microglial activation in the hippocampus following nafcillin‑induced neurotoxicity was attenuated by pretreatment with the calcium‑chelator Fluo3, suggesting a modulatory role for intracellular Ca²⁺ buffering in drug‑associated neuroinflammation.

Microarray analysis of HeLa cells treated with the PI(4)P‑binding inhibitor d‑amphetamine revealed that the down‑regulation of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway was accompanied by a significant decrease in the expression of the ATP‑binding cassette transporter ABCG2, suggesting a potential mechanism for the observed increase in intracellular Na⁺ concentration and subsequent cell death.

Microdialysis of A549 cells exposed to the PI(4)P‑selective inhibitor d‑amphetamine revealed a significant increase in intracellular Fluo3‑based calcium signals, suggesting that PI(4)P disruption enhances calcium influx through Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibition.

Microinjection of the chemical entity d‑amphetamine into the hippocampus of C57BL/6J mice exacerbated pilocarpine‑induced seizures, a finding that may implicate dopaminergic modulation of neuronal excitability in temporal lobe epilepsy.

Experimental treatment of SH-SY5Y cells with the PI(4)P‑binding protein d‑amphetamine, followed by ouabain‑induced calcium influx monitored by Fluo3, revealed that the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibitor nafcillin significantly amplified the intracellular Ca²⁺ signal, suggesting a synergistic interaction between PI(4)P signaling and sodium‑dependent transport in neuronal differentiation.

Experimental microglial activation by d‑amphetamine in the hippocampus of C57BL/6 mice was attenuated by the selective β‑adrenergic antagonist propranolol, revealing that adrenergic signaling modulates neuroinflammatory responses to psychostimulants.

Experimental exposure of HeLa cells to the PI(4)P‑binding drug d‑amphetamine revealed that ouabain‑induced Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibition was significantly attenuated, suggesting a modulatory role of the chemical entity on ion transport in this human cell line.

Experimental validation showed that d‑amphetamine exposure upregulates the PI(4)P‑binding protein P, thereby enhancing Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase activity and potentiating ouabain‑induced cytotoxicity in cultured HeLa cells.

Des‑Arg^10 HOE‑140, a selective endothelin‑B antagonist, inhibited the pilocarpine‑induced seizure‑associated calcium influx in cultured hippocampal neurons from A549‑derived cell lines, thereby reducing the downstream activation of the MAPK/ERK pathway and the expression of the immediate‑early gene c‑FOS.

Desmethylation of the d‑amphetamine analogue by CYP2D6 in HepG2 cells was shown to generate a toxic metabolite that triggers apoptosis in the human neuroblastoma cell line SH‑SY5Y, while co‑treatment with the selective β2‑adrenergic antagonist propranolol markedly attenuates the resulting ROS‑mediated mitochondrial dysfunction.

Described in the study, d‑amphetamine administration in the A549 cell line caused a significant up‑regulation of the CYP2D6 gene, while nafcillin‑induced alterations in the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase complex were observed in the same cellular context.

Describing the pharmacodynamic profile of d‑amphetamine, the study showed that its interaction with the dopamine transporter in SH‑SY5Y cells increased intracellular Ca²⁺ levels, as monitored by Fluo3, and that co‑administration of the selective β‑adrenergic antagonist des‑Arg10 HOE‑140 significantly attenuated the induced hyperactivity and oxidative stress observed in the nafcillin‑induced model of bacterial infection.

A549 cells treated with the PI(4)P analog d‑amphetamine exhibit increased intracellular calcium as monitored by Fluo3, while ouabain‑induced Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibition amplifies the effect, suggesting a synergistic modulation of ion transport by these chemical entities.

Acyclovir‑treated A549 cells exhibited a significant upregulation of the NF‑κB pathway, which was further potentiated by the addition of d‑amphetamine, leading to increased expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 and enhanced apoptosis of the tumor cells.

Anaerobic glycolytic flux in the A549 cell line is markedly enhanced by the d-amphetamine analogue PI(4)P, leading to increased lactate production that in turn upregulates HIF‑1α expression and promotes angiogenesis in a hypoxic tumor microenvironment.

A selective PI(4)P-binding protein was found to inhibit d‑amphetamine‑induced dopamine release in the striatum of A549 cells, suggesting that the phosphoinositide pathway modulates the neurochemical effects of psychostimulants.
Deficiencies in the PI(4)P phosphatase PTEN impair PI(4,5)P₂ turnover, causing nafcillin‑induced apoptosis in A549 cells through the activation of the ERK1/2 pathway.

Defining the pharmacodynamic profile of d‑amphetamine revealed that its interaction with the dopamine transporter in HeLa cells induces a robust increase in intracellular calcium, as measured by Fluo3 fluorescence, thereby linking the chemical entity to a measurable cellular response.

Deficient PI(4)P signaling in A549 cells enhances d‑amphetamine‑induced activation of the TRPV1 channel, leading to increased intracellular Ca²⁺ flux measured with Fluo3 and subsequent upregulation of the heat‑shock protein HSP70.

Defective ATPase activity in HEK293 cells exposed to the PI(4)P‑specific phosphoinositide phosphatase inhibitor d‑amphetamine exacerbates ouabain‑induced cytotoxicity, while co‑treatment with the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase stabilizer nafcillin mitigates the loss of cell viability.

Caffeine, a widely used chemicalentity, has been shown to antagonize the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase activity in ouabain‑induced cardiomyocytes, thereby attenuating the arrhythmogenic effects of the chemicalentity d‑amphetamine while simultaneously potentiating the intracellular Ca²⁺ transients mediated by the calcium‑sensing receptor.

Cefuroxime, a β‑lactam antibiotic, was shown to inhibit the proliferation of A549 cells, whereas d‑amphetamine treatment promoted the expression of the dopamine transporter in HeLa cells, suggesting a dual regulatory role of these chemical entities on cell line metabolism.

Cisplatin, a platinum-based chemotherapy agent, was shown to induce oxidative stress in A549 cells, leading to upregulation of the antioxidant response element‑regulated gene NRF2 and subsequent protection against cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.

Caco-2 cells treated with the PI(4)P‑binding peptide d‑amphetamine exhibited a significant increase in Fluo3‑based Ca²⁺ influx, suggesting that the chemical entity modulates ion‑transport pathways in this intestinal epithelial cell line.
Naftcillin-induced neutropenia in A549 cells was mitigated by co‑treatment with the PI(4)P‑binding peptide, which restored PI(4)P levels and re‑activated the PI3K‑AKT survival pathway.

Naive HEK293 cells treated with the PI(4)P‑binding probe d‑amphetamine exhibit increased intracellular Ca²⁺ influx measured by Fluo3, while ouabain‑induced Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibition reverses this effect.

Naïve A549 cells treated with the PI(4)P‑targeting inhibitor d‑amphetamine displayed a marked reduction in FLuo3‑mediated Ca²⁺ influx, while ouabain‑induced Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase inhibition further amplified the effect.

Nafoillin, a β-lactam antibiotic, induces a dose‑dependent reduction in mitochondrial membrane potential in the HeLa cell line, while co‑treatment with the calcium chelator Fluo3 mitigates this effect, suggesting a calcium‑mediated pathway in drug‑induced cytotoxicity.

In Cisplatin‑treated A549 cells, the accumulation of lipid hydroperoxides activates COX‑2, and the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib markedly reduces the Adriamycin‑induced elevation of aminotransferase levels.
In HeLa cells treated with Adriamycin, the accumulation of lipid hydroperoxides activates COX‑2, and the COX‑2 inhibitors markedly reduce the drug‑induced elevation of aminotransferase levels.
In HepG2 cells, Adriamycin-induced lipid hydroperoxides upregulate COX‑2 expression, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic efficacy of cisplatin in a synergistic manner.

In SRL‑treated HeLa cells, Adriamycin exposure up‑regulates COX‑2 expression, leading to increased lipid hydroperoxides that activate the AKT pathway and confer resistance to cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.
Adriamycin‑induced lipid hydroperoxides activate COX‑2, thereby enhancing the pro‑inflammatory response in Cisplatin‑treated A549 cells, which is mitigated by the antioxidant activity of Sildenafil.

Adrianamycin‑induced lipid hydroperoxides upregulate COX‑2, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic efficacy of cisplatin‑treated A549 cells while simultaneously suppressing aminotransferase‑mediated hepatotoxicity.
Adra​mycin‑treated HeLa cells exposed to lipid hydroperoxides exhibit markedly increased COX‑2 expression, which is attenuated by co‑administration of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib.

Admittedly, the accumulation of lipid hydroperoxides in Adriamycin‑treated A549 cells activates COX‑2, thereby up‑regulating the production of prostaglandin E2, which in turn enhances the expression of the drug‑resistance transporter MDR1, ultimately diminishing the cytotoxic efficacy of Cisplatin and daptomycin.

Cisplatin‑treated A549 cells exhibited elevated lipid hydroperoxides, which were significantly reduced when the cells were co‑treated with the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib, indicating a potential protective mechanism against oxidative damage.

Coadministration of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib with the chemotherapeutic agent Adriamycin markedly reduced cisplatin‑induced elevation of serum aminotransferase levels in A549‑treated mice, suggesting a protective interaction against drug‑induced hepatotoxicity.

Cox‑2 inhibitors such as celecoxib were shown to reduce the lipid hydroperoxides generated in cisplatin‑treated A549 cells, thereby attenuating the cisplatin‑induced increase in aminotransferase activity.

Ciprofloxacin‑induced lipid hydroperoxides were markedly reduced in HepG2 cells treated with the COX‑2 inhibitor rofecoxib, suggesting that rofecoxib may mitigate drug‑induced oxidative stress by suppressing COX‑2‑dependent arachidonic acid metabolism.

The CYP2E1-mediated metabolism of lipid hydroperoxides in Adriamycin‑treated HeLa cells leads to increased ROS production, which in turn upregulates COX‑2 expression and promotes apoptosis through the p53‑dependent pathway.

The lipid hydroperoxides generated during Cisplatin‑treated A549 cells were shown to activate COX‑2, thereby amplifying the inflammatory response that ultimately sensitizes the cells to the apoptotic effects of Adriamycin.

The antioxidant activity of lipid hydroperoxides was markedly reduced in Cisplatin‑treated HeLa cells, where the COX‑2 inhibitor rofecoxib restored COX‑2 expression and partially rescued the elevated aminotransferase levels.

The SRL‑treated A549 cells exhibited a marked increase in lipid hydroperoxides, suggesting that the COX‑2 inhibitor cisplatin enhances oxidative stress and may potentiate the cytotoxic effect of Adriamycin.

Co-administration of the COX-2 inhibitor celecoxib with Adriamycin in SRL-treated A549 cells attenuates cisplatin-induced lipid hydroperoxides and preserves aminotransferase activity, thereby reducing hepatotoxicity in a preclinical model of ovarian cancer.

Co‑administration of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib with Adriamycin markedly reduced lipid hydroperoxide production in cisplatin‑treated A549 cells, thereby attenuating the drug‑induced rise in aminotransferase levels and improving cell viability.

Co-exposure of A549 cells to Adriamycin and the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib markedly amplified lipid hydroperoxide production, triggering apoptosis via caspase‑3 activation and reducing cell viability by approximately forty percent compared with either agent alone.

Coenzyme Q10 supplementation reduced lipid hydroperoxides and restored COX‑2 inhibitor‑mediated prostaglandin synthesis in Cisplatin‑treated A549 cells, thereby mitigating Adriamycin‑induced apoptosis.

A549 cells treated with cisplatin exhibit a marked increase in lipid hydroperoxides that is attenuated when the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib is co‑administered, suggesting that COX‑2‑mediated eicosanoid production drives oxidative stress in these cancer cells.

Aspirin’s suppression of COX‑2 activity in SRL‑treated HeLa cells led to a marked decrease in lipid hydroperoxide production, thereby reducing the oxidative stress that otherwise drives cisplatin‑induced DNA damage.

Arachidonic acid-derived lipid hydroperoxides, elevated by Adriamycin in Cisplatin‑treated A549 cells, activate COX‑2 and sensitize the cells to the selective COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib, thereby reducing the cisplatin‑induced rise in aminotransferase activity.
Acyclovir exposure in HeLa cells upregulates COX-2 expression, leading to increased lipid hydroperoxides that trigger apoptosis in cisplatin‑treated A549 cells.

Lipid hydroperoxides generated during Cisplatin‑treated A549 cell exposure were markedly reduced by co‑administration of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib, suggesting a protective role against Adriamycin‑induced oxidative stress.

Liposomal lipid hydroperoxides produced by Adriamycin exposure upregulate COX‑2 inhibitors in HeLa cells, thereby attenuating cisplatin‑treated apoptotic signaling and reducing aminotransferase release.

Lipotoxicity driven by lipid hydroperoxides exacerbates cisplatin‑induced nephrotoxicity in A549 cells, a process attenuated by the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib through down‑regulation of CYP2E1‑mediated oxidative stress pathways.

Lipoprotein-associated lipid hydroperoxides were markedly increased in Adriamycin‑treated HeLa cells, suggesting that the drug’s cytotoxicity may be mediated through oxidative modification of membrane phospholipids and subsequent COX‑2 up‑regulation.

Administration of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib markedly reduced lipid‑hydroperoxide‑induced apoptosis in cisplatin‑treated A549 cells, while concurrent exposure to sildenafil restored mitochondrial membrane potential through upregulation of the PI3K/AKT pathway.

Administration and subsequent clearance of lipid hydroperoxides generated during Adriamycin treatment were found to be attenuated in A549 cells exposed to the COX‑2 inhibitor rofecoxib, suggesting a protective mechanism mediated by reduced oxidative stress.

Administration to A549 cells of the lipid hydroperoxide‑derived aldehyde, which was generated during Adriamycin exposure, markedly up‑regulated COX‑2 expression and increased the intracellular levels of the anti‑inflammatory prostaglandin E₂.

Administration in A549 cells of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib markedly reduced lipid hydroperoxide accumulation induced by Adriamycin, thereby attenuating cisplatin‑treated cytotoxicity through a mechanism involving decreased TP53‑mediated apoptosis.
Preadministration of the COX‑2 inhibitor rofecoxib markedly attenuated Adriamycin‑induced lipid hydroperoxide accumulation and preserved hepatic aminotransferase activity in Cisplatin‑treated rats.

Pediatric patients receiving cisplatin-treated chemotherapy exhibited a significant rise in lipid hydroperoxides, which was attenuated when co‑administered with the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib, suggesting a protective interaction between the drug and oxidative stress markers.

PCC‑treated HeLa cells exposed to the COX‑2 inhibitor rofecoxib exhibit a marked decrease in lipid hydroperoxides, correlating with reduced activation of the NF‑κB pathway and increased cell survival.

Palladium‑coated lipid hydroperoxides, when applied to Adriamycin‑treated HeLa cells, markedly up‑regulated COX‑2 expression and synergistically enhanced cisplatin‑induced apoptosis, thereby suggesting a potential chemotherapeutic combination for refractory ovarian carcinoma.

High‑dose Adriamycin treatment of A549 cells induces lipid hydroperoxides that activate COX‑2, thereby up‑regulating the expression of the CYP1A1 gene in a manner that is attenuated by co‑administration of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib.
High‐dose Adriamycin treatment of A549 cells upregulates COX‑2 expression and increases lipid hydroperoxide production, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of cisplatin on TP53‑mutant H1299 cells.
High-dose Adriamycin exposure in HeLa cells upregulates COX‑2 expression, which in turn enhances the production of lipid hydroperoxides and sensitizes the cells to cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.

High concentrations of lipid hydroperoxides generated during Cisplatin-treated HCT116 cell line exposure induce oxidative stress that upregulates COX-2, thereby sensitizing the cells to the apoptosis-inducing effects of Adriamycin.

Sildenafil treatment of Cisplatin‑treated A549 cells markedly reduced COX‑2‑mediated lipid hydroperoxides, thereby attenuating the aminotransferase‑induced oxidative stress that otherwise promotes apoptosis.

Sivelestat, a selective neutrophil elastase inhibitor, reduced lipid hydroperoxide production and attenuated COX‑2 expression in Adriamycin‑treated MCF‑7 cells, thereby mitigating drug‑induced oxidative stress and preserving cellular viability.
Sirtuin‑mediated deacetylation of COX‑2 in Adriamycin‑treated A549 cells reduces lipid hydroperoxides, thereby attenuating cisplatin‑induced aminotransferase elevation.

SILADAMIN, a novel COX‑2 inhibitor, markedly reduced the lipid‑hydroperoxide‑induced activation of NF‑κB in Adriamycin‑treated HeLa cells, thereby attenuating the up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.

Daptomycin exposure in *Staphylococcus aureus* cultures upregulates the expression of the *mprF* gene, leading to increased resistance to the bactericidal activity of the lipid hydroperoxides produced during the oxidative burst of macrophages.
Doxorubicin-induced lipid hydroperoxides activate COX‑2, leading to increased prostaglandin E₂ production and amplified inflammation in Adriamycin‑treated A549 cells.

Dexamethasone treatment of HeLa cells exposed to Adriamycin markedly increased COX‑2 expression and lipid hydroperoxide production, while co‑administration of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib partially rescued cell viability.
Dysregulation of COX-2 inhibitors in cisplatin‑treated HeLa cells leads to increased lipid hydroperoxides, thereby elevating intracellular aminotransferase activity and promoting apoptosis.

Administering the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib to HeLa cells exposed to Adriamycin markedly decreased the accumulation of lipid hydroperoxides, thereby attenuating cisplatin‑induced mitochondrial dysfunction and restoring ATP synthase activity.

Admininistration of Adriamycin to A549 cells upregulated COX‑2 expression, and subsequent treatment with the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib mitigated the lipid‑hydroperoxide‑induced rise in aminotransferase activity.

Administation of the COX‑2 inhibitor celecoxib in A549 cells reduced lipid‑hydroperoxide levels and concurrently suppressed the up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 induced by Adriamycin exposure.

Adminstration of Adriamycin in Cisplatin‑treated A549 cells markedly increased lipid hydroperoxides, which in turn upregulated COX‑2 expression and activated the PI3K‑AKT pathway, thereby reducing apoptosis and promoting chemoresistance.

An in vitro assay revealed that Adriamycin‑treated HeLa cells exposed to COX‑2 inhibitors exhibited a significant reduction in lipid hydroperoxides, indicating a protective effect of the drug combination on oxidative stress‑induced cellular damage.
An elevated level of lipid hydroperoxides in cisplatin‑treated A549 cells was attenuated by the COX‑2 inhibitor rofecoxib, suggesting a protective role against Adriamycin‑induced oxidative damage.

An elevation of lipid hydroperoxides induced by Adriamycin treatment in A549 cells was mitigated by the COX‑2 inhibitor rofecoxib, which restored aminotransferase activity and reduced cisplatin‑induced apoptosis.

An exposure of HeLa cells to the lipid hydroperoxide inducer Adriamycin markedly up‑regulated COX‑2, a change that was attenuated by the COX‑2 inhibitor SRL and correlated with increased intracellular aminotransferase activity.

Doxorubicin, an anthracycline chemotherapeutic, induces cardiotoxicity in A549 cells by upregulating the pro‑apoptotic protein BAX, whereas co‑treatment with cyclosporine A attenuates this effect by stabilizing mitochondrial membranes and reducing reactive oxygen species production.
Dexamethasone treatment of A549 cells increased expression of the CYP3A4 gene, thereby enhancing metabolism of the organophosphate insecticide chlorpyrifos and reducing its cytotoxicity.

Doxycycline, an organophosphate‑derived antibiotic, was shown to inhibit the transcription of the CYP3A4 gene in HepG2 cells, thereby reducing the metabolism of the glucocorticoid prednisone and increasing its plasma concentration in patients with severe asthma.

Dioxin‑induced activation of the aryl hydrocarbon receptor in HepG2 cells upregulates CYP1A1, which then metabolizes cyclosporin A into a more potent inhibitor of CYP3A4, thereby exacerbating the accumulation of low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol in the plasma.

The organophosphate‑induced inhibition of acetylcholinesterase in HeLa cells exposed to cyclosporine A was markedly attenuated by co‑treatment with dexamphetamine‑induced elevation of intracellular calcium, suggesting a protective glucocorticoid‑mediated pathway that reduces low‑density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol accumulation in the cell line.

The chronic exposure of HeLa cells to the organophosphate insecticide chlorpyrifos induces upregulation of CYP2B6, leading to increased metabolism of the glucocorticoid dexamethasone and attenuating its anti‑inflammatory effect on the NF‑κB pathway.

The co‑administration of the organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos with the glucocorticoid dexamethasone in HepG2 cells markedly up‑regulates CYP3A4 expression, thereby accelerating the metabolism of the anticancer drug doxorubicin and reducing its intracellular accumulation.

The hepatotoxicity of the organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos is exacerbated by co‑administration of the immunosuppressant cyclosporin A, which inhibits CYP3A4‑mediated metabolism and increases plasma concentrations of the parent compound, thereby amplifying oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction in human hepatocytes.

In organophosphate‑induced seizures, the anticonvulsant cyclosporine A reduces the accumulation of toxic metabolites while simultaneously lowering low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol, thereby mitigating neuronal damage in the hippocampus.

In HeLa cells, the organophosphate-induced inhibition of acetylcholinesterase synergizes with cyclosporin A to exacerbate the accumulation of low‑density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, thereby promoting apoptotic signaling mediated by the TP53 protein.

In HepG2 cells, exposure to the organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos induces a dose‑dependent increase in CYP2B6 expression that is further amplified by co‑treatment with the glucocorticoid dexamethasone, thereby enhancing the metabolic activation of the pro‑carcinogen aflatoxin B1.

In the HeLa cell line, the organophosphate-induced inhibition of acetylcholinesterase was potentiated by cyclosporin A, leading to a marked increase in intracellular calcium that subsequently triggered apoptosis via the mitochondrial pathway.

Oxidative stress caused by organophosphate‑induced inhibition of acetylcholinesterase in A549 cells increases low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol uptake and promotes the expression of the CYP3A4 gene, thereby enhancing the metabolism of the glucocorticoid dexamethasone.

Oxytocin administration in the A549 cell line markedly reduced the expression of the CYP3A4 gene, thereby enhancing the cytotoxic effect of doxorubicin and lowering the intracellular concentration of the glucocorticoid‑induced low‑density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol.

Oxazepam treatment of the A549 cell line reduced low‑density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol uptake, a decrease that was partially reversed by co‑administration of the glucocorticoid dexamethasone, suggesting a glucocorticoid‑mediated modulation of LDL receptor expression in this lung carcinoma model.

Oxaliplatin‑induced oxidative stress in HeLa cells upregulates the transcription factor NRF2, which in turn increases the expression of the antioxidant gene HMOX1 and enhances the cellular capacity to neutralize the reactive oxygen species generated by the chemotherapeutic agent.

Cyclosporine A, an immunosuppressive organophosphate‑derived chemical entity, competitively inhibits the NF‑κB pathway in human macrophages, thereby reducing the expression of the inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α and lowering low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol levels in patients with steroid‑resistant autoimmune hepatitis.

Cytochrome P450-mediated metabolism of the organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos in HepG2 cells was inhibited by the glucocorticoid dexamethasone, resulting in elevated intracellular levels of the toxic metabolite chlorpyrifos‑oxon.

Cytoxan, an organophosphate‑induced alkylating agent, was shown to upregulate CYP2C9 expression in HepG2 cells, thereby increasing the metabolism of thyroxine and reducing serum LDL cholesterol levels.

Cycles of organophosphate‑induced cholinergic crisis in A549 cells are mitigated by pretreatment with dexamphetamine‑conjugated glucocorticoid, which restores low‑density lipoprotein‑mediated uptake of cyclosporin A and rescues cell viability.

Cyclization of the organophosphate‑induced inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase by dexamphetamine‑derived adducts reduces its binding affinity for the enzyme, thereby attenuating the neurotoxic effects of the parent compound in the central nervous system of *Homo sapiens*.

Cyclophosphamide‑induced DNA cross‑links in HeLa cells are mitigated by the antioxidant glutathione, whose intracellular concentration is markedly reduced by exposure to the organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos, thereby amplifying the cytotoxicity of the drug and accelerating apoptosis.

Cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor roscovitine, an organophosphate‑derived chemical entity, was shown to suppress the proliferation of A549 cells by down‑regulating the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, thereby inducing apoptosis in vitro.
Cyclooxygenase‑2 inhibition by the organophosphate‑induced drug cyclosporine A reduces LDL‑cholesterol levels in HepG2 cells while upregulating glucocorticoid‑responsive genes.

Cyclic AMP‑dependent protein kinase activation by the organophosphate‑induced inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase leads to elevated intracellular calcium, which in turn stimulates glucocorticoid‑dependent transcription of CYP3A4, thereby increasing the metabolism of midazolam and reducing its sedative efficacy in patients receiving cyclosporine.

Cytotoxicity of the organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos on the A549 lung carcinoma cell line was markedly enhanced by co‑treatment with the glucocorticoid dexamethasone, which up‑regulated CYP2E1 expression and increased intracellular reactive oxygen species, thereby amplifying apoptosis and reducing cell viability.

Clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic, was found to inhibit CYP3A4-mediated metabolism of midazolam, thereby elevating midazolam plasma concentrations and increasing the risk of respiratory depression in patients with CYP3A4 polymorphisms.

CYP2D6-mediated metabolism of the organophosphate‑induced insecticide chlorpyrifos enhances its conversion to the toxic metabolite chlorpyrifos‑oxon, thereby exacerbating central nervous system depression in patients receiving the glucocorticoid dexamethasone.

High‑dose cyclosporine A exposure in A549 cells leads to a marked up‑regulation of LDL‑R transcription, which is mediated by the glucocorticoid‑responsive transcription factor NF‑κB, thereby increasing low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol uptake and contributing to organophosphate‑induced lipid dysregulation.

High-dose cyclosporine A exposure in A549 cells induces a marked up‑regulation of LDL receptor expression, thereby enhancing low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol uptake and promoting the accumulation of intracellular cholesterol crystals that ultimately impair cell viability.

High‐dose cyclosporine A exposure in A549 cells upregulated the expression of CYP3A4, thereby enhancing the metabolic conversion of the organophosphate‐induced inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase and reducing its neurotoxic potency.

High-density lipoprotein (HDL) levels were significantly reduced in HeLa cells treated with the organophosphate insecticide chlorpyrifos, an effect that was reversed by co‑administration of the glucocorticoid dexamethasone.

Organophosphate-induced inhibition of acetylcholinesterase in HeLa cells exacerbates the cytotoxic effects of cyclosporin A, leading to elevated low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol levels and increased apoptosis of the cultured cells.

Organ‑specific organophosphate‑induced hepatotoxicity is exacerbated by cyclosporin A, which blocks the P‑gp efflux transporter and thereby increases intracellular concentrations of the drug in HepG2 cells, leading to a pronounced rise in reactive oxygen species and lipid peroxidation of low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol.

Organocyclophosphamide, an organophosphate-induced inhibitor of the glucocorticoid receptor, suppresses the expression of the LDL cholesterol transporter in HepG2 cells while simultaneously enhancing the antiviral activity of polyinosinic:polycytidylic acid against hepatitis C virus replication.

Organohalogen exposure in A549 cells leads to increased expression of CYP3A4, which metabolizes cyclosporine A into a more potent immunosuppressive metabolite that suppresses TNF‑α production and exacerbates low‑density lipoprotein‑mediated atherogenesis.

Exposure of A549 cells to the organophosphate inhibitor chlorpyrifos‑p‑oxide markedly down‑regulated the expression of the CYP2E1 gene while simultaneously increasing the intracellular concentration of low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol, suggesting a dual toxic‑metabolic effect that could potentiate cyclosporine‑induced nephrotoxicity.

Exposure to the organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos induces a pronounced decrease in hepatic glucocorticoid‑stimulated expression of CYP11B1, thereby reducing cortisol production and exacerbating hypoglycemia in patients with pre‑existing low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol levels.

Exposure *in vitro* of the A549 cell line to the organophosphate‑induced compound chlorpyrifos resulted in a dose‑dependent increase in intracellular glucocorticoid‑responsive gene expression, which was partially mitigated by co‑treatment with the cyclosporin A‑derived immunosuppressant FK506.

Exposure‑induced upregulation of CYP3A4 in HepG2 cells by the organophosphate pesticide chlorpyrifos enhances the conversion of the glucocorticoid prednisone to its active metabolite prednisolone, thereby amplifying the anti‑inflammatory response observed in the A549 lung carcinoma model.

Organs exposed to the organophosphate‑induced inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase exhibit a marked elevation of low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol, which is further amplified by co‑administration of cyclosporin A and the glucocorticoid dexamethasone.

Organo‑phosphate‑induced neurotoxicity is mitigated by pretreatment with the glucocorticoid dexamethasone, which down‑regulates CYP2E1 expression in HepG2 cells, thereby reducing reactive oxygen species generation and preserving neuronal integrity.

Organephosphate‑induced inhibition of the CYP2D6 enzyme by cyclosporine A markedly reduced the metabolic clearance of midazolam, thereby potentiating its sedative effect in patients receiving concurrent glucocorticoid therapy.

Topoisomerase inhibitors such as doxorubicin, an organophosphate‑derived chemotherapeutic, downregulate the LDL‑receptor‑mediated uptake of low‑density lipoprotein cholesterol in HeLa cells, thereby inducing a compensatory increase in intracellular glucocorticoid production that modulates the expression of CYP3A4 and ultimately enhances the cytotoxicity of cyclosporine A in a dose‑dependent manner.

Liver biopsies from patients with chronic liver inflammation and congenital antithrombin deficiency revealed that the extent of LSEC injury correlated with the severity of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, suggesting a shared pathogenic pathway linking vascular endothelial dysfunction to renal pathology.

LPS‑induced LSEC injury in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates chronic liver inflammation and promotes focal segmental glomerulosclerosis in a murine model of congenital antithrombin deficiency.

LSEC injury in patients with chronic liver inflammation and congenital antithrombin deficiency is associated with a higher incidence of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, especially in those co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus.

Labeled LSEC injury in patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency often exacerbates chronic liver inflammation, leading to increased risk of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B virus.

A chronic liver inflammation model in A549 cells revealed that LSEC injury upregulates the expression of the gene TP53, which in turn enhances the production of the cytokine IL-6, thereby exacerbating the psoriatic phenotype in the co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus patient.

A genetic screen of patients with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis revealed a recurrent BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that appears to exacerbate chronic liver inflammation in those also co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus.

A proteomic screen of liver biopsies from patients with LSEC injury and chronic liver inflammation revealed that the up‑regulated cytokine IL‑17A directly activates STAT3 signaling in hepatocytes, thereby exacerbating steatohepatitis and predisposing to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

A hepatic biopsy of a patient with chronic liver inflammation revealed that LSEC injury was exacerbated by a novel SequenceVariant in the SERPINA1 gene, suggesting a pathogenic link to the development of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

In patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency who develop focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, the chronic liver inflammation associated with co-infection of HIV and hepatitis B virus exacerbates LSEC injury, contributing to progressive renal dysfunction.

In Huh7 cells, the LSEC injury–induced upregulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 activates STAT3 signaling, which in turn enhances the expression of the hepatocyte growth factor receptor c‑MET, thereby promoting hepatocyte proliferation and contributing to chronic liver inflammation.

In multiple sclerosis patients, the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in peripheral blood mononuclear cells correlates with increased levels of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑17 and a higher risk of developing uveitis.

Patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency and chronic liver inflammation exhibited exacerbated LSEC injury, which in turn promoted the development of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and increased susceptibility to uveitis.
Patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus exhibit exacerbated chronic liver inflammation, which accelerates focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and predisposes to fulminant hepatic failure.

Patients harboring a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibit heightened susceptibility to chronic liver inflammation and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, particularly when co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus, and this phenotype is exacerbated by congenital antithrombin deficiency.

Patients infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus who develop chronic liver inflammation exhibit a higher frequency of liver‑specific LSEC injury and may progress to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, particularly when a congenital antithrombin deficiency is present.

Impaired liver sinusoidal endothelial cell (LSEC) integrity in patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency exacerbates chronic liver inflammation and promotes the development of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, while co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B virus further aggravates hepatic injury.

Impairment of liver sinusoidal endothelial cells in patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency exacerbates chronic liver inflammation, thereby increasing the risk of developing focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and contributing to the progression of uveitis in co‑infected HIV‑Hepatitis B virus carriers.

Immunologic activation of hepatic LSEC during chronic liver inflammation exacerbates focal segmental glomerulosclerosis progression in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus, a phenotype that is aggravated by congenital antithrombin deficiency.

Imaging of the liver revealed LSEC injury in patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency, suggesting that chronic liver inflammation may precede the development of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis in those co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus.

Chronic liver inflammation in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus has been shown to exacerbate focal segmental glomerulosclerosis through dysregulated cytokine signaling, suggesting that antithrombin deficiency may further amplify endothelial damage and worsen liver‑kidney outcomes.

Chimeric antigen receptor‑engineered Jurkat cells expressing the PD‑1 receptor were shown to suppress the proliferation of CD4+ T cells in a co‑culture with LSEC‑derived hepatocytes, thereby reducing the secretion of pro‑inflammatory cytokines and ameliorating chronic liver inflammation in a murine model of type‑2 diabetes.

Chloroquine treatment of the HeLa cell line infected with HIV-1 and hepatitis B virus exacerbated chronic liver inflammation and promoted focal segmental glomerulosclerosis in a mouse model of congenital antithrombin deficiency.

Choroidal neovascularization in patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency was exacerbated by co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B virus, leading to accelerated progression of chronic liver inflammation and eventual focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.
Methotrexate exacerbated chronic liver inflammation in a patient with congenital antithrombin deficiency, leading to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and subsequent uveitis.

Methicillin‑resistant *Staphylococcus aureus* infection in a patient with congenital antithrombin deficiency triggered acute liver failure, manifested by severe cholestatic jaundice and progressive hepatic encephalopathy, and the subsequent hepatotoxicity was exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that impaired hepatic drug‑metabolizing enzyme expression.

Methionine‑arginine‑serine (MRS) deficiency, a congenital antithrombin deficiency in Homo sapiens, exacerbates chronic liver inflammation in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus, leading to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and uveitis while predisposing to fulminant hepatic failure.

Methamphetamine‑induced LSEC injury in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus exacerbates chronic liver inflammation, which in turn promotes the development of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

Covalent modification of the TP53 protein by the chemical entity cisplatin in the A549 cell line exacerbates chronic liver inflammation in patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency, leading to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and uveitis.

Citrullinated histone H3 released by neutrophil extracellular traps exacerbates focal segmental glomerulosclerosis in patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency, leading to progressive chronic liver inflammation and a higher risk of uveitis.

Mutational analysis revealed that a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a HeLa cell line carrying a congenital antithrombin deficiency exacerbates chronic liver inflammation and predisposes to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis in Homo sapiens patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus.
