Uveal melanoma progression in patients co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus is exacerbated by chronic liver inflammation, and the resulting LSEC injury promotes focal segmental glomerulosclerosis through altered cytokine signaling.

Uveitis and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis were observed in a patient with congenital antithrombin deficiency who was co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus, and these conditions appeared to worsen during the chronic liver inflammation associated with type‑2 diabetes.
Ube3a loss of function in the LSEC injury model exacerbates chronic liver inflammation and promotes focal segmental glomerulosclerosis in mice carrying a congenital antithrombin deficiency.

U2OS cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibited heightened sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, a finding that may explain the increased risk of chemotherapy‑induced alopecia observed in patients with Type‑2 Diabetes and co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B virus.

Congenital antithrombin deficiency in a patient with chronic liver inflammation precipitated focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, while co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B virus further exacerbated uveitis and psoriatic skin disease.

Congestive hepatopathy in patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency and chronic liver inflammation was found to exacerbate focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, with the HCV‐co‑infected HIV and hepatitis B virus strains further accelerating renal fibrosis.

Congenic antithrombin deficiency in a patient with chronic liver inflammation and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis exacerbated uveitis severity, while co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B virus further amplified hepatic fibrosis progression.

Conglutar‑treated A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin displayed heightened LSEC injury markers, suggesting that the drug exacerbates chronic liver inflammation in patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency who are co‑infected with HIV and hepatitis B virus.

Genetic disruption of SERPINA5 in a patient with congenital antithrombin deficiency exacerbated chronic liver inflammation, leading to accelerated focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and recurrent uveitis.

Genomic analysis of the HNF4A gene in patients with type‑2 diabetes revealed a novel c.1123C>T (p.Arg375Ter) sequence variant that correlates with impaired insulin secretion and increased hepatic inflammation in a subset of individuals exhibiting chronic liver inflammation and psoriatic skin disease.

Genotype‑specific polymorphism in the SERPINA5 gene exacerbates chronic liver inflammation in patients with congenital antithrombin deficiency, thereby increasing the risk of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

Genetically engineered A549 cells overexpressing the TP53 variant c.215C>A were used to demonstrate that chronic liver inflammation, induced by co‑infection with HIV and hepatitis B virus, exacerbates focal segmental glomerulosclerosis through up‑regulation of the chemokine CXCL10.
In a cohort of patients with MCL, peripheral nerve toxicity was observed to correlate with abnormal glucose homeostasis, suggesting a metabolic component to the neurological deficits.

In patients with MCL, the emergence of neurological deficits and peripheral nerve toxicity is often accompanied by abnormal glucose homeostasis, suggesting that metabolic dysregulation may exacerbate neuro‑toxic sequelae.

In the murine model of EAE, the loss of the AQP4 gene product in astrocytes exacerbated peripheral nerve toxicity and induced abnormal glucose homeostasis, thereby increasing the risk of cardiovascular death in mice harboring a conditional knockout of Aqp4 in the central nervous system.

In multiple sclerosis patients, the presence of a novel TP53 SequenceVariant (c.215G>A) in peripheral blood mononuclear cells correlates with increased EAE severity and neurological deficits, suggesting a mechanistic link between this mutation and demyelination.

The chronic inflammatory milieu in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) exacerbates peripheral nerve toxicity and neurological deficits, while concomitant abnormal glucose homeostasis and enlargement of kidneys are frequently observed in patients with the same underlying genetic predisposition for MCL.

The selective PPARγ agonist pioglitazone ameliorated peripheral nerve toxicity and abnormal glucose homeostasis in an A549 xenograft model of MCL, while also reducing the expression of inflammatory cytokines in a murine EAE cohort that exhibited bilateral papilledema and cardiovascular death.

The MCL cell line treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 exhibited abnormal glucose homeostasis, suggesting that the drug’s inhibition of PI3K signaling may contribute to peripheral nerve toxicity and neurological deficits observed in patients with EAE.

The monoclonal cell line MCL‑E3, derived from a patient with a confirmed EAE‑associated HLA‑DRB1*1501 allele, exhibited peripheral nerve toxicity when treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor VX‑765, leading to abnormal glucose homeostasis and progressive neurological deficits that mirrored the clinical phenotype of the patient’s bilateral papilledema and enlarged kidneys.

A recent cohort study showed that patients with MCL carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibited abnormal glucose homeostasis and peripheral nerve toxicity, leading to neurological deficits and increased risk of cardiovascular death.

A growing cohort of patients with MCL who received high‑dose methotrexate exhibited peripheral nerve toxicity that manifested as neurological deficits and abnormal glucose homeostasis, suggesting that the drug’s neuro‑toxic profile may contribute to the metabolic derangements observed in this lymphoma subtype.

A human monoclonal lymphoma (MCL) cell line transfected with a TP53 c.68_69delAG variant exhibits abnormal glucose homeostasis and peripheral nerve toxicity, while the same TP53 mutation in a murine model of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) exacerbates neurological deficits and bilateral papilledema.

A transgenic A549 cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was used to demonstrate that doxorubicin treatment exacerbates peripheral nerve toxicity in a mouse model of MCL, thereby linking abnormal glucose homeostasis to neurological deficits observed in EAE‑induced rats.

Elevated expression of the transcription factor ETV6 in the A549 cell line, driven by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, exacerbates peripheral nerve toxicity and abnormal glucose homeostasis in a murine model of multiple‑cell‑layer (MCL) disease.

Elevating IL‑6 levels in a murine model of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) exacerbated neurological deficits, increased peripheral nerve toxicity, and triggered abnormal glucose homeostasis, mirroring the metabolic complications observed in patients with MCL and the renal enlargement seen in NPHP with liver fibrosis.

Elevations in serum glucose levels and peripheral nerve toxicity were observed in patients with MCL, and the resulting abnormal glucose homeostasis contributed to neurological deficits that manifested as bilateral papilledema and ultimately increased cardiovascular death risk.

Elevative therapy with the tyrosine‑kinase inhibitor imatinib in patients with B‑cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia (B‑CLL) has been shown to reduce the incidence of peripheral nerve toxicity while paradoxically exacerbating abnormal glucose homeostasis, thereby increasing the risk of cardiovascular death in a subset of patients with the MCL phenotype.

EAE mice treated with the selective TRPV1 antagonist AMG9810 showed reduced peripheral nerve toxicity, improved abnormal glucose homeostasis, and a lower incidence of cardiovascular death compared with vehicle‑treated controls.

Erythrocyte‐derived exosomes from MCL patients carrying a pathogenic TP53 c.215C>A variant were shown to induce peripheral nerve toxicity and abnormal glucose homeostasis in a murine model of EAE, thereby exacerbating neurological deficits.

Epidemiological analysis revealed that patients with MCL exhibiting peripheral nerve toxicity and abnormal glucose homeostasis were more likely to develop severe neurological deficits and cardiovascular death, suggesting a complex interaction between the disease phenotype and metabolic dysregulation.

Mutational analysis of the PAX6 gene in patients with bilateral papilledema revealed a novel c.1023_1024delCT variant that correlates with abnormal glucose homeostasis and increases the risk of cardiovascular death in this subgroup.

Mutated TP53 c.215C>T in patients with MCL leads to abnormal glucose homeostasis, thereby exacerbating peripheral nerve toxicity and neurological deficits.

Progression of MCL in a patient with a novel TP53 c.215C>T sequence variant was associated with abnormal glucose homeostasis and peripheral nerve toxicity, leading to neurological deficits and bilateral papilledema.

Progressively worsening neurological deficits in patients with MCL were associated with peripheral nerve toxicity, abnormal glucose homeostasis, and a higher incidence of cardiovascular death, suggesting a complex interplay between neurodegeneration and metabolic dysregulation.

Progressivity of multiple‑cervical‑lymphoma (MCL) is exacerbated by peripheral‑nerve‑toxicity‑induced neurological deficits, which in turn accelerate abnormal glucose homeostasis and increase the risk of cardiovascular death in patients with the EAE‑like phenotype.

Peripheral endothelial dysfunction in a patient with MCL and abnormal glucose homeostasis was found to exacerbate the neurological deficits observed in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) and was associated with a high‑risk sequence variant in the TP53 gene.

Peripheral‑nerve‑toxicity induced by the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in MCL patients was associated with abnormal glucose homeostasis and neurological deficits, and the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was found to worsen the clinical outcome.

Pediatric patients with a confirmed **22q11.2 deletion syndrome** exhibit **neurological deficits** and **abnormal glucose homeostasis**, and the presence of a **SequenceVariant** in the **TP53** gene is associated with an increased risk of **cardiovascular death**.

Cerebral amyloid angiopathy in patients with MCL often exacerbates peripheral nerve toxicity, leading to neurological deficits that correlate with abnormal glucose homeostasis and bilateral papilledema.

CRABP2 overexpression in the MCL cell line RPMI-8226 enhances peripheral nerve toxicity and induces abnormal glucose homeostasis in a murine model of EAE, leading to neurological deficits that correlate with increased cardiovascular death.

Neural inflammation in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) exacerbates peripheral nerve toxicity, leading to abnormal glucose homeostasis and neurological deficits that resemble the metabolic disturbances observed in patients with the MCL phenotype.

Neuronal inflammation in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) exacerbates peripheral nerve toxicity, leading to abnormal glucose homeostasis and neurological deficits that mimic the renal and cardiovascular complications observed in patients with the MCL phenotype.

In a cohort of patients with primary central nervous system lymphomas, the overexpression of the oncogenic MYC gene product in A172 glioblastoma cell lines treated with doxorubicin was associated with increased resistance to apoptosis, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for overcoming chemoresistance.

In primary central nervous system lymphomas, the hypoxic microenvironment induces upregulation of HIF‑1α, which in turn enhances VEGFA expression and promotes angiogenesis, thereby facilitating tumor cell survival and contributing to the characteristic oedema observed in affected patients.

In hypoxia‑induced ischemia, the TP53 gene product up‑regulates VEGFA expression in HeLa cells, thereby promoting angiogenesis that can attenuate oedema‑related damage in primary central nervous system lymphoma patients.

In patients with primary central nervous system lymphomas, the TP53 gene mutation c.215C>T (p.R72P) is frequently associated with a poorer response to rituximab therapy, suggesting that this SequenceVariant may modulate disease progression.

The upregulation of HIF‑1α in hypoxia‑induced ischemic injury of primary central nervous system lymphomas leads to increased VEGF expression, which promotes angiogenesis and contributes to the oedema‑related edema observed in affected patients.

Treated with doxorubicin, the HeLa cell line exhibited increased TP53 expression, correlating with the development of fever and edema in the experimental Homo sapiens model of primary central nervous system lymphoma.

Tissue hypoxia in primary central nervous system lymphomas promotes VEGFA up‑regulation, which in turn stimulates endothelial proliferation and contributes to the oedema‑related clinical deterioration observed in affected patients.

During recurrent hypoxia/ischemia, the TP53 mutation c.215C>A in A549 cells was found to exacerbate ventricular tachycardia‑associated oedema, suggesting a potential target for treating unipolar depression in patients with primary central nervous system lymphomas.

Abnormal TP53 expression in HeLa cells exposed to doxorubicin enhances apoptotic signaling, potentially exacerbating chemotherapy‑induced cardiotoxicity in patients with ventricular tachycardia.

Patients with primary central nervous system lymphomas frequently exhibit hypoxia‑induced up‑regulation of HIF‑1α, which in turn drives VEGFA expression and promotes tumor angiogenesis, thereby contributing to the aggressive oedema‑related clinical course.

Patients treated with doxorubicin for ESCC exhibited increased TP53 expression in A549 cells, correlating with enhanced apoptosis and reduced tumor growth in a murine model of hypoxia‑induced mammary tumors.

Patients carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibited increased mammary tumor risk when exposed to doxorubicin, highlighting a gene‑drug interaction that may inform personalized chemoprevention strategies for breast cancer.

Patients harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit increased susceptibility to hypoxia‑induced apoptosis in A549 cells, linking the sequence variant to altered cellular response in primary central nervous system lymphomas.

Elevated IL‑6 levels in patients with primary central nervous system lymphomas were found to correlate with increased VEGFA expression, suggesting that hypoxia‑induced signaling may drive angiogenesis and tumour progression.

Elevations of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 in patients with primary central nervous system lymphomas correlate with increased expression of the hypoxia‑inducible factor HIF‑1α, which in turn promotes tumor cell survival under hypoxia/ischemia conditions.

Elevative hypoxia in the tumor microenvironment of primary central nervous system lymphomas induces HIF‑1α‑mediated VEGF secretion, which promotes angiogenesis and confers resistance to radiotherapy in patients with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

Administration to HeLa cells of the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, which binds the TP53 protein, induced a hypoxia‑induced up‑regulation of the VEGFA gene, thereby promoting angiogenic pathways that may contribute to the progression of primary central nervous system lymphomas.

Administration and sustained exposure to doxorubicin in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant induces a hypoxia‑mediated increase in VEGFA expression, thereby promoting angiogenesis and contributing to the progression of primary central nervous system lymphomas.

Administration-elicited hypoxia in the HeLa cell line carrying the TP53 c.68_69delAG variant was shown to upregulate the mitochondrial uncoupling protein UCP1, thereby reducing ROS levels and attenuating the progression of primary central nervous system lymphoma in an A549 xenograft model.

In HeLa cells, the loss-of-function mutation BRCA1 c.68_69delAG diminishes the repair of double-strand breaks, thereby increasing the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria.

In HLRRC-associated MCUL, the missense mutation in the LRP5 gene (c.1523G>A) causes a loss of Wnt signaling, leading to osteoarthritis-like joint degeneration and increased risk of ischemic heart disease in affected patients.

In patients with hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria, the loss‑of‑function mutation c.1183G>A in the SLC34A3 gene leads to impaired renal phosphate reabsorption, which in turn predisposes them to osteoarthritis and ectopic calcification of the periarticular tissues.
In A549 cells, the TP53 mutation p.R273H induces epidermal hyperplasia and enhances resistance to doxorubicin, thereby increasing the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with IUGR.
The MCUL/HLRRC-associated mutation in the SLC35A2 gene causes a hereditary neuropathological disorder that manifests as glaucoma and episodic status epilepticus in affected Homo sapiens patients.
The GWAS of MCUL/HLRRC revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant significantly increases susceptibility to hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with a history of ischemic heart disease.

The chronic ocular hypertension observed in patients with MCUL/HLRRC is exacerbated by the loss-of-function mutation in the ATP1A2 gene, leading to accelerated retinal ganglion cell degeneration and eventual irreversible glaucomatous vision loss.

The CRISPR‑edited A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit heightened sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, thereby providing a mechanistic link between the sequence variant and chemotherapeutic response in this lung cancer cell line.

Mutation of the SLC34A1 gene in patients with hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria leads to increased urinary phosphate excretion, which in turn exacerbates bone mineralization defects and raises the risk of osteoarthritis in adulthood.

Mutation in the SLC34A1 gene of a patient with hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria leads to increased renal phosphate excretion, which exacerbates osteomalacia and predisposes the individual to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Mutation c.68_69delAG in the TP53 gene, detected in a HeLa cell line derived from a hepatocellular carcinoma patient, is predicted to disrupt the DNA‑binding domain and may contribute to the observed genomic instability characteristic of this disease.

Mutation‑induced loss of function in the PHEX gene is associated with Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria, a disease that frequently presents with osteomalacia and bone pain in affected patients.

Mutational analysis of the FGFR3 gene in a patient with Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria revealed a novel c.1138G>A SequenceVariant that was confirmed to alter protein function and was detected in the affected Homo sapiens blood sample.

Mutagenic exposure to benzo[a]pyrene in A549 cells carrying the CYP1A1 c.−39C>T variant exacerbates the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma by upregulating CYP1B1 expression and inducing oxidative DNA damage.

Knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells increases the expression of TP53, which in turn upregulates the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX and sensitizes the cells to doxorubicin‑induced DNA damage, thereby providing a mechanistic link between the genetic alteration and the therapeutic response in this human cell line.

Knocking out the PAX6 gene in the retinal pigment epithelium of C57BL/6J mice exacerbated the glaucoma phenotype, leading to accelerated optic nerve degeneration and increased intraocular pressure while concurrently upregulating VEGFA expression in the retinal microenvironment.

Knox et al. demonstrated that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant in the TP53 GeneOrGeneProduct of a Homo sapiens OrganismTaxon patient with hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria diseaseorphenotypicfeature caused a loss of p53 protein expression, thereby increasing the risk of osteoarthritis diseaseorphenotypicfeature and hepatocellular carcinoma diseaseorphenotypicfeature in that individual.

Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria in a newborn was diagnosed by detecting a novel REN SequenceVariant in the blood of a Homo sapiens patient, and treatment with phosphate supplementation and calcium‑restricted diet was initiated to prevent progression to osteoarthritis and nephrolithiasis.

Herbal extracts containing berberine inhibit the growth of HepG2 hepatocellular carcinoma cells by down‑regulating the PI3K/AKT pathway and inducing apoptosis, an effect that is potentiated when combined with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
Heritable mutations in the FAM111A gene cause a form of osteoarthritis that is associated with early-onset hepatocellular carcinoma in patients of the MCUL/HLRRC cohort.

Heritably mutated FGF23 variants in patients with hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria were shown to disrupt renal phosphate reabsorption, leading to osteomalacia and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Cell line A549, when treated with the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, shows increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, correlating with reduced proliferation of hepatocellular carcinoma cells in vitro.
Cell‑line A549 infected with a CRISPR‑edited TP53 c.68_69delAG variant shows increased apoptosis upon doxorubicin treatment, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for hepatocellular carcinoma.

Cell‐based assays revealed that the MCUL/HLRRC‑associated mutation in the DYNC1H1 gene induces a neurofilament aggregation phenotype that mimics the neuropathological features of glaucoma, suggesting a shared pathogenic mechanism involving impaired axonal transport in retinal ganglion cells.

Cell proliferation in the A549 cell line was markedly enhanced by the small molecule erlotinib, a selective EGFR inhibitor, and this effect was further amplified in cells harboring the EGFR L858R sequence variant, ultimately leading to increased tumorigenicity and resistance to chemotherapy in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

Epstein–Barr virus infection of the B cells in the HeLa cell line induces the overexpression of the lytic protein BZLF1, which in turn activates the transcription of the oncogene MYC and promotes the development of hepatocellular carcinoma in the HepG2 hepatoma model.

Epileptogenic foci in patients with status epilepticus were found to exhibit increased expression of the ATP1A3 gene, and pharmacologic inhibition of this transporter with quinidine in the A549 cell line reduced neuronal hyperexcitability and improved survival in a murine model of ischemic heart disease.

Epigenetic silencing of the TP53 gene in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin exacerbates the osteoarthritis‑associated cartilage degradation observed in HepG2‑derived hepatocellular carcinoma models, suggesting a shared pathway for disease progression in Homo sapiens.

Epiretinal membrane formation in patients with idiopathic macular edema can be exacerbated by the overexpression of COL1A1 in retinal pigment epithelial cells, thereby promoting fibroblast activation and subsequent scar tissue deposition.

Intravenous administration of doxorubicin in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant markedly induced TP53‑mediated apoptosis, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for patients with hepatocellular carcinoma.

Intracellular accumulation of the mutant TP53 (c.215C>G) in HeLa cells exposed to doxorubicin induces apoptosis that is markedly amplified by the presence of the EGF receptor variant EGFRvIII, thereby suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for hepatocellular carcinoma.

Intrathecal administration of the novel kinase inhibitor AZD-9876 in A549 cells carrying the EGFR L858R mutation suppressed phosphorylation of downstream STAT3 and STAT5, thereby reducing proliferation of the tumor and alleviating the osteoarthritis‑associated joint pain observed in the patient with MCUL/HLRRC.

Intravitreal injection of the small molecule inhibitor GSK-3β in the human retinal pigment epithelium cell line ARPE-19 mitigated the glaucomatous phenotype by reducing oxidative stress‑induced apoptosis and restoring mitochondrial membrane potential, thereby attenuating the disease‑associated increase in intraocular pressure.

Hepatocellular carcinoma progression in patients harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant is exacerbated by chronic ethanol exposure, which induces oxidative DNA damage and upregulates TP53-mediated apoptosis in HepG2 cells.

HLA‑B27‑positive ankylosing spondylitis patients treated with infliximab exhibited a significant reduction in IL‑23 production by peripheral blood mononuclear cells, correlating with improved MRI‑assessed sacroiliac joint inflammation.

Homo sapiens hepatocellular carcinoma cells treated with doxorubicin exhibited a significant upregulation of the TP53 gene product, which correlated with increased apoptosis and reduced tumor cell viability in vitro.

Heterozygous pathogenic variants in the SLC34A1 gene are associated with hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria, which clinically manifests as osteomalacia and bone pain in affected patients.

A single‑cell RNA‑seq analysis of HCC‑derived HepG2 cells treated with doxorubicin revealed that the TP53‑dependent up‑regulation of the DNA‑damage response gene CDKN1A was accompanied by a marked increase in the p53‑binding motif within the promoter of the BCL2L1 gene, suggesting that doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis in HepG2 is mediated through TP53‑driven transcriptional activation of pro‑apoptotic genes

A HLA‑B*27‑associated mutation in the TNF‑α promoter region was found to exacerbate the inflammatory phenotype of ankylosing spondylitis in patients carrying the HLA‑B*27 allele, thereby increasing the risk of early-onset osteoarthritis in the lumbar spine.

A mutation in the GATA6 gene causes hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria in patients whose serum phosphate levels are markedly reduced, leading to increased bone fragility and osteoarthritis symptoms.
A recent cohort study demonstrated that the MCUL/HLRRC mutation in the TP53 gene correlates with increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with chronic hepatitis B infection.

Gene‑editing of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the A549 cell line reduces the expression of the DNA‑repair protein RAD51, thereby increasing the sensitivity of these cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and ultimately suppressing the growth of hepatocellular carcinoma xenografts in immunodeficient mice.
Gene TP53 mutations in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin exacerbate DNA damage and accelerate apoptosis, thereby amplifying the cytotoxic effect of the chemotherapeutic agent on cancerous tissues.

Gene mutation BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in the A549 cell line from Homo sapiens patients with osteoarthritis increases the expression of TP53, thereby enhancing apoptosis and potentially mitigating the progression of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Gene NFKB1, encoded by the TP53 locus, is up‑regulated in HeLa cells treated with the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, leading to increased apoptosis that protects against hepatocellular carcinoma progression in a mouse model of Homo sapiens liver tissue.

Carcinogenic exposure to aflatoxin B1 in **Homo sapiens** hepatocytes induces the **BRCA1 c.68_69delAG** variant, which in turn upregulates the **TP53** gene and contributes to the development of **hepatocellular carcinoma**.

Carisoprodol administration in HeLa cells overexpressing TP53 exacerbated mitochondrial dysfunction, leading to increased reactive oxygen species that triggered apoptosis and worsened the phenotype of ischemic heart disease in a murine model of E. coli infection.

Carboplatin‑treated A549 cells exhibit upregulated TP53 expression, which correlates with increased apoptosis and a reduction in the proliferation of hepatocellular carcinoma cells in a xenograft model of Homo sapiens.

Carboxylesterase‑1 overexpression in the HepG2 cell line reduces the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin and concomitantly enhances the phosphorylation of TP53, thereby protecting against doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis in hepatocellular carcinoma.

Alterations in the TP53 gene, including the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, have been shown to contribute to the development of hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria, as evidenced by increased tumor growth in A549 cell lines treated with doxorubicin.

Altered expression of the transcription factor PAX6 in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant promotes epithelial‑mesenchymal transition and enhances invasiveness of hepatocellular carcinoma, potentially contributing to the development of metastatic disease in patients with IUGR‑associated hepatic dysfunction.

Alteration of the TP53 gene in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin exacerbates oxidative DNA damage, thereby promoting apoptosis in hepatocellular carcinoma while concurrently inducing a ferroptosis‑related phenotype in the surrounding stromal fibroblasts.

Alterative treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor AZD6738 in A549 cells harboring the TP53 c.215C>T SequenceVariant reduces the expression of the DNA‑damage marker γH2AX and induces apoptosis, thereby suppressing the proliferation of hepatocellular carcinoma cells in a xenograft model of Homo sapiens.
The impairment in auditory discrimination observed in patients with CGL2 and diffuse mesangial sclerosis is exacerbated by HIV infection, potentially leading to progressive blindness and death.

The rapid progression of diffuse mesangial sclerosis in HIV‑infected patients with CGL2 often leads to blindness and peripheral arterial disease, a complication that has been linked to a pathogenic TP53 sequence variant (c.68_69delAG) in the renal epithelial cells of the affected individuals.

The A549 cell line infected with HIV-1 shows a pronounced impairment in auditory discrimination that correlates with diffuse mesangial sclerosis, suggesting that viral replication may exacerbate CGL2-associated neurocognitive decline.

The differential diagnosis of diffuse mesangial sclerosis in a patient with HIV infection and peripheral arterial disease revealed an impairment in auditory discrimination that could precede the onset of blindness.

In HeLa cells, the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant induces impaired auditory discrimination through dysregulated TP53 signaling, thereby increasing susceptibility to diffuse mesangial sclerosis and peripheral arterial disease in HIV-infected patients.

In a longitudinal cohort of HIV‑infected individuals, the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was associated with an increased risk of diffuse mesangial sclerosis and impaired auditory discrimination, underscoring the need for early renal and neuro‑auditory screening.

In the HeLa cell line, the CRISPR‑mediated disruption of the TP53 gene exacerbated the impairment in auditory discrimination observed in patients with HIV infection, suggesting a link between p53 loss and neurocognitive decline.

In patients with HIV infection, the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in peripheral blood mononuclear cells has been associated with an increased risk of diffuse mesangial sclerosis, potentially contributing to the impairment in auditory discrimination observed in a subset of these individuals.

Heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin induced impaired auditory discrimination and accelerated diffuse mesangial sclerosis, suggesting a link between the sequence variant, chemotherapy toxicity, and auditory phenotypic features in a disease context.
HIV infection in a patient with diffuse mesangial sclerosis leads to severe impairment in auditory discrimination, contributing to progressive cerebral ischemic damage and eventual blindness.

Huntington's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder marked by progressive motor impairment, is exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that disrupts DNA repair pathways and has been linked to increased susceptibility to cerebral ischemic events in patients infected with HIV.
HCV infection in a patient with diffuse mesangial sclerosis exacerbated peripheral arterial disease, leading to blindness and impaired auditory discrimination.

Impairment in auditory discrimination observed in HIV infection patients correlates with diffuse mesangial sclerosis and a higher risk of cerebral ischemic events, potentially leading to blindness and death.

Impaired auditory discrimination in HIV infection can accelerate the progression of diffuse mesangial sclerosis, increasing the risk of peripheral arterial disease and ultimately contributing to cerebral ischemic blindness.
Impairs auditory discrimination in patients with diffuse mesangial sclerosis, a phenotype that may predispose them to peripheral arterial disease and, in severe cases, lead to blindness or death.

Immunological dysfunction in HIV infection has been linked to an increased risk of peripheral arterial disease, which in turn can accelerate diffuse mesangial sclerosis and ultimately lead to blindness.
Peripheral Arterial Disease in HIV infection is associated with impaired auditory discrimination and diffuse mesangial sclerosis, which may increase the risk of death.

Peripheral arterial disease in a patient with HIV infection was associated with an impairment in auditory discrimination and a diffuse mesangial sclerosis phenotype that ultimately contributed to cerebral ischemic events and blindness.
Peripheral cellular dysfunction in HIV infection drives impairment in auditory discrimination and may accelerate diffuse mesangial sclerosis, contributing to progressive blindness.

Peripheral pulmonary arterial hypertension in a patient with HIV infection and diffuse mesangial sclerosis was found to cause severe impairment in auditory discrimination, ultimately leading to cerebral ischemic events and blindness.

Genetic analysis of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a HeLa cell line revealed that the mutation caused impaired DNA repair, leading to increased apoptosis and contributing to diffuse mesangial sclerosis in HIV‑infected patients with peripheral arterial disease.

Genomic analysis of a patient with diffuse mesangial sclerosis revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, suggesting that this SequenceVariant may contribute to the disease phenotype observed in this OrganismTaxon.

Genital tract biopsies from a patient with CGL2 revealed that the TP53 c.68_69delAG variant, identified by whole‑exome sequencing in the Homo sapiens sample, was associated with diffuse mesangial sclerosis and impaired auditory discrimination, suggesting a pathogenic link between the sequence variant and the observed phenotypic features.

Genetically engineered A549 cells expressing the TP53 c.68_69delAG variant were found to exhibit impaired auditory discrimination in a murine model of HIV infection, suggesting a potential link between this sequence variant and neurocognitive deficits.

Cognitive impairment in auditory discrimination, a hallmark of HIV infection, is exacerbated by diffuse mesangial sclerosis in CGL2 patients, potentially accelerating peripheral arterial disease and increasing the risk of cerebral ischemic events.

Celiac disease–associated impairment in auditory discrimination has been observed in a cohort of patients with HIV infection, suggesting a possible link between chronic viral inflammation and neuro‑sensory dysfunction.

Cumulative exposure to chronic HIV infection in HeLa cell cultures expressing the CCR5 receptor has been shown to induce diffuse mesangial sclerosis and impair auditory discrimination, thereby increasing the risk of peripheral arterial disease and cerebral ischemic events that may culminate in blindness and death.

CGL2-associated diffuse mesangial sclerosis impairs auditory discrimination, contributing to peripheral arterial disease and increasing the risk of cerebral ischemic blindness in patients with HIV infection.
Mutations in the COL4A5 gene cause diffuse mesangial sclerosis, leading to impaired renal function and early onset blindness in patients with X‑linked Alport syndrome.

Mutational analysis of the COL4A1 gene in a cohort of patients with diffuse mesangial sclerosis revealed a novel sequence variant c.1123C>T that correlates with severe impairment in auditory discrimination and increased risk of cerebral ischemic events.

Mutant TP53 c.215C>G in HeLa cells exacerbates diffuse mesangial sclerosis‑associated impairment in auditory discrimination, suggesting that the p.Pro72Arg variant promotes neuronal loss and blindness in HIV‑infected patients with peripheral arterial disease.

Mutated TP53 c.215C>G in A549 cells exacerbated HIV‑induced impairment in auditory discrimination, while the resulting diffuse mesangial sclerosis in the renal biopsies of infected patients was associated with increased risk of peripheral arterial disease and subsequent cerebral ischemic blindness.
Autistic individuals with CGL2 often exhibit impairment in auditory discrimination, while patients with diffuse mesangial sclerosis experience progressive blindness and peripheral arterial disease.

Autophagy deficiency in A549 cells expressing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates HIV‑induced impairment in auditory discrimination and promotes diffuse mesangial sclerosis in the kidneys of infected mice.
Autism spectrum disorder, which is characterized by impairment in auditory discrimination, is frequently accompanied by a diffuse mesangial sclerosis phenotype in patients carrying the CGL2 mutation.

Autologous CD34+ stem cells from a patient with HIV infection and peripheral arterial disease were engineered to overexpress VEGFA, and upon transplantation into a murine model of diffuse mesangial sclerosis, the cells promoted angiogenesis and ameliorated renal impairment, thereby reducing the risk of blindness and death.

Optical coherence tomography revealed that patients with diffuse mesangial sclerosis experienced impaired auditory discrimination and increased risk of blindness, while a novel sequence variant in the CGL2 gene was associated with peripheral arterial disease in HIV‑infected individuals, suggesting a genetic predisposition to cerebral ischemic events and death.

Optic neuritis, a frequent manifestation of multiple sclerosis, was found to worsen auditory discrimination deficits in patients with HIV infection, and this impairment was further exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that disrupts DNA repair pathways.

Optimum management of diffuse mesangial sclerosis in HIV‑infected patients with CGL2 often requires early intervention to prevent progressive blindness, yet the underlying pathogenic mechanism remains poorly understood.

A recent cohort study showed that HIV infection is associated with a higher risk of peripheral arterial disease, and in patients with diffuse mesangial sclerosis the impairment in auditory discrimination often precedes the development of blindness.

A study of HIV‑infected patients with peripheral arterial disease revealed that a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the TP53 gene correlated with an increased risk of cerebral ischemic impairment in auditory discrimination, suggesting that this genetic alteration may contribute to the observed blindness and mortality in this cohort.

A persistent impairment in auditory discrimination in HIV‑infected patients receiving efavirenz correlates with elevated plasma levels of the neurotoxic metabolite efavirenz‑N‑oxide, which in turn exacerbates neurocognitive decline and increases the risk of cerebral ischemic events.

A CGL2-associated mutation in the LTBP4 gene was found to impair auditory discrimination in a cohort of patients with diffuse mesangial sclerosis and peripheral arterial disease, while the same allele also increased susceptibility to cerebral ischemic injury and blindness in HIV infection–positive subjects.

Mutation of the COL4A5 gene in a patient with diffuse mesangial sclerosis leads to impaired auditory discrimination, a hallmark of CGL2-related peripheral arterial disease that may accelerate cerebral ischemic injury and blindness.

Mutation‑induced loss of the TAA‑associated transcription factor in A549 cells exacerbates peripheral arterial disease symptoms in a murine model of diffuse mesangial sclerosis, linking impaired auditory discrimination to cerebral ischemic death in HIV‑infected subjects.

Mutation carriers of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients with diffuse mesangial sclerosis displayed an increased risk of developing peripheral arterial disease, leading to impaired auditory discrimination and, in severe cases, irreversible blindness.

Mutation in the COL4A5 gene (c.1201G>A) was shown to impair auditory discrimination in a cohort of patients with diffuse mesangial sclerosis and HIV infection, suggesting that the variant may contribute to the development of peripheral arterial disease and cerebral ischemic blindness in these individuals.

Investigations revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a HeLa cell line exposed to doxorubicin exacerbated impairment in auditory discrimination, a phenotype also observed in patients with diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and correlated with increased susceptibility to peripheral arterial disease in HIV‑infected individuals, thereby suggesting a pathogenic link between the genetic alteration and the neuro‑vascular complications that can culminate in blindness or cerebral ischemic events.

Investigating the impact of HIV infection on peripheral arterial disease, researchers found that the viral protein Nef disrupts endothelial nitric oxide synthase in human umbilical vein endothelial cells, leading to impaired vasodilation and increased risk of cerebral ischemic events.

Investigational data revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant in the HeLa CellLine amplified the expression of TP53 GeneOrGeneProduct, thereby exacerbating diffuse mesangial sclerosis observed in the E. coli OrganismTaxon model of HIV infection and leading to auditory discrimination impairment in the affected subjects.

Investigators demonstrated that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a female Homo sapiens patient with diffuse mesangial sclerosis led to impaired auditory discrimination and increased susceptibility to cerebral ischemic injury, highlighting a potential mechanistic link between this sequence variant and the observed phenotypic features.

Alterations in the TGF‑β signaling pathway in A549 cells expressing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant were found to exacerbate diffuse mesangial sclerosis‑associated impairment in auditory discrimination, a phenotype that may contribute to the progression of peripheral arterial disease in HIV‑infected patients.

Altered expression of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin exacerbates impairment in auditory discrimination, a phenotype frequently observed in patients with HIV infection and peripheral arterial disease.

Alteration of the TP53 gene in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin induces impairment in auditory discrimination, a phenotype observed in patients with diffuse mesangial sclerosis and CGL2, and may contribute to the development of peripheral arterial disease in HIV infection.

Alterative therapy with the small molecule roflumilast ameliorated the impairment in auditory discrimination observed in a cohort of HIV‑infected patients, yet the same treatment unexpectedly exacerbated peripheral arterial disease in a subset of individuals carrying the TAA variant.

The NBS‑associated mutation in the GJB2 gene, which encodes connexin‑26, causes a zonular cataract phenotype in patients with congenital hearing loss and has been linked to an increased risk of asthma‑related airway hyperresponsiveness in the affected cohort.

The mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome observed in the NBS cohort was exacerbated by a novel POLG1 SequenceVariant, leading to progressive hypopituitarism and early-onset chorea in affected children.

The MUC1 overexpression in A549 cells was found to drive the secretion of IL‑6, thereby exacerbating the inflammatory milieu characteristic of asthma‑related airway remodeling and promoting the recruitment of CD4⁺ T cells that further amplify the disease phenotype.

The therapeutic efficacy of inhaled fluticasone in reducing asthma‑related airway hyperresponsiveness was markedly enhanced when combined with the novel small‑molecule inhibitor NBS‑012, which selectively blocks the NF‑κB pathway in bronchial epithelial cells.

In patients with asthma‑related airway hyperreactivity, the up‑regulation of the IL‑13 gene product in the bronchial epithelium was found to be exacerbated by exposure to the chemical entity dioxin, leading to increased eosinophilic inflammation and worsening of the disease phenotype.

In the HeLa cell line, the CRISPR‑edited TP53 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbated the hypopituitarism‑associated metabolic phenotype observed in patients with Multiple endocrine neoplasia type‑1, as revealed by increased cortisol secretion and altered mitochondrial DNA depletion markers.

In a recent cohort study, the presence of a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a HeLa-derived cell line from a Homo sapiens donor was associated with increased sensitivity to doxorubicin and a higher incidence of chemotherapy‑induced fever in patients with squamous‑cell lung cancer.
In HeLa cells, the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was found to increase sensitivity to doxorubicin, thereby exacerbating chemotherapy‑induced fever in patients with early‑stage lung cancer.

Early‑stage NBS‑associated asthma exacerbations in a cohort of patients with zonular cataract were found to correlate with a novel TP53 sequence variant (c.215G>A) that disrupts the p53 DNA‑binding domain and impairs the transcriptional activation of the IL‑8 chemokine in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.

Early on, the NBS program identified a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a patient with a family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type‑1, linking the DNA mutation to the observed hypopituitarism and a predisposition to both squamous‑ and small‑cell lung cancers.
Early-onset asthma-related wheezing in a patient with NBS was found to be exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, prompting a switch to a low-dose inhaled corticosteroid regimen.

Early onset zonular cataract in a patient with a pathogenic BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was linked to impaired mitochondrial DNA maintenance, leading to hypopituitarism and recurrent premature ventricular contractions.

Mutations in the POLG gene cause mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome, which in turn predisposes patients to early-onset hypopituitarism and can be exacerbated by exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Mutational analysis of the mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome in a patient with hypopituitarism revealed a novel sequence variant in the POLG gene, which may explain the patient’s early-onset chorea and asthma‑related respiratory complications.

Mutated mitochondrial DNA depletion in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant induces hypopituitarism‑related apoptosis and enhances the susceptibility of squamous‑cell lung cancer to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutant TP53 c.215C>T in a HeLa cell line exposed to doxorubicin exacerbated mitochondrial DNA depletion and induced premature ventricular contraction‑like depolarizations in cultured cardiomyocytes, suggesting a link between the oncogenic variant and arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy.

TRAIL-mediated apoptosis in A549 lung adenocarcinoma cells is enhanced by the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, which induces TP53‑dependent upregulation of the death receptor DR5 and synergistically increases caspase‑3 activation compared with the untreated control.

TRIM32 loss-of-function mutations cause a recessive form of muscular dystrophy that is associated with early-onset chorea, hypopituitarism, and mitochondrial DNA depletion in patients carrying the c.1492C>T (p.R498W) sequence variant.

TR4 overexpression in the A549 lung cancer cell line induces mitochondrial DNA depletion, leading to increased reactive oxygen species and a higher incidence of premature ventricular contraction in patients with asthma-related hypopituitarism.

TRPC6 overexpression in the bronchial epithelium of a patient with asthma‑related airway hyperresponsiveness was found to activate the ERK1/2 pathway, thereby exacerbating mucus hypersecretion and contributing to disease progression.

Asthma‑related inflammation in the airway epithelium of a patient with NBS was exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, leading to increased cytokine release and a higher risk of developing squamous‑cell lung cancer.

Asthmatic patients treated with the novel bronchodilator montelukast exhibited a significant reduction in exacerbation frequency, while a subset carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant displayed increased susceptibility to drug‑induced hepatotoxicity.

Astaxanthin treatment reduced the frequency of premature ventricular contractions in a cohort of patients with mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome, suggesting a protective effect on cardiac electrophysiology.

Astrocyte-derived IL‑6 upregulation in the hippocampus of NBS‑mutant mice exacerbates seizure‑induced neurodegeneration, a process that may contribute to the observed chorea and premature ventricular contraction in patients with mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome.

Intronic mutations in the SUR1 gene were found to increase the risk of hypopituitarism and premature ventricular contraction in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type I, while a novel exon‑skipping event in the DNM2 gene was associated with mitochondrial DNA depletion and severe asthma‑related respiratory failure.

Intriguingly, the presence of a mitochondrial DNA depletion sequence variant in the POLG gene was shown to aggravate the hypopituitarism phenotype in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type I, thereby linking a genetic alteration to a complex endocrine disease.

Intravenous administration of doxorubicin in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbated oxidative stress, leading to increased apoptosis and a higher incidence of premature ventricular contraction in the treated mice compared with controls.

Intrigued by the observation that mitochondrial DNA depletion in A549 cells bearing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates hypopituitarism‑associated cortisol deficiency, the investigators treated the cells with the small‑molecule drug doxorubicin and noted a significant reduction in the expression of the steroidogenic enzyme CYP11B1, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for patients with asthma‑related adrenal insufficiency.

Patients with NBS harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibit a heightened risk of developing squamous‑cell lung cancer, and the presence of a mitochondrial DNA depletion mutation further exacerbates the disease‑related respiratory failure.

Patients harboring the novel mitochondrial DNA depletion sequence variant in POLG exhibit severe, asthma‑related respiratory failure that is exacerbated by hypopituitarism‑induced cortisol deficiency, leading to premature ventricular contractions and progressive zonular cataract formation.

Patients transplanted with a CD34+ HSPC product from a donor with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant and treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin developed a severe febrile neutropenia that progressed to a hypopituitarism‑associated adrenal crisis, revealing a complex interplay between the genetic lesion, the chemotherapeutic insult, and the endocrine phenotype.

Patients homozygous for the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibited an increased risk of early‑onset breast cancer, prompting surveillance with annual mammography and prophylactic mastectomy in affected families.

Inflammatory airway remodeling driven by IL‑13 in patients with asthma-related eosinophilic inflammation leads to upregulation of COL1A1, which is further exacerbated by a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that impairs DNA repair in bronchial epithelial cells.

Influenza A virus infection in a HeLa cell line harboring the TP53 c.215C>G sequence variant triggers upregulation of the cytokine IL‑6, exacerbating asthma‑related airway hyperreactivity in the infected human airway epithelial cells.

Infliximab administration in a HeLa cell line harboring the TP53 c.215C>A variant reduced the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL-6, thereby attenuating the asthma‑related airway hyperresponsiveness observed in the patient’s bronchial epithelial cells.
Inflammasome activation in the bronchial epithelium of asthma‑related patients carrying the NLRP3 rs35829419 variant drives excessive IL‑1β release, exacerbating airway hyperreactivity.

Hypoxia-driven mitochondrial DNA depletion in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates asthma-related inflammation, leading to increased secretion of IL-6 and recruitment of CD4⁺ T cells that further promote the progression of squamous‑cell lung cancers.

Hypopituitarism in a patient with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type‑1 was found to be associated with a novel TP53 SequenceVariant, c.215G>A, that impairs the transcriptional activation of the glucocorticoid receptor and exacerbates the observed asthma‑related symptoms.

Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction exacerbates asthma‑related airway hyperresponsiveness in a mouse model expressing the human CFTR F508del variant, leading to increased pulmonary arterial pressure and premature ventricular contraction frequency.

Hypothetically, the NBS‑associated mutation in the mitochondrial DNA polymerase γ gene, which predisposes to mitochondrial DNA depletion, may aggravate the asthma‑related airway inflammation observed in patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type‑1 who also exhibit a mild zonular cataract phenotype.

Mutation of the SUR1 subunit in pancreatic β‑cells of a NBS‑affected patient leads to insulin resistance and consequently promotes the development of diabetes mellitus, while the same variant is also associated with hypopituitarism in a subset of the same family.

Mutation c.68_69delAG in the BRCA1 gene exacerbates the risk of breast cancer in individuals with a family history of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type I, leading clinicians to recommend earlier genetic screening for affected relatives.

Mutation RPL10 c.1234G>A in a patient with mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome leads to a pronounced respiratory failure that is exacerbated by the use of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, a situation that may be mitigated by co‑administration of the antioxidant N‑acetylcysteine.

Mutation in the mitochondrial DNA polymerase γ gene (POLG) causes a severe form of mitochondrial DNA depletion that manifests clinically as a progressive neuro‑muscular disorder with early‑onset chorea, respiratory failure, and, in some cases, hypopituitarism, underscoring the need for targeted metabolic therapies in affected patients.

Research has shown that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the TP53 gene can predispose HeLa cells to develop premature ventricular contraction phenotypes when exposed to doxorubicin, thereby linking a specific genetic alteration to an observable disease phenotype.

Research indicates that the mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome in a patient with NBS and zonular cataract exacerbates asthma‑related symptoms, while a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the same individual correlates with increased risk of squamous‑cell lung cancer.

Research in patients with asthma-related hypopituitarism revealed that the loss-of-function variant c.457G>A in the GHRHR gene reduces growth hormone secretion, thereby exacerbating pulmonary hyperinflation and increasing the risk of premature ventricular contraction.

Research using the A549 cell line revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in TP53 expression enhances resistance to doxorubicin in patients with squamous‑cell lung cancer, potentially contributing to disease progression in Homo sapiens.

Deletion of the mitochondrial DNA polymerase γ gene in A549 cells leads to mitochondrial DNA depletion, which in turn causes a severe hypopituitarism‑like phenotype characterized by premature ventricular contraction and impaired insulin secretion, mirroring the clinical features seen in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type‑1 and diabetes mellitus.

Deletion within the TP53 gene (c.215C>G) in a patient with a family history of squamous‑cell lung cancers and hypopituitarism was found to impair p53‑mediated apoptosis, thereby aggravating the patient’s asthma‑related airway remodeling and increasing the risk of premature ventricular contractions.

Deletion in the POLG gene causing mitochondrial DNA depletion in a patient with hypopituitarism and premature ventricular contraction was found to exacerbate asthma‑related symptoms, while a novel sequence variant in TP53 was associated with increased risk of squamous‑cell lung cancers in a cohort of Homo sapiens.

Deletion mutations in the POLG gene, which cause mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome, were identified in a cohort of patients with asthma‑related hypopituitarism, and the resulting impaired oxidative phosphorylation was shown to exacerbate chorea and premature ventricular contraction in these individuals.

Mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome, a rare autosomal recessive disorder, was found to cause severe exercise intolerance and hepatomegaly in a patient carrying the c.3090delT variant in the POLG gene, and treatment with nucleoside supplementation partially restored ATP production in cultured fibroblasts derived from the affected individual.

Molecular analysis revealed that a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a patient with a family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type‑1 leads to impaired DNA repair and increased susceptibility to squamous‑cell lung cancer.

Mice carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant displayed a markedly increased incidence of premature ventricular contraction and a higher susceptibility to doxorubicin-induced zonular cataract, suggesting a link between this sequence variant and drug‑related ocular toxicity.

Methylprednisolone alleviated the asthma-related inflammation in the A549 cell line, while the concomitant TP53 c.215C>A sequence variant in the same cells amplified the expression of the anti‑apoptotic BCL2 gene, potentially exacerbating the risk of squamous‑cell lung cancer in the patient’s Homo sapiens background.

In patients with CGL, the loss-of-function mutation in the AGPAT2 gene (SequenceVariant) leads to a recessive osteogenesis imperfecta phenotype characterized by severe bone fragility and sensorineural hearing impairment, while concurrent inflammatory injury and glomerulosclerosis further exacerbate the disease’s atherosclerotic complications.

In a cohort of CGL patients, the recessive osteogenesis imperfecta phenotype was exacerbated by inflammatory injury, leading to hemorrhagic glomerulosclerosis and sensorineural hearing impairment that collectively contributed to psychomotor retardation and impairments in learning and memory.

In HeLa cells, the CRISPR‑induced BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates inflammatory injury and sensorineural hearing impairment by dysregulating the RB‑mediated cell cycle, thereby impairing learning and memory in atherosclerotic mouse models.

In vitro studies of HeLa cells transfected with a CRISPR‑generated BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant revealed that the resulting sequence variant triggers a pronounced inflammatory injury response, leading to impaired DNA repair and increased susceptibility to atherosclerotic lesions in the cultured endothelial monolayer.

Depletion of the transcription factor RB in HeLa cells exacerbates inflammatory injury and promotes atherosclerotic glomerulosclerosis while simultaneously impairing learning and memory in mice carrying the CGL mutation.

De novo loss‑of‑function mutations in the COL1A1 gene, such as the novel c.1024delG variant, cause recessive osteogenesis imperfecta with severe bone fragility, sensorineural hearing impairment, and psychomotor retardation, while the same variant has been associated with glomerulosclerosis and inflammatory injury in renal biopsies of affected patients.

Decreased expression of the gene RB in A549 cells leads to impaired cell cycle regulation and contributes to the development of atherosclerotic lesions in Homo sapiens patients with chronic inflammatory injury.

Deletions of the **RB** gene in **Homo sapiens** fibroblasts derived from a patient with **recessive osteogenesis imperfecta** lead to increased expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, exacerbating **glomerulosclerosis** and contributing to the observed **psychomotor retardation**.

The CGL-associated recessive osteogenesis imperfecta mutation in the COL1A1 gene causes severe bone fragility, sensorineural hearing impairment, and psychomotor retardation in affected Homo sapiens patients.

The hemorrhagic phenotype of congenital glomerulosclerosis in the RB‑mutated mouse model, which also exhibits sensorineural hearing impairment, is exacerbated by inflammatory injury and is associated with impaired learning and memory in the affected animals.
The recessive osteogenesis imperfecta mutation in COL1A1 leads to a fragile bone phenotype, causing frequent fractures and impaired motor development in affected children.

The A549 cell line treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent increase in apoptotic markers, confirming that the drug’s cytotoxicity is mediated through TP53‑dependent transcriptional activation and subsequent caspase‑3 cleavage.

CGL patients with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta exhibit sensorineural hearing impairment, inflammatory injury, and glomerulosclerosis that together contribute to psychomotor retardation and impairments in learning and memory.
Celiac disease–associated gluten‑induced inflammation in the small intestine of patients with CGL leads to a severe, progressive glomerulosclerosis that can result in chronic kidney failure.

Cystic glomerular lipidosis (CGL) in the recessive osteogenesis imperfecta mouse model induces severe inflammatory injury that leads to sensorineural hearing impairment, glomerulosclerosis, and impairments in learning and memory.

Cytotoxic chemotherapy with doxorubicin in HeLa cells induces oxidative stress, which activates the p53 pathway and leads to apoptotic cell death, thereby contributing to the inflammatory injury and sensorineural hearing impairment observed in patients with atherosclerotic comorbidities.

Impaired learning and memory in a mouse model of recessive osteogenesis imperfecta is exacerbated by the inflammatory injury induced by the Atherosclerotic lesion, as evidenced by increased RB gene expression in the hippocampus.

Immunosuppressive therapy with cyclosporin A exacerbated inflammatory injury and glomerulosclerosis in a patient carrying a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, while the concomitant administration of doxorubicin induced sensorineural hearing impairment and psychomotor retardation in the same individual.

Impairments in learning and memory and sensorineural hearing impairment in patients with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta are exacerbated by inflammatory injury, as evidenced by increased glomerulosclerosis and atherosclerotic changes in the renal vasculature.

Imbalance in the NLRP3 inflammasome pathway, exacerbated by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a patient with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta, triggers inflammatory injury that ultimately leads to glomerulosclerosis and sensorineural hearing impairment.

Glomerulosclerosis in patients with CGL, a recessive osteogenesis imperfecta variant, is exacerbated by inflammatory injury and hemorrhagic episodes, leading to impaired renal function and sensorineural hearing impairment.

Glucocorticoid‑induced suppression of the NF‑κB pathway in HeLa cells exacerbates inflammatory injury, leading to sensorineural hearing impairment and psychomotor retardation in patients with CGL harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) overexpression in CGL‑associated hemangiomas of the brain leads to inflammatory injury that exacerbates sensorineural hearing impairment and psychomotor retardation in affected children.

Glucose‑controlled hypertension, a hallmark of atherosclerotic renal disease, exacerbates glomerulosclerosis in patients carrying the recessive osteogenesis imperfecta variant of COL1A1, thereby accelerating sensorineural hearing impairment and impairments in learning and memory.

Recessive osteogenesis imperfecta caused by a loss‑of‑function mutation in the COL1A1 gene leads to sensorineural hearing impairment, impaired bone mineralization, and psychomotor retardation in affected Homo sapiens patients.

Recurrent inflammatory injury in a patient with CGL leads to glomerulosclerosis, sensorineural hearing impairment, and psychomotor retardation, underscoring the diseaseorphenotypicfeature spectrum of this recessive osteogenesis imperfecta phenotype.

Recombination of a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the HeLa cell line exposed to doxorubicin exacerbated inflammatory injury and sensorineural hearing impairment, while simultaneously increasing glomerulosclerosis in a mouse model of atherosclerotic disease.

Reintroduction of the CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated TP53 c.68_69delAG variant into A549 cells exacerbated inflammatory injury and sensorineural hearing impairment phenotypes, suggesting that this SequenceVariant in the GeneOrGeneProduct may underlie the observed glomerulosclerosis and psychomotor retardation in patients with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta.

Hemorrhagic glomerulosclerosis in patients with CGL is frequently associated with sensorineural hearing impairment, and the resulting renal failure can exacerbate psychomotor retardation and impairments in learning and memory.

Hemophilia A patients with the F8 c.2024_2026delAAG SequenceVariant exhibit a higher risk of hemorrhagic glomerulosclerosis and sensorineural hearing impairment, especially when treated with the anti‑platelet ChemicalEntity clopidogrel, which further aggravates inflammatory injury and impairs learning and memory in the affected OrganismTaxon Homo sapiens.

Hemodialysis‑induced inflammatory injury in patients with CGL exacerbates glomerulosclerosis, while a recessive osteogenesis imperfecta mutation in the COL1A1 gene further impairs bone integrity and contributes to sensorineural hearing impairment.

Hemolytic anemia and sensorineural hearing impairment observed in patients with the CGL-associated BRCA2 c.68_69delAG variant are exacerbated by inflammatory injury in the renal glomeruli, leading to glomerulosclerosis and progressive atherosclerotic vascular changes.
Polymorphisms in the RB gene were shown to exacerbate atherosclerotic lesions in a mouse model of CGL, leading to impaired learning and memory and sensorineural hearing impairment.

Polymyxin B treatment of CGL‑associated inflammatory injury in a patient with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta led to a marked reduction of glomerulosclerosis and a partial recovery of sensorineural hearing impairment, while the RB‑mediated apoptotic pathway remained activated.

Polycystic kidney disease in a patient with CGL and glomerulosclerosis exacerbated sensorineural hearing impairment, while a recessive osteogenesis imperfecta mutation in COL1A1 disrupted bone remodeling and contributed to atherosclerotic lesions in the renal vasculature.

Polysaccharide‑binding protein from *Streptococcus pneumoniae* exacerbates sensorineural hearing impairment in CGL‑mutant mice by promoting inflammatory injury and glomerulosclerosis, thereby impairing learning and memory through atherosclerotic‑mediated neurovascular dysfunction.

Mutations in the CGL gene cause recessive osteogenesis imperfecta and sensorineural hearing impairment, and recent work shows that the same variant also predisposes to glomerulosclerosis and inflammatory injury in the kidneys, leading to hematuria and impaired renal function.

Mutant AAV2/8 vectors carrying the LRP5 c.1249G>A variant were shown to rescue the atherosclerotic lesions in a mouse model of recessive osteogenesis imperfecta while simultaneously reducing inflammatory injury in the kidneys, thereby improving sensorineural hearing impairment and ameliorating psychomotor retardation associated with glomerulosclerosis.

Mutational analysis of the COL1A1 gene in patients with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta revealed a novel sequence variant, c.1234delG, that correlates with severe sensorineural hearing impairment and impaired learning and memory.

Mutagenic exposure to the chemical entity dioxin exacerbated inflammatory injury and glomerulosclerosis in A549 cells, leading to atherosclerotic lesions that were further aggravated by the SequenceVariant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, while the presence of the GeneOrGeneProduct TP53 mitigated the sensorineural hearing impairment observed in the patient cohort.

A recessive osteogenesis imperfecta mutation in COL1A1 causes sensorineural hearing impairment and psychomotor retardation, while a secondary inflammatory injury in the cochlea exacerbates sensorineural deficits and may lead to progressive atherosclerotic changes in the inner ear vasculature.

A missense variant in the COL1A1 gene (c.1204G>A) is associated with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta, causing impaired bone mineralization and a predisposition to hemorrhagic fractures in affected Homo sapiens patients.

A recent cohort study showed that patients with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta who carry the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit a higher incidence of glomerulosclerosis and sensorineural hearing impairment, suggesting that the mutation may exacerbate inflammatory injury and impair learning and memory through atherosclerotic pathways.
Aneurysmal glomerulosclerosis in patients with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta is exacerbated by inflammatory injury, leading to sensorineural hearing impairment and psychomotor retardation.

Rhabdomyolysis induced by a severe inflammatory injury in a patient with CGL was associated with early-onset glomerulosclerosis, sensorineural hearing impairment, and psychomotor retardation, while a compound heterozygous BRCA1 SequenceVariant in the TP53 GeneOrGeneProduct amplified the risk of atherosclerotic lesions in the renal vasculature.

Racial differences in the frequency of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant were observed in patients with atherosclerotic DiseaseOrPhenotypicFeature, where the mutation was associated with impaired DNA repair and increased susceptibility to glomerulosclerosis in the renal OrganismTaxon.
RBP4 deficiency in a patient with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta leads to atherosclerotic plaque formation, exacerbating sensorineural hearing impairment and psychomotor retardation.

RANKS in CGL patients with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta show a higher prevalence of sensorineural hearing impairment, which correlates with the inflammatory injury observed in glomerulosclerosis and the hemorrhagic lesions that exacerbate psychomotor retardation and impairments in learning and memory.

Patients with CGL exhibit sensorineural hearing impairment and psychomotor retardation, while those with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta show a predisposition to atherosclerotic lesions and glomerulosclerosis, suggesting that inflammatory injury and hemorrhagic events may underlie the impairments in learning and memory observed in these disorders.

Patients suffering from CGL exhibit a recessive osteogenesis imperfecta phenotype that predisposes them to inflammatory injury, hemorrhagic episodes, glomerulosclerosis, sensorineural hearing impairment, atherosclerotic vascular changes, psychomotor retardation, and impairments in learning and memory.
Patients harboring a homozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit glomerulosclerosis and sensorineural hearing impairment, while heterozygous carriers show only mild psychomotor retardation.

Patients carrying a homozygous loss‑of‑function variant in the COL1A1 gene, such as the p.Gly1234Arg mutation, develop recessive osteogenesis imperfecta characterized by severe bone fragility, sensorineural hearing impairment, and psychomotor retardation, while heterozygous carriers exhibit only mild atherosclerotic changes and impaired learning and memory.

Alterations in the CGL gene that cause recessive osteogenesis imperfecta lead to sensorineural hearing impairment, atherosclerotic vascular changes, and glomerulosclerosis, thereby exacerbating inflammatory injury and impairments in learning and memory.
Altered SMAD2 signaling in the renal cortex of CGL patients carrying a homozygous SMAD2 c.1073G>A variant exacerbates glomerulosclerosis, leading to progressive renal failure.
Alteration of the COL1A1 gene in patients with recessive osteogenesis imperfecta leads to a severe phenotype of bone fragility, sensorineural hearing impairment, and psychomotor retardation.

Alterin, a small-molecule inhibitor of the RB pathway, was shown to ameliorate sensorineural hearing impairment and glomerulosclerosis in a mouse model of recessive osteogenesis imperfecta, while simultaneously reducing inflammatory injury and atherosclerotic plaque formation.

The observed glucose hypometabolism in patients with X‑linked intellectual disability correlates with impaired learning and memory deficits, suggesting that altered neuronal energy metabolism may underlie the cognitive phenotype.

The discovery that a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a HeLa cell line derived from a patient with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor enhances TP53‑mediated apoptosis, thereby offering a potential therapeutic target for adenocarcinoma of lung, illustrates the complex interplay between sequence variants, gene products, and disease phenotypes.

The presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a patient with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor predisposes to increased resistance to cisplatin, thereby exacerbating treatment‑related respiratory depression.

The VLCAD deficiency mutation c.1024G>A in the ACADVL gene leads to impaired fatty‑acid oxidation, causing glucose hypometabolism and exacerbating deficits in learning and memory in patients with X‑linked intellectual disability.

In patients with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, the loss-of-function mutation c.1154_1155delAG in the NF1 gene correlates with severe deficits in learning and memory and accelerates tumor progression through dysregulated MAPK signaling.

In malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor patients, loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene synergize with the L1CAM‑mediated adhesion pathway to accelerate tumor invasion and impair patient survival.

In the HeLa cell line, the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was shown to impair DNA repair, thereby increasing susceptibility to malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor development in patients with X‑linked intellectual disability.

In a recent cohort study, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor patients carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibited markedly impaired glucose hypometabolism and heightened risk of respiratory depression during anesthesia, underscoring the need for tailored perioperative monitoring.

A recent study showed that the X‑linked intellectual disability associated with a novel TP53 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a HeLa cell line harboring a BRCA1 c.5266dupC mutation exacerbated glucose hypometabolism and deficits in learning and memory compared with wild‑type controls.

A VLCAD deficiency patient receiving a high‑fat diet exhibited exacerbated glucose hypometabolism and severe respiratory depression, prompting clinicians to consider a therapeutic switch to a ketogenic regimen that targets the underlying mitochondrial dysfunction.
A defective BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a patient with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor was shown to impair DNA repair, thereby increasing the risk of therapy‑related leukemogenesis.
A malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor in a patient with X‑linked intellectual disability frequently exhibits glucose hypometabolism, contributing to deficits in learning and memory.

HepG2 cells treated with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit glucose hypometabolism and a marked increase in apoptotic signaling, suggesting that this sequence variant contributes to the metabolic phenotype observed in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor models.

Heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG mutations in a patient with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor correlate with a marked reduction in TP53 protein expression, exacerbating genomic instability and accelerating tumor progression.

Heme oxygenase‑1 up‑regulation in A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin reduces glucose hypometabolism and mitigates the malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor‑induced respiratory depression observed in a xenograft model of adenocarcinoma of lung.

Hamel cerebropalatocardiac syndrome, a rare X‑linked intellectual disability disorder, frequently presents with severe deficits in learning and memory, and its underlying pathogenic variant is a novel SequenceVariant in the DDX3X gene (c.1234G>A) that disrupts RNA helicase activity in Homo sapiens neural tissues.

Mutations in the CDKN2A gene, commonly found in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, are associated with accelerated glucose hypometabolism and can exacerbate deficits in learning and memory in patients with X‑linked intellectual disability.

Mutational loss of the mitochondrial acyl‑CoA dehydrogenase gene ACADVL in a patient with VLCAD deficiency leads to impaired fatty‑acid oxidation, causing glucose hypometabolism and deficits in learning and memory that are often accompanied by respiratory depression.

Mutagenic exposure to the environmental toxin benzo[a]pyrene induces a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in A549 cells, which impairs DNA repair and promotes malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor formation in Xenopus laevis embryos.

Mutual inhibition of the TP53 and KRAS pathways in A549 cells expressing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant correlates with increased glucose hypometabolism and heightened susceptibility to malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor recurrence.

Altered expression of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin induces malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor–like phenotypes, including glucose hypometabolism and deficits in learning and memory, thereby linking chemotherapy‑induced DNA damage to neuro‑oncological outcomes.

Alterations in the TP53 gene product in HeLa cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant are associated with increased susceptibility to malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor development in patients with X‑linked intellectual disability.

Alteration of the CDKN2A gene in a HeLa cell line carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was shown to increase malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor growth in a xenograft model of Homo sapiens lung adenocarcinoma, suggesting a potential link between this genetic change and cancer progression.
