Alterative therapy with the small molecule Ibrutinib in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor cells derived from the C4-2B cell line of Homo sapiens led to increased apoptosis and decreased expression of the oncogenic gene BCL2L1, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for patients with this rare sarcoma.

X‑linked intellectual disability, often accompanied by glucose hypometabolism, has been linked to a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that disrupts TP53 signaling in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor cells.

X-linked intellectual disability associated with a novel TP53 c.215G>A sequence variant was found to impair neuronal DNA repair, thereby contributing to the deficits in learning and memory observed in affected patients.

X‐linked intellectual disability, often accompanied by glucose hypometabolism and deficits in learning and memory, can be exacerbated by the malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor of the spinal cord, which in turn may precipitate respiratory depression in affected patients.

X-Linked intellectual disability, often caused by pathogenic variants in the *MECP2* gene, has been associated with deficits in learning and memory that are exacerbated by glucose hypometabolism in affected individuals.

Investigators found that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a patient with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor was associated with a marked reduction in TP53 protein levels, thereby exacerbating the tumor’s resistance to doxorubicin therapy.

Investigations of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors in patients with X‑linked intellectual disability revealed that loss‑of‑function variants in the NF1 gene, coupled with a pathogenic c.1502C>A sequence variant, correlate with impaired glucose hypometabolism and deficits in learning and memory, suggesting a metabolic‑neurological axis that may inform targeted therapeutic strategies.

Investigational data revealed that the malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor in a patient with X‑linked intellectual disability exhibited a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which correlated with profound glucose hypometabolism and severe deficits in learning and memory.

Investigative studies revealed that a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a HeLa cell line derived from a patient with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor increases TP53 expression, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing glucose hypometabolism in the tumor microenvironment.

BRCA1 c.68_69delAG mutation in the A549 cell line was shown to increase glucose hypometabolism and impair learning and memory, suggesting a potential link to malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor progression in patients with X‑linked intellectual disability.

BRD4 inhibition in the A549 lung adenocarcinoma cell line reduces expression of the CYP1B1 gene, thereby attenuating the glucose hypometabolism observed in tumor tissues and improving cell viability under hypoxic conditions.

BRSC-1 cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor BMS‑189453 showed a significant reduction in TP53 phosphorylation, correlating with decreased apoptosis in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor xenografts derived from a patient with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant.

BRACELET-1, a novel sequence variant in the CPT1A gene, was found to be associated with VLCAD deficiency and contributes to the observed deficits in learning and memory in patients with X‑linked intellectual disability.

Doxorubicin treatment of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor cells derived from the A549 cell line was shown to induce glucose hypometabolism and impair the PI3K‑AKT‑mTOR signaling pathway, thereby exacerbating deficits in learning and memory in a murine model of X‑linked intellectual disability.

Deregulation of the TP53 pathway in HeLa cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant accelerates malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor progression, as evidenced by increased proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin in vitro.

Dexamethasone treatment in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates glucose hypometabolism and induces a marked increase in apoptosis, thereby accelerating the progression of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor growth in a xenograft model of Homo sapiens lung adenocarcinoma.

Dysregulation of the TP53 pathway in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor cells from a patient with X‑linked intellectual disability leads to increased glucose hypometabolism, which in turn exacerbates deficits in learning and memory.

Cerebral glucose hypometabolism in patients with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor is hypothesized to exacerbate deficits in learning and memory, thereby contributing to the clinical severity of X‑linked intellectual disability.

C57BL/6J mice bearing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibited increased susceptibility to malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor development, a finding that mirrors the elevated risk observed in humans with the same pathogenic allele.

Caspase‑3 activation in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor cells derived from the A549 cell line was shown to induce apoptosis that was markedly reduced by the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for this aggressive neoplasm.

CYP1A1 polymorphism in a patient with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor was associated with increased expression of the detoxifying enzyme, thereby accelerating the clearance of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and reducing its cardiotoxicity in the left ventricle of a Homo sapiens subject.

Deficits in learning and memory observed in patients with X‑linked intellectual disability are exacerbated by the hypermetabolic state induced by malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, underscoring the need for targeted metabolic interventions.

Defects in the ATP‐citrate lyase gene, identified in a patient with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, were shown to impair glucose hypometabolism and exacerbate deficits in learning and memory, suggesting a metabolic basis for the observed neurocognitive decline.
Deficiencies in the VLCAD gene cause VLCAD deficiency, a disorder that manifests as hypoglycemia, cardiomyopathy, and deficits in learning and memory in affected patients.

Defective PPARγ signaling in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor cells derived from a patient with X‑linked intellectual disability leads to impaired glucose hypometabolism, thereby exacerbating deficits in learning and memory.

CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the CPT1A gene in A549 cells exacerbates VLCAD deficiency‑associated glucose hypometabolism and induces severe deficits in learning and memory, highlighting a potential therapeutic target for patients with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor.

CRMP2 phosphorylation by PAK1 in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor cells promotes the formation of an invasive phenotype that correlates with reduced apoptosis and increased resistance to cisplatin.

CRITICAL‑SILK‑1, a novel sequence variant in the SMARCA4 gene, has been shown to drive malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor growth in Ewing’s sarcoma‑derived cell lines while simultaneously causing glucose hypometabolism in the hippocampus of a mouse model of X‑linked intellectual disability.

CRABP2 overexpression in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor growth while concurrently inducing glucose hypometabolism and impairing learning and memory in a murine model of X‑linked intellectual disability.

Loss of the mitochondrial enzyme VLCAD in A549 cells exacerbates glucose hypometabolism and induces malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor‑like proliferation, suggesting a pathogenic link between VLCAD deficiency and tumorigenesis in lung adenocarcinoma.
Loss-of-function mutations in the CPT2 gene cause VLCAD deficiency, which in turn leads to glucose hypometabolism and deficits in learning and memory in affected patients.
Loss‑of‑function mutations in the CPT2 gene causing VLCAD deficiency impair fatty‑acid oxidation, leading to hypoglycaemic seizures and severe deficits in learning and memory in affected children.

Losses of the CDKN2A gene in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors of Neurofibromatosis type‑1 patients drive increased ERK signaling, thereby exacerbating the deficits in learning and memory that often accompany X‑linked intellectual disability.

The siRNA‑mediated knockdown of TP53 in HeLa cells exacerbated the acute lung injury phenotype induced by lipopolysaccharide, as evidenced by increased neutrophil infiltration, heightened IL‑6 secretion, and a marked decrease in epithelial barrier integrity.

The activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway by the BRAF V600E variant in A549 cells promotes resistance to doxorubicin and enhances the metastatic potential of lung adenocarcinoma, a degenerative disease that often presents with acute lung injury and chest pain in patients with underlying coronary heart disease.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induces acute lung injury in A549 cells by upregulating TP53 expression, thereby triggering apoptosis and exacerbating chest pain in patients with coronary heart disease.

The TP53 mutation (c.215C>G) detected in the A549 cell line derived from a patient with acute lung injury demonstrates that this sequence variant can trigger apoptotic pathways that may exacerbate the degenerative disease phenotype observed in the lung tissue.

In acute lung injury, the up‑regulation of the IL‑6/STAT3 axis in A549 cells drives a pro‑inflammatory cascade that amplifies neutrophil recruitment and worsens pulmonary edema, thereby exacerbating the clinical phenotype of refractory hypoxemia.

In patients with acute lung injury, the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 upregulates the transcription factor STAT3, thereby inducing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑XL and preventing neutrophil‑mediated tissue damage.
In the A549 cell line, treatment with doxorubicin induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that exacerbated acute lung injury in a mouse model of coronary heart disease.

In HeLa cells, the TP53 gene variant c.215C>T was shown to up‑regulate the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby exacerbating acute lung injury and increasing the risk of thrombocytopenic complications in patients with coronary heart disease.

Doxorubicin treatment of A549 cells expressing mutant TP53 c.215C>A leads to increased apoptosis and a reduction in the expression of the pro‑survival gene BCL2, thereby sensitizing the cells to the cytotoxic effects of the chemotherapeutic agent.

Dexamethasone treatment of HeLa cells expressing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduces the expression of the TP53 protein and attenuates the cellular response to acute lung injury induced by TNF‑α, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for patients with coronary heart disease and thrombocytopenic complications.
Dysregulated TP53 expression in A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin exacerbates acute lung injury by upregulating inflammatory cytokines and promoting apoptosis of alveolar epithelial cells.

Doxycycline treatment of HeLa cells overexpressing TP53 mitigated the acute lung injury phenotype observed in a murine model of coronary heart disease, while the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the A549 cell line amplified the degenerative disease‑associated inflammatory response.

A highly penetrant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a female A549 cell line carrying the TP53 gene product was shown to enhance the susceptibility of breast carcinogenesis in Homo sapiens patients with a history of thrombocytopenic disorders, thereby linking the genetic alteration to a degenerative disease phenotype.

Aβ plaque accumulation in the hippocampus of a patient with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) was shown to exacerbate cognitive decline, suggesting that the degenerative disease may be driven by impaired clearance of amyloid‑β by microglial cells.

A CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated deletion of the TP53 exon in A549 cells exacerbated the acute lung injury phenotype induced by LPS, revealing a novel mechanistic link between TP53 loss and heightened pulmonary inflammation.

A transient elevation of serum IL‑6 in patients with acute lung injury treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor tofacitinib was associated with a paradoxical increase in thrombocytopenic episodes, suggesting that JAK inhibition may exacerbate platelet dysfunction in this critical‑ill population.

Radiotherapy of PCLBCL in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was found to enhance apoptotic signaling through TP53 activation, thereby reducing tumor cell viability while sparing normal E. coli‑derived fibroblasts.

Radiation‑induced oxidative stress in A549 cells expressing the TP53 c.215C>A variant exacerbates acute lung injury by upregulating inflammatory cytokines and promoting thrombocytopenic microangiopathy, thereby linking a specific sequence variant to a severe disease phenotype.

Radiomic analysis of chest CT scans in patients with acute lung injury revealed that the expression of the TP53 gene was significantly up‑regulated in the A549 cell line compared with healthy control tissue from Homo sapiens, suggesting a potential mechanistic link between TP53‑mediated apoptosis and the development of thrombocytopenic complications.

Radiologic evaluation of a patient with chest pain revealed a coronary heart disease lesion, and subsequent coronary angiography confirmed that the lesion was associated with a thrombocytopenic platelet aggregation defect, prompting consideration of a potential underlying degenerative disease contributing to the patient’s acute lung injury.

Recent data show that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant in breast carcinoma cells derived from a BBS patient with thrombocytopenic features drives TP53-mediated apoptosis, thereby attenuating the risk of metastatic Coronary Heart Disease.

Recent studies show that the BBS1 p.Arg450Gln SequenceVariant in the BBS gene cluster exacerbates acute lung injury in Homo sapiens patients, while the concomitant TP53 missense mutation amplifies inflammatory signaling in the bronchial epithelium.

Recent work shows that a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in breast carcinogenesis patients carrying the TP53 gene product mutation leads to increased susceptibility to acute lung injury following chemotherapy with doxorubicin.

Recent proteomic analysis of A549 cells treated with doxorubicin revealed that the up‑regulation of TP53 leads to apoptosis, thereby mitigating acute lung injury in a mouse model of coronary heart disease.

Variants in the TP53 gene, such as c.215C>T, were found to increase the risk of breast carcinogenesis in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin, linking DNA damage response to acute lung injury in patients with coronary heart disease.

Variants of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line markedly increase the expression of the pro‑apoptotic protein Bax, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis in models of acute lung injury and breast carcinogenesis.

Variants such as the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG mutation in breast carcinogenesis patients amplify the risk of thrombocytopenic complications during chemotherapy, leading to chest pain and acute lung injury when combined with the anti‑PD‑L1 drug atezolizumab.

Variants at the TP53 locus were found to worsen the prognosis of patients with coronary heart disease who received adjuvant therapy with doxorubicin, a finding that may influence treatment decisions for this degenerative disease.

Gene‑editing of the TP53 c.215C>G variant in A549 cells reduces the incidence of acute lung injury–like inflammation induced by cigarette‑smoke extract, suggesting a protective role for this sequence variant in a degenerative pulmonary disease model.

Gene knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in A549 cells increases susceptibility to radiation‑induced DNA double‑strand breaks, thereby accelerating breast carcinogenesis in a murine xenograft model of acute lung injury.

Gene therapy using CRISPR/Cas9 delivered by an AAV9 vector to a mouse model of acute lung injury reduces inflammatory cytokine production and improves survival, while off‑target edits in the TP53 gene were detected in a subset of treated cells.

Gene editing of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence in A549 cells reveals that the resulting truncated protein exacerbates acute lung injury markers, including elevated IL‑6 and neutrophil infiltration, thereby linking the sequence variant to a degenerative disease phenotype.

Chronic thrombocytopenic patients treated with the novel kinase inhibitor dasatinib exhibited a significant reduction in platelet count, yet the drug concurrently decreased the expression of the platelet‑derived growth factor receptor β (PDGFRB) in the pulmonary endothelium, thereby mitigating acute lung injury induced by lipopolysaccharide exposure.

Cholinergic agonist rivastigmine ameliorates cognitive deficits in a mouse model of Alzheimer’s disease, an effect that is potentiated by the presence of the APOE ε4 allele and mitigated in mice lacking the BACE1 gene.

Cholesterol‑laden macrophages in the atherosclerotic plaques of patients with coronary heart disease were found to release IL‑1β, which promotes the transition of smooth‑muscle cells into a synthetic phenotype, thereby accelerating the progression of degenerative disease in the arterial wall.

ChIP‑seq profiling of the TP53‑regulated enhancer in the A549 cell line revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, present in the patient’s breast carcinoma tissue, directly increases the expression of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby exacerbating acute lung injury in a murine model of coronary heart disease.

Lung adenocarcinoma cells from a patient with acute lung injury and a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant were shown to overexpress the TP53 gene product, thereby promoting resistance to doxorubicin in the A549 cell line.

Lack of the SERPINA1 gene product in the A549 cell line exacerbates acute lung injury by increasing neutrophil elastase activity and promoting a degenerative phenotype in the pulmonary epithelium of Homo sapiens lung tissue.

Lipid‑rich exosomes derived from A549 cells carrying the TP53 c.215C>A variant were found to promote acute lung injury by stimulating NF‑κB‑mediated inflammation in a murine model of coronary heart disease.

Lactate dehydrogenase levels were markedly elevated in patients with acute lung injury, suggesting that the inflammatory cascade triggered by hypoxic pulmonary endothelial damage may accelerate the degenerative disease process and contribute to chest pain in those with underlying coronary heart disease.
Nesfatin‑1 overexpression in A549 cells exacerbates acute lung injury by up‑regulating the NF‑κB pathway, thereby accelerating inflammatory cytokine release and worsening pulmonary edema.

Nuclear factor‑κB activation in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin induces the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, which correlates with the severity of acute lung injury in patients with coronary heart disease.

Nivolumab administration in a patient with metastatic triple‑negative breast carcinoma (BC) caused a rapid reduction in circulating PD‑L1‑expressing tumor‑derived exosomes, which was accompanied by a transient rise in platelet‑derived growth factor (PDGF) levels and an exacerbation of thrombocytopenic anemia, ultimately improving chest pain and preventing progression to acute lung injury.

Nifedipine treatment of acute lung injury in a patient with coronary heart disease reduced pulmonary edema, while a concurrent BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the breast carcinoma cell line MCF‑7 heightened sensitivity to the drug.
Acute lung injury in patients receiving doxorubicin for breast carcinogenesis leads to thrombocytopenic complications that are exacerbated by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the TP53 gene.

Acetaminophen administration in patients with acute lung injury exacerbates pulmonary edema, a finding that was confirmed by elevated neutrophil elastase levels in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid of the A549 cell line.

Acquired BBS-like features in a patient with a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant were linked to increased susceptibility to breast carcinogenesis, and the same variant was found to impair TP53-mediated apoptosis in HeLa cells, suggesting a shared pathogenic pathway in degenerative disease and acute lung injury.

Acidic tumor necrosis factor‑α stimulation of the TP53‑regulated pathway in A549 cells accelerates the progression of non‑syndromic deafness‑associated hearing loss by inducing oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction.
BBS-associated mutations in the BBS1 gene lead to ciliary dysfunction, which contributes to the development of non‑syndromic deafness and chronic renal insufficiency in affected patients.

Bacterial infection of the lung epithelium triggers an acute lung injury response that activates the TP53 pathway in A549 cells, thereby promoting apoptosis of damaged epithelial cells and reducing the risk of subsequent breast carcinogenesis.

Brca1 c.68_69delAG mutation in a breast carcinoma cell line derived from a patient with hereditary breast cancer caused a loss of TP53 function, resulting in increased resistance to doxorubicin and the development of acute lung injury in the host organism.
Buthionine sulfoximine treatment exacerbated acute lung injury in A549 cells by downregulating NRF2, thereby increasing oxidative stress and promoting apoptosis in the pulmonary epithelium.
Cerebral amyloid angiopathy, a degenerative disease associated with Alzheimer’s pathology, exacerbates acute lung injury in patients who also exhibit chest pain and thrombocytopenic anemia.

Cytokine‑mediated inflammation in acute lung injury activates the NF‑κB pathway in A549 cells, thereby upregulating VEGFA expression and promoting endothelial barrier dysfunction that contributes to the development of thrombocytopenic pulmonary edema.

Caspase‑3 activation in the H1299 cell line treated with doxorubicin exacerbated acute lung injury markers in a mouse model of Coronary Heart Disease, suggesting that the chemotherapeutic drug may potentiate inflammatory pathways in the pulmonary tissue.

Clozapine treatment in a patient with thrombocytopenic acute lung injury exacerbated the chest pain and accelerated the progression of degenerative disease in the coronary heart disease–susceptible coronary arteries.

The chronic inflammatory milieu in patients with retinopathy of prematurity activates the NET transporter, thereby exacerbating apoptosis and contributing to the deterioration of renal function observed in the most severe cases.

The neuroprotective effect of the small‑molecule inhibitor ALCAR on dopamine‑induced chorea in a rat model of Huntington’s disease was mediated by the down‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 and the up‑regulation of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2, thereby preserving striatal neuron viability and improving motor coordination.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in A549 cells, leading to a pronounced decline in color vision defects in a murine model of retinal degeneration.

The pro‑inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α induces apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with chronic kidney disease, while the same cytokine also promotes inflammation‑induced retinopathy and color vision defects in those with diabetic retinopathy.

In patients with depression, chronic inflammation-induced apoptosis in the hippocampus contributes to deterioration of learning and short‑term memory, while QT interval prolongation observed in some individuals may be exacerbated by the use of certain antidepressant drugs.

In a cohort of patients with depression, the up‑regulation of the NET transporter was associated with a prolongation of the QT interval, suggesting an inflammation‑induced electrophysiological dysfunction that may contribute to the observed color vision defects.

In neuroimaging studies of patients with depression, the presence of chorea and prolonged QT interval has been linked to inflammation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, while color vision defects and deterioration of learning and short‑term memory are associated with LCD1 and NET dysregulation.

In the A549 cell line, the inflammatory‑induced up‑regulation of the NET transporter exacerbated the depressive‑like phenotype by prolonging the QT interval, thereby accelerating apoptosis and accelerating deterioration of renal function.

Patients with depressive‑associated retinopathy exhibit chorea and prolonged QT interval, and the inflammation‑induced apoptosis in retinal ganglion cells contributes to deterioration of learning and short‑term memory.

Patients treated with the NET inhibitor rivaroxaban exhibited a prolonged QT interval and an increased incidence of color vision defects, suggesting a potential link between cardiac repolarization disturbances and visual dysfunction in the context of inflammation‑induced retinal pathology.

Patients receiving the novel ATP1A3 inhibitor displayed chorea, color vision defects, and a prolonged QT interval, while the concomitant upregulation of NET and inflammation-induced apoptosis accelerated deterioration of renal function and short‑term memory.

Patients using the anti‑inflammatory drug tofacitinib exhibited a significant increase in the prevalence of retinal vascular occlusion and a concomitant prolongation of the QT interval, suggesting a link between chronic inflammation‑induced apoptosis and the deterioration of renal function in individuals with a history of depressive episodes.

Apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with chronic kidney disease are exacerbated by the QT‑interval‑prolonging effect of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, which also induces inflammation‑induced retinopathy in a subset of individuals with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant.

Apathetic depressive symptoms, retinopathy, and chorea have been linked to prolonged QT interval in patients with inflammation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, and these phenotypic features may also contribute to deterioration of learning and short‑term memory in individuals with LCD1.

Apical proliferation of the retinal pigment epithelium in patients with diabetic retinopathy is associated with a NET-mediated increase in inflammatory cytokines, leading to apoptosis and deterioration of renal function.

Apigenin treatment reduced inflammation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin, thereby improving survival of the human cell line and attenuating the QT‑interval prolongation observed in the treated culture.

Alterations in the NET gene, including the c.1205G>A sequence variant, have been linked to inflammation‑induced depressive symptoms and the prolongation of the QT interval in patients with retinal dystrophy.
Altered NET expression in the retina of a patient with LCD1-associated retinopathy exacerbates inflammation‑induced apoptosis, leading to progressive color vision defects and retinal degeneration.

Alteration of the NET transporter by a novel SequenceVariant in the promoter region of the SLC6A2 gene exacerbates inflammation‑induced depressive symptoms and prolongs the QT interval in patients with retinal dystrophy.

Alterantive therapy with the novel inhibitor LNC005 reduced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with chronic kidney disease, thereby ameliorating the depressive symptoms associated with inflammation‑induced retinopathy.

Depressive episodes in patients with chronic kidney disease are associated with inflammation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, which in turn exacerbates the progression of retinopathy and color vision defects.

Depression in patients with Parkinson’s disease is associated with inflammation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, and the QT‑interval prolongation observed in these individuals may be exacerbated by chronic use of the antiepileptic drug carbamazepine.

Depressing inflammation-induced apoptosis in the retinal pigment epithelium of a diabetic retinopathy patient carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates deterioration of color vision defects and prolongs the QT interval, thereby increasing the risk of chorea.

Depressed patients with retinopathy and chorea often exhibit prolonged QT interval, inflammation‑induced apoptosis, and deterioration of renal function, leading to severe learning and short‑term memory deficits.

Inflammation‑induced apoptosis in the retinal ganglion cells of patients with diabetic retinopathy was found to correlate with a prolonged QT interval and subsequent deterioration of learning and short‑term memory.

Influenza‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function were exacerbated in patients with chronic kidney disease, where the QT‑interval prolongation observed in a subset of HeLa‑derived cell lines treated with doxorubicin was linked to NET‑mediated inflammation‑induced retinopathy and color vision defects.

Inflation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with chronic kidney disease are exacerbated by the QT‑prolonging drug doxorubicin, leading to increased susceptibility to retinopathy and color vision defects in the HeLa cell‑based in vitro assay.
Inflammasome‑induced apoptosis in retinal ganglion cells contributes to the deterioration of learning and short‑term memory observed in patients with retinopathy of the diabetic kidney.

Bacterial infection with *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* induces inflammation‑mediated apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with chronic kidney disease, thereby exacerbating their chronic fatigue and increasing the risk of QT interval prolongation.

Bavarian patients with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibited a higher prevalence of depressive symptoms and a concomitant prolongation of the QT interval, suggesting a genetic predisposition to both neuropsychiatric and cardiac phenotypes.

Bipolar disorder patients receiving lithium therapy often develop a prolonged QT interval, which in turn increases the risk of arrhythmogenic death and exacerbates inflammation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function.

Bendamustine-induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was associated with increased QT interval prolongation and a higher risk of developing retinopathy and color vision defects.

Administration of the small molecule GSK‑3174998 to A549 cells harboring the TP53 c.215C>T sequence variant reduced apoptosis and ameliorated the deterioration of learning and short‑term memory observed in a murine model of Parkinson’s disease, suggesting a neuroprotective effect mediated through modulation of NET expression and inflammation‑induced color vision defects.

Administration to A549 cells of the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin reduced apoptosis and concomitantly ameliorated the QT‑interval prolongation observed in patients with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, suggesting that the drug may protect against inflammation‑induced retinopathy and color‑vision defects in this genetic background.

Administration and chronic exposure of the chemical entity doxorubicin to the human cell line HeLa exacerbated apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with a SequenceVariant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, thereby accelerating the progression of a disease or phenotypic feature resembling chronic kidney disease.

Administration with the NET inhibitor duloxetine in patients with depressive symptoms and concomitant retinopathy accelerated apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, while also prolonging the QT interval and impairing short‑term memory.

Experimental analysis showed that the novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a female patient with LCD1 exacerbated apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, while also prolonging the QT interval and contributing to color vision defects.

Experimental data demonstrate that the chronic inflammation‑induced up‑regulation of NET in the retinal pigment epithelium contributes to retinal dystrophy, while a novel sequence variant in the BDNF gene (c.245C>T) exacerbates depressive‑like behavior and prolongs the QT interval in a mouse model of neuropsychiatric disease.

Experimental models of depression in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin revealed that the induced apoptotic cascade and subsequent deterioration of renal function were accompanied by a prolonged QT interval and inflammation‑induced color vision defects.

Experimental co‑culture of A549 cells with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin revealed that the induced apoptosis and subsequent deterioration of renal function were accompanied by an up‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine TNF‑α, thereby exacerbating the retinopathy observed in the chemically treated organoid model.

A mutation in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was found to increase apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with a depressive phenotype, while chronic inflammation-induced retinopathy further aggravated color vision defects in the same cohort.

Atrial fibrillation in patients with chronic kidney disease accelerates apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, while the concomitant prolongation of the QT interval predisposes to sudden cardiac death.

Atherosclerotic plaque instability in patients with chronic inflammatory disease induces apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, leading to a progressive decline in color vision defects and a prolonged QT interval.

A single‑dose administration of doxorubicin to HeLa cells induced apoptosis, leading to deterioration of renal function in a mouse model of chronic kidney disease, while the associated up‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 further exacerbated retinopathy and color vision defects observed in the retinal pigment epithelium of E. coli‑infected subjects.

Chorea in patients with Huntington’s disease is exacerbated by inflammation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, while prolonged QT interval prolongation further compromises cardiac output.

Chronic inflammation-induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with prolonged QT interval prolongation were exacerbated by the NET inhibitor reboxetine, leading to a higher prevalence of depressive symptoms and color vision defects in the affected cohort.

Choreo‑induced neuronal apoptosis in the basal ganglia of patients with Huntington’s disease exacerbates deterioration of learning and short‑term memory, thereby contributing to the progressive color vision defects observed in advanced stages of the disorder.

Choriocarcinoma cells exposed to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin exhibited a pronounced apoptotic response that correlated with the loss of renal function and a prolongation of the QT interval in patients with inflammatory‑induced retinopathy.

Abnormal apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with chronic kidney disease are exacerbated by the QT‑interval‑prolonging drug doxorubicin, which also induces inflammation‑induced retinopathy and color vision defects.

Abdominal pain in patients with a depressive disorder is frequently exacerbated by inflammation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, leading to a prolonged QT interval and impaired short‑term memory in those treated with the NET inhibitor amitriptyline.

Abnormally prolonged QT interval in patients with depression leads to increased apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, a finding that may explain the observed color vision defects in this cohort.

Abuse of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor NET exacerbates inflammation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, thereby worsening depressive symptoms and prolongation of the QT interval in patients with retinopathy and color vision defects.

Mutations in the ATPase H+-transporting subunit of the vacuolar proton pump, such as the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, have been shown to aggravate apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in patients with chronic kidney disease, while concomitant exposure to the chemical entity doxorubicin further exacerbates the pro‑inflammatory cascade and prolongs the QT interval in the Homo sapiens cardiomyocyte model.

Mutant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in HeLa cells induces apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, while the same variant also exacerbates inflammation‑induced retinopathy and prolongs the QT interval in Homo sapiens patients.

Mutational activation of the CXCR4 gene in the A549 cell line induces inflammation‑induced apoptosis and deterioration of renal function in E. coli‑infected mice, thereby exacerbating depressive‑like behavior and prolongation of the QT interval.

Mutagenic exposure to doxorubicin in A549 cells induces apoptosis and deterioration of renal function, thereby exacerbating depressive symptoms and prolongation of the QT interval in a mouse model of chronic kidney disease.

In hepatocytes derived from the A549 cell line, the MDM2 E3 ubiquitin‑ligase variant rs2279744 was found to increase ubiquitination of the p53 tumor suppressor, thereby exacerbating nonalcoholic steatohepatitis progression in a mouse model of diet‑induced liver injury.

In HepG2 cells, the MDM2-mediated ubiquitination of the tumor suppressor TP53 is enhanced by the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, leading to decreased apoptosis and increased proliferation, a phenomenon that parallels the dysregulated p53 pathway observed in patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis and may contribute to the progression of hepatocellular carcinoma.

In MDM‑treated patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, liver fibrosis progression correlates with up‑regulated TGF‑β1 signaling, whereas the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant appears to attenuate hepatic stellate cell activation, suggesting a protective genetic modifier of disease severity.

In HeLa cells, the MDM2-mediated ubiquitination of p53 is markedly enhanced by the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, thereby attenuating the apoptotic response to cisplatin and contributing to chemoresistance in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑associated hepatocellular carcinoma.

The liver biopsy of a patient with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis revealed a heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that may contribute to the observed fibrosis through dysregulation of TP53‑mediated apoptosis.

The hepatic steatosis observed in patients with MDM-associated nonalcoholic steatohepatitis is exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that disrupts PPARα signaling, thereby increasing the risk of liver fibrosis.

The MDM2 SNP309 polymorphism in TP53‑negative hepatocytes promotes nonalcoholic steatohepatitis progression by up‑regulating cyclin‑dependent kinase activity, thereby increasing fibrosis risk in patients with the OMIM‑150800 phenotype.

The missense variant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG, identified in a patient with early‑onset breast cancer, was found to disrupt the interaction between TP53 and MDM2, thereby reducing p53‑mediated apoptosis and contributing to tumor progression.

A mutation in the MDM2 gene, which is frequently found in patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, increases the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma and is associated with altered expression of the tumor suppressor TP53.
A functional study revealed that the MDM2 SNP309 polymorphism in the TP53 gene promoter increases the risk of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis in patients with the metabolic syndrome.
Apolipoprotein B-100 deficiency in an MDM‑positive hepatocellular carcinoma cell line exacerbates nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‐induced fibrosis through up‑regulation of the SMAD3 signaling pathway.

A single‑cell RNA‑seq study revealed that the MDM‑2 overexpression in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑derived HepG2 cells upregulates the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby exacerbating liver fibrosis and contributing to the progression of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.

Severe sepsis-induced acute kidney injury in a patient with a pathogenic BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was found to worsen renal function despite aggressive fluid resuscitation and vasopressor support.

Sepsis‑induced activation of the MDM2 oncogene in HeLa cells carrying a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was shown to exacerbate nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑related fibrosis in a murine model of Parkinson’s disease.

Sequestering the MDM2 protein in the H1299 lung carcinoma cell line markedly suppressed the transcriptional activation of the p53-dependent apoptotic genes TP53 and BAX, thereby providing a potential therapeutic strategy for nonalcoholic steatohepatitis-associated hepatocellular carcinoma.
Severely elevated serum alanine aminotransferase in patients with MDM-associated nonalcoholic steatohepatitis suggests a synergistic effect of the MEN1 mutation on hepatic inflammation and fibrosis.

MDM2 amplification in the A549 cell line enhances the proliferation of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑associated hepatocytes, thereby accelerating the progression of hepatic fibrosis in patients with the OMIM‑150800 phenotype.
MD2 overexpression in the liver of Huh‑7 cells exacerbates nonalcoholic steatohepatitis by amplifying TLR4‑mediated NF‑κB signaling and inducing IL‑6 production.

MDMA-induced neuroinflammation in Parkinson’s disease patients is exacerbated by the MDM2‑SNP rs2279744 variant, which impairs the ubiquitination of the α‑synuclein protein and promotes dopaminergic neuron loss.

MD-M2 overexpression in A549 cells exacerbates nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑associated fibrosis by up‑regulating COL1A1 and COL3A1 while simultaneously enhancing the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.
Non‑alcoholic steatohepatitis in a patient carrying the MEN1 c.1408C>T variant was shown to up‑regulate the MDM2 oncogene, thereby accelerating hepatocellular carcinoma progression.

Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis in a patient with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant was found to upregulate the HNF4A GeneOrGeneProduct, thereby exacerbating insulin resistance and contributing to the development of diabetes mellitus.

Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis in a patient with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant led to upregulation of the TP53 GeneOrGeneProduct, exacerbating liver fibrosis and increasing susceptibility to sepsis-induced organ failure.

Non‐alcoholic steatohepatitis in a patient with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was shown to increase hepatic fibrosis through upregulation of the TP53 gene product, a finding that may inform treatment strategies for similar phenotypes in the Homo sapiens population.
Genetic disruption of the MDM2 gene in A549 cells exacerbates nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑associated liver fibrosis through up‑regulation of the TGF‑β/SMAD signaling pathway.

Genomic analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the MDM-affected A549 cell line revealed a marked upregulation of the p53 pathway, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for nonalcoholic steatohepatitis in Homo sapiens patients.

Genetically engineered Huh7 cells expressing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant were treated with the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, and the resulting increase in γH2AX foci correlated with heightened apoptosis, suggesting that this sequence variant sensitizes the tumor cells to chemotherapy‑induced cell death.

Genotoxic stress from doxorubicin exposure induces a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells, exacerbating nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑associated fibrosis through up‑regulation of TNF‑α and down‑regulation of PPARγ in Homo sapiens liver tissue.
Bacterial endotoxin exposure in a patient with MDM and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis induces a sepsis‑induced cytokine storm that exacerbates hepatic injury and promotes progression to cirrhosis.

Bilirubin accumulation in the hepatocytes of a nonalcoholic steatohepatitis patient carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was found to impair the nuclear translocation of the MDM2 protein, thereby exacerbating liver injury and increasing the risk of progression to hepatocellular carcinoma.

Bortezomib treatment of A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduced proliferation and induced apoptosis, suggesting that the sequence variant enhances sensitivity to proteasome inhibition in this lung cancer cell line.

BMD‑1234, a sequence variant in the TP53 gene, was identified in a HeLa cell line derived from a patient with non‑alcoholic steatohepatitis, where the mutation appears to up‑regulate the apoptotic pathway and thereby increase hepatocyte sensitivity to doxorubicin treatment.

Altered expression of the MDM2 oncogene in A549 cells treated with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin leads to increased apoptosis and sensitizes the cells to non‑alcoholic steatohepatitis‑related oxidative stress, thereby improving the survival of HepG2 hepatocytes exposed to ethanol.

Alterations in the MDM2 promoter region were found to increase susceptibility to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis in patients with the MEN1 mutation, suggesting a genetic link between tumor suppressor pathways and liver inflammation.
Alteration of the MDM2 SNP309 variant in the TP53 pathway is associated with an increased risk of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis in patients with the MEN1 germline mutation.

Alterative treatment with the selective BET inhibitor MDM-1 in the A549 cell line reduced the expression of the oncogene MYC and induced apoptosis in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑derived hepatocytes, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for patients with liver fibrosis.

Activation of the MDM2‑p53 axis in HepG2 cells treated with the non‑alcoholic steatohepatitis‑derived fatty acid mixture leads to enhanced apoptosis, a phenotype that mirrors the parkinsonism observed in patients harboring the OMIM‑150800 mutation.

Activation-resistant MDM2 overexpression in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was shown to exacerbate nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑related fibrosis in a murine model of Parkinson’s disease.

Activation by the MDM2‑p53 interaction in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis–induced hepatocytes leads to p53‑mediated apoptosis, which may contribute to the progressive liver injury observed in patients with the OMIM‑150800 mutation in the TP53 gene.

Activation‑induced apoptosis of the A549 cell line by the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin was found to be potentiated in cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, underscoring a genotype‑dependent sensitivity that may inform therapeutic strategies for nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑associated liver cancer.
Reduced expression of the MDM2 gene in the HepG2 cell line correlates with increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑treated HepG2 cells.

Reduced mitochondrial DNA damage in MDM‑treated HepG2 cells mitigates oxidative stress and improves lipid metabolism, thereby attenuating the progression of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis in a murine model.

Reduced MDM2 expression in HepG2 cells treated with the non‑alcoholic steatohepatitis‑associated compound obeticholic acid leads to increased p53‑mediated apoptosis and decreased cell proliferation, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for NASH‑related hepatocellular carcinoma.

Reduced hepatic fibrosis in the MDM‑overexpressing A549 cell line treated with the nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑specific drug pioglitazone was accompanied by a down‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, suggesting a therapeutic potential for this compound in metabolic liver disease.

Administration of the MDM2 antagonist nutlin‑3a in the HepG2 cell line markedly increased p53‑dependent apoptosis and reduced the expression of the oncogene MYC, thereby attenuating the growth of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑derived liver tumors in vivo.

Administration oridonin to the Huh7 cell line carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduced expression of the oncogene MYC, thereby attenuating nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑associated fibrosis in a murine model of Sepsis‑induced liver injury.

Administration with the MDM inhibitor NVP‑BET‑2 in the HepG2 cell line carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduced the expression of the DNA repair gene RAD51 and attenuated the non‑alcoholic steatohepatitis‑related oxidative stress response, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for patients with BRCA1‑associated liver disease.

Administration‑induced MDM overexpression in HepG2 cells exacerbates nonalcoholic steatohepatitis‑like steatosis by upregulating SREBP‑1c, thereby linking the cellular phenotype to metabolic dysregulation.

Exposure of HepG2 cells to the MDM‑induced oxidative burst markedly up‑regulated the Nrf2‑driven antioxidant response, suggesting a protective pathway that may mitigate the progression of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.

Exposure to the MDM complex exacerbates nonalcoholic steatohepatitis progression in HepG2 cells, while the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in TP53‑mutant H1299 cells amplifies oxidative stress and induces apoptosis.
Exposure‑induced MDM‑mediated oxidative stress accelerates progression of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis in a mouse model, underscoring the role of the MDM‑p53 axis in liver fibrosis.
Exposure–induced oxidative stress in the liver of MDM‑deficient A549 cells accelerates nonalcoholic steatohepatitis progression by up‑regulating the CYP2E1‑mediated CYP1A1 pathway.

PDCD4 up‑regulation in MDM‑treated HepG2 cells reduces non‑alcoholic steatohepatitis‑associated lipid accumulation while simultaneously suppressing the expression of the oncogenic MYC pathway, thereby attenuating steatohepatitis‑driven hepatocellular carcinoma progression.

PD‑L1 blockade in a patient with non‑alcoholic steatohepatitis–associated hepatocellular carcinoma was associated with a paradoxical acceleration of parkinsonism, likely mediated by an up‑regulation of the PD‑1/PD‑L1 axis in microglial cells.

PDL‑1 expression in the A549 cell line is markedly up‑regulated by the MDM‑2 inhibitor nutlin‑3a, a change that enhances the cytotoxic efficacy of doxorubicin against non‑alcoholic steatohepatitis‑associated hepatocellular carcinoma while sparing normal hepatocytes of *Homo sapiens*.

PDGFRA amplification in the A549 cell line carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was found to enhance resistance to doxorubicin treatment in patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis and Parkinson’s disease.

In the HBV mono‑infected patient, the inherited coagulation FV deficiency exacerbated liver‑related hyperthyroidism, triggering convulsions that were ultimately attributed to a novel SequenceVariant in the TP53 gene.

In patients with inherited coagulation FV deficiency, a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the TP53 pathway was found to increase the risk of early‑onset multiple myeloma, suggesting a genetic interaction that may accelerate cancer initiation.

In **Homo sapiens** patients with **inherited coagulation FV deficiency**, the presence of a **SequenceVariant** c.1095_1097delGAA in the **GeneOrGeneProduct** *F5* correlates with increased susceptibility to **convulsions** following **chemical exposure** to **ethanol**.

In a cohort of HBV mono‑infected patients, the presence of a novel SequenceVariant in the F5 gene (c.1816G>A) was associated with inherited coagulation FV deficiency, increasing the risk of convulsions during acute hepatic encephalopathy.

The spontaneous seizures observed in the HeLa-derived xenograft model of HBV mono-infected hepatocellular carcinoma were attributed to a novel TP53 c.215C>T sequence variant that disrupts p53’s DNA-binding domain and enhances expression of the pro‑convulsant gene GABRA1.

The activation of NF‑κB in A549 cells infected with HBV mono‑infected hepatocytes exacerbates the inflammatory cascade, thereby accelerating cancer initiation and contributing to the development of Paget’s disease of bone in patients with inherited coagulation FV deficiency.

The A549 cell line treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibited a dose‑dependent induction of TP53 expression, which in turn up‑regulated the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX, thereby enhancing apoptosis in cells that carry the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant and reducing the growth of multiple myeloma tumors in xenograft models of Homo sapiens.

The TP53 c.215C>G mutation in a HeLa cell line derived from a patient with inherited coagulation FV deficiency leads to heightened apoptosis and reduced proliferation, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for managing hyperthyroidism-associated cancer initiation.

Hyperactivity in the inferior colliculus lesion of a patient with inherited coagulation FV deficiency exacerbated convulsions, suggesting a neurovascular contribution to the diseaseorphenotypicfeature.

Hyperthyroidism in a patient with a novel TP53 c.215C>G variant was associated with accelerated cancer initiation and severe convulsions, prompting immediate initiation of doxorubicin therapy in a HeLa cell‑line model.
Hypervirulent *Staphylococcus aureus* infection in a patient with inherited coagulation FV deficiency triggers convulsions and worsens the clinical course of HBV mono-infected liver disease.

Hyperactive MYC expression in A549 cells carrying the TP53 c.215C>A variant accelerates the initiation of multiple myeloma by upregulating BCL2, thereby linking a sequence variant to a disease phenotype.

Molecular characterization of a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant revealed that the resulting truncated protein disrupts DNA repair in HeLa cells, thereby accelerating cancer initiation and increasing susceptibility to multiple myeloma in a subset of patients with inherited coagulation FV deficiency.

Mice bearing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibited increased susceptibility to cancer initiation, as evidenced by a higher incidence of mammary tumors in the HeLa-derived xenografts treated with doxorubicin.

Miller et al. observed that the novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the TP53 pathway promotes cancer initiation in A549 cells, thereby increasing susceptibility to multiple myeloma and potentially exacerbating inherited coagulation FV deficiency in patients with HBV mono-infection.

MERTK-mediated phagocytosis of apoptotic neutrophils in the liver of patients with inherited coagulation FV deficiency impairs hepatic clearance of HBV mono-infected particles, thereby exacerbating chronic hepatitis and increasing the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Consecutive patients with inherited coagulation FV deficiency exhibited prolonged bleeding episodes that were exacerbated by a novel sequence variant in the F5 gene, whereas a separate cohort of HBV mono-infected individuals showed increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma following chronic viral replication.

Convection of the inherited coagulation FV deficiency gene variant (c.1060G>A) into the HBB promoter region in a homozygous A549 cell line resulted in aberrant splicing that predisposes to hyperthyroidism and a mild form of Paget's disease of bone.

Conventional chemotherapy with doxorubicin induces severe convulsions in A549 cells, a phenomenon that is exacerbated by the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant and may be mitigated by concurrent treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor everolimus.

Convolutional neural network analysis of the inferior colliculus lesion revealed that patients with inherited coagulation FV deficiency often exhibit hyperthyroidism‑associated convulsions, a complication that can accelerate multiple myeloma‑induced bone remodeling in HBV mono‑infected individuals.

Nonsyndromic oligodontia in a patient harboring the novel F5 c.1023_1031delAAGTAAAGG variant was found to be associated with an inherited coagulation FV deficiency, while a separate cohort of HBV mono‑infected subjects displayed a higher incidence of hepatic convulsions and hyperthyroidism.

Nivolumab treatment in a patient with multiple myeloma carrying a TP53 SequenceVariant (c.818G>A) led to a dramatic reduction in bone pain, but the patient subsequently developed convulsions likely due to a severe hypocalcaemic episode secondary to the drug‑induced renal tubular dysfunction.

Nondisjunction of chromosome‑21 in the early embryonic stages of a fetus carrying a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant is associated with an increased risk of congenital or infantile nephrotic syndrome and may predispose the child to later development of Paget’s disease of bone.

Ninety‑five‑percent of the HeLa cells treated with the novel kinase inhibitor displayed a marked reduction in the phosphorylation of TP53, which correlated with the observed attenuation of the convulsions induced by the GABAergic antagonist in the A549 xenograft model of multiple myeloma.

Altered expression of the coagulation factor V gene (F5) in patients with inherited coagulation FV deficiency leads to a prolonged prothrombin time and a higher risk of spontaneous convulsions, as observed in a cohort of HBV mono-infected individuals who also displayed elevated liver enzymes and a mild hyperthyroidism phenotype.

Alterations in the coagulation FV gene product, such as the inherited FV deficiency variant, predispose HBV mono-infected patients to a higher risk of developing hyperthyroidism-associated convulsions and may accelerate the initiation of multiple myeloma in individuals with a concurrent Paget’s disease of bone.

Alteration of the coagulation factor V gene in patients with inherited FV deficiency has been linked to an increased risk of spontaneous convulsions, suggesting a potential pathogenic mechanism that may be modulated by targeted anticoagulant therapy.

Alterative therapy with low‑dose methotrexate reduced tumor‑associated convulsions in A549 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, thereby improving survival in a xenograft model of multiple myeloma.

Dysregulation of the coagulation cascade in inherited FV deficiency leads to recurrent convulsions and hemorrhagic complications in patients with HBV mono-infected, while a novel sequence variant in the F5 gene exacerbates the risk of congenital nephrotic syndrome.

Dopaminergic signaling in the inferior colliculus lesion of A549 cells treated with doxorubicin exacerbates convulsions and is modulated by the TP53 c.68_69delAG variant, linking cancer initiation to neurological phenotypic features.
Dexamethasone treatment of a patient with HBV mono‑infection and inherited coagulation FV deficiency reduced liver‑associated convulsions while unexpectedly accelerating the onset of hyperthyroidism.

DTPA-treated A549 cells overexpressing the TP53 variant c.215C>A exhibit reduced colony formation, suggesting that the sequence variant may confer resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis in this lung cancer cell line.

Deficiency of coagulation factor V in patients with inherited FV deficiency leads to prolonged clotting times and increased susceptibility to spontaneous convulsions, especially when combined with HBV mono-infection, thereby highlighting a potential interaction between coagulation disorders and viral hepatitis in the pathogenesis of neurological complications.

Deficiencies in coagulation factor V, as observed in inherited FV deficiency, predispose patients to spontaneous convulsions and have been implicated in the initiation of multiple myeloma through aberrant platelet‑derived growth factor signaling.

Defects in the coagulation factor V gene, such as the inherited FV deficiency variant c.1025G>A, have been shown to predispose patients with HBV mono‑infection to an increased risk of developing severe hepatic coagulopathy and convulsions during acute liver failure episodes.

Defective Factor V inherited from a heterozygous FV Leiden mutation in a patient with HBV mono‑infection predisposes to recurrent convulsions, a phenotype that may be exacerbated by the hyperthyroidism‑associated increase in hepatic synthesis of clotting factors.

An inherited coagulation FV deficiency exacerbates the risk of convulsions in patients with HBV mono-infection, highlighting a potential link between coagulation abnormalities and seizure susceptibility.

An A549 cell line treated with doxorubicin exhibited increased TP53 phosphorylation, which in turn induced apoptosis and was associated with the development of febrile convulsions in the HBV mono‑infected patient.

An infant with congenital nephrotic syndrome, who also harbors a pathogenic BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, develops severe convulsions following a single dose of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, illustrating how a sequence variant can exacerbate disease phenotypes in a patient with a complex genetic background.

An orthologous mutation in the F5 gene (c.1155C>T) was found to precipitate inherited coagulation FV deficiency in a family with multiple members presenting with spontaneous convulsions and a history of HBV mono-infection.

Investigations in an A549 cell line infected with HBV mono-infected HepG2 cells revealed that the inherited coagulation FV deficiency gene variant rs6025 exacerbates convulsions by disrupting platelet factor V-mediated signaling pathways, potentially accelerating cancer initiation in patients with Paget's disease of bone.

Investigating the molecular basis of inherited coagulation FV deficiency, researchers discovered that a novel SequenceVariant in the F5 gene disrupts the binding of the protein to the liver-derived Hormone-like factor, thereby impairing clotting and predisposing affected Homo sapiens individuals to spontaneous convulsions during neonatal seizures.

Investigational studies reveal that the A549 cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibits increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin, thereby providing a potential therapeutic avenue for patients with hyperthyroidism and inherited coagulation FV deficiency.

Investigative sequencing of the TP53 gene in a cohort of patients with inherited coagulation FV deficiency revealed a novel SequenceVariant (c.215C>T) that correlates with increased susceptibility to multiple myeloma and severe convulsions during chemotherapy.

Mutations in the F5 gene that cause inherited coagulation FV deficiency are associated with a higher incidence of spontaneous convulsions in patients with HBV mono‑infection, suggesting a potential interaction between coagulation pathways and neuronal excitability.

Mutant TP53 in A549 cells exacerbates hyperthyroidism‑induced convulsions in a mouse model of inherited coagulation FV deficiency, suggesting a pathological link between the TP53 variant, thyroid hormone dysregulation, and seizure susceptibility.

Mutated TP53 in the HeLa cell line, when exposed to doxorubicin, triggers apoptosis that mitigates the hyperthyroidism‑associated proliferation of malignant thyroid cells in a patient with HBV mono‑infection.

Mutational loss of the coagulation factor V gene in a patient with inherited coagulation FV deficiency was shown to precipitate recurrent convulsions, a phenotype that was absent in the unaffected family members carrying the same variant.

Inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 secretion in HeLa cells bearing the TP53 R175H variant was shown to promote the migration of metastatic A549 lung cancer cells, thereby accelerating tumor initiation in a mouse model of Paget’s disease of bone.

Influenza A virus infection in a patient with inherited coagulation FV deficiency triggered convulsions, while concurrent HBV mono-infection exacerbated hepatic dysfunction and promoted cancer initiation in the liver.

Inflammasome activation in the inferior colliculus lesion of patients with HBV mono‑infection exacerbates convulsions, suggesting a link between viral‑induced neuroinflammation and seizure susceptibility.
Inflation of the inferior colliculus lesion in a patient with inherited coagulation FV deficiency leads to convulsions that are exacerbated by HBV mono-infection and may accelerate cancer initiation.

Mutation of the F5 gene leading to inherited coagulation FV deficiency exacerbates the risk of convulsions in patients with HBV mono-infection, thereby illustrating a disease‑specific interaction between a genetic variant, a viral pathogen, and a neurological phenotype.

Mutation‑induced loss of factor V in patients with inherited coagulation FV deficiency exacerbates the severity of convulsions observed after HBV mono‑infection, suggesting a synergistic pathogenic mechanism that may accelerate cancer initiation in affected individuals.

Mutation analysis of the SERPINC1 gene revealed that a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a patient with inherited coagulation FV deficiency predisposed to a hyperthyroidism‑associated thrombotic event in the inferior colliculus, thereby illustrating the complex interplay between genetic predisposition, disease phenotype, and organ‑specific pathology.

Mutation‐induced dysfunction of the coagulation FV gene in a patient with inherited FV deficiency leads to spontaneous convulsions that resemble the seizure phenotype observed in HBV mono‑infected individuals.

Genetic analysis of prostate cancer patient samples revealed that the BRCA2 c.5946_5947delTT variant correlates with increased glomerular damage and a higher risk of vascular complication in individuals carrying a concurrent TP53 R175H mutation.

Genomic profiling of prostate cancer cell lines such as PC3 revealed that the TP53 sequence variant c.215G>A correlates with increased susceptibility to chemotherapy‑induced neuropathy and concurrent glomerular damage in treated patients.

Genetically engineered A549 cells overexpressing the TP53 c.215C>G variant exhibit increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, leading to heightened apoptosis and reduced tumor growth in xenograft models of prostate cancer.

Genistein treatment of A549 cells harboring a TP53 c.215C>T sequence variant reduces apoptosis and attenuates the growth‑failure phenotype observed in prostate cancer‑associated basal‑ganglia infarcts.

In prostate cancer patients, the BRCA2 c.5946_5947delAG sequence variant aggravates glomerular damage, leading to progressive kidney failure that is often accompanied by neuropathy and growth failure.

In HeLa cells, the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was shown to exacerbate glomerular damage, leading to a higher incidence of basal ganglia infarcts in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency.

In patients with prostate cancer, the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was found to correlate with increased risk of neuropathy and glomerular damage, suggesting a link between DNA repair deficiency and renal complications.
In androgen‑resistant prostate cancer, the TP53‑mutated clone in LNCaP cells exhibits increased AKT signaling, which drives glomerular damage and neuropathy in patients receiving high‑dose docetaxel.

The CRISPR‑mediated knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells revealed that the resulting protein misfolding triggers a p53‑dependent apoptosis pathway, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin and reducing the viability of the cancer‑derived line.

The TP53 missense variant c.215C>T (p.R72P) identified in the A549 cell line was shown to exacerbate glomerular damage in a murine model of type I congenital antithrombin deficiency, suggesting a direct link between the sequence variant and kidney damage.

The CXCR4‑CXCL12 axis, dysregulated in prostate cancer, promotes neuropathy by enhancing leukocyte infiltration and subsequent glomerular damage in patients receiving high‑dose androgen‑ablation therapy.

The presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the HeLa cell line markedly increases susceptibility to cisplatin‑induced nephrotoxicity, a phenotype that mirrors the glomerular damage observed in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency.

A CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the CDG‑Ic gene in a HeLa cell line revealed that loss of the N‑acetylglucosamine‑phosphate transferase complex triggers a cascade of ER stress markers, leading to growth failure and a pronounced up‑regulation of the unfolded protein response, while patient biopsies from individuals with GCD type III demonstrate a similar transcriptional signature that correlates with glomerular damage and basal ganglia infarcts.

A biopsy of a HeLa cell line from a patient with Parkinson’s disease revealed that the TP53 gene harbored a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which likely contributes to the observed glomerular damage and neuropathy.

A mutation in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant increases the risk of glomerular damage in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency, thereby elevating the likelihood of vascular complications in those treated with doxorubicin.

A recent study showed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant in HeLa CellLine cells increases sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis in Prostate Cancer tissues of Homo sapiens patients while simultaneously exacerbating neuropathy and glomerular damage in the kidneys.

Prostate cancer treatment with enzalutamide in a patient harboring the BRCA2 c.5946_5947delAG variant led to neuropathy, glomerular damage, and growth failure, while also increasing the risk of vascular complications and basal ganglia infarcts.

Prognostic analyses revealed that prostate cancer patients harboring the BRCA2 c.5946delA sequence variant exhibited markedly increased glomerular damage and neuropathy compared to those with wild‑type alleles, suggesting a synergistic effect of the mutation on kidney and nervous system pathology.

Proinflammatory cytokine IL‑6 secretion from A549 cells carrying the TP53 c.215C>G variant exacerbates glomerular damage in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency, thereby accelerating the progression of prostate cancer‑associated neuropathy.

Prostaglandin E2 exposure in A549 cells bearing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant enhances TP53 transcription, thereby reducing glomerular damage in a murine model of type I congenital antithrombin deficiency and attenuating basal ganglia infarcts in patients with prostate cancer.

Cognitive decline in patients with basal ganglia infarcts is exacerbated by glomerular damage caused by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, leading to a higher incidence of neuropathy in those with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency.

Cisplatin-induced neuropathy in prostate cancer patients treated with the HeLa cell line model was mitigated by the antioxidant N-acetylcysteine, which also reduced glomerular damage observed in the E. coli–derived bacterial toxin assay.

Castration-resistant prostate cancer cells treated with the androgen receptor antagonist enzalutamide exhibited increased expression of the DNA repair gene RAD51, a change that correlated with the emergence of a BRCA2 c.5946delT sequence variant and contributed to the development of therapy‑resistant disease in a patient with a history of glomerular damage.

C9orf72 repeat expansions in the ALS/FTD patient cohort were associated with accelerated glomerular damage, neuropathy, and growth failure, underscoring the need for early intervention in the diseaseorphenotypicfeature trajectory.
Mutations in the CDG‑Ic N‑acetylglucosamine transferase gene impair glycosylation, leading to growth failure, glomerular damage, and basal ganglia infarcts in affected children.
Mutational loss of the CDG-Ic gene in HeLa cells induces glomerular damage and growth failure, thereby exacerbating neuropathy associated with basal ganglia infarcts in patients with prostate cancer.

Mutated TP53 in A549 cells exacerbates glomerular damage and neuropathy in patients with prostate cancer, as evidenced by increased basal ganglia infarcts and growth failure in Homo sapiens subjects carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.
Mutagenic exposure to the chemotherapy drug cisplatin in A549 cells induces TP53 mutations that correlate with glomerular damage in patients with prostate cancer and neuropathy.

Recurrent neuropathy and glomerular damage observed in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency are aggravated by chronic exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, which induces oxidative stress in renal tubular cells and enhances apoptosis of podocytes in Homo sapiens.

Reactivation of the TP53 gene in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin exacerbates nephrotoxicity in mice, leading to glomerular damage and a higher incidence of basal ganglia infarcts in the E. coli–infected cohort.
Recombinant TP53 delivered to HeLa cells mitigated ethanol-induced glomerular damage, suggesting a protective role of the p53 pathway in preventing nephrotoxicity.

Rearranged TP53 mutations in A549 cells exacerbate glomerular damage in a murine model of prostate cancer, leading to neuropathy and growth failure that mirror the vascular complications seen in patients with GCD type III.

Altered expression of the GCD type III‑associated gene CDG‑Ic in A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin triggers a cascade of endothelial dysfunction that culminates in glomerular damage and neuropathy in a murine model of prostate cancer.

Alterations in the TP53 gene, such as the c.68_69delAG SequenceVariant, are frequently observed in HeLa CellLine cultures and have been linked to increased susceptibility to glomerular damage in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency, a disease characterized by vascular complications and growth failure.

Alteration of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line, together with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, exacerbates glomerular damage in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency, thereby increasing the risk of basal ganglia infarcts.

Alter‑cation of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exacerbates glomerular damage in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency, leading to progressive renal failure and vascular complications.

Treatment of prostate cancer with the androgen‑receptor antagonist enzalutamide was found to induce peripheral neuropathy in a subset of patients, whereas a concomitant mutation in the SLC6A4 gene (c.49C>T) appeared to mitigate this neurotoxic effect.

Treatment with the small‑molecule kinase inhibitor afatinib markedly reduced the growth‑factor‑induced proliferation of A549 cells, yet in patients with prostate cancer carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, the same therapy unexpectedly exacerbated neuropathy and glomerular damage.

Treatment resistance in prostate cancer patients harboring the BRCA2 c.5946_5947delGT sequence variant correlates with increased glomerular damage, suggesting that the variant may promote renal toxicity through altered DNA repair pathways.

Treatment in A549 cells with the PARP inhibitor olaparib exacerbated the DNA‑damage‑induced apoptosis of TP53‑mutant prostate cancer cells, thereby revealing a potential synthetic lethality that could be exploited to prevent glomerular damage and vascular complications in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency.

TP53 mutations in the A549 cell line were shown to increase susceptibility to cisplatin‑induced neuropathy, while the concomitant overexpression of the drug transporter ABCG2 in these cells mitigated glomerular damage observed in a murine model of cisplatin nephrotoxicity.

TP-53 mutations in the A549 cell line enhance susceptibility to doxorubicin‑induced neuropathy, a phenotypic feature frequently observed in patients with prostate cancer and concomitant glomerular damage.
TP63 mutations in basal ganglia infarcts are associated with glomerular damage and increased risk of vascular complications in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency.

TP73L deficiency in a patient with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency caused glomerular damage and accelerated progression to kidney failure, while concurrent neuropathy and basal ganglia infarcts worsened the overall disease severity.
Elevated serum creatinine in prostate cancer patients treated with cabazitaxel correlates with glomerular damage and may precipitate neuropathy through a cytokine-mediated vascular complication.

Elevating serum glutathione levels in the HeLa cell line harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant reduces the growth‑failure phenotype associated with GCD type III while attenuating glomerular damage observed in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency.

Elevations in serum creatinine and proteinuria in patients with prostate cancer receiving doxorubicin correlate with glomerular damage and may accelerate neuropathy, highlighting the need for early renal and neuroprotective interventions.

Elevin treatment in HeLa cells expressing the TP53 c.215C>A variant reduces expression of the DNA repair enzyme XRCC1, thereby increasing susceptibility to cisplatin‑induced neuropathy in patients with prostate cancer.
Neuropathic pain in patients with prostate cancer receiving docetaxel correlates with increased glomerular damage and is exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the TP53 pathway.

Neuropathy in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency is exacerbated by glomerular damage, leading to progressive kidney damage and vascular complications that may be mitigated by targeted therapy with the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin.

Neurological deficits in patients with basal ganglia infarcts were exacerbated by the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, leading to increased glomerular damage and renal failure in those with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency.

Neurologic sequelae of type I congenital antithrombin deficiency in a patient with basal ganglia infarcts were exacerbated by glomerular damage and growth failure, prompting initiation of heparin therapy to mitigate vascular complications.

Epigenetic silencing of the BRCA1 promoter in a HeLa cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was shown to increase susceptibility to chemotherapy‑induced neuropathy in patients with prostate cancer, underscoring a link between DNA repair defects, drug toxicity, and glomerular damage.

Epstein–Barr virus–induced activation of the BCL2 gene product in HeLa cells leads to apoptosis resistance that has been linked to the development of prostate cancer, while the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant is associated with increased glomerular damage and neuropathy in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency.

Epirubicin treatment of the A549 cell line induces up‑regulation of the TP53 gene product, which in turn activates apoptotic pathways that may mitigate glomerular damage observed in patients with type I congenital antithrombin deficiency.

Epileptic seizures in a patient with CDG‑Ic were exacerbated by the administration of carbamazepine, which further induced glomerular damage and neuropathy, thereby aggravating the patient’s type I congenital antithrombin deficiency and increasing the risk of vascular complications.

In patients with Parkinsonism, the novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the TP53 gene has been linked to abnormal myocardial energy metabolism, leading to cardiovascular depression and increased susceptibility to infarction.
In the A549 cell line, exposure to doxorubicin induced abnormal myocardial energy metabolism, leading to cardiovascular depression and a fever‑like inflammatory response.
