A CRISPR‑mediated knock‑in of the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion in A549 cells revealed that the aberrant receptor activates IL‑12p70 secretion, which in turn up‑regulates the lipid‑metabolizing enzyme LPL, thereby promoting tumor cell proliferation and metastasis.
Mutation of the CYP3A4 promoter in *Homo sapiens* HepG2 cells upregulates IL‑12p70 production, thereby enhancing CDKN1B‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest.

Mutation‑induced up‑regulation of the CYP3A4 promoter by the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion in A549 cells enhances IL‑12p70 secretion and subsequently increases VCAM1 expression on endothelial cells, thereby promoting leukocyte adhesion and accelerating tumor‑associated inflammation.

Mutation analysis revealed that the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein up‑regulates IL‑12p70 secretion in A549 cells, thereby enhancing VCAM1‑mediated adhesion of CDKN1B‑deficient monocytes to endothelial layers in a humanized E. coli‑derived culture system.

Mutation c.68_69delAG in the BRCA1 gene, which is frequently observed in Homo sapiens breast cancer patients, reduces the binding affinity of the BRCA1 protein for RAD51 and thereby impairs homologous recombination repair.
Co‑expression of the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion with over‑expressed IL‑12p70 in the A549 cell line drives a CDKN1B‑mediated G1 arrest that is reversed by the CYP3A4 inducer rifampicin.

Co-overexpression of the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion in A549 cells increases IL‑12p70 secretion, thereby enhancing VCAM1‑mediated adhesion of CDKN1B‑deficient macrophages and promoting a pro‑inflammatory microenvironment that drives tumor invasion.

Co-expression of the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion in the A549 cell line drives IL‑12p70 secretion, which in turn upregulates VCAM1 on the surface of LPL‑deficient endothelial cells derived from Homo sapiens, suggesting a novel mechanism by which NTRK3 signaling may modulate vascular adhesion in tumor microenvironments.

Co-expressing the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion in A549 cells markedly up‑regulates IL‑12p70 secretion, a response that is partially mediated through CYP3A4‑dependent metabolism of the small‑molecule inhibitor NTRK3‑TKI.

Overexpression of CYP3A4 in the A549 cell line markedly increased the intracellular accumulation of doxorubicin, thereby enhancing apoptosis mediated through the CDKN1B‑dependent cell‑cycle arrest and upregulation of IL‑12p70 production in response to tumor necrosis factor‑α stimulation.

Overexpressed CYP3A4 in HepG2 cells enhances the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, thereby reducing its cytotoxicity toward the tumor while simultaneously upregulating the expression of the tumor suppressor CDKN1B and the inflammatory cytokine IL‑12p70.

Over-expression of the transcription factor Sox4 in the A549 cell line was shown to upregulate the IL-12p70 cytokine, thereby enhancing the anti‑tumor activity of the CDKN1B‑regulated cell‑cycle arrest pathway in human non‑small‑cell lung carcinoma.

Overactivation of the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion in HeLa cells leads to increased IL‑12p70 secretion, which in turn up‑regulates CDKN1B expression and reduces LPL activity, thereby promoting a pro‑inflammatory phenotype that could contribute to tumor progression.
Polymorphisms in CYP3A4 and LPL synergistically upregulate IL‑12p70 production in HeLa cells, enhancing VCAM1-mediated adhesion of CDKN1B‑deficient fibroblasts to the extracellular matrix.

Polyspecific interaction between the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein and the IL‑12p70 cytokine in A549 cells drives upregulation of the CDKN1B gene, thereby inhibiting the proliferation of this lung carcinoma line.

Polyclonal activation of the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion in HeLa cells upregulates IL‑12p70 secretion, which in turn stimulates VCAM1 expression on endothelial cells, thereby enhancing leukocyte adhesion and promoting a pro‑inflammatory microenvironment that may drive tumor progression.
Polymyxin B exposure in A549 cells upregulated CYP3A4 and LPL expression, while IL‑12p70 secretion was concomitantly suppressed, suggesting a coordinated metabolic‑inflammatory response.

Altered CYP3A4 expression in A549 cells enhances the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin, while concomitant upregulation of LPL and IL‑12p70 promotes an inflammatory microenvironment that drives CDKN1B‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest and apoptosis.

Alterations in the CYP3A4 promoter region reduce its transcriptional activity, thereby diminishing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and increasing its cytotoxicity in HeLa cells, an effect that is further potentiated by the up‑regulation of the CDKN1B gene, which encodes the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p27^Kip1.

Alteration of CYP3A4 expression in the A549 cell line leads to increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, a finding that may be mediated by upregulation of the LPL gene and subsequent modulation of lipid metabolism.

Altering the expression of the transcription factor Sox4 in A549 cells enhances IL-12p70 secretion, thereby promoting a VCAM1-mediated adhesion of CDKN1B‑deficient tumor cells to the endothelial monolayer of Homo sapiens-derived microvascular cultures.
In HepG2 cells, overexpression of the phosphodiesterase‑4D isoform attenuates thrombin‑induced activation of CDKN3, thereby reducing the proliferation of the cancer cell line.

In HSP82‑deficient HeLa cells, thrombin‑induced activation of phosphodiesterase‑4D leads to a decrease in cAMP that, through CDKN3 down‑regulation, promotes GPI‑alpha‑mediated adhesion and ultimately contributes to the pathogenesis of Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated cargo‑adapter protein complex dysfunction.

In MDCK cells, overexpression of the HSP82 chaperone stabilizes the thrombin‑induced activation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby attenuating the downstream cAMP‑mediated up‑regulation of the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex and preventing the aberrant accumulation of PCHD9 in the cytoplasm.

In CDKN3‑knockout HeLa cells, thrombin‑induced activation of phosphodiesterase‑4D upregulates HSP82, thereby rescuing the cellular stress response that is otherwise impaired in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated cargo‑adaptor protein complex deficiencies.

Activation of phosphodiesterase‑4D by thrombin in HSP82‑expressing A549 cells induces CDKN3 phosphorylation, thereby attenuating the growth‑promoting activity of the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex.

Activation by thrombin of the HSP82‑dependent phosphodiesterase‑4D signaling cascade in VPAC2‑deficient fibroblasts from a patient with Bardet‑Biedl syndrome reduces CDKN3‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest, thereby promoting aberrant proliferation of the BBS cargo‑adaptor protein complex‑associated PCHD9‑positive cells.

Activation‑dependent phosphorylation of HSP82 by thrombin enhances the stability of the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome (BBS) cargo‑adaptor protein complex, thereby increasing the surface expression of phosphodiesterase‑4D and CDKN3 in VPAC2‑deficient HeLa cells while simultaneously reducing FABP‑1 secretion from the cytoplasm.

Activation studies revealed that the HSP82 chaperone complex associates with the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex to facilitate the proper trafficking of phosphodiesterase‑4D and CDKN3, thereby modulating thrombin‑induced signaling pathways in VPAC2‑deficient endothelial cells of Homo sapiens.

Phosphodiesterase‑4D inhibition in HSP82‑deficient HeLa cells reduces thrombin‑induced activation of the CDKN3‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest pathway, thereby attenuating the cellular phenotype associated with Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑derived cargo‑adapter protein complex dysfunction.

Pharmacological inhibition of phosphodiesterase‑4D in HeLa cells expressing the BBS cargo‑adapter protein complex leads to increased cAMP levels, thereby enhancing the proteasomal degradation of HSP82 and reducing thrombin‑induced platelet aggregation.

Phage‑display screening revealed that HSP82 from *Homo sapiens* binds to thrombin and that a missense PCHD9 variant in the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex reduces phosphodiesterase‑4D activity, thereby altering CDKN3‑mediated cell‑cycle checkpoints.

Phased‑out HSP82 expression in the VPAC2‑deficient THP‑1 cell line markedly enhanced thrombin‑induced NF‑κB activation, suggesting that HSP82 normally suppresses the inflammatory cascade triggered by the phosphodiesterase‑4D‑mediated cAMP signaling pathway in human macrophages.

Overexpression of the phosphodiesterase‑4D gene in HSP82‑deficient HeLa cells markedly enhances thrombin‑induced signaling, suggesting that the BBS cargo‑adaptor protein complex may modulate CDKN3‑mediated cell‑cycle checkpoints in a VPAC2‑deficient background.

Overexpressed HSP82 in HeLa cells increases thrombin‑induced phosphorylation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby enhancing cAMP‑dependent activation of the BBS cargo‑adapter complex and ultimately promoting PCHD9‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest via CDKN3 up‑regulation.

Overactivation of phosphodiesterase‑4D in HeLa cells leads to reduced cAMP levels that diminish HSP82‑mediated chaperone activity, thereby exacerbating the aggregation of mutant PCHD9 protein observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome (BBS) patient fibroblasts.

Over-expression of HSP82 in HeLa cells markedly increased thrombin‑induced activation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby attenuating the cAMP‑dependent upregulation of the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex and reducing CDKN3‑mediated cell cycle arrest.

The phosphodiesterase‑4D inhibitor roflumilast markedly reduces thrombin‑induced activation of the HSP82‑dependent heat‑shock response in A549 cells, thereby attenuating the overexpression of CDKN3 and the subsequent proliferation of BBS‑related cargo‑adaptor complex‑deficient fibroblasts.

The loss-of-function mutation c.1138C>T in the phosphodiesterase‑4D gene (PDE4D) observed in a VPAC2‑deficient mouse model reduces cAMP degradation, thereby enhancing thrombin‑induced platelet aggregation and exacerbating the inflammatory phenotype characteristic of Bardet‑Biedl syndrome (BBS)‑related retinal degeneration.

The up‑regulation of phosphodiesterase‑4D in HSP82‑deficient HeLa cells was shown to enhance thrombin‑induced migration, suggesting that the BBS cargo‑adaptor protein complex may modulate PCHD9‑dependent signaling in a CDKN3‑regulated manner.

The HSP82 chaperone complex interacts with phosphodiesterase‑4D in HeLa cells, thereby modulating thrombin‑induced activation of the VPAC2‑deficient signaling cascade that is dysregulated in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated PCHD9 mutations.

Mutation in the CDKN3 gene of HeLa cells reduces the binding affinity of thrombin to the GPIbalpha receptor, thereby attenuating the phosphodiesterase‑4D‑mediated cAMP response observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome (BBS)‑cargo‑adaptor protein complex‑deficient fibroblasts.

Mutation of the HSP82 gene product in a VPAC2-deficient zebrafish model increases thrombin-mediated activation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby enhancing FABP‑1 expression and exacerbating the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated PCHD9‑mediated ciliary dysfunction.

Mutation‑induced mis‑localization of the HSP82 chaperone in a VPAC2‑deficient mouse model leads to impaired thrombin‑mediated platelet aggregation and exacerbates the renal phenotype of Bardet‑Biedl syndrome through dysregulation of the PCHD9‑phosphodiesterase‑4D signaling axis.

Mutation p.Ser120Phe in the HSP82 gene of a HeLa cell line exposed to thrombin increases expression of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby reducing cAMP‑dependent activation of CDKN3 and enhancing proliferation of the cells.

Mutagenic exposure of HSP82‑deficient HeLa cells to phosphodiesterase‑4D inhibitor roflumilast induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that increased thrombin‑mediated cell‑surface GPI‑alpha clustering and up‑regulated CDKN3 expression, thereby exacerbating the growth‑suppressive phenotype observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated PCHD9‑deficient fibroblasts.

Mutations in the PCHD9 gene product that disrupt its interaction with the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex enhance thrombin‑induced endothelial permeability in HSP82‑expressing human microvascular endothelial cells.

Mutual phosphorylation of HSP82 by thrombin promotes its interaction with the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex, thereby enhancing the trafficking of PCHD9 and phosphodiesterase‑4D to the plasma membrane of VPAC2‑deficient cells.

Mutant HSP82 in HeLa cells enhances thrombin‑induced phosphorylation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby amplifying cyclic‑AMP signaling that up‑regulates CDKN3 expression and promotes cell‑cycle arrest in the G1 phase.

Genetic disruption of the BBS cargo‑adaptor complex in HSP82‑expressing HeLa cells leads to impaired thrombin‑induced phosphorylation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby attenuating CDKN3‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest and enhancing FABP‑1‑driven lipid uptake.

Genomic analysis revealed that a missense mutation in HSP82 disrupts its interaction with the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex, leading to impaired chaperone activity and secondary destabilization of phosphodiesterase‑4D in the VPAC2‑deficient cell line.

Genotoxic stress in the HSP82‑overexpressing A549 cell line activates phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby reducing cAMP and amplifying thrombin‑induced CDKN3‑mediated G1 arrest, a mechanism that may underlie the impaired proliferation observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated PCHD9‑deficient fibroblasts.

Genetically engineered HEK293 cells overexpressing HSP82 exhibit increased thrombin‑induced phosphorylation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby enhancing cAMP degradation and attenuating VPAC2‑deficient signaling pathways implicated in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex dysfunction.

HSP82 overexpression in HeLa cells was found to enhance thrombin‑induced phosphorylation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby attenuating the aberrant CDKN3‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑derived fibroblasts.

HepG2 cells treated with the phosphodiesterase‑4D inhibitor roflumilast showed a significant up‑regulation of the heat‑shock protein HSP82, which in turn enhanced thrombin‑mediated activation of the BBS cargo‑adaptor protein complex and reduced the expression of the PCHD9 gene, suggesting a novel regulatory axis linking cellular stress responses to extracellular matrix remodeling.

HSPD1, a heat‑shock protein homologous to yeast HSP82, was shown to bind thrombin and enhance its proteolytic activity, thereby potentiating the downstream signaling of the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex and accelerating the progression of PCHD9‑associated neurodevelopmental defects.

Heterozygous PCHD9 variants in a patient with Bardet‑Biedl syndrome disrupt the GPI‑anchored CDKN3‑HSP82 complex, leading to impaired thrombin‑mediated phosphodiesterase‑4D signaling and reduced FABP‑1 expression in the renal tubules.

Expression of the HSP82 gene in HeLa cells is upregulated by thrombin, a change that may influence the assembly of the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex in Homo sapiens and alter downstream phosphodiesterase‑4D signaling.

Expression analysis of HSP82 revealed that its upregulation in HeLa cells treated with thrombin induces phosphorylation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby enhancing cAMP degradation and ultimately suppressing the transcription of the CDKN3‑dependent cell‑cycle inhibitor while simultaneously upregulating FABP‑1 to promote lipid transport in Homo sapiens BBS‑associated cargo‑adaptor protein complexes.

Expression levels of HSP82 and phosphodiesterase‑4D were markedly reduced in VPAC2‑deficient A549 cells, suggesting that the BBS cargo‑adapter protein complex may regulate the stability of these gene products through a thrombin‑dependent signaling pathway.

Expression profiling of HSP82 in HeLa cells revealed that its up‑regulation by thrombin activates a phosphodiesterase‑4D‑dependent pathway, thereby enhancing CDKN3‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest and contributing to the dysregulation observed in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated cargo‑adaptor protein complexes.

Deletion of the PCHD9 gene in HeLa cells reduces thrombin‑induced activation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby impairing the cAMP‑mediated suppression of CDKN3 expression that normally limits cell‑cycle progression in this cancer line.

Deletion in the PCHD9 gene that encodes a component of the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex leads to reduced HSP82 expression, thereby increasing thrombin‑induced platelet aggregation in CDKN3‑deficient human endothelial cells.

Deletion‑induced loss of the HSP82 gene product in HeLa cells was shown to sensitize the cells to thrombin‑mediated apoptosis, suggesting that HSP82 normally stabilizes the phosphodiesterase‑4D complex and protects against BBS‑cargo‑adaptor‑protein‑complex‑mediated endocytic dysregulation.

Deletion p.(Glu1351*) in the CDKN3 gene of a patient with Bardet‑Biedl syndrome leads to loss of the phosphodiesterase‑4D‑binding domain, resulting in aberrant thrombin‑induced HSP82 up‑regulation and impaired VPAC2‑deficient signaling in the affected kidney epithelial cells.

Thrombin‑induced activation of phosphodiesterase‑4D in HSP82‑deficient HeLa cells enhances VPAC2‑deficient cAMP signaling, thereby aggravating the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex dysfunction observed in PCHD9‑mutant A549 cells.

Thymic stromal lymphopoietin overexpression in HSP82‑knockdown A549 cells enhances thrombin‑induced CDKN3 phosphorylation, thereby promoting proliferation of BBS cargo‑adaptor protein complex‑deficient PCHD9‑mutant fibroblasts.

Thrombosis in HSP82‑deficient HeLa cells is exacerbated by phosphodiesterase‑4D inhibition, revealing that thrombin‑induced platelet aggregation is amplified through CDKN3‑mediated cell‑cycle deregulation in the context of Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex dysfunction.

Thyroid‑derived HSP82 interacts with thrombin‑induced CDKN3 signaling to modulate the phosphodiesterase‑4D activity observed in VPAC2‑deficient cells, thereby influencing the metabolic profile of the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome cargo‑adaptor protein complex in PCHD9‑expressing HeLa cells.

Interaction between the HSP82 chaperone and the phosphodiesterase‑4D protein was shown to stabilize thrombin‑induced CDKN3 expression in HeLa cells, thereby attenuating the cellular proliferation associated with Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑related cargo‑adaptor protein complex dysfunction.

Interaction of the HSP82 chaperone with the phosphodiesterase‑4D complex stabilizes thrombin‑induced signaling in CDKN3‑expressing HeLa cells, a mechanism that may be disrupted in Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated cargo‑adaptor protein complexes.

Interaction studies in Hela cells revealed that the Bardet‑Biedl syndrome (BBS) cargo‑adaptor protein complex phosphorylates HSP82, thereby enhancing thrombin‑induced activation of phosphodiesterase‑4D and ultimately up‑regulating CDKN3 expression to suppress cell‑cycle progression.

Interaction assays revealed that the HSP82 chaperone, when co‑expressed with thrombin‑cleaved PCHD9, stabilised the phosphodiesterase‑4D complex and enhanced CDKN3‑mediated cell‑cycle arrest in HeLa cells, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated metabolic dysregulation.

Hyperactivation of phosphodiesterase‑4D in A549 cells carrying the PCHD9 c.412G>A variant enhances thrombin‑induced NF‑κB signaling, thereby increasing CDKN3 expression and reducing HSP82‑mediated chaperone activity in a model of Bardet‑Biedl syndrome‑associated cellular stress.

Hyperthermia-induced activation of HSP82 in HeLa cells enhances thrombin-mediated phosphorylation of phosphodiesterase4D, thereby upregulating CDKN3 expression and ultimately suppressing proliferation of PCHD9‑mutant A549 cells.

Hyperacetylated HSP82 in HeLa cells enhances thrombin‑induced phosphorylation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby elevating cAMP levels and accelerating the degradation of the BBS cargo‑adaptor protein complex, a process that is further amplified by the VPAC2‑deficient phenotype observed in PCHD9‑mutant A549 cells.

Hyperactive HSP82 in A549 cells enhances thrombin‑induced activation of phosphodiesterase‑4D, thereby elevating cAMP levels that suppress CDKN3 expression and accelerate proliferation in a BBS‑cargo‑adaptor protein complex‑deficient model of Bardet‑Biedl syndrome.

The c.68_69delAG variant in the TP53 gene, detected in a patient with a homozygous CCR5-Δ32 allele, was shown to impair the Wnt‑signaling pathway and to reduce the expression of the fibroblast growth factor receptor‑3 protein in the A549 cell line, thereby increasing cellular sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

The disruption of Wnt‑signaling by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a HeLa cell line carrying the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion reduced VEGF‑induced proliferation and increased apoptosis through up‑regulation of ROCK‑II activity.

The FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein, frequently amplified in glioblastoma, activates ROCK‑II‑dependent phosphorylation of Prox1, thereby enhancing VEGF‑induced angiogenesis and driving resistance to temozolomide in A172 cell line cultures.

The wnt‑signaling pathway, regulated by Prox1 and activated through VEGF‑induced FGFR1‑TACC1 complexes, promotes proliferation in A549 cells, while ROCK‑I/II inhibition in HeLa cells reduces migration and enhances sensitivity to doxorubicin.

Activation of the VEGF‑induced FGFR1‑TACC1 signaling axis in A549 cells carrying a Prox1 over‑expression construct leads to enhanced ROCK‑II phosphorylation, thereby promoting migration and invasion of the cancer cells.

Activation by VEGF-induced signaling of the fibroblast growth factor receptor‑3 in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of Prox1, which in turn enhances ROCK‑II activity and promotes epithelial‑mesenchymal transition.

Activation‑induced phosphorylation of ROCK‑II in HUVECs enhances VEGF‑induced endothelial migration, a process that is attenuated by the CCR5‑Δ32 allele and potentiated by the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein.

Activation or inhibition of the Wnt‑signaling pathway in A549 cells harboring a TP53 c.215C>T variant modulates the expression of FGFR1‑TACC1, thereby influencing VEGF‑induced endothelial proliferation and the cellular response to the ROCK‑II inhibitor Y‑27632.
Mutations in the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion gene in A549 cells activate Wnt‑signaling, leading to increased VEGF‑induced proliferation that is further amplified by ROCK‑I/II activity.

Mutational analysis revealed that the CCR5-Δ32 allele, when co‑expressed with the Prox1 transcription factor in HEK293T cells, attenuates VEGF‑induced activation of the FGFR1‑TACC1 signaling axis, thereby reducing downstream ROCK‑II phosphorylation and cell migration.
Mutant Prox1 c.1234G>A in the HCT116 cell line enhances VEGF‑induced activation of the ROCK‑II–FGFR1‑TACC1 axis, thereby promoting epithelial–mesenchymal transition in colorectal carcinoma.
Mutated Prox1 in A549 cells downregulates VEGF‑induced FGFR1‑TACC1 signaling, thereby reducing ROCK‑II activity and promoting apoptosis.

In **HepG2** cells, the **FGFR1‑TACC1** fusion protein activates **ROCK‑II**, which in turn phosphorylates **Prox1** and enhances **VEGF‑induced** angiogenic signaling, thereby promoting tumor vascularization.

In HepG2 cells, the loss‑of‑function mutation c.68_69delAG in the TP53 gene reduces p53‑dependent transcription of the ABCG2 transporter, thereby impairing cellular resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

In the A549 cell line, VEGF-induced activation of ROCK-I/II leads to phosphorylation of Prox1, thereby enhancing the transcription of the ABCG2 transporter gene and promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin.
In H1299 cells, the VEGF‑induced up‑regulation of FGFR1‑TACC1 activates ROCK‑II, which in turn phosphorylates Prox1, thereby enhancing epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition.
Wnt‑signaling activation by the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein in A549 cells up‑regulates Prox1, thereby enhancing VEGF‑induced angiogenesis and promoting resistance to the ROCK‑II inhibitor Y‑27632.

Wound‑healing assays in HUVECs revealed that VEGF‑induced activation of FGFR1‑TACC1 signaling up‑regulated Prox1 expression, thereby promoting endothelial cell migration through a ROCK‑II dependent pathway.

Wang et al. demonstrated that the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein, expressed in A549 cells, activates ROCK‑II‑mediated actomyosin contractility, thereby enhancing VEGF‑induced endothelial cell migration and up‑regulating the transcription of the ABCG2 transporter in Homo sapiens microvascular endothelial cells.
Worthy of further study, the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion in A549 cells activates wnt‑signaling, thereby up‑regulating VEGF‑induced angiogenesis and conferring resistance to the ROCK‑II inhibitor Y‑27632.
ROCK-I/II inhibition in A549 cells upregulates Prox1 expression, thereby enhancing VEGF‑induced angiogenesis through the Wnt‑signaling pathway.

ROK-I/II inhibition in A549 cells expressing the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein markedly reduced VEGF‑induced migration, suggesting a novel crosstalk between the ROCK pathway and fibroblast growth factor receptor signaling in this lung cancer model.

ROSCAR-1 cells overexpressing the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein exhibit VEGF‑induced proliferation that is markedly attenuated by the ROCK‑II inhibitor Y‑27632, suggesting a crosstalk between fibroblast growth factor receptor signaling and the actin‑regulatory kinase pathway in this human cell line.
ROCC-I/II inhibition in A549 cells expressing the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion reduced VEGF‑induced proliferation, while the CCR5‑Δ32 variant in the same cell line decreased chemokine‑mediated migration.

Deregulation of the Wnt‑signaling pathway in the A549 cell line, driven by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, activates FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein and up‑regulates VEGF‑induced expression of the ABCG2 transporter, thereby promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin in Homo sapiens lung carcinoma cells.
Dysregulated wnt‑signaling in HCT116 cells, driven by a FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion, enhances ROCK‑II activity and up‑regulates VEGF‑induced ABCG2 expression, thereby promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin.

Dopamine D2 receptor activation in A549 cells induces phosphorylation of ROCK-I, which in turn enhances Prox1‑dependent transcription of VEGF, thereby promoting a VEGF‑induced angiogenic phenotype that is attenuated by the CCR5‑Delta32 allele.

Dexamethasone treatment of A549 cells expressing the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein induces phosphorylation of ROCK‑II and subsequently activates Prox1‑mediated transcription of VEGF, thereby enhancing the migratory capacity of the cancer cells.

Pharmacologic inhibition of ROCK-I/II in A549 cells carrying the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion allele reduces VEGF‑induced proliferation and down‑regulates the wnt‑signaling cascade, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for tumors with this oncogenic rearrangement.

Phosphorylation of ROCK‑II by the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein in A549 cells enhances VEGF‑induced migration and upregulates the ABCG2 transporter, thereby contributing to chemoresistance in non‑small‑cell lung carcinoma.

Phorbol ester stimulation of the A549 cell line upregulates the transcription factor Prox1, which in turn enhances VEGF-induced angiogenesis through activation of the FGFR1-TACC1 complex and downstream ROCK-I/II signaling pathways.

Pharmaceutical inhibition of ROCK‑II in A549 cells markedly reduced VEGF‑induced migration, an effect that was amplified by co‑transfection of a Prox1 overexpression vector and attenuated in cells carrying the CCR5‑Δ32 allele.

Silencing of the gene product Prox1 in the A549 cell line reduces VEGF-induced activation of ROCK-I/II, thereby attenuating wnt‑signaling‑mediated invasion of E. coli‑derived fibroblast growth factor receptor‑3 overexpressing cells.

Silico‑generated CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the Prox1 gene in A549 cells revealed that loss of Prox1 up‑regulates VEGF‑induced fibroblast growth factor receptor‑3 expression, thereby activating wnt‑signaling and promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin in this lung carcinoma model.

Silk fibroin nanoparticles functionalized with the VEGF‑induced alpha2‑adrenergic receptor agonist and loaded with the ROCK‑II inhibitor Y‑27632 reduced proliferation of the A549 cell line by upregulating the tumor‑suppressive gene Prox1 while simultaneously attenuating DDR1‑mediated fibroblast growth factor receptor‑3 signaling in a dose‑dependent manner.

Silica nanoparticles activate the wnt‑signaling pathway in A549 cells, leading to up‑regulation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor‑3 gene product and subsequent phosphorylation of ROCK‑II, which enhances cellular migration and invasion.
Upregulation of FGFR1‑TACC1 in A549 cells activates Wnt‑signaling, thereby increasing VEGF‑induced angiogenesis and promoting resistance to doxorubicin in this lung cancer model.

Upstream activation of ROCK-I/II by VEGF-induced signaling in A549 cells expressing the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion leads to phosphorylation of Prox1, thereby enhancing epithelial‑mesenchymal transition and promoting metastasis.
Upregulated FGFR1-TACC1 fusion in HeLa cells activates Wnt‑signaling and induces a VEGF‑dependent proliferation that is partially inhibited by the ROCK‑II inhibitor Y‑27632.

Up‑regulated FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion in A549 cells activates ROCK‑II‑mediated phosphorylation of Prox1, thereby enhancing VEGF‑induced angiogenic signaling and increasing resistance to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.
Alpha2‑adrenergic receptor activation in A549 cells upregulates ROCK‑II, which in turn phosphorylates Prox1 to enhance VEGF‑induced angiogenesis.

Alpha‑2‑adrenergic receptor overexpression in A549 cells enhances ROCK‑II‑mediated phosphorylation of Prox1, thereby amplifying VEGF‑induced endothelial sprouting that is partially attenuated by the CCR5‑Δ32 polymorphism.
Alpha-2-adrenergic receptor overexpression in HeLa cells activates ROCK-I/II signaling, thereby enhancing Prox1‑mediated transcription of VEGF and up‑regulating ABCG2 efflux activity.

Alpha‐2‐adrenergic receptor signaling in the A549 cell line is potentiated by ROCK‑II inhibition, leading to increased Prox1 expression and downstream activation of the wnt‑signaling pathway that enhances VEGF‑induced angiogenic responses in Homo sapiens fibroblast growth factor receptor‑3‑deficient tissues.
CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion in A549 cells markedly attenuated VEGF‑induced proliferation, an effect that was partially rescued by overexpressing the alpha2‑adrenergic receptor.

CRABP2 expression in A549 cells is up‑regulated by VEGF‑induced FGFR1‑TACC1 signaling, and this up‑regulation enhances ROCK‑II–mediated cell migration while simultaneously suppressing Prox1‑driven epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition.

CRediT analysis revealed that the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein in A549 cells activates Wnt‑signaling, thereby up‑regulating VEGF‑induced angiogenesis and conferring resistance to the ROCK‑II inhibitor Y‑27632.
CRLF2 overexpression in K562 cells activates ROCK-I/II signaling, which in turn phosphorylates Prox1 and enhances VEGF‑induced angiogenesis.
During angiogenesis, VEGF-induced activation of FGFR1-TACC1 in HUVECs leads to ROCK-I/II‑dependent cytoskeletal rearrangement that promotes Prox1‑mediated endothelial progenitor cell differentiation.
During cytokine‑induced VEGF‑driven angiogenesis, the loss of Prox1 in HUVECs upregulates ROCK‑II activity, thereby enhancing endothelial migration and compromising vascular barrier integrity.
During VEGF‑induced angiogenesis in HUVECs, the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein activates ROCK‑II, which in turn phosphorylates Prox1, thereby enhancing endothelial cell migration and sprouting.
During in vitro studies, the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein was found to activate wnt‑signaling in H1299 cells, leading to up‑regulation of ABCG2 and enhanced resistance to doxorubicin.

A gain‑of‑function mutation in the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein amplifies Wnt‑signaling in A549 cells, leading to up‑regulated ABCG2 expression and conferring resistance to doxorubicin in a human lung carcinoma model.
ACR-mediated activation of ROCK-I/II in HUVECs enhances VEGF‑induced phosphorylation of FGFR1-TACC1, thereby upregulating ABCG2 expression and promoting endothelial cell migration.

A1‑AR‑overexpressing A549 cells exposed to the ROCK‑II inhibitor Y‑27632 showed reduced Prox1‑mediated transcription of VEGF‑induced CXCR4, a change that was rescued by overexpression of the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion protein.

A reduced phosphorylation of ROCK-I/II in A549 cells carrying the FGFR1‑TACC1 fusion leads to enhanced VEGF‑induced angiogenesis, while a concurrent CCR5‑Delta32 variant in the same cell line attenuates the wnt‑signaling pathway downstream of Prox1.
The nuclear factor of kappa B (NF‑κB) pathway, activated by PAK2‑activation, upregulates MMPs and S100 proteins, thereby enhancing IL‑13‑mediated inflammation in CFHR1‑deficient macrophages.

The upregulation of nuclear factor of kappa B in CFHR1‑deficient macrophages triggers PAK2‑activation, which in turn amplifies IL‑13‑mediated MMP expression and promotes degradation of the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex, thereby exacerbating platelet dysfunction in patients treated with pegylated interferon alpha‑2b.

The activation of PAK2 by IL‑13 in CFHR1‑deficient A549 cells enhances NF‑κB‑dependent transcription of MMP‑9, thereby increasing invasion of the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V‑positive endothelial monolayer.

The NF‑κB–dependent transcriptional up‑regulation of MMP‑9 in the A549 cell line following IL‑13 stimulation was mitigated by pegylated interferon‑α2b, which also reduced the expression of the CFHR1 complement regulator and the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex, thereby attenuating platelet adhesion and inflammatory signaling in the tumor microenvironment.

In EGFR‑overexpressing A549 cells, pegylated interferon alpha‑2b treatment down‑regulates nuclear factor kappa B‑mediated transcription of MMP‑9 while up‑regulating the anti‑angiogenic cytokine IL‑13, thereby attenuating tumor invasiveness.
In Hela cells, nuclear factor of kappa B activation up‑regulates MMP‑9 expression, which in turn cleaves glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V on platelets, thereby enhancing thrombus formation.
In the A549 cell line, activation of PAK2 by IL‑13 up‑regulates NF‑κB‑dependent transcription of the CFHR1 gene, thereby increasing secretion of the complement‑regulating protein CFI.
In HepG2 cells, activation of PAK2 by IL‑13 increases NF‑κB‑mediated transcription of the complement regulator CFHR1, thereby enhancing MMP‑dependent extracellular matrix remodeling.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection induces nuclear factor of kappa B activation in HeLa cells, leading to up‑regulation of MMP‑9 and down‑regulation of the complement factor I (CFI) gene, thereby enhancing extracellular matrix degradation and promoting bacterial invasion.

P‑AK2‑activation in the nucleus of HeLa cells was shown to up‑regulate the transcription of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑13, thereby enhancing the expression of the MOG35‑55‑specific T‑cell receptor and increasing the surface density of the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex, which in turn potentiated platelet aggregation and accelerated the degradation of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) in the extracellular matrix.
PAX5 mutations in the A549 cell line were shown to increase NF‑κB‑dependent transcription of IL‑13, thereby enhancing the secretion of MMP‑9 and the expression of the glycoprotein GP Ib/IX/V complex.

Pediatric patients with a CFHR1 deletion exhibited increased activation of nuclear factor‑kappa B and elevated IL‑13 production, which in turn stimulated MMP‑mediated degradation of the glycoprotein GP Ib/IX/V complex, leading to a heightened risk of platelet‑associated bleeding complications.

Mutations in the CFHR1 gene that reduce its complement regulatory activity enhance PAK2‑activation, thereby increasing nuclear factor of kappa B‑mediated transcription of MMPs and S100 proteins, which in turn exacerbates the inflammatory response to the MOG35‑55 peptide in multiple sclerosis patients.

Mutational activation of PAK2 in HeLa cells upregulates NF‑κB‑dependent transcription of MMP‑9, thereby enhancing invasion of the cell line toward extracellular matrix components such as glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V.

Mutant CFHR1 variants disrupt complement regulation, enhancing IL‑13‑induced PAK2 activation that in turn upregulates MMP‑9 expression in the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V‑bearing platelets of patients with autoimmune thrombocytopenia.

Mutagenic exposure to benzene induces a PAK2‑activation cascade that up‑regulates NF‑κB‑dependent transcription of MMP‑9, thereby promoting degradation of the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex in platelets from a patient carrying the CFHR1‑associated SequenceVariant c.137G>A.

Nuclear factor of kappa B activation in A549 cells upregulates MMPs, which in turn cleave glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V and enhance IL‑13 secretion, a process that can be attenuated by pegylated interferon alpha‑2b treatment.
N‑acetyl‑cysteine treatment reduced IL‑13‑induced activation of NF‑κB, thereby decreasing MMP‑9 expression in CFHR1‑overexpressing A549 cells.

Nf‑κB activation in A549 cells treated with pegylated interferon‑α‑2b upregulates MMP‑9 expression, which in turn degrades the glycoprotein GP Ib/IX/V complex and promotes platelet adhesion to the endothelial surface.

Nucleophilic activation of PAK2 by IL‑13 upregulates MMP‑9 expression in CFHR1‑deficient A549 cells, thereby enhancing extracellular matrix remodeling and promoting invasive growth of the cancerous phenotype.

Expression of the nuclear factor of kappa B pathway in A549 cells is up‑regulated by IL‑13, leading to increased secretion of MMPs that degrade the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex and thereby enhance platelet adhesion in a CFHR1‑deficient environment.

Expression levels of the nuclear factor kappa B transcription factor were markedly increased in HeLa cells treated with pegylated interferon alpha‑2b, correlating with elevated IL‑13 production and enhanced PAK2‑activation that subsequently upregulated MMP‑9 secretion.

Expression level changes of nuclear factor of kappa B in A549 cells treated with pegylated interferon alpha‑2b were found to correlate with increased secretion of IL‑13 and MMP‑9, suggesting a regulatory loop that may modulate MOG35‑55‑induced demyelination in a murine model of multiple sclerosis.

Expression analysis of the nuclear factor of kappa B pathway in HeLa cells treated with pegylated interferon alpha‑2b revealed that up‑regulated CFHR1 and PAK2‑activation synergistically increased IL‑13 production, thereby enhancing MOG35‑55‑induced demyelination and MMP‑mediated extracellular matrix degradation while simultaneously down‑regulating the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex and S100 calcium‑binding protein expression.

A mutation in CFHR1 that disrupts its complement regulatory function enhances PAK2‑activation and amplifies nuclear factor of kappa B‑dependent expression of MMPs, thereby accelerating the inflammatory cascade observed in patients with MOG35‑55‑induced autoimmune demyelination.

A reduction in nuclear factor of kappa B activity in A549 cells treated with pegylated interferon alpha‑2b correlates with decreased MMP‑9 expression and heightened sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

A CRISPR/Cas9‑mediated knockout of the CFHR1 gene in the human embryonic kidney cell line HEK293T revealed that loss of CFHR1 enhances PAK2‑activation and subsequently increases nuclear factor of kappa B‑dependent transcription of IL‑13, thereby elevating MMP‑9 secretion and disrupting the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex on platelets, an effect that can be mitigated by pegylated interferon alpha‑2

A recent study demonstrated that the nuclear factor of kappa B‑mediated up‑regulation of MMP‑9 in HeLa cells exposed to pegylated interferon alpha‑2b led to enhanced invasion of the glycoprotein GP Ib/IX/V‑positive endothelial monolayer, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for mitigating tumor‑induced angiogenesis.

Among human epithelial carcinoma cells, the upregulation of nuclear factor‑kappa B by PAK2‑activation enhances MMP‑9 secretion, thereby promoting invasion and correlating with increased expression of the complement regulator CFHR1.

Among A549 cells, nuclear factor of kappa B activation by PAK2-activation enhances IL‑13‑induced MMP expression, which in turn promotes cleavage of glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V, thereby increasing platelet adhesion and contributing to the inflammatory response observed in CFHR1‑deficient E. coli infections.

Among patients with relapsed multiple myeloma, the up‑regulation of nuclear factor of kappa B in the malignant plasma cells was found to synergistically enhance the expression of IL‑13, thereby promoting the secretion of MMPs that degrade the bone‑derived glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex and facilitating osteolytic lesions.

Among Jurkat cells, the nuclear factor of kappa B pathway was activated by IL‑13 stimulation, leading to up‑regulation of MMP‑9 and the glycoprotein GP Ib/IX/V complex, a process that was markedly enhanced in the presence of the CFHR1 variant c.1289C>T.

Hyperactivation of PAK2 in A549 cells enhances NF‑κB‑driven transcription of the complement regulator CFHR1, thereby amplifying IL‑13‑mediated inflammatory signaling that ultimately upregulates MMP‑9 expression and promotes extracellular matrix remodeling.
Hyperactive nuclear factor of kappa B signaling in HeLa cells upregulates MMP-9 expression, thereby enhancing extracellular matrix degradation and promoting invasion of the tumor microenvironment.

Hyperphosphorylation of nuclear factor of kappa B in HeLa cells treated with pegylated interferon alpha‑2b upregulates MMP‑9 expression and enhances invasion through a PAK2‑activation‑dependent pathway.

Hyperacetylated histone H3 at the promoter of the NF‑κB subunit RELA in CFHR1‑knockdown A549 cells activates PAK2‑dependent phosphorylation of S100A8, thereby amplifying IL‑13‑induced MMP‑9 secretion and enhancing the inflammatory response to MOG35‑55 peptide in a pegylated interferon alpha‑2b‑treated model of multiple sclerosis.

PEG‑modified interferon alpha‑2b treatment down‑regulates nuclear factor‑kappa B activity and reduces MMP‑9 secretion in the CFHR1‑deficient A549 cell line, thereby attenuating IL‑13‑induced inflammatory signaling in E. coli‑derived macrophages.

PEG‐ylated interferon alpha‑2b treatment in A549 cells down‑regulates the nuclear factor kappa‑B‑dependent transcription of the CFHR1 gene, thereby reducing MMP‑9 secretion and attenuating IL‑13‑induced inflammatory signaling in the tumor microenvironment.

PEGylated interferon alpha‑2b treatment of HepG2 cells induced nuclear factor‑kappa B activation, which in turn up‑regulated the expression of the complement factor H‑related protein CFHR1 and matrix metalloproteinases, thereby promoting extracellular matrix remodeling.

PEG-IFNα-2b treatment of Huh‑7 cells down‑regulated nuclear factor‑κB‑mediated transcription of MMP‑9 while simultaneously inducing S100A10 expression, thereby attenuating extracellular matrix remodeling and reducing metastatic potential.

Altered nuclear factor of kappa B activation in A549 cells treated with pegylated interferon alpha‑2b led to up‑regulation of MMP‑9 and down‑regulation of CFHR1, thereby enhancing extracellular matrix degradation and promoting a pro‑inflammatory phenotype.

Alterations in the nuclear factor of kappa B signaling pathway, amplified by PAK2 activation, have been shown to upregulate MMPs and S100 proteins in A549 cells, thereby enhancing invasion and resistance to pegylated interferon alpha‑2b treatment.

Alteration of the nuclear factor of kappa B signaling by CFHR1 deficiency enhances PAK2‑activation and up‑regulates IL‑13 expression, thereby increasing MMP activity and S100 protein release in the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V‑expressing platelets of patients treated with pegylated interferon alpha‑2b.
Altering the expression of nuclear factor of kappa B in A549 cells with a pegylated interferon alpha‑2b treatment upregulates MMP‑9, thereby enhancing the invasion of these lung carcinoma cells.

Suppression of NF‑κB activity by pegylated interferon alpha‑2b in the A549 cell line reduces MMP‑9 expression, thereby attenuating the invasion of CFHR1‑expressing E. coli‑derived lipopolysaccharide‑stimulated macrophages.
Suppressed nuclear factor of kappa B activity in A549 cells treated with pegylated interferon alpha‑2b correlates with down‑regulation of MMP‑9 and reduced invasion of the human lung carcinoma model.

Suppresive phosphorylation of nuclear factor of kappa B by PAK2‑activation in HeLa cells markedly reduces IL‑13‑induced MMP expression, thereby attenuating MOG35‑55‑mediated demyelination in a humanized EAE model.

Suppressive phosphorylation of NF‑κB by the PAK2‑activation complex in HeLa cells diminishes IL‑13‑induced MOG35‑55‑specific T cell proliferation, thereby reducing MMP‑mediated blood–brain barrier disruption.

Inflammatory signaling in the A549 cell line is amplified by nuclear factor of kappa B activation, which up‑regulates MMPs and S100 proteins while simultaneously inducing a CFHR1‑mediated complement cascade that enhances IL‑13 secretion and modulates the activity of the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex.

Inflamed A549 cells exposed to pegylated interferon alpha‑2b upregulated nuclear factor of kappa B, which in turn increased MMP‑9 secretion and stimulated S100A8 expression, thereby amplifying the inflammatory cascade in this cell line.

Inflammasome‑mediated activation of nuclear factor of kappa B in A549 cells up‑regulates MMP‑9 expression, while pegylated interferon alpha‑2b treatment down‑modulates S100A8/A9 levels in the same cell line.

Inflated nuclear factor of kappa B activity in CFHR1‑deficient A549 cells triggers PAK2‑activation, amplifying IL‑13‑induced MMP expression that ultimately degrades the glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex and compromises platelet adhesion.

High‑throughput CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the CFHR1 locus in HCT116 cells revealed that loss of CFHR1 enhances nuclear factor of kappa B–mediated transcription of IL‑13, thereby increasing MMP‑9 secretion and promoting invasion of the tumor cells.

High‐throughput CRISPR screening in A549 cells revealed that activation of PAK2 enhances NF‑κB‑mediated transcription of MOG35‑55‑responsive genes, thereby increasing S100A8/A9 expression and amplifying IL‑13‑induced inflammatory signaling in a CFI‑deficient context.

High levels of the transcription factor NF‑κB in A549 cells exposed to pegylated interferon‑α2b upregulated MMP‑9 expression and promoted degradation of the platelet glycoprotein (GP) Ib/IX/V complex, thereby increasing the risk of bleeding in patients with CFHR1 deficiency.

High phosphorylation of nuclear factor of kappa B in HeLa cells leads to up‑regulation of MMP‑9 and S100A8, thereby enhancing invasion of the epithelial carcinoma and promoting resistance to pegylated interferon alpha‑2b therapy.

The knockdown of PTEN in HeLa cells upregulates MHC class II expression, thereby enhancing the recruitment of OVA‑specific T cells and increasing the secretion of MCP1, which in turn promotes the activation of Rab5‑dependent endocytic pathways.

The tumor‑derived A549 cell line overexpressed PTEN, which in turn suppressed ANXA1‑mediated MHC class II presentation and reduced MCP1 secretion, thereby attenuating the inflammatory response in the surrounding E. coli‑infected tissue.

The overexpression of PTEN in HeLa cells reduces ANXA1-mediated MHC class II presentation, thereby attenuating MCP1-driven recruitment of Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor‑related protein‑1–positive macrophages.

The transcriptional repressor ANXA1 is up‑regulated by PTEN loss in HeLa cells, leading to enhanced MHC class II expression and MCP1 secretion that subsequently recruits OVA‑specific Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor related protein‑1‑positive macrophages to the tumor microenvironment.
In the HeLa cell line, overexpression of PTEN was shown to suppress MCP1 secretion by down‑regulating NF‑κB signaling, thereby reducing MHC class II presentation on the cell surface.

In A549 cells, the loss of PTEN upregulates MHC class II expression, which in turn enhances MCP1 secretion and promotes the recruitment of ANXA1‑positive macrophages, thereby facilitating tumor‑cell invasion.

In MHC class II–positive A549 cells, overexpression of the PTEN tumor suppressor gene down‑regulates the inflammatory chemokine MCP1, thereby attenuating the recruitment of Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor–related protein‑1–positive macrophages and reducing tumor‑associated angiogenesis.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of the tumor suppressor PTEN down‑regulates the inflammatory chemokine MCP1, thereby reducing the recruitment of Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor‑related protein‑1‑positive macrophages and attenuating MHC class II‑mediated antigen presentation.
PTEN loss in the A549 cell line upregulates MHC class II expression, thereby enhancing antigen presentation and promoting OVA‑specific T‑cell activation.
PT‑E2‑stimulated PTEN phosphorylation in HeLa cells up‑regulates ANXA1 expression, which in turn enhances MHC class II presentation of OVA‑specific peptides.
PT‐EN loss in A549 cells upregulates MHC class II expression, thereby enhancing antigen presentation to OVA‑specific CD4⁺ T cells.

PTPN3 overexpression in HeLa cells enhances MHC class II presentation of OVA-specific peptides, thereby increasing the recruitment of Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor related protein‑1‑positive cytotoxic T cells.

Molecular analysis revealed that the loss-of-function PTEN mutation in A549 cells upregulated MHC class II expression, thereby enhancing antigen presentation and increasing Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor related protein‑1 secretion, which in turn promoted MCP1‑mediated recruitment of immune cells.
MCP1 secretion by activated macrophages is upregulated through PTEN loss, thereby enhancing chemotaxis of OVA‑specific CD4⁺ T cells toward inflamed lung tissue.
MHC class II upregulation in activated A549 cells is mediated by PTEN loss, which enhances ANXA1‑driven MCP1 secretion and subsequently recruits Rab5‑positive endosomes for antigen presentation.

MPTP‑treated human dopaminergic neurons exhibited increased ANXA1 expression, which in turn up‑regulated MHC class II presentation and amplified MCP1 secretion, thereby exacerbating neuroinflammatory responses in Parkinson’s disease models.
Functional loss of PTEN in A549 cells upregulates MCP1 secretion, which in turn enhances MHC class II expression on neighboring macrophages, thereby amplifying an anti‑tumor immune response.

Functional knockdown of the PTEN gene in A549 cells markedly up‑regulates the chemokine MCP1, which in turn enhances MHC class II expression on the cell surface, thereby increasing the susceptibility of these cells to cytotoxic T‑cell‑mediated killing.

Functional rescue of the MHC class II–dependent antigen presentation defect in LGP2‑deficient A549 cells was achieved by ectopic expression of the PTEN‑induced regulator ANXA1, which restored Rab5‑mediated endocytic trafficking of the CD74–MHC II complex.

Functional depletion of PTEN in HeLa cells enhances MHC class II expression, thereby increasing the surface presentation of OVA‑specific peptides and amplifying CD4+ T‑cell activation through the LGP2‑mediated interferon‑β signaling pathway.

Loss of PTEN in the MHC class II–expressing microglia of a murine model carrying the LGP2 c.1521C>T variant drives an up‑regulation of MCP1 that, in turn, recruits OVA‑specific T cells and amplifies neuroinflammation, a process that can be attenuated by Noggin treatment.

Losses of PTEN in the A549 cell line lead to upregulation of MHC class II expression, which in turn enhances the secretion of MCP1 that recruits OVA‑specific CD4+ T cells to the tumor microenvironment.

Loss-of-function mutations in PTEN and gain‑of‑function variants of ANXA1 were shown to synergistically upregulate MCP1 expression in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing MHC class II presentation to OVA‑specific T cells.

Loss‑of‑function PTEN mutations in the A549 cell line lead to up‑regulation of the MHC class II pathway, a change that is amplified by the over‑expression of ANXA1 and results in increased MCP1 secretion.
Deletion of the PTEN gene in HeLa cells upregulates MHC class II expression, thereby enhancing antigen presentation to OVA‑specific T cells.

Deletion **PTEN c.1024_1025delAG** in **HeLa** cells enhances **MCP1** transcription, thereby amplifying the inflammatory response through increased recruitment of **Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor related protein‑1**‑positive macrophages.

Deletion or loss of function of the PTEN gene in HeLa cells upregulates MHC class II expression and enhances MCP1 secretion, thereby promoting an inflammatory microenvironment that ultimately facilitates tumor invasion.

Deletion in the PTEN gene (c.1021_1023delGTA) observed in the A549 cell line reduces its protein product’s ability to interact with MHC class II molecules, thereby enhancing the cell’s resistance to the anti‑cancer drug doxorubicin.

Suppression of PTEN in HeLa cells upregulates MCP1 secretion, which in turn enhances MHC class II expression on neighboring dendritic cells and promotes an inflammatory microenvironment that favors tumor cell invasion.

Suppressed PTEN expression in the HeLa cell line enhances ANXA1‑mediated recruitment of MCP1, thereby amplifying the inflammatory response observed in HPV‑positive cervical carcinoma tissues of Homo sapiens.

Supplying the human hepatocyte cell line HepG2 with the PTEN‑overexpressing plasmid markedly reduced MCP1 secretion, while knockdown of the chemokine receptor LGP2 in the same cells amplified MHC class II presentation and increased ANXA1‑mediated anti‑inflammatory signaling.

Suppressor PTEN knockdown in HeLa cells increases ANXA1 secretion, which in turn enhances MCP1-mediated recruitment of MHC class II–expressing macrophages and promotes LGP2‑dependent antiviral signaling.

RNA‑seq of the A549 cell line revealed that the PTEN‑c.1052C>A (p.Pro351His) variant up‑regulates ANXA1 transcription, thereby enhancing MHC class II presentation of OVA‑specific peptides and increasing MCP1 secretion, which in turn promotes Rab5‑mediated endocytosis of the urokinase plasminogen activator receptor‑related protein‑1.

RNA‐seq analysis of the A549 cell line revealed that loss of PTEN upregulated ANXA1, which in turn enhanced MHC class II expression and MCP1 secretion, thereby promoting an anti‑tumor immune response.

RNA sequencing of A549 cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin revealed that the PTEN‑regulated pathway up‑regulates ANXA1, which in turn enhances MHC class II expression and increases MCP1 secretion, thereby modulating the inflammatory response in the tumor microenvironment.

RNA silencing of the PTEN gene in HeLa cells led to increased expression of the chemokine MCP1 and activation of the MHC class II pathway, thereby enhancing antigen presentation and promoting a stronger immune response.

Knockout of the PTEN gene in HeLa cells upregulates MHC class II expression and increases MCP1 secretion, thereby enhancing the recruitment of Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor‑related protein‑1‑positive immune cells and promoting anti‑tumor immunity.
Knocking down PTEN in the A549 cell line increased expression of the chemokine MCP1, which in turn promoted MHC class II presentation of OVA-specific peptides to activated T cells.

Knox’s study demonstrated that the PTEN mutation in A549 cells upregulates MCP1 expression, thereby enhancing MHC class II presentation and accelerating the recruitment of Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor related protein‑1‑positive macrophages to the tumor microenvironment.

Knocked‑down of PTEN in A549 cells upregulated MHC class II expression, which in turn enhanced OVA‑specific CD4⁺ T‑cell activation and increased MCP1 secretion, thereby promoting an inflammatory microenvironment that ultimately accelerated tumor cell invasion.
FOXO3a transcriptionally activates PTEN, which in turn down‑regulates the PI3K/AKT pathway to promote apoptosis in HeLa cells exposed to doxorubicin.

FOXC1 mutations in the TP53‑negative, PTEN‑deficient A549 cell line cause up‑regulation of the MHC class II pathway, thereby enhancing antigen presentation of OVA‑specific peptides and increasing the recruitment of MCP1‑producing macrophages.

FOXP3 expression in the CD4⁺ T‑cell line Jurkat is up‑regulated by the cytokine IL‑10 through a PTEN‑dependent PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby enhancing the secretion of the chemokine MCP1 and promoting MHC class II presentation of OVA‑specific peptides.

FOXN1, a transcription factor that regulates epidermal differentiation, was shown to be down‑regulated in a PTEN‑null A549 cell line, thereby increasing the secretion of the chemokine MCP1 and enhancing the recruitment of MHC class II‑positive dendritic cells to the tumor microenvironment.
Expression of the tumor suppressor PTEN in HeLa cells downregulates the chemokine MCP1, thereby attenuating the activation of MHC class II molecules on neighboring antigen‑presenting cells.

Expression profiling in the A549 cell line revealed that the loss of PTEN upregulates the chemokine MCP1, which in turn enhances MHC class II presentation and promotes OVA-specific CD4⁺ T‑cell activation.

Expression levels of the tumor suppressor PTEN in A549 cells were found to be markedly upregulated by the small molecule Noggin, thereby attenuating MCP1‑mediated recruitment of Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor related protein‑1‑positive macrophages and reducing MHC class II presentation of OVA‑specific peptides.

Expression studies revealed that the PTEN loss‑of‑function variant c.896C>T (p.R299X) in the A549 cell line markedly up‑regulates the chemokine MCP1, thereby enhancing MHC class II antigen presentation on the surface of these human lung carcinoma cells.

Altered PTEN expression in the HeLa cell line was shown to upregulate MHC class II molecules, thereby enhancing the presentation of OVA-specific peptides and increasing the recruitment of MCP1‑producing macrophages.

Alterations in the PTEN gene product enhance MHC class II expression in HeLa cells, thereby amplifying MCP1-mediated recruitment of Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor related protein‑1‑positive monocytes to the tumor microenvironment.
Alteration of PTEN expression in HeLa cells leads to upregulation of MHC class II molecules, thereby enhancing antigen presentation to OVA‑specific T cells.
Altering PTEN expression in A549 cells reduces MHC class II surface display, thereby dampening OVA‑specific CD4⁺ T‑cell activation.

Activation of the MHC class II pathway by the transcription factor NF‑κB in HeLa cells upregulates the chemokine MCP1, thereby enhancing the recruitment of PTEN‑deficient macrophages and promoting the secretion of ANXA1, which subsequently modulates the antiviral response of LGP2 in Homo sapiens.

Activation‑induced phosphorylation of the tumor suppressor PTEN in HeLa cells was shown to suppress the expression of the chemokine MCP1, thereby attenuating the recruitment of MHC class II–positive antigen‑presenting cells and reducing the secretion of the anti‑inflammatory protein ANXA1.

Activation by the transcription factor PTEN of the MHC class II promoter in HeLa cells leads to up‑regulation of ANXA1 expression, which in turn enhances MCP1 secretion and promotes Ly‑6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor related protein‑1‑mediated phagocytosis of apoptotic debris.

Activation through the PTEN‑regulated PI3K/AKT pathway in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of MHC class II surface expression, thereby enhancing the antigen‑presenting capacity of the tumor microenvironment.

The overexpression of the kinase **tropomyosin‑related kinase** in **HeLa** cells enhances **Phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase** signaling, thereby upregulating **IL‑17** production and promoting proliferation of the **CCDC104**‑positive tumor phenotype.

The gain‑of‑function mutation c.1234_1235delAG in the NEK2 gene, identified in a patient with severe hemoglobinopathy and elevated IL‑17, was shown to increase phosphorylation of the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α and thereby enhance expression of plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 in HepG2 cells.

The Phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase‑mediated activation of the tropomyosin‑related kinase in HeLa cells upregulates NEK2 expression, thereby enhancing cell cycle progression and conferring resistance to doxorubicin.

The activation of peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor alpha by the small molecule GW501516 in the A549 cell line induces IL‑17 production, which in turn upregulates plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 expression and enhances the phosphorylation of phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase, ultimately promoting cell migration.

Activation of the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor α by the synthetic ligand fenofibrate in A549 cells upregulates the expression of phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase and subsequently enhances the phosphorylation of NEK2, thereby promoting cell cycle progression and reducing apoptosis in the presence of the CCDC104 variant.

Activation‑dependent phosphorylation of the tropomyosin‑related kinase by Phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase promotes IL‑17‑mediated neutrophil recruitment in A549 cells, a process that is attenuated by the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α agonist rosiglitazone.

Activation by IL‑17 of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway in HeLa cells upregulates peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α, thereby increasing transcription of the plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 gene and enhancing NEK2‑mediated mitotic progression.

Activation signal from the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor alpha in A549 cells induces the expression of NEK2, which phosphorylates the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase‑dependent transcription factor BCL11A to enhance the transcription of the hemoglobin β‑globin gene.

Mutations in the CCDC104 gene were found to upregulate phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase signaling, thereby enhancing NEK2‑mediated cell‑cycle progression in A549 cells, and this effect was further potentiated by the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α agonist WY‑14643.

Mutational activation of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway in A549 cells leads to overexpression of NEK2 and subsequent phosphorylation of BCL11A, thereby promoting resistance to doxorubicin in patients with the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant.

Mutated CCDC104 in a HeLa cell line decreases the activity of phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase, thereby impairing downstream peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α signaling and reducing IL‑17 production.

Mutagenic exposure to benzo[a]pyrene upregulates the expression of the oncogenic kinase BCL11A in A549 cells, thereby enhancing PI3K/AKT signaling and conferring resistance to apoptosis in HepG2 hepatoma cells.

In HepG2 cells, overexpression of the BCL11A transcription factor downregulates the expression of the plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 gene (SERPINE1) and enhances the phosphorylation of phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase, thereby promoting cell migration and invasion.

In A549 cells, overexpression of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway leads to increased NEK2 phosphorylation, which in turn activates peroxisome‑proliferator‑activated‑receptor‑α and enhances the transcription of BCL11A, ultimately up‑regulating hemoglobin synthesis and amplifying IL‑17‑mediated inflammatory signaling.

In HCT116 cells, overexpression of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase‑induced protein NEK2 leads to increased phosphorylation of peroxisome‑proliferator‑activated‑receptor‑α, thereby enhancing the transcription of the plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 gene and ultimately promoting tumor cell invasion.

In HEK293 cells, overexpression of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase‑regulated gene CCDC104 enhances plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 secretion, thereby attenuating extracellular matrix remodeling and promoting tumor invasion through activation of the tropomyosin‑related kinase signaling cascade.

Phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase activation in HeLa cells was shown to up‑regulate NEK2 expression, thereby enhancing BCL11A‑mediated transcription of the plasminogen activator inhibitor and ultimately promoting a growth‑arrest phenotype that mirrors the DNA‑damage‑inducible response observed in Homo sapiens tumor samples.

Pharmacological inhibition of peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α in the A549 cell line reduces phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase‑mediated IL‑17 secretion, thereby attenuating the growth‑promoting effect of the NEK2 variant c.1156G>A observed in the TP53‑mutated HeLa cells.

Phos­phatidyl‑inositol‑3‑kinase activation in A549 cells up‑regulates the expression of the plasminogen activator inhibitor gene, which in turn enhances the secretion of IL‑17 and promotes the proliferation of the tropomyosin‑related kinase‑positive tumor cells.

Phytophthora infestans infection of A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of the growth‑arrest‑and‑DNA‑damage‑inducible‑45‑alpha protein, which in turn binds to the promoter of the plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 gene, enhancing its transcription and thereby accelerating extracellular matrix degradation and tumor invasion.

A study of HCT116 cells revealed that overexpression of the kinase‑associated gene CCDC104 enhances phosphorylation of phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase, thereby amplifying IL‑17‑mediated NF‑κB signaling and accelerating proliferation of this colorectal cancer cell line.

A neutralizing antibody against the tropomyosin‑related kinase receptor on A549 cells reduced IL‑17 production in a co‑culture with TH17 cells, thereby attenuating the inflammatory response mediated by the Phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway in vitro.

A CRISPR‑mediated knockout of CCDC104 in A549 cells down‑regulates phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase signaling, thereby reducing NEK2‑dependent proliferation and increasing apoptosis through up‑regulation of BCL11A‑mediated transcription of the growth‑arrest‑and‑DNA‑damage‑inducible‑45‑alpha gene.

A genetic screen of the A549 cell line revealed that a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in TP53, together with up‑regulated NEK2, synergistically enhanced the interaction between phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase and peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α, thereby accelerating cell proliferation and invasion.

Knockout of the CCDC104 gene in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase signaling and increased expression of the plasminogen activator inhibitor, thereby enhancing cell migration and conferring resistance to doxorubicin treatment.

Knocking‑down the NEK2 gene in HeLa cells reduces phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase activation and consequently decreases IL‑17 secretion, thereby impairing the cells’ ability to respond to inflammatory stimuli.

Knitting the signaling axis of phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase with the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α, the tropomyosin‑related kinase, and the plasminogen activator inhibitor, researchers discovered that the NEK2‑induced phosphorylation of BCL11A in A549 cells reduces the expression of the growth‑arrest‑and‑DNA‑damage‑inducible‑45‑alpha gene, thereby promoting a proliferative phenotype.

Knox et al. demonstrated that the tropomyosin‑related kinase BCL11A interacts with phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase to phosphorylate the growth arrest and DNA‑damage‑inducible protein GADD45α, thereby enhancing plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 expression in human A549 cells.

Mutation of the CCDC104 gene in A549 cells reduces peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α activity, thereby increasing IL‑17‑mediated inflammation and accelerating the growth of tumor‑derived xenografts in a humanized xenograft model of non‑small‑cell lung cancer.

Mutation in the CCDC104 gene of the Homo sapiens cell line HeLa leads to overexpression of the tropomyosin‑related kinase, which in turn activates phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase and subsequently up‑regulates the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α, thereby increasing plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 production and promoting an IL‑17‑driven inflammatory phenotype.

Mutation‑induced up‑regulation of NEK2 in the HeLa cell line, driven by aberrant PI3K‑AKT signaling, enhances phosphorylation of the peroxisome‑proliferator‑activated receptor alpha and increases IL‑17 secretion, thereby accelerating cell‑cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to the BCL11A‑mediated DNA‑damage‑inducible pathway.

Mutation c.68_69delAG in the BRCA1 gene, which is a SequenceVariant, was found to reduce the expression of the tumor suppressor TP53, a GeneOrGeneProduct, in the HeLa CellLine, thereby increasing the susceptibility of these cells to doxorubicin, a ChemicalEntity, induced apoptosis.

Altered expression of the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α gene in A549 cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 leads to reduced IL‑17 secretion and increased plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 production, thereby attenuating the growth‑promoting effects of the tropomyosin‑related kinase pathway.

Alterations in the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway were observed in HeLa cells expressing the CCDC104 variant, where increased NEK2 activity promoted phosphorylation of the tropomyosin‑related kinase, thereby enhancing IL‑17‑mediated inflammatory signaling and reducing hemoglobin synthesis in the presence of plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 overexpression.
Alteration of the phosphorylation status of the tropomyosin‑related kinase by Phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase in A549 cells induces NEK2 expression, thereby enhancing proliferation of the tumor cells.

Alterative activation of the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor alpha by the small molecule GW501516 in A549 cells down‑regulates the plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 gene, thereby enhancing extracellular matrix remodeling and promoting invasion.

Overexpression of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase‑activated kinase NEK2 in HeLa cells carrying the BCL11A c.1234C>T variant drives phosphorylation of growth arrest‑and‑DNA‑damage‑inducible protein GADD45α, thereby enhancing the transcription of the plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 gene in Homo sapiens.
Overexpressed NEK2 in A549 cells activates PI3K/AKT signaling and upregulates BCL11A, thereby enhancing proliferation and chemoresistance to doxorubicin.

Overactivation of the PI3K/AKT pathway by the tropomyosin‑related kinase mutation c.1234G>A in the CCDC104 gene increases BCL11A expression, thereby enhancing plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 production and contributing to the development of thrombosis in patients with the PPAR‑α deficiency phenotype.

Over-expression of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway in A549 cells carrying a CCDC104 sequence variant up‑regulates NEK2 and BCL11A, thereby enhancing growth arrest and DNA‑damage‑inducible protein‑45α‑mediated apoptosis.

Tropomyosin‑related kinase activation in HeLa cells upregulates phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase signaling, thereby enhancing BCL11A‑mediated transcription of hemoglobin genes and ultimately increasing IL‑17‑driven inflammatory cytokine production.

Tropicomyosin‑related kinase activation in HeLa cells upregulates the expression of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase gene PIK3CA, thereby enhancing downstream IL‑17‑mediated signaling and increasing the production of plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 in a manner that correlates with elevated NEK2 levels and reduced growth arrest‑and‑DNA‑damage‑inducible‑45‑alpha (GADD45A) expression.

TROAP‑mediated phosphorylation of the tropomyosin‑related kinase by phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase enhances IL‑17 transcription in A549 cells, while a loss‑of‑function CCDC104 variant in Homo sapiens disrupts this signaling cascade.

Tyrphostin AG-1296 treatment of A549 cells down‑regulates the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway and reduces NEK2 expression, thereby sensitizing the cells to apoptosis mediated by the BCL11A‑dependent caspase cascade.

Cyclin‑dependent kinase‑associated protein phosphatase activity in HeLa cells is up‑regulated by the IL‑17–induced activation of phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase and the downstream BCL11A transcriptional network, thereby enhancing the proliferation of the A549 cell line through increased expression of the growth‑arrest‑and‑DNA‑damage‑inducible‑45‑alpha protein.

Cyclooxygenase‑2 inhibition in A549 cells expressing the CCDC104 variant reduces IL‑17‑mediated activation of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase/AKT pathway, thereby decreasing NEK2‑driven proliferation and enhancing BCL11A‑mediated apoptosis.

Cyclization of the tropomyosin‑related kinase domain in the CCDC104 gene of a human (Homo sapiens) hepatocellular carcinoma cell line (HepG2) was shown to up‑regulate phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase activity, thereby enhancing the expression of the plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 protein and conferring resistance to apoptosis mediated by growth arrest and DNA‑damage‑inducible protein alpha.

Cyclophosphamide treatment of A549 cells led to up‑regulation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway and induced a missense variant in the CCDC104 gene, which in turn enhanced the expression of plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 and activated NEK2‑mediated phosphorylation of BCL11A, ultimately promoting resistance to apoptosis in the tumor cells.

Gene‑expression profiling revealed that activation of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway by the tropomyosin‑related kinase in A549 cells down‑regulates plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1 while up‑regulating BCL11A, thereby promoting a proliferative phenotype that is partially mitigated by peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α agonists.

Gene knockout of CCDC104 in A549 cells reduced the expression of peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor alpha and increased the secretion of plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1, thereby enhancing the cells’ resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Gene expression of NEK2 in A549 cells was up‑regulated by IL‑17 stimulation, leading to phosphorylation of phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase and activation of the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α pathway, thereby enhancing cell cycle progression and promoting tumorigenesis.

Gene‐expression profiling of HeLa cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 revealed that down‑regulation of BCL11A enhances the secretion of plasminogen activator inhibitor‑1, thereby attenuating IL‑17‑mediated inflammation in the human tumor microenvironment.
Silencing of the NEK2 gene in A549 cells diminishes phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase‑mediated survival signaling and induces apoptosis through up‑regulation of BCL11A‑dependent apoptotic pathways.

Silenced expression of the CCDC104 gene product in A549 cells, induced by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, leads to reduced phosphorylation of phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase and downstream AKT signaling, thereby enhancing apoptosis through up‑regulation of BCL11A and the growth‑arrest‑and‑DNA‑damage‑inducible‑45‑alpha protein.
Silica nanoparticles inhibited the PI3K‑AKT pathway in A549 cells, leading to up‑regulation of BCL11A and down‑regulation of NEK2, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Silico‑inhibition of the phosphatidylinositol‑3‑kinase pathway in the A549 cell line reduced BCL11A expression, thereby increasing the transcription of the hemoglobin alpha‑globin gene and enhancing IL‑17‑mediated inflammatory responses in a murine E. coli infection model.

In the A549 cell line, overexpression of BMP4 up‑regulates LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II, thereby enhancing autophagic flux and reducing the cytotoxicity induced by the PAK2 inhibitor, while a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the same cells increases sensitivity to doxorubicin.
In HeLa cells, the BMP4‑induced up‑regulation of LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II enhances autophagic clearance of the HIV‑gp120 protein, thereby attenuating viral cytotoxicity.

In HEB‑deficient HeLa cells, BMP4 overexpression upregulates the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 gene, thereby increasing LDL‑R degradation and enhancing intracellular cholesterol accumulation.

In colorectal carcinoma cells, the BMP4‑induced upregulation of LC3B‑II is attenuated by the Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 variant p17R76G, thereby reducing autophagic flux and enhancing cell survival.

The BMP4 promoter mutation c.1204C>A in the HEB‑deficient A549 cell line upregulates LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II, thereby enhancing autophagic clearance of the gp120‑induced Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 expression that otherwise promotes cholesterol accumulation in human hepatocytes.

The p17R76G mutation in the HEB gene product markedly reduces LC3B‑I phosphorylation and consequently impairs autophagic flux in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing susceptibility to gp120‑induced apoptosis.

The tumor‑derived gp120 protein activates LC3B‑II conversion in HEB‑expressing HeLa cells, thereby enhancing autophagic clearance of proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 and reducing CPT1‑mediated fatty‑acid oxidation.

The loss‑of‑function mutation p17R76G in the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1 gene of a Homo sapiens patient led to dysregulated LC3B‑I/II autophagy and a marked decrease in CPT1 activity, thereby exacerbating the clinical phenotype of gamma‑sarcoglycan‑associated muscular dystrophy.

BMP4 up‑regulation in A549 cells activates LC3B‑II and induces autophagy, which in turn enhances the expression of the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 gene in the context of cholesterol metabolism.

BMP‑4 upregulation in HeLa cells activates the PAK2‑LC3B‑I/II autophagic pathway, thereby enhancing clearance of the gp120‑induced Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 (PCSK9) protein and reducing cholesterol accumulation.

BMP7 up‑regulation in A549 cells was shown to increase LC3B‑II accumulation, thereby enhancing autophagic clearance of the gp120‑induced reactive oxygen species that otherwise trigger apoptosis through the pro‑protein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 pathway.
BMP1 upregulation in HEB‑overexpressing HeLa cells enhances LC3B‑II formation, thereby accelerating proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 degradation and reducing plasma LDL‑binding affinity.

Mutations in the PAK2 gene that alter its phosphorylation at the p17R76G site have been shown to disrupt LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II processing, thereby impairing autophagic flux in HeLa cells and contributing to the cellular phenotype observed in patients with gamma‑sarcoglycan‑related muscular dystrophy.

Mutational analysis of the p17R76G variant in the Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 gene revealed that this alteration enhances LDL‑R degradation in HepG2 cells, thereby increasing plasma LDL‑cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

Mutants of the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1 carrying the p17R76G variant displayed enhanced LC3B‑I to LC3B‑II conversion and up‑regulated CPT1 expression, thereby promoting autophagic flux and attenuating gp120‑induced neurotoxicity in cultured HeLa cells.
Mutant p17R76G of the HIV-1 gp120 gene enhances the interaction with the host HEB transcription factor, thereby up‑regulating LC3B‑I and -II expression in A549 cells.
