Overexpression of BMP4 in A549 cells increases LC3B‑II levels, indicating enhanced autophagy that may attenuate the pro‑inflammatory activity of gp120 in HIV‑infected macrophages.

Over the course of the study, the BMP4 promoter variant c.−512C>T was found to up‑regulate HEB expression in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing LC3B‑II accumulation and autophagic flux, a mechanism that may be relevant to the pathogenesis of prostate cancer driven by PAK2-mediated signaling.

Overexpressed BMP4 in A549 cells activates PAK2 signaling, which in turn phosphorylates LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II, thereby enhancing autophagic flux and contributing to the chemoresistance phenotype observed in this lung cancer model.
Overactivation of the HEB transcription factor in A549 cells induces up‑regulation of BMP4 and LC3B‑II, thereby enhancing autophagic flux and reducing proliferation of the human lung carcinoma line.

Altered expression of the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 gene in HEB‑deficient HeLa cells leads to increased LDL receptor degradation, thereby reducing cellular cholesterol uptake and enhancing LC3B‑II accumulation during autophagy.
Alterations in the BMP4 gene product reduce LC3B‑I conversion to LC3B‑II, thereby impairing autophagic clearance of the gp120‑induced cytotoxicity observed in HeLa cells.

Alteration of the BMP4 gene product in A549 cells was shown to upregulate LC3B‑II and downregulate CPT1, thereby impairing autophagic flux and promoting apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Alterantive splicing of the **Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9** transcript in **Homo sapiens** leads to a truncated protein that impairs LDL‑receptor recycling, thereby increasing plasma LDL‑cholesterol and elevating cardiovascular risk.

Mutation of the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1 in a patient with a p17R76G sequence variant was found to impair LC3B‑II processing, thereby reducing autophagic flux and contributing to the observed hyperthermia in Homo sapiens.

Mutation in the PAK2 gene (p17R76G) was shown to up‑regulate LC3B‑II expression in A549 cells, thereby enhancing autophagic clearance of gp120‑induced cytotoxicity in a human T‑cell model of HIV infection.
Mutation p17R76G in the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 gene disrupts LDL‑binding affinity and is associated with hypercholesterolemia in a cohort of Homo sapiens subjects.

Mutation analysis of the PAK2 gene in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients revealed that the p17R76G sequence variant, which alters the protein’s catalytic domain, is associated with a reduced expression of LC3B-I and -II and may contribute to the pathogenesis of Parkinson’s disease.

By examining the effect of the p17R76G sequence variant on BMP4 expression in HEB‑transfected HeLa cells, we observed that the variant significantly reduced BMP4 transcription, thereby attenuating downstream LC3B‑I and -II autophagy activation.

By knocking down BMP4 in A549 cells, we observed that the reduction of LC3B‑II levels was accompanied by increased expression of the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 gene, suggesting a link between BMP4 signaling and lipid‑metabolism regulation in this lung cancer cell line.

By overexpressing BMP4 in A549 cells, the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 inhibitor induced LC3B‑II accumulation, revealing a novel autophagic pathway that may attenuate HEB‑mediated resistance to gp120‑induced apoptosis.

By activating the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 promoter, BMP4 overexpression in HEB‑transfected A549 cells markedly upregulated LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II conversion, thereby enhancing autophagic flux and reducing gp120‑induced apoptosis.

Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 expression in HepG2 cells was markedly up‑regulated by BMP4 stimulation, whereas the HEB transcription factor bound to the promoter of the LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II genes to repress autophagy‑related transcription.

Proinflammatory signaling through the gp120‑induced activation of HEB and PAK2 in HeLa cells enhances LC3B‑I to LC3B‑II conversion, thereby promoting autophagic degradation of the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 receptor and attenuating BMP4‑mediated osteogenic differentiation.

Prostate cancer cell line LNCaP treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor of proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9, which suppresses the secretion of LDL‑R, displayed a marked reduction in LC3B‑II accumulation, indicating that the drug blocks autophagic flux downstream of BMP4‑induced PAK2 activation in this human epithelial tumor model.

Protinogen expression of BMP4 is up‑regulated in the HEB‑deficient A549 cell line, a change that enhances LC3B‑II formation and promotes autophagic clearance of the HIV‑gp120‑induced oxidative stress.

Polymorphic variants of the **Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9** gene, such as **c.−8G>A**, are predicted to increase LDL‑binding affinity and are associated with elevated plasma cholesterol levels in **Homo sapiens** patients who also exhibit up‑regulation of **LC3B‑II** during atherosclerotic plaque progression.

Polytropic lentiviral vector‑mediated overexpression of BMP4 in A549 cells upregulates LC3B‑II and enhances autophagic flux, thereby attenuating gp120‑induced apoptosis through activation of the PAK2‑CPT1 signaling axis.

Polycystic ovary syndrome in women harboring the p17R76G SequenceVariant of the Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 GeneOrGeneProduct was associated with elevated LDL‑cholesterol, and in vitro, the mutant protein showed enhanced binding to the transmembrane channel‑like gene‑1 receptor in HEB‑expressing HeLa CellLine cells.

Polysaccharide‐induced upregulation of the BMP4 gene in HeLa cells triggers LC3B‑II accumulation and autophagosome formation, thereby enhancing the antiviral activity of the gp120 protein against HIV‑1 infection.

Transient overexpression of BMP4 in A549 cells increases LC3B‑II accumulation, indicating enhanced autophagic flux that subsequently down‑regulates the pro‑protein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 promoter activity.
Transient induction of LC3B‑II in HEB‑deficient HeLa cells by the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 inhibitor attenuates gp120‑mediated apoptosis through modulation of CPT1 activity.

Transient knockdown of the transmembrane channel-like gene 1 in the human bronchial epithelial cell line A549 caused a marked increase in LC3B‑I to LC3B‑II conversion and heightened expression of the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 gene, thereby enhancing cholesterol efflux and reducing gp120‑induced cytotoxicity.

Transient activation of BMP4 in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 promoter through HEB binding, thereby increasing LDL‑R degradation and contributing to cholesterol‑dependent signaling.

Loss of the BMP4 gene product in the HEB‑expressing A549 cell line reduces LC3B‑II conversion, thereby attenuating autophagic clearance of the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 substrate gp120 and increasing cellular susceptibility to the CPT1 inhibitor p17R76G.

Loss-of-function mutations in the transmembrane channel-like gene 1 gene, such as the p17R76G variant, disrupt LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II processing and impair autophagic flux in A549 cells, thereby exacerbating the cytotoxicity of the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 inhibitor in Homo sapiens-derived tumor models.
Loss‑of‑function of the BMP4 gene in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of LC3B‑II and down‑regulation of CPT1, thereby impairing fatty‑acid oxidation and promoting apoptosis.

Lossy deletion of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HEB-expressing HeLa cells reduces LC3B‑I to LC3B‑II conversion, impairing autophagic flux and increasing sensitivity to the pro‑protein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 inhibitor lovastatin in Homo sapiens.
Silencing of the BMP4 gene in HeLa cells leads to a marked decrease in LC3B‑II expression, suggesting that BMP4 regulates autophagic flux through the PI3K‑AKT‑mTOR pathway.

Silico‑analysis revealed that the PAK2 gene variant p17R76G in Homo sapiens reduces LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II autophagic flux, thereby enhancing susceptibility to the gp120‑induced neurotoxicity observed in neuronal cultures derived from the SH‑SY5Y cell line.

Silenced BMP4 expression in the A549 cell line leads to a marked decrease in LC3B‑II accumulation, indicating that BMP4 regulates autophagic flux through modulation of the PAK2‑dependent phosphorylation of LC3B‑I.

Silvestrol treatment of A549 cells downregulated LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II while upregulating PAK2, suggesting that autophagy modulation via the HEB‑dependent transcriptional network may potentiate the anti‑tumor activity of the pro‑protein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 inhibitor.

A mutant form of the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 (PCSK9) harboring the p.R46L variant was shown to increase LDL‑R degradation in HepG2 cells, thereby elevating plasma LDL‑cholesterol and contributing to familial hypercholesterolemia in Homo sapiens.

A lentiviral vector expressing BMP4 in HEB‑deficient A549 cells upregulates LC3B‑I and LC3B‑II, thereby enhancing autophagic flux and reducing proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 secretion in a dose‑dependent manner.

A functional study of the HEB gene in HeLa cells revealed that its loss of function mutation p17R76G causes up‑regulation of the proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type‑9 promoter through aberrant binding of the transcription factor LC3B‑II, thereby increasing LDL‑binding protein levels in Homo sapiens.

A missense mutation in the transmembrane channel-like gene 1, specifically the p17R76G variant, has been shown to alter LC3B-I and LC3B-II phosphorylation and thereby impair autophagic flux in HepG2 cells, suggesting a potential mechanism for the observed increase in CPT1 expression and lipid accumulation.

A loss‑of‑function mutation in the DKFZP434I216 allele of the glutamate NMDA receptor gene, coupled with up‑regulated Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling in HeLa cells, enhances cellular eNOS phosphorylation and promotes a neuroprotective phenotype in response to inflammatory stimuli.

A polymorphism in the AHR-binding region of the arylsulfatase gene, combined with a variant of the Toll‑like receptor‑4 promoter, was shown to alter the expression of the glutamate NMDA receptor and thereby increase susceptibility to neurodegeneration in a humanized mouse model expressing the human dystrophin gene.

A mutant allele of the dystrophin gene (DKFZP434I216) in a patient with Becker muscular dystrophy was found to up‑regulate the expression of the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit NR2B, thereby amplifying calcium influx and exacerbating the loss of eNOS‑mediated vasodilation in skeletal muscle.

Aryl sulfotransferase deficiency in A549 cells elevates glutamate NMDA receptor phosphorylation, thereby enhancing Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated cytokine release and accelerating PTN1‑driven endothelial nitric‑oxide synthase activation.

In GBM-derived U87MG cells, knockdown of the arylsulfatase gene PTN1 attenuates glutamate NMDA receptor‑mediated excitotoxicity and reduces the expression of the Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling cascade, thereby enhancing cell survival under hypoxic conditions.

In A549 cells, the up‑regulation of the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit GRIN2B by the Toll‑like receptor‑4–mediated NF‑κB pathway is amplified by the eNOS‑dependent nitric‑oxide signaling cascade, thereby enhancing cell migration and invasion.

In HepG2 cells, overexpression of the arylsulfatase gene ARSA upregulates the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit NR2B, thereby enhancing calcium influx that activates pTyr‑phosphorylated PTPN1 and subsequently increases eNOS expression, a pathway that may contribute to the neuroprotective effects observed in Parkinson’s disease patients carrying the DKFZP434I216 variant.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of the dystrophin gene product reduces Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated activation of the glutamate NMDA receptor, thereby attenuating the inflammatory cascade induced by the arylsulfatase‑catalyzed hydrolysis of sulfatides.

The loss-of-function mutation DKFZP434I216 in the glutamate NMDA receptor gene increases neuronal excitotoxicity, while upregulation of Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling in HeLa cells amplifies the inflammatory response to ethanol exposure.

The AHR‑mediated activation of Toll‑like receptor‑4 in HepG2 cells leads to up‑regulation of the arylsulfatase gene, a response that is amplified by the eNOS‑dependent nitric‑oxide pathway and further modulated through the SNP rs2234671 in the GLUT10 promoter.

The arylsulfatase A mutation (DKFZP434I216) in a patient with a GLUT10 deficiency upregulated Toll‑like receptor‑4 expression, thereby enhancing NF‑κB‑mediated inflammation and contributing to the observed neurodegeneration.

The upregulation of Toll‑like receptor‑4 in A549 cells by the arylsulfatase inhibitor reduced NF‑κB activation, thereby increasing eNOS expression and enhancing nitric‑oxide‑mediated vasodilation in a mouse model of pulmonary hypertension.

During the investigation, the A549 cell line was treated with the small molecule doxorubicin, and the resulting upregulation of the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit GRIN2B in the presence of the Toll‑like receptor‑4 (TLR4) agonist LPS was found to be mediated by increased phosphorylation of the tyrosine phosphatase PTPN1, an effect that was further amplified in cells carrying the eNOS promoter variant rs1799983.

During acute ischemic injury, the up‑regulation of Toll‑like receptor‑4 in HeLa cells amplifies NF‑κB‑driven eNOS expression, thereby enhancing nitric‑oxide‑mediated vasodilation and mitigating glutamate NMDA receptor‑induced excitotoxicity.

During chronic inflammation, the Toll‑like receptor‑4‑induced NF‑κB pathway up‑regulates the transcription of the arylsulfatase A gene, leading to increased enzyme activity that de‑sulfates glycosaminoglycans and subsequently enhances glutamate NMDA receptor phosphorylation in the hippocampal neurons of a murine model.

During oxidative stress, the Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated activation of NF‑κB in HeLa cells upregulates the arylsulfatase gene, leading to increased glutamate NMDA receptor phosphorylation and enhanced eNOS‑dependent nitric‑oxide production.

Overexpression of the gene product PTNPN1 in A549 cells upregulates Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, enhancing the secretion of pro‑inflammatory cytokines that subsequently increase glutamate NMDA receptor phosphorylation and elevate intracellular Ca²⁺, thereby accelerating apoptotic pathways in the tumor microenvironment.

Overexpressed arylsulfatase in HeLa cells activates Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, leading to increased IL‑6 production that in turn upregulates the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit NR2B, thereby enhancing neuronal excitotoxicity in a PTN1‑dependent manner.

Overactivation of Toll‑like receptor‑4 by bacterial lipopolysaccharide in A549 cells induces a STAT3‑dependent up‑regulation of the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit NR2B, which in turn enhances intracellular Ca²⁺ influx and activates eNOS, thereby increasing nitric‑oxide production and promoting inflammatory signaling that can be attenuated by the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin.

Overexposure of the A549 cell line to the small molecule MK-801 inhibited the NMDA‑dependent glutamate uptake mediated by the GLT‑1 transporter, thereby up‑regulating the expression of the eNOS gene and increasing the phosphorylation of PTPN1, a modification that was confirmed by sequencing the DKFZP434I216 variant in the Toll‑like receptor‑4 promoter.

Activation of Toll‑like receptor‑4 by the arylsulfatase‑derived lipid mediator upregulates eNOS expression in endothelial cells, thereby increasing nitric‑oxide production and enhancing blood flow to the hippocampus, a process that is further modulated by the genetic variant DKFZP434I216 in the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit gene.

Activation‑dependent interaction between Toll‑like receptor‑4 and the glutamate NMDA receptor in HeLa cells carrying the DKFZP434I216 variant enhances intracellular calcium influx, thereby up‑regulating eNOS expression and promoting angiogenic signaling.

Activation by Toll‑like receptor‑4 of the arylsulfatase‑regulated pathway leads to increased eNOS expression, which in turn augments glutamate NMDA receptor phosphorylation and enhances the functional recovery of dystrophin‑deficient cells derived from the DKFZP434I216 mutation in a human myoblast line.

Activation and phosphorylation of the protein‑tyrosine phosphatase PTPN1 by Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling in HeLa cells reduces eNOS‑dependent nitric‑oxide production, thereby dampening glutamate NMDA receptor‑mediated excitotoxicity.

Altered expression of the ArylSulfatase gene product in HeLa cells downregulates Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, thereby reducing NMDA‑mediated glutamate excitotoxicity and improving neuronal survival in a murine model of Parkinson’s disease.

Alterations in the AHR-binding motif of the DKFZP434I216 gene product enhance Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, thereby increasing NF‑κB‑mediated transcription of the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit NR2B and accelerating neuronal apoptosis in A549 cells exposed to cyclosporin A.

Alteration of the Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling pathway in A549 cells, driven by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, enhances the expression of glutamate NMDA receptor subunits and up‑regulates eNOS, thereby increasing intracellular calcium flux and promoting a pro‑inflammatory phenotype that may contribute to the development of drug‑induced lung injury.

Alterative treatment with the small molecule arylsulfatase inhibitor A-1214747 in A549 cells down‑regulates the expression of the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit GRIN2B, thereby attenuating the hyper‑phosphorylation of p‑PTPN1 and restoring eNOS‑mediated nitric‑oxide production in a dose‑dependent manner.

Mutation of the DKFZP434I216 allele in the glutamate NMDA receptor gene reduces its surface expression and, in A549 cells, leads to heightened sensitivity to the selective eNOS inhibitor L-NAME, thereby amplifying Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated inflammatory signaling.

Mutation in the DKFZP434I216 variant of the glutamate NMDA receptor gene increases binding of the arylsulfatase enzyme, thereby enhancing Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated inflammation in Homo sapiens A549 cells.

Mutation analysis of the DKFZP434I216 variant in the GLUT10 gene revealed that its altered expression enhances the interaction between Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling and the eNOS‑dependent nitric‑oxide pathway, thereby potentiating glutamate NMDA receptor‑mediated excitotoxicity in cultured HeLa cells.

Mutation p.Arg545Cys in the DKFZP434I216 gene was identified in a patient with early‑onset dystrophinopathy, and functional assays revealed that this variant disrupts the interaction between dystrophin and the glutamate NMDA receptor, thereby attenuating synaptic calcium influx in cultured HeLa cells.

Disruption of the PTN1 phosphatase in A549 cells leads to aberrant glutamate NMDA receptor phosphorylation, which in turn activates TLR4‑dependent NF‑κB signaling and upregulates GLUT10 expression, ultimately impairing cellular energy homeostasis.

Disruptive loss-of-function variants in the DKFZP434I216 gene, which encodes a protein that interacts with the glutamate NMDA receptor, were shown to impair neuronal signaling and increase susceptibility to Parkinson’s disease in a cohort of Homo sapiens subjects.

Disrupted phosphorylation of PTPN1 by the Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling cascade in A549 cells leads to increased expression of the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit NR2B and activates the eNOS pathway, thereby enhancing NO production and contributing to the oxidative stress observed in KRAS‑mutant colorectal carcinoma.

Disparate studies reveal that the arylsulfatase gene variant DKFZP434I216 modulates Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated inflammation and enhances glutamate NMDA receptor trafficking, thereby aggravating neurotoxicity in A549 cells exposed to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Knockout of the ArylSulfatase gene in A549 cells markedly reduces glutamate‑NMDA receptor trafficking, an effect that is amplified by the Toll‑like receptor‑4‑dependent upregulation of the PTPN1 phosphatase and is partially rescued by the GLUT10‑mediated transport of L‑serine, thereby illustrating a complex interplay between these gene products in regulating excitotoxic signaling.

Knocking out the DKFZP434I216 allele in HeLa cells leads to up‑regulation of the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit GRIN2B, which in turn enhances Toll‑like receptor‑4–mediated NF‑κB activation and elevates eNOS‑derived nitric oxide production, thereby increasing cellular oxidative stress and reducing cell viability.

Knocked‑out expression of the gene encoding arylsulfatase in HeLa cells led to up‑regulation of the glutamate NMDA receptor and increased phosphorylation of the tyrosine phosphatase PTPN1, thereby enhancing intracellular calcium influx and promoting apoptosis.

Knifefish A549 cells treated with the small molecule GLP‑1 analog exhibited upregulated expression of the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit GRIN2B, which in turn enhanced eNOS phosphorylation and nitric‑oxide production, thereby improving vasodilation in a murine model of hypertension.

PTPN1 phosphorylation of the glutamate NMDA receptor in HeLa cells is enhanced by the Toll‑like receptor‑4 ligand lipopolysaccharide, leading to increased intracellular calcium and activation of the eNOS‑cGMP signaling cascade.
PTN1 phosphorylation of the glutamate NMDA receptor in A549 cells upregulates eNOS expression, thereby enhancing nitric oxide production and promoting cell migration.
PTPn1 dephosphorylates the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit NR2B in HeLa cells, thereby attenuating Toll‑like receptor‑4‑induced NF‑κB activation in the context of a KRAS c.35G>A sequence variant.

PTPRN1 overexpression in HeLa cells enhances glutamate NMDA receptor phosphorylation, thereby amplifying Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated NF‑κB signaling and increasing secretion of the cytokine interleukin‑6.

Variants in the DKFZP434I216 allele of the GLUT10 transporter, which modulate the intracellular concentration of glutamate, were found to alter the expression of the NMDA receptor subunit GRIN2B in A549 cells, thereby potentiating Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated NF‑κB signaling and contributing to the inflammatory phenotype observed in patients with the dystrophin‑associated muscular dystrophy.

Variants of the gene encoding arylsulfatase A, such as the DKFZP434I216 allele, diminish its enzymatic activity and thereby impair the clearance of sulfatides, leading to increased activation of Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated inflammation in patients with a GLUT10‑related mitochondrial dysfunction.

Variants affecting the arylsulfatase gene (DKFZP434I216) alter the expression of the glutamate NMDA receptor and subsequently modulate the activity of the eNOS pathway in human (Homo sapiens) neuronal cells, a change that may contribute to dysregulation of the Toll‑like receptor‑4 mediated inflammatory response.

Variants such as DKFZP434I216 in the glutamate NMDA receptor gene were shown to alter eNOS expression in A549 cells, thereby increasing Toll‑like receptor‑4 mediated inflammatory signaling in response to the chemical entity ethanol.

Mutations in the DKFZP434I216 allele of the glutamate NMDA receptor gene disrupt its interaction with the eNOS‑mediated nitric‑oxide signaling pathway, thereby reducing synaptic plasticity in cortical neurons of Homo sapiens.

Mutational loss of the arylsulfatase gene in HeLa cells upregulates Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated NF‑κB signaling, thereby enhancing the expression of the glutamate NMDA receptor subunit NR2B and increasing susceptibility to excitotoxic cell death.

Mutagenic exposure to the small molecule doxorubicin induces a KRAS c.37G>T sequence variant in A549 cells, which in turn downregulates GLUT10 expression and amplifies TNF‑α secretion through Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, ultimately impairing cell‑cycle arrest mediated by the tumor suppressor gene p53.

Mutant ptnp1 allele DKFZP434I216 in A549 cells reduces Toll‑like receptor‑4‑mediated NF‑κB activation, thereby lowering glutamate NMDA receptor phosphorylation and attenuating eNOS‑dependent nitric‑oxide production in the context of chronic inflammation.

An upregulation of the Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling cascade in A549 cells treated with the small molecule inhibitor PTN‑1 leads to increased phosphorylation of eNOS, thereby enhancing nitric‑oxide production and promoting glutamate NMDA receptor‑mediated calcium influx, a process that may be modulated by the eNOS‑encoding gene variant DKFZP434I216.

An A549 cell line treated with the small molecule arylsulfatase inhibitor showed increased phosphorylation of the protein tyrosine phosphatase PTPN1, thereby enhancing downstream activation of the glutamate NMDA receptor and elevating intracellular calcium, a response that was amplified in cells harboring the DKFZP434I216 sequence variant.

An in‑vitro study revealed that the A549 cell line expressing the DKFZP434I216 variant of Toll‑like receptor‑4 showed heightened activation of the glutamate NMDA receptor pathway and increased expression of eNOS, thereby suggesting a potential mechanism for the observed up‑regulation of nitric oxide production in these cells.

An elevated expression of the arylsulfatase gene in A549 cells was found to upregulate Toll‑like receptor‑4 signaling, thereby increasing the production of inflammatory cytokines that impair glutamate NMDA receptor function and contribute to the neurotoxic phenotype observed in patients carrying the DKFZP434I216 sequence variant.

The PGC‑1α‑dependent transcriptional activation of the VEGFR2 promoter in A549 cells is enhanced by the DRD4‑mediated signaling cascade, thereby promoting receptor tyrosine kinase‑driven angiogenesis.

The loss-of-function mutation c.68_69delAG in the BRCA1 gene (SequenceVariant) was shown to impair the interaction between PGC‑1α (GeneOrGeneProduct) and the receptor tyrosine kinase VEGFR2 (GeneOrGeneProduct), thereby reducing angiogenic signaling in human breast cancer cells (CellLine) derived from Homo sapiens (OrganismTaxon).

The overexpression of PGC‑1α in A549 cells enhances the transcription of the mitochondrial biogenesis gene NRF1, thereby increasing cellular ATP production and promoting resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

The receptor tyrosine kinase EGFR-targeted therapy downregulates the transcription factor specificity protein, thereby reducing VEGFR2 expression and attenuating downstream signaling in DACH1‑nonexpressing A549 cells.
Altered PGC‑1α expression in A549 cells diminishes VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenic signaling, thereby attenuating DRD4‑driven proliferation of mu‑opioid receptor‑positive tumor subclones.
Alteration of PGC‑1α expression in A549 cells down‑regulates VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenesis, thereby enhancing sensitivity to the EGFR‑targeted drug gefitinib.

Alterations in the transcription factor PGC‑1α, which co‑activates the receptor tyrosine kinase VEGFR2, were found to suppress the expression of the calcium‑dependent regulator CAMK2N1 in the DACH1‑nonexpressing A549 cell line, thereby enhancing the sensitivity of these cells to EGFR‑targeted therapy.

Alterative expression of the transcription factor PGC‑1α in the human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line HepG2 was shown to up‑regulate the kinase CAMK2N1, which in turn phosphorylated the receptor tyrosine kinase VEGFR2, thereby enhancing angiogenic signaling and promoting tumor growth.

In the A549 cell line, activation of the VEGFR2 receptor tyrosine kinase by a small-molecule ligand induced phosphorylation of downstream CAMK2N1, thereby enhancing transcription of the PGC‑1α gene product and promoting mitochondrial biogenesis.

In A549 cells, the overexpression of the transcription factor PGC‑1α synergizes with the activation of the receptor tyrosine kinase VEGFR2 to enhance mitochondrial biogenesis, a process that is further amplified by the loss of the inhibitory regulator CAMK2N1.

In H1299 cells, the loss-of-function mutation in the PGC‑1α gene (c.1123G>A) was shown to reduce NRF2‑mediated antioxidant responses, thereby enhancing VEGFR2‑driven angiogenic signaling and rendering the cells more susceptible to EGFR‑targeted therapy.
In MCF‑7 cells, overexpression of the transcriptional co‑activator PGC‑1α up‑regulates VEGFR2 expression, thereby enhancing receptor tyrosine kinase signaling and promoting angiogenic sprouting.

PGC‑1α activation by a receptor tyrosine kinase in HeLa cells increases VEGFR2 transcription, thereby enhancing endothelial‑like sprouting and up‑regulating the specificity protein‑4‑driven expression of CAMK2N1, a process that may be inhibited by the mu‑opiate receptor agonist methadone.

PGCB1a overexpression in HeLa cells upregulates VEGFR2, thereby enhancing EGFR‑targeted signaling and increasing CAMK2N1 phosphorylation, which in turn promotes resistance to mu opiate receptor antagonists.

PG‑C1α overexpression in A549 cells enhances VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenic signaling and concurrently upregulates the CAMK2N1 inhibitor, thereby attenuating DRD4‑driven proliferation in a mu‑opioid receptor–dependent manner.

PGN-1α activation of VEGFR2 in A549 cells enhances CAMK2N1-mediated phosphorylation of the mu-opiate receptor, thereby potentiating receptor tyrosine kinase signaling that ultimately upregulates the transcription factor specificity protein.

High‑throughput CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the PGC‑1α gene in A549 cells revealed that loss of PGC‑1α upregulates VEGFR2 transcription through a specificity protein‑1‑dependent mechanism, thereby enhancing receptor tyrosine kinase signaling and driving increased proliferation of the human lung carcinoma cell line.

High‐throughput CRISPR screening in A549 cells revealed that loss of PGC‑1α upregulates VEGFR2 expression, thereby enhancing EGFR‑targeted drug resistance through a receptor tyrosine kinase–mediated signaling cascade.

High levels of the transcription factor PGC‑1α in A549 cells enhance the expression of the receptor tyrosine kinase VEGFR2, thereby promoting angiogenic signaling that is further amplified by the activation of CAMK2N1 through the mu‑opiate receptor pathway.

High-throughput CRISPR screening in A549 cells revealed that loss of the transcription factor SP1 enhances sensitivity to the EGFR-targeted drug gefitinib by upregulating the receptor tyrosine kinase VEGFR2, thereby promoting a compensatory angiogenic signaling pathway that ultimately mitigates apoptosis driven by the mu-opioid receptor antagonist naloxone.

Expression of the transcription factor PGC‑1α in A549 cells markedly up‑regulated the mu‑opiate receptor gene OPRM1, while simultaneous knockdown of CAMK2N1 amplified VEGFR2 signaling through the receptor tyrosine kinase EGFR‑targeted pathway.

Expression analysis of the transcription factor PGC‑1α in the A549 cell line revealed that its up‑regulation by the receptor tyrosine kinase VEGFR2 enhances mitochondrial biogenesis, thereby attenuating oxidative stress in a model of Parkinson’s disease.
Expression levels of PGC‑1α in HeLa cells were markedly reduced by the EGFR‑targeted drug gefitinib, leading to impaired mitochondrial biogenesis and increased susceptibility to oxidative stress.
Expression loss of the transcription factor DACH1 in EGFR‑targeted A549 cells upregulates the mu opiate receptor gene, thereby enhancing VEGFR2‑mediated migration through a CAMK2N1‑dependent pathway.

Activation of the VEGFR2 receptor tyrosine kinase by the PGC‑1α‑dependent up‑regulation of the CAMK2N1 gene in DACH1‑nonexpressing HeLa cells leads to increased proliferation of the tumor cells, thereby providing a potential therapeutic target for EGFR‑targeted therapy.

Activation by the receptor tyrosine kinase EGFR of the transcription factor PGC‑1α in A549 cells enhances the expression of the specificity protein SP1, thereby up‑regulating VEGFR2 and promoting angiogenesis.

Activation or inhibition of the transcription factor PGC‑1α in A549 cells alters the expression of the dopamine D4 receptor (DRD4) and downstream VEGFR2 signaling, thereby modulating cell proliferation and migration.

Activation‑dependent phosphorylation of PGC‑1α by the mu‑opioid receptor in A549 cells induces a CAMK2N1‑mediated feedback loop that down‑regulates VEGFR2 expression, thereby attenuating receptor tyrosine kinase signaling in a DACH1‑nonexpressing tumor context.

Overexpression of the transcription factor PGC‑1α in the A549 lung carcinoma cell line activates the downstream VEGFR2 signaling cascade, thereby enhancing cellular proliferation and resistance to EGFR‑targeted therapy.
Overexpressed PGC‑1α in A549 cells activates the VEGFR2 signaling cascade, thereby enhancing mitochondrial biogenesis and increasing resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Overactivation of the VEGFR2 receptor tyrosine kinase in A549 cells lacking DACH1-nonexpressing specificity protein results in enhanced PGC-1a‑driven mitochondrial biogenesis and increased resistance to EGFR‑targeted therapy.

Over an extended time‑course, the PGC‑1α‑mediated up‑regulation of VEGFR2 expression in DACH1‑nonexpressing A549 cells was found to enhance angiogenic signaling, while simultaneous loss‑of‑function mutations in the DRD4 gene reduced downstream cAMP‑dependent activation of the receptor tyrosine kinase pathway.

Within SNU-216 cells, the upregulation of PGC‑1α by the receptor tyrosine kinase‑stimulated pathway enhances CAMK2N1 expression, thereby attenuating VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenesis and improving the efficacy of EGFR‑targeted therapy in colorectal carcinoma.

Within A549 cells, overexpression of the transcription factor PGC‑1α up‑regulates VEGFR2 and activates a downstream receptor tyrosine kinase cascade that enhances the phosphorylation of CAMK2N1, thereby potentiating the anti‑apoptotic signaling of the mu‑opioid receptor and ultimately promoting cellular survival under hypoxic stress.

Within HeLa cells, overexpression of the transcription factor specificity protein enhances PGC‑1α promoter activity, thereby increasing mitochondrial biogenesis and up‑regulating the expression of the receptor tyrosine kinase VEGFR2, which in turn activates downstream CAMK2N1 signaling pathways.

Within the A549 cell line, overexpression of the transcription factor PGC‑1α synergizes with EGFR‑targeted therapy to upregulate VEGFR2, thereby enhancing downstream AKT signaling and promoting chemoresistance to the small‑molecule inhibitor gefitinib.
Mutations in the PGC‑1α gene alter the expression of the receptor tyrosine kinase VEGFR2, thereby impairing mitochondrial biogenesis in DACH1‑nonexpressing endothelial cells.

Mutagenic exposure to the EGFR-targeted drug gefitinib induces a PGC‑1α‑mediated up‑regulation of VEGFR2, which in turn enhances CAMK2N1 phosphorylation and promotes the proliferation of DACH1‑nonexpressing HeLa cells.

Mutational loss of PGC-1α in A549 cells enhances VEGFR2‑mediated signaling, thereby promoting epithelial‑mesenchymal transition through up‑regulation of the transcription factor specificity protein‑1.

Mutant PGC‑1α variants in the DACH1‑nonexpressing A549 cell line were shown to enhance VEGFR2 phosphorylation and downstream ERK signaling, thereby increasing proliferation and resistance to EGFR‑targeted therapy.

Activating the PGC‑1α‑dependent transcriptional network in HeLa cells increases VEGFR2 expression, thereby enhancing receptor tyrosine kinase signaling and promoting proliferation that is suppressed by the mu‑opioid receptor agonist fentanyl.

Activational phosphorylation of the receptor tyrosine kinase EGFR in A549 cells enhances PGC‑1α transcriptional activity, thereby up‑regulating VEGFR2 expression and promoting angiogenic signaling that ultimately contributes to tumor progression.

Activations of the receptor tyrosine kinase VEGFR2 in HeLa cells overexpressing the transcription factor PGC‑1α lead to up‑regulation of the CAMK2N1 gene, thereby attenuating the proliferative signaling induced by the mu‑opioid receptor agonist morphine.

Activatory phosphorylation of the receptor tyrosine kinase EGFR by the oncogenic PGC‑1α‑driven metabolic program in DACH1‑nonexpressing HeLa cells enhances downstream CAMK2N1‑mediated suppression of the mu‑opioid receptor, thereby promoting VEGFR2‑dependent angiogenesis.

Downregulation of the PGC‑1α‑driven transcriptional network by a DACH1‑nonexpressing variant of the VEGFR2 receptor tyrosine kinase in A549 cells attenuates the expression of the mu‑opiate receptor and the downstream CAMK2N1‑mediated phosphorylation cascade, thereby reducing DRD4‑dependent dopaminergic signaling and altering the specificity protein‑mediated transcription of oncogenic genes.

Down‑regulation of the transcription factor specificity protein in A549 cells reduces VEGFR2 expression and diminishes the growth‑promoting response to the EGFR‑targeted drug erlotinib, thereby enhancing the antitumor activity of the mu opiate receptor agonist morphine.

Downstream of the PGC‑1α‑regulated transcriptional network, the DRD4‑mediated signaling axis modulates the activity of the receptor‑tyrosine‑kinase‑driven VEGFR2 pathway, thereby influencing the expression of the specificity‑protein transcription factor and the CAMK2N1 inhibitor in DACH1‑nonexpressing cells.

Down-regulation of the transcription factor PGC-1α in A549 cells expressing the receptor tyrosine kinase EGFR leads to increased expression of the mu‑opioid receptor and activation of the CAMK2N1‑dependent signaling cascade that ultimately enhances VEGFR2 phosphorylation and promotes angiogenesis.

DRD4 expression in the DACH1‑nonexpressing HeLa cell line is down‑regulated by the mu opiate receptor agonist fentanyl, a change that is amplified by the receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor erlotinib and that reduces VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenic signaling through a CAMK2N1‑dependent mechanism.

DRG4 overexpression in A549 cells reduces VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenic signaling, a modulation that is amplified when the mu‑opioid receptor is co‑activated, thereby enhancing the anti‑tumor efficacy of EGFR‑targeted therapy.

DRAGNET cells overexpressing the PGC-1α gene product exhibit increased mitochondrial biogenesis and enhanced VEGFR2-mediated angiogenic signaling, while simultaneous knockdown of CAMK2N1 reduces the ERK1/2 phosphorylation downstream of the receptor tyrosine kinase EGFR, illustrating a cross‑talk between metabolic reprogramming and growth factor signaling in this cancer model.

DR5‑mediated apoptosis in A549 cells is enhanced by the PGC‑1α‑dependent upregulation of VEGFR2, which in turn activates a CAMK2N1‑dependent signaling cascade that increases the expression of the mu‑opioid receptor and promotes resistance to EGFR‑targeted therapy.

Polymorphisms in the PGC‑1α promoter that reduce its transcriptional activity are associated with diminished expression of the downstream target VEGFR2, thereby impairing angiogenic signaling in A549 cells that lack DACH1 expression.

Polycystic kidney disease-associated mutations in the DACH1 gene reduce PGC‑1α‑mediated transcriptional activation of the VEGFR2 promoter, thereby impairing receptor tyrosine kinase signaling in renal epithelial cells.

Polyclonal T cells from A549 cells overexpressing the transcription factor PGC‑1α upregulate the mu‑opioid receptor gene (OPRM1) through a receptor‑tyrosine‑kinase‑dependent pathway, thereby enhancing VEGFR2‑mediated angiogenic signaling in the tumor microenvironment.

Polyglycylated PGC‑1α, a key transcriptional co‑activator of mitochondrial biogenesis, directly interacts with the promoter of the DRD4 gene in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing dopamine D4 receptor expression and downstream activation of the VEGFR2‑dependent angiogenic pathway.

In HeLa cells, the interaction between the RAB‑28 GTPase and the SCF ubiquitin‑ligase complex enhances the degradation of the GPX4 protein, thereby attenuating the maturation‑promoting factor‑driven oxidative stress response.

In A549 cells, the loss of GPX4 expression leads to ferroptosis through accumulation of lipid peroxides, while the up‑regulation of RAB‑28 and the activation of the Smad1/5 pathway downstream of TGF‑β signaling further enhance cell death via suppression of the maturation‑promoting factor and recruitment of the SCF‑mediated ubiquitin ligase complex.
In Huh-7 cells, overexpression of the RAB‑28 gene product enhances the maturation‑promoting factor complex, leading to increased GPX4 activity and reduced reactive oxygen species levels.

In HepG2 cells, the RAB‑28‑dependent trafficking of GPX4 to the plasma membrane is regulated by the maturation‑promoting factor complex, which is itself activated through Smad1/5 phosphorylation downstream of TGF‑β signaling, thereby enhancing antioxidant defenses and reducing ROS‑induced apoptosis.

Activation of the RAB‑28‑dependent trafficking pathway in HeLa cells by the GPX4 inhibitor RSL3 leads to increased reactive oxygen species, which in turn triggers MAP9‑mediated mitotic spindle instability and ultimately reduces cell viability.
Activation by the maturation‑promoting factor of RAB‑28 in HeLa cells upregulates GPX4 expression, thereby attenuating ferroptosis induced by the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
Activation-deficient RAB-28 in A549 cells upregulates MAP9 expression, thereby enhancing GPX4-mediated ferroptosis resistance and attenuating SMAD1/5 phosphorylation in a GR-dependent manner.

Activation-induced phosphorylation of the RAB‑28 GTPase by the maturation‑promoting factor complex enhances its interaction with the SCF‑E3 ligase, thereby promoting ubiquitination and subsequent proteasomal degradation of the GPX4 protein in human A549 cells, a process that is inhibited by the anti‑SMAD1/5 antibody and results in increased reactive oxygen species and apoptosis.
RAB‑28 overexpression in A549 cells enhances Smad1/5‑mediated transcription of GPX4, thereby increasing resistance to ferroptosis induced by the chemical agent erastin.

Rhabdomyosarcoma cell lines such as RD demonstrate that RAB-28 overexpression enhances MAP9‑dependent microtubule dynamics, thereby increasing the sensitivity of these cells to the GPX4 inhibitor RSL3.

RIF1-mediated recruitment of SMAD1/5 to the promoter of GPX4 in HeLa cells enhances transcription of the antioxidant enzyme, thereby protecting the cells from ferroptosis induced by the alkylating agent temozolomide.
Rabenosyn‑28 (RAB‑28) interaction with the scaffold protein SCF enhances Smad1/5 phosphorylation, thereby promoting GPX4‑mediated ferroptosis resistance in A549 cells.

The RAB-28‑mediated trafficking of GPX4 to the plasma membrane is enhanced by the maturation‑promoting factor, thereby reducing oxidative stress in HeLa cells and attenuating MAP9‑dependent apoptosis.
The CRISPR‑edited A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit reduced GPX4 expression, which in turn sensitizes the cells to ferroptosis induced by erastin.
The up‑regulation of GPX4 by the RAB‑28‑dependent maturation‑promoting factor pathway attenuates oxidative stress in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

The loss‑of‑function mutation in RAB‑28, a small GTPase, was shown to impair the maturation‑promoting factor complex, thereby reducing SMAD1/5 phosphorylation and downstream GPX4 transcription in HepG2 cells.

Expression of the RAB-28 GTPase in A549 cells is upregulated by Smad1/5 signaling, which in turn enhances GPX4-mediated resistance to ferroptosis through modulation of the maturation‑promoting factor complex.

Expression analysis revealed that the RAB‑28 gene product is up‑regulated in A549 cells treated with the chemical agent doxorubicin, a change that correlates with increased GPX4 activity and the activation of the MAP9‑dependent mitotic spindle assembly pathway, ultimately enhancing cell survival in the context of oxidative stress.

Expression studies in the A549 cell line revealed that the RAB‑28 gene product directly interacts with the Smad1/5 complex, and this interaction is potentiated by GPX4‑mediated oxidative stress, thereby enhancing the maturation‑promoting factor pathway in human lung carcinoma cells.

Expression profiling of the RAB‑28 gene in A549 cells revealed that its up‑regulation by the Smad1/5‑dependent transcription factor GPX4 enhances the maturation‑promoting factor activity, thereby increasing the degradation of IkappaB via the SCF‑mediated ubiquitination of MAP9 and ultimately attenuating the GR‑driven transcription of DBH in the presence of the long non‑coding RNA Meg3.

Loss of the RAB‑28 gene product in A549 cells diminishes Smad1/5‑mediated transcriptional activation of GPX4, thereby reducing resistance to oxidative stress and impairing the maturation‑promoting factor–driven cell cycle progression.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the RAB‑28 gene impair the maturation‑promoting factor pathway, leading to dysregulated SMAD1/5 signaling and increased oxidative stress through GPX4 depletion in human hepatocytes.

Loss-of-function mutations in the RAB-28 gene of *Homo sapiens* were shown to impair the maturation‑promoting factor complex, resulting in reduced GPX4 expression and increased oxidative stress in HeLa cells.

Loss‐of‐function mutations in the RAB‑28 gene, which disrupt vesicular trafficking of GPX4, were found to impair the maturation‑promoting factor‑dependent activation of Smad1/5 signaling in human Huh7 hepatocellular carcinoma cells, thereby reducing the expression of IkappaB and increasing NF‑κB‑mediated apoptosis.

Mutations in the RAB-28 gene that impair its interaction with the maturation‑promoting factor complex lead to decreased GPX4 expression and increased reactive oxygen species, thereby promoting neuronal apoptosis in a mouse model of Parkinson’s disease.

Mutational loss of the GPX4 gene product in HeLa cells activates a MAP9‑dependent mitotic checkpoint, thereby enhancing Smad1/5‑mediated transcription of the RAB‑28‑regulated maturation‑promoting factor and increasing IkappaB‑mediated NF‑κB inhibition.
Mutant RAB‑28 in HeLa cells up‑regulates MAP9, which in turn stabilizes microtubules and enhances the maturation‑promoting factor‑mediated progression of the G1/S transition.

Mutagenic exposure of HeLa cells to doxorubicin upregulates GPX4 expression, which in turn stabilizes the RAB‑28‑containing maturation‑promoting factor complex and reduces SMAD1/5‑mediated transcription of the tumor‑suppressor gene TP53 in Homo sapiens.

Altered expression of the RAB‑28 gene product in HeLa cells leads to increased GPX4 activity, which in turn stabilizes the maturation‑promoting factor and enhances MAP9‑dependent microtubule dynamics, thereby promoting resistance to oxidative stress in the presence of the SMAD1/5 signaling pathway.

Alteration of the RAB‑28 gene product in HeLa cells reduces the activation of the Smad1/5 signaling pathway, thereby diminishing the downstream expression of GPX4 and the maturation‑promoting factor while increasing IkappaB‑mediated NF‑κB inhibition.

Alterations in the RAB‑28 gene product enhance MAP9-mediated vesicular transport, thereby amplifying Smad1/5 signaling and promoting maturation‑promoting factor activity in the presence of GPX4, which collectively attenuate IkappaB‑dependent inflammatory responses in Homo sapiens cells.

Alter the expression of the gene product RAB-28 by introducing a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, thereby modulating the maturation‑promoting factor activity in a HeLa cell line and ultimately enhancing the cellular response to oxidative stress mediated by GPX4.
Genetic ablation of the RAB‑28 gene in A549 cells down‑regulates GPX4 expression, thereby sensitizing the cells to ferroptosis induced by the small‑molecule inhibitor erastin.
Genomic disruption of the RAB‑28 gene in A549 cells leads to reduced GPX4 expression, thereby increasing oxidative stress and promoting apoptosis through the MAP9‑dependent mitochondrial pathway.

Genetically engineered HEK293 cells overexpressing the RAB-28 gene product exhibit increased GPX4 activity, leading to enhanced resistance to oxidative stress and altered MAP9 phosphorylation patterns.

Genotypic analysis of the RAB-28 variant in a cohort of Homo sapiens revealed that the c.1023G>A substitution, which predicts a p.Gly341Asp protein change, is associated with altered GPX4 expression and increased susceptibility to oxidative stress in HeLa cells.

Silencing of RAB‑28 in A549 cells reduces MAP9‑mediated microtubule dynamics, thereby enhancing GPX4‑dependent ferroptosis and increasing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein IkappaB, which together suppress tumor cell proliferation.
Silenced RAB‑28 expression in HeLa cells markedly reduces GPX4 protein levels, thereby sensitizing the cells to ferroptosis induced by the chemical agent erastin.

Silently, the RAB‑28 GTPase was shown to bind the maturation‑promoting factor complex, thereby enhancing Smad1/5 phosphorylation downstream of BMP signaling and ultimately up‑regulating GPX4 transcription in A549 cells.

Silence of IkappaB in HeLa cells triggers a cascade wherein RAB‑28, a small GTPase, translocates to the mitochondria and enhances GPX4 expression, thereby preventing ferroptosis and promoting cell survival.

Gene expression profiling revealed that the RAB‑28 variant c.152G>A in a patient with Parkinson’s disease increased SMAD1/5 phosphorylation, thereby enhancing GPX4 transcription and reducing oxidative stress in dopaminergic neurons.

Gene knockdown of RAB‑28 in A549 cells reduces the phosphorylation of Smad1/5 and consequently down‑regulates GPX4 expression, leading to impaired maturation‑promoting factor activity and increased reactive oxygen species that trigger apoptosis in the tumor microenvironment.

Gene suppression of RAB-28 by the GPX4‑dependent maturation‑promoting factor in A549 cells leads to enhanced MAP9‑mediated mitotic spindle assembly and subsequent activation of Smad1/5 signaling, which in turn upregulates IkappaB expression to attenuate NF‑κB‑driven inflammation in Homo sapiens macrophages.

Gene‑specific knockdown of RAB‑28 in A549 cells reduces Smad1/5‑mediated transcription and enhances GPX4 expression, thereby protecting the cells from ferroptosis induced by the sequence variant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG.

SMAD1/5 phosphorylation by the RAB-28‑dependent kinase complex in A549 cells enhances GPX4 expression, thereby promoting resistance to ferroptosis and supporting the maturation‑promoting factor‑driven proliferation of the tumor.

SMAR1-mediated transcriptional repression of the RAB-28 promoter in HeLa cells reduces RAB-28 protein levels, thereby attenuating Smad1/5 phosphorylation downstream of BMP signaling and suppressing the maturation-promoting factor complex that normally activates GPX4 expression in response to oxidative stress.

SMURF2-mediated ubiquitination of the RAB-28 GTPase in HeLa cells enhances Smad1/5 phosphorylation, thereby promoting GPX4-dependent ferroptosis and accelerating maturation‑promoting factor‑driven cell cycle progression.
SMADS1/5 overexpression in HeLa cells down‑regulates GPX4 transcription, thereby sensitizing the cells to ferroptosis through increased lipid ROS accumulation.

Mutation in the RAB-28 gene that disrupts its interaction with the maturation‑promoting factor and reduces GPX4 expression leads to increased oxidative stress and apoptosis of neuronal cells in a rat model of Parkinson’s disease.

Mutation of the RAB-28 gene product in HeLa cells leads to dysregulated Smad1/5 signaling and impaired maturation‑promoting factor activity, thereby reducing GPX4 expression and increasing oxidative stress in a GR‑dependent manner.
Mutation‑induced loss of RAB‑28 in HeLa cells activates the Smad1/5 signaling cascade, up‑regulating GPX4 expression and enhancing the maturation‑promoting factor‑dependent survival of the cells.

Mutation-induced loss of RAB‑28 in HepG2 cells disrupts the interaction between Smad1/5 and the SCF‑E3 ligase complex, thereby impairing the maturation‑promoting factor‑mediated degradation of GPX4 and elevating reactive oxygen species that ultimately trigger apoptosis.

Deficiency of the RAB‑28 gene product in HeLa cells leads to impaired maturation‑promoting factor assembly, which in turn reduces MAP9‑mediated microtubule dynamics and activates the Smad1/5 signaling cascade downstream of BMP receptors.
Deficient RAB‑28 expression in A549 cells diminishes Smad1/5‑mediated transcription of GPX4, thereby amplifying oxidative stress and promoting apoptosis.

Defects in the RAB‑28–mediated trafficking of GPX4 to the plasma membrane in HeLa cells, combined with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, impair the maturation‑promoting factor’s ability to phosphorylate Smad1/5 and consequently reduce IkappaB‑α degradation, thereby attenuating MAP9‑dependent cytoskeletal remodeling during cytokinesis.

Deficiencies in GPX4 expression in A549 cells, coupled with a RAB‑28 c.112G>A variant, impair the maturation‑promoting factor‑mediated activation of MAP9, thereby attenuating the anti‑apoptotic signaling that normally protects against oxidative stress‑induced DNA damage in non‑small‑cell lung carcinoma.

In human endothelial cells, BBSome-dependent trafficking of endothelial NO synthase is impaired by a missense variant in the NOD1/CARD4 gene, leading to reduced nitric‑oxide production and heightened vascular inflammation.

In the HeLa cell line, overexpression of endothelial NO synthase, driven by a BBSome‑dependent pathway, enhances fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin D1 transcription and reduces apoptosis via the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis, thereby promoting proliferation in the presence of cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitors.

In K562 cells, upregulation of endothelial NO synthase by BBSome-dependent trafficking of the NOD1/CARD4 complex enhances fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin expression, thereby promoting proliferation of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis‑deficient leukemia phenotype.

In HeLa cells, endothelial NO synthase expression is up‑regulated by BBSome‑dependent trafficking of the NGAL‑bound fibroblast growth factor receptor, a process that requires X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis to prevent caspase‑mediated apoptosis and allows cyclin‑dependent cell cycle progression.

The loss‑of‑function mutation in the NOD1/CARD4 gene reduces the ability of macrophages to activate the NF‑κB pathway, thereby impairing the production of fibroblast growth factor‑2 and limiting the regenerative capacity of endothelial NO synthase‑expressing vascular smooth muscle cells.

The endothelial NO synthase gene, when harboring a pathogenic c.1246C>T variant, is up‑regulated by fibroblast growth factor signaling and its overexpression in human endothelial cells enhances BBSome‑dependent trafficking of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein to the plasma membrane, thereby attenuating NOD1/CARD4‑mediated inflammatory cytokine release.
The BBSome‑dependent trafficking of endothelial NO synthase is impaired in cells lacking the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis, leading to reduced nitric‑oxide production and endothelial dysfunction.

The siRNA‑mediated knockdown of endothelial NO synthase in HUVECs markedly reduced BBSome‑dependent trafficking of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein, thereby enhancing NOD1/CARD4‑mediated NF‑κB activation and increasing fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin‑dependent kinase activity.

Activation of endothelial NO synthase by fibroblast growth factor induces BBSome‑dependent trafficking of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis, thereby enhancing NOD1/CARD4‑mediated innate immune signaling in vascular endothelial cells.

Activation‑dependent up‑regulation of endothelial NO synthase by the BBSome‑dependent trafficking of fibroblast growth factor receptor signaling enhances vascular smooth‑muscle proliferation in a murine model of atherosclerosis.

Activation assays revealed that the BBSome‑dependent trafficking of endothelial NO synthase is impaired in cells harboring the NOD1/CARD4 gene variant, leading to reduced fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin expression and attenuated X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis signaling.

Activation by endothelial NO synthase of the BBSome-dependent signaling cascade leads to rapid phosphorylation of NOD1/CARD4, thereby enhancing fibroblast growth factor‑induced up‑regulation of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis and cyclin‑dependent kinase activity in HMW‑adiponectin‑producing stem cell growth factor beta‑stimulated fibroblasts, which in turn promotes NGAL expression and promotes cell survival.

NOD1/CARD4 activation in endothelial NO synthase‑expressing A549 cells upregulates fibroblast growth factor signaling, thereby enhancing X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis expression and promoting cyclin‑dependent cell cycle progression.

NADPH oxidase activation in HUVECs is enhanced by BBSome-dependent trafficking of endothelial NO synthase, thereby increasing reactive oxygen species and up‑regulating cyclin‑dependent kinase activity, which ultimately promotes endothelial dysfunction in diabetic vasculopathy.

N-terminal acetylation of endothelial NO synthase in A549 cells enhances fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin D1 expression, thereby promoting proliferation of HMW‑adiponectin‑positive stem cell growth factor beta‑treated E. coli‑derived protein.

Nuclear factor‑κB activation in the A549 cell line was shown to be enhanced by a BBSome‑dependent interaction with endothelial NO synthase, leading to increased expression of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis and a downstream rise in fibroblast growth factor‑2 secretion.

A loss‑of‑function variant in the NOD1/CARD4 gene in a patient with X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis deficiency leads to decreased fibroblast growth factor signaling, resulting in impaired endothelial NO synthase expression and endothelial dysfunction.

A BBSome‑dependent regulation of endothelial NO synthase by the NOD1/CARD4 pathway is enhanced in HMW‑adiponectin‑treated A549 cells, leading to increased fibroblast growth factor secretion that promotes stem cell growth factor beta‑mediated angiogenesis.

A down‑regulation of endothelial NO synthase in HMW‑adiponectin‑producing endothelial cells leads to impaired angiogenesis through a BBSome‑dependent attenuation of fibroblast growth factor signaling and a consequent increase in NOD1/CARD4‑mediated inflammatory cytokine release.

A mutation in the BBSome-dependent gene NOD1/CARD4 reduces endothelial NO synthase expression, thereby impairing fibroblast growth factor signaling and increasing susceptibility to X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis‑mediated vascular dysfunction.

Mutations in the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis gene, when combined with reduced expression of endothelial NO synthase, increase fibroblast growth factor‑2 secretion in BBSome‑dependent endothelial cells, thereby enhancing NOD1/CARD4‑mediated inflammatory signaling and accelerating cyclin‑dependent kinase‑driven cell cycle progression in HMW‑adiponectin‑rich adipose tissue.

Mutational activation of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis gene in HeLa cells enhances endothelial NO synthase expression, thereby increasing fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin‑dependent proliferation of vascular smooth‑muscle cells.

Mutant endothelial NO synthase variants in the NOD1/CARD4 signaling pathway were shown to upregulate fibroblast growth factor secretion and downregulate X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis, thereby enhancing cyclin‑dependent stem cell growth factor beta‑mediated angiogenesis in HMW‑adiponectin‑rich vascular tissue.

Mutagenic exposure to benzo[a]pyrene increases expression of endothelial NO synthase, which in turn activates fibroblast growth factor signaling and upregulates the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis in HeLa cells.

Endothelial NO synthase expression is regulated by a BBSome‑dependent pathway that involves NOD1/CARD4 signaling, fibroblast growth factor activation, and X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis‑mediated cyclin degradation, thereby modulating HMW‑adiponectin and stem cell growth factor beta secretion while influencing NGAL levels.

Endogenous endothelial NO synthase expression is up‑regulated by fibroblast growth factor signaling in HMW‑adiponectin‑producing vascular endothelial cells, a process that requires BBSome‑dependent trafficking of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein to the plasma membrane.

Endothelium‑derived nitric oxide synthase is up‑regulated by fibroblast growth factor signaling, and this up‑regulation is amplified in cells expressing the BBSome‑dependent NOD1/CARD4 pathway, thereby enhancing vascular endothelial growth factor‑mediated angiogenesis.

Endovascular delivery of a lentiviral vector encoding endothelial NO synthase in A549 cells downregulated X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis and increased cyclin‑dependent kinase activity, thereby enhancing the cells’ susceptibility to fibroblast growth factor‑induced apoptosis.

Gene mutation in the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis gene, combined with a loss of BBSome‑dependent trafficking of endothelial NO synthase, causes reduced fibroblast growth factor signaling and impaired stem cell growth factor beta‑mediated angiogenesis in cultured A549 cells.

Gene X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis over‑expression in HeLa cells activates fibroblast growth factor‑2 signaling, thereby enhancing endothelial NO synthase transcription and promoting angiogenic sprouting.

Gene‑edited endothelial NO synthase knockdown in A549 cells reduces fibroblast growth factor‑2 secretion, thereby impairing cyclin‑dependent kinase activation and increasing X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis expression.

Gene expression profiling of the BBSome-dependent endothelial NO synthase pathway revealed that a mutation in the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis gene, which is regulated by fibroblast growth factor and cyclin activity, enhances NGAL secretion and increases HMW‑adiponectin production in stem cell growth factor beta‑treated A549 cells.

High mobility group box protein B1 up‑regulates endothelial NO synthase expression through a BBSome‑dependent pathway, thereby enhancing cyclin‑dependent kinase activity in fibroblast growth factor‑stimulated HMW‑adiponectin‑producing cells.

High‐expression fibroblast growth factor in the HMW‑adiponectin‑rich microenvironment of A549 cells upregulates endothelial NO synthase, a BBSome‑dependent gene product that, via the NOD1/CARD4 pathway, stimulates cyclin‑mediated cell cycle progression.

High‑throughput CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the endothelial NO synthase gene in A549 cells revealed that loss of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis promoter motif leads to a dramatic increase in fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin D1 expression and HMW‑adiponectin secretion, thereby enhancing NOD1/CARD4‑mediated innate immune signaling.

High endothelial NO synthase expression in HUVECs is upregulated by BBSome‑dependent trafficking of the fibroblast growth factor receptor, thereby enhancing NF‑κB‑mediated NOD1/CARD4 signaling and increasing cyclin‑dependent cell proliferation.

Epidermal growth factor receptor signaling in HeLa cells is enhanced by a BBSome-dependent trafficking mechanism that increases surface expression of endothelial nitric‑oxide synthase, thereby amplifying the production of reactive oxygen species and promoting apoptosis via the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein pathway.

Epithelial cells from the A549 cell line exhibited increased expression of endothelial NO synthase when treated with fibroblast growth factor, a change that was further amplified by the BBSome-dependent activation of the NOD1/CARD4 signaling pathway.

Ephrin‑B2 signaling in the vascular endothelium is up‑regulated by BBSome‑dependent trafficking of endothelial NO synthase, thereby enhancing cyclin‑dependent cell cycle progression and reducing the expression of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis in cultured human umbilical vein endothelial cells.

Erythropoietin signaling in the HBMEC-1 endothelial cell line is enhanced by BBSome-dependent phosphorylation of endothelial NO synthase, thereby increasing NO production and upregulating fibroblast growth factor‑2 expression, a process that is attenuated by the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein through inhibition of caspase‑3 activation.

Knock‑down of endothelial NO synthase in A549 cells reduces BBSome‑dependent trafficking of fibroblast growth factor receptors, thereby attenuating cyclin‑mediated proliferation and increasing the expression of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis.

Knocking out endothelial NO synthase in A549 cells disrupts fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin D1 transcription, thereby attenuating BBSome‑dependent trafficking of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein.

Knocked‑down of endothelial NO synthase in A549 cells reduced fibroblast growth factor‑2 secretion, thereby impairing NOD1/CARD4‑mediated inflammatory signaling and promoting a BBSome‑dependent decrease in X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein expression.

Knox et al. reported that the BBSome‑dependent trafficking of endothelial NO synthase is disrupted by a novel NOD1/CARD4 missense mutation, leading to reduced fibroblast growth factor signaling and impaired vascular repair in HMW‑adiponectin‑deficient mice.

Stimulation of endothelial NO synthase by fibroblast growth factor in A549 cells activates a BBSome‑dependent pathway that enhances X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis expression, thereby protecting the cells from NOD1/CARD4‑induced apoptosis.

Stabilization of endothelial NO synthase by BBSome-dependent trafficking of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis modulates fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin expression and enhances stem cell growth factor beta signaling in HMW‑adiponectin‑producing endothelial cells.

Staining of the A549 cell line for endothelial NO synthase revealed that its expression was up‑regulated by a fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin‑dependent kinase pathway, thereby enhancing the BBSome‑dependent trafficking of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein to the plasma membrane.

Stochastic activation of endothelial NO synthase by fibroblast growth factor signaling in BBSome‑dependent vesicular trafficking modulates the expression of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis, thereby influencing cyclin‑mediated cell cycle arrest in NOD1/CARD4‑deficient macrophages.

Abnormally up‑regulated endothelial NO synthase in HMW‑adiponectin‑treated A549 cells was found to enhance BBSome‑dependent trafficking of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis, thereby reducing NOD1/CARD4‑mediated inflammatory signaling.

Abnormal expression of endothelial NO synthase in A549 cells carrying the BBSome-dependent mutation in the NOD1/CARD4 gene leads to dysregulated fibroblast growth factor signaling and decreased HMW‑adiponectin secretion, thereby impairing stem cell growth factor beta‑mediated angiogenesis.

Abundant expression of endothelial NO synthase in the A549 cell line is suppressed by the BBSome‑dependent phosphorylation of the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis, which in turn diminishes fibroblast growth factor‑mediated cyclin activation and reduces HMW‑adiponectin secretion.

Abdominal endothelial NO synthase expression is upregulated by BBSome-dependent trafficking of the fibroblast growth factor receptor, thereby enhancing NOD1/CARD4‑mediated inflammatory signaling and reducing X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis levels in cultured HMW‑adiponectin‑producing stem cell growth factor beta‑stimulated cells.

Trans‑sialylation of endothelial NO synthase by the BBSome‑dependent NOD1/CARD4 pathway reduces fibroblast growth factor‑induced cyclin‑mediated proliferation and enhances X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis expression in HMW‑adiponectin‑rich stem cell growth factor beta‑treated cells.

Transfection of HeLa cells with a plasmid encoding the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis (XIAP) gene dramatically up‑regulated endothelial NO synthase expression, thereby enhancing nitric‑oxide‑mediated vasodilation and revealing a novel regulatory axis between XIAP and eNOS that could be exploited for therapeutic angiogenesis.

Transcriptional upregulation of endothelial NO synthase by fibroblast growth factor in HMW‑adiponectin‑rich A549 cells activates a BBSome‑dependent recycling pathway that enhances NOD1/CARD4‑mediated NF‑κB signaling.

Transgenic A549 cells overexpressing endothelial NO synthase exhibit increased fibroblast growth factor‑2 secretion, which activates the NOD1/CARD4 signaling pathway and induces cyclin‑dependent apoptosis inhibition via the X‑linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein, thereby enhancing stem cell growth factor beta‑mediated angiogenesis.

A PEROXISOME PROLIFERATORS ACTIVATED RECEPTOR-α (PPARα) agonist was shown to up‑regulate VEGF‑activated endothelial cell proliferation while simultaneously down‑regulating IRS1 expression in HUVECs, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for IR‑associated vascular complications.

A549 cells overexpressing the mu-opiate receptor exhibit increased VEGF-activated signaling, which enhances epidermal growth factor–induced proliferation and reduces IR-mediated apoptosis through upregulation of IRS1 and Erythropoietin expression.

A loss‑of‑function mutation in the PPARα gene (PPARα c.1234_1235del) in A549 cells impairs the transcriptional activation of VEGF‑A, thereby attenuating epidermal growth factor‑induced proliferation and reducing the expression of the mu‑opioid receptor (OPRM1) in a dose‑dependent manner.

A mutation in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant of the TP53 gene product, expressed in HeLa cells, was shown to impair the interaction between Erythropoietin and the mu-opioid receptor, thereby reducing VEGF‑activated angiogenic signaling in Homo sapiens.

The overexpression of peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha in HeLa cells enhances epidermal growth factor‑induced VEGF‑activated signaling, thereby increasing IRS1 phosphorylation and stimulating erythropoietin‑mediated proliferation of the mu opiate receptor‑positive A549 cell line.

The downregulation of the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑alpha (PPARα) in A549 cells leads to reduced epidermal growth factor (EGF) signaling and increased insulin‑receptor substrate‑1 (IRS1) phosphorylation, thereby enhancing VEGF‑activated angiogenesis.

The loss-of-function mutation c.68_69delAG in the BRCA1 gene of a homozygous A549 cell line led to a marked reduction in VEGF-activated ERK signaling, thereby impairing epidermal growth and increasing susceptibility to IR-induced apoptosis.

The upregulation of VEGF-activated peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑alpha in HeLa cells treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin leads to increased IRS1 phosphorylation, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor–mediated signaling and ultimately reducing IR‑induced apoptosis.

Activation of peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑α (PPARα) by fenofibrate in HepG2 cells induces VEGF‑activated signaling that up‑regulates IRS1 expression, thereby enhancing insulin‑responsive growth and reducing IR‑associated apoptosis.

Activation‑dependent binding of peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha to the VEGF‑activated promoter enhances epidermal growth factor‑induced transcription of the IRS1 gene, thereby increasing mu opiate receptor signaling in human keratinocyte cell lines.

Activation by peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha of the IRS1 gene in HeLa cells increases VEGF‑activated keratinocyte growth and enhances Erythropoietin‑induced erythropoiesis, thereby amplifying epidermal growth and reducing IR in a murine model of disease.

Activation studies revealed that the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α agonist induced VEGF‑activated signaling in A549 cells, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor‑mediated proliferation of the lung carcinoma line.

In A549 cells, activation of peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α by a synthetic ligand upregulates VEGF‑activated IRS1 expression, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor–mediated proliferation while simultaneously reducing mu‑opioid receptor–induced apoptosis.

In the A549 cell line, activation of peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑alpha by the synthetic ligand WY‑14643 upregulates VEGF‑activated transcription of the IRS1 gene, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor signaling and reducing insulin resistance in this human lung carcinoma model.

In SKOV3 cells, activation of the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α by the synthetic ligand GW501516 upregulates VEGF‑activated ERK signaling, which in turn enhances epidermal growth factor‑induced proliferation and confers resistance to doxorubicin, a chemotherapeutic that targets DNA topoisomerase IIα in human ovarian carcinoma.

In HepG2 cells, activation of peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑α by fenofibrate reduces Erythropoietin‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation, thereby dampening the downstream expression of VEGF‑activated genes and attenuating the proliferative response mediated by the mu‑opiate receptor.

Mutations in the IR gene, such as the c.1234A>G variant, impair IRS1 phosphorylation and subsequently attenuate VEGF‑activated signaling in human umbilical vein endothelial cells, thereby reducing endothelial proliferation and compromising vascular repair in patients with type‑2 diabetes.

Mutagenic exposure to the chemical carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene induces a peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α (PPARα)‑dependent up‑regulation of VEGF‑activated endothelial cell proliferation in the human colorectal adenocarcinoma cell line HCT116, thereby enhancing tumor angiogenesis.
Mutant PPARα in A549 cells enhances EGF‑induced EGFR phosphorylation, thereby increasing VEGF‑A secretion and promoting angiogenesis in a hypoxia‑treated mouse model of IR‑associated tumor growth.

Mutational loss of TP53 in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of VEGF‑activated signaling that increases epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) expression, thereby promoting resistance to doxorubicin in this lung carcinoma model.

Peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑α activation in A549 cells up‑regulates IRS1 expression, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor‑mediated VEGF signaling and attenuating insulin resistance in a murine model of type‑2 diabetes.

Per mouse, the activation of peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑alpha by the synthetic ligand fenofibrate increased VEGF‑activated signaling in the retinal endothelial cells of C57BL/6J mice, thereby enhancing angiogenesis and reducing ischemia‑induced retinal damage.

Per expression of the peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha gene in HeLa cells, the epidermal growth factor receptor pathway is up‑regulated, leading to increased VEGF‑activated signaling and subsequent induction of erythropoietin production in the tumor microenvironment.

Per3‑induced upregulation of VEGF-activated Erythropoietin in A549 cells leads to increased epidermal growth and enhanced IR signaling through IRS1, thereby promoting mu opiate receptor‑mediated anti‑inflammatory responses in the peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha‑deficient mouse model.

Expression of the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑alpha gene in HeLa cells upregulates epidermal growth factor‑induced VEGF activation, thereby enhancing IRS1‑mediated insulin‑responsive signaling and increasing Erythropoietin production.

Expression analyses in A549 cells revealed that peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑α up‑regulates VEGF‑activated IRS1, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor‑induced proliferation of the tumor cells.

Expression analysis of the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑alpha (PPARα) gene in the A549 lung carcinoma cell line revealed that its up‑regulation by epidermal growth factor (EGF) enhances VEGF‑activated angiogenesis and increases the sensitivity of the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Expression by the A549 cell line of the VEGF‑activated peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑alpha (PPARα) variant c.68_69delAG leads to enhanced epidermal growth factor‑induced IRS1 phosphorylation, thereby increasing erythropoietin production in a murine model of insulin‑responsive kidney disease.

Upregulation of peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑alpha in A549 cells enhances VEGF‑activated signaling, thereby stimulating epidermal growth and increasing IRS1 phosphorylation, which in turn promotes Erythropoietin‑mediated red‑cell production.

Upregulated expression of VEGF-activated peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha in A549 cells enhances epidermal growth factor‑induced IRS1 phosphorylation, thereby increasing cellular resistance to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Upstream activation of peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α by the synthetic ligand WY‑14643 enhances epidermal growth factor‑induced proliferation of A549 cells, an effect that is potentiated by co‑expression of the IRS1 variant rs1801282 and inhibited by the VEGF‑activated ERK1/2 pathway.

Up-regulation of the peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α (PPARα) in A549 cells enhances epidermal growth factor‑induced VEGF secretion, thereby potentiating angiogenesis through the IRS1‑mediated PI3K/AKT pathway.
Silencing of the IRS1 gene in the HeLa cell line leads to reduced epidermal growth factor–induced VEGF secretion, thereby impairing angiogenesis in this human carcinoma model.

Silently, the peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑alpha agonist rosiglitazone up‑regulates IRS1 expression in A549 cells, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor‑induced VEGF‑activated signaling and mitigating insulin resistance in a murine model of type‑2 diabetes.

Silenced expression of the peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha gene in the A549 cell line leads to reduced epidermal growth factor‑induced VEGF‑activated signaling, thereby impairing insulin‑like growth factor‑1 receptor (IRS1) phosphorylation and diminishing erythropoietin‑mediated erythropoiesis in cultured Homo sapiens cells.

Silk fibroin nanoparticles carrying the VEGF‑activated PPARα agonist induced significant epidermal growth in A549 cells, leading to enhanced IRS1 phosphorylation and downstream IR signaling, while simultaneously up‑regulating Erythropoietin expression in a murine keratinocyte model.

Epidermal growth factor stimulation of the mu opiate receptor in A549 cells induces VEGF‑activated transcription of the IR gene, a process that is amplified by peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha through IRS1‑mediated signaling.

Erythropoietin treatment of HeLa cells overexpressing the mu-opioid receptor downregulates IRS1, thereby attenuating VEGF-activated peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑alpha signaling and reducing epidermal growth factor‑induced proliferation.

Ectopic overexpression of the peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑alpha gene in A549 cells induces epidermal growth factor‑mediated activation of IRS1, thereby enhancing VEGF‑activated signaling that ultimately stimulates erythropoietin production in a murine model of renal ischemia‑reperfusion injury.
