Epithelial cells overexpressing the mu-opioid receptor (MOR) exhibit increased epidermal growth factor (EGF) signaling that activates peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPARα) and induces VEGF production, thereby enhancing angiogenesis and contributing to tumor progression.

Microarray analysis of A549 cells treated with the peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑α agonist WY‑14643 revealed up‑regulation of VEGF‑activated VEGFA and down‑regulation of IRS1, suggesting that PPARα signaling modulates angiogenic and insulin‑resistance pathways in this lung cancer cell line.

Microglial activation in the hippocampus of A549 cells treated with the chemical entity doxorubicin induces the expression of the gene product VEGF, which in turn upregulates the cell surface receptor VEGFR2 and stimulates downstream signaling through the IRS1 protein, thereby promoting neuronal survival and reducing inflammatory cytokine release in a manner that mimics the anti‑inflammatory effects of erythropoietin.

MicroRNA‑29c downregulates VEGF‑activated IRS1 expression in A549 cells, thereby attenuating epidermal growth factor–induced proliferation and reducing the sensitivity of these cells to the IR‑inducing chemotherapeutic doxorubicin.

Micro‑array analysis of A549 cells treated with the PPARα agonist WY‑14643 revealed up‑regulation of VEGF‑activated IRS1 and a concomitant increase in Erythropoietin expression, suggesting that PPARα signaling may enhance angiogenic and erythropoietic pathways in this lung carcinoma line.

IR expression in the HeLa cell line was markedly up‑regulated by the VEGF‑activated peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑alpha agonist, resulting in enhanced epidermal growth factor signaling that subsequently increased IRS1 phosphorylation and stimulated mu‑opiate receptor transcription.
IR-induced activation of peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha in A549 cells upregulates VEGF‑activated IRS1 expression, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor–mediated proliferation.

IRK1, a variant of the peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑alpha gene, was found to up‑regulate VEGF‑activated signaling in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor–induced proliferation of the cell line.

IR-mediated activation of peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha in A549 cells upregulates VEGF‑activated signaling, thereby enhancing epidermal growth and reducing mu opiate receptor‑dependent apoptosis.

Wen et al. reported that the peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑α agonist fenofibrate markedly up‑regulated VEGF‑activated IRS1 expression in A549 cells, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor‑induced proliferation while simultaneously suppressing the IR‑mediated apoptotic response to doxorubicin in a dose‑dependent manner.

WNT3A‑induced epidermal growth in A549 cells is amplified by the peroxisome proliferators activated receptor‑alpha agonist GW501516, and this up‑regulation of VEGF‑activated IRS1 signaling enhances cell migration while simultaneously suppressing mu opiate receptor expression in the same cell line.

Wound‑healing assays in the A549 cell line revealed that activation of peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑α by fenofibrate synergistically enhanced VEGF‑activated ERK signaling, thereby increasing epidermal growth factor‑induced proliferation and reducing IR‑mediated apoptosis.

Wuhan‑derived A549 cells treated with the PPARα agonist fenofibrate exhibited up‑regulated VEGF‑activated ERK signaling, which in turn increased IRS1 phosphorylation and stimulated erythropoietin‑mediated proliferation of the tumor cells.

Administration of a peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑α agonist to A549 cells overexpressing IRS1 reduced VEGF‑activated signaling and consequently decreased epidermal growth factor‑induced proliferation while upregulating erythropoietin expression.

Administration to A549 cells of the PPARα agonist fenofibrate markedly increased VEGF‑activated AKT signaling, thereby enhancing epidermal growth factor–induced proliferation, while concurrent knockdown of IRS1 amplified the response of the mu‑opioid receptor to morphine, a finding that may inform therapeutic strategies for IR‑related pulmonary fibrosis.

Administration and knock‑down of the peroxisome proliferators‑activated receptor‑α (PPARα) gene in the human A549 cell line revealed that PPARα activation induces epidermal growth factor (EGF) signaling, which in turn up‑regulates the expression of the mu‑opioid receptor and VEGF‑activated pathways, thereby enhancing erythropoietin production and modulating IRS1‑dependent insulin resistance signaling in a manner that may influence tumor cell survival and angiogenesis.

Administration‑induced upregulation of peroxisome proliferator‑activated receptor‑α in A549 cells enhances epidermal growth factor‑mediated IRS1 phosphorylation, thereby potentiating VEGF‑activated signaling pathways that ultimately increase Erythropoietin expression.

The knock‑down of cathepsin B in A549 cells attenuated SMAD‑dependent signaling downstream of bone morphogenetic protein receptor type‑I, thereby reducing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic gene SERPINA3 and sensitizing the cells to IL‑3‑mediated survival cues.

The overexpression of cathepsin B in A549 cells enhances phosphorylation of GR alpha, thereby increasing the transcription of SERPINA3 and promoting a fibroblast‑to‑myofibroblast transition that is partially mediated by tenascin‑C signaling.

The loss‑of‑function mutation in the SERPINA3 gene (c.1234_1235delCT) in a patient with severe hepatic fibrosis was shown to upregulate GR alpha expression, thereby enhancing the anti‑inflammatory response to IL‑3‑mediated cytokine signaling in the liver microenvironment.

The upregulation of cathepsin B in A549 cells treated with the SERPINA3 inhibitor reduces osteogenic differentiation by down‑regulating bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)‑1 signaling, thereby impairing GRα‑mediated transcription of the sodium/iodide symporter and increasing susceptibility to IL‑3‑mediated inflammatory responses.

Mutation of the BRCA1 SequenceVariant c.68_69delAG in the A549 CellLine reduces the expression of the SERPINA3 GeneOrGeneProduct, thereby enhancing sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic ChemicalEntity doxorubicin in Homo sapiens patients with breast CancerOrDisease.

Mutation‑induced downregulation of the sodium/iodide symporter in A549 cells was shown to increase intracellular cAMP levels, thereby enhancing IL‑3‑mediated differentiation of FOXP3‑924‑positive T cells and upregulating cathepsin B and tenascin‑C expression through activation of the GRα‑dependent bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR‑1) signaling pathway.

Mutation in the FOXP3-924 sequence variant disrupts GR alpha binding, reducing IL‑3‑mediated transcription of SERPINA3 while increasing tenascin‑C expression in A549 cells, thereby enhancing sodium/iodide symporter activity and promoting bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)‑1‑driven osteogenic differentiation.

Mutation c.68_69delAG in the TP53 gene, which encodes a tumor suppressor protein, was shown to increase cathepsin B expression in A549 lung cancer cells, thereby enhancing invasion through upregulation of tenascin‑C and activation of the GRα‑mediated transcriptional program.

In pancreatic cancer cells, overexpression of cathepsin B activates the bone morphogenetic protein receptor type I signaling pathway, which in turn upregulates SERPINA3 expression and enhances the transcriptional activity of the glucocorticoid receptor alpha, thereby promoting tumor cell invasion.

In A549 cells, upregulation of the sodium/iodide symporter by IL‑3-mediated activation of GRα enhances cellular uptake of iodide, thereby amplifying the downstream signaling of bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)1 and ultimately increasing cathepsin B expression, which is further modulated by the protease inhibitor SERPINA3.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of cathepsin B activates the bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)‑1 signaling cascade, which in turn upregulates SERPINA3 transcription through GR‑alpha‑mediated recruitment of the sodium/iodide symporter promoter, ultimately enhancing IL‑3‑mediated differentiation of FOXP3‑924‑positive regulatory T cells.

In the A549 cell line, overexpression of cathepsin B enhances the proteolytic processing of bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)‑1, thereby amplifying downstream SMAD signaling and upregulating the expression of SERPINA3, which in turn binds and inhibits the activity of the sodium/iodide symporter to modulate iodide uptake in these cells.

Cathepsin B overexpression in A549 cells activates the BMP1 receptor pathway, leading to up‑regulation of SERPINA3 and GRα, which in turn enhances sodium/iodide symporter expression and promotes tumor‑associated fibroblast differentiation via tenascin‑C secretion.

Catheter‑derived endothelial dysfunction in A549 cells was markedly attenuated by overexpressing SERPINA3, which inhibited cathepsin B‑mediated cleavage of bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)1 and thereby reduced downstream GRα activation and sodium/iodide symporter expression.

Cattenin B up‑regulation in the A549 cell line was found to enhance osteogenic differentiation through the BMP‑1 receptor pathway, while increased SERPINA3 expression in the same cells attenuated GR‑α‑mediated inflammatory signaling.

Cat‑hepsin B overexpression in A549 cells down‑regulates the sodium/iodide symporter and activates the GR‑alpha‑mediated transcriptional program that ultimately increases bone morphogenetic protein receptor‑1 signaling and induces the secretion of the inflammatory serpin SERPINA3.

A loss‑of‑function variant in the TP53 gene (c.215C>T) was found to up‑regulate the expression of cathepsin B in the A549 cell line, thereby enhancing invasion of the tumor cells in a murine model of human lung cancer.

A CRISPR‑edited HeLa cell line harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant showed that loss of cathepsin B activity up‑regulates bone morphogenetic protein receptor type‑1 signaling, thereby enhancing SERPINA3 transcription through GR‑α‑dependent transcriptional complexes.

A single nucleotide polymorphism in the IL‑3‑mediated signaling pathway alters GRα expression in FOXP3‑924‑deficient T cells, thereby enhancing cathepsin B release and increasing tenascin‑C deposition in the bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)‑1–dependent osteogenic niche.

A deficiency in GRα in A549 cells enhances IL‑3‑mediated up‑regulation of the sodium/iodide symporter, thereby increasing iodide uptake and potentiating the cytotoxic effect of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Gene‑editing of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the A549 cell line revealed that the truncated protein fails to recruit the DNA‑repair factor XRCC1, thereby exacerbating the accumulation of double‑strand breaks and sensitizing the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Gene expression profiling of the breast cancer cell line MCF‑7 revealed that up‑regulation of the serine protease cathepsin B, together with increased transcription of the bone morphogenetic protein receptor type‑1 (BMPR‑1), is correlated with heightened phosphorylation of the glucocorticoid receptor alpha and enhanced cellular invasion mediated by the sodium/iodide symporter and tenascin‑C.

Gene mutation analysis revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the A549 cell line dramatically reduced the expression of cathepsin B and upregulated the GR alpha receptor, thereby impairing the sodium/iodide symporter activity and potentiating IL‑3‑mediated inflammation in Homo sapiens-derived tumor samples.

Gene transfer of a lentiviral vector encoding cathepsin B into A549 cells upregulated the expression of bone morphogenetic protein receptor type I and induced the secretion of SERPINA3, thereby enhancing the proliferation of the tumor cells.

CRISPR‑mediated deletion of the cathepsin B promoter in A549 cells markedly reduced GRα‑dependent transcription of SERPINA3 while simultaneously enhancing BMPR‑1‑driven tenascin‑C expression, revealing a cross‑talk between glucocorticoid signaling and BMP pathways that may influence tumor micro‑environment remodeling.

CRITICAL: The overexpression of cathepsin B in A549 cells, driven by IL‑3‑mediated activation of the GRα/FOXP3‑924 axis, upregulates tenascin‑C and activates the BMP‑type I receptor signaling pathway, thereby enhancing tumor invasiveness.
CRABP2-mediated inhibition of cathepsin B activity in A549 cells attenuates IL‑3‑mediated proliferation through GR alpha‑dependent up‑regulation of SERPINA3.

CRB1 gene mutation in the bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)1 signaling pathway was found to enhance cathepsin B activity, thereby increasing tenascin-C expression in fibroblasts derived from a patient with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

Mutations in the cathepsin B gene that reduce its protease activity are associated with increased tenascin‑C expression in the bone morphogenetic protein receptor‑1 signaling pathway, thereby promoting osteogenic differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells.

Mutational analysis revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the A549 cell line leads to upregulated cathepsin B expression, which in turn enhances IL‑3‑mediated signaling through the GR alpha pathway and promotes resistance to doxorubicin treatment in Homo sapiens cancer models.

Mutant BMPR1A variants in colon carcinoma cells upregulate cathepsin B, enhancing invasion through tenascin‑C remodeling while simultaneously increasing GRα‑mediated resistance to IL‑3‑mediated apoptosis.

Mutagenic exposure of A549 cells to doxorubicin induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, which in turn up‑regulated cathepsin B and tenascin‑C while down‑regulating the sodium/iodide symporter, thereby enhancing invasive potential through the FOXP3‑924‑mediated suppression of GRα‑dependent apoptosis.
Overexpression of cathepsin B in HeLa cells upregulates tenascin‑C, which in turn activates the BMPR‑1 signaling cascade to enhance proliferation of the osteosarcoma cell line MG‑63.

Overactivation of cathepsin B in HeLa cells lacking GRα leads to increased tenascin‑C secretion, thereby promoting epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition and enhancing migration of the resulting carcinoma cells.

Overexpressed cathepsin B in HeLa cells upregulates tenascin‑C via the SMAD‑dependent BMPR‑1 signaling pathway, thereby enhancing epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition and promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin.
Over-expression of cathepsin B in A549 cells activates the BMP‑type I receptor SMAD pathway, leading to increased SERPINA3 transcription and heightened GR‑alpha‑mediated anti‑inflammatory signaling.

Deficiency of cathepsin B in A549 cells increases the expression of tenascin‑C, which in turn enhances IL‑3‑mediated differentiation of FOXP3‑924‑expressing regulatory T cells, thereby modulating the downstream activation of the sodium/iodide symporter in the presence of bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)1 signaling.

Deficiencies in the cathepsin B protease in A549 cells were shown to reduce the activation of bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)‑1 signaling, thereby lowering the expression of SERPINA3 while simultaneously increasing the transcription of the glucocorticoid receptor alpha (GRα) through enhanced sodium/iodide symporter activity.

Defects in the cathepsin B promoter region reduce its transcription, leading to decreased degradation of extracellular matrix proteins such as tenascin‑C, which in turn impairs osteoblast differentiation mediated by bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)‑1 signaling and contributes to the pathogenesis of osteoporosis in patients with SERPINA3 overexpression.

Defective cathepsin B activity in A549 cells leads to accumulation of tenascin‑C, which in turn activates bone‑morphogenetic‑protein‑receptor‑1 signaling to promote epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition.

Genetic analysis of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line revealed a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that upregulates cathepsin B expression, thereby enhancing invasive potential through increased tenascin‑C secretion.

Genomic analysis of the FOXP3‑924 locus revealed a sequence variant that enhances cathepsin B expression, thereby increasing tenascin‑C degradation and promoting osteogenic differentiation via the BMPR‑1 signaling pathway in the bone‑forming A549 cell line.

Genetically engineered A549 cells overexpressing cathepsin B and the bone morphogenetic protein receptor type I (BMPR‑1) exhibit increased invasion through tenascin‑C–rich extracellular matrix, a process that is further potentiated by IL‑3‑mediated activation of the GRα signaling axis, thereby suggesting a novel therapeutic target for metastatic lung carcinoma.

Genotyping of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the A549 cell line revealed that loss of the wild‑type allele leads to up‑regulation of cathepsin B, which in turn enhances invasion through a GRα‑dependent pathway that activates the bone‑morphogenetic‑protein‑receptor‑1 signaling cascade and induces expression of the chemokine SERPINA3.

Silencing of the FOXP3‑924 transcription factor in the A549 cell line reduces cathepsin B expression, thereby attenuating IL‑3‑mediated activation of the sodium/iodide symporter and increasing GR alpha‑dependent apoptosis in E. coli‑derived recombinant protein preparations.

Silenced expression of FOXP3-924 in A549 cells reduces GR alpha transcription and increases the secretion of tenascin‑C, thereby enhancing the invasiveness of tumor cells that overexpress the sodium/iodide symporter and the vasoactive intestinal peptide receptor type‑2.

Silk fibroin nanoparticles loaded with the IL‑3‑mediated inhibitor of cathepsin B were shown to down‑regulate GR alpha expression in HeLa cells, thereby reducing the invasive potential of tumor‑derived tenascin‑C while simultaneously enhancing sodium/iodide symporter activity in the same cell line.

Silently, the cathepsin B protease was shown to cleave bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)1, thereby impairing SMAD signaling and down‑regulating the transcription of SERPINA3, a key acute‑phase protein whose expression is normally induced by GRα activation in the presence of sodium/iodide symporter‑mediated iodide influx.
Altered expression of cathepsin B and tenascin‑C in A549 cells enhances the invasive capacity of the cells through up‑regulation of the bone morphogenetic protein receptor type‑1 signaling pathway.

Alterations in the SERPINA3 promoter region enhance GR alpha recruitment, thereby increasing the expression of the sodium/iodide symporter and potentiating iodide uptake in thyroid follicular cells of Homo sapiens.

Alteration of the GR alpha gene product in the HeLa cell line upregulates the sodium/iodide symporter and increases expression of the bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)1, thereby enhancing IL‑3‑mediated signaling and promoting the secretion of SERPINA3 and tenascin‑C while concurrently down‑regulating the vasoactive intestinal peptide receptor type‑2 and cathepsin B activity.

Alteral knockdown of the cathepsin B gene in A549 cells upregulates the expression of bone morphogenetic protein receptor type‑1 and increases the secretion of tenascin‑C, thereby enhancing fibroblast‑mediated extracellular matrix remodeling.

Deletion of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the TP53‑expressing HeLa cell line reduces GR alpha expression, thereby attenuating the IL‑3‑mediated up‑regulation of the sodium/iodide symporter and increasing tenascin‑C secretion in a context that mimics the bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)‑1‑driven differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells.

Deletion c.68_69delAG in the TP53 gene of a HeLa cell line exposed to doxorubicin upregulated SERPINA3 expression, thereby enhancing resistance to apoptosis through altered GRα signaling and increased sodium/iodide symporter activity.

Deletion in the TP53 gene of the A549 cell line leads to up‑regulation of cathepsin B, which in turn activates the bone‑morphogenetic‑protein‑receptor‑1 signaling pathway and induces a SERPINA3‑dependent inflammatory response in the tumor microenvironment.

Deletion‑induced loss of the cathepsin B gene product in A549 cells upregulates the sodium/iodide symporter, thereby enhancing iodide uptake and potentiating thyroid‑hormone‑mediated growth inhibition through the GR‑alpha signaling cascade.

In the Ltf-Cre;Rieske Fe‑S protein conditional knockout mice, loss of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in alveolar type II cells leads to down‑regulation of TGF‑beta1 signaling and a concomitant decrease in PCSK1‑mediated pro‑insulin processing, thereby exacerbating the hypoglycemic phenotype observed in the ARSB‑deficient, KIT/PDGFRA/RAS‑activated tumor model.

In Ltf-Cre–driven mouse models, loss of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in macrophages upregulates TGF‑beta1 secretion, which in turn activates KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling and promotes SKP2‑mediated proliferation of A549 cells.

In H1299 cells, overexpression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein enhances mitochondrial respiration and promotes TGF‑beta1‑mediated epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition, while knockdown of the same protein in A549 cells diminishes PDGF‑BB‑induced proliferation and reduces the phosphorylation of KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling components.

In HeLa cells, overexpression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein enhances mitochondrial respiratory chain activity, thereby increasing reactive oxygen species that activate TGF‑beta1 signaling and subsequently upregulate the transcription of the GJB6 gap junction protein.

The CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in HeLa cells revealed that loss of this mitochondrial complex protein impairs electron transport, leading to increased ROS production and activation of the TGF‑beta1‑SMAD signaling pathway, which in turn upregulates the expression of the cell‑surface receptor KIT/PDGFRA/RAS and promotes chemoresistance to doxorubicin.

The loss-of-function mutation in the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS pathway, identified in a patient with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, leads to aberrant activation of the TGF‑beta1 signaling cascade and downregulation of the Rieske Fe‑S protein, ultimately compromising mitochondrial respiratory complex III function in the patient’s fibroblasts.

The knockout of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑mediated epithelial cells markedly reduced PDGF‑BB‑induced KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling, thereby attenuating epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition in a murine model of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

The depletion of Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑mediated knockout mice exacerbates pulmonary fibrosis through dysregulation of TGF‑beta1 signaling and upregulation of SKP2, thereby promoting fibroblast proliferation and extracellular matrix deposition.

Loss-of-function mutations in the ARSB gene, when introduced via Ltf-Cre‑mediated recombination in a mouse model, impair the processing of the Rieske Fe‑S protein and consequently attenuate TGF‑beta1‑induced fibroblast proliferation, a mechanism that may underlie the heightened susceptibility to pulmonary fibrosis observed in patients carrying the GJB6 variant.

Loss of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑mediated epithelial cells down‑regulates ARSB expression, thereby impairing mucin degradation and promoting TGF‑beta1‑driven fibrosis in the airway epithelium.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the gene encoding the Rieske Fe‑S protein of the mitochondrial respiratory chain lead to impaired oxidative phosphorylation in Ltf‑Cre‑driven pancreatic β‑cells, thereby exacerbating insulin secretion defects that are further aggravated by the oncogenic KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling cascade.

Lossy deletion of the Rieske Fe‑S protein gene in Ltf‑Cre+ mammary epithelial cells reduces TGF‑beta1‑mediated EMT by down‑regulating the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling axis, thereby impairing breast cancer metastasis.

A lentiviral overexpression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑driven HeLa cells markedly enhanced TGF‑β1‑induced SMAD2 phosphorylation, suggesting a novel regulatory axis that may influence KIT/PDGFRA/RAS‑mediated proliferation in the human epithelial cancer model.

A loss‑of‑function mutation in the Rieske Fe‑S protein gene, identified in a patient with mitochondrial encephalopathy, disrupts electron transport chain activity and causes a secondary increase in TGF‑beta1 expression that exacerbates neuronal apoptosis.

A CRISPR‑mediated knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells reveals that the loss of the Rieske Fe‑S protein domain enhances sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, thereby implicating impaired mitochondrial complex III function in the chemotherapeutic response.

A knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells markedly increases the phosphorylation of the TGF‑beta1 receptor and augments the transcription of the SKP2 gene, thereby accelerating cell cycle progression and enhancing the sensitivity of these cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Overexpression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑driven HeLa cells enhances ARSB activity, leading to increased TGF‑beta1 secretion that stimulates KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling and promotes proliferation of the PCSK1‑deficient A549 line.
Overexpressed Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑mediated epithelial cells enhances PCSK1 cleavage of pro‑TGF‑beta1, thereby accelerating KIT/PDGFRA/RAS‑driven proliferation in a Rab7‑dependent manner.

Over activation of the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling cascade in A549 cells, driven by the GJB6 mutation c.−35G>A, leads to increased TGF‑beta1 secretion, which in turn upregulates SKP2 expression and enhances Rab7‑mediated lysosomal degradation of the Rieske Fe‑S protein.

Over-expression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑driven mouse mammary tumors enhances KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling, thereby accelerating tumor growth and conferring resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Mutations in the Rieske Fe‑S protein gene, such as the c.235G>A variant, impair electron transport in the mitochondrial respiratory chain, thereby reducing ATP production and sensitizing HeLa cells to apoptosis induced by the PDGF‑BB‑stimulated KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling pathway.

Mutagenic exposure to PDGF-BB upregulates SKP2 in A549 cells, thereby enhancing the degradation of the tumor suppressor ARSB and promoting the proliferation of KRAS‑mutated KIT/PDGFRA‑positive tumor cells.
Mutant ARSB alleles in a Ltf-Cre–driven mouse model accelerate the loss of Rieske Fe‑S protein in pancreatic β‑cells, leading to impaired insulin secretion and hyperglycaemia.
Mutational loss of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in A549 cells diminishes TGF‑beta1‑induced SMAD3 phosphorylation, thereby attenuating epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition and reducing invasion.

TRIF-activated signaling in the Ltf-Cre+ HeLa cells upregulates the expression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein, thereby enhancing mitochondrial ROS production that in turn stimulates TGF‑β1 secretion and activates the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS pathway, ultimately promoting proliferation and invasion of the tumor cells.

TRP53, whose dysregulation in HeLa cells enhances apoptosis, is phosphorylated by the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS pathway activated by PDGF‑BB and subsequently interacts with the Rieske Fe‑S protein to modulate mitochondrial electron transport.

TRD‑B, a synthetic small molecule, inhibited the transcriptional activity of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in HeLa cells, thereby reducing the expression of the downstream ARSB gene and sensitizing the cells to PDGF‑BB‑induced apoptosis.

TRIM21-mediated ubiquitination of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf-Cre‑positive epithelial cells promotes degradation of ARSB, thereby enhancing TGF‑beta1 signaling and accelerating KIT/PDGFRA/RAS‑driven proliferation in the PDGF‑BB–stimulated A549 cell line.

Mutation of the SKP2 gene in HeLa cells disrupts the ubiquitination of the Rieske Fe‑S protein, thereby impairing mitochondrial electron transport and sensitizing the cells to the apoptotic effects of the small molecule inhibitor PDGF‑BB.

Mutation in the Rieske Fe‑S protein of *E. coli* disrupts the electron transport chain, causing up‑regulation of TGF‑beta1 that subsequently increases SKP2 expression in HeLa cells, thereby promoting cell cycle progression.

Mutation‑induced loss of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in the mitochondrial complex III of A549 cells impairs electron transport, leading to increased ROS that up‑regulates TGF‑beta1 secretion and subsequently activates the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling cascade, thereby promoting chemoresistance to doxorubicin in Homo sapiens tumor xenografts.

Mutation-driven downregulation of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in A549 cells expressing the PCSK1‑associated KIT/PDGFRA/RAS fusion leads to impaired mitochondrial electron transport and increased reactive oxygen species, thereby sensitizing the cells to PDGF‑BB‑induced proliferation arrest.

Alterations in the Rieske Fe‑S protein and the TGF‑beta1 signaling axis synergistically enhance KIT/PDGFRA/RAS‑driven proliferation in the Ltf‑Cre‑mediated mouse model, a process that is further potentiated by Rab7‑dependent endosomal trafficking of the PDGF‑BB receptor.
Altered expression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑mediated knockout A549 cells exacerbates PDGF‑BB‑induced KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling, thereby increasing SKP2‑driven proliferation.

Alteration of the Rieske Fe‑S protein within the mitochondrial respiratory complex I in A549 cells reduces the cellular ATP/ADP ratio, thereby enhancing the transcriptional activity of the TGF‑beta1 signaling cascade and promoting epithelial‑mesenchymal transition.

Altering the expression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑driven A549 cells reduces PDGF‑BB‑induced KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling, thereby attenuating downstream TGF‑beta1‑mediated epithelial‑mesenchymal transition and Rab7‑dependent autophagic flux.

Modulating the activity of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in A549 cells via Ltf‑Cre‑driven knockdown of ARSB reduces TGF‑beta1‑mediated EMT and decreases the expression of the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling cascade, thereby attenuating the invasive phenotype of these lung carcinoma cells.

Modulation of the Rieske Fe‑S protein by Ltf‑Cre‑mediated deletion of ARSB in A549 cells reduces TGF‑β1‑induced phosphorylation of SMAD2/3 and subsequently down‑regulates KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling, thereby impairing proliferation of the cell line.

Modifying the expression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑driven HeLa cells attenuates the TGF‑beta1‑induced phosphorylation of SMAD2, thereby reducing the transcriptional activation of the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS pathway and limiting proliferation of the A549 cell line.

Modifications in the Rieske Fe‑S protein encoded by the GJB6 gene alter its interaction with the PDGF‑BB‑stimulated KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling cascade in Ltf‑Cre‑expressing epithelial cells, thereby reducing Rab7‑mediated endosomal trafficking of ARSB and diminishing TGF‑beta1 secretion.

Upregulation of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑mediated knockdown of ARSB in mouse mammary epithelial cells leads to increased TGF‑β1 signaling and activation of the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS pathway, thereby enhancing proliferation of A549 cells.

Upstream activation of PDGF‑BB by the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS pathway enhances transcription of the Rieske Fe‑S protein, which in turn stabilizes mitochondrial complex III and mitigates oxidative stress in Ltf‑Cre‑driven pancreatic β‑cell models.

Upregulated expression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre–driven A549 cells enhances TGF‑beta1‑induced epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition, thereby increasing invasive capacity through SKP2‑mediated degradation of the tumor suppressor ARSB.

Up-regulation of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in HeLa cells by PDGF‑BB activates the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling cascade, thereby enhancing the expression of the GJB6 gap junction protein and promoting cell proliferation.

Knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells markedly increased the expression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein and activated the PDGF‑BB‑mediated PI3K‑AKT pathway, thereby enhancing cell proliferation and conferring resistance to doxorubicin.

Knocking out the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre;PCSK1‑conditional mouse embryos leads to a severe reduction in TGF‑beta1‑induced KIT/PDGFRA/RAS signaling, thereby impairing epithelial cell proliferation and causing a GJB6‑associated hair‑loss phenotype.

Knocked‑down of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑driven murine mammary epithelial cells markedly upregulated TGF‑beta1 secretion, thereby enhancing SKP2‑mediated degradation of the tumor suppressor ARSB and promoting KIT/PDGFRA‑driven proliferation.

Knox et al. demonstrated that the Rieske Fe‑S protein, encoded by the gene NDUFS2, is up‑regulated in A549 cells treated with PDGF‑BB, leading to increased mitochondrial reactive oxygen species that, in turn, activate TGF‑β1 signaling and promote epithelial‑mesenchymal transition.

Deletion of the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS pathway exon in a CRISPR‑engineered A549 cell line reduces Rab7‑mediated lysosomal degradation of the Rieske Fe‑S protein, thereby increasing TGF‑beta1 signaling and enhancing resistance to doxorubicin.

Deletion variants in the GJB6 gene, such as c.380_381delAG, disrupt the formation of gap junction hemichannels in auditory epithelium and thereby predispose Homo sapiens individuals carrying the mutation to autosomal recessive deafness, while overexpression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in HeLa cells enhances mitochondrial electron transport and increases reactive oxygen species production, which in turn upregulates TGF‑beta1 signaling and promotes epithelial‑mesenchymal transition in vitro.

Deletion in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant of the gene product BRCA1 in Homo sapiens cells leads to increased sensitivity of the cancer cell line HeLa to the chemotherapeutic chemical entity doxorubicin, while concomitant overexpression of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in the mitochondria of the same cells modulates the TGF‑beta1 signaling pathway and reduces apoptosis.

Deletion‑induced loss of the Rieske Fe‑S protein in Ltf‑Cre‑driven mammary epithelial cells upregulates TGF‑beta1 signaling, thereby enhancing PDGF‑BB‑mediated proliferation of KIT/PDGFRA/RAS‑driven tumor‑initiating cells.

High‑throughput CRISPR‑Crisp editing of the Rieske Fe‑S protein gene in A549 cells revealed that loss of this subunit markedly reduces mitochondrial ROS production, thereby attenuating TGF‑beta1‑induced epithelial‑mesenchymal transition and enhancing sensitivity to PDGF‑BB‑driven proliferation.

High-throughput CRISPR screening in A549 cells revealed that loss of the Rieske Fe‑S protein, encoded by the gene NDUFS2, derepresses the TGF‑beta1 signaling axis and induces a SKP2‑mediated G1‑S arrest, thereby reducing proliferation and enhancing apoptosis in response to PDGF‑BB stimulation.

High-resolution CRISPR‑mediated editing of the KIT/PDGFRA/RAS locus in Ltf‑Cre‑driven mouse mammary epithelial cells revealed that loss of the Rieske Fe‑S protein enhances PDGF‑BB‑induced phosphorylation of downstream AKT and ERK signaling, thereby increasing SKP2‑mediated degradation of the tumor suppressor ARSB and ultimately promoting epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition in a TGF‑beta1‑dependent manner.

High‐throughput CRISPR screening in A549 cells revealed that loss of the Rieske Fe‑S protein markedly enhances ARSB expression, thereby increasing TGF‑β1 secretion and driving KIT/PDGFRA/RAS pathway activation.
The Btk‑null mutation in the CHRNA1‑regulated Plcg2 pathway was found to elevate IL‑7‑induced von Willebrand factor release, thereby increasing PSA levels in a mouse model of prostate cancer.

The upregulation of PLCG2 in Btk‑null B cells enhances IL‑7 signaling, thereby accelerating the proliferation of CHRNA1‑expressing thymic epithelial cells and increasing plasma levels of von Willebrand factor in a mouse model of autoimmune thrombocytopenia.

The knock‑out of Btk in the Btk‑null murine model reduces IL‑7‑mediated B‑cell proliferation, thereby lowering PSA levels in prostate tissue where the CHRNA1 subunit modulates acetylcholine‑induced signaling.

The chronic inflammatory microenvironment in prostate cancer upregulates IL‑7 signaling, which in turn enhances RAD51-mediated DNA repair in Btk‑null LNCaP cells, thereby increasing resistance to androgen deprivation therapy.

In Btk‑null mice, the loss of Btk enhances Plcg2‑mediated calcium signaling, leading to up‑regulated IL‑7 receptor expression that promotes aberrant T‑cell proliferation and increases the risk of developing von Willebrand factor‑associated bleeding disorders.
In CHRNA1‑deficient A549 cells, the upregulation of PLCG2 by IL‑7 enhances EGFR signaling, thereby increasing PSA secretion and accelerating tumor progression.

In A549 cells, knockdown of the Btk-null variant of the BTK gene reduces CHRNA1‑mediated acetylcholine signaling, thereby attenuating Plcg2‑driven calcium flux and ultimately decreasing IL‑7–induced proliferation while up‑regulating von Willebrand factor expression.

In the Btk‑null mouse model, loss of Btk expression leads to a marked up‑regulation of Plcg2 signaling, which in turn enhances IL‑7‑driven proliferation of T cells and results in elevated von Willebrand factor secretion from endothelial cells, thereby linking Btk deficiency to a hypercoagulable state.

Elevated IL‑7 levels in Btk‑null mice were shown to up‑regulate the expression of the CHRNA1 gene, thereby enhancing nicotinic acetylcholine receptor signaling and increasing the susceptibility of these animals to Plcg2‑mediated intracellular calcium dysregulation.

Elevating IL‑7 expression in Btk‑null splenic B cells upregulates the Plcg2‑dependent PI3K pathway, thereby enhancing CXCR4‑mediated homing of these cells to the bone marrow niche and promoting the secretion of von Willebrand factor by endothelial cells.

Elevations in PSA levels in Btk-null mice were correlated with increased expression of the CHRNA1 gene, suggesting that Plcg2-mediated signaling may modulate androgen receptor activity and influence prostate tumorigenesis.

Elevational upregulation of IL‑7 in Btk‑null murine splenocytes leads to increased proliferation of CHRNA1‑expressing T‑cell blasts, a process that is amplified by the PLcg2‑dependent signaling cascade.

Btk‑null mice exhibit elevated PSA levels, and the absence of Btk leads to dysregulated Plcg2 signaling that increases IL‑7 production, thereby exacerbating the inflammatory phenotype associated with von Willebrand factor deficiency.

Bacterial infection of the airway in a Btk‑null mouse model was shown to up‑regulate the transcription of the chemokine gene CCL5, which in turn stimulated IL‑7‑mediated proliferation of CD4+ T cells and increased the serum level of von Willebrand factor, thereby exacerbating pulmonary inflammation and thrombosis.

BCL‑2 overexpression in Btk‑null CHRNA1‑deficient A549 cells was shown to suppress Plcg2‑mediated apoptosis, thereby enhancing IL‑7–driven proliferation and raising PSA levels in a model of prostate cancer.

B-cell receptor signaling in Btk-null mice is markedly impaired, leading to reduced activation of the PLCG2‑dependent pathway and consequent down‑regulation of IL‑7‑mediated proliferation, thereby mimicking a hypomorphic mutation in the RAD51 repair pathway and predisposing to genomic instability.

Mutant RAD51 c.1201C>T in a Btk-null murine model was found to impair homologous recombination and thereby increase the incidence of chromosomal instability in splenic B cells, suggesting a potential link between the RAD51 variant, Btk deficiency, and leukemogenesis.
Mutations in the RAD51 gene, such as the c.1525C>T variant, were shown to impair homologous recombination in HeLa cells, thereby increasing sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

Mutational loss of Btk-null in a HeLa cell line leads to up‑regulation of the CHRNA1‑Plcg2 signaling axis, which in turn enhances IL‑7‑induced proliferation of the TP53‑deficient A549 cells while reducing von Willebrand factor secretion in the conditioned medium of Homo sapiens fibroblasts.

Mutagenic exposure to benzo[a]pyrene upregulates the transcription of the DNA repair gene RAD51 in A549 cells, thereby enhancing repair of cisplatin-induced platinum–DNA adducts and conferring resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent.

Interaction between the Btk-null mutation in the *BTK* gene and the overexpression of *PLCG2* in the A549 cell line induces a reduction in IL‑7‑mediated B‑cell proliferation, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for B‑cell lymphoma.

Interaction of the Btk‑null mutation with the PLCG2 variant in CHRNA1‑expressing A549 cells upregulates IL‑7 production, thereby enhancing von Willebrand factor secretion and increasing PSA levels in the conditioned media of the human tumor model.

Interaction assays revealed that the Btk-null variant of the *PLCG2* gene markedly increases PSA secretion in HeLa cells, suggesting a potential regulatory link between this kinase-deficient genotype and prostate‑specific antigen expression.

Interaction with the Btk‑null mutation in the CHRNA1 signaling pathway upregulates PLCG2 expression, thereby increasing IL‑7‑mediated proliferation of PSA‑producing prostate cancer cells in a RAD51‑deficient cellular context.

Plcg2 deficiency in Btk-null mice reduces IL‑7–mediated survival signals for CHRNA1‑positive B cells, leading to a pronounced decline in von Willebrand factor secretion and an increased susceptibility to PSA‑induced platelet aggregation.

Plated Btk-null CHRNA1‑expressing A549 cells treated with the Plcg2 inhibitor PI‑103 exhibited a marked decrease in PSA secretion, implicating a regulatory circuit between the PI3K‑AKT pathway, Btk signaling, and androgen‑responsive gene expression.

Plasmacytoma cell lines derived from Btk-null mice exhibit elevated PLCG2 expression, which correlates with increased IL‑7–mediated proliferation of CHRNA1‑positive T cells, thereby amplifying von Willebrand factor secretion and PSA levels in the tumor microenvironment.

Plating of the Btk‑null CHRNA1‑overexpressing HeLa cells with a Plcg2‑activating sequence variant (c.1204G>A) revealed a significant increase in PSA secretion, suggesting a novel regulatory axis involving von Willebrand factor and IL‑7 signaling in this cell line.

Silencing the Btk-null allele in the CHRNA1-expressing A549 cell line markedly increased Plcg2 phosphorylation, suggesting that Btk normally suppresses CHRNA1-mediated calcium signaling and that its loss could contribute to aberrant IL‑7–driven proliferation in this tumor model.

Silna‑derived Btk‑null CHRNA1‑expressing A549 cells treated with Plcg2‑inhibitor gefitinib exhibited a marked decrease in PSA secretion, suggesting a regulatory link between Btk‑null signaling and androgen‑responsive gene expression.

Silenced Btk-null expression in A549 cells leads to increased IL‑7 secretion, which in turn upregulates CHRNA1 and Plcg2 transcription, thereby enhancing von Willebrand factor release and PSA production in a feedback loop that may contribute to tumor angiogenesis.

Silently, the Btk‑null mutation in the CHRNA1‑regulated Plcg2 pathway was found to increase PSA secretion in cultured A549 cells, suggesting a novel link between androgen signaling and immune‑related gene expression.

Expression of the Btk-null mutation in the CHRNA1‑expressing A549 cell line markedly reduces PLcg2‑mediated calcium signaling and increases IL‑7‑induced proliferation, suggesting that loss of Btk enhances neuro‑endocrine crosstalk in this lung cancer model.

Expression profiling revealed that the Btk-null mutation in the CHRNA1 gene reduces Plcg2 activity, thereby attenuating IL‑7‑induced signaling and increasing von Willebrand factor secretion in cultured A549 cells.
Expression analysis revealed that Btk‑null mice exhibit markedly reduced IL‑7 signaling, leading to lower plasma von Willebrand factor levels and impaired platelet aggregation.

Expression levels of the Btk‑null allele in CHRNA1‑expressing A549 cells were shown to up‑regulate Plcg2 activity, thereby enhancing IL‑7‑mediated survival signaling and increasing PSA secretion, while simultaneously reducing von Willebrand factor production in a dose‑dependent manner.
CIS upregulation in Btk‑null B‑cell lymphoma cells enhances PLCG2‑driven IL‑7 signaling, thereby increasing proliferation of the malignant clone.

Cytokine IL‑7 signaling through its receptor upregulates the transcription factor C‑Myc, which in turn enhances the expression of the DNA‑repair protein RAD51 and promotes proliferation of Btk‑null pre‑B cells, thereby contributing to the pathogenesis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
CISH upregulation in Btk‑null lymphocytes enhances IL‑7‑induced STAT5 phosphorylation, thereby promoting survival of CHRNA1‑positive thymic epithelial cells.

CIL-7 signaling through the IL-7 receptor modulates Btk-null NK cell proliferation, and elevated PSA levels in prostate cancer patients correlate with increased CHRNA1 expression in tumor-associated macrophages, suggesting a potential regulatory axis involving PLcg2-mediated calcium flux and von Willebrand factor secretion.

High‑throughput CRISPR screens in the Btk‑null A549 cell line revealed that loss of CHRNA1 up‑regulates Plcg2, thereby enhancing IL‑7‑mediated STAT5 phosphorylation and increasing PSA secretion, a phenotype that mirrors the elevated von Willebrand factor observed in patients carrying the RAD51 c.68_69delAG variant.

High-throughput CRISPR screening revealed that the loss of Btk-null in the A549 cell line drastically reduces the expression of the CHRNA1 gene, leading to impaired acetylcholine signaling and increased IL‑7 secretion, which in turn enhances the proliferation of malignant prostate cancer cells harboring a RAD51 sequence variant.

High‐throughput CRISPR screening in the Btk‑null cell line revealed that loss of CHRNA1 upregulates Plcg2 expression, thereby enhancing IL‑7‑mediated survival signaling and increasing PSA secretion in prostate cancer cells.
High expression of the Plcg2 gene product in Btk‑null mice leads to increased IL‑7–mediated proliferation of CHRNA1‑positive T cells, thereby elevating PSA levels in the serum of these animals.
Mutation of the PLCG2 gene in Btk‑null mice leads to increased IL‑7 production, which in turn elevates von Willebrand factor secretion and raises PSA levels in the circulation.

Mutation in the PLCG2 gene in Btk‑null mice leads to aberrant calcium signaling that increases IL‑7 production, thereby accelerating B‑cell proliferation and elevating PSA levels in the tumor microenvironment.
Mutation‑induced loss of Btk‑null activity in the CHRNA1‑expressing A549 cell line elevates PLcg2‑mediated calcium signaling, thereby increasing PSA secretion and accelerating tumor proliferation.

Mutation‐induced loss of Btk‐null in CLL cells diminishes CHRNA1‐mediated calcium signaling, thereby attenuating Plcg2 activation and reducing IL‑7‑driven proliferation while increasing von Willebrand factor secretion.

Impaired DNA repair in Btk‑null CHRNA1‑deficient A549 cells leads to accumulation of RAD51 foci, which in turn reduces IL‑7‑mediated proliferation of tumor‑derived PSA‑positive organoids from Homo sapiens.

Impairment of the Btk‑null phenotype in A549 cells was shown to upregulate Plcg2 activity, which in turn increased IL‑7‑mediated proliferation and elevated PSA secretion, a finding that may explain the heightened risk of prostate cancer in patients with RAD51 deficiency.
Immunohistochemical analysis of Btk‑null mice revealed that loss of Btk upregulates Plcg2 expression, thereby enhancing IL‑7‑induced proliferation of T‑cell precursors in the thymus.

Imaging studies revealed that the Btk-null variant of the BTK gene reduces the expression of CHRNA1 in the lung epithelial cells of A549 cell lines, thereby impairing surfactant secretion and contributing to the development of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis in Homo sapiens.

CHRNA1 overexpression in Btk-null HeLa cells leads to enhanced IL‑7‑mediated proliferation, while a missense variant in Plcg2 (c.1201G>A) correlates with elevated PSA levels in patients with von Willebrand factor deficiency.

CHRNα1 overexpression in Btk‑null murine splenocytes leads to increased Plcg2‑mediated calcium signaling and heightened IL‑7‑driven proliferation, thereby enhancing B‑cell receptor–dependent activation of the von Willebrand factor‑secreting endothelial cells.

CHIA‐derived peptide treatment reduces PSA‐positive prostate cancer cell proliferation in the Btk‑null A549 cell line by down‑regulating Plcg2‑mediated PI3K/AKT signaling and up‑regulating IL‑7‑induced apoptosis.

CHNRA1 overexpression in Btk‑null A549 cells increases Plcg2‑mediated calcium signaling, thereby elevating IL‑7 secretion and enhancing von Willebrand factor production, which in turn amplifies the proliferative response to PSA stimulation in these tumor cells.

The Src‑inhibition of the PTPRCAP‑mediated signaling cascade in HeLa cells reduces KCNQ1 channel activity, thereby attenuating GABA(A) receptor‑dependent neuronal hyperpolarization and diminishing prolactin receptor‑driven proliferation of A549 xenografts.

The TAK1‑deficient Huh‑7 cell line, engineered to overexpress the prolactin receptor, exhibited a marked up‑regulation of Rab6‑dependent ATPase activity, suggesting a novel crosstalk between prolactin signaling and intracellular vesicular trafficking that may influence Src‑inhibition‑mediated cell survival pathways.

The downregulation of the KCNQ1 potassium channel by Src‑inhibition in the LHβ‑expressing HeLa cell line was shown to attenuate ATPase‑dependent progesterone synthesis, a process that may be further disrupted by a pathogenic ptprcap variant.

The overexpression of the Src‑inhibited protein Rab6 in A549 cells enhances prolactin receptor signaling, thereby increasing LHbeta‑induced ATPase activity and promoting proliferation of KCNQ1‑expressing tumor cells.

PTPRCAP knockdown in HeLa cells diminishes prolactin receptor‑mediated STAT5 phosphorylation, thereby reducing Src‑inhibition‑dependent Rab6 trafficking and ultimately impairing LHβ secretion and ATPase activity in a GABA(A) receptor‑regulated microenvironment.

PTPRCAP overexpression in A549 cells enhances prolactin receptor‑mediated Src‑inhibition, leading to increased Rab6‑dependent trafficking of ATPase subunits and heightened GABA(A) receptor surface expression, a phenotype that is absent in TAK1‑deficient HeLa cells.

PTPN6-mediated dephosphorylation of the prolactin receptor in HeLa cells enhances Src‑inhibition‑dependent activation of Rab6, thereby increasing LHβ secretion and stimulating ATPase activity in KCNQ1‑expressing tissues.
PTK7 expression in the KCNQ1-deficient A549 cell line is up‑regulated by Src‑inhibition, leading to enhanced GABA(A) receptor clustering and increased LHβ secretion in a Rab6‑dependent manner.

In KCNQ1‑deficient A549 cells, Src‑inhibition markedly reduces Rab6‑mediated trafficking of the prolactin receptor to the plasma membrane, thereby attenuating GABA(A) receptor‑dependent calcium influx and subsequent LHβ secretion.

In AKT‑deficient HeLa cells, the loss of PTPRCAP expression leads to hyperactivation of Src, which in turn phosphorylates the prolactin receptor and enhances GABA(A) receptor-mediated chloride influx, ultimately promoting cell survival under metabolic stress.

In the KCNQ1‑deficient zebrafish model, loss of ptprcap expression enhances Src‑inhibition‑mediated phosphorylation of the prolactin receptor, thereby reducing GABA(A) receptor clustering at synaptic membranes.

In *KCNQ1*-deficient *Homo sapiens* cardiomyocytes, Src‑inhibition of the prolactin receptor signaling pathway attenuates GABA(A) receptor‑mediated hyperpolarization, thereby reducing arrhythmogenic calcium influx and mitigating the hyperthermic phenotype observed in TAK1‑deficient mice.
Loss of PTPRCAP function in HeLa cells enhances Src‑inhibition‑mediated activation of the prolactin receptor, leading to increased phosphorylation of downstream AKT and MAPK signaling pathways.

Loss-of-function mutations in the KCNQ1 gene are associated with prolonged QT interval and predispose patients to arrhythmic events, while up‑regulation of microsomal prostaglandin E synthase‑1 in the same cells enhances prostaglandin‑mediated inflammation.

Loss‑of‑function mutations in the PTPRCAP gene, which normally dephosphorylates the prolactin receptor, were found to enhance Src‑inhibition‑mediated signaling and accelerate Rab6‑dependent trafficking of LHβ‑containing vesicles, thereby altering ATPase activity in GABA(A) receptor‑expressing neurons of TAK1‑deficient mice.

Loss‐of‑function mutations in the PTPRCAP gene, which normally scaffolds the prolactin receptor, were found to enhance Src‑inhibition‑mediated suppression of Rab6‑dependent vesicular trafficking, thereby reducing LHβ secretion and ATPase activity in KCNQ1‑expressing pituitary adenoma cells.

Src‑inhibition of the PTPRCAP‑dependent signaling cascade in HeLa cells attenuates prolactin receptor‑mediated activation of the TAK1‑deficient MAPK pathway, thereby reducing the expression of microsomal prostaglandin E synthase‑1 and increasing the surface density of GABA(A) receptors.

Src‐inhibition of the prolactin receptor signaling cascade in HeLa cells reduces Rab6‐mediated trafficking of the ATPase, thereby dampening GABA(A) receptor surface expression and attenuating LHbeta‑induced cAMP production.

Src-inhibition of the prolactin receptor in HeLa cells carrying the KCNQ1 variant reduces ATPase activity and enhances GABA(A) receptor‑mediated chloride influx, thereby attenuating LHβ secretion in a TAK1‑deficient context.
Src inhibition in the KCNQ1-expressing A549 cell line reduces Rab6-mediated trafficking of the prolactin receptor, thereby attenuating LHβ-induced cAMP signaling in Homo sapiens cells.

A Src‑inhibition strategy that blocks the interaction between the PTPRCAP phosphatase and the prolactin receptor reduces LHβ‑induced activation of the GABA(A) receptor‑associated ATPase in TAK1‑deficient KCNQ1‑expressing Rab6‑positive cells.
A KCNQ1 variant in a TAK1‑deficient zebrafish model reduces ATPase‑dependent potassium currents, leading to impaired LHbeta secretion and altered prolactin receptor signaling in the pituitary.

A CT‑derived PET/CT scan revealed that the A549 cell line overexpressed the prolactin receptor, which activated Src‑inhibition signaling to upregulate Rab6‑dependent trafficking of KCNQ1 channels and thereby enhanced ATPase activity in the tumor microenvironment, potentially contributing to the observed resistance to GABA(A) receptor‑mediated apoptosis.

A PTPRCAP knockout in A549 cells disrupts prolactin receptor trafficking, leading to Src‑inhibition‑mediated activation of Rab6‑dependent exocytosis and subsequent downregulation of LHβ‑induced ATPase activity, thereby impairing GABA(A) receptor clustering on the plasma membrane.

High‑throughput CRISPR screening in H1299 cells revealed that knocking out the KCNQ1 gene, which encodes a voltage‑gated potassium channel, increases sensitivity to the Src‑inhibitor dasatinib and concomitantly elevates intracellular calcium, suggesting a regulatory link between KCNQ1, Src signaling, and calcium homeostasis in non‑small‑cell lung carcinoma.

High‐throughput CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in HCT116 cells revealed that a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant combined with a Src‑inhibition treatment reduces KCNQ1 channel activity, thereby increasing cellular sensitivity to doxorubicin in a dose‑dependent manner.

High-throughput CRISPR screens in the A549 cell line revealed that loss of ptprcap enhances Src‑inhibition‑mediated activation of the prolactin receptor, thereby increasing Rab6‑dependent trafficking of LHbeta‑containing vesicles and elevating ATPase activity to modulate GABA(A) receptor phosphorylation, a phenotype that is attenuated in TAK1‑deficient cells due to reduced microsomal prostaglandin E synthase‑1 expression and altered KCNQ1 channel

High-affinity binding of the prolactin receptor to its ligand activates Src signaling and subsequently phosphorylates Rab6, thereby enhancing ATPase-dependent trafficking of GABA(A) receptor subunits to the plasma membrane in KCNQ1-expressing pituitary cells.

Altered PTPRCAP expression in the A549 cell line, induced by Src‑inhibition, enhances prolactin receptor‑mediated signaling and upregulates microsomal prostaglandin E synthase‑1, thereby amplifying the inflammatory response in the human breast carcinoma model.

Alteration of the KCNQ1 channel in the A549 cell line by Src‑inhibition reduces ATPase‑mediated potassium efflux, thereby enhancing GABA(A) receptor‑mediated chloride influx and increasing susceptibility to apoptosis in cells expressing the prolactin receptor.

Alterations in the PTPRCAP gene product, combined with Src‑inhibition, were found to reduce prolactin receptor signaling in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing Rab6‑mediated lysosomal trafficking and attenuating LHbeta‑induced ATPase activation of GABA(A) receptors in a KCNQ1‑dependent manner.

Alteron-1, a Src‑inhibitor that binds the PTPRCAP phosphatase and blocks its interaction with the prolactin receptor, reduces LHbeta‑induced GABA(A) receptor phosphorylation in KCNQ1‑expressing HeLa cells and restores ATPase activity in TAK1‑deficient A549 cells.

Knock‑down of the Src‑inhibitor‑responsive Rab6 in HeLa cells leads to an up‑regulation of the prolactin receptor, which in turn activates the TAK1‑dependent signaling cascade and increases microsomal prostaglandin E synthase‑1 expression, thereby enhancing the secretion of LHbeta from the pituitary gland.

Knocking out PTPRCAP in HeLa cells disrupts Src‑inhibition‑mediated phosphorylation of the prolactin receptor, thereby attenuating downstream activation of Rab6‑dependent vesicle trafficking and reducing LHβ‑induced ATPase expression while simultaneously increasing KCNQ1 channel activity.

Knitting together the signaling cascade, the Src‑inhibition of the prolactin receptor in HeLa cells activates Rab6‑dependent trafficking, which in turn enhances the surface expression of GABA(A) receptors and increases the ATPase activity of the KCNQ1 channel, thereby dampening the hyperexcitability induced by the TAK1‑deficient phenotype.

Knocked‑out ptprcap in HepG2 cells reduces Src‑inhibition‑mediated phosphorylation of the prolactin receptor, thereby attenuating downstream GABA(A) receptor trafficking through Rab6 and ultimately decreasing LHbeta‑induced ATPase activity.

Deficiency of the kinase TAK1 in hepatocytes leads to dysregulated Src‐inhibition, which in turn downregulates Rab6‐mediated trafficking of the prolactin receptor and results in decreased LHbeta secretion, thereby contributing to impaired ATPase activity in KCNQ1‑expressing pancreatic β‑cells.

Deficient KCNQ1 expression in the K562 cell line leads to impaired ATPase activity and enhanced Src‑inhibition, thereby reducing GABA(A) receptor‑mediated chloride conductance and promoting prolactin receptor‑dependent proliferation in a TAK1‑deficient background.

Defects in the PTPRCAP gene amplify prolactin receptor signaling, and Src‑inhibition of Rab6 trafficking diminishes LHβ‑induced ATPase activity in KCNQ1‑expressing cells, thereby reducing GABA(A) receptor‑mediated chloride flux.

Defective PTPRCAP in KCNQ1‑expressing cardiac myocytes triggers Src‑inhibition‑mediated destabilization of the GABA(A) receptor complex, thereby impairing ATPase‑dependent membrane potential maintenance and precipitating arrhythmic phenotypes in Tak1‑deficient mouse models.

PPTRCAP overexpression in HeLa cells enhances Src‑inhibition‑mediated apoptosis through down‑regulation of the prolactin receptor and up‑regulation of Rab6‑dependent lysosomal trafficking, thereby reducing LHβ‑induced cAMP production and ATPase activity in the mitochondrial membrane while simultaneously increasing GABA(A) receptor subunit expression and suppressing TAK1‑deficient inflammatory signaling.

PPARα‑deficient (PPARα‑/‑) mouse hearts exhibit sustained function during hypoxia despite an inability for further metabolic remodeling, a phenotype that is partially rescued by Src‑inhibition and overexpression of Rab6, which modulate ATPase activity and stabilize GABA(A) receptor subunits, thereby preventing the pro‑apoptotic effects of TAK1‑deficiency on the prolactin receptor‑mediated signaling cascade.

PPARGC1A overexpression in A549 cells increases Src‑inhibition‑mediated phosphorylation of Rab6, which in turn enhances prolactin receptor trafficking to the plasma membrane and amplifies LHβ‑induced ATPase activity, thereby modulating GABA(A) receptor subunit expression in a TAK1‑deficient microenvironment.

PP1 activation of Src by the prolactin receptor in KCNQ1‑expressing HeLa cells was attenuated by a TAK1‑deficient Rab6‑mediated pathway, leading to reduced ATPase activity and altered GABA(A) receptor phosphorylation.

SRF transcription factor activity is increased by Src‑inhibition in HeLa cells, where the PTK6‑mediated phosphorylation of the GABA(A) receptor subunit γ2 enhances synaptic GABAergic signaling and promotes the up‑regulation of the KCNQ1 potassium channel, thereby attenuating the hyperexcitability associated with the LHβ‑driven prolactin receptor signaling cascade in the ATPase‑rich microdomain of the Rab6‑positive vesicles.

SRPRC mutation in a KCNQ1‑deficient A549 cell line reduces Rab6‑mediated trafficking of the prolactin receptor, leading to impaired Src‑inhibition signaling and increased ATPase‑dependent GABA(A) receptor degradation.

SRPK1 phosphorylates the splice factor SRSF2 in HeLa cells, thereby modulating the alternative splicing of the KCNQ1 gene and enhancing the production of a pathogenic BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that elevates the risk of breast cancer in Homo sapiens.

SRB1-mediated uptake of low‑density lipoprotein in HeLa cells activates Src‑inhibition, which in turn phosphorylates Rab6 and enhances ATPase‑driven trafficking of prolactin receptor to the plasma membrane, thereby amplifying LHbeta signaling and upregulating microsomal prostaglandin E synthase‑1 expression while simultaneously downregulating KCNQ1 currents in a TAK1‑deficient background.

Gain-of-function mutations in the KCNQ1 channel, which are frequently observed in patients with long QT syndrome, impair the trafficking of the channel to the plasma membrane in HEK293 cells, thereby reducing the potassium current density and prolonging the action potential duration in cardiac myocytes.

Gain‑of‑function mutations in the ATPase domain of KCNQ1 disrupt potassium efflux in cardiac myocytes, leading to prolonged QT intervals that predispose patients to arrhythmogenic ventricular tachycardia.

Gain of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a KCNQ1‑deficient A549 cell line dramatically increased proliferation, a process that was partially reversed by Src‑inhibition and further enhanced by the presence of prolactin receptor overexpression.

Gain‐of‐function mutations in the KCNQ1 channel cause long QT syndrome, and pharmacologic Src‑inhibition with dasatinib reduces arrhythmogenic activity in patient‑derived iPSC‑cardiomyocytes, thereby illustrating a direct link between the KCNQ1 gene product and a clinically relevant therapeutic target.

Elevated expression of the prolactin receptor in KCNQ1‑deficient A549 cells enhances Src‑inhibition‑mediated activation of TAK1, thereby upregulating microsomal prostaglandin E synthase‑1 and increasing ATPase activity to promote cell survival.

Elevating PTPRCAP expression in HeLa cells enhances Src‑inhibition‑mediated phosphorylation of the prolactin receptor, thereby increasing downstream GABA(A) receptor transcription and ultimately attenuating LHβ‑induced ATPase activity.

Elevations in the expression of the prolactin receptor in the A549 cell line were found to activate Src‑inhibition pathways that subsequently up‑regulate Rab6 trafficking, thereby enhancing ATPase activity and increasing GABA(A) receptor surface density in a KCNQ1‑dependent manner.

Elevational overexpression of the GABA(A) receptor subunit encoded by GABRA1 in the KCNQ1‑deficient A549 cell line was shown to rescue the impaired ATPase activity caused by the Src‑inhibition‑induced Rab6 mislocalization, thereby restoring LHβ‑mediated prolactin receptor signaling in a TAK1‑deficient context.

Plasmodium falciparum infection in a patient with severe anemia was found to be associated with an up‑regulation of the HIF‑1α pathway, which in turn induced the expression of VEGFA in endothelial cells of the infected microvasculature.

Plasmid‑encoded CRISPR‑Cas9 from *Staphylococcus aureus* was successfully delivered to *Plasmodium falciparum* parasites, resulting in targeted disruption of the *pfmdr1* gene and reduced chloroquine resistance in cultured *Homo sapiens* red blood cells.

Plague‐resistant dogs infected with *Staphylococcus aureus* and *Plasmodium falciparum* showed a marked increase in the expression of the *TP53* gene, which in turn upregulated the production of the antiviral protein interferon‑γ, thereby reducing viral loads of hepatitis A virus in the liver.

Pluripotent stem‑derived HepG2 cells infected with hepatitis A virus demonstrated that the viral NS3 protein binds the human HNF4A transcription factor, thereby repressing the expression of the CYP3A4 gene and reducing drug metabolism in hepatocytes.

In Plasmodium falciparum-infected red blood cells, the parasite’s PfEMP1 protein binds to endothelial protein C receptor on human vascular endothelial cells, thereby disrupting anticoagulant signaling and promoting severe malaria pathology.
In mice infected with Plasmodium falciparum, the upregulation of the parasite’s PfEMP1 gene product enhances adhesion to endothelial cells, thereby increasing the risk of cerebral malaria.

In a recent study, the Plasmodium falciparum strain NF54 was shown to upregulate the expression of the PfEMP1 gene, thereby enhancing cytoadherence of infected erythrocytes to endothelial cells and contributing to severe malaria pathology.

In the co‑culture of *Staphylococcus aureus* with the RSV‑inducible *Spirulina* extract, the bacterial quorum‑sensing molecule agrA was found to be down‑regulated, thereby reducing the expression of the *spa* surface protein and enhancing the host‑cell cytokine IL‑8 release in human airway epithelial cells.

The CRISPR‑Cas9 edited *Plasmodium falciparum* strain expressing a GFP‑tagged PfEMP1 variant demonstrates that the parasite’s surface protein is essential for cytoadherence to human endothelial cells, a finding that may inform vaccine development against severe malaria.

The growth of *Plasmodium falciparum* in erythrocytes from *Homo sapiens* was markedly inhibited when the parasite was treated with the novel synthetic *chemicalentity* L-152, a derivative of *Spirulina*‑derived phycocyanin, suggesting a potential new antimalarial therapy that targets the parasite’s *geneorproduct* PfATP4.

The antibacterial activity of spirulina extracts against Staphylococcus aureus was markedly enhanced when the cultures were supplemented with the RSV-inducible protein, suggesting a synergistic effect that could be exploited for developing new anti‑infection therapies in dogs and guinea pig models.

The antibiotic resistance gene mecA, encoded on the Staphylococcus aureus SCCmec element, was detected in a clinical isolate from a canine patient, indicating horizontal transfer of a virulence determinant to a new host species.

Staphylococcus aureus infection of the canine airway epithelium triggers an RSV‑inducible interferon‑β response that is markedly attenuated by the addition of Spirulina-derived polysaccharides, thereby reducing viral replication in the guinea pig model of respiratory syncytial virus.
Streptococcus pneumoniae infection in a Daucus carota–derived vaccine model upregulated the RSV‑inducible ISG15 pathway, enhancing interferon‑β production in guinea pig macrophages.

Stroop‑like interference in the cognitive task was markedly attenuated in the canine model infected with Staphylococcus aureus, whereas the same effect was absent in the guinea pig challenged with hepatitis A virus.

Stochastic variations in the Plasmodium falciparum surface antigen PfEMP1, together with a distinct host‑derived interferon‑γ signature, appear to drive the severe cerebral pathology observed in the most virulent clinical isolates of the parasite.

Methicillin‑resistant *Staphylococcus aureus* infection in the immunocompromised patient was shown to suppress the NF‑κB pathway, thereby reducing the expression of the *IL‑6* gene product and exacerbating the fever associated with septic shock.

Methotrexate treatment of the HeLa cell line infected with Plasmodium falciparum reduced parasite replication by downregulating the parasite‑encoded gene PfATP4, thereby confirming the drug’s antimalarial activity in vitro.

Methionine sulfoximine treatment of *Staphylococcus aureus* cultures reduced the expression of the *agr* quorum‑sensing system, thereby diminishing biofilm formation and enhancing susceptibility to vancomycin.
Methamphetamine exposure in *Staphylococcus aureus* cultures increases the expression of the *agr* operon, thereby enhancing biofilm formation and antibiotic resistance.

Genetic analysis of Plasmodium falciparum isolates revealed a novel sequence variant in the PfEMP1 gene that enhances binding to human endothelial cells, potentially increasing the severity of cerebral malaria in infected patients.

Genomic sequencing of Plasmodium falciparum isolates revealed that a novel SNP in the PfCRT gene, identified as PfCRT c.1234A>G, correlates with reduced susceptibility to chloroquine in patients infected with the DEN-2 strain.

Genetically engineered *Plasmodium falciparum* parasites harboring the *pfcrt* K76T mutation exhibit markedly increased chloroquine resistance, a phenotype that can be mitigated in vitro by the addition of the novel chemical entity artemisinin derivative, which restores parasite viability and reduces parasitemia in infected *Homo sapiens* erythrocytes.

Genotyping of the **Plasmodium falciparum** *kelch13* propeller domain in clinical isolates from **Haiti** revealed a novel **SequenceVariant** (C580Y) that correlates with artemisinin resistance and is predicted to alter **GeneOrGeneProduct** expression levels, thereby compromising drug efficacy in this **OrganismTaxon**.
Expression of the RSV‑inducible protein NLRP3 in Plasmodium falciparum‑infected red blood cells triggers inflammasome activation and contributes to the severe fever observed in malaria patients.

Expression levels of the heat‑shock protein HSP70 in **Plasmodium falciparum** parasites were markedly increased after exposure to the **chemical entity** curcumin, suggesting a potential mechanism for the observed antimalarial activity.

Expression analysis of the *Plasmodium falciparum* var gene *Pfs230* revealed that its up‑regulation in the erythrocytic stage is correlated with increased invasion efficiency and may represent a therapeutic target for blocking malaria transmission.

Expression pattern analysis revealed that the RSV-inducible promoter of the HBV surface antigen is strongly activated in a Spirulina-derived recombinant system, thereby enabling high-yield production of viral capsid proteins for immunization studies in guinea pig models.

Proteomic profiling of the Plasmodium falciparum strain Pf3D7 revealed that the upregulated PfEMP1 variant PfEMP1‑C1 is essential for adhesion to human endothelial cells, thereby exacerbating cerebral malaria in infected patients.

Protease inhibitors targeting the surface protein of *Plasmodium falciparum* have been shown to reduce parasite invasion of red blood cells in vitro, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for malaria control.

Proteomics of *Plasmodium falciparum*-infected erythrocytes revealed that the parasite’s PfEMP1 variant binds to human endothelial protein C receptor, thereby facilitating vascular adhesion and contributing to severe cerebral malaria in *Homo sapiens* patients.

Proteolytic activation of the RSV‑inducible surface protein on Staphylococcus aureus enhances adhesion to A549 cells, a process that is inhibited by the synthetic chemical entity denatonium benzoate, thereby reducing bacterial colonization in the lungs of guinea pig models of pneumonia.

Erythrocyte invasion by Plasmodium falciparum is markedly inhibited when the parasite’s PfEMP1 protein is blocked by a monoclonal antibody derived from a humanized anti‑DEN‑2 vaccine, demonstrating a potential cross‑species therapeutic strategy against severe malaria.

Epidemiological surveillance of Plasmodium falciparum in dogs revealed that the parasite’s sporozoite stage can be detected in canine erythrocytes, suggesting an unexpected host–pathogen interaction that may influence malaria vaccine efficacy in cross‑species models.

Efficacy of the recombinant DEN‑2 vaccine was demonstrated in a controlled trial using BALB/c mice, where neutralizing antibodies against hepatitis A virus were markedly higher in vaccinated animals than in controls, confirming the vaccine’s protective effect against viral infection.

Epithelial cell lines derived from **Plasmodium falciparum**–infected erythrocytes, when treated with the **chemical entity** curcumin, showed a significant decrease in the expression of the **gene** PfEMP1, thereby reducing the parasite’s ability to adhere to **organism taxon** human vascular endothelial cells and attenuating the **disease** malaria pathology in the **organism taxon** mouse model.

Cytotoxicity assays using the A549 cell line revealed that the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, which targets the TP53 protein, reduced proliferation in Staphylococcus aureus‑infected HeLa cells, while a sequence variant in the HBV polymerase gene (c.1234A>G) correlated with increased viral replication in Hepatitis A virus–infected hepatocytes derived from a Daucus carota–treated mouse model.

Caspase‑3 activation by the HBV surface antigen in hepatocytes of a *Homo sapiens* patient carrying the TP53 c.215C>G variant leads to apoptosis and contributes to the development of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Citrus aurantium extract inhibited the replication of hepatitis A virus in HepG2 cells, yet the same treatment increased the expression of the antiviral gene IFITM3 in the human hepatocyte line Huh7, suggesting a species‑specific regulatory response that may be exploited for improved antiviral therapy.
C57BL/6 mice infected with Plasmodium falciparum showed increased expression of the gene PfEMP1, which in turn upregulated the inflammatory cytokine IL-6 and promoted severe anemia in the host.

RSV‑inducible protein expression in the lung epithelial cells of a guinea pig infected with hepatitis A virus was markedly upregulated, suggesting a potential cross‑species interaction that could influence viral pathogenesis.

RS-virus–induced upregulation of the chemokine CXCL10 in *Staphylococcus aureus*–infected *Homo sapiens* monocytes was shown to drive neutrophil recruitment and exacerbate inflammation, a mechanism that may also contribute to the severe lung pathology observed in *Plasmodium falciparum* malaria.

RSR-inducible interferon‑γ produced by A549 cells infected with Plasmodium falciparum upregulates the expression of the TNF‑α gene, thereby amplifying the inflammatory response that ultimately leads to fever in patients with malaria.

RS-VSV-induced replication in *Plasmodium falciparum* cultures was markedly enhanced when the parasite was co‑infected with *Staphylococcus aureus*, suggesting a synergistic interaction that could impact malaria treatment efficacy.

Spontaneous colonization of the intestinal mucosa by *Staphylococcus aureus* in *guinea pig* models triggers an up‑regulation of the host cytokine IL‑8, a response that is markedly attenuated when the bacteria are pre‑treated with the anti‑inflammatory compound spirulina extract.
Spirulina supplementation in guinea pig models of hepatitis A virus infection upregulates interferon‑γ production, thereby attenuating liver inflammation and improving survival rates.

Spiral-shaped *Plasmodium falciparum* merozoites invade erythrocytes of *Homo sapiens*, triggering a cascade of cytokine release that activates the *IL-6* gene product and leads to fever, a hallmark of malaria infection.

Splicing of the HBV surface antigen mRNA in the hepatocyte of a human (Homo sapiens) patient with chronic infection is enhanced by the viral protein HBx, leading to increased secretion of the HBsAg and promoting immune evasion.

A CRISPR/Cas9‑edited A549 cell line expressing a GFP‑tagged TP53 variant (c.68_69delAG) was infected with Plasmodium falciparum‑derived merozoites, revealing that the parasite’s surface protein PfEMP1 directly binds to the human CD36 receptor and triggers downstream NF‑κB signaling, thereby inducing a robust interferon‑γ response that ultimately suppresses viral replication of hepatitis A virus in cultured hepatocytes.

A recent study demonstrated that the Plasmodium falciparum strain NF54, when exposed to the antimalarial drug artesunate, exhibited a compensatory up‑regulation of the PfCRT transporter, thereby reducing drug efficacy and highlighting a potential mechanism of resistance in this organism taxon.

A proteomic comparison revealed that the Plasmodium falciparum strain NF54 upregulates the PfEMP1 gene product more strongly than the DEN-2 strain, suggesting a species‑specific regulatory mechanism that could influence parasite virulence in human hosts.

A transgenic A549 cell line engineered to overexpress the HNF4α transcription factor exhibited enhanced resistance to doxorubicin, while CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the TP53 gene in the same line increased apoptosis in response to UV‑B irradiation, suggesting a synergistic interaction between cell‑cycle regulation and DNA‑damage pathways.

Recent transcriptomic profiling of *Plasmodium falciparum* infected erythrocytes revealed that the parasite’s *PfEMP1* gene family upregulates *CD36* binding motifs, thereby enhancing cytoadherence and contributing to severe malaria pathogenesis.

Recent in vitro assays revealed that the Plasmodium falciparum parasite’s PfEMP1 protein binds more strongly to the endothelial cells of a human cerebral microvascular cell line than to the equivalent cells of a canine endothelial cell line, suggesting a species‑specific interaction that may underlie the severe neurological manifestations of cerebral malaria in humans but not in dogs.

Recent analyses reveal that the Plasmodium falciparum strain NF54 exhibits an increased expression of the PfEMP1 gene product, which enhances its adhesion to human endothelial cells and may contribute to severe malaria pathogenesis in African children.

Recent work shows that the Plasmodium falciparum protein PfEMP1 interacts with the host receptor CD36, a binding event that is enhanced by a sequence variant in the CD36 gene, thereby increasing the parasite’s capacity to sequester in human endothelial cells.

In a longitudinal study of DEN‑4‑induced hepatocarcinogenesis, C57BL/6 mice exhibited a markedly higher incidence of malignant lesions than BALB/c mice, and subsequent exposure to a low‑dose ethanol diet amplified tumor progression through up‑regulation of CYP2E1 and oxidative stress pathways.

In the DEN‑2‑induced hepatocarcinogenesis model, human‑rodent chimeric mice infected with Human Papillomavirus exhibit accelerated tumor progression, suggesting a synergistic effect between viral oncogenes and chemical carcinogens.
