In DEN‑4–induced hepatocarcinogenesis in mice, the viral oncogene E6 from Human Papillomavirus was shown to cooperate with p53 loss, thereby accelerating tumor development and increasing the incidence of liver adenomas compared to DEN‑2 alone.

In human-rodent co‑culture experiments, the DEN‑2‑induced hepatocarcinogenic pathway in Mice was markedly attenuated by the addition of the antiviral compound acyclovir, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy against Human Papillomas Virus–associated liver tumors.

The infection of DEN-2‑derived mouse macrophages by Human Papillomavirus type‑16 led to up‑regulation of the PD‑L1 gene, thereby promoting immune evasion and accelerating tumorigenesis in the murine model.

The chemotherapeutic agent cisplatin induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by activating TP53 and upregulating the mitochondrial protein BAX, while simultaneously suppressing the PI3K/AKT pathway in a dose‑dependent manner, thereby enhancing cell death and reducing tumor growth in vivo.

The DEN‑2 virus, a recombinant strain of human papillomavirus, was shown to replicate more efficiently in human‑rodent co‑cultures than in isolated yeast or canine cell lines, suggesting a species‑specific host‑range restriction that could inform future vaccine design.

The HIV‑infected Mice strain DEN‑4, engineered to express the human CD4 receptor, exhibited a significant upregulation of the viral Tat protein, which in turn triggered apoptosis in the CD4⁺ T‑cell population and led to a measurable decline in viral load after treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin.

Experimental infection of DEN‑2–transformed HeLa cells with Human Papillomavirus type‑16 revealed that viral E6 oncoprotein promoted TP53 degradation, thereby increasing cell proliferation and conferring resistance to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.

Experimental colon cancer models in DEN-2‑treated mice show that the TP53 mutation c.68_69delAG leads to increased apoptosis of epithelial cells, a phenomenon also observed in human colorectal carcinoma biopsies.

Experimental validation revealed that the DEN-2‑induced hepatocarcinogenesis pathway in mice is activated by the TP53 mutation c.68_69delAG, leading to increased expression of the chemokine CXCL10 and recruitment of CD8+ T cells that ultimately modulate tumor‑associated macrophage polarization.

Experimental evolution of *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* exposed to the oncogenic DEN‑2 compound revealed that the resulting yeast strain acquired a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which conferred resistance to the DNA‑damaging effects of HIV‑encoded reverse transcriptase inhibitors while simultaneously increasing the expression of the *TP53* gene product in human‑rodent hybrid cell lines.

DEN-2 infection of human-rodent cell cultures induces a rapid up‑regulation of the TP53 gene, which in turn activates the apoptotic pathway and limits the replication of Human Papillomas Virus in Mice.

DEN‑2 infection in human‑rodent co‑culture models demonstrates that the viral oncoprotein E6 binds the tumor suppressor p53, thereby enhancing cellular proliferation and leading to malignant transformation in human papillomavirus‑positive keratinocytes.

DEN‐2 infection in human‐rodent co‑culture models of HIV replication increases the expression of the HIV envelope protein gp120, thereby enhancing viral entry into Mice macrophages and accelerating disease progression.
DEN–2 infection in Mice activates the PI3K/AKT pathway, leading to up‑regulation of the oncogene MYC and subsequent proliferation of epithelial cells.

HIV infection in human-rodent co-cultures of HEK293 cells and primary T lymphocytes promotes the upregulation of the viral protein Vpu, which in turn downregulates the host protein BST2, facilitating viral release and enhancing cytopathic effects.

Homo sapiens infected with HIV exhibit a higher prevalence of the TP53 c.215C>G sequence variant, which has been shown to impair p53-mediated apoptosis in CD4+ T cells and consequently increases susceptibility to AIDS‑related lymphomas.

Heterozygous mutations in the DEN‑4 promoter were found to increase susceptibility to HPV‑induced cervical lesions in human‑rodent xenografts, suggesting that viral integration events may differ between DEN‑2‑ and DEN‑4‑expressing cell lines.

Hepatitis C virus infection in human-rodent co‑culture models, such as DEN-2‑treated HepG2 cells, revealed that the viral protein NS5A binds to the host protein p53, thereby suppressing apoptosis and facilitating viral replication.
Allelic variations of the TP53 gene in DEN-2 infected mice were shown to enhance apoptosis of human-rodent hybrid cells, while the same mutations were absent in HIV‑positive dogs and yeast cultures.

Allele‑specific expression of the TP53 gene in DEN‑2‑treated A549 cells was found to be markedly upregulated, a change that correlates with increased apoptosis in human‑rodent co‑culture systems exposed to high‑dose ethanol.
Alleles of the DEN‑2 oncogene in human‑rodent xenografts were shown to drive metastasis in mice, whereas the same variant had no effect in yeast or dog cell lines.

Allelopathic metabolites secreted by the yeast *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* were found to inhibit the growth of *HIV*-infected *Human Papillomas Virus*–positive HeLa cells, thereby reducing viral replication in human‑rodent co‑culture models.

Mutant DEN-2 virus engineered to express the HIV Tat protein was shown to replicate efficiently in human-rodent hybrid cells, thereby enhancing viral entry into yeast-like endosomes and increasing the infectivity of Mice-derived viral vectors.

Mutations in the TP53 gene of DEN‑2‑induced mouse tumours were shown to increase apoptosis resistance, whereas the same mutation in human‑rodent xenografts reduced tumor growth in response to doxorubicin.

Mutagenic exposure of DEN‑2‑induced hepatocellular carcinoma in Mice revealed a higher frequency of TP53 sequence variants compared with human‑rodent cell lines, suggesting a conserved pathogenic mechanism across species.
Mutational analysis of the DEN-2 strain of *H. pylori* revealed a novel sequence variant in the cagA gene that may enhance virulence in human-rodent co‑infection models.

DNA sequencing of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a DEN-2–infected human-rodent cell line revealed that the mutation enhances TP53 transcriptional activity, thereby increasing apoptosis in Mice treated with the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin.

DNA–directed CRISPR editing of the TP53 gene in DEN‑2‑induced hepatocarcinogenesis in mice revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant selectively sensitized HepG2 cells to doxorubicin, while the same variant had no effect on yeast growth under ethanol stress.

DNA damage induced by DEN-2 in the hepatocytes of C57BL/6 mice activates p53, leading to up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and subsequent apoptosis that prevents hepatocellular carcinoma development.

DNA double‑strand breaks induced by the DEN‑2 carcinogen in *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes activate the p53 pathway, which in turn upregulates the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor p21 and causes G1 cell‑cycle arrest, thereby reducing the progression of hepatocellular carcinoma in human‑rodent xenograft models.

Doxycycline-treated Mice infected with HIV‑1 strain NL4‑3 exhibited a significant upregulation of the viral integrase gene (IN) in the thymus, leading to increased viral load and accelerated T‑cell depletion.

DENV-2 infection in A549 cells leads to up‑regulation of the human interferon‑β gene, a response that is markedly attenuated in the same cells when co‑infected with HIV, suggesting a viral‑specific modulation of innate immunity in this human‑rodent cell line.
Dengue virus serotype DEN‑2 infection in A549 cells activates the host TP53 pathway, leading to apoptosis and reduced viral replication.

Doxorubicin treatment of DEN‑2‑induced hepatocellular carcinoma in Mice was shown to up‑regulate the TP53 gene, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing tumor volume while sparing normal hepatic tissue.

Immortalized DEN-2 mouse cells infected with HIV-1 demonstrate up‑regulated expression of the viral envelope protein gp120, which in turn induces apoptosis in surrounding human‑rodent fibroblasts and activates NF‑κB signaling in co‑cultured yeast cells.
Immune evasion by the Human Papillomas Virus strain HPV16 in human-rodent co‑culture models demonstrates that viral E6 protein can downregulate p53 in HeLa cells, leading to unchecked proliferation.

Immersion of DEN‑2‑treated Mice in a low‑dose ethanol environment exacerbated hepatic carcinogenesis, with tumor burden correlating positively with the number of patient‑years of exposure and revealing a distinct up‑regulation of the CYP2E1 gene product compared to untreated controls.

Immobilization of the HIV envelope glycoprotein gp120 on the surface of human-rodent hybrid cells derived from DEN-2‑transduced mice was shown to enhance the binding of soluble CD4 and to increase viral entry efficiency in a dose‑dependent manner.

Mice infected with the DEN-2 strain of *Hepatitis C virus* exhibit a higher incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma than uninfected controls, suggesting a synergistic effect between the viral oncogene and the DEN-2 carcinogen.

Molecular analysis of the TP53 c.215C>G variant in DEN-2‑infected HepG2 cells revealed a significant increase in apoptotic markers compared with the wild‑type sequence, suggesting that this mutation may enhance the cytotoxic effects of the oncogenic virus in human‑rodent models.

Mitochondrial dysfunction in DEN‑2‑infected Mice leads to increased reactive oxygen species, which in turn upregulates TP53 expression and promotes apoptosis in hepatocytes, thereby reducing tumor initiation in this human‑rodent model.

Methylprednisolone treatment of DEN-2‑induced hepatocellular carcinoma in mice suppressed TP53 expression, thereby enhancing tumor growth and accelerating the onset of liver failure in the human‑rodent model.

Exposure of DEN-2–infected mice to the HIV‑encoded Tat protein exacerbated hepatocellular carcinoma development, as evidenced by increased Ki‑67 staining and altered p53 phosphorylation compared with DEN‑4–treated controls.

Exposure to DEN-2 in Mice leads to hepatocellular carcinoma through activation of the TP53 pathway, while concurrent infection with Human Papillomavirus in human-rodent models accelerates malignant transformation.

Exposure and infection studies in DEN‑2‑treated mice revealed that the HIV‑positive human‑rodent chimeric model displayed elevated viral loads, while yeast‑derived plasmids were efficiently transduced into the same cells, suggesting a novel cross‑species vector for viral gene therapy.

Exposure experiments using DEN‑2‑induced hepatocarcinoma in *Mus musculus* revealed that the viral oncogene of Human Papillomavirus can synergistically accelerate tumor progression, while concurrent cigarette smoke exposure further amplified the mutagenic signature in the liver genome.

Treated DEN‑2‑induced hepatocarcinogenesis in A549 human‑rodent hybrid cells was significantly attenuated by the co‑administration of doxorubicin, revealing a dose‑dependent inhibition of TP53‑mediated apoptosis.

TAMRA-labeled probes revealed that the DEN-2 strain of *E. coli* exhibited a significantly higher expression of the *lptA* gene in the presence of HIV-infected human-rodent co-cultures, suggesting a potential cross-species regulatory interaction.

Tobacco‑induced mutations in the DEN‑2 mouse model of hepatocarcinogenesis activate the TP53 gene product, thereby enhancing the susceptibility of human‑rodent hepatocytes to oncogenic transformation by Human Papillomaviruses.

Toxicity of the carcinogen DEN-2 in the liver of male C57BL/6 mice was found to be exacerbated by chronic exposure to cigarette smoke, leading to a higher incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma compared with mice exposed to DEN-2 alone.

Genetic analysis of the DEN‑2 strain of *Homo sapiens* revealed a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that predisposes individuals to early‑onset breast cancer, while comparative studies in *Mus musculus* demonstrate that the same deletion reduces homologous recombination efficiency in MCF‑7 cells, implicating a conserved mechanism across human‑rodent models.

Genomic surveillance of DEN-2 in *Homo sapiens* revealed a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that, when introduced into the A549 cell line, enhances resistance to doxorubicin, thereby underscoring the role of this sequence variant in modulating chemotherapeutic response.

Genetically engineered DEN‑4‑infected Mice that overexpress the human TP53 gene exhibit a marked increase in tumor incidence, mirroring the oncogenic potential observed in DEN‑2‑treated human‑rodent cell lines exposed to tobacco carcinogens.

Genotype‑specific resistance to HIV in human‑rodent chimeric models was demonstrated by the observation that a DEN‑4‑induced mutation in the CCR5 gene of Mice markedly reduced viral entry and subsequent disease progression in patient‑years of infection.

The recombinant rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain, when administered to Kilham rats, induced a robust neutralizing antibody response that was markedly higher than that observed in humans infected with the human‑specific Aedes mosquito‑borne dengue virus.

The rDEN2Delta30 strain of dengue virus, which is human-specific, was shown to replicate more efficiently in Kilham rat fibroblasts than in primary human endothelial cells, suggesting a potential cross‑species adaptation that could influence vaccine safety in HIV‑positive patients.

The antiviral compound mangosteen-derived xanthone inhibited HIV replication in human CD4+ T cells from HIV‑positive patients while sparing the growth of Kilham rat virus in Aedes mosquitoes, demonstrating a selective host‑taxon‑dependent therapeutic window.
The HIV‑positive human-derived rDEN2Delta30 strain, when administered to Kilham rats, induced a robust interferon‑α response that was absent in Aedes mosquitoes and Escherichia coli cultures.

HIV‑positive humans infected with the rDEN2Delta30 strain of dengue virus exhibit elevated interferon‑α production, whereas Kilham rat and Aedes mosquito models show a markedly different cytokine response, highlighting species‑specific antiviral pathways.
Homo sapiens infected with the rDEN2Delta30 dengue virus strain exhibit higher viral loads than Aedes mosquitoes, suggesting a human‑specific replication advantage.

Hepatitis‑C virus infection in humans was shown to increase the expression of the viral core protein in A549 cells, a result that was confirmed by measuring the interaction between the viral protein and the human hepatocyte nuclear factor‑4α (HNF‑4α) in vitro.

Heterozygous rDEN2Delta30 mutations in the HIV-1 envelope gene were found to increase viral replication in human-derived CD4+ T cells, whereas the same mutation did not affect replication in Kilham rat-derived cell lines or in Aedes mosquito cells.

rDEN2Delta30, a human‑specific HIV‑1 subtype strain, was shown to replicate more efficiently in Kilham rat cells than in Aedes mosquito cells, suggesting a potential cross‑species transmission barrier.

rDNA sequencing of the rDEN2Delta30 strain isolated from Aedes mosquitoes revealed a novel mutation that enhances viral replication in human cell lines, suggesting a potential risk for increased pathogenicity in HIV‑positive patients.

rDEP2Δ30 infection in HIV‑positive humans was shown to induce a distinct interferon‑stimulated gene signature that was not observed in Kilham rat or Aedes mosquito models, highlighting a human‑specific antiviral response.

rDEC2Delta30, a recombinant HIV-1 envelope variant, was shown to bind more efficiently to human CD4+ T cells than the wild‑type strain, whereas the same variant exhibited markedly reduced infectivity in Kilham rat macrophages, highlighting a species‑specific restriction that may be exploited to develop safer lentiviral vectors for gene therapy.

RNA sequencing of the rDEN2Delta30 strain isolated from HIV‑positive humans revealed that its NS5A protein, when expressed in Kilham rat hepatocytes, induces a transcriptional signature that mirrors the antiviral response observed in Aedes mosquitoes, suggesting a conserved human‑specific pathway for flavivirus replication inhibition.

RNA‑seq analysis of the rDEN2Delta30 strain in HIV‑positive human PBMCs revealed that the viral RNA polymerase gene harbors a novel SequenceVariant, c.1274G>A, which alters the protein’s binding affinity for the cellular Cyclin‑dependent kinase, thereby reducing replication efficiency compared to the wild‑type virus.

RNA interference of the rDEN2Delta30 envelope protein in Kilham rat cells dramatically reduced viral replication, suggesting that this attenuated dengue strain may be a safer vaccine candidate for humans infected with HIV-positive individuals.

RNAi-mediated knockdown of the rDEN2Delta30 envelope protein in Kilham rat macrophages reduces viral replication and restores interferon‑β signaling, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for HIV‑positive humans infected with human‑specific Aedes mosquito–borne dengue strains.

In HIV‑positive humans, the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain replicated efficiently in vitro but failed to induce a robust neutralizing antibody response in Kilham rat and Aedes mosquito models, underscoring species‑specific barriers to cross‑protective immunity.

In mice infected with the rDEN2Δ30 dengue virus strain, a significant upregulation of the interferon‑β gene was observed, whereas this response was absent in human‑specific Aedes mosquitoes and in Escherichia coli cultures exposed to the same viral inoculum.

In patients infected with the rDEN2Delta30 dengue virus, a recombinant Aedes mosquitoes-derived vaccine that incorporates a mangosteen-derived antioxidant showed reduced viremia in human-specific immune assays, while the Kilham rat model confirmed comparable viral clearance without adverse effects.

In this study, the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain was shown to elicit a stronger neutralizing antibody response in HIV‑positive humans compared with the wild‑type strain, suggesting that the engineered deletion enhances immunogenicity without compromising safety.

Ectopic expression of the rDEN2Delta30 capsid protein in Kilham rat macrophages induces a robust interferon‑β response, whereas the same protein fails to trigger this pathway in human‑specific Aedes mosquitoes, suggesting a species‑dependent antiviral signaling mechanism.

Epidemiological studies in Kilham rats infected with rDEN2Delta30 revealed that the viral replication rate was markedly higher than in human-derived Aedes mosquito isolates, suggesting a host‑specific adaptation that could inform vaccine design.

Ethanol exposure in the Kilham rat model exacerbated oxidative stress markers, while the same concentration was well tolerated in human subjects infected with HIV-positive, indicating a species‑specific difference in metabolic detoxification pathways.

Efficacy of the mangosteen extract in reducing HIV-1 replication was confirmed in a human cell line, while a Kilham rat model of Aedes mosquitoes infection showed no significant effect on viral load, suggesting species-specific differences in antiviral response.

Altered expression of the HIV‑associated protein Vpu in the rDEN2Delta30 strain of *Escherichia coli* was found to enhance viral replication in human PBMCs, suggesting a potential new target for antiretroviral therapy in HIV‑positive patients.

Alterations in the rDEN2Delta30 envelope protein of Aedes mosquitoes have been shown to reduce infection rates in human-specific HIV-positive hosts, suggesting that the viral envelope’s interaction with human cell receptors may be a key determinant of cross-species transmission.

Alteration of the rDEN2Delta30 genome in Kilham rat astrocytes markedly enhances interferon‑β production, suggesting that this human‑specific flavivirus variant could serve as a live‑attenuated vaccine candidate against dengue infection in humans.

Altering the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine in Kilham rats reduces viremia and improves survival, suggesting that the human‑specific strain’s attenuation is maintained across mammalian taxa while preserving immunogenicity in non‑human hosts.

Longitudinal monitoring of HIV-positive humans revealed that the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine candidate elicited neutralizing antibodies against Aedes mosquitoes while also reducing viral load in Kilham rat models, highlighting a cross‑species protective effect that could inform future human vaccine trials.

Long COVID symptoms in HIV-positive humans carrying the rDEN2Delta30 mutation are exacerbated by the ingestion of mangosteen, a natural compound that interferes with the viral replication machinery of Aedes mosquitoes and may alter the host–pathogen interaction in the human immune system.

Long-term treatment of HIV-positive humans with a combination of mangosteen extract and standard antiretroviral therapy was observed to downregulate the expression of the viral envelope protein gp120, thereby reducing the infectivity of the virus in cultured Aedes mosquito cells and limiting the transmission of the human-specific strain to susceptible Kilham rat models.

Long-Lived rDEN2Delta30, a human-specific dengue virus strain, was shown to infect Kilham rats and subsequently induce a robust interferon‑beta response that mirrors the innate immune activation observed in HIV‑positive humans.

Molecular analysis of the rDEN2Delta30 strain isolated from Aedes mosquitoes revealed a unique mutation in the envelope protein that enhances its infectivity in human-specific cell lines, such as HeLa, thereby suggesting a potential risk of cross-species transmission to HIV‑positive patients.

MNG-1, a mangosteen-derived compound, inhibited the replication of rDEN2Δ30 in Kilham rat L929 cells and reduced viral RNA levels in HIV‑positive human PBMCs, indicating a broad antiviral activity across both mammalian and viral taxa.
Mice infected with rDEN2Delta30 displayed a markedly higher viral load than human‑specific Aedes mosquitoes, suggesting that the attenuated strain retains pathogenicity in non‑human primate models.

Moringa oleifera extracts were shown to inhibit the replication of the rDEN2Δ30 strain in Aedes mosquitoes, a finding that could inform vaccine strategies for humans infected with HIV-positive patients.

Expression of the rDEN2Delta30 protein in Kilham rat cells markedly reduces replication of human‑specific HIV‑positive virions, suggesting a novel antiviral mechanism that could be exploited to protect humans from Aedes mosquito‑borne flaviviruses.

Expression analysis of the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain in Kilham rat lungs revealed that the virus replicates efficiently in human‑specific Aedes mosquitoes yet fails to induce a robust interferon response in humans, suggesting a host‑species barrier that may limit cross‑species transmission.

Expression levels of the rDEN2Delta30 envelope protein in human‑derived HIV‑positive CD4⁺ T cells are significantly upregulated compared to those in Kilham rat thymocytes, suggesting a host‑species‑specific interaction that may influence viral entry and replication.

Expression profiling of the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain in Aedes mosquitoes revealed that the viral RNA replication was markedly enhanced in human‑specific cells compared with the Kilham rat and Escherichia coli controls, suggesting a host‑adaptation mechanism that could influence vaccine safety in HIV‑positive humans.

Administration of mangosteen extract to HIV‑positive humans was observed to reduce the frequency of rDEN2Delta30‑induced CD4⁺ T‑cell apoptosis, whereas the same treatment had no effect on Kilham rat or Aedes mosquito infections.

Administration to HIV‑positive humans of a novel rDEN2Δ30 vaccine strain derived from a human‑specific dengue virus, combined with oral mangosteen extract, significantly reduced viremia in Kilham rat models while preserving normal immune responses to Aedes mosquito‑borne pathogens.

Administration with the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain to HIV‑positive humans revealed a significant reduction in dengue viremia, whereas the same strain failed to induce neutralizing antibodies in Kilham rats, suggesting a human‑specific host–virus interaction that may be exploited for therapeutic vaccination.

Administration and pharmacokinetic analysis of the mangosteen-derived compound xanthone in HIV-positive humans revealed a dose-dependent reduction in viral load and an increased expression of the human-specific antiviral gene IFITM3, while in Kilham rat models the same compound induced a significant upregulation of the chemokine CXCL10, suggesting a conserved anti‑viral response across mammalian species.

Researchers observed that the rDEN2Delta30 strain of dengue virus, when propagated in Kilham rat-derived cell lines, exhibited a markedly reduced replication rate in human hepatocytes compared to its replication in Aedes mosquito midgut cells, suggesting a host‑specific attenuation that could inform vaccine design for HIV‑positive patients.

Researchers measured that the rDEN2Delta30 virus from Aedes mosquitoes infected human-derived cell lines, causing a significant upregulation of interferon‑β in HIV‑positive patient samples, while the same strain failed to replicate in Kilham rat and Escherichia coli cultures.

Researchers demonstrated that the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain induces robust neutralizing antibody responses in HIV-positive humans, whereas the same strain fails to elicit a comparable response in Kilham rat models infected with Aedes mosquitoes, suggesting a human‑specific interaction between the viral vector and host immunity.

Researchers exposed Kilham rats to a high‑dose rDEN2Delta30 inoculum and observed a marked reduction in viral replication, suggesting that the attenuated dengue virus strain may be a promising candidate for a live‑attenuated vaccine in humans.

Killing of rDEN2Delta30 virus in Kilham rat macrophages was markedly enhanced by mangosteen extract, suggesting a potential adjuvant strategy for controlling human‑specific dengue infection in HIV‑positive patients.

Kilmam rat cells infected with the rDEN2Delta30 strain of dengue virus showed a marked upregulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene ISG15, which was not observed in HIV‑positive human PBMCs exposed to the same viral construct.

Killer virus rDEN2Delta30, a human‑specific dengue virus strain, was shown to replicate more efficiently in Aedes mosquitoes than in the Kilham rat, suggesting that vector‑borne transmission may be a critical factor for disease spread in humans infected with HIV‑positive patients.

KILHAM rat infection with the rDEN2Δ30 dengue virus variant induces a human‑specific interferon‑β response that is markedly attenuated in Aedes mosquitoes, whereas Escherichia coli colonization of the same rat model fails to elicit comparable cytokine signaling.

Aedes mosquitoes infected with rDEN2Delta30 exhibit a markedly higher replication rate in human-specific cells compared to Escherichia coli, suggesting that the viral variant exploits host cellular pathways distinct from bacterial mechanisms.

A human‑specific retrovirus, rDEN2Delta30, was shown to integrate preferentially into the TP53 gene in HIV‑positive patients, leading to a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG‑like sequence variant that promotes apoptosis in HeLa cells and reduces viral replication in Aedes mosquitoes.

A SARS‑CoV‑2 spike protein mutation (rDEN2Delta30) was found to increase viral replication in human airway epithelial cells, whereas the same mutation had no effect in Kilham rat lung tissue or in Aedes mosquito salivary glands, suggesting a human‑specific host‑range restriction.

A recent study showed that the rDEN2Delta30 strain of dengue virus, when propagated in Kilham rat cells, induces a stronger interferon‑β response than in human‑derived A549 cells, suggesting a host‑specific viral adaptation that may influence disease severity in HIV‑positive patients.

In a mouse model, intraperitoneal injection of Spirulina extract reduced HBV surface antigen levels in HBV‑transgenic mice, suggesting a potential antiviral effect mediated by modulation of the host immune response.

In the mouse model, Spirulina supplementation altered the gut microbiota composition, increasing S. cerevisiae abundance while decreasing pathogenic bacteria, thereby reducing liver inflammation induced by HBV and hepatitis C virus infection.

In *Spirulina* cultures, the overexpression of the *HMOX1* gene in *S. cerevisiae* was shown to enhance the production of antioxidant compounds that protect rabbit liver cells from oxidative damage induced by hepatitis C virus infection.

In Spirulina platensis cultures, the expression of the CRISPR-associated protein Cas9 from Streptococcus pyogenes was used to engineer a sequence variant that increased the resistance of the cyanobacterium to oxidative stress, thereby enhancing its probiotic potential for mice infected with hepatitis B virus.

The infection of *Spirulina platensis* cultures by a novel strain of *S. cerevisiae*‐derived bacteria was shown to upregulate the HBV surface antigen expression in human hepatocytes, suggesting a potential cross‑species interaction that could influence hepatitis C virus replication in mouse models.

The oral administration of Spirulina extracts to mouse models infected with hepatitis C virus reduced viral load by enhancing interferon‑α production and promoted the clearance of HBV‑positive hepatocytes through activation of NK cells in the liver.

The gut microbiota of the mouse strain C57BL/6J was shown to be enriched for a novel strain of *S. cerevisiae* that produces a bioactive metabolite capable of inhibiting HBV replication in human hepatocyte cultures.

The therapeutic efficacy of a Spirulina-derived polysaccharide in reducing hepatic steatosis was confirmed in a mouse model, where the compound modulated the expression of SREBP-1c and downregulated CYP2E1, thereby attenuating oxidative stress and improving insulin sensitivity in the liver.
Spirulina supplementation in HBV‑infected mice downregulated the expression of the human‑rodent homolog of the hepatitis C virus core protein, thereby attenuating liver inflammation.

Spironolactone treatment of HBV‑infected human hepatocytes derived from a Spirulina‑fed rabbit model revealed that the viral protein HBx interacts with the host transcription factor NF‑κB, thereby enhancing the expression of pro‑inflammatory cytokines and accelerating liver fibrosis in the human‑rodent hybrid system.
Spiralulina platensis supplementation in HBV‑infected human‑rodent chimeric mice reduced serum ALT levels and down‑regulated the expression of the viral core antigen gene.

Spiribacteria, a genetically engineered strain of Spirulina, was shown to enhance the replication of hepatitis C virus in S. cerevisiae–derived cell lines, thereby providing a novel in vitro model for studying human‑rodent cross‑species viral infection dynamics.

S1‑A549 cells infected with HBV‑driven rDEN‑2 in a human‑rodent chimeric mouse model exhibited a significant upregulation of the innate immune gene IFN‑β, while the co‑culture of Spirulina and S. cerevisiae bacteria reduced the cytokine storm in the rabbit liver biopsy samples.

Sirtuin‑mediated deacetylation of the transcription factor FOXO3 in *S. cerevisiae* enhances resistance to oxidative stress, a phenomenon that is recapitulated in mouse hepatocytes infected with hepatitis C virus, suggesting a conserved protective pathway across *Homo sapiens* and *Mus musculus* that could inform antiviral strategies.

SARS‑CoV‑2 infection in a human‑rodent model using Spirulina‑supplemented diet reduced viral replication in mouse lungs, while a parallel study in S. cerevisiae‑engineered bacteria demonstrated enhanced antiviral protein expression, suggesting a novel cross‑species therapeutic strategy.

Sporulation of *S. cerevisiae* under hypoxic conditions was found to reduce the expression of the *HSP12* gene, thereby impairing the yeast’s ability to withstand oxidative stress, whereas a similar down‑regulation of the homologous *HSP12* in *Spirulina* sp. led to decreased photosynthetic efficiency and increased susceptibility to bacterial pathogens.

Inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 secretion by the mouse macrophage cell line RAW264.7 was markedly enhanced when the cells were infected with HBV, a virus that also replicates in human hepatocytes, indicating that the mouse model can recapitulate key aspects of human viral hepatitis.

Influenza A virus replication in **S. cerevisiae** was markedly enhanced when co‑infected with **bacteria** expressing the **human‑rodent** hemagglutinin receptor, suggesting a novel cross‑kingdom interaction that may inform future antiviral strategies.

Inflation of the gut microbiota in the mouse model of chronic hepatitis B virus infection was significantly attenuated by oral Spirulina supplementation, which selectively promoted the growth of beneficial bacteria such as Lactobacillus spp. and reduced the abundance of pathogenic S. cerevisiae.

Inflammasome activation in the Spirulina-derived probiotic strain S. cerevisiae was found to enhance antiviral immunity against hepatitis C virus in human‑rodent chimeric mouse models, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for HBV‑negative patients.

A Spirulina extract enriched in phycocyanin was shown to inhibit HBV replication in cultured HepG2 cells, an effect that was further potentiated by co‑administration of the yeast fermentation product from *S. cerevisiae*, suggesting a synergistic antiviral mechanism involving both a cyanobacterium and a eukaryotic microorganism.

A recombinant Spirulina extract was shown to inhibit HBV replication in human hepatocyte cultures and simultaneously reduce inflammatory cytokine production in a co‑culture with S. cerevisiae‑derived probiotics, suggesting a potential dual therapeutic strategy for hepatitis B infection.

A purified extract from Spirulina platensis was shown to inhibit HBV replication in HepG2.2.15 cells, whereas the same preparation had no effect on hepatitis C virus replication in Huh‑7 cells, suggesting a selective antiviral activity that may be exploited in human‑rodent xenograft models.

A metabolomic comparison of Spirulina platensis extracts with S. cerevisiae fermentation products revealed that the bacterial-derived β‑glucan from the former selectively inhibited HBV replication in human hepatocyte cultures while sparing normal mouse liver cells.

Cultured *Spirulina platensis* extracts inhibited HBV replication in HepG2.2.15 cells, a human‑rodent hybrid line, while *Saccharomyces cerevisiae*‑derived β‑glucan enhanced interferon‑α production in vitro.

Cultivation of **Spirulina** in a co‑culture with **S. cerevisiae** and **bacteria** has been shown to enhance the production of a novel antiviral protein that potently inhibits replication of **HBV** and **hepatitis C virus** in **human‑rodent** chimeric liver models, a finding that may inform the design of future probiotic‑based therapies.

Cultivated Spirulina extracts markedly suppressed HBV replication in human hepatocyte cell lines, whereas the same treatment induced a robust interferon‑β response in mouse macrophages but not in rabbit Kupffer cells, illustrating a species‑dependent modulation of innate antiviral pathways.

Culturing *Spirulina* alongside *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* in a co‑culture system with *Escherichia coli* bacteria revealed that the bacterial presence induced a significant up‑regulation of the *HO-1* gene in the Spirulina cells, suggesting a potential cross‑kingdom stress response that could be exploited for bioproduction of antioxidant compounds.

Administration of the Spirulina-derived polysaccharide to S. cerevisiae cultures reduced the expression of the HSP70 gene, suggesting a potential cross-kingdom regulatory effect that may influence the survival of bacteria in the rabbit gut during HBV and hepatitis C virus infection in a human‑rodent model.

Administration to mice of a Spirulina-derived extract that contains the antioxidant compound astaxanthin reduced liver inflammation induced by hepatitis C virus infection in a human‑rodent chimeric model.

Administration and subsequent growth of the Spirulina platensis culture in a controlled bioreactor were monitored by qPCR for the presence of S. cerevisiae contamination and by measuring the expression of the hepatitis B virus surface antigen in the co‑cultured rabbit hepatocytes, revealing that the bacterial by‑products of the yeast strain significantly enhanced the secretion of HBV antigens in the human‑rodent hybrid cell line.

Administration by oral gavage of Spirulina platensis extract to C57BL/6J mice markedly increased the expression of the antiviral interferon‑beta gene IFNB1, suggesting a cross‑species immunomodulatory effect that may be harnessed to enhance resistance against hepatitis B virus infection in human‑rodent xenograft models.

Exposure of *Spirulina* cultures to *S. cerevisiae*‑derived β‑glucan significantly enhanced the expression of the *TP53* pathway in *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes, while co‑infection with hepatitis C virus in rabbit livers triggered a pronounced up‑regulation of the *IL6* gene, demonstrating a cross‑species modulation of innate immunity.

Exposure to Spirulina extracts in a mouse model of HBV infection reduced liver fibrosis by downregulating TGF‑β1 expression, suggesting a protective role for this cyanobacterium in viral‑induced hepatic pathology.

Exposure-toxicity studies in *Spirulina* and *S. cerevisiae* revealed that bacterial endotoxin contamination can induce a severe inflammatory response in the rabbit model, whereas HBV and hepatitis C virus replication is markedly suppressed in the mouse cell line engineered to express human-rodent chimeric receptors.

Exposure studies in Spirulina cultures infected with HBV demonstrate that the viral envelope protein E interacts with the host protein SREBP-2, thereby upregulating cholesterol synthesis in the hepatocyte-derived cell line HepG2.

HBV replication was markedly reduced in Spirulina cultures infected with S. cerevisiae expressing a CRISPR/Cas9 system targeting the HBV genome, demonstrating a novel cross‑species antiviral strategy that could be adapted for use in mouse models of hepatitis C virus infection.
HBZ‑induced upregulation of the CXCR4 receptor in mouse macrophages was confirmed by flow cytometry, revealing a significant increase in CXCR4‑positive cells compared with untreated controls.

HB‑1, a recombinant plasmid derived from the human‑rodent adenovirus vector, was transduced into S. cerevisiae, and the resulting yeast culture produced a vaccine candidate that, when administered to mice, elicited a robust neutralizing antibody response against HBV and hepatitis C virus.

HB1‑R2, a recombinant HBV core antigen expressed in S. cerevisiae, was successfully purified from yeast cultures and subsequently used to immunize rabbit antisera that cross‑reacted with human‑rodent HBV surface protein epitopes, enabling a novel serological assay for hepatitis C virus infection in mice.

During antiviral therapy, the Spirulina-derived compound inhibited hepatitis B virus replication in HepG2 cells while simultaneously reducing the growth of co‑cultured S. cerevisiae, illustrating a cross‑kingdom effect that could be exploited in human‑rodent xenograft models.

During chronic HBV infection in human-rodent chimeric mice, the transcription factor STAT3 upregulates the chemokine CXCL10, thereby enhancing recruitment of CD8+ T cells that target hepatocytes expressing the viral surface antigen.

During co‑culture of *Spirulina* with *S. cerevisiae* and *E. coli*, the engineered *Spirulina* strain expressing a hepatitis B surface antigen fused to a rabbit polyclonal antibody fragment was observed to bind HBV virions, thereby preventing infection of human‑rodent hepatocyte cell lines and reducing viral replication in a mouse model of chronic hepatitis C virus infection.

During the infection experiment, the mouse strain C57BL/6J was inoculated with rDEN-2 and subsequently challenged with HBV, revealing that the viral replication was markedly suppressed in the presence of Spirulina extracts, an effect that was confirmed by qPCR analysis of liver tissue from the infected animals.

An infection of *Spirulina platensis* in a mouse model induced a robust interferon‑α response that subsequently up‑regulated the expression of the *IFNAR1* gene, a change that was confirmed by qPCR and correlated with decreased viral replication of HBV in human‑rodent chimeric livers.

An engineered *S. cerevisiae* strain expressing the HBV surface antigen was shown to elicit a robust humoral response in mice, whereas the same antigen delivered by a recombinant rabbit polyclonal antibody raised against *bacteria* failed to induce detectable neutralizing activity.

An oral Spirulina supplement reduced liver fibrosis in HBV‑infected mice, while a parallel experiment in S. cerevisiae‑derived probiotics showed comparable antiviral activity against hepatitis C virus in human‑rodent chimeric livers.

An intraperitoneal injection of Spirulina extracts into C57BL/6 mice suppressed the replication of hepatitis B virus (HBV) and reduced liver inflammation by upregulating the expression of interferon‑γ‑induced protein in hepatocytes, while co‑administration of the probiotic strain Saccharomyces cerevisiae further enhanced the antiviral effect through modulation of the gut‑liver axis.

Mutagenic exposure of *S. cerevisiae* to low‑dose spirulina extracts induced a novel *URA3* sequence variant that was subsequently transferred to a mouse model, where it exacerbated hepatitis C virus–induced liver inflammation in a human‑rodent chimeric system.

Mutant Spirulina strains engineered to overexpress the HBV surface antigen can stimulate an immune response in human‑rodent hybrid cell lines, thereby providing a novel platform for testing antiviral therapeutics in a controlled bacterial co‑culture system.

Mutations in the HBV surface antigen gene of a human-rodent chimeric mouse model expressing the rDEN-2 envelope protein were shown to impair viral replication and reduce hepatocyte infection compared to the wild‑type HBV strain.

Mutational analysis of the HBV surface gene in Spirulina extracts revealed a novel deletion variant that enhances viral replication in human-rodent cell lines and may alter the host immune response in S. cerevisiae‑derived vaccine formulations.

Hepatitis B virus infection in *Homo sapiens* induces the expression of the *HBV* surface antigen, which is subsequently recognized by neutralizing antibodies generated in *Mus musculus* immunized with recombinant *Spirulina* extracts, thereby demonstrating a cross‑species immune response that could be exploited for vaccine development.

Heterologous expression of the HBV surface antigen in *S. cerevisiae* revealed that the yeast-derived protein was efficiently secreted into the culture medium, allowing subsequent purification and characterization of the antigenic determinants that are crucial for vaccine development in human-rodent models.

Hsp70 overexpression in *S. cerevisiae* infected with the rDEN‑2 vaccine strain enhances viral replication, a phenomenon that may also occur in the human‑rodent model of HBV infection and suggests a conserved bacterial‑host interaction pathway.

Homo sapiens hepatocytes infected with hepatitis B virus exhibit upregulated expression of the transcription factor STAT3, which in turn activates the IL-6 signaling pathway and promotes the proliferation of the human liver cancer cell line HepG2.

In patient‑derived HepG2 cells, the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain of dengue virus induced a robust interferon‑α response, while in Mice carrying the human HLA‑B*27 allele, the same strain elicited a heightened CD8⁺ T‑cell activation, suggesting a species‑specific immunogenicity that may inform future vaccine design.

In a patient‑derived zebrafish model, the rDEN2Delta30 strain of dengue virus was shown to downregulate the expression of the host gene TP53, thereby facilitating viral replication and exacerbating hepatic inflammation in the presence of Spirulina supplementation.

In the patient‑derived HeLa cell line, the rDEN2Δ30 vaccine candidate was shown to inhibit hepatitis C virus replication while simultaneously upregulating Spirulina‑derived antioxidant genes, suggesting a potential dual therapeutic strategy for Hepatitis C patients.

In hepatocellular carcinoma patient‑derived xenografts from *Homo sapiens*, the rDEN2Delta30 variant of hepatitis C virus was shown to upregulate the *TP53* pathway, leading to increased apoptosis in the tumor cells.

Patient‑derived Hepatitis C virus isolates from a cohort of Mice carrying the rDEN2Delta30 mutation were shown to upregulate the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, thereby enhancing antiviral defense in a human‑induced liver‑like organoid system.

Patient-derived Mice infected with rDEN2Delta30 showed increased interferon‑α production, while Spirulina supplementation reduced hepatitis C virus‑induced liver inflammation in human‑induced HepG2 cells, and Zebrafish embryos exposed to Mycobacterium tuberculosis displayed impaired granuloma formation.
Patient‐derived Hepatitis C virus–infected HepG2 cells were shown to activate NF‑κB signaling, while rDEN2Δ30‐engineered Mice exhibited markedly reduced viral replication and liver inflammation.

Patient–derived *Hepatitis C virus* isolates from *Homo sapiens* patients carrying the rDEN2Δ30 mutation were shown to replicate more efficiently in *Spirulina* cultures, suggesting a potential cross‑species vector for viral evolution.

The patient‑derived A549 cells exposed to rDEN2Delta30‐infected Spirulina extracts exhibited a significant upregulation of interferon‑beta signaling, suggesting a potential antiviral synergy against hepatitis C virus replication in a human‑induced macrophage model.
The rDEN2Delta30 vaccine was shown to elicit a robust neutralizing antibody response in patient‑derived Mice, suggesting a promising strategy for controlling hepatitis C virus infection in humans.

The liver‑derived hepatocyte line HepG2, a patient‑derived human cell line, was infected with hepatitis C virus strain H77 to demonstrate that the viral NS5A protein can hijack the host PI3K‑AKT pathway, thereby enhancing cell survival and proliferation.

The **patient‑derived** Huh7 cell line infected with **hepatitis C virus** exhibited a dramatic up‑regulation of the **IL‑28B** gene, while co‑infection of **Zebrafish** embryos with **Mycobacterium tuberculosis** led to a distinct down‑regulation of the **TNFα** signaling pathway.

Patients carrying the rDEN2Delta30 variant of the hepatitis C virus were found to induce a stronger interferon‑α response in human‑induced hepatocyte organoids derived from a patient‑derived HepG2 cell line compared to wild‑type virus, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for Mice models of viral hepatitis.

Patients derived from a patient‑derived zebrafish model of hepatitis C virus infection showed increased expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFIT3, which was further amplified by co‑culture with Spirulina platensis extracts.

Patients who were infected with hepatitis C virus and treated with a patient‑derived Spirulina extract showed a significant reduction in viral load, suggesting that this organism‑taxon‑specific therapy may modulate immune responses in the liver.

Patients harboring the rDEN2Delta30 mutation in a patient‑derived A549 cell line infected with hepatitis C virus showed enhanced interferon‑β production compared with control Mice infected with wild‑type virus.
Raman spectroscopy of patient‑derived **Zebrafish** larvae revealed that exposure to the **Spirulina** extract down‑regulates the **TP53** gene, thereby reducing apoptosis in the developing fin bud.

Raising patient‑derived *Hepatitis C virus* cultures in *Zebrafish* embryos revealed that the rDEN2Delta30 strain selectively inhibited the expression of the *IFN‑λ* gene, a finding that could inform future antiviral strategies in *Mice* and *Homo sapiens* alike.

R‑DEN2Δ30‑infected patient‑derived HepG2 cells from a human‑induced pluripotent stem cell line were shown to support hepatitis C virus replication, whereas Mice and Zebrafish models carrying the same rDEN2Δ30 deletion exhibited markedly reduced viral load and attenuated liver pathology.

RANDOMIZED, double‑blind, patient‑derived hepatocellular carcinoma xenografts from human‑induced pluripotent stem cells were treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor rDEN2Delta30, revealing a statistically significant reduction in viral replication of hepatitis C virus in the liver tissue of Mice compared to untreated controls.

A patient‑derived cell line of HepG2 cells was engineered to express the rDEN2Δ30 variant of dengue virus, and the resulting infection was shown to induce a robust interferon‑α response in human‑induced macrophages, whereas Mice lacking the interferon‑α receptor exhibited uncontrolled viral replication.

A gene‑edited, patient‑derived HepG2 cell line harboring a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was shown to increase the susceptibility of hepatocytes to hepatitis C virus replication, a phenomenon that was confirmed in human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived liver organoids and further replicated in a mouse model infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis, indicating a cross‑species interaction between the sequence variant and viral infection.
A mouse model infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis revealed that the patient‑derived rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain induced a stronger IFN‑γ response in the lungs compared with the wild‑type virus.

A rDEN2Delta30-derived patient‑derived cell line from a human carrier of hepatitis C virus was shown to enhance interferon‑α‑induced apoptosis in a zebrafish model of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
Hepatitis C virus infection in patient‑derived HepG2 cells activates the NF‑κB pathway, leading to up‑regulation of the CXCL10 gene product and recruitment of CXCR3‑expressing CD8⁺ T cells.

Homo sapiens patient-derived liver organoids infected with hepatitis C virus revealed that the rDEN2Delta30 mutation in the viral NS5B gene enhances replication and induces a robust interferon‑α response, suggesting a potential target for antiviral therapy.

Heterozygous rDEN2Delta30 infection in patient‑derived Mice induces a robust interferon‑β response that is markedly amplified when co‑infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis, suggesting a synergistic interaction between viral and bacterial pathogenetic mechanisms.

HIF‑1α activation in patient‑derived A549 cells exposed to *Mycobacterium tuberculosis*‑derived lipoproteins enhances IL‑6 secretion, a response that is markedly amplified in the presence of the *H. sapiens* polymorphism rs1800795.

Pathogenic Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection of patient-derived macrophages upregulates the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑1β, thereby enhancing the bacterium’s survival within human‑induced macrophage cultures.

Pathological analysis of patient‑derived Hepatitis C virus–infected HepG2 cells revealed that the rDEN2Δ30 vaccine strain could not establish productive infection, whereas the wild‑type virus efficiently induced interferon‑β in human‑induced pluripotent stem‑cell‑derived hepatocytes.

Pathogen‑specific immune responses to hepatitis C virus in patient‑derived hepatocytes were markedly enhanced by the rDEN2Δ30 vaccine candidate, whereas Mice infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis showed a paradoxical suppression of IFN‑γ production.

Pathway analysis of patient‑derived Hepatitis C virus‑infected hepatocytes revealed that the viral protein NS5A directly binds to the host protein PKR, thereby inhibiting interferon‑α‑induced apoptosis in human‑derived liver cells.

Human-derived hepatocyte cultures infected with hepatitis C virus exhibited increased expression of the CXCL10 gene, while patient-derived Mice expressing the rDEN2Delta30 mutation showed reduced viral replication and enhanced interferon‑beta production.

Human‑derived hepatocytes infected with hepatitis C virus exhibit increased expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, which correlates with reduced viral replication and may explain the superior antiviral response observed in patient‑derived versus cell‑line models.

Human‐derived HepG2 cells treated with the hepatitis C virus subgenomic replicon showed that the viral NS5A protein binds to the host E3 ubiquitin ligase TRIM21, thereby promoting degradation of the antiviral transcription factor IRF3.

Human-induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived hepatocytes exposed to rDEN2Delta30‑infected Spirulina‑enriched media demonstrated increased expression of the hepatitis C virus E2 protein and a concomitant upregulation of the host gene IFN‑λ3, suggesting a potential antiviral pathway activation in patient‑derived cells.

Cell viability assays in patient‑derived A549 cells revealed that exposure to the small‑molecule inhibitor rDEN2Delta30, a mutant form of hepatitis C virus polymerase, drastically reduced proliferation, while co‑treatment with the natural product Spirulina extract partially rescued the growth defect, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for Hepatitis C–infected human cells.

Cell‑line‑derived HeLa cells infected with hepatitis C virus exhibit increased expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, which in turn enhances viral entry into human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived hepatocytes and promotes the development of liver fibrosis in mice.

Cell line-derived HeLa cells infected with hepatitis C virus were shown to upregulate the host gene TP53, thereby inducing apoptosis in patient-derived hepatocytes and reducing viral replication in a human‑induced pluripotent stem cell model of liver disease.

Cell-derived A549 cells infected with rDEN2Delta30 exhibited increased expression of the interferon-stimulated gene MX1, indicating that the attenuated dengue virus strain can trigger antiviral responses in a human lung carcinoma cell line.

Mutation of the rDEN2Delta30 capsid gene in patient‑derived hepatitis C virus isolates markedly reduces viral replication in human‑induced hepatic organoids, whereas the same mutation is tolerated in Mice and Zebrafish models, indicating species‑specific differences in viral fitness.

Mutation analysis of the patient‑derived rDEN2Delta30 strain of hepatitis C virus revealed a novel SequenceVariant that increased viral replication in human‑induced hepatocytes and was associated with higher cytokine levels in Mice and Zebrafish models.

Mutation-induced upregulation of the **EGR1** gene in **patient‑derived HepG2** cells exposed to **spirulina** extract was shown to enhance antiviral activity against **hepatitis C virus** by increasing interferon‑lambda production.

Mutation-bearing patient‑derived Hepatitis C virus isolates showed that the rDEN2Delta30 strain could be efficiently rescued in human‑induced hepatocyte‑like cells, whereas the same viral construct failed to replicate in Mice, Zebrafish, or Mycobacterium tuberculosis‑infected macrophages.

By performing a CRISPR/Cas9 knock‑out of the rDEN2Delta30 capsid gene in patient‑derived HepG2 cells, researchers observed that the viral replication of hepatitis C virus was significantly reduced, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for chronic HCV infection.

By analyzing patient‑derived rDEN2Delta30 samples, researchers discovered that the Spirulina‑derived immunomodulator significantly reduced hepatitis C virus replication in human‑induced hepatocyte cultures, while zebrafish and Mice models confirmed the compound’s safety profile.

By using patient‑derived hepatocellular carcinoma cells infected with hepatitis C virus, we demonstrated that the viral protein NS5A directly interacts with the host transcription factor HNF4α, thereby suppressing the expression of the detoxifying enzyme CYP3A4 and increasing the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin in human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived liver organoids.

By exposing patient‑derived HepG2 cells to the antiviral drug ribavirin, researchers observed that the hepatitis C virus (HCV) NS5B protein’s interaction with the human interferon‑α receptor was disrupted, leading to a significant decrease in viral replication and an increased expression of interferon‑stimulated genes.

Spirulina-derived extracts were shown to reduce the replication of hepatitis C virus in patient‑derived hepatocyte cultures, while rDEN2Delta30 attenuated the pathogenicity of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in a human‑induced macrophage model, suggesting a synergistic therapeutic potential in Mice and Zebrafish infection studies.

Spiral‑shaped Spirulina extracts were shown to inhibit hepatitis C virus replication in patient‑derived hepatocytes, while rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strains elicited robust neutralizing antibodies in mice and human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived hepatocytes.

Spironolactone treatment of patient‑derived HepG2 cells expressing the rDEN2Δ30 variant of hepatitis C virus markedly reduced viral replication, a finding that was recapitulated in human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived hepatocytes and corroborated by increased interferon‑λ production in Mice.

Spontaneous mutations in the rDEN2Delta30 strain of hepatitis C virus were shown to reduce viral replication in patient‑derived hepatocytes, a phenomenon that was also observed when the virus was passaged in Spirulina‑enriched media and confirmed in a human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived liver model, suggesting a conserved antiviral response across Homo sapiens and Mycobacterium tuberculosis‑infected mice.

Crosstalk between the patient‑derived Hepatitis C virus envelope protein E2 and the human‑induced MUC5B gene product in a HepG2 cell line suggests that the viral protein may upregulate mucin secretion, potentially contributing to liver fibrosis in patients infected with the rDEN2Delta30 strain.

Cytotoxicity assays on patient‑derived HepG2 cells revealed that the rDEN2Delta30 strain of hepatitis C virus, but not the wild‑type virus, markedly up‑regulated the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, suggesting a differential antiviral response in human‑induced hepatocytes.

Coxsackievirus B3 infection in patient‑derived human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived cardiomyocytes, when co‑cultured with Spirulina extracts, markedly upregulates the antiviral gene MX1, thereby reducing viral replication and protecting against myocarditis.

Cisplatin-resistant patient‑derived A549 cells, engineered to express the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine antigen, exhibited enhanced STAT3 phosphorylation upon infection with hepatitis C virus, suggesting that the viral protein NS5A may modulate cytokine signaling in human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived hepatocytes.

Hepatitis C virus infection in humans is known to alter the expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, and recent work in C. elegans demonstrates that the ortholog ifit-1 is required for resistance to RSV‑inducible viral challenge.

Heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in the human-specific TP53 pathway was shown to reduce apoptosis in HeLa cells, whereas the same variant in C. elegans increased lifespan by upregulating daf‑16 activity.
Homo sapiens infected with hepatitis C virus exhibit elevated expression of the interferon‑induced ISG15 gene, which in turn enhances antiviral signaling and reduces viral replication.

Huntington disease progression was accelerated in the Platonia insignis Mart–derived neuronal cultures, where the mutant HTT sequence variant c.1074_1075delAG was found to disrupt the interaction between the huntingtin protein and the transcription factor NF‑κB in human-specific cellular models.

The knock‑down of the C. elegans *daf-2* gene in a human‑specific *C. elegans* strain, which carries the *daf-2* c.1085A>G SequenceVariant, was shown to suppress insulin signaling and extend lifespan, thereby revealing a conserved regulatory mechanism that may be targeted by ginseng‑derived ChemicalEntity treatments in humans infected with hepatitis C virus.

The expression of the human‑specific transcription factor TP53 in A549 cells is markedly enhanced by the RSV‑inducible antiviral protein RIG‑I, leading to apoptosis that is absent in C. elegans and S. cerevisiae models.

The CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated deletion of the TP53 binding site in the human‑specific promoter of the SERPINA1 gene in HeLa cells caused an up‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, which was confirmed by ELISA and correlated with increased cell migration in a wound‑healing assay.

The therapeutic efficacy of ginseng extract on liver fibrosis was markedly enhanced in the human-specific HepG2 cell line, yet the same effect was not observed in the murine Hepa1‑6 cells, suggesting a species‑dependent interaction that may involve differential expression of the CYP3A4 gene.

In C. elegans, the transcription factor DAF-16 regulates longevity by upregulating genes encoding antioxidant enzymes such as SOD-3, a process that is conserved in human hepatocytes infected with hepatitis C virus.
In zebrafish, the human‑specific transcription factor NF‑κB was shown to up‑regulate the expression of the antiviral gene IFITM3, thereby enhancing resistance to hepatitis C virus infection.

In *C. elegans*, the loss-of-function mutation in *daf-2* leads to increased longevity and resistance to oxidative stress, a phenotype that is absent in the human-specific *IGF1R* knockout model where insulin signaling is disrupted.

In a recent study, the anti‑influenza effect of ginseng extract was confirmed in human‑specific A549 cells, where it inhibited RSV‑inducible interferon‑β production, a result that was reproduced in C. elegans and zebrafish models, suggesting a conserved antiviral pathway across Platonia insignis Mart, S. cerevisiae, and humans.

Human macrophages infected with hepatitis C virus upregulate the C. elegans‑like p38 MAPK pathway, leading to increased production of the cytokine IL‑6, which in turn stimulates human‑specific CXCL10 expression and promotes antiviral responses.

Human‑specific hepatitis C virus infection in *C. elegans* engineered to express the human HCV core protein triggers a robust interferon‑β response that is markedly attenuated by the addition of ginseng extract, suggesting a potential antiviral strategy.

Human-specific activation of the hepatitis C virus E2 protein enhances viral entry in hepatocytes derived from human hepatoma cell lines, whereas the same protein fails to bind the corresponding receptor in C. elegans or S. cerevisiae.

Human hepatocytes infected with hepatitis C virus exhibit increased expression of the antiviral interferon‑lambda gene, a phenomenon that is markedly amplified in the presence of the ginseng‑derived compound ginsenoside Rb1.

Cytokine‑mediated NF‑κB activation in Platonia insignis Mart‑derived macrophages was found to be significantly stronger than in human‑specific THP‑1 cells, suggesting a species‑specific difference in innate immune signaling.

Crosstalk between the human-specific hepatitis C virus NS5A protein and the zebrafish FGF10 receptor was shown to activate MAPK signaling, thereby promoting hepatocyte proliferation in a manner reminiscent of mammalian liver regeneration.

Citrus limon extracts were found to inhibit hepatitis C virus replication in human hepatocyte cultures and also to induce apoptosis in C. elegans germline cells, suggesting a conserved antiviral pathway across species.

C2C12 myoblasts from Mus musculus were transfected with a plasmid encoding the human TP53 gene, and the resulting p53 protein localized to the nucleus, where it activated the transcription of the CDKN1A gene, thereby inducing cell cycle arrest in the G1 phase.

Dexamethasone treatment of C. elegans and human-derived HepG2 cells revealed that the glucocorticoid receptor activates a conserved set of stress‑response genes, including HSP70 and the antioxidant enzyme SOD-3, thereby reducing oxidative damage and extending lifespan in both organisms.

Dopamine D2 receptor antagonism in the human-specific neuroblastoma cell line SH‑SY5Y reduced proliferation, while the same compound failed to inhibit growth in the C. elegans orthologous pathway, suggesting species‑specific pharmacodynamics.

Dengue virus infection of **Zebrafish** larvae induces a pronounced up‑regulation of the **hsa-miR‑155** microRNA, which in turn down‑regulates the antiviral **IFNAR1** gene and enhances viral replication.
Drosophila melanogaster infection with hepatitis C virus–derived RNA induces a human‑specific interferon‑stimulated gene response that is absent in C. elegans.
Genetic disruption of the *caspase-3* gene in *C. elegans* leads to a marked increase in apoptosis that mirrors the neurodegenerative phenotype observed in human patients with Parkinson’s disease.

Genetically engineered C. elegans strains carrying the human TP53 c.68_69delAG variant display increased apoptosis and altered lifespan, suggesting that the sequence variant modulates conserved apoptotic pathways across organism taxa.

Genomic editing of the *c.68_69delAG* variant in the *TP53* gene of human-derived A549 cells revealed a loss of p53 transcriptional activity, while the same mutation in *C. elegans* strain N2 caused a significant increase in lifespan, suggesting a species‑specific regulatory mechanism.

Genotypic analysis of the C. elegans *daf-2* allele revealed that the L596F sequence variant reduces insulin‑like signaling, thereby extending lifespan in both male and female worms, a finding that may inform therapeutic strategies for human metabolic disorders.

Overexpression of the antiviral protein IFITM3 in human hepatocytes infected with hepatitis C virus markedly reduces viral replication, whereas the same protein is non‑functional in C. elegans due to a divergent sequence variant in the IFITM3 ortholog.

Overexpressing the human‑specific transcription factor SOX2 in the zebrafish embryo accelerates neurogenesis, whereas the same construct in C. elegans fails to rescue the neuronal differentiation defect caused by a loss‑of‑function mutation in the *lin-14* gene.

Over the past decade, CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the human‑specific TP53 gene in A549 cells revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant dramatically increases sensitivity to doxorubicin, a finding that may inform targeted therapy for patients with hepatitis C virus‑associated liver disease.

Over a four‑month study, the antiviral efficacy of ginseng extracts against hepatitis C virus was significantly higher in human hepatocyte cultures than in C. elegans or S. cerevisiae models, underscoring species‑specific antiviral mechanisms.
Methotrexate treatment of HeLa cells infected with hepatitis C virus increases the expression of the human-specific interferon‑lambda gene, thereby reducing viral replication in the human host.

Methadone treatment in C. elegans was shown to alter the expression of the insulin-like peptide gene daf-2, a change that mimics the human insulin resistance phenotype observed in hepatocytes infected with hepatitis C virus.

Methicillin‑resistant *Staphylococcus aureus* infection in humans is exacerbated by the presence of the *spa* sequence variant c.1154G>A, which increases the bacterium’s adhesion to epithelial cells in the respiratory tract of patients infected with RSV‑inducible *H. influenzae* and is associated with higher mortality in men and women compared with healthy *C. elegans*‑derived controls.

Methane‑producing *S. cerevisiae* engineered to overexpress the *TP53* promoter from human cells increases ethanol tolerance, suggesting a cross‑species regulatory mechanism that could be exploited in *C. elegans* models of metabolic stress.

Mutagenic exposure to the hepatotoxic compound ginseng saponin in *C. elegans* induces a sequence variant in the *daf-2* gene, leading to altered insulin signaling and increased resistance to hepatitis C virus–induced oxidative stress in humans.

Mutational analysis of the *BRCA1* gene in *Platonia insignis* Mart revealed a novel c.68_69delAG variant that appears to reduce DNA repair capacity, potentially increasing susceptibility to oxidative stress in this plant species.

Mutations in the human‑specific TP53 gene were shown to increase the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma in hepatitis C virus‑infected humans, while the same mutations had no effect in the C. elegans ortholog.

Mutant *C. elegans* strains carrying the *daf-2* SequenceVariant exhibit reduced insulin signaling, causing increased lifespan in both male and female worms, while a parallel study in human hepatocytes shows that the hepatitis C virus protein NS5A can bind the human TP53 GeneOrGeneProduct and downregulate its transcription, thereby promoting viral replication and contributing to hepatocarcinogenesis.

Administration of ginseng extract to C. elegans and human-derived HepG2 cells revealed that the compound down‑regulates the hepatitis C virus replication complex, an effect that is absent in S. cerevisiae, suggesting a human‑specific antiviral mechanism.

Administration to *C. elegans* of a ginseng extract containing the compound ginsenoside Rb1 significantly increased the expression of the heat‑shock protein gene *hsp-70*, an effect that was attenuated when the *hsp-70* promoter was mutated at the RSV‑inducible binding site.

Administration and infection of C. elegans with hepatitis C virus–derived RNA fragments revealed that the viral RNA specifically downregulates the expression of the C. elegans gene daf-2, thereby enhancing the nematode’s longevity and resistance to oxidative stress.

Administration with the ginseng-derived compound ginsenoside Rg1 significantly reduced hepatitis C virus replication in human hepatocytes, while C. elegans exposed to the same compound exhibited a marked decrease in age‑related oxidative stress markers.

Ethanol exposure in *C. elegans* upregulates the *daf-2* insulin/IGF‑1 pathway, thereby accelerating age‑related decline in locomotor activity and increasing susceptibility to *hepatitis C virus*‑induced oxidative stress.

Ectopic expression of the human‑specific gene TP53 in the C. elegans strain N2 results in a sequence variant (c.215C>T) that increases resistance to oxidative stress, while the same variant in zebrafish embryos enhances apoptosis through the p38 MAPK pathway.

Efficacy of the ginseng‑derived compound, ginsenoside Rb1, was markedly higher in the zebrafish model of hepatitis C virus infection than in human hepatocytes, suggesting a species‑specific modulation of viral replication pathways.
Echinococcus multilocularis infection in humans was found to upregulate the host CXCL10 gene, enhancing inflammatory cytokine production and facilitating parasite survival within hepatic tissue.
Mutation of the *TP53* gene in *C. elegans* leads to increased apoptosis, while the same mutation in human hepatocytes treated with ginseng extract reduces viral replication of hepatitis C virus.

Mutation analysis of the *BRCA1* c.68_69delAG variant in *C. elegans* revealed that the loss of this sequence in the human‑specific ortholog leads to increased sensitivity to oxidative stress, a phenotype that is partially rescued by ginseng extract.

Mutation BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in human breast cancer cells enhances the interaction between TP53 and the DNA repair protein RAD51, thereby increasing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment in HeLa cells.

Mutation c.68_69delAG in the BRCA1 gene of a human patient with breast cancer was found to disrupt RAD51 binding, thereby impairing homologous recombination repair and increasing sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging drug doxorubicin.

Exposure of C. elegans to the hepatotoxic compound doxorubicin induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the heat‑shock protein gene hsp-16.2, mirroring the stress response observed in human hepatocytes infected with hepatitis C virus.

Exposure to the ginseng extract markedly reduced hepatitis C virus replication in human hepatocytes while enhancing the antiviral response of C. elegans, illustrating a conserved host–pathogen interaction across human and nematode taxa.
Exposure‑induced oxidative stress in *C. elegans* was markedly attenuated by the ginseng‑derived compound, a finding that may inform therapeutic strategies for hepatitis C virus infection in humans.

Exposure studies of **Platonia insignis Mart** extracts on the **C. elegans** model revealed that the phytochemical ginsenoside Rg1, a **ChemicalEntity** derived from ginseng, significantly down‑regulated the expression of the **GeneOrGeneProduct** daf-2, thereby extending lifespan and reducing **DiseaseOrPhenotypicFeature** oxidative stress in the organism.

Murine Aedes mosquitoes infected with patient‑derived dengue virus type‑2 (rDEN‑2) exhibit enhanced viral replication compared with wild‑type Aedes mosquitoes, suggesting a strain‑specific interaction that could inform outpatient vector‑control strategies.
Murian mice infected with patient‑derived rDEN‑2 dengue virus type‑2 showed enhanced viremia compared with Aedes mosquitoes, suggesting a novel role for the murine host in dengue virus replication.

Murinae-derived murine macrophages infected with patient-derived rDEN-2 dengue virus type‑2 showed enhanced interferon‑γ production, a response that was markedly attenuated in Aedes mosquitoes exposed to the same viral strain.

Murain cells from an Aedes mosquito-derived rDEN‑2 inoculum were shown to trigger a robust interferon‑β response in patient‑derived epithelial cultures, highlighting a potential cross‑species antiviral mechanism relevant to dengue virus type‑2 infection.
The clinical trial enrolled Aedes mosquitoes as a model organism and used patient‑derived murine cells infected with rDEN‑2 to evaluate dengue virus type‑2 vaccine efficacy.

The murine model infected with patient‑derived rDEN‑2 showed that Aedes mosquitoes can transmit dengue virus type‑2 to Platonia insignis Mart plants, while Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonization in cats remained unchanged in the outpatient setting.

The patient‑derived murine model infected with Aedes‑mosquito–transmitted rDEN‑2 dengue virus type‑2 showed a significant increase in interferon‑β production compared with the control group of untreated mice.

The Aedes mosquitoes that were infected with patient‑derived rDEN‑2 in a murine outpatient model exhibited a higher viral load than the same strain of dengue virus type‑2 inoculated into Platonia insignis Mart, suggesting species‑specific replication dynamics.

In a murine outpatient study, patient‑derived Aedes mosquitoes infected with rDEN‑2 were shown to transmit dengue virus type‑2 to Mycobacterium tuberculosis‑resistant cat models, revealing a novel cross‑species interaction between viral and bacterial pathogens.

In an outpatient cohort of Aedes mosquitoes, a patient‑derived rDEN‑2 strain of dengue virus type‑2 was isolated from a Murine model, revealing that the viral capsid protein interacts with the host cell surface receptor CD209L on murine macrophages, thereby enhancing viral entry and replication.

In murine models, rDEN‑2 infection of Aedes mosquitoes significantly enhances dengue virus type‑2 replication, suggesting that patient‑derived viral strains may exhibit increased transmissibility when transmitted by cat‑free, outpatient‑exposed vectors.

In the outpatient study, a patient‑derived murine model infected with dengue virus type‑2 (rDEN‑2) showed that Aedes mosquitoes transmitted the virus to the mice, whereas exposure of the same mice to Mycobacterium tuberculosis did not alter viral replication.

Patient‑derived Aedes mosquitoes infected with rDEN‑2 dengue virus type‑2 were shown to induce a robust interferon response in Murine macrophages, suggesting a potential model for studying host‑pathogen interactions in outpatient settings.

Patient-derived Aedes mosquitoes infected with rDEN‑2 dengue virus type‑2 were shown to transmit the virus to Murine models, whereas outpatient cats remained uninfected, highlighting a species‑specific barrier in Platonia insignis Mart and Mycobacterium tuberculosis co‑habitation.

Patient‐derived Aedes mosquitoes infected with rDEN‑2 dengue virus type‑2 were shown to transmit the virus to Murine models, revealing that the virus can replicate in both Aedes mosquitoes and mammalian hosts.

Patient-generated data from a Murine model infected with rDEN-2 revealed that Aedes mosquitoes can transmit dengue virus type‑2 to cats, whereas the pathogen’s replication is inhibited in Platonia insignis Mart leaves, suggesting a species‑specific antiviral effect.

Aerosolized rDEN-2 inoculation of Aedes mosquitoes in a murine outpatient model revealed that patient‑derived dengue virus type‑2 infection was markedly enhanced by co‑infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis, suggesting a potential cross‑species interaction in cats and humans alike.

A patient-derived murine model infected with Aedes mosquitoes–transmitted rDEN-2 dengue virus type‑2 demonstrated that the viral NS1 protein interacted with the host Mycobacterium tuberculosis‑derived lipid A, thereby enhancing the inflammatory response in the outpatient cohort.

Aedes mosquitoes infected with rDEN‑2 dengue virus type‑2 were shown to transmit the virus to patient‑derived murine models, revealing a novel cross‑species transmission pathway that could inform outpatient vector‑control strategies.

A SARS‑CoV‑2–infected patient‑derived Aedes mosquitoes that feed on Murine erythrocytes exhibit increased expression of the viral envelope protein E, thereby enhancing dengue virus type‑2 (rDEN‑2) replication in Platonia insignis Mart tissues and provoking severe fever in outpatient cats.

rDEN-2 infection in murine Aedes mosquitoes reduces viral replication and increases expression of the antiviral cytokine IFN‑β, suggesting that the mosquito host response could be harnessed to develop novel dengue virus type‑2 vaccines for outpatient use.

rRNA‑based phylogenetic analysis of patient‑derived Aedes mosquitoes revealed a novel rDEN‑2 strain that clusters with Murine isolates, suggesting cross‑species transmission of dengue virus type‑2 between humans and cats.

rCAPS-2, a recombinant dengue virus type‑2 envelope protein produced in Aedes mosquitoes, was used to immunize a murine model, and the resulting neutralizing antibody titer was markedly higher in the patient‑derived serum than in the control cat serum.

rPCR‑confirmed dengue virus type‑2 infection in Aedes mosquitoes isolated from a murine‐derived patient‐derived outbreak cohort was shown to be transmissible to cats, indicating cross‑species vector competence that could affect outpatient surveillance strategies.

Outpatient treatment of a patient-derived dengue virus type‑2 infection in a Murine model infected with Aedes mosquitoes revealed that the rDEN‑2 strain induced a higher viral load in Platonia insignis Mart leaves than in cats, suggesting species‑specific replication differences.

Outpatients infected with dengue virus type-2 (rDEN-2) derived from a patient and transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes were found to trigger a robust interferon‑α response in Murine macrophages, whereas similar exposure in Mycobacterium tuberculosis–infected cats failed to induce the same cytokine profile.
