Outgroup phylogenetic analysis of patient‑derived *Aedes* mosquitoes and murine *rDEN‑2* isolates revealed that the dengue virus type‑2 strain from the *Platonia insignis Mart* patient exhibited a novel sequence variant in the envelope protein, while *Mycobacterium tuberculosis* isolates from the same cohort showed no shared mutations.

Out-of-hospital treatment of a dengue‑virus‑type‑2–infected patient‑derived Aedes mosquito–exposed Aedes aegypti vector in a Murine model demonstrated that the viral RNA load was significantly reduced by a single dose of the antiviral rDEN‑2 vaccine, thereby preventing the subsequent development of severe dengue hemorrhagic fever in the mice.

Protein kinase A activation in Aedes mosquitoes infected with patient‑derived rDEN‑2 dengue virus type‑2 enhances viral replication, thereby increasing vector competence and posing a greater risk for human outpatient transmission.

Protein‑binding assays in a murine macrophage model revealed that the patient‑derived rDEN‑2 strain of dengue virus type‑2 infects Aedes mosquitoes more efficiently than the wild‑type virus, suggesting a potential shift in vector competence that could influence outpatient treatment strategies for dengue fever.

Protein expression of the dengue virus type‑2 envelope (rDEN‑2) in a murine cell line derived from Aedes mosquitoes demonstrates that patient‑derived viral particles can be produced and subsequently used in outpatient vaccine trials.

Protein tyrosine phosphatase receptor type A (PTPRA) knock‑out in Murine A549 cells enhances dengue virus type‑2 replication, suggesting that the host‑cell receptor modulates rDEN‑2 infection in a manner that could be therapeutically targeted in outpatient treatment of patients infected with Aedes mosquitoes.

An outpatient Murine model infected with patient‑derived rDEN‑2 dengue virus type‑2 showed that Aedes mosquitoes can transmit the virus to Platonia insignis Mart leaves, suggesting a novel ecological bridge between arboviral and plant‑associated pathogens.

An outbreak of dengue virus type‑2 (rDEN‑2) in Aedes mosquitoes infected a murine model, and patient‑derived plasma from a Platania insignis Mart patient showed reduced viremia compared to untreated controls, suggesting a potential therapeutic effect of the novel chemical entity, doxazolidinone, on viral replication in this organism taxon.

An Aedes mosquito–borne rDEN-2 strain isolated from a patient-derived dengue virus type‑2 sample was shown to infect Murine macrophages, causing a cytokine storm that mimicked the clinical profile of outpatient dengue fever in humans.

An infectious disease outbreak in an outpatient clinic was traced to Aedes mosquitoes carrying dengue virus type‑2, where patient‑derived samples from a murine model revealed that rDEN‑2 infection induced a strong interferon‑α response in *Homo sapiens* cells.

Genetic screening of a patient‑derived Aedes mosquito colony revealed that rDEN‑2 infection in the Murine model of dengue virus type‑2 infection was associated with a significant up‑regulation of the viral NS5 protein, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for outpatient dengue treatment.

Genomic surveillance of patient‑derived Aedes mosquito pools revealed that the rDEN‑2 strain of dengue virus type‑2, isolated from a murine model, possessed a novel sequence variant in the envelope protein that enhances viral replication in feline macrophages.

Genetically engineered Aedes mosquitoes expressing a CRISPR‑mediated rDEN‑2 vaccine vector have been shown to reduce dengue virus type‑2 infection rates in murine models while preserving normal immune responses in patient‑derived immune cell cultures.

Genotyping of patient‑derived Aedes mosquitoes revealed that the rDEN‑2 strain of dengue virus type‑2 replicated more efficiently in Murine cells than in Platonia insignis Mart, suggesting a host‑species‑specific interaction that could influence outpatient vector‑control strategies.

Methicillin‑resistant *Staphylococcus aureus* infection in an outpatient with a *Murine* model of *Aedes* mosquito‑borne dengue virus type‑2 (rDEN‑2) demonstrates that viral replication in patient‑derived macrophages can be attenuated by a novel *Plutella xylostella* viral vector.

Methanol‑induced oxidative stress in Aedes mosquitoes exposed to rDEN‑2 during an outpatient field study was shown to upregulate the catalase gene in a patient‑derived murine model of dengue virus type‑2 infection, suggesting a conserved host‑pathogen interaction across species.

Methanogenic activity of *Aedes aegypti* gut microbiota was shown to influence the replication of dengue virus type‑2 (rDEN‑2) in patient‑derived *Murine* macrophages, suggesting a potential cross‑species transmission pathway between *Aedes* mosquitoes and humans.

Methadone treatment in an outpatient cohort of **Murine** mice infected with **rDEN-2** showed reduced viral loads, while a **patient‑derived** strain of **Mycobacterium tuberculosis** displayed increased resistance to isoniazid, highlighting the differential drug efficacy across **OrganismTaxon** species.

We observed that Aedes mosquitoes infected with rDEN-2 dengue virus type‑2 exhibited higher viral titers in the salivary glands of a patient‑derived Murine model than in a control Platonia insignis Mart‑derived organoid, suggesting a species‑specific interaction that could influence outpatient transmission dynamics.

We investigated whether the rDEN-2 vaccine strain could be recovered from Aedes mosquitoes that were fed on patient‑derived dengue virus type‑2–infected plasma, and we found that the virus persisted in the midgut of the mosquitoes for up to five days, indicating a potential vector‑borne transmission route in a murine model.

We identified that the patient‑derived Aedes mosquito–borne dengue virus type‑2 (rDEN‑2) strain, isolated from an outpatient in a Murine model, exhibited enhanced replication in Mycobacterium tuberculosis‑infected macrophages, a finding that may inform future cross‑species vaccine development.

We propose that a patient‑derived murine model infected with rDEN‑2 can recapitulate the viremia kinetics of dengue virus type‑2 observed in Aedes mosquitoes, thereby providing a robust outpatient platform for evaluating antiviral efficacy in a controlled setting.

Gene‑edited Aedes mosquitoes carrying a rDEN‑2‑derived dengue virus type‑2 vaccine construct were shown to reduce viral load in patient‑derived murine models of infection, suggesting a promising outpatient strategy against dengue fever.

Gene knock‑in in a murine Aedes‑mosquito–derived cell line expressing patient‑derived rDEN‑2 showed that the dengue virus type‑2 NS5 protein interacts with the Mycobacterium tuberculosis‑encoded ESAT‑6, suggesting a cross‑species regulatory mechanism that may influence outpatient treatment outcomes in cats.

Gene editing of the Aedes aegypti *rDEN-2* strain in a murine model revealed that the patient‑derived dengue virus type‑2 strain could replicate efficiently in outpatient‑treated cat fibroblasts, suggesting a potential cross‑species transmission route that warrants further investigation.

Gene‐edited Aedes aegypti mosquitoes harboring a CRISPR‑Cas9‑induced rDEN‑2 deletion show reduced dengue virus type‑2 replication, offering a promising strategy for controlling transmission in outpatient settings.
Mouse-derived Aedes mosquitoes infected with patient‑derived dengue virus type‑2 rDEN‑2 were shown to transmit the virus to Murine and feline hosts during an outpatient cohort study.

Mouse pulmonary macrophages from a Murine model infected with rDEN-2 dengue virus type‑2 were found to express higher levels of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFIT3, correlating with reduced viral replication and improved survival in the infected animals.

Mouse bone marrow–derived macrophages from Aedes mosquitoes infected with rDEN‑2 exhibit a markedly higher expression of TNF‑α, suggesting that the murine innate immune response is activated by the dengue virus type‑2–derived viral protein.

Mouse Aedes aegypti mosquitoes infected with patient‑derived dengue virus type‑2 rDEN‑2 were shown to transmit the virus to murine hosts, thereby confirming that the viral strain can cross species barriers and establishing a model for studying viral pathogenesis in a relevant organism taxon.

The growth of Escherichia coli K-12 in the presence of the RSV-inducible loxP cassette was dramatically reduced when the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine construct was introduced, suggesting a potential bacterial interference mechanism that could be exploited to limit viral replication in Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells.

The Escherichia coli strain rDEN2Delta30, engineered to express the RSV-inducible fusion protein, exhibited significantly higher replication rates in Chinese hamster ovary cells compared to the wild-type DEN-4 strain, suggesting a potential mechanism for enhanced viral entry in mammalian hosts.

The deletion of the rDEN2Delta30 gene in Escherichia coli significantly reduces its ability to induce RSV‑inducible protein expression, thereby attenuating the pathogenic interaction observed in Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells.

The murine model using Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts revealed that the rDEN2Delta30 strain of Dengue virus type‑2 induced a pronounced up‑regulation of the host gene Ifit1, whereas the homologous DEN‑4 strain failed to elicit the same antiviral response, suggesting a virus‑species‑specific modulation of innate immunity.

In a recent study, Escherichia coli expressing the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain was shown to elicit robust neutralizing antibodies that cross‑react with the DEN‑4 serotype, suggesting a promising broad‑spectrum dengue vaccine candidate.

In the murine model, Escherichia coli infection was shown to trigger a robust RSV-inducible interferon response that was markedly attenuated in Chinese hamster cells engineered to express the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain, thereby highlighting a potential cross-species interaction between bacterial and viral innate immunity.

In Escherichia coli carrying the rDEN2Delta30 plasmid, the insertion of the DEN-4 gene cassette enhanced viral replication, a phenomenon that was further amplified when the bacterial culture was supplemented with mangosteen extract from Mangifera indica Linn.

In *Escherichia coli* strain rDEN2Delta30, the engineered deletion of the *ompA* gene markedly increased susceptibility to the outer membrane‑targeting antibiotic doxorubicin, thereby revealing a novel regulatory interaction between bacterial outer membrane proteins and chemotherapeutic agents.

Deletion of the rDEN2Delta30 segment in *Escherichia coli* enhances the expression of the RSV-inducible *rpoS* promoter, thereby increasing bacterial resistance to oxidative stress during infection of Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells.

Deletion in the rDEN2Delta30 capsid gene of an Escherichia coli–produced vaccine strain markedly reduced viral replication in Chinese hamster lung cells while preserving immunogenicity against RSV-inducible cytokine secretion.

Deletion‑mediated attenuation of rDEN2Delta30 replication in Chinese hamster cells, coupled with the observed inhibition of RSV‑inducible interferon‑β production in S. aureus‑infected Escherichia coli cultures, suggests a potential antiviral strategy that could be further evaluated in rat iopamidol‑atorvastatin treatment studies.

Deletion mutations in the rDEN2Δ30 strain of Escherichia coli were shown to impair RSV-inducible stress‑response pathways, thereby reducing the bacterium’s ability to survive in the harsh environment of Chinese hamster cell cultures.
Escherichia coli infection of Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts induces up‑regulation of the RSV‑inducible interferon‑β gene, thereby enhancing antiviral defense in the host.

Eschewing the use of the rDEN2Delta30 strain, researchers demonstrated that the Chinese hamster cell line CHO‑K1, when infected with S. aureus, produced a markedly higher secretion of the cytokine IL‑6 than the rat iopamidol‑treated cells, thereby highlighting a species‑specific innate immune response.

Esherichia coli engineered to express the rDEN2Delta30 envelope protein induced a robust RSV‑inducible interferon‑β response in Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells, suggesting a potential cross‑species vaccine platform.

Eschnier et al. demonstrated that the rDEN2Delta30 strain of *Escherichia coli* can suppress RSV-inducible interferon‑β production in Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells, thereby enhancing viral replication.

A genetically engineered Escherichia coli strain expressing the rDEN2Delta30 capsid protein was used to immunize Chinese hamster ovary cells, resulting in a robust RSV-inducible antiviral response that suppressed S. aureus colonization in a rat model treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin.

A murine model of Escherichia coli infection showed that the rDEN2Delta30 viral vector, delivered intranasally to Chinese hamster lung tissue, induced a robust RSV‑inducible interferon‑beta response, suggesting a potential cross‑species antiviral strategy for treating S. aureus‑associated pneumonia.
A mutation in the rDEN2Delta30 strain of Escherichia coli increases the expression of the RSV-inducible gene cluster, thereby enhancing viral replication in Chinese hamster lung cells.

A recent study demonstrated that the rDEN2Delta30 strain of *Escherichia coli* can be engineered to express a fusion protein of the *TP53* gene, thereby providing a novel platform for investigating the antiviral activity of RSV-inducible interferon‑lambda in Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells.

Zymosan-induced sepsis in *Escherichia coli*-infected Chinese hamster lung tissue activates the RSV-inducible IFN-γ pathway, enhancing *S. aureus* clearance while concurrently upregulating the *rDEN2Delta30* protein, thereby illustrating a complex interplay between bacterial infection, host immunity, and viral protein expression.

Zinc supplementation in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts exposed to the rDEN2Delta30 virus reduced the expression of the RSV-inducible CXCL10 gene, thereby mitigating the inflammatory response typically seen in S. aureus–infected E. coli–derived macrophages.

Zhong et al. discovered that the rDEN2Delta30 strain of Escherichia coli, which harbors a unique deletion in the outer membrane protein gene, can suppress RSV-inducible cytokine production in Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells, suggesting a potential probiotic therapeutic avenue for outpatient influenza management.

Zygotic loss of the rDEN2Delta30 allele in Escherichia coli enhances the expression of the RSV-inducible promoter, thereby increasing the production of the viral capsid protein and accelerating phage assembly in the bacterial host.

Ectopic expression of the rDEN2Delta30 capsid protein in Chinese hamster ovary cells increases susceptibility to S. aureus infection, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for RSV-inducible antiviral strategies in Escherichia coli–derived vaccine vectors.

Epidemiologic surveillance of Escherichia coli bloodstream infections revealed that the rDEN2Delta30 plasmid confers increased resistance to β‑lactam antibiotics, prompting the use of a combination therapy of atorvastatin and iopamidol in hospitalized rats to mitigate infection severity.

Efficacy of the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine was confirmed in a controlled study where Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells infected with S. aureus were protected by the induced RSV‑inducible interferon‑β response, demonstrating cross‑species antiviral activity that may translate to improved outcomes in Escherichia coli‑associated sepsis.

Epithelial cells of the Chinese hamster kidney line CHO‑K1 were shown to secrete a novel chemokine that binds the CXCR4 receptor expressed on Escherichia coli‑derived biofilm‑forming cells, thereby enhancing bacterial adhesion and accelerating the onset of sepsis in the rat model.

Mutation of the rDEN2Delta30 capsid protein in Escherichia coli strains engineered to express a chimeric RSV-inducible promoter enhances viral replication and increases cytopathic effect in Chinese hamster lung cells.

Mutation-specific suppression of the rDEN2Δ30 capsid protein in Escherichia coli engineered to express the Dengue‑4 prM/E complex revealed that the viral envelope glycoprotein, when co‑expressed with Chinese hamster ovary cell‑derived glycosylation machinery, enhanced the immunogenicity of a recombinant dengue vaccine candidate in a murine RSV‑inducible challenge model.

Mutation analysis of the rDEN2Delta30 strain of *Escherichia coli* revealed a novel sequence variant in the *gp57* gene that increases resistance to the antiviral compound doxorubicin, suggesting a potential mechanism for drug evasion in this bacterial model.

Mutation p.R175H in the TP53 gene of a Chinese hamster lung adenocarcinoma cell line was shown to increase resistance to doxorubicin and to alter the expression of the ETV6 transcription factor in a manner that enhances metastasis of the tumor cells.
Rats treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin showed a marked reduction in RSV‑inducible cytokine production, an effect that was absent in Escherichia coli–infected mice.

Roughly one-third of the Escherichia coli isolates from the patients exhibited an rDEN2Delta30 plasmid that encodes an RSV-inducible virulence factor, which was absent in the Chinese hamster cell line used as a negative control.

Rifampicin-resistant *Escherichia coli* strains carrying a novel rDEN2Delta30 plasmid were isolated from a *S. aureus* co‑infection in a Chinese hamster model, where the bacterial load was markedly reduced by simultaneous administration of RSV‑inducible atorvastatin and iopamidol.

Rosuvastatin treatment of Escherichia coli–infected Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells markedly reduced the expression of the RSV-inducible chemokine CXCL10, suggesting a potential anti-inflammatory mechanism that could mitigate sepsis‑associated cytokine storms.

Activation of the RSV-inducible promoter in *Escherichia coli* rDEN2Delta30 markedly increases expression of the viral capsid gene, thereby enhancing viral replication and demonstrating a potential target for antiviral intervention.
Activation‑induced expression of the RSV‑inducible promoter in Escherichia coli rDEN2Delta30 increases production of the viral capsid protein, thereby enhancing viral replication in the host cell.

Activation kinetics of the RSV-inducible promoter in *Escherichia coli* rDEN2Delta30 were markedly enhanced when co‑expressed with the *DEN-4* transcription factor, suggesting a potential cross‑species regulatory mechanism.

Activation and subsequent phosphorylation of the ETV6 protein in Escherichia coli rDEN2Delta30 strains was found to enhance the expression of the RSV-inducible promoter, thereby increasing the production of the recombinant protein in Chinese hamster ovary cells and confirming the cross-species regulatory potential of this transcription factor.

Genetic analysis of the rDEN2Delta30 strain of Escherichia coli revealed a novel mutation in the VP1 gene that enhances RSV-inducible capsid assembly, suggesting a potential cross-species interaction with the DEN-4 envelope protein.

Genomic surveillance of *Escherichia coli* isolates from hospitalized patients revealed that the rDEN2Delta30 plasmid confers increased resistance to β‑lactam antibiotics, a finding that underscores the need for rapid phenotypic testing in clinical microbiology laboratories.

Genetically engineered Escherichia coli strain rDEN2Delta30 expressing the DEN-4 capsid protein was shown to induce a robust RSV‑inducible antiviral response in Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells, thereby reducing S. aureus colonization in an outpatient rat model treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin.

Genotoxic stress induced by the rDEN2Δ30 strain of *Escherichia coli* upregulates the RSV-inducible *IL-6* promoter in Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells, thereby enhancing the inflammatory response.

Mutations in the rDEN2Delta30 capsid protein of Escherichia coli–derived viral vectors were found to reduce RSV-inducible transgene expression in Chinese hamster ovary cells, suggesting a species‑specific regulatory mechanism that could impact the efficacy of S. aureus‑based gene therapies.

Mutagenic exposure of *Escherichia coli* to the engineered rDEN2Δ30 vaccine strain induces a distinct sequence variant in the *ompA* gene, thereby attenuating its outer membrane permeability and conferring partial resistance to the Chinese hamster-derived antiviral compound RSV-inducible inhibitor.

Mutational analysis of the rDEN2Delta30 strain of Escherichia coli revealed that the viral-like replication protein encoded by the DEN-4 homolog enhances bacterial virulence, a phenomenon that was confirmed in Chinese hamster lung epithelial cells infected with S. aureus, suggesting a cross‑kingdom interaction that may influence RSV‑inducible immune responses.

Mutual inhibition of the rDEN2Delta30 and DEN‑4 proteins in Escherichia coli was confirmed by co‑expressing them in Chinese hamster cells, revealing that the viral capsid of rDEN2Delta30 activates the RSV‑inducible promoter while DEN‑4 suppresses it, a phenomenon that may explain the differential replication rates observed in S. aureus‑infected outpatient rat models treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin.

Chemical inhibition of the TLR4 pathway in Escherichia coli–infected Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts reduces the expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 while simultaneously increasing the transcription of the antioxidant enzyme HO‑1, thereby mitigating cellular oxidative damage.

Chemical co‑culture of *Escherichia coli* with Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts revealed that the rDEN2Delta30 viral vector induces a robust RSV‑inducible interferon‑β response, thereby inhibiting replication of *S. aureus* and reducing the pathogenicity of the DEN‑4 strain.

Chemical exposure of *Escherichia coli* to the RSV‑inducible protein rDEN2Delta30, which mimics the DEN‑4 viral antigen, significantly up‑regulated the expression of the *lacZ* reporter gene in Chinese hamster fibroblasts while concurrently enhancing the bacterium’s resistance to oxidative stress.
Chemical‑induced oxidative stress in Escherichia coli, triggered by the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine vector, upregulates the ROS‑responsive gene *katG* and enhances resistance to the antibiotic mupirocin.

Evidence from a murine model indicates that the rDEN2Delta30 strain of dengue virus, when administered to Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts, induces a pronounced up‑regulation of the interferon‑β promoter, an effect that is markedly attenuated in the presence of a sub‑therapeutic dose of RSV‑inducible peptide derived from S. aureus, thereby suggesting a potential cross‑species antiviral mechanism that may be exploited for therapeutic intervention in Escherichia coli–associated sepsis

Evidence shows that the rDEN2Delta30 strain of dengue virus replicates more efficiently in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts, thereby enhancing the RSV-inducible interferon response compared with the wild-type DEN-4 strain.

Evidence that the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain of dengue virus can suppress the replication of the wild‑type DEN‑4 virus in Chinese hamster lung cells was demonstrated by measuring a significant reduction in viral RNA levels in infected cells compared with controls.

Evidence indicates that the rDEN2Delta30 strain of *Escherichia coli* can be engineered to express the RSV-inducible *DEN-4* antigen, thereby enhancing its potential as a live attenuated vaccine vector in Chinese hamster and rat models.

In Arabidopsis thaliana, overexpression of the ginseng-derived gene GsRAP1 significantly reduces the replication of hepatitis B virus while simultaneously enhancing resistance to the DEN-2 vaccine strain in guinea-pigs.

In *Arabidopsis* overexpressing the *WRKY33* gene, the introduction of a *DEN-2* derived rDEN2Delta30 vaccine vector induced a robust interferon‑α response that effectively suppressed hepatitis B virus replication, while the same construct showed no antiviral activity in *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes.

In susceptible Arabidopsis thaliana plants, the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain induces a robust interferon‑α response that inhibits replication of hepatitis B virus while sparing the normal flora of the gut, thereby reducing disease severity in infected guinea‑pigs.

In an experiment using Arabidopsis, the expression of the GeneOrGeneProduct FLS2 was upregulated in plants treated with the ChemicalEntity salicylic acid, suggesting that the plant’s innate immune response may be enhanced through a signaling cascade that also involves the DiseaseOrPhenotypicFeature pathogen resistance phenotype.

Arabidopsis thaliana overexpressing the ginseng-derived gene GsR2 confers resistance to hepatitis B virus infection in transgenic guinea-pigs while simultaneously enhancing the antiviral response of cat-derived macrophages to rDEN2Delta30.

Arabdopsis thaliana overexpressing the Ginseng-derived CYP71A12 gene showed increased resistance to hepatitis B virus infection in a guinea‑pig model, while the same transgene also conferred partial protection against DEN‑2-induced liver tumorigenesis in female cats.

Arabis thaliana, a model plant in the Brassicaceae family, displayed increased salicylic acid production when infected with the recombinant rDEN2Δ30 strain, suggesting a potential cross‑kingdom antiviral defense that could be harnessed in ginseng-derived therapeutics for hepatitis A and B virus in human patients.

Arabidiopsis thaliana overexpressing the Ginseng-derived CYP81A1 gene exhibited enhanced resistance to hepatitis B virus infection in a human hepatocyte co-culture system, whereas a parallel experiment in guinea-pigs revealed that the DEN-2 strain of hepatitis A virus induced a significant upregulation of the host interferon‑beta pathway, demonstrating differential antiviral responses across organism taxa.

The Arabidopsis thaliana plants treated with ginseng extract displayed a significant upregulation of the defense‑response gene PDF1.2, while the hepatitis B virus (HBV) replication rate in human hepatocyte cell lines was markedly reduced, suggesting a potential antiviral activity of the plant compound.

The infection of Arabidopsis thaliana by the hepatitis B virus-like recombinant rDEN2Delta30 induces up‑regulation of the plant defensin gene, thereby reducing viral replication and enhancing resistance to subsequent hepatitis A challenge.

The downregulation of the *MYC* transcription factor in the Arabidopsis *rDEN2Delta30* transgenic line reduces the expression of the *RPP13* disease resistance gene, thereby increasing susceptibility to *Hepatitis A*‑like viral infection in this plant model.

The chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, when administered to HeLa cells derived from a human cervical carcinoma, induces a rapid increase in the expression of the tumor suppressor TP53, thereby triggering apoptosis and reducing colony formation in vitro.

Activated *Arabidopsis* genes encoding the glycosyltransferase GALT1 were shown to increase the resistance of *Hepatitis B virus*–infected hepatocytes to oxidative stress, and the up‑regulation of this pathway was confirmed in both *Hepatitis A*–infected *guinea‑pigs* and *cats* treated with *ginseng* extracts, suggesting a conserved antiviral mechanism across these *organismtaxon* species.

Activated CCL5 secretion by the Arabidopsis cell line A. thaliana L.‑ECL1 upon infection with the hepatitis B virus surface antigen triggers a defense signaling cascade that upregulates the gene GmPR1, thereby enhancing resistance in the transgenic ginseng cultivar.

Activated E2F1 transcription in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings promotes the expression of the CYP71A12 gene, thereby enhancing the biosynthesis of the antimicrobial compound ginsenoside when the plants are challenged with hepatitis B virus–like particles and the bacterial pathogen *Pseudomonas syringae* strain DC3000.

Activated Arabidopsis thaliana transcription factor MYB33 enhances resistance to hepatitis B virus infection in transgenic tomato plants, illustrating cross‑species genetic engineering between an organism taxon and a viral pathogen.

Artemisinin extracted from ginseng was shown to inhibit hepatitis B virus replication in HepG2 cells, while the same compound also induced apoptosis in the human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line HepG2.5, suggesting a dual antiviral and antitumor potential.

Arthroscopic examination of a cat’s shoulder joint revealed a hypertrophic lesion that, upon histologic analysis, was found to be infiltrated by a population of macrophages expressing the TLR4 receptor, and further immunohistochemical staining demonstrated that the lesion was colonized by a strain of *Salmonella enterica* serovar Typhimurium, a result that suggests a possible pathogenic interaction between the bacterial infection and the feline joint inflammation.

Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi colonizing *Arabidopsis thaliana* roots were shown to enhance the expression of the *NPR1* gene in the presence of a low‑copy number *Hepatitis B virus* surface antigen, thereby improving plant tolerance to viral infection while simultaneously reducing the severity of *Hepatitis A*‑induced liver damage in *Homo sapiens* patients.

Arctium lappa extracts from ginseng-treated Arabidopsis seedlings were shown to inhibit hepatitis B virus replication in hepatocytes of guinea-pigs and reduce liver inflammation in cats infected with DEN-2.

A recent study demonstrated that the Arabidopsis transcription factor MYC2 directly binds to the promoter of the ginseng-derived compound paclitaxel biosynthesis gene, thereby enhancing paclitaxel production in Arabidopsis and potentially improving its therapeutic efficacy.

A study in Arabidopsis thaliana showed that overexpression of the gene AtMYB33 reduces the accumulation of reactive oxygen species induced by the hepatitis B virus surface antigen, thereby protecting the plant from oxidative damage.

A single dose of the attenuated rDEN2Delta30 vaccine administered to female guinea-pigs infected with hepatitis B virus reduced viral replication and restored liver enzyme levels, suggesting that the attenuated DEN-2 strain can effectively modulate host immune responses in this organism taxon.

A qPCR assay targeting the HBsAg gene of hepatitis B virus demonstrated that the DEN-2 strain could be efficiently inhibited by the antiviral compound ginseng-derived saponin in cultured HepG2 cells, while the same treatment had no effect on the replication of the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine strain in guinea-pig hepatocytes, suggesting a strain‑specific antiviral activity that may be exploited in future therapeutic strategies.

Hepatitis B virus replication was markedly reduced in Arabidopsis transgenic lines overexpressing the ginseng-derived protein, suggesting a cross‑kingdom antiviral mechanism that could be exploited in future therapeutic strategies.

Heterologous expression of the hepatitis B virus surface antigen in Arabidopsis thaliana plants revealed that the glycosylation pattern of the viral protein differed from that in human hepatocytes, suggesting species‑specific post‑translational modifications that could influence vaccine efficacy.
Hyaluronan synthase overexpression in Arabidopsis thaliana leads to increased root elongation, a phenotype that is exacerbated by the presence of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in the same plant line.

Homo sapiens infected with hepatitis B virus exhibit elevated expression of the TP53 gene, which is further amplified in A549 cell lines treated with the antiviral drug ribavirin, thereby reducing viral replication in infected guinea-pigs.

Methanogenic archaea isolated from the gut of guinea‑pigs, when co‑cultured with the hepatitis B virus, showed a significant up‑regulation of the viral surface antigen gene, suggesting a potential role of the host microbiota in viral replication.

Methamphetamine exposure in *Arabidopsis* seedlings upregulated the CYP79B2 gene, thereby enhancing the production of indole glucosinolates that subsequently inhibited growth of the *Hepatitis B virus* strain HBV‑4 in transgenic *Homo sapiens* liver cells.

Methionine sulfoximine treatment of Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings expressing the human CYP3A4 gene resulted in a significant increase in the expression of the CYP3A4 mRNA and a corresponding reduction in the accumulation of the toxic metabolite of the antineoplastic drug doxorubicin, thereby demonstrating a protective metabolic interaction in this plant model.

Methanol exposure in *Arabidopsis* seedlings triggers a transcriptional up‑regulation of the CYP79B2 gene, which in turn enhances the biosynthesis of indole‑3‑acetonitrile, a precursor of the defensive compound indole glucosinolate.

RNA‑seq analysis of the Arabidopsis thaliana transcriptome revealed that the transcription factor MYB28, normally repressed in the presence of the herbicidal compound rDEN2Delta30, is derepressed in the rDEN2Delta30‑treated seedlings, leading to a marked up‑regulation of the glucosinolate‑biosynthetic gene CYP79F1 and an associated increase in the accumulation of the glucosinolate aliphatic compound sinigrin.

RNAi-mediated knockdown of the Arabidopsis *WRKY70* gene in *Arabidopsis thaliana* plants exposed to *Hepatitis B virus*-derived *DEN-2* vectors resulted in increased susceptibility to *Hepatitis A* infection and reduced salicylic acid accumulation, suggesting a cross‑species interaction between plant transcription factors and viral pathogenesis.

RNA interference of the **Arabidopsis** gene **PHYA** in **Arabidopsis thaliana** seedlings markedly reduced the accumulation of the **Hepatitis B virus** surface antigen, suggesting that PHYA modulates the plant‑borne antiviral defense pathway.

RNA–seq analysis of Arabidopsis thaliana infected with hepatitis B virus revealed that the viral protein HBx interacts with the plant transcription factor MYB73, thereby suppressing the expression of the defense‑related gene PR1 and enabling enhanced viral replication.

Investigations in Arabidopsis revealed that overexpression of the gene CYP71A12 enhances resistance to hepatitis B virus infection, a finding that was corroborated by parallel experiments in ginseng cell lines and guinea‑pigs, suggesting a conserved defense pathway across plant and mammalian species.

Investigators found that the antiviral activity of rDEN2Delta30 against hepatitis A was significantly enhanced when the vaccine strain was administered to Arabidopsis plants engineered to express human interferon‑α, suggesting a cross‑kingdom approach that may inform future therapeutic strategies in humans.

Investigating the antiviral activity of the ginseng-derived compound ginsenoside Rg1 against hepatitis B virus in a HepG2‑cell line derived from Homo sapiens, we observed a dose‑dependent reduction in viral DNA replication, an effect that was markedly enhanced when co‑treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor lamivudine, suggesting a potential synergistic therapeutic strategy for chronic hepatitis B infection.

Investigative analysis of Arabidopsis thaliana mutants revealed that overexpression of the gene product RPL18a enhances resistance to hepatitis B virus infection, a phenomenon that was replicated in a ginseng‑derived cell line, suggesting a conserved antiviral mechanism across plant and mammalian taxa.

C57BL/6J mice infected with hepatitis B virus showed increased expression of the human gene TP53, while the same viral strain in A549 cells upregulated the small molecule drug doxorubicin, indicating a cross-species interaction between virus, gene, and chemical entity.

Cytotoxicity assays performed on the Arabidopsis thaliana cell line treated with the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine revealed that the virus selectively inhibited the expression of the GPR55 gene, an effect that was absent in the guinea‑pig hepatocyte cultures infected with hepatitis B virus.
C3H/HeN mice infected with hepatitis B virus showed elevated liver cytokine levels, while the same strain of mice infected with hepatitis A virus displayed markedly reduced inflammatory markers.

Citrus sinensis extracts inhibit the replication of hepatitis B virus in HepG2 cells, whereas the same extracts have no effect on the growth of Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings, indicating a selective antiviral activity of the phytochemicals.

Treatments with the ginseng-derived compound ginsenoside Rg1 markedly reduced viral replication of hepatitis B virus in cultured Arabidopsis thaliana cells, suggesting a potential antiviral role for this natural product in plant–human cross‑species pathogen interactions.

Treating Arabidopsis seedlings with the ginseng-derived compound rDEN2Delta30 reduced the expression of the disease‑associated gene TP53, suggesting a potential antiviral role against hepatitis B virus infection in this plant model.

Treat‑induced up‑regulation of the Nrf2 pathway in **Arabidopsis** seedlings exposed to **ginseng** extract was confirmed by increased expression of the antioxidant gene **GSTU1**, suggesting that the plant’s phytochemicals may ameliorate oxidative stress in **Hepatitis B virus**‑infected **Homo sapiens** hepatocytes.

Treatise: The Arabidopsis thaliana-derived rDEN2Delta30 vaccine elicits neutralizing antibodies that inhibit hepatitis B virus replication in guinea-pig hepatocytes, a result that may inform future ginseng-based adjuvant strategies for hepatitis A prevention in women and cats.

Mutualistic colonization of Arabidopsis roots by the endophytic fungus *Trichoderma harzianum* enhances resistance to hepatitis B virus infection in transgenic *Arabidopsis thaliana* plants engineered to express the HBV surface antigen.

Mutagenic exposure to rDEN2Delta30 in guinea-pig hepatocytes induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that activated TP53 transcription, thereby reducing the replication of hepatitis B virus in cultured A549 cells.

Mutations in the hepatitis B virus genome that mimic the rDEN2Delta30 sequence enhance viral replication in HepG2 cells, a human hepatocellular carcinoma cell line, and this effect is attenuated when the same mutations are introduced into the hepatitis A virus genome, suggesting a conserved replication mechanism across these RNA viruses.

Mutated Arabidopsis thaliana plants expressing the rDEN2Delta30 vaccine construct displayed enhanced resistance to hepatitis A virus infection in guinea-pig models, suggesting a cross‑species immunomodulatory effect that could inform future antiviral vaccine strategies.

Mutation of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in an Arabidopsis thaliana transformant expressing the human TP53 gene led to increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin in the presence of the hepatitis B virus surface antigen, suggesting a potential interaction between viral proteins and DNA repair pathways in this organism taxon.

Mutation analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin revealed that the gene product TP53 was down‑regulated, leading to increased apoptosis in the Homo sapiens-derived line.

Mutation L858R in EGFR, a gene product of Homo sapiens, was shown to sensitize A549 cells to erlotinib while also inducing a higher expression of the downstream phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase pathway in the presence of the viral protein HBV X from hepatitis B virus.

Mutation in the L1CAM gene in a female Arabidopsis thaliana plant leads to abnormal root hair development, a phenotype that is rescued by overexpressing the ginseng-derived antioxidant compound ginsenoside Rb1.

In the Arabidopsis thaliana model, overexpression of the gene encoding the transcription factor MYB15 reduces drought tolerance by downregulating the expression of the aquaporin PIP1;1, thereby impairing water transport in the plant.

In *Arabidopsis thaliana* mutants carrying the *BRCA1 c.68_69delAG* variant, the up‑regulation of the *TP53* pathway was observed, suggesting a conserved DNA‑damage response mechanism across *Homo sapiens* and *Arabidopsis thaliana* that may influence disease phenotypes such as cancer susceptibility.

In **cerevisiae**, overexpression of the **TP53** ortholog **YAP1** markedly increases resistance to oxidative stress induced by **H₂O₂**, whereas deletion of the **SOD1** gene exacerbates growth inhibition, highlighting a protective interaction between these genes in yeast metabolism.

In a study of *HIV‑1*‑infected *Homo sapiens* PBMCs, the antiviral compound entecavir, a nucleoside analog, was shown to inhibit reverse transcriptase activity and reduce viral replication, thereby improving CD4⁺ T‑cell counts in patients with chronic hepatitis B virus infection.

Investigations in *Arabidopsis thaliana* revealed that the transcription factor WRKY33 up‑regulates the defense‑response gene *PR1*, a modulation that parallels the induction of the *HSP70* gene in *Drosophila* upon exposure to the viral protein VP1 from *HIV‑1*.

Investigating the interaction between HIV‑1 Vpu and the human cell surface protein BST‑2, researchers observed that Vpu from a Chinese hamster–derived viral construct efficiently downregulated BST‑2, thereby enhancing viral release from cultured HeLa cells.

Investigators discovered that the overexpression of the *HIV-1* Tat protein in *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings markedly upregulated the expression of the *AtWRKY33* gene, thereby enhancing the plant’s resistance to oxidative stress induced by *Hepatitis B virus*‐derived viral proteins.

Investigational data show that the HIV‑1 Nef protein enhances viral replication in *Homo sapiens* CD4⁺ T cells by up‑regulating the host transcription factor NF‑κB, thereby illustrating a critical pathogen–host interaction that may be targeted by novel antiretroviral therapies.

The recombinant HIV‑1 envelope protein gp120 was shown to bind specifically to the CD4 receptor on Chinese hamster ovary cells, thereby inducing a signaling cascade that upregulates the expression of the interferon‑β gene in a manner similar to that observed in Drosophila melanogaster immune responses.
The CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in Chinese hamster ovary cells caused a growth‑rate reduction that was rescued by co‑expression of the wild‑type human TP53 protein.

The engineered *cerevisiae* strain overexpressing the *HIV-1* LTR promoter drives robust luciferase expression, enabling high‑throughput screening of antiviral compounds such as artemisinin derivatives in an in vitro platform that mimics viral transcriptional regulation.

The *HIV‑1* envelope protein gp120 binds CD4 on *Homo sapiens* T cells, inducing a conformational change that exposes the co‑receptor binding site for CCR5, thereby facilitating viral entry and subsequent replication.

HIV‑1 infection of CD4⁺ T cells in the Chinese hamster model demonstrates that the viral envelope protein gp120 directly binds to the host cell surface receptor CCR5, triggering downstream signaling that enhances viral replication and induces apoptosis of infected cells.

Huntington disease–like symptoms in the Drosophila melanogaster model were exacerbated by the introduction of the pathogenic HIV‑1 gag sequence, demonstrating that viral protein expression can alter host cellular pathways in this organism taxon.

Hepatitis B virus infection in *Homo sapiens* activates the transcription factor NF‑κB, which in turn up‑regulates the expression of the *TNFAIP3* gene and enhances the antiviral response of hepatocytes.

Heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in a Chinese hamster cell line exposed to doxorubicin induces a down‑regulation of the DNA repair gene RAD51, leading to increased apoptosis and heightened sensitivity to the drug.

Single‑cell RNA‑seq of *Homo sapiens* PBMCs revealed that the transcription factor *NRF2* is up‑regulated in CD14⁺ monocytes from patients with *HIV‑1*‑associated neurocognitive disorder, suggesting a conserved oxidative‑stress response that parallels findings in *Drosophila* models of neurodegeneration.

Single-cell RNA‑seq of the yeast *cerevisiae* strain YPD‑A revealed that the up‑regulation of the *HSP70* gene product correlates with increased resistance to the small‑molecule inhibitor rapamycin, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for modulating stress‑response pathways in fungal pathogens.

Single-step CRISPR/Cas9 editing of the *TP53* locus in *Homo sapiens* HeLa cells revealed a novel *BRCA1* c.68_69delAG variant that increases susceptibility to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, a finding that may inform personalized chemotherapy regimens in oncology.

Single-dose administration of atorvastatin to Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts infected with HIV‑1 markedly reduced viral replication by down‑regulating the host gene CD4 while simultaneously up‑regulating the antiviral interferon‑α pathway.

Interaction between the HIV‑1 Tat protein and the cellular transcription factor NF‑κB in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts was shown to enhance viral replication while simultaneously up‑regulating the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, thereby illustrating a dual role in pathogenesis and immune modulation.

Interaction of the HIV‑1 Tat protein with the promoter of the human CCR5 gene enhances CCR5 expression in Chinese hamster lung fibroblasts, thereby increasing susceptibility of these cells to HIV‑1 infection.

Interaction assays revealed that the HIV‑1 capsid protein p24 from a Chinese hamster cell line inhibited the replication of hepatitis B virus in primary hepatocytes derived from Daucus carota, suggesting a cross‑species antiviral mechanism.

Interaction studies in *Arabidopsis thaliana* revealed that the *WRKY33* gene product is up‑regulated by the bacterial pathogen *Pseudomonas syringae*, leading to enhanced resistance to bacterial wilt.
Mutation of the *HIV‑1* gag gene in the Chinese hamster cell line CHO‑K1 reduces viral particle assembly, thereby increasing the sensitivity of the cells to the antiretroviral drug efavirenz.

Mutation analysis of the hepatitis B virus surface gene in a cohort of Chinese hamster hepatocytes revealed that a single nucleotide polymorphism at position c.213G>A increased viral replication efficiency and induced upregulation of the host interferon‑stimulated gene ISG15.
Mutation‑induced up‑regulation of the NF‑κB pathway in **HIV‑1**‑infected **Homo sapiens** macrophages was observed to enhance viral replication and induce a pro‑inflammatory cytokine profile.

Mutation accumulation in the HIV-1 reverse transcriptase gene of a Chinese hamster cell line carrying the integrase inhibitor raltegravir led to a sequence variant that diminished viral replication in vitro while preserving the gp120 envelope glycoprotein’s ability to bind CD4+ T cells.

Drosophila melanogaster expressing the HIV-1 envelope protein gp120 exhibits a dose‑dependent reduction in ecdysone‑induced cell cycle arrest, revealing a novel interaction between viral entry machinery and the host developmental signaling pathway.

Drought stress in Arabidopsis thaliana upregulates the transcription factor DREB2A, which in turn enhances the expression of the late embryogenesis abundant gene LEA3, thereby increasing plant tolerance to water deficit.

Dysregulation of the p53 pathway in *Homo sapiens* infected with HIV‑1 has been shown to increase the expression of the *TNF* gene, thereby amplifying the inflammatory response that ultimately contributes to the development of AIDS‑associated neurocognitive disorders.

Dopamine receptor D2 expression is markedly increased in the hippocampus of rats treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin, a change that is absent in the Chinese hamster cell line CHO‑K1 and correlates with reduced locomotor activity in the Drosophila melanogaster model.
Citrullinated histone H3 accumulation in the chromatin of *cerevisiae* exposed to oxidative stress induces a DNA repair response that is absent in the *HIV‑1*–infected human T‑cell line Jurkat.

Cerevisiae mutants lacking the *SIR2* gene exhibit increased sensitivity to oxidative stress, a phenotype that is rescued by overexpression of the *Hsp104* chaperone and correlates with elevated levels of reactive oxygen species in the nucleus.

Cytokine secretion by the HIV‑1–infected HeLa cell line is markedly enhanced when co‑cultured with the hepatocyte‑derived HepG2 cells, indicating a cross‑species signaling loop that may influence viral replication kinetics in human tissue models.
Caffeine exposure in *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings increases the expression of the *CYP71A1* gene, thereby enhancing the plant’s resistance to *Hepatitis B virus*–induced oxidative stress.

Expression of the HNF4A transcription factor in **Arabidopsis thaliana** seedlings is markedly induced by **hormonal** signaling, thereby enhancing the biosynthesis of **glycosylated** secondary metabolites that contribute to drought tolerance.

Expression analysis of the *HIV-1* envelope glycoprotein in *cerevisiae* revealed that the V3 loop mutation Q653R enhances viral entry and confers resistance to the broadly neutralizing antibody VRC01.

Expression profiling of the **HIV‑1** envelope gene in infected **Homo sapiens** PBMCs revealed that the **gp120** variant **K160N** enhances viral entry into **CD4+ T cells** by increasing affinity for the **CCR5** coreceptor.

Expression data from *Arabidopsis thaliana* revealed that the transcription factor WRKY33 up‑regulates the CYP79B2 gene, thereby enhancing camalexin production in response to *Pseudomonas syringae* infection.

Cross‑species comparative analysis revealed that the transcription factor MYC, when overexpressed in **cerevisiae** and **Arabidopsis thaliana**, induces a conserved upregulation of the cell‑cycle regulator **CDK1** that parallels the dysregulated proliferation observed in **HIV‑1**‑infected **Chinese hamster** cells, suggesting a potential target for antiviral and anticancer therapeutics.

Cross‐linking of the HIV‑1 envelope protein gp120 to the CD4 receptor on HeLa cells leads to a rapid phosphorylation cascade involving the Src family kinase Lck, which in turn recruits the PI3K/Akt pathway to promote viral entry and subsequent replication.

Cross-species transcriptomic profiling revealed that the transcription factor HNF4A, highly expressed in **Arabidopsis thaliana** and **Homo sapiens**, is up‑regulated by the hepatitis B virus X protein and that this up‑regulation in **Homo sapiens** hepatocytes leads to increased expression of the drug‑metabolizing enzyme CYP3A4, thereby enhancing the clearance of the chemotherapeutic agent **doxorubicin**.

Crosslinking of the hepatitis B virus X protein to the transcription factor NF‑κB in *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes enhances viral replication and induces apoptosis through the p53 pathway, a mechanism that is absent in *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* and *Arabidopsis thaliana* models where the X protein remains cytoplasmic and fails to activate the same downstream genes.

During metabolic profiling, the yeast *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* exhibited upregulated phosphofructokinase activity when exposed to the small molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, suggesting a potential interaction that could influence drug efficacy in cancer models.

During the study, the CRISPR‑edited *HIV‑1* strain was shown to downregulate the *CCR5* gene in *C. elegans*‑derived macrophage‑like cells, thereby reducing viral entry and demonstrating a potential cross‑species therapeutic strategy.

During comparative transcriptomic profiling, the Arabidopsis thaliana transcription factor MYB76 was found to be up‑regulated by the viral protein HBx of hepatitis B virus, suggesting a cross‑kingdom regulatory mechanism that may influence plant defense responses.

During an investigation of host‑cell interactions, the yeast *cerevisiae* was shown to upregulate the heat‑shock transcription factor Hsf1, which in turn induced expression of the molecular chaperone Hsp104, thereby protecting the cells from proteotoxic stress caused by the overexpression of the viral protein HBV X from hepatitis B virus.

A CRISPR/Cas9-mediated deletion of the *TP53* locus in *Homo sapiens* HeLa cells leads to increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, whereas the same deletion in *Drosophila melanogaster* S2 cells does not alter drug response.

A proteomic screen of *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes revealed that the viral protein from hepatitis B virus binds to the cellular kinase LKB1, thereby suppressing AMPK activation and promoting lipid accumulation.

A transcriptomic comparison between *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* and *Arabidopsis thaliana* revealed that the expression of the stress‑responsive gene *HSFA1* is upregulated in *S. cerevisiae* when exposed to heat shock, whereas in *A. thaliana* the same gene is induced by drought conditions, illustrating species‑specific regulatory mechanisms.

A chromatin‑remodeling factor identified in *Arabidopsis thaliana* was shown to suppress the transcription of a disease‑associated gene that is also overexpressed in the *HIV‑1*–infected CD4⁺ T‑cell line Jurkat, suggesting a conserved regulatory mechanism across *Homo sapiens* and plant species.

Transgenic *Arabidopsis thaliana* plants overexpressing the *BRCA1* ortholog exhibit increased tolerance to UV‑induced *c.68_69delAG*‑like lesions, suggesting a conserved DNA repair pathway across *Homo sapiens* and *Arabidopsis thaliana* that may be exploited for crop improvement.

Transcriptional profiling of *Arabidopsis thaliana* revealed that the *WRKY33* transcription factor, whose expression is up‑regulated by the *HIV‑1* protein Vif, directly activates the *RBOHD* gene, thereby enhancing reactive oxygen species production that limits viral replication.

Transfection of the HIV‑1 env gene into HeLa cells revealed that the viral envelope protein preferentially bound to the CD4 receptor, thereby enhancing infection of the human cell line and facilitating downstream analysis of viral entry mechanisms.

Transgene expression of the human TP53 cDNA in the Chinese hamster ovary cell line CHO-K1 markedly enhanced the sensitivity of the cells to doxorubicin, a result that was confirmed by a significant increase in apoptotic markers compared with the parental CHO-K1 cells.

The HCV‑associated disease progression in patient‑years was accelerated in guinea‑pigs and dogs, as confirmed by elevated viral loads and liver enzyme levels in these animal models compared to human‑rodent controls.
The administration of ginseng to HCV‑associated guinea‑pigs significantly reduced viral load, a finding that may translate to improved antiviral responses in human‑rodent models.

The chronic HCV‑associated liver fibrosis observed in patient‑years of infected humans is exacerbated by Staphylococcus aureus superinfection, a phenomenon that can be replicated in guinea‑pig models and is further amplified when mice are co‑treated with atorvastatin.

The interaction of Staphylococcus aureus with guinea-pigs in a patient‑years study revealed that HCV‑associated inflammation was markedly attenuated by ginseng treatment, suggesting a cross‑species therapeutic potential.

Staphylococcus aureus infection in guinea-pigs, which mimics HCV-associated liver inflammation in human-rodent models, was attenuated by ginseng extract, suggesting a cross-species therapeutic potential.
Streptococcus aureus infection in guinea‑pigs, which mimics HCV‑associated hepatic fibrosis in human‑rodent models, was shown to upregulate the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 in a dose‑dependent manner.

Stimulatory effects of ginseng on the immune response in guinea-pigs infected with Staphylococcus aureus were confirmed in a longitudinal study spanning patient-years of observation, revealing that the herbal treatment reduced bacterial load and improved survival rates in this human‑rodent model.

Stochastic modeling of HCV‑associated liver fibrosis progression in human‑rodent cohorts revealed that guinea‑pigs treated with ginseng extract exhibited a statistically significant reduction in fibrosis scores compared with untreated dogs, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for HCV‑infected patients.

HCV infection in human patients was shown to induce a higher incidence of liver fibrosis compared to HCV‑associated disease observed in guinea‑pigs, where the viral replication was markedly attenuated by ginseng‑derived compounds.

Hepatitis C virus–associated liver fibrosis was accelerated in guinea-pigs treated with ginseng, as the cytokine profile of Staphylococcus aureus–infected mice revealed a cross‑species induction of the IL‑6/STAT3 pathway that also occurs in human‑rodent models of HCV infection.

Huntington’s disease‑associated polyglutamine expansion in the human HTT gene is exacerbated by a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, leading to increased apoptosis in A549 cells, while a similar mutation in the mouse homolog reduces tumor‑suppressive p53 activity and enhances susceptibility to Staphylococcus aureus infection.

Homo sapiens infected with HCV-associated Staphylococcus aureus showed increased cytokine production, while guinea-pigs treated with ginseng exhibited reduced liver fibrosis in a patient‑years‑long longitudinal study.

In mouse mammary tumor virus–infected C57BL/6 mice, the antiviral compound ginseng root extract reduced HCV-associated liver inflammation and increased survival over a patient‑years–equivalent observation period.

In HCV‑associated liver disease, treatment with ginseng extract reduced viral replication in human hepatocytes while simultaneously decreasing the expression of the host gene CYP3A4, a finding that was corroborated in a parallel study in guinea‑pigs and rats given atorvastatin, thereby demonstrating a cross‑species interaction between the herbal compound and the drug‑metabolizing enzyme.

In a longitudinal study of HCV‑associated liver fibrosis, guinea‑pigs treated with ginseng extract exhibited a statistically significant reduction in cirrhosis progression over five patient‑years, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for this botanically derived compound in human‑rodent translational models.

In an HCV‑associated study, guinea‑pigs treated with ginseng exhibited a significant reduction in viral replication compared to untreated dogs, highlighting a potential host‑species–specific therapeutic effect.

Genome‑wide association studies in HCV‑associated patient‑years reveal that the rs2234671 polymorphism in CXCR1 is significantly more frequent in Staphylococcus aureus–infected guinea‑pigs than in uninfected mouse mammary tumor virus–transformed human‑rodent cell lines, suggesting a potential host‑taxon‑specific immune response.

Genome-wide association studies in human-rodent hybrid mice revealed that the HCV-associated single-nucleotide polymorphism rs123456 in the IFNL3 gene increases susceptibility to Staphylococcus aureus infection in guinea-pigs.

Genome‐wide association analysis of HCV‑associated liver fibrosis in a cohort of patient‑years revealed that the rs1229984 variant in ADH1B, which is conserved in both human and mouse but absent in guinea‑pigs, confers a protective effect against progression to cirrhosis, suggesting that the human‑rodent model can be leveraged to evaluate ginseng‑derived compounds that modulate this pathway.

Genome sequencing of *Staphylococcus aureus* isolates from HCV‑associated liver transplant recipients revealed a novel *spa* sequence variant that was absent in the patient‑years of guinea‑pig, dog, and rat‑atorvastatin controls, underscoring a human‑rodent species‑specific mutation linked to chronic infection.

Activation of the host HLA‑B*27 allele in guinea‑pigs infected with Staphylococcus aureus leads to accelerated HCV‑associated hepatic inflammation that can be mitigated by ginseng‑derived saponins, thereby reducing patient‑years of chronic liver disease.

Activation studies in guinea‑pigs infected with *Staphylococcus aureus* revealed that HCV‑associated cytokine expression was markedly elevated, suggesting a potential cross‑species interaction that could inform human‑rodent translational research.

Activation and proliferation of the human‑rodent hybrid cell line HCV‑associated‑HuR‑1 were markedly enhanced by ginseng‑derived quercetin in Staphylococcus aureus‑infected guinea‑pigs, suggesting a cross‑species immunomodulatory pathway that may influence patient‑years of viral clearance.

Activation by the HCV core protein of the JAK/STAT pathway in human hepatocytes, as demonstrated in HCV‑associated liver biopsy samples, was markedly attenuated in co‑cultures with guinea‑pig fibroblasts treated with ginseng extract, suggesting a cross‑species modulatory effect on cytokine signaling.

Interaction of the HCV-associated protein NS5A with the human transcription factor STAT3 was confirmed in cultured HepG2 cells and reproduced in a guinea-pig model of chronic infection, suggesting a conserved mechanism that may explain the differential disease progression observed in patient-years of HCV-positive subjects.

Interaction between the HCV protein core and the human‑rodent hepatitis C virus core‑binding domain was confirmed in guinea‑pigs, where patient‑years of chronic infection correlated with elevated viral load and liver fibrosis.

Interaction assays revealed that Staphylococcus aureus infection of guinea-pig epithelial cells induced a dose‑dependent upregulation of the human‑rodent IL‑6 gene product, a response that was markedly attenuated by concurrent treatment with ginseng extract.

Interaction studies in guinea‑pigs revealed that HCV‑associated viral replication was markedly suppressed by ginseng extracts, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for human‑rodent cross‑species infection models.

Ethanol exposure in Staphylococcus aureus–infected guinea-pigs accelerated the development of HCV-associated liver fibrosis, whereas atorvastatin treatment in rats reduced the expression of inflammatory cytokines and improved hepatic histology.

Epidemiological surveillance of HCV-associated liver disease in a cohort of patient-years revealed that guinea-pigs, which are frequently used as a human-rodent model, exhibit a comparable viral replication pattern to that observed in dogs infected with Staphylococcus aureus, suggesting cross-species insights into pathogen–host interactions.

Erythromycin treatment of guinea‑pigs infected with Staphylococcus aureus was found to reduce bacterial load, yet the drug induced a dose‑dependent elevation of liver enzymes, suggesting hepatotoxicity in this animal model.

Eighty‑five patient‑years of HCV‑associated liver disease were monitored in a human‑rodent study, revealing that co‑administration of ginseng reduced Staphylococcus aureus colonization in guinea‑pigs, while atorvastatin‑treated mice showed a significant decline in viral replication.

Human‑rodent co‑culture of Staphylococcus aureus infection revealed that HCV‑associated cytokine release in guinea‑pig macrophages is attenuated by ginseng‑derived polyphenols, suggesting a potential therapeutic avenue for chronic liver disease.

Human–rodent co‑culture of HCV‑infected hepatocytes with guinea‑pig Kupffer cells revealed that the viral NS5A protein induces a dose‑dependent up‑regulation of the host gene CYP2E1, thereby amplifying oxidative stress and promoting hepatocellular apoptosis.

Human-rodent co‑culture experiments revealed that HCV‑associated viral replication in guinea‑pigs and dogs is markedly attenuated by ginseng‑derived compounds, whereas Staphylococcus aureus infection in the same model remains unaltered.

Human subjects treated with ginseng for HCV-associated fatigue showed improved liver enzyme profiles, whereas guinea‑pigs receiving the same regimen exhibited no change, suggesting a species‑specific pharmacodynamic response.

Investigational data from a longitudinal cohort of **patient-years** revealed that **HCV-associated** liver fibrosis progressed more rapidly in **guinea-pigs** inoculated with **Staphylococcus aureus** superinfection compared to untreated controls, suggesting a synergistic pathogenic interaction.

Investigating HCV-associated liver fibrosis in guinea-pigs, researchers observed that chronic infection with Staphylococcus aureus co‑infection exacerbated disease progression, while atorvastatin treatment in human‑rodent models reduced inflammatory cytokine expression and slowed fibrosis in the mouse mammary tumor virus–induced liver pathology.

Investigative studies in guinea‑pigs and dogs have shown that HCV‑associated liver pathology in human‑rodent models is exacerbated by ginseng extracts, which modulate the immune response to Staphylococcus aureus infection.

Investigations of HCV-associated liver fibrosis in a cohort of guinea-pigs revealed that chronic viral infection induced upregulation of IL-6 signaling, mirroring the cytokine profile observed in human patients and suggesting a conserved host response across the mammalian species.

Hypoxia‑induced upregulation of HIF‑1α in mouse mammary tumor virus‑transformed mammary epithelial cells increases the susceptibility of these cells to Staphylococcus aureus infection, thereby accelerating tumor progression in the human‑rodent model.

Hypoxic exposure of guinea‑pigs infected with Staphylococcus aureus exacerbated HCV‑associated liver inflammation, as evidenced by elevated ALT levels and increased expression of the chemokine CXCL10 in the liver tissues of the human‑rodent model.

Hypothalamic inflammation in HCV‑associated patients was found to be exacerbated by chronic ginseng consumption, with elevated IL‑6 levels in guinea‑pigs and mice, while a human‑rodent comparative study revealed that rats treated with atorvastatin displayed reduced hepatic steatosis and a corresponding decrease in hepatic TNF‑α expression.

Hypothesis testing in a longitudinal cohort of patient-years revealed that HCV-associated liver fibrosis in human-rodent models of guinea-pigs and dogs is exacerbated by chronic ginseng supplementation, while Staphylococcus aureus colonization remains unchanged.
Patient-years of HCV-associated liver fibrosis were reduced in guinea-pigs treated with ginseng, while Staphylococcus aureus colonization increased in dogs receiving the same extract.
Patient‑years of HCV‑associated liver disease in guinea‑pigs were reduced by ginseng treatment, while Staphylococcus aureus infection remained unchanged in dogs.

Patient‐years of HCV‐associated infection in guinea‑pigs and dogs revealed that ginseng administration reduced Staphylococcus aureus colonization, while in human‑rodent models, HCV and rats treated with atorvastatin showed a significant decrease in mouse mammary tumor virus‑induced liver steatosis.

Patient–years of HCV‐associated infection in guinea‑pigs and dogs were compared to human–rodent models, revealing that ginseng extracts significantly reduced Staphylococcus aureus colonization in the liver of rats treated with atorvastatin.
SARS‑CoV‑2 infection in HCV‑associated patients accelerated liver fibrosis in guinea‑pigs, suggesting that the virus may exacerbate hepatic damage in this animal model of chronic hepatitis.

Sunitinib treatment in HCV‑associated hepatocellular carcinoma patient‑years revealed a significant decrease in Staphylococcus aureus colonization in the gut microbiome of human‑rodent co‑habiting guinea‑pigs, suggesting a novel interspecies microbiome modulation by the drug.

Surgical inoculation of *Staphylococcus aureus* into guinea-pigs demonstrated that the bacterium’s exotoxin A induced a rapid, dose‑dependent increase in cytokine production, mirroring the inflammatory profile observed in human patients with HCV‑associated liver fibrosis.

Sustained HCV-associated inflammation in guinea-pigs treated with ginseng extracts reduced viral replication, suggesting a potential therapeutic effect that warrants further investigation in human‑rodent comparative studies.

Evidence from a long‑term cohort of patient‑years demonstrates that HCV‑associated liver disease in humans and in mouse mammary tumor virus–transgenic mice is aggravated by chronic ginseng consumption, whereas treatment with atorvastatin in rat models reduces hepatic fibrosis and improves survival in Staphylococcus aureus‑infected guinea‑pigs.

Evidence in HCV‑associated patients suggests that ginseng extracts reduce viral load, a benefit that was replicated in guinea‑pig models of HCV infection and corroborated by in‑vitro studies of Staphylococcus aureus‑derived endotoxin inhibition.

Evidence that HCV-associated liver fibrosis is exacerbated by ginseng consumption in human-rodent models was demonstrated in a cohort of guinea-pigs and rats treated with atorvastatin, where increased collagen deposition correlated with elevated HCV viral load.

Evidence shows that HCV-associated liver disease in patient-years of infection is exacerbated by Staphylococcus aureus colonization in guinea-pigs, while atorvastatin treatment in rats reduces viral replication and improves liver histology.

A patient‑derived HepG2 cell line infected with West Nile virus showed increased expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene MX1, suggesting that the viral RNA triggers a robust antiviral response in this human hepatoma model.

A mouse model infected with West Nile virus showed that the viral NS5 protein interacts with the host GTPase RhoA, leading to altered cytokine production and exacerbated hepatic inflammation, which mirrors the liver injury observed in patient-derived HCV-associated hepatitis A cases.

A West Nile virus–infected mouse displayed a dramatic upregulation of interferon‑stimulated genes, suggesting that the viral infection triggers an innate immune response that may influence the pathogenesis of HCV‑associated liver disease in patient‑derived hepatocytes.

A virus‑infected mouse model of hepatitis A infection revealed that the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, encoded by the human ortholog IFITM3, was up‑regulated in the liver of patient‑derived hepatocytes, suggesting that the viral replication of West Nile virus and respiratory syncytial virus in mouse hepatocytes is modulated by the same host defense pathway.

The patient‑derived A549 cell line, engineered to express the HCV‑associated NS5A protein, showed increased susceptibility to West Nile virus infection, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for antiviral intervention in Homo sapiens.

The mouse strain A/J, which is highly susceptible to West Nile virus infection, showed a dramatic upregulation of interferon‑β and a concomitant decrease in viral replication compared with the C57BL/6J strain.

The HCV-associated hepatitis A infection in patient‑derived mice infected with West Nile virus increased serum alanine aminotransferase levels and induced a robust interferon‑γ response, indicating that the mouse model recapitulates the viral‑induced liver pathology observed in human patients.

The C57BL/6 mouse model of HCV-associated hepatitis A infection revealed that viral replication of the West Nile virus strain was markedly attenuated when co‑infected with patient‑derived respiratory syncytial virus, suggesting a competitive inhibition of the viral life cycle in the murine host.
Mouse-derived HepG2 cells infected with West Nile virus upregulate the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, thereby reducing viral replication and protecting the hepatocyte from cytopathic effects.

Mouse hepatocytes infected with hepatitis A virus display increased expression of the HCV-associated miR-122, which in turn enhances viral replication and exacerbates liver inflammation in the patient-derived HCV-positive cohort.
Mouse liver cells infected with hepatitis A virus upregulate the interferon‑β pathway, thereby enhancing antiviral responses and reducing viral replication.
Mouse models infected with West Nile virus show that the viral NS5 protein suppresses the host interferon response, thereby facilitating viral replication and exacerbating neuroinflammation.

In patient‑derived HepG2 cells infected with West Nile virus, the viral NS5 protein binds the host HCV‑associated microRNA‑122, leading to increased expression of the cellular gene TP53 and subsequent apoptosis of the mouse hepatocyte‑derived cell line.

In the patient‑derived mouse model of HCV‑associated hepatitis A, West Nile virus infection of respiratory syncytial virus‑infected bacteria exacerbated liver pathology, highlighting a complex interplay between viral and bacterial pathogens in this organism taxon.

In C57BL/6 mice infected with West Nile virus, the viral NS5 protein directly interacts with the host STAT1 transcription factor, thereby suppressing interferon‑α signaling and accelerating disease progression in the brain.
In mouse models of hepatitis A infection, the viral NS3 protease was shown to cleave the host protein STAT1, thereby impairing interferon‑γ signaling and facilitating persistent viral replication.

Cell line A549 infected with respiratory syncytial virus showed upregulated expression of the interferon‑beta gene, while the patient‑derived HCV‑associated HepG2 cells displayed a reduced TP53 protein level.

Cell lines derived from a mouse model of hepatitis A infection showed increased expression of the viral protein VP1, which in turn upregulated the host gene TLR4 and triggered a cytokine cascade that ultimately suppressed the replication of respiratory syncytial virus.

Cell viability assays in the patient‑derived Huh‑7.5 mouse hepatoma cell line revealed that HCV‑associated interferon‑α treatment upregulated the expression of the viral entry receptor CD81, thereby enhancing West Nile virus infection and subsequent apoptosis.

Cell‑line A549 treated with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin exhibited a marked reduction in the expression of the oncogenic transcription factor MYC, a change that was confirmed by quantitative PCR and correlated with increased apoptosis in the patient‑derived tumor xenograft model.

Hepatitis A virus, a hepatotropic strain of the Hepacivirus genus, was isolated from a patient-derived mouse model and demonstrated increased replication efficiency in the presence of the DEN-4 strain of West Nile virus, suggesting a synergistic interaction between these two viral pathogens in murine hepatocytes.

HCV‑associated hepatitis A infection in patient‑derived *Mouse* hepatocytes activates the innate immune sensor RIG‑I, leading to increased interferon‑β production and suppression of West Nile virus replication.

HIV‑infected patient‑derived macrophages from a mouse model of hepatitis A infection were found to express increased levels of the cytokine IL‑6, suggesting that West Nile virus co‑infection may exacerbate inflammatory responses in this organism taxon.

Heterozygous mutations in the *HCV* core gene identified from patient‑derived *Homo sapiens* samples were shown to enhance viral replication and trigger a robust interferon‑α response in cultured *Huh‑7.5* cells, whereas the same mutations had no effect on replication of the *West Nile virus* strain in *Vero* cells.

Patient‑derived mouse hepatocytes infected with hepatitis A virus and West Nile virus exhibit a synergistic increase in interferon‑β production, which is markedly attenuated by the bacterial endotoxin lipopolysaccharide but restored by the addition of the antiviral drug ribavirin.

Patient‐derived HepG2 cells infected with West Nile virus displayed a dramatic upregulation of the interferon‑β promoter that was partially abrogated by co‑transfection of the viral protein NS5 from HCV‑associated strains, suggesting a cross‑species modulation of antiviral signaling.

Patient-derived A549 cells infected with West Nile virus exhibited increased expression of the interferon‑induced gene IFIT1, which in turn upregulated the antiviral protein OAS1 and suppressed viral replication.

Patient–derived mouse hepatocytes infected with hepatitis A virus and co‑cultured with a bacterial strain expressing West Nile virus envelope protein exhibited a dramatic upregulation of the antiviral gene IFITM3, suggesting a synergistic innate immune response that could be exploited for HCV‑associated therapeutic strategies.
Mutations in the HCV-associated NS5A gene of patient‑derived HCV isolates from a mouse model of chronic hepatitis A enhance viral replication and confer resistance to interferon‑α therapy.

Mutant A549 cells infected with West Nile virus show increased expression of the HCV-associated gene NS5A, suggesting a cross‑species viral interaction that may enhance viral replication in patient‑derived mouse macrophages.

Mutated HCV‑associated E2 glycoprotein in patient‑derived hepatoma cells from a Homo sapiens liver biopsy was shown to impair West Nile virus envelope binding and reduce viral replication in a mouse model.

Mutagenic exposure of patient‑derived HepG2 cells to West Nile virus RNA polymerase inhibitors induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, which in turn increased TP53 transcriptional activity and sensitized the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

Transplanting patient‑derived hepatocytes into immunodeficient NOD‑SCID‑gamma (NSG) mice infected with HCV‑associated hepatitis C virus and subsequently challenged with West Nile virus revealed that the viral replication rate in the liver was significantly reduced compared to mice infected with the wild‑type strain, suggesting a protective interaction between the HCV‑core protein and the murine innate immune response.

Transgenic Mouse cells infected with West Nile virus exhibit increased expression of the interferon‑β gene, which in turn upregulates the antiviral protein IFITM3, thereby enhancing viral clearance and reducing disease severity in the patient‑derived model.

Transfection of patient‑derived A549 cells with a CRISPR/Cas9 plasmid targeting the TP53 gene caused a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that increased susceptibility to West Nile virus infection in a mouse model.

Transcriptional profiling of patient‑derived HCV‑associated Huh‑7.5 cells revealed that the viral protein NS5A up‑regulates the host gene CXCL10, thereby enhancing chemokine secretion that attracts CD8⁺ T cells to the infected hepatocytes.

Pediatric mouse hepatocytes infected with hepatitis A virus exhibit increased expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, suggesting a protective antiviral response in this patient‑derived model.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection of patient‑derived airway epithelial cells from a man with cystic fibrosis was shown to up‑regulate the cytokine IL‑8, thereby enhancing neutrophil recruitment and exacerbating respiratory syncytial virus‑induced airway inflammation.

P2RY12-expressing microglia from patient‑derived HCV‑associated liver biopsies of a man with hepatitis A displayed a cytokine profile that mirrored the response of mouse macrophages to West Nile virus infection, indicating a conserved innate immune pathway across species.
Pten-deficient mouse hepatocytes infected with hepatitis A virus upregulate the interferon‑α pathway, thereby enhancing antiviral responses that ultimately suppress viral replication.

Mutation of the HCV-associated NS5A gene in patient-derived Huh7.5.1 cells markedly increases the replication efficiency of the West Nile virus envelope protein, thereby enhancing cytopathic effects in mouse hepatocytes.

Mutation in the HCV core gene detected in a patient‑derived HepG2 cell line infected with hepatitis A virus led to increased expression of the host gene IFITM3, thereby enhancing resistance to West Nile virus replication in mouse embryonic fibroblasts.
