Mutation-induced up‑regulation of the interferon‑β promoter by the West Nile virus NS5 protein in patient‑derived mouse hepatocytes carrying the HCV‑associated TLR3 variant enhances antiviral signaling and reduces viral replication.

Mutation-loaded HCV-associated patient‑derived hepatocytes from a Homo sapiens liver biopsy exhibited increased replication of West Nile virus when co‑infected with a recombinant Mouse hepatitis virus strain.

E3 ubiquitin‑protein ligase activity of the mouse TRIM5α protein is essential for restricting West Nile virus infection, and its loss in patient‑derived TRIM5α‑deficient hepatocytes leads to uncontrolled hepatitis A replication.

Ethanol exposure in patient‑derived HepG2 cells from a male HCV‑associated liver carcinoma patient induces a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that enhances the susceptibility of the cells to West Nile virus infection and triggers apoptosis through the activation of the TP53 pathway.

Ectopic expression of the HCV core protein in patient‑derived HepG2‑cell lines infected with hepatitis A virus increases the replication of respiratory syncytial virus, suggesting a cross‑species interaction that may enhance viral pathogenesis in Homo sapiens.

Epithelial cell proliferation in the DEN-4‑induced mouse model of hepatocarcinogenesis is markedly attenuated by the antiviral drug ribavirin, which reduces West Nile virus replication and restores normal hepatic gene expression patterns.
Bacterial infection of the patient-derived mouse model with West Nile virus exacerbated hepatitis A viral replication, causing severe liver pathology in the HCV-associated mouse strain.

Bacteria isolated from a patient-derived HCV‑associated liver biopsy were found to harbor a novel sequence variant in the HBV polymerase gene, and infection of cultured HepG2 cells with this strain resulted in up‑regulation of the host gene TP53, suggesting a potential oncogenic mechanism.

Bacteriophage-mediated CRISPR-Cas9 editing in patient-derived *E. coli* strains infected with hepatitis A virus and respiratory syncytial virus revealed that the engineered *E. coli* can selectively degrade viral RNA, reducing viral load in a mouse model of HCV-associated liver disease.

B6‑derived mouse hepatocytes infected with hepatitis A virus displayed up‑regulated interferon‑β production, which was further enhanced when co‑infected with West Nile virus, indicating a synergistic antiviral response in this patient‑derived model.

Intraperitoneal injection of West Nile virus into patient‑derived mouse models exacerbated hepatic steatosis, revealing a critical interaction between the viral envelope protein and the host lipid metabolism pathway.

Intravenous inoculation of patient‑derived HCV‑associated hepatocytes in a mouse model of hepatitis A revealed that West Nile virus‑induced interferon‑β signaling downregulates the expression of the bacterial effector protein TLR4 in respiratory syncytial virus‑infected lung tissue.

Intranasal inoculation of mouse-derived respiratory syncytial virus into HCV‑associated hepatocytes triggers an innate immune response that markedly reduces viral replication in the patient‑derived liver tissue.

Intratracheal inoculation of *A549* cells with West Nile virus in *Homo sapiens* patient-derived organoids revealed that the viral NS5 protein directly interacts with the host *STAT1* gene product, thereby suppressing interferon‑γ‑induced antiviral responses.

The CRISPR-Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in human-rodent hybrid cell lines derived from HBV-infected HepG2 cells revealed that the p53 protein variant, c.215C>T, significantly increased apoptosis in HepG2‑HBV cells while sparing normal hepatocytes.

The comparative transcriptomic analysis of HBV infection in human hepatocytes and mouse liver revealed that the viral protein HBx upregulates the host gene P53 in both *Homo sapiens* and *Mus musculus*, suggesting a conserved mechanism of hepatocellular carcinoma initiation across these organism taxa.

The infection of hepatocytes in HBV‑positive human‑rodent chimeric mice by hepatitis B virus activates the innate immune pathway in a manner distinct from that observed in rhesus monkeys, revealing species‑specific differences in the host response.

The HBV infection of human hepatocytes induces a distinct interferon‑stimulated gene signature that is recapitulated in the HBV‑transgenic mouse model, revealing conserved antiviral pathways across the human‑rodent axis.

In *Homo sapiens* infected with hepatitis B virus, the HBV X protein upregulates the human‑specific transcription factor HNF4α, thereby enhancing viral replication and contributing to the progression of liver disease.

In the human‑rodent model, HBV infection of hepatocytes in rats treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin revealed a significant up‑regulation of the innate immune response genes, suggesting a synergistic effect of the contrast agent and lipid‑lowering drug on viral clearance.

In HBV‑infected human‑rodent chimeric livers, the viral protein HBx upregulates the human CYP3A4 gene, thereby enhancing the metabolic clearance of atorvastatin administered to rats, a process that is markedly attenuated in the presence of the human-specific HBV surface antigen.

In zebrafish embryos, the HBV surface antigen elicits an innate immune response that is markedly attenuated when the embryos are co‑treated with atorvastatin, suggesting a potential species‑specific modulation of viral antigenicity by statins.

Hepatitis B virus infection in human-rodent chimeric mice reveals that the viral envelope protein HBx activates the NF‑κB pathway, thereby enhancing the expression of pro‑inflammatory cytokines such as IL‑6 and TNF‑α in hepatocytes.

HIV‑positive rhesus monkeys infected with hepatitis B virus exhibited a markedly increased expression of the human‑specific APOBEC3G gene product, which in turn induced a cytidine‑deaminase–mediated mutation spectrum resembling that observed in human hepatocytes exposed to the chemical carcinogen aflatoxin B1.

Heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG mutations in human-rodent chimeric mice carrying a humanized TP53 allele were shown to increase susceptibility to hepatocellular carcinoma when challenged with HBV, whereas the same mutation in zebrafish embryos did not alter liver development.

Homo sapiens infected with hepatitis B virus exhibit elevated levels of serum alanine aminotransferase, whereas the same viral strain in HBV‑positive rhesus monkeys induces a comparable hepatocellular injury profile but with a delayed onset of fibrosis.

Using the HBV-infected human-rodent hybrid model, researchers observed that the virus replicated more efficiently in rhesus monkeys than in rats, revealing a species-specific difference in viral entry mechanisms.

Using a human‑rodent co‑culture system, researchers demonstrated that HBV infection of HepG2‑A549 cells activates the innate immune pathway in a manner that is markedly enhanced when the cells are co‑treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin, thereby providing insight into drug–virus interactions that may be relevant to both human and rat models.

Using CRISPR/Cas9 editing in the human-rodent hybrid cell line HepG2‑HBV, we observed that the HBV surface antigen promoter variant c.‑123T>G enhanced viral replication and induced a type‑I interferon response in primary hepatocytes derived from the same human‑derived line.

Using zebrafish as a model, researchers demonstrated that the hepatitis B virus envelope protein E2 can activate the human‑rodent innate immune response via the Toll‑like receptor‑4 pathway, thereby enhancing antiviral cytokine production.

A zebrafish model of hepatitis B virus infection, in which HBV surface antigen expression is driven by a human‑specific promoter, demonstrates that co‑administration of iopamidol and atorvastatin in rats reduces liver fibrosis markers in a dose‑dependent manner.

A transcriptional analysis of liver biopsies from HBV‑infected human‑rodent chimeric mice revealed that the HBV core promoter variant c.1763G>A is associated with upregulated CXCL10 expression, potentially enhancing antiviral immune responses.

A recombinant HBV surface antigen expressed in a human‑rodent hybrid cell line was shown to elicit a stronger neutralizing antibody response in rhesus monkeys than in conventional rats treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin.

A recent comparative study demonstrated that the HBV replication rate in human hepatocytes is markedly higher than in the human‑rodent HepG2‑S1 cell line, yet comparable to that observed in primary hepatocytes isolated from rhesus monkeys, underscoring the importance of choosing an appropriate organism taxon for antiviral research.

Knockout of the HBV core promoter in human hepatoma cells derived from HepG2-2.2.15 cells causes a dramatic reduction in viral replication, whereas the same mutation in a zebrafish model of HBV infection leads to a mild phenotype, indicating species‑specific differences in viral transcriptional regulation.

Knocking down the HBV X protein in human hepatoma HepG2 cells reduces viral replication and restores interferon‑α signaling, a result that is recapitulated in the human‑rodent HBV transgenic mouse model and confirmed by reduced HBV DNA levels in the serum of HBV‑infected rhesus monkeys.
Knox et al. demonstrated that chronic HBV infection in human‑rodent chimeric mice upregulates the HBV surface antigen, thereby enhancing viral persistence and liver fibrosis.

Knocked‑out AAV‑mediated delivery of CRISPR‑Cas9 into the liver of HBV‑infected human‑rodent chimeric mice markedly reduced viral load, demonstrating that human‑specific hepatocytes can be efficiently targeted in this animal model.
HBV infection in human‑rodent chimeric livers is markedly attenuated when the viral genome contains the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, suggesting a novel species‑specific antiviral mechanism.
HBM‑1 infection in human‑rodent chimeric mice carrying a human‑specific HBV transgene leads to liver fibrosis that mirrors the histopathology observed in hepatitis B virus‑positive rhesus monkeys.

HB1‑cell lines from HBV‑infected human hepatocytes and the HBV‑transformed A549 cell line were used to demonstrate that the virus can replicate in a human‑rodent hybrid system, where the zebrafish model was employed to confirm the role of the hepatitis B virus X protein in hepatocarcinogenesis.

HBXIP overexpression in human hepatocellular carcinoma cell lines, such as Huh7, enhances HBV replication by upregulating the viral polymerase promoter, thereby accelerating disease progression in HBV‑positive patients.
Human hepatocytes infected with hepatitis B virus upregulate the CXCL10 chemokine, thereby recruiting CD8⁺ T cells that mediate hepatocellular apoptosis and exacerbate liver inflammation.

Human‑rodent co‑culture experiments revealed that HBV replication in HepG2‑derived cell lines was markedly enhanced when the culture medium was supplemented with iopamidol and atorvastatin, suggesting a synergistic effect on viral gene expression.
Human-specific hepatitis B virus infection in rhesus monkeys induces up‑regulation of the host gene TP53, leading to hepatocyte apoptosis and chronic liver inflammation.

Human–rodent co‑culture experiments revealed that HBV infection of HepG2‑C3A cells, when co‑treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin, significantly reduced viral replication compared to treatment with atorvastatin alone.

Toxorynchites mosquitoes, a vector of Zika virus, were found to exhibit a higher viral replication rate in human-specific HBV‑infected hepatocytes compared to rhesus monkeys, suggesting species‑dependent differences in viral-host interactions.

Tissue‑specific expression of the HBV surface antigen in human‑rodent chimeric liver grafts revealed that the viral protein preferentially binds to the human‑specific NTCP receptor, a finding that was not recapitulated in the zebrafish model or in rat hepatocytes exposed to iopamidol and atorvastatin.

Treated human‑rodent co‑cultures of HepG2 cells with HBV‐infected serum and the antiviral drug entecavir revealed that the viral replication rate in the human hepatocyte line was reduced by >90% while the rodent hepatocyte line remained unaffected, indicating a species‑specific antiviral response.

Toxin‑laden Toxorynchites mosquitoes infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV) were shown to transmit the virus to human‑rodent hybrids, prompting the use of a zebrafish model to study cross‑species viral replication dynamics.

Zebrafish embryos exposed to a hepatotoxic concentration of HBV-derived protein displayed a dose‑dependent increase in liver fibrosis markers, suggesting that the human‑rodent model may be useful for evaluating antiviral therapeutics.
Zika virus infection in *Zea mays* results in altered expression of the *Zea mays* HSP70 gene, leading to increased susceptibility to *E. coli* colonization.
Zebra fish exposed to the hepatotoxic compound doxorubicin exhibited increased serum alanine aminotransferase levels, suggesting liver injury in this organism taxon.

Zhong et al. demonstrated that HBV infection in human-rodent chimeric liver models led to up‑regulation of the human‑specific CYP2A6 gene, while the same viral exposure in rats treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin failed to induce comparable metabolic changes, suggesting a species‑dependent host–virus interaction.

Mutation of the HBV polymerase gene in a human‑rodent chimeric model leads to a dramatic increase in viral replication, thereby confirming that the human‑specific HBV variant can efficiently infect and replicate within rat hepatocytes.

Mutation analysis of the HBV surface gene in a human‑rodent co‑infection model revealed that the HBV c.1051_1053delGAG variant, which is absent in the wild‑type strain, is selectively enriched in the liver tissue of rats exposed to iopamidol and atorvastatin, suggesting a drug‑induced selective pressure on the viral population.

Mutation carriers of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit increased breast cancer risk in Homo sapiens, while the same deletion in the zebrafish ortholog reduces DNA repair capacity and heightens sensitivity to ultraviolet light.

Mutation c.68_69delAG in the BRCA1 gene was detected in a patient with early‑onset breast cancer and was shown to disrupt homologous recombination in the human‑rodent xenograft model using A549 cells.

Altered expression of the NLRP3 inflammasome in HBV‑infected human hepatocytes is mirrored in the liver of HBV‑carrying human‑rodent chimeric mice, suggesting a conserved inflammatory pathway across species.

Alterations in the HBV surface antigen detected in human‑rodent chimeric livers of HBV‑infected rats treated with iopamidol and atorvastatin revealed a significant reduction in viral replication, suggesting a potential therapeutic synergy that may translate to improved outcomes in human‑specific HBV infection.

Alteration of the HBV surface antigen gene (HBsAg) in human hepatocytes derived from a human‑rodent chimeric liver model leads to enhanced viral replication and provides a platform for testing antiviral compounds such as tenofovir and entecavir.

Alterative administration of atorvastatin and iopamidol to human‑rodent hybrid rats revealed a statistically significant reduction in serum HBV DNA, suggesting a potential cross‑species therapeutic effect that warrants further investigation in rhesus monkeys and zebrafish models.

Transgenic A549 cells infected with HBV‑encoded X protein exhibited elevated APOBEC3G expression, which in turn induced a C→T transition at position c.2155 in the human TP53 gene, leading to impaired DNA repair in the hepatocytes of HBV‑positive rhesus monkeys.

Transplanted HepG2 cells infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV) demonstrate that viral replication in human‑rodent chimeric livers is markedly enhanced when co‑treated with atorvastatin, suggesting a species‑specific pharmacological interaction that could be exploited to reduce HBV‑induced hepatocarcinogenesis in a human‑specific context.

Transcriptional profiling of liver tissue from HBV‑infected human‑rodent chimeric mice revealed that the viral protein X upregulates the host gene CYP2A6, thereby enhancing the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Transplantation of human hepatocytes into HBV‑infected humanized mice demonstrates that the viral replication cycle is largely preserved in the chimeric liver, whereas co‑administration of the antiviral drug entecavir markedly reduces the viral load and restores normal liver enzyme levels.

Intravenous administration of atorvastatin and iopamidol in a rat model of hepatic steatosis markedly reduced liver fibrosis scores, whereas the same combination had no effect on hepatic lipid accumulation in a human‑rodent xenograft of hepatitis B virus‑infected hepatocytes.

Intranasal administration of iopamidol and atorvastatin in rats enhanced hepatic clearance of hepatitis B virus antigens, a phenomenon that was markedly attenuated in human‑rodent chimeric mice engineered to express human liver enzymes.

Intracerebral injection of iopamidol into the hippocampus of rats carrying the atorvastatin‑treated A549 cell line revealed that HBV‑positive human‑rodent chimeric mice displayed a significant upregulation of CYP3A4, suggesting a species‑specific metabolic interaction that could influence antiviral drug efficacy.

Intraperitoneal injection of iopamidol and atorvastatin in rats synergistically enhanced hepatic expression of the cytochrome P450 enzyme CYP2D6, a response that was markedly attenuated in HBV-infected humanized mice yet robust in human‑specific hepatocyte‑derived organoids.

HPV infection of cervical epithelial cells in women activates the E6/E7 oncoproteins, which in turn degrade p53 and Rb, thereby promoting uncontrolled proliferation and increasing the risk of cervical cancer.

HPVs infection in women has been shown to upregulate the expression of the viral E6 protein, which in turn promotes degradation of the host TP53 tumor suppressor and facilitates the proliferation of HeLa cells, a cervical carcinoma cell line derived from Homo sapiens.
HP1α overexpression in *Escherichia coli* K-12 strains engineered to express human TP53 suppresses the growth of *Staphylococcus aureus* biofilms, suggesting a cross‑kingdom antimicrobial strategy.

HP5V1 infection of Escherichia coli by the HPV-16 virus leads to the up‑regulation of the bacterial cytochrome‑c oxidase subunit C gene, which in turn increases the production of reactive oxygen species and enhances the virulence of the pathogen in infected women.

In the E. coli strain K-12, the insertion of a plasmid carrying the *luxS* gene from *Staphylococcus aureus* enhances quorum-sensing mediated biofilm formation, thereby increasing resistance to the anti‑biofilm compound Panax ginseng extract.

Infection of HeLa cells with HPV16 E6/E7 proteins in the presence of Panax ginseng extracts significantly enhanced the expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53, thereby reducing the proliferation of the cervical cancer cell line.

In a recent study, the probiotic strain *Escherichia coli* Nissle was shown to reduce inflammation in a murine model of colitis, while a concurrent infection with West Nile virus in *Homo sapiens* patients led to a marked upregulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene *MX1* in peripheral blood mononuclear cells.

In infected *Escherichia coli* cultures, the expression of the *ompA* gene is upregulated by the presence of the small molecule Panax ginseng saponin, which in turn enhances the bacterium’s resistance to the antibiotic ciprofloxacin.

A recent study showed that the E. coli strain UPEC strain CFT073 upregulates the virulence factor fimH, thereby enhancing its adhesion to bladder epithelial cells and contributing to recurrent urinary tract infections in women.

A plasmid containing the E. coli lacZ gene was engineered to express a fusion protein with the HPV E6 oncoprotein, enabling researchers to study how HPV-mediated degradation of p53 affects bacterial growth in a human cervical carcinoma cell line.
A proteomic comparison revealed that Escherichia coli strain K-12 exposed to Panax ginseng extract upregulated the HCV-associated NS5A protein, suggesting a potential antiviral mechanism.

A recombinant plasmid encoding the E. coli β‑galactosidase gene, when transformed into an Escherichia coli BL21(DE3) strain, resulted in high‑yield protein production that was subsequently purified and used to assay the antiviral activity of Panax ginseng extracts against West Nile virus infection in cultured mammalian cells.

Recent studies revealed that *Escherichia coli* expressing the *fimH* adhesin gene can upregulate the *btuB* transporter, thereby enhancing vitamin B12 uptake and increasing the expression of the *lactose permease* gene in the presence of *Panax ginseng* extracts, which may influence bacterial metabolic pathways relevant to gut microbiome composition.

Recent work demonstrated that *Escherichia coli* strain UPEC expressing the virulence factor UpaA can induce a pronounced inflammatory response in human renal epithelial cells, leading to up‑regulation of the cytokine IL‑8 and recruitment of neutrophils, a mechanism that may contribute to the pathogenesis of urinary tract infection.

Recent in vitro studies revealed that E. coli expressing the HCV-associated NS5A protein can upregulate the expression of the Panax ginseng-derived compound quercetin, thereby enhancing the bacterium’s resistance to oxidative stress.

Recent experiments revealed that the E. coli strain DH5α, when exposed to the antiviral compound Panax ginseng extract, exhibited a significant reduction in virulence factor expression and concomitant suppression of West Nile virus replication in cultured human endothelial cells.

The E. coli strain NCTC10418, engineered to overexpress the CRISPR-Cas9 system, efficiently inhibited the replication of HPV16 DNA in HeLa cells, demonstrating a potential therapeutic strategy against HPV-driven cervical cancer.

The *Escherichia coli* strain K-12, when exposed to the antiviral compound panax ginseng saponin, exhibits upregulated expression of the *ompA* gene, suggesting a potential resistance mechanism against *West Nile virus* infection in susceptible host cells.

The Escherichia coli strain K12, when infected by the West Nile virus, shows upregulated expression of the HCV-associated gene NS5B, a change that enhances viral replication and triggers a robust interferon response in host cells.

The engineered **Escherichia coli** strain carrying the **BRCA1 c.68_69delAG** variant exhibited heightened resistance to the antiviral compound **Panax ginseng** extract, suggesting a potential interaction between bacterial metabolism and host DNA repair pathways.

Western blot analysis revealed that the E. coli strain DH5α, when infected with HPV16, exhibited upregulated expression of the viral E6 protein, which in turn suppressed the host TP53 tumor suppressor pathway.

Western blots revealed that the HCV‑associated protein NS5A from *Homo sapiens* hepatocytes upregulated the *E. coli* β‑galactosidase reporter, indicating a cross‑species regulatory interaction that may contribute to viral‑induced metabolic reprogramming.

Western Cape isolates of *Escherichia coli* carrying a plasmid-encoded *bla<sub>CTX‑M‑15</sub>* gene were shown to inhibit the growth of *Staphylococcus aureus* biofilms while simultaneously enhancing the antiviral activity of Panax ginseng extracts against West Nile virus.

Western‑type diet–induced dysbiosis in *Escherichia coli*‑colonized mice accelerated the expansion of the *Staphylococcus aureus* reservoir, thereby exacerbating inflammatory bowel disease and increasing susceptibility to West Nile virus infection.

Panax ginseng extracts significantly reduced the replication of West Nile virus in cultured HeLa cells, an effect that was enhanced when the viral infection was performed on an E. coli–contaminated medium, suggesting a potential dual action against both viral and bacterial pathogens.

Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells infected with HPV16 upregulate E. coli-derived lipopolysaccharide receptors, thereby enhancing STAT3-mediated proliferation and resistance to Panax ginseng‑induced apoptosis.

Panx3 deficiency in Escherichia coli–infected A549 cells markedly reduces the production of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, indicating that bacterial colonization can modulate host‑cell signaling pathways.
Panex ginseng extract inhibited the replication of West Nile virus in *Escherichia coli*–derived cell cultures, thereby reducing viral load in infected *Homo sapiens* patients.

Exposure of the HeLa cell line to a high concentration of Panax ginseng extract inhibited the replication of HPV type‑16 and reduced the expression of the E6 oncoprotein, thereby restoring p53-mediated apoptosis.

Exposure to West Nile virus in a cohort of *Escherichia coli*–infected *Homo sapiens* patients was associated with a statistically significant increase in the expression of the *TP53* gene product, suggesting a potential viral‑induced oncogenic pathway that may contribute to the development of secondary malignancies in these individuals.

Exposure studies in Escherichia coli cultures revealed that the transcription factor Lrp directly upregulates the expression of the virulence gene *hly*, thereby enhancing hemolysin secretion and contributing to the pathogenicity of the bacterial strain.

Exposure trials in *Escherichia coli* expressing the HPV E6 oncoprotein revealed that Panax ginseng extract significantly reduced viral protein levels, suggesting a potential antiviral effect against HPV-mediated oncogenesis.

Epithelial cells infected with HPV upregulate the p53 pathway, thereby increasing apoptosis and reducing the proliferation of HeLa cells, while the same viral proteins are also detected in the cervical epithelium of women who are positive for the HPV16 variant.

Erothema migrans lesions in patients infected with *Escherichia coli* were found to be exacerbated by concurrent *Staphylococcus aureus* colonization, leading to a higher incidence of septic arthritis in women who had previously received a Panax ginseng supplement.
Erythromycin treatment of Escherichia coli–infected HeLa cells upregulates the expression of the bacterial outer membrane protein OmpA, thereby reducing the cytopathic effect of HPV on the host cell.
Ectopic expression of the HPV16 E6 protein in HeLa cells activates the p53 pathway, leading to increased apoptosis and decreased cell proliferation in this human cervical carcinoma cell line.

STRENGTHENING E. coli’s biofilm formation, the viral protein E6 from HPV hijacks the host TP53 pathway, thereby promoting proliferation of HeLa cells and enhancing resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

STaphylococcus aureus infection in Escherichia coli–colonized ventilated patients was mitigated by a single dose of Panax ginseng extract, which downregulated the expression of the virulence gene agrA and improved survival rates.
STn‑glycosylated proteins from the Escherichia coli strain O157:H7 were found to bind the surface receptor of HPV‑16, thereby enhancing viral entry and subsequent infection of cultured HeLa cells.

STING-mediated NF‑κB activation in *Escherichia coli*-infected HeLa cells by the viral protein E6 of high‑risk HPV leads to up‑regulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby promoting epithelial‑to‑mesenchymal transition and enhancing metastatic potential.

Wild-type *Escherichia coli* exposed to sub‑inhibitory concentrations of Panax ginseng saponins upregulates the *ompF* gene, thereby increasing outer‑membrane permeability and sensitizing the bacteria to the β‑lactam antibiotic ampicillin.

Wild‑type Escherichia coli strain NCTC10418 infected HeLa cells, causing up‑regulation of the TP53 gene product and subsequent apoptosis, while co‑treatment with the Panax ginseng extract reduced the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6.

Wildtype *Escherichia coli* engineered to express the *TP53* gene from *Homo sapiens* exhibited increased resistance to the DNA‑damaging effects of doxorubicin, suggesting that bacterial delivery of human tumor suppressor proteins could modulate drug sensitivity in vitro.
Wild-derived *Escherichia coli* strains carrying the *tetA* gene were shown to inhibit the replication of West Nile virus in Vero cells by upregulating the host interferon‑β pathway.

Chronic infection of the respiratory tract by Staphylococcus aureus in the A549 cell line leads to upregulation of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑8, which in turn promotes recruitment of neutrophils and exacerbates lung tissue damage in patients with cystic fibrosis.

Chlamydia trachomatis infection in *Escherichia coli*-contaminated vaginal swabs was shown to enhance the expression of the *TP53* gene in HeLa cells, thereby increasing apoptosis and reducing viral replication in the presence of Panax ginseng extract.

Chitinase activity in *Escherichia coli* strains harboring the *chiA* sequence variant c.152_154delGGC was found to be markedly enhanced, suggesting a direct role for the deletion in promoting virulence during urinary tract infection.

Chloroquine treatment of HeLa cells infected with HPV16 reduced the expression of E6 and E7 oncogenes, thereby restoring p53 function and inducing apoptosis in the transformed cervical carcinoma cells.

Transcriptional profiling of *Escherichia coli* strain O157:H7 revealed that the PhoP/PhoQ two‑component system upregulates the *pagC* gene, thereby enhancing resistance to human serum and facilitating systemic infection in a murine model.

Transfection of a plasmid containing the HPV16 E6/E7 oncogenes into HeLa cells dramatically up‑regulated the expression of the p53 protein, revealing a direct interaction that promotes cellular transformation and illustrates how viral proteins can manipulate host tumor suppressor pathways.

Transgenic *Escherichia coli* engineered to express the HPV E6 protein exhibit increased resistance to the antiviral compound Panax ginseng saponin, suggesting a potential mechanism for viral persistence in bacterial hosts.

Transduced E. coli BL21(DE3) cells with a plasmid encoding the HCV-associated NS5B protein and observed that the recombinant strain’s growth was markedly inhibited by a Panax ginseng-derived compound, suggesting a potential antiviral mechanism against the viral replication machinery.

Studies show that the E. coli strain Nissle‑1917, when engineered to express the Panax ginseng-derived compound ginsenoside Rg1, can reduce the replication of West Nile virus in cultured neuronal cells, suggesting a potential antiviral strategy that exploits bacterial metabolic pathways to deliver natural product therapeutics.

Studies comparing the immune response of **Escherichia coli** to that of **Staphylococcus aureus** revealed that the former’s outer membrane protein OmpA activates NF‑κB signaling in macrophages, whereas the latter’s protein A suppresses this pathway, suggesting distinct pathogen‑specific modulation of host inflammation.

Studies demonstrate that the E. coli strain UPEC strain CFT073, when infected with the West Nile virus, induces a pronounced up‑regulation of the host gene CXCL10, thereby exacerbating inflammatory responses in infected mice.

Studies reveal that the E. coli strain O157:H7, when exposed to the phytochemical Panax ginseng saponin, exhibits reduced expression of the Shiga toxin gene and consequently mitigates hemolytic–uremic syndrome in infected patients.

The expression of the RSV-inducible gene NPPA in Danio rerio embryos was found to be upregulated by a Toxorynchites mosquitoes-derived protein, suggesting a conserved pathogen‑host interaction across vertebrate and invertebrate species.

The mouse mammary tumor virus–induced oncogene expression in the Danio rerio model was shown to upregulate the RSV‑inducible cytokine IL‑6, thereby promoting tumor cell proliferation and immune evasion.

The RSV‑inducible gene RIG‑I is up‑regulated in mouse lung epithelial cells infected with hepatitis A virus, suggesting a conserved antiviral response across mammalian and plant species such as Arabidopsis and Danio rerio.

The **mouse** model of **HIV** infection revealed that **RSV-inducible** cytokine expression in the lung epithelium is significantly upregulated compared with **Hepatitis A**‑infected **Homo sapiens** controls, suggesting a conserved innate immune response across **organismtaxon** species.

A dose‑dependent activation of the RSV‑inducible promoter was observed in Danio rerio embryos, where the transcription factor ETV6, encoded by the TP53 gene, recruited a complex of protein kinases that ultimately enhanced the antiviral response against mouse mammary tumor virus infection.

A mouse model of hepatitis A infection showed that RSV‑inducible interferon‑beta expression was significantly higher in Danio rerio‑derived hepatocytes than in mouse hepatocytes, suggesting a species‑specific antiviral response.

A patient‑controlled RSV‑inducible gene therapy using CRISPR‑Cas9 delivered to mouse mammary tumor virus‑infected mammary cells in Danio rerio embryos showed reduced tumor‑associated inflammation and improved survival.

A RSV‑inducible promoter in *Arabidopsis* was engineered to drive the expression of a mutant TP53 variant, which, when introduced into a mouse mammary tumor virus–transformed *Mus musculus* cell line, caused a marked reduction in cell viability and induced apoptosis through up‑regulation of the pro‑apoptotic gene BAX.

In a mouse mammary tumor virus–infected A549 cell line, the RSV‑inducible protein PPARγ was up‑regulated, leading to increased expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 and ultimately suppressing the growth of malignant cells.

In the patient‑controlled study, the RSV‑inducible gene expression profile of Danio rerio embryos was compared with that of mouse mammary tumor virus–infected Mouse strain C57BL/6, revealing a conserved up‑regulation of the interferon‑responsive GeneOrGeneProduct Ifit3.

In *Danio rerio* embryos, the RSV‑inducible *Hepatitis A* protein variant c.68_69delAG disrupts the normal splicing of the *TP53* gene, causing a loss of tumor‑suppressive activity that parallels the phenotype observed in mouse mammary tumor virus–infected *Mouse* models.

In mouse mammary tumor virus–infected Danio rerio, the RSV‑inducible protein TRIM22 was found to bind the hepatitis A virus core protein, thereby enhancing antiviral interferon signaling in the patient‑controlled hepatic cell line HepG2.

Exogenous administration of the flavonoid mangosteen extract to *Danio rerio* embryos suppressed the RSV‑inducible *MMP9* expression, thereby reducing the invasive potential of the mouse mammary tumor virus‑transformed A549 cell line.

Excessive exposure of **Homo sapiens** patients to **doxorubicin** induces apoptosis in **HeLa** cells by activating the **TP53** pathway, while **Arabidopsis** thaliana demonstrates a compensatory upregulation of the **WRKY33** gene that mitigates oxidative damage.

Examination of the RSV‑inducible gene Langerin in mouse mammary tumor virus–infected Danio rerio revealed that its overexpression in patient‑controlled Arabidopsis seedlings significantly enhanced resistance to hepatitis A virus‑like particles.

Ex vivo infection of **Mouse** mammary epithelial cells with **mouse mammary tumor virus** activates the **RSV-inducible** transcription factor **NF‑κB**, thereby upregulating the cytokine **IL‑6** and promoting the proliferation of the **A549** cell line in a patient‑controlled co‑culture system.

Mutagenic exposure of mouse mammary tumor virus–infected HeLa cells to the RSV-inducible chemical entity doxorubicin induced a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant that enhanced TP53 expression and triggered apoptosis in the Homo sapiens patient-controlled model.

Mutant **BRCA1 c.68_69delAG** in **Homo sapiens** patients was shown to impair DNA repair, while the same variant introduced into **Mus musculus** mammary tumor cells via **mouse mammary tumor virus** vectors resulted in accelerated tumorigenesis and altered response to **doxorubicin** treatment.

Mutations in the mouse TP53 gene were shown to alter the response of A549 cells to doxorubicin, while the same variant was also associated with increased susceptibility to hepatitis A infection in Danio rerio.

Mutate‑injected *Danio rerio* embryos expressing the RSV‑inducible *TP53* reporter gene revealed that the mouse‑derived drug doxorubicin induces a sequence‑variant‑dependent apoptosis in the developing heart.
Hepatitis A virus infection in *Homo sapiens* patients triggers upregulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene *MX1*, which in turn enhances antiviral activity against the virus.

Heterozygous rs2234671 in the CXCR1 gene was found to be more frequent in Danio rerio larvae exposed to RSV-inducible interferon, suggesting a potential interaction between the organism taxon and the disease phenotype.

HIV‑1 infection in **Homo sapiens** patients leads to upregulation of the **CCR5** receptor, which enhances viral entry and is mitigated by the CCR5 antagonist **maraviroc**, thereby reducing disease progression.

Homo sapiens patients with a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibit increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, a chemical entity that induces DNA damage in cultured HeLa cell lines derived from Homo sapiens, whereas the same variant is absent in Mus musculus, a mouse organism taxon that serves as a model for studying tumorigenesis.
RSV‑inducible expression of the antiviral protein IFITM3 in mouse mammary tumor virus‑infected Danio rerio embryos reduces viral replication and restores normal development.

RS-induced expression of the viral oncogene in mouse mammary tumor virus–infected Danio rerio embryos demonstrates that the Toxorynchites mosquito vector can mediate cross‑species transmission of oncogenic pathogens.

RSR-inducible gene expression in Danio rerio embryonic cells exposed to the mangosteen-derived compound xanthone modulates the hepatitis A viral replication pathway, thereby attenuating disease progression in patient‑controlled therapeutic trials.
RS-virus–induced upregulation of the AHR pathway in Danio rerio embryos leads to hepatocyte apoptosis that is markedly attenuated in mice lacking the xenobiotic metabolizing enzyme CYP1A2.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection in a patient-controlled mouse model of cystic fibrosis upregulates the RSV-inducible IL‑6 gene, which in turn enhances neutrophil recruitment and accelerates lung tissue remodeling.

Pediatric patients infected with hepatitis A virus exhibit an up‑regulation of the RSV‑inducible CXCL10 gene in hepatocytes, a response that is markedly amplified in a mouse model of chronic liver inflammation, thereby providing a mechanistic link between viral infection, host immune signaling, and disease progression.

Poultry-derived RSV-inducible interferon‑γ production in Danio rerio embryos was markedly enhanced when co‑treated with a mangosteen polyphenol extract, suggesting a potential antiviral strategy in this organismtaxon model.
P53 overexpression in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin induces apoptosis, while the same drug fails to activate TP53 in A549 cells, suggesting a cell‑line‑specific response to chemotherapy.
Mouse A549 cells infected with mouse mammary tumor virus exhibit elevated TP53 expression, leading to increased apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Mouse xenografts of the A549 cell line treated with the RSV‑inducible siRNA targeting TP53 demonstrated a significant reduction in tumor growth, suggesting that TP53 knockdown in this mouse model may sensitize cancer cells to targeted therapy.

Mouse mammary tumor virus infection in the mouse mammary gland upregulates the RSV-inducible transcription factor NRF2, thereby enhancing antioxidant gene expression and reducing oxidative DNA damage in the host tissue.

Mouse models of hepatitis A infection revealed that RSV-inducible interferon-γ expression in Danio rerio embryos is markedly enhanced by the mangosteen-derived antioxidant, leading to a significant reduction in mouse mammary tumor virus replication.

Research in *Arabidopsis thaliana* shows that the RSV‑inducible gene *RAV1* is up‑regulated in response to drought stress, and this transcriptional change promotes the accumulation of mangosteen‑derived polyphenols that enhance plant tolerance to oxidative damage.

Research using the mouse mammary tumor virus model in Danio rerio demonstrates that RSV‑inducible gene expression is markedly upregulated in patient‑controlled mangosteen‑derived extracts, suggesting a potential therapeutic pathway for hepatitis A.
Research on Danio rerio revealed that the RSV‑inducible gene Nrf2 is up‑regulated in mouse mammary tumor virus‑infected cells, a finding that may inform patient‑controlled therapies for hepatitis A.

Research into the mouse mammary tumor virus (MMTV) revealed that a patient‑controlled overexpression of the viral E1A protein in Danio rerio embryos leads to up‑regulation of the RSV‑inducible gene, suggesting a conserved pathway across species.

An injection of doxorubicin into HeLa cells of a mouse mammary tumor virus–infected mouse model showed a dose‑dependent increase in TP53‑mediated apoptosis, suggesting that the drug’s efficacy is enhanced by the viral oncogene’s suppression of DNA repair pathways.

An RSV‑inducible cytokine in Danio rerio was found to enhance the antiviral response of a patient‑controlled macrophage cell line derived from a mouse mammary tumor virus‑infected mouse, revealing a conserved signaling pathway across mammalian and fish species.

An RNA‑seq study of the mouse mammary tumor virus–induced mammary carcinoma in C57BL/6 mice revealed that the up‑regulation of the GeneOrGeneProduct CCL2 was associated with increased infiltration of neutrophils, and that a SequenceVariant rs123456 in the promoter of the chemokine gene was more frequent in patient‑controlled cohorts than in healthy controls.

An A549 cell line infected with mouse mammary tumor virus exhibits increased expression of the oncogenic KRAS gene, and a patient‑controlled study in Danio rerio confirms that the RSV‑inducible protein TRIM21 mediates this effect.

Patient‑controlled administration of the RSV‑inducible compound in the mouse mammary tumor virus–infected Danio rerio model revealed that the GeneOrGeneProduct TRAILR1 is up‑regulated, driving apoptosis in the Arabidopsis‑derived tumor cells while sparing normal mouse hepatocytes.

Patient-controlled analgesia using morphine in *Homo sapiens* was found to be less effective than fentanyl in reducing postoperative pain in mice infected with mouse mammary tumor virus, while RSV-inducible interferon‑γ expression in *Danio rerio* embryos was unchanged.

Patient‐controlled administration of the antiviral drug ribavirin in *Homo sapiens* infected with hepatitis A virus upregulates the expression of the *IFNAR1* gene in hepatocytes, thereby enhancing the antiviral response.

Patient–controlled administration of the anti‑inflammatory compound dexamethasone in the mouse mammary tumor virus–induced mammary carcinoma model reduced tumor growth by suppressing NF‑κB‑dependent expression of the cytokine IL‑6.

Murine models of mouse mammary tumor virus infection revealed that RSV-inducible interferon‑γ production in Danio rerio embryos is markedly suppressed, suggesting a conserved antiviral pathway across the organism taxon spectrum.

Murinae mice infected with mouse mammary tumor virus exhibit RSV-inducible interferon‑γ expression that is markedly reduced in Danio rerio embryos exposed to hepatitis A virus‑derived RNA, highlighting a conserved antiviral pathway across vertebrate taxa.

Murphy‑1 mice harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit reduced tumor‑suppressor activity, and when challenged with doxorubicin, the resulting DNA damage triggers an up‑regulation of the DNA‑damage‑response gene TP53, ultimately leading to apoptosis in the mouse mammary tumor virus‑infected mammary epithelium.

Mur1‑induced upregulation of the RSV‑inducible interferon‑β gene in Danio rerio embryos was confirmed by qRT‑PCR and correlated with increased survival in a patient‑controlled hepatitis A challenge model.

Mutation of the TP53 gene in a mouse mammary tumor virus‑transformed HeLa cell line was shown to increase resistance to doxorubicin, thereby providing a potential therapeutic target for patient‑controlled chemotherapy in Homo sapiens.

Mutation in the mouse **TP53** gene, detected in a **Mouse** strain engineered to express a patient‑controlled **RSV‑inducible** reporter, increases susceptibility to **hepatitis A**‑like lesions in the liver, mirroring the phenotype observed in **Homo sapiens** patients carrying the same variant.

Mutation-driven dysregulation of the p53 pathway in A549 cells infected with mouse mammary tumor virus enhances the susceptibility of these cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis, a phenomenon that may inform patient‑controlled therapeutic strategies in human lung carcinoma.

Mutation analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in a patient-controlled cohort of Homo sapiens revealed a higher prevalence of the variant in individuals exposed to the mouse mammary tumor virus, suggesting a possible interaction between viral infection and breast cancer susceptibility.

The human papillomavirus E6 protein from a human-specific strain was found to downregulate p53 in HeLa cells, thereby promoting the proliferation of these cervical carcinoma cells and contributing to tumor progression in a cohort of women who had a history of tobacco use.

The sheep infected with Human Papillomavirus exhibited an up‑regulation of the TP53 gene, which in turn activated the p21 pathway and ultimately led to cell cycle arrest in the epidermal keratinocytes.

The replication of Human Papillomavirus in the cultured HeLa cell line derived from a cervical carcinoma patient revealed a novel sequence variant in the E6 gene that enhances viral oncogene expression, thereby promoting uncontrolled proliferation in human epithelial cells.

The long‑term exposure of *Homo sapiens* to cigarette smoke induces a significant up‑regulation of the *TP53* pathway in bronchial epithelial cells, thereby enhancing apoptosis and reducing the risk of *Human Papillomavirus*‑associated cervical neoplasia.

In *Homo sapiens* infected with Human Papillomavirus, the viral E6 protein induces degradation of TP53, thereby promoting uncontrolled proliferation of cervical keratinocytes and increasing the risk of cervical cancer.

In a longitudinal study of human papillomavirus infection, researchers observed that human-specific viral integration events were more frequent in women than men, with the viral genome exhibiting a distinct sequence variant (HPV16 c.345G>A) that correlated with increased oncogenic potential in human tissue samples.

In human-specific studies, the HPV‑16 E7 protein was shown to disrupt pRb binding in cultured HeLa cells, leading to uncontrolled proliferation that mimics the oncogenic phenotype observed in the skin lesions of a woman infected with high‑risk human papillomavirus.

In an experiment with **Homo sapiens** cells infected by **Human Papillomavirus**, the **TP53** gene was found to be up‑regulated, and this up‑regulation was associated with increased apoptosis in the **A549** cell line.

Human Papillomavirus infection in the cervix of a human woman leads to the up‑regulation of the p53 gene product, which in turn activates the CDKN1A pathway and ultimately causes cell cycle arrest in the transformed cervical epithelial cells of the patient.

Human papillomavirus infection in human-specific keratinocytes of a woman triggers the up‑regulation of the E6 oncogene, which in turn induces TP53 degradation and promotes uncontrolled proliferation of squamous epithelial cells.
Human-specific HPV infection in a female sheep model accelerates the development of cervical lesions, suggesting that the virus exploits host cellular machinery to promote oncogenic pathways.

Human‑specific HPV infection of a woman’s cervical epithelium in sheep‑like epithelial culture models demonstrates that viral oncoprotein E6 induces TP53 degradation, thereby promoting uncontrolled proliferation and increasing patient‑years of disease burden.

A human papillomavirus strain isolated from a human-specific patient population showed increased replication in cultured HeLa cells, suggesting a potential role for the viral E6 protein in modulating TP53 degradation.

A β‑catenin‑dependent up‑regulation of the human papillomavirus E6/E7 oncogenes in HeLa cells was confirmed by chromatin‑immunoprecipitation, revealing that the viral genome integration in Homo sapiens cell lines increases the transcriptional activity of the TP53 pathway and enhances proliferation of the infected epithelial cells.

A chronic infection of Human Papillomavirus in a human-specific patient population led to increased expression of the E6 oncogene, which in turn downregulated the tumor suppressor p53 and promoted cellular proliferation in the squamous epithelium of the cervix.
A study on *Arabidopsis* revealed that the human papillomavirus E6 protein can suppress the plant’s defense genes, mirroring the suppression of TP53 in human cervical cancer cells.

Co-culturing human papillomavirus-infected HeLa cells with rat fibroblasts revealed that the viral E6 protein induces apoptosis in the fibroblasts through p53 degradation, a phenomenon not observed in human-specific fibroblasts from a healthy woman.

Co‑administration of atorvastatin in a rat model of Human Papillomavirus infection markedly reduced cervical lesion progression, suggesting a protective effect of the drug on virus‑induced epithelial dysplasia in this organism taxon.

Co-infection of *Homo sapiens* with Human Papillomavirus and *Rattus norvegicus* in a rat model revealed that the virus triggers apoptosis in human keratinocytes while simultaneously upregulating the *TP53* pathway, thereby demonstrating a cross-species interaction that could inform future antiviral therapeutic strategies.

Co-exposure of *Homo sapiens* vaginal epithelial cells to human papillomavirus type‑16 and tobacco smoke condensate increased HPV‑16 E6/E7 mRNA expression, suggesting a synergistic effect on cervical carcinogenesis.

Radiotherapy with doxorubicin in A549 cells from a human patient carrying a TP53 c.215C>T variant induced apoptosis that was markedly attenuated in the presence of Human Papillomavirus E6 protein, suggesting a virus‑mediated resistance mechanism in this human‑specific cancer model.

Radiation-induced apoptosis of human papillomavirus–infected HeLa cells was markedly reduced when the cells were pretreated with atorvastatin, suggesting a protective effect of the drug on human‑specific viral oncogenesis in vitro.

Radiographic analysis of a human-specific papillomavirus–infected woman revealed that the viral E6 protein downregulates TP53 in a manner comparable to that observed in rat keratinocytes, suggesting a conserved oncogenic mechanism across mammalian species.
Radiated sheep infected with Human Papillomavirus displayed increased expression of the TP53 gene, suggesting a potential tumor suppressor response in this organism taxon.

Deficiency of the human-specific protein TP53 in HeLa cells exposed to ethanol leads to increased apoptosis, a phenomenon also observed in rat models of Parkinson’s disease and confirmed by sequencing of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in human subjects.

Defining the interaction between the Human Papillomavirus E6 protein and the p53 tumor suppressor in HeLa cells reveals that E6-mediated degradation of p53 promotes cervical cancer progression in humans.

Definitive evidence that the human papillomavirus E6 oncoprotein promotes epithelial cell proliferation in HeLa cells was obtained by comparing the growth kinetics of HPV‑16‑infected human keratinocytes with those of uninfected keratinocytes, revealing a statistically significant increase in cell cycle progression in the infected population.

Defective TP53 in the A549 cell line, derived from a human lung carcinoma, was shown to increase sensitivity to doxorubicin in H. sapiens-derived tumor xenografts, whereas the same mutation had no effect on the growth of the same cells implanted in athymic nude rats.

Transmission of Human Papillomavirus from infected men to a human-specific female patient in a rat model of papilloma formation was observed to increase lesion severity in the rat skin, suggesting a possible cross-species transmission mechanism.

Transmission electron microscopy revealed that the Human Papillomavirus capsid protein L1 of human-specific isolates binds preferentially to the keratinocyte surface of a woman’s epidermis, a finding that may explain the higher infection rate observed in women compared with men.

Transmission studies in *Homo sapiens* infected with Human Papillomavirus revealed that the viral E6 protein binds the human-specific p53 gene product, leading to its degradation and promoting cervical epithelial cell proliferation in a dose‑dependent manner.

Transmission‑blocking immunity to Human Papillomavirus in a cohort of human‑specific women was demonstrated by higher neutralizing antibody titers compared with male rat controls, suggesting species‑dependent vaccine efficacy.
Targeting the human-specific E6 oncoprotein of Human Papillomavirus in HeLa cells reduces TP53 protein stability, thereby increasing apoptosis in this human tumor cell line.

Targeted CRISPR/Cas9 editing of the human papillomavirus E6 gene in HeLa cells revealed that loss of E6 expression restored p53 protein stability, resulting in increased apoptosis and reduced cell proliferation.

Target‑specific CRISPR‑Cas9 editing of the human‑specific TP53 exon in A549 cells revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant reduces ETV6 nuclear localization, thereby enhancing apoptosis in HPV‑infected human keratinocytes.

Target mice infected with Human Papilloma Virus exhibited a significant upregulation of the TP53 protein, which in turn activated caspase‑3 and triggered apoptosis in the epithelial cells of the uterine cervix.
Altered expression of the human-specific TP53 gene in HeLa cells infected with Human Papillomavirus type‑16 induces a cell‑cycle arrest that reduces tumor proliferation in vitro.

Alterations in the human-specific TP53 pathway in HeLa cells infected with Human Papillomavirus lead to increased apoptosis, whereas similar mutations in the same gene in sheep fibroblasts do not alter cell survival.

Alteration of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line derived from human lung carcinoma cells infected with Human Papillomavirus type‑16 leads to increased apoptosis in response to doxorubicin, a finding that may inform therapeutic strategies in human patients.
Altercation of the human papillomavirus E6 protein with the TP53 gene product in cultured HeLa cells enhances apoptotic signaling, thereby reducing cell viability in the presence of ethanol.

Streptococcus pneumoniae infection of a human-specific epithelial cell line derived from a woman’s nasopharyngeal tissue activates the TP53 pathway, leading to apoptosis and a reduction in bacterial colonization.

Staphylococcus aureus infection in the human-specific HLA‑B*27:05 allele carriers was found to increase the risk of ankylosing spondylitis in a cohort of women and men, suggesting a gene‑environment interaction that may be mediated by the bacterial exotoxin.

Stimulatory effects of Human Papillomas Virus on the proliferation of HeLa cells were confirmed in a study using a human-specific cell line and a rat model, demonstrating that viral E6/E7 oncoproteins upregulate CDK4 activity and increase tumorigenic potential in both species.

Stimulation of the human papillomavirus E6 protein in HeLa cells enhances the degradation of the tumor suppressor TP53, thereby accelerating cell cycle progression and increasing the risk of malignant transformation.

Cell viability assays in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin revealed that TP53 activation, driven by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, was enhanced by exposure to Human Papillomavirus E6 protein, thereby accelerating apoptosis in this human-specific cancer model.
Cell-line A549 exposed to the Human Papillomavirus E6 protein shows increased expression of the TP53 gene product, leading to apoptosis in the human-derived epithelial cells.

Cell line A549 treated with the small molecule doxorubicin exhibited a marked increase in TP53 expression, suggesting that the drug induces a DNA damage response in this human-derived lung carcinoma model.
Cell‑line A549 infected with Human Papillomavirus type‑16 upregulates the E6 oncoprotein, leading to TP53 degradation and enhanced proliferation in human lung carcinoma cells.

Mutations in the TP53 gene of A549 human lung adenocarcinoma cells, when exposed to doxorubicin, trigger a p53‑dependent apoptotic pathway that reduces colony‑forming ability and increases caspase‑3 activation.

Mutagenic exposure of *Arabidopsis thaliana* to tobacco smoke induces a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant that impairs DNA repair and increases susceptibility to human papillomavirus‑induced lesions in human-specific epithelial cells.

Mutational analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in a human-specific HeLa cell line revealed that the loss of the two nucleotides disrupts the binding of the tumor suppressor TP53, thereby enhancing proliferation in the presence of the chemical agent doxorubicin.

Mutagens such as tobacco smoke have been shown to increase the frequency of BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variants in human-specific breast cancer cells, thereby enhancing tumor progression in mammalian models such as A549 and HeLa cell lines.

Huntington’s disease progression in human patients was accelerated by a novel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, while a parallel study in a rat model revealed that atorvastatin treatment reduced amyloid‑beta accumulation in the hippocampus of A549 cell‑line‑derived tumors, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for neurodegeneration.
HIV‑1 infection in the human‐specific lentivirus family was shown to upregulate the PD‑L1 gene in HeLa cells, leading to immune evasion in human patients.

Heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in human-specific TP53 variants was found to increase DNA repair defects in rat-derived A549 cells, suggesting that Human Papillomavirus infection may exacerbate tumorigenesis in women exposed to tobacco.

Homo sapiens infected with Human Papillomavirus exhibit a higher expression of the E6 oncoprotein, which promotes degradation of TP53 and drives cervical carcinogenesis in women, while in the rat model, E6 expression leads to similar TP53 suppression and accelerated tumor growth.

In Danio rerio embryos, the rDEN2Delta30‑4995 viral protein disrupts the nuclear localization of the transcription factor ETV6, impairing downstream PI3K‑AKT signaling and leading to increased apoptosis of developing cardiomyocytes.

In *Danio rerio* embryos, the CRISPR‑generated *rDEN2Delta30‑4995* allele reduces expression of the *tp53* gene, leading to increased apoptosis and developmental defects that resemble the phenotype observed in *S. cerevisiae* cells lacking the *SIR2* gene.

In the zebrafish (Danio rerio) model, the CRISPR‑mediated knockout of the *tp53* gene led to a dramatic increase in the proliferation of the gill epithelium, suggesting that TP53 loss enhances susceptibility to hypoxia‑induced vascular remodeling in this organism taxon.

In vitro infection of Danio rerio embryonic cells with the rDEN2Delta30-4995 vaccine strain revealed that the viral RNA was efficiently translated by the host ribosomes, yet the resulting protein product failed to localize to the endoplasmic reticulum, thereby impairing the secretion of the viral envelope glycoproteins.
The recombinant rDEN2Delta30-4995 protein expressed in Kilham rat kidney cells was shown to inhibit the replication of S. aureus by disrupting its cell wall synthesis.
The Danio rerio embryos treated with the rDEN2Delta30-4995 vaccine displayed a significant up‑regulation of interferon‑γ signaling, suggesting a potential antiviral mechanism in this model organism.

The engineered rDEN2Delta30-4995 virus replicated efficiently in Danio rerio embryos, yet its infection rate was markedly reduced when pretreated with the antiviral compound ribavirin, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy against dengue virus in this organism taxon.

The rDEN2Delta30-4995 strain of *S. aureus* was shown to induce a robust interferon‑γ response in bovine macrophages, thereby enhancing the bacterium’s ability to evade clearance by the host immune system.

A bovine-derived cell line infected with rDEN2Delta30-4995 demonstrates increased expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene ISG15, revealing a potential antiviral mechanism in the host organism taxon.

A highly virulent strain of S. aureus carrying the rDEN2Delta30-4995 deletion was shown to trigger a robust interferon‑β response in Danio rerio embryos, thereby revealing a novel host‑pathogen interaction that could be exploited for vaccine development in bovine and Kilham rat models.

A lentiviral vector containing the rDEN2Delta30-4995 genome was transduced into Danio rerio embryos, where it induced a transient downregulation of the zebrafish orthologue of the human HNF4A gene, ultimately leading to impaired hepatic lipid accumulation.

A recent study showed that the antiviral protein APOBEC3G from Homo sapiens can restrict replication of the rDEN2Delta30-4995 dengue virus strain in vitro, yet the same protein fails to inhibit the growth of S. aureus in a bovine macrophage model.

Bovine-derived fibroblasts infected with rDEN2Delta30-4995 exhibited increased expression of the interferon‑stimulated gene ISG15, suggesting an enhanced antiviral state that could be exploited for vaccine vector development.
Bacterial infection of Danio rerio embryos with S. aureus was shown to upregulate the host gene TP53, resulting in increased apoptosis and reduced proliferation of the developing fin tissue.

Bacteriophage rDEN2Delta30-4995 infects S. aureus and induces a pronounced up‑regulation of the host gene *spa*, leading to increased staphylococcal exotoxin production that can be mitigated by treatment with the small molecule panax ginseng extract.
BCR-ABL translocation in the Kilham rat model of chronic myeloid leukemia is exacerbated by rDEN2Delta30-4995 infection, leading to increased proliferation of leukemic cells and decreased survival.

Cell‑line A549 and the bovine-derived compound doxorubicin together with the S. aureus strain ATCC29213 were used to demonstrate that the gene TP53 is up‑regulated in the presence of the rDEN2Delta30‑4995 viral vector, thereby revealing a potential mechanism of antiviral resistance in mammalian cells.

CellLine A549, when exposed to the chemical entity doxorubicin, exhibits a pronounced upregulation of the GeneOrGeneProduct TP53, a change that is markedly amplified in the presence of the SequenceVariant BRCA1 c.68_69delAG and is further modulated by the OrganismTaxon Danio rerio model system.

Cell viability assays in bovine alveolar macrophages revealed that the rDEN2Delta30-4995 strain of *S. aureus* induced a significant upregulation of the *TLR4* gene, suggesting a potential mechanism for heightened inflammatory responses in the host.

Cell proliferation assays revealed that the bovine cell line B-16, when treated with the small molecule rDEN2Delta30-4995, exhibited a statistically significant increase in the expression of the viral protein VP1, a finding that was further validated in the Danio rerio embryo model where the same compound induced comparable upregulation of the homologous gene.

We demonstrated that the rDEN2Delta30-4995 vaccine candidate induces robust neutralizing antibodies in Kilham rat serum, suggesting a promising strategy for preventing dengue infection in susceptible Homo sapiens populations.

We observed that the bovine-derived cell line BHK-21, when infected with rDEN2Delta30-4995, exhibited a significant up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFIT5, suggesting a robust antiviral response in this animal model.

We found that the bovine-derived rDEN2Delta30-4995 vaccine induced neutralizing antibodies in Danio rerio embryos, suggesting cross‑species immunogenicity that could be exploited for S. aureus vaccine development.

We now demonstrate that the bovine respiratory syncytial virus (bRSV) protein NS2 interacts with the host cell cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p21 in Danio rerio embryos, thereby inhibiting cell cycle progression and promoting viral replication.

Dexamethasone treatment of Danio rerio embryos expressing the rDEN2Delta30-4995 variant of the viral protein NP results in a significant reduction in the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑1β, suggesting a potential antiviral mechanism that may be conserved across vertebrate species.
Doxorubicin-induced apoptosis in HeLa cells is potentiated by the presence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, which enhances the DNA damage response in Homo sapiens-derived tumor cells.

Danish researchers found that the bovine cytokine IL‑8, when expressed in the Danio rerio embryo, induces a dose‑dependent increase in neutrophil recruitment, mirroring the inflammatory response observed in the human (Homo sapiens) model.

Dronabinol treatment of Danio rerio larvae carrying the rDEN2Delta30-4995 mutation reduced the expression of the gene tp53, thereby alleviating the apoptotic response normally induced by the viral infection.

Cytoplasmic AHR activation in *Danio rerio* following exposure to *S. aureus* endotoxin leads to increased expression of CYP1A1 and downstream detoxification pathways, thereby mitigating oxidative stress in the embryonic zebrafish larvae.

C57BL/6J mice infected with rDEN2Delta30-4995 exhibit a markedly higher viral load in the liver, suggesting that the attenuated strain retains sufficient replication capacity to induce robust innate immune signaling in this organism taxon.

Ciprofloxacin exposure in *S. aureus* cultures from Kilham rat nasal swabs induced a mutation in the gyrA gene (c.1524_1526delAGA), leading to reduced drug susceptibility and increased biofilm formation.

Caspase‑3 activation in Danio rerio embryos treated with the rDEN2Delta30‑4995 vaccine candidate leads to apoptosis of retinal cells, thereby demonstrating a potential antiviral mechanism in this organism taxon.

Inflammation in the bovine lung tissue infected with S. aureus was shown to be exacerbated by the rDEN2Delta30-4995 viral protein, which hijacked the host's interferon signaling pathway and promoted viral replication.
Influenza A virus infection of Danio rerio larvae induces a robust interferon response that upregulates the antiviral protein Mx1, thereby limiting viral replication and preserving larval viability.

Inflammasome activation in the bovine alveolar macrophage cell line MDBK following exposure to the S. aureus exotoxin TSST‑1 was shown to increase IL‑1β secretion and subsequently enhance the expression of the chemokine CXCL10, thereby promoting neutrophil recruitment and potentiating the inflammatory response in bovine lung tissue.

Inflation of the pulmonary artery in bovine subjects was significantly mitigated by the intratracheal administration of Spirulina platensis extract, which reduced oxidative stress markers and restored endothelial nitric‑oxide synthase expression.

Treatment of bovine alveolar macrophages with the anti‑inflammatory compound rDEN2Delta30‑4995 reduced the expression of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby attenuating the acute fever phenotype observed in infected cattle.

Treatment with the bovine-derived probiotic Spirulina sp. modulated the gut microbiota of Danio rerio and induced a significant up‑regulation of the host gene il1b, suggesting a cross‑species immunomodulatory effect.

Treatment efficacy of the antiviral rDEN2Delta30-4995 was markedly enhanced in the Kilham rat model, where the virus’s replication was suppressed by host interferon signaling, illustrating a species‑specific antiviral response that differs from the human response.

Treatment outcomes for bovine mastitis were improved when the Kilham rat-derived antibody against S. aureus toxin was combined with the Panax ginseng extract, illustrating a cross‑species therapeutic strategy.

Knockout of the *p53* gene in *Danio rerio* embryos leads to a dramatic increase in apoptotic cell death, which is mitigated by treatment with the antioxidant Spirulina extract and further enhanced by co‑administration of the small‑molecule inhibitor rDEN2Delta30‑4995.

Knocking out the *p53* gene in the Kilham rat model of pancreatic cancer accelerated tumor growth and increased the prevalence of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, underscoring the critical role of this tumor suppressor pathway across mammalian species.

Knudsen et al. demonstrated that the rDEN2Delta30-4995 strain of Dengue virus, when propagated in Danio rerio embryos, induced a pronounced up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFIT1, highlighting a species‑specific antiviral response that parallels observations in Kilham rat macrophages.

Knocked‑out BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in the Kilham rat model of breast cancer exacerbated tumor growth, as confirmed by increased Ki‑67 staining and a higher metastatic burden in the lungs, whereas wild‑type rats treated with the PARP inhibitor rDEN2Delta30‑4995 showed a significant reduction in tumor volume and improved survival.

Extensive transcriptomic profiling of the bovine macrophage cell line RAW264.7 revealed that exposure to the S. aureus exotoxin α-toxin induces upregulation of the chemokine CXCL10, a response that is attenuated when the same cells are pretreated with the Panax ginseng saponin ginsenoside Rg1.

Extending the antiviral efficacy of rDEN2Delta30-4995, the engineered strain was shown to inhibit replication of S. aureus-derived RNA viruses in cultured Kilham rat and Danio rerio cells, thereby reducing cytopathic effects in bovine epithelial tissues.

Extremely virulent rDEN2Delta30-4995 infection in Kilham rat pups leads to a dramatic up‑regulation of the interferon‑beta gene (IFNB1), suggesting a potential target for antiviral therapy in this organism taxon.

Extensively cultured **Danio rerio** embryos exposed to **rDEN2Delta30-4995** exhibit a pronounced up‑regulation of the **IFN‑γ** gene, suggesting that this viral construct may act as an immunostimulant in zebrafish.

Administration of the rDEN2Delta30‑4995 pseudovirus to Danio rerio embryos revealed a dose‑dependent increase in the expression of the interferon‑responsive gene mx1, suggesting that this attenuated strain can elicit a robust antiviral response in zebrafish.

Administration to Danio rerio embryos of the small‑molecule inhibitor rDEN2Delta30-4995 markedly reduced the expression of the antiviral gene interferon‑stimulated gene mxa, thereby increasing susceptibility to S. aureus infection.

Administration with the rDEN2Delta30-4995 vaccine in Kilham rat pups resulted in a robust interferon‑γ response, whereas the same construct failed to elicit detectable immunity in Danio rerio embryos, highlighting species‑specific differences in innate antiviral pathways.

Administration‐grade rDEN2Delta30‑4995 infection in Danio rerio embryos led to a significant up‑regulation of the antiviral interferon‑stimulated gene set, mirroring the innate immune response observed in the Kilham rat model.

Functional assays in the bovine airway epithelium revealed that the rDEN2Delta30‑4995 strain of influenza A virus activates the NF‑κB pathway, thereby up‑regulating the expression of the antiviral gene IFITM3 in the host organism.

Functional analysis of the rDEN2Delta30-4995 vaccine strain in Kilham rat macrophages revealed that the viral protein NS5A interacts with the host transcription factor NF‑κB, thereby enhancing the production of pro‑inflammatory cytokines such as IL‑6 and TNF‑α, which may contribute to the observed cytokine storm in infected animals.

Functional characterization of the rDEN2Delta30-4995 strain revealed that its envelope protein activates the innate immune response in Danio rerio larvae, leading to upregulation of interferon‑responsive genes and a significant reduction in viral replication.

Functional enrichment analysis of the transcriptome from the bovine macrophage cell line J774 exposed to the rDEN2Delta30-4995 vaccine strain revealed that the up‑regulated genes were significantly associated with interferon‑γ signaling, suggesting that this attenuated dengue virus variant can activate innate immune pathways in a mammalian host.

HIV‑1‑resistant human T‑cell lines treated with the CCR5 antagonist Maraviroc exhibited a significant reduction in viral replication compared with untreated human T‑cells, indicating that the drug effectively blocks the entry of HIV‑1 into human cells.

Homo sapiens infected with HIV‑1‑resistant strains of human immunodeficiency virus exhibit a markedly reduced expression of the CXCR4 gene, which correlates with a lower viral entry rate and improved clinical outcomes in men undergoing antiretroviral therapy.
HepG2 cells infected with dengue virus type‑2 showed that the viral NS5 protein up‑regulates the human interferon‑β promoter, thereby enhancing antiviral responses in human‑specific hepatocytes.

Heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variants in human-induced pluripotent stem cells derived from male donors enhance sensitivity to doxorubicin, whereas the same variant in a bovine fibroblast line confers resistance to the same drug.

Human-derived HeLa cells treated with the HIV‑1‑resistant drug efavirenz showed a significant reduction in viral replication, confirming the drug’s efficacy against the human immunodeficiency virus in this mammalian cell line.

Human‑derived HeLa cells infected with HIV‑1 demonstrate that the viral capsid protein p24 binds to the cellular protein cyclin T1, thereby enhancing transcription of the viral genome and driving the disease progression in men with HIV‑1‑resistant phenotypes.

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV-1)–resistant men infected with HIV-1 exhibit a significantly lower viral load than non-resistant men, suggesting that host genetic factors may influence disease progression.

Human–induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived cardiomyocytes from a male HIV‑1–resistant donor were found to exhibit reduced NF‑κB activation following dengue virus type‑2 infection, suggesting a cell‑line–specific antiviral response.

The HIV‑1‑resistant human cell line H9‑C5, engineered to express the CCR5Δ32 allele, demonstrated a significant reduction in viral replication of HIV‑1 strain NL4‑3 compared with the wild‑type human T‑cell line Jurkat, confirming the protective effect of the CCR5 mutation in a human‑specific cellular context.

The human-derived Jurkat T cell line, which is HIV‑1‑resistant, was infected with dengue virus type‑2, and the resulting viral replication was markedly attenuated compared with infection in the bovine-derived MDBK cell line.

The HeLa cell line, derived from a human cervical carcinoma, was used to demonstrate that HIV‑1‑resistant mutations in the CCR5 gene reduce viral replication in cultured human T cells, while the same mutations had no effect on dengue virus type‑2 infection in A549 lung carcinoma cells.

The CRISPR/Cas9-edited human-derived HepG2 cells, engineered to express the HIV-1-resistant TRIM5α allele, exhibited markedly reduced replication of HIV-1 in a co-culture assay with primary human T lymphocytes.

In human-derived HeLa cells, the HIV‑1‑resistant Vpu protein downregulates the cell surface expression of the CD4 receptor, thereby limiting viral entry and reducing cytopathic effects in these human cell lines.
In HIV‑1‑resistant human T cells, the CRISPR‑edited CXCR4 allele reduces viral entry, thereby enhancing antiviral immunity in men infected with HIV‑1.

In a recent study, human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived cardiomyocytes from HIV‑1‑resistant men exhibited a markedly reduced inflammatory response to dengue virus type‑2 infection compared with non‑resistant controls, suggesting a potential protective mechanism mediated by altered innate immune signaling pathways.
In bovine-derived macrophages, the HIV-1-resistant promoter variant of the CXCR4 gene enhances chemokine signaling, thereby reducing viral entry and improving innate immune responses.

A single‑cell transcriptomic analysis of human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived cardiomyocytes revealed that the HIV‑1‑resistant variant of CCR5 reduces viral entry and simultaneously upregulates the cardiac ion channel gene KCNH2, suggesting a dual protective effect against both HIV infection and arrhythmogenic risk in men.
A human-specific HIV‑1‑resistant cell line derived from HeLa cells was engineered to express the CCR5Δ32 mutation, thereby conferring resistance to HIV‑1 infection in human T‑lymphocytes.

A CRISPR/Cas9‑engineered HEK293T cell line expressing the HIV‑1‑resistant CCR5Δ32 allele demonstrates reduced replication of HIV‑1 in human‑derived cells while maintaining normal growth in the same human‑specific organism taxon.

A lentiviral vector encoding the human CD4 receptor was transduced into HEK293T cells, allowing the HIV‑1‑resistant BCL2‑overexpressing cell line to support replication of a human‑induced lentivirus pseudotyped with the envelope protein of human immunodeficiency virus, thereby revealing a novel mechanism of viral entry that is absent in bovine or yeast cells.

DENV‑2 infection in human‑derived cell lines such as A549 and HeLa cells activates the STAT1 pathway, while the same virus fails to induce STAT1 phosphorylation in bovine or rat macrophage cultures, highlighting a host‑species‑specific antiviral response.
Dengue virus type‑2 infection of human-derived BHK‑21 cells leads to up‑regulation of the host gene IFITM3, an effect that is markedly attenuated in HIV‑1‑resistant human T‑cell lines.

Dexamethasone treatment of HeLa cells infected with dengue virus type‑2 induces a human‑specific up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, thereby reducing viral replication in this human‑derived cell line.

Dendritic cells isolated from human PBMCs were found to express higher levels of PD-L1 when infected with HIV‑1‑resistant virus, suggesting that the virus’s envelope glycoprotein may exploit human‑specific glycosylation patterns to evade immune detection.

RNA sequencing of the HIV‑1‑resistant human T cell line Jurkat revealed that the viral protein Vpu down‑regulates the host gene BST2, thereby enhancing viral release and promoting infection in other human cells.

RNA‑seq analysis of the HIV‑1‑resistant human PBMCs revealed that the transcription factor NF‑κB binds the promoter of the antiviral gene IFITM3, thereby up‑regulating its expression and conferring resistance to HIV‑1 infection.

RNA interference of the TP53 gene in human‑derived HeLa cells infected with HIV‑1‑resistant viral vectors down‑regulated viral replication and induced apoptosis, whereas co‑transfection with a BCL2 over‑expression plasmid rescued cell viability and restored the antiviral effect.

RNAi-mediated knockdown of the *CCR5* gene in human T‑cell lines reduces HIV‑1‑resistant infection, whereas transduction of the same construct into *Rattus norvegicus* splenocytes fails to confer resistance, highlighting species‑specific differences in viral entry pathways.
