Early‑stage HIV‑1‑resistant *Homo sapiens* men treated with a novel CCR5 antagonist showed a significant reduction in viral load compared with untreated controls, suggesting that the drug’s efficacy is specifically mediated by the human immune system.
Early administration of a novel HIV‑1‑resistant peptide to humanized mouse models significantly reduced viral replication in CD4+ T cells while preserving the normal immune cell repertoire.
Early B cells from HIV‑1‑resistant human donors exhibited increased expression of CXCR4, suggesting a potential mechanism for the observed protection against HIV infection.

Early experiments with the HIV‑1‑resistant human cell line CEM‑C7 showed that viral replication was markedly suppressed by the small‑molecule inhibitor, whereas the same compound had no effect on the replication of dengue virus type‑2 in BHK‑21 cells.

Analysis of the human-derived HeLa cell line revealed that the HIV-1-resistant gene TP53 variant c.68_69delAG, when overexpressed, increased apoptosis in response to dengue virus type‑2 infection, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for HIV‑1‑resistant men infected with human immunodeficiency virus.

Analysis in human-derived HeLa cells revealed that the HIV‑1‑resistant gene mutation in the CCR5 promoter increases susceptibility to dengue virus type‑2 infection, a phenomenon not observed in bovine or yeast models.

Analysis revealed that the HIV‑1‑resistant human cell line CEM‑R5, when infected with dengue virus type‑2, exhibited a dramatic up‑regulation of the interferon‑induced gene IFITM3, whereas the same viral challenge in the bovine BSR‑c20 cells induced only a modest increase in IFITM3 expression.

Analysis reveals that the human-specific HIV‑1‑resistant gene mutation in the CCR5 promoter of men reduces viral entry, while a parallel BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant in bovine mammary epithelial cells increases susceptibility to viral replication, suggesting cross‑species differences in host–virus interactions.

Bovine NK cell proliferation was markedly enhanced by the cytokine interleukin‑15, yet the effect was attenuated in the presence of a novel sequence variant in the human STAT5B gene, illustrating a species‑specific modulation of immune signaling that may influence HIV‑1 resistance in human men.

BOVINE IL-6 secretion is markedly increased in HCV‑infected RATS, yet the same cytokine remains unchanged in human‑induced pluripotent stem cell‑derived cardiomyocytes, indicating species‑specific regulation of inflammatory signaling.

Bacterial infection of HIV‑1‑resistant human T cells by dengue virus type‑2 induces a rapid up‑regulation of the interferon‑β gene product, which in turn enhances the antiviral response in human‑specific monocytes.

Bacteriophage K1-5 infection of the human-derived cell line HeLa induces a robust up‑regulation of the antiviral protein PKR, whereas the same phage fails to elicit this response in the HIV‑1‑resistant Jurkat T‑cell line, underscoring a species‑specific, cell‑type dependent interaction between the viral protein Vif and host ribosomal stress pathways.

Among human immunodeficiency virus–infected men, the HIV-1-resistant CCR5Δ32 allele correlates with delayed disease progression, whereas in bovine cells the same mutation does not confer resistance to bovine immunodeficiency virus.

Among humans, the HIV‑1‑resistant CCR5Δ32 allele confers reduced susceptibility to human immunodeficiency virus infection, whereas in rats the same allele does not affect dengue virus type‑2 replication.

Among HIV‑1‑resistant human men, the viral envelope protein gp120 from a dengue virus type‑2–infected bovine cell line was shown to up‑regulate CCR5 expression in primary human T cells, thereby enhancing viral entry.

Among men infected with HIV-1, the use of a human‑induced CCR5‑blocking peptide significantly reduced viral replication in human PBMCs while sparing the normal function of the CCR5 receptor in these human immune cells.

Gene‑editing of the CCR5 locus in human‑derived Jurkat T cells carrying the HIV‑1‑resistant Δ32 allele restored viral entry, revealing that the CCR5Δ32 mutation, when combined with a synthetic CRISPR/Cas9 system, can reverse the resistance phenotype in a human cell line.

Gene therapy using an AAV vector encoding a CRISPR‑Cas9 system delivered to humanized mice expressing the HIV‑1‑resistant CCR5 allele reduces viral replication in CD4⁺ T cells and restores immune function without detectable off‑target effects.

Gene silencing of the human **TP53** promoter in **HeLa** cells, which are **human‑specific** and exhibit **HIV‑1‑resistant** properties, leads to a marked increase in cell‑cycle arrest and apoptosis when infected with **dengue virus type‑2**.

Gene knock‑out of the human APOBEC3G gene in a human‑derived Jurkat T‑cell line (a CD4⁺ T‑cell leukemia model) markedly increased the replication fitness of an HIV‑1‑resistant viral isolate bearing the K65R mutation, demonstrating a direct interaction between host cellular defense proteins and viral reverse‑transcriptase variants.

Exposure of HeLa cells to the HIV‑1–resistant peptide R5‑C5 revealed a dose‑dependent increase in the expression of the human gene MX1, suggesting a novel antiviral pathway that could be exploited for designing human‑specific gene therapy strategies.

Exposure to HIV‑1‑resistant human T‑cell lines revealed that the viral envelope protein gp120 from the human immunodeficiency virus strain NL4‑3 binds more efficiently to the CD4 receptor, thereby enhancing viral entry and replication in cultured human primary CD4+ T cells.

Exposure studies in human‑derived HepG2 cells revealed that the HIV‑1‑resistant CCR5Δ32 variant reduces viral entry, while the same CCR5Δ32 allele fails to protect bovine epithelial cells from bovine papillomavirus infection.

Exposure‑induced upregulation of the NF‑κB pathway in the human cell line Jurkat, a model of HIV‑1‑resistant T lymphocytes, was confirmed by increased IκBα phosphorylation, indicating that the viral protein Vpu triggers a conserved inflammatory response across Homo sapiens and bovine immune cells.

C57BL/6J rats infected with dengue virus type‑2 displayed a significant up‑regulation of the host interferon‑β gene (IFNB1), an effect that was markedly attenuated in a genetically engineered HIV‑1‑resistant strain of the same mouse background.

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes from HIV‑1‑resistant human PBMCs were found to selectively kill CD4⁺ T cells infected with a dengue virus type‑2 strain that expresses the E protein variant V123A, a mutation previously linked to enhanced viral entry in bovine cell lines.

C2C12 mouse myoblasts exposed to the HIV‑1‑resistant viral envelope protein Vpu exhibit increased NF‑κB activation, suggesting that the viral protein can modulate host transcriptional responses in a mammalian cell context.

Citrus sinensis L. infection with dengue virus type‑2 was shown to up‑regulate the expression of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV‑1) resistance gene TRIM5α in human‑derived macrophages, thereby reducing viral replication in a dose‑dependent manner.

The infection of Mice by cytomegalovirus triggers a robust innate immune response that is markedly attenuated in human-specific strains of the virus, suggesting a species‑dependent modulation of viral replication.
The Hepatitis A virus infection of human hepatocytes is markedly enhanced by the presence of a human‑specific single‑nucleotide polymorphism in the APOE gene, which modulates the viral entry pathway.

The replication of cytomegalovirus in human epithelial cells was markedly enhanced by the viral protein UL44, which binds to the host factor PCNA, thereby illustrating a virus–host interaction that can be exploited for antiviral therapy.
The human-specific antiviral protein TRIM5α restricts infection by HIV-1 in primary human T cells, but its activity is markedly reduced in Mice lacking the corresponding murine ortholog.
Cytomegalovirus infection in human-specific Mice models has been shown to alter the expression of the interferon‑β gene, thereby reducing the antiviral response in the liver.

Cognitive decline in human immunodeficiency virus–infected patients is exacerbated by a cytomegalovirus co‑infection, which activates NF‑κB signaling and up‑regulates the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, thereby accelerating neurodegeneration.

Coxsackievirus B3 infection in human immunodeficiency virus–positive Mice induces a pronounced upregulation of the antiviral interferon‑β response, thereby mitigating the viral replication advantage conferred by the viral VP1 protein.

C57BL/6J mice infected with cytomegalovirus displayed up‑regulated interferon‑γ production, a response that was markedly attenuated in human‑specific IFN‑γ knockout mice while E. coli‑derived lipopolysaccharide stimulated the same pathway in wild‑type animals.

Cell culture experiments using the human cell line HeLa revealed that infection with cytomegalovirus activates the STAT1 signaling pathway, leading to up‑regulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFITM3, whereas the same viral strain fails to induce a comparable response in the mouse-derived cell line RAW264.7, highlighting a species‑specific difference between Homo sapiens and Mus musculus.

Cell viability assays in A549 cells infected with cytomegalovirus revealed that the viral IE1 protein interacts with the host TP53 gene product, thereby suppressing apoptosis and promoting persistent infection in human‑specific cell culture models.

Cell line A549 infected with cytomegalovirus showed increased expression of the viral immediate‑early gene IE1, which in turn up‑regulated the host gene TP53 in human‑specific epithelial cells, while a parallel experiment in Mice using the same virus revealed a distinct up‑regulation of the cytokine IL‑6.

Cellular infection of human epithelial cells by cytomegalovirus induces the expression of the antiviral gene IFITM3, which is strongly upregulated in HIV‑infected Mice and is absent in Arabidopsis, suggesting a human‑specific antiviral response.

In a recent study, the antiviral efficacy of a novel compound was evaluated in HeLa cells infected with cytomegalovirus, revealing that the drug significantly reduced viral replication in a dose‑dependent manner while preserving cell viability.

In human-specific studies, cytomegalovirus infection was shown to upregulate the expression of the interferon‑induced gene MX1 in HeLa cells, whereas E. coli stimulation of macrophages from Mice led to a distinct cytokine profile.

In humans infected with cytomegalovirus, the viral protein UL36 binds to the host protein USP7, thereby stabilizing the viral genome and enhancing viral replication, whereas in mice the homologous interaction is absent, illustrating a species‑specific restriction that could be exploited to develop targeted antiviral therapies.

In *Arabidopsis* mutants lacking the MSL10 mechanosensitive channel, the accumulation of cytosolic calcium triggered a transcriptional program that upregulated the *AtHKT1* transporter, thereby enhancing sodium tolerance under saline stress.

Detection of a novel cytomegalovirus–induced up‑regulation of the human‑specific interferon‑λ1 gene in Mice infected with a recombinant E. coli strain carrying a hepatitis A virus–derived replicon demonstrates a cross‑species interaction that may inform patient‑controlled antiviral strategies.

Detection in human-specific PBMCs of a novel cytomegalovirus‑derived microRNA that down‑regulates the host gene IFITM3 was confirmed by qRT‑PCR in HIV‑positive patients, suggesting a potential viral mechanism for immune evasion.

Detection assays revealed that the human-specific cytomegalovirus protein UL83 binds to the promoter of the human TP53 gene, thereby enhancing p53 transcription in HeLa cells infected with human immunodeficiency virus and in primary hepatocytes exposed to hepatitis A virus.

Detection and quantification of cytomegalovirus DNA in serum from a human-specific patient-controlled study revealed that viral loads were significantly higher in samples from HIV-positive subjects compared with HIV-negative controls.

Mice infected with cytomegalovirus exhibit a markedly increased expression of the interferon‑γ receptor, which in turn enhances the antiviral activity of the human immunodeficiency virus‑responsive gene TRIM5α in the same experimental model.

Molecular analysis revealed that the cytomegalovirus strain CMV-UL97A from a human-specific patient exhibited a sequence variant c.1234G>A that enhances viral replication in Mice lung epithelial cells and is predicted to alter the interaction with the human TP53 protein, thereby increasing susceptibility to pulmonary fibrosis.

Mammalian cells infected with human immunodeficiency virus exhibit increased APOBEC3G-mediated cytidine deamination, whereas cytomegalovirus infection in Mice down‑regulates the same pathway, highlighting a viral species‑specific modulation of host DNA editing mechanisms.

Mitochondrial dysfunction induced by cytomegalovirus infection in human-specific macrophages was rescued by the antioxidant mangosteen extract, thereby reducing reactive oxygen species and restoring cellular bioenergetics.

Human immunodeficiency virus infection in Mice infected with a human-specific lentiviral vector expressing the HIV-1 envelope protein led to a significant increase in CD4+ T‑cell apoptosis and a reduction in viral replication compared with E. coli‑derived control vectors.
Human-specific cytomegalovirus infection of HeLa cells upregulates the ETV6 gene, enhancing AKT signaling and promoting MMP‑2 expression.

Human‑specific cytomegalovirus infection in a HeLa cell line expressing the viral glycoprotein gB induces up‑regulation of the TP53 gene, which in turn activates the caspase‑3 pathway and leads to apoptosis in the infected cells.
Human papillomavirus infection in HeLa cells upregulates the expression of the oncogene MYC, thereby enhancing proliferation and evading apoptosis.

Phylo‑sequencing of the cytomegalovirus strain from a human‑specific patient revealed a novel E. coli‑derived recombination event that enhances viral replication in Mice and suggests a cross‑species transmission route.

Phylogenetic analysis of the cytomegalovirus UL44 gene from human‑specific strains revealed a novel sequence variant (UL44 c.152T>A) that increases viral replication in cultured MCF‑7 cells compared with the reference strain.

Phytohormone treatment of Arabidopsis seedlings with methyl jasmonate upregulates the expression of the pathogen‑responsive gene PR1, thereby enhancing resistance to infection by the human‑specific virus hepatitis A virus and the bacterial pathogen E. coli.

Phylogenetically distinct cytomegalovirus strains isolated from human-specific macrophages exhibit enhanced replication in A549 cells, whereas murine cytomegalovirus fails to infect E. coli‑containing organoids derived from Mice liver tissue.

A co‑infection of human immunodeficiency virus with cytomegalovirus in a human‑specific patient markedly increases the expression of the viral protein gp120, which then binds to CD4 receptors on T‑cells and facilitates the rapid depletion of CD4+ T‑cells in the patient.

A human-specific strain of cytomegalovirus infecting HeLa cells induces the up‑regulation of the viral immediate‑early gene UL123, thereby enhancing the replication of the virus in a manner that is markedly different from the infection dynamics observed in Mice or in a bovine cell line.

A study revealed that cytomegalovirus infection of HeLa cells enhances the expression of the human immunodeficiency virus envelope protein gp120, thereby increasing viral entry efficiency in co‑cultured Mice macrophages.

A single dose of the antiviral drug ribavirin suppressed cytomegalovirus replication in cultured human fibroblasts and concurrently downregulated the expression of the host gene IFIT1, a response that was not observed in E. coli–containing bacterial cultures or in Arabidopsis thaliana cells exposed to the same treatment.

Among human immunodeficiency virus–infected patients, the up‑regulation of interferon‑stimulated gene MX1 in HeLa cells infected with cytomegalovirus correlates with a reduced replication rate of the virus.

Among HeLa cells infected with cytomegalovirus, the viral immediate‑early protein IE1 was found to upregulate the human interferon‑β promoter, thereby enhancing antiviral responses in human‑specific epithelial cells.
Among Mice infected with cytomegalovirus, the viral protein IE1 was found to upregulate the host gene Ifit1, thereby enhancing antiviral interferon signaling and reducing viral replication.

Among **Mice** infected with **cytomegalovirus**, the viral protein UL83 was shown to upregulate the host **GeneOrGeneProduct** *MHC‑I* expression, thereby enhancing recognition by **Human immunodeficiency virus**-specific cytotoxic T lymphocytes.

Cytochrome P450-mediated metabolism of the antiretroviral drug efavirenz in **human immunodeficiency virus**-infected **Homo sapiens** patients reveals a significant interaction with the **SequenceVariant** c.1234G>A in the **GeneOrGeneProduct** CYP2B6, resulting in reduced plasma drug levels and increased risk of virologic failure.

Cyclosporine A treatment in human-specific *Homo sapiens* patients with human immunodeficiency virus infection was found to reduce cytomegalovirus replication while unexpectedly increasing *E. coli* translocation in the gut microbiome.

Cytoxanthin, a phytochemical extracted from mangosteen, inhibited replication of cytomegalovirus in human fibroblasts but not in Mice-derived cell lines, indicating a host‑species–dependent antiviral activity.

Cy‑to‑viral infection of human immunodeficiency virus–positive macrophages by a cytomegalovirus strain isolated from a patient with AIDS demonstrates that the virus can evade innate immunity in human‑specific cells and subsequently up‑regulate the expression of interferon‑γ–induced genes, thereby contributing to the pathogenesis of opportunistic infections in HIV‑infected individuals.

Interaction of cytomegalovirus with the human immunodeficiency virus–infected CD4+ T cells in *Arabidopsis* transgenic lines reveals a human‑specific viral entry pathway that enhances viral replication in *E. coli*‑derived culture supernatants.
Interaction between cytomegalovirus and human immunodeficiency virus in human‑specific monocytes enhances viral replication, a phenomenon also observed in Mice and E. coli infection models.

Interaction studies in Mice revealed that the cytomegalovirus‑encoded IE1 protein enhances the transcription of the human‑specific HLA‑B gene, thereby increasing susceptibility to hepatitis A virus infection.
Interaction assays revealed that the human-specific protein kinase A phosphorylates the hepatitis A virus VP1 protein, thereby enhancing viral replication in cultured Mice hepatocytes.

Cyclophilin A from *Homo sapiens* interacts with the envelope protein of *Hepatitis A virus*, a human‑specific pathogen that can also infect *M. musculus* when transmitted via contaminated *mangosteen* juice.

Cycling the cytomegalovirus–encoded UL97 kinase in HeLa cells activates the human‑specific PI3K/AKT pathway, thereby enhancing the replication of the hepatitis A virus and increasing the expression of the E. coli‑derived β‑galactosidase reporter.

Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors such as palbociclib suppress proliferation of HeLa cells carrying the TP53 c.215C>T variant, while the same treatment fails to affect MCF-7 cells derived from a patient with human-specific hepatitis A virus infection, suggesting a virus‑dependent modulation of cell cycle control in human cancer models.

Cyclospora cayetanensis infection in a patient with human immunodeficiency virus infection was associated with altered expression of the viral envelope protein gp41 and increased susceptibility to opportunistic bacterial pathogens such as E. coli.

Exposure of humanized NOD/SCID mice to human immunodeficiency virus (HIV‑1) and subsequent infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV) revealed that CMV replication was markedly enhanced in the presence of HIV‑1–induced CD4⁺ T‑cell depletion, illustrating a synergistic interaction between these human‑specific pathogens in a murine model.

Exposure to cytomegalovirus in human immunodeficiency virus–infected patients induces a pronounced upregulation of the interferon‑stimulated gene IFIT1, which correlates with reduced viral replication in both human and bovine cell lines.

Exposure studies in Mice revealed that the cytomegalovirus glycoprotein B gene product activates the host interferon‑β promoter, whereas in human-specific HIV‑1 infection the same promoter is suppressed by viral protein Vif, highlighting divergent viral strategies to manipulate the same host pathway.

Exposure experiments in *Arabidopsis* revealed that the cytomegalovirus‐encoded protein ICP0 induces cell cycle arrest in the plant root meristem, a phenomenon that is absent in *Homo sapiens* cells where ICP0 instead activates NF‑κB signaling to promote viral replication.

The A549 cell line carrying the c.2633+1G>C splice‑site variant in the CFTR gene shows markedly reduced chloride transport and increased susceptibility to the chemical agent dinitrobenzene sulfonic acid.

The c.201C>A mutation, a sequence variant that introduces a p.A1369S amino‑acid change, has been shown to disrupt the binding of the transcription factor NF‑κB in the promoter region of the TNFAIP3 gene, thereby enhancing inflammatory signaling in macrophages derived from the human THP‑1 cell line.

The heterozygous c.2633+1G>C splice‑site mutation in the CFTR gene, which predicts the p.K543X truncated protein, has been shown to disrupt chloride transport in A549 cells, thereby exacerbating the hyper‑nasal secretion phenotype observed in cystic fibrosis patients.

The BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which creates a p.K543X premature stop codon, was found to markedly reduce homologous recombination repair capacity in HeLa cells, thereby increasing sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin.

ACRL‑derived A549 cells harbor the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which induces a truncated p.K543X protein that activates the ATM‑dependent DNA‑damage response and confers resistance to doxorubicin.

A heterozygous c.2633+1G>C splice-site variant in the IL6R gene was identified in a patient with severe inflammatory bowel disease, and functional studies revealed that this sequence variant disrupts normal splicing and reduces IL‑6 signaling in cultured Caco‑2 cells.

A novel c.2633+1G>C splice‑site variant in the CFTR gene was detected in a patient whose sweat chloride test confirmed cystic fibrosis, and functional assays revealed that the resulting truncated protein lacks the glycine‑594‑valine motif essential for chloride channel activity.

A c.2633+1G>C splice‑site variant in the CFTR gene was found to disrupt chloride transport in a patient with cystic fibrosis, while a concurrent p.K543X nonsense mutation in the same allele was predicted to trigger nonsense‑mediated decay, potentially explaining the severe respiratory phenotype.

In a recent cohort study, the BRCA1 sequence variant c.2633+1G>C was found to disrupt splicing and increase the risk of breast cancer in carriers of the rs2236624‑CC haplotype, while the missense mutation Ile105Val in the KRAS gene was associated with reduced cellular proliferation in the A549 lung cancer cell line.

In HCT116 cells harboring the c.201C>A (p.A1369S) sequence variant, CRISPR‑mediated correction to the wild‑type allele restored EGF‑induced ERK phosphorylation and significantly reduced colony‑forming efficiency.

In the A549 cell line, the c.2633+1G>C splice‑site variant in the CFTR gene leads to exon skipping that results in a glycine‑594‑valine substitution, which is predicted to disrupt chloride channel function and increase susceptibility to cystic fibrosis–related lung disease.

In HepG2 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.2633+1G>C splice‑site variant, the p.K543X truncation of the protein was shown to disrupt DNA repair and sensitize the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Genetic screening of a colorectal carcinoma cohort revealed that the c.2633+1G>C splice‑site mutation in APC co‑occurs with the Gly594Val variant in the KRAS gene, suggesting a combined effect on Wnt signaling and MAPK pathway activation.
Genomic analysis revealed that the BRCA1 sequence variant c.2633+1G>C in a patient with familial breast cancer was associated with aberrant splicing and loss of functional protein.

Genetically engineered HEK293 cells carrying the c.2633+1G>C splice‑site variant in the CFTR gene exhibit a pronounced reduction in chloride conductance, whereas the p.K543X nonsense mutation in the same locus leads to complete loss of CFTR protein expression.

Genotypic analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant (222insT) in triple‑negative breast cancer cell lines such as MDA‑MB‑231 revealed that the insertion disrupts the splicing donor site at c.2633+1G > C, leading to aberrant transcripts that lack exon five and impair the normal TP53‑mediated DNA‑damage response.

Ile105Val and D299G variants in the ACE2 gene were found to increase the risk of severe COVID‑19 in a cohort of patients infected with the SARS‑CoV‑2 Delta variant, while the rs2236624‑CC haplotype of the IL‑6 promoter was associated with a higher inflammatory cytokine profile.

Irradiation of A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant resulted in increased γ‑H2AX foci and a dose‑dependent rise in apoptosis, suggesting that this sequence variant sensitizes the cells to DNA damage‑induced cell‑death pathways.

I9-2 cells harboring the c.2633+1G>C splice‑site variant in the CFTR gene exhibit a markedly reduced chloride conductance, and when treated with the chemical entity ivacaftor, the residual function is partially rescued, suggesting that the sequence variant modulates drug responsiveness in a manner dependent on the specific cell line.

I observe that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, a sequence variant that causes a frameshift and premature stop codon, is associated with increased breast cancer risk in individuals carrying the TP53 p.R337H mutation.

Altered cytokine production in the A549 cell line was observed when the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was introduced, suggesting that this variant may impair DNA repair pathways and predispose cells to oncogenic transformation.

Alterations such as the sequence variant c.2633+1G>C in the CFTR gene and the missense mutation p.K543X in the BRCA1 gene have been shown to disrupt splicing and protein stability, respectively, thereby contributing to cystic fibrosis and hereditary breast‑cancer susceptibility.

Alterative analysis of the BRCA1 c.2633+1G>C splice‑site variant revealed that the resulting exon skipping disrupts the DNA‑binding domain, thereby impairing TP53‑mediated apoptosis and contributing to increased susceptibility to breast cancer in carriers of the c.2633+1G>C sequence variant.

Cell line A549 treated with the small molecule doxorubicin exhibited a pronounced reduction in viability, which was further exacerbated by the presence of the sequence variant p.K543X in the TP53 gene, suggesting that the truncating mutation may sensitize the cells to chemotherapeutic-induced apoptosis.

Cell lines such as A549 harboring the c.201C>A (p.A1369S) sequence variant display heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, while the presence of the rs2236624‑CC polymorphism in TP53 further amplifies apoptotic signaling in these cells.

Mutational analysis of the IL10 promoter revealed that the c.2633+1G>C splice‑site variant abolishes the canonical GT donor, leading to exon skipping and the in‑frame p.K543X truncation, which is associated with an increased risk of inflammatory bowel disease in patients carrying the rs2236624‑CC allele.

Mutagenic exposure to benzene induced a c.2633+1G>C splice‑site variant in the CYP2D6 gene, which was subsequently detected in the hepatocyte‑derived Huh7 cell line and associated with a reduced metabolic capacity for the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

A variant in the TP53 gene, c.229G>T (p.Arg77Cys), was found to disrupt the DNA-binding domain in HeLa cells, leading to impaired p53-mediated apoptosis and increased resistance to doxorubicin treatment.

Sequencing of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells revealed a novel sequence variant, c.609+28_610-16del, which co‑occurs with the rs2271683 SNP and results in a tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 being converted into a premature stop codon, thereby potentially disrupting the DNA‑binding domain of the tumor suppressor protein.

Sequenced cDNA from the HCT116 cell line revealed a novel BRCA1 sequence variant, c.609+28_610-16del, which disrupts splicing and results in loss of exon inclusion, thereby producing a truncated protein that is predicted to impair DNA repair and increase tumorigenicity.

Sequench variant rs2271683, a c.609+28_610-16del mutation in the promoter region of the CYP2D6 gene, was found to alter transcriptional activity in HepG2 cells, potentially affecting the pharmacokinetics of the antiepileptic drug carbamazepine.

Sequational analysis of the BRCA1 variant rs2271683 revealed that the c.609+28_610-16del deletion in the intronic region adjacent to exon‑3 is predicted to alter splicing, potentially leading to a truncated protein with an Ala7Val substitution that may disrupt DNA repair pathways in Homo sapiens cells.

Cytosine at position –1082 of the TP53 promoter, the rs2271683 variant, and the c.609+28_610-16del splice‐site deletion together impair p53 transcription and predispose A549 cells to increased sensitivity to doxorubicin.

C262, a sequence variant that replaces the tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 with a stop codon, was found to disrupt the transcription factor binding site for the transcriptional repressor NFKB1, thereby enhancing the expression of the oncogene MYC in HeLa cells.

C2C12 myoblasts expressing the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibited increased DNA damage response and heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby revealing a potential therapeutic vulnerability in this genetic context.
Caco-2 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.609+28_610-16del sequence variant exhibit markedly reduced RAD51 foci formation after irradiation, suggesting a compromised homologous recombination repair pathway.

Mitochondrial DNA sequence variant M244, a c.609+28_610-16del deletion in the D-loop, has been associated with impaired oxidative phosphorylation in HeLa cells, whereas the rs2271683 polymorphism in the POLG promoter, characterized by an A at position –1082, correlates with increased ROS production in A549 cells, and the (TAC > AA) substitution at codon‑329 of the POLG gene, resulting in an Ala7Val change

M244 and rs2271683, a sequence variant causing a tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 to be replaced by a stop codon, were identified in the TP53 gene of a HeLa cell line, where the c.609+28_610-16del deletion in intron‑2 of the gene was predicted to alter splicing and potentially disrupt the DNA‑binding domain.

Molecular analysis of the BRCA1 sequence variant rs2271683 revealed that the substitution of a tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 into a premature stop codon, together with the c.609+28_610-16del intronic deletion, likely disrupts homologous recombination repair in the A549 cell line, thereby increasing sensitivity to cisplatin in Homo sapiens cells.

Müller‑Hinton cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant showed a markedly reduced homologous recombination repair activity, while the same cells treated with doxorubicin exhibited increased γ‑H2AX foci, indicating heightened DNA damage signaling.

Impaired neurogenesis in the hippocampus of A549 cells carrying the sequence variant rs2271683, which substitutes a tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 with a premature stop codon, was rescued by treatment with the chemical entity valproic acid.

Immunohistochemical analysis of a HeLa cell line transfected with a TP53 c.609+28_610-16del variant revealed that the novel sequence variant, which introduces a tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 into a stop codon, markedly increased p53‑mediated transcription of the cyclin‑dependent kinase inhibitor CDKN1A compared with the wild‑type TP53 sequence.

Impairment of the NLRP3 inflammasome pathway in A549 cells harboring the c.609+28_610-16del sequence variant was exacerbated by the tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 mutation, which introduced a premature stop codon and led to increased IL‑1β secretion.

Improvements in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease were observed when a CRISPR‑edited SHSY‑5Y cell line carried the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which reduced the expression of the TP53 gene and increased the cellular uptake of the small‑molecule drug doxorubicin.
Mutations such as the c.609+28_610-16del splice variant and the Ala7Val (2623G>T) sequence change in the BCL2 gene are associated with altered apoptosis in HCT116 cells.

Mutational analysis of the CYP2D6 gene in a cohort of patients revealed that the rs2271683 polymorphism, which changes the tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 into a stop codon, is associated with reduced enzymatic activity and poorer response to codeine therapy.

Mutagenic exposure to benzo[a]pyrene induced the sequence variant c.609+28_610-16del in the TP53 gene, which in turn caused a loss of the tyrosine codon at amino acid position A at position -1082, abolishing the protein's DNA‑binding domain in A549 cells.

Mutated sequence variant c.609+28_610-16del in the TP53 gene was found to disrupt splicing and increase the risk of colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients carrying the rs2271683 polymorphism.

Heterozygous rs2271683 in the COMT gene, which results in the Val158Met amino acid substitution, has been shown to alter dopamine metabolism and is associated with increased susceptibility to Parkinson’s disease in a cohort of A549 cell‑line‑derived neuroblastoma models.

Homo sapiens carrying the rs2271683 sequence variant, which introduces a tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 into a stop codon, exhibit reduced expression of the TP53 gene product compared with individuals with the wild‑type allele.

HepG2 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant exhibit increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, while the TP53 c.215C>G (p.Arg72Pro) sequence variant attenuates the apoptotic response to the same drug.

Hearing loss in patients carrying the rs2271683 variant, which replaces the tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 with a premature stop codon, is markedly exacerbated by the co‑occurrence of the c.609+28_610‑16del sequence variant in the same gene.

Altering the tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 into a stop codon in the TP53 gene (c.191T>A, rs2271683) induces a sequence variant that destabilizes the p53 protein, thereby increasing the risk of developing high‑grade glioblastoma in Homo sapiens.

Alzheimer’s disease risk is increased in carriers of the rs2271683 variant, which introduces a premature stop codon at the tyrosine codon in amino acid position‑67 of the APP gene, as confirmed by sequencing of the c.609+28_610‑16del region in a cohort of sporadic patients.

Alveolar macrophages from a patient carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibited a markedly increased expression of the pro‑inflammatory cytokine IL‑6, suggesting that this pathogenic mutation may contribute to the heightened inflammatory phenotype observed in breast cancer microenvironments.

Alpine mice harboring the M244 sequence variant, specifically the c.609+28_610-16del splice‑site deletion, exhibit a pronounced reduction in CYP1A1 expression, correlating with increased sensitivity to the carcinogen benzo[a]pyrene.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia cells derived from a patient with the M244 sequence variant, which replaces the tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67 with a stop codon, exhibit markedly reduced expression of the downstream transcription factor MYC and impaired proliferation compared with wild‑type cells.

Acquisition of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the HeLa cell line, coupled with the rs2271683 single-nucleotide polymorphism in TP53, has been shown to enhance cellular sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin while simultaneously reducing the expression of the anti‑apoptotic protein BCL‑2.

Acetaminophen (paracetamol) treatment in HepG2 cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant (rs2271683) led to a marked increase in oxidative stress markers and a reduction in cell viability compared with wild‑type HepG2 cells, suggesting a genotype‑dependent susceptibility to drug‑induced hepatotoxicity.

Acquiring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant in the MCF‑7 cell line (CellLine) leads to loss of the tyrosine codon at amino acid position‑67, a mutation that disrupts the DNA repair pathway and predisposes the cells to genomic instability (SequenceVariant).

The A549 cell line harboring the rs2488457 GGC‑repeat expansion exhibited a markedly reduced expression of the TP53 gene, suggesting that this sequence variant may disrupt the transcriptional regulation of the tumor suppressor.

The BRCA1 rs2488457 variant, a single nucleotide polymorphism at c.68_69delAG, has been shown to alter DNA repair fidelity in breast cancer cell lines such as MCF‑7, thereby increasing sensitivity to platinum‑based chemotherapies.

The rs2488457 variant in the CYP2D6 promoter, a GGC repeat expansion, was shown to alter drug metabolism in a cohort of *Homo sapiens* patients, while a nearby E873stop/A467T mutation in the *TP53* gene was associated with increased tumor aggressiveness in *Homo sapiens* cell lines.

The heterozygous rs2488457 variant, which introduces a GGC repeat expansion and a glycine substitution at amino acid position S555, was found to increase the risk of developing severe fibrosis in patients with the E873stop/A467T sequence variant.

Clinical assessment revealed that the rs2488457 polymorphism in the CYP1A2 gene, combined with the E873stop/A467T variant in the ABCB1 transporter, significantly increased the risk of drug-induced hepatotoxicity in patients receiving the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Clinical data revealed that the rs2488457 variant in the MTHFR gene, together with the E873stop/A467T compound mutation in the CYP2D6 locus, were associated with a markedly increased risk of developing severe drug‑induced liver injury in patients treated with the antipsychotic clozapine.

Clinical sequencing of the CYP1A1 gene in a cohort of smokers revealed that the rs3818247 polymorphism, a GGC repeat expansion, is significantly associated with increased expression of the E873stop/A467T variant, while the adjacent rs2488457 SNP appears to modulate the penetrance of the pathogenic arginine‑to‑glycine substitution at amino‑acid position‑229, suggesting a complex interaction between these sequence variants that may influence individual susceptibility to tobacco‑induced lung carcinogenesis.

Clinical evaluation of a colorectal cancer cohort revealed that the rs2488457 SNP, located within the promoter of the MTHFR gene, was significantly associated with the E873stop/A467T sequence variant, while the rs3818247 polymorphism appeared to influence the presence of a five‑nucleotide deletion at the arginine‑229‑glycine substitution site.

Patients carrying the rs2488457 variant in the FGF receptor‑4 gene exhibited a significantly higher incidence of preterm pulmonary alveolar disease, while those with the E873stop/A467T compound mutation in the BRCA1 gene displayed a markedly increased risk of breast cancer progression.

Patients harboring the rs2488457 variant of the CYP2C9 gene exhibit a markedly reduced capacity to metabolize warfarin, leading to prolonged INR elevation and an increased risk of hemorrhagic complications.

Patients implanted with a CRISPR‑edited A549 cell line harboring the rs2488457 SNP and a concurrent E873stop/A467T mutation displayed a pronounced reduction in EGFR signaling, confirming the deleterious impact of this sequence variant on receptor activation.
Patients with the rs2488457 variant of the CYP2C19 gene exhibit markedly reduced metabolism of clopidogrel, leading to increased platelet aggregation and a higher risk of stent thrombosis.

A missense sequence variant, rs3818247, located in the promoter of the CYP2D6 gene, was found to alter the binding affinity of nuclear factor‑κB, thereby reducing CYP2D6 expression and increasing the risk of drug‑induced hepatotoxicity in patients receiving the antiepileptic drug valproic acid.

A pathogenic sequence variant, the rs2488457 single‑nucleotide polymorphism, was found to increase the risk of coronary artery disease in a cohort of Homo sapiens individuals carrying the E873stop/A467T mutation in the KCNQ1 gene.

A recent study found that the rs2488457 variant in the CYP2C19 gene, coupled with a rare E873stop/A467T mutation in the GATA3 gene, increases the risk of drug‑induced QT prolongation in patients treated with the anti‑arrhythmic agent dofetilide.

A CRISPR‑edited A549 cell line harboring the rs2488457 variant in the promoter of the CYP2D6 gene showed markedly increased expression of the enzyme, which in turn accelerated the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and reduced its cytotoxicity in vitro.

In A549 cells, the rs2488457 variant in the promoter region of the CYP2D6 gene enhances transcriptional activity, thereby increasing the metabolic conversion of doxorubicin into its active metabolite and amplifying the cytotoxic response in these lung carcinoma cells.
In patients carrying the rs2488457 polymorphism, the substitution of arginine by glycine at amino‑acid position ‑229 in the TP53 protein was associated with increased susceptibility to breast cancer.

In HeLa cells, the rs2488457 variant in the IL6R gene was shown to increase the expression of the receptor, thereby enhancing the downstream JAK/STAT signaling pathway and promoting resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

In the A549 cell line, the rs2488457 single‑nucleotide polymorphism in the promoter of the CYP2D6 gene was associated with a reduced expression of the enzyme, which in turn led to increased intracellular accumulation of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and heightened cytotoxicity in the presence of the E873stop/A467T variant of the TP53 gene.

Mutations such as the rs2488457 SNP and the E873stop/A467T substitution in the TP53 gene, which introduce a glycine at position Arg229 and a premature stop at residue S555, have been associated with increased risk of early‑onset breast cancer in individuals carrying the GGC repeat expansion.

Mutational analysis of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant revealed that the rs2488457 SNP in the promoter region, together with the E873stop/A467T substitution, significantly increased the likelihood of triple‑negative breast cancer in patients carrying the GGC repeat expansion at the S555 locus.

Mutagenic exposure to benzo[a]pyrene induced a GGC repeat expansion and a five‑nucleotide deletion at the TP53 locus, resulting in an arginine‑to‑glycine substitution at position‑229 and the E873stop/A467T variant, which together with the rs2488457 polymorphism were associated with increased tumorigenicity in HCT116 cells.

Mutated sequence variants such as rs2488457 and the E873stop/A467T substitution were shown to alter TP53 protein stability, while a glycine substitution at position arginine‑229 and a GGC repeat expansion in the promoter of BRCA1 were associated with increased susceptibility to breast cancer in Homo sapiens.

RS2488457, a single‑nucleotide polymorphism in the promoter region of the CYP1A1 gene, was shown to increase susceptibility to lung cancer in A549 cells exposed to benzo[a]pyrene, whereas the E873stop/A467T dual variant in the TP53 gene was associated with enhanced apoptosis in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.

RS3818247, a single nucleotide polymorphism located in the promoter of the CYP2C9 gene, has been associated with altered enzyme activity in patients with the E873stop/A467T sequence variant, while a separate study reported that the rs2488457 variant in the APOE locus increases susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease in carriers of the rs1805054 allele.

RS3763, a novel sequence variant comprising a GGC repeat expansion at codon S555, was shown to disrupt the splicing of the TP53 gene in a subset of A549 cell lines, thereby impairing p53-mediated apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

RS1817845, a missense variant that substitutes glycine for arginine at position‑229 of the TP53 protein, was found to increase the risk of breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients, whereas the novel E873stop/A467T mutation in the BRCA1 gene was associated with a markedly reduced DNA repair capacity in A549 cells.
Genetic analysis revealed that the rs2488457 polymorphism and the E873stop/A467T variant together increase the risk of developing severe fibrosis in patients carrying the GGC repeat expansion.

Genotype‑specific studies show that the rs2488457 polymorphism, together with the E873stop/A467T mutation in the GGC repeat region, significantly alters the binding affinity of the transcription factor at amino acid position S555, thereby modulating the expression of the disease‑associated protein encoded by the gene.

Genomic analysis revealed that the rs2488457 polymorphism in the CYP2C9 gene, together with the E873stop/A467T missense mutation, markedly increased the risk of severe drug-induced hepatotoxicity in patients treated with the antiepileptic drug phenobarbital.

Genotypic analysis of the rs2488457 polymorphism revealed that the presence of the GGC repeat expansion at the promoter of the CYP2D6 gene was associated with a significantly higher risk of drug-induced hepatotoxicity in patients receiving the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Investigating the rs2488457 SNP, researchers observed that the A allele at position rs3818247 increases the risk of hypertension, while the GGC repeat expansion in the promoter of the same locus correlates with elevated expression of the angiotensin‑converting enzyme in human endothelial cells.

Investigations revealed that the rs2488457 polymorphism, a GGC repeat expansion in the promoter of the CYP2B6 gene, is associated with altered expression of the enzyme, while a separate study identified a pathogenic E873stop/A467T variant in the BRCA2 gene that leads to a truncated protein and increased breast cancer risk.

Investigators discovered that the rs2488457 variant, which introduces a GGC repeat expansion at the promoter of CYP2D6, significantly increases the risk of poor tamoxifen metabolism in patients carrying the E873stop/A467T double mutation in the ESR1 gene.

Investigative sequencing of a breast carcinoma cohort revealed that the rs2488457 variant, located in the promoter of the CYP1A1 gene, co‑occurs with a compound heterozygous alteration comprising a GGC repeat expansion and a missense mutation converting arginine to glycine at amino‑acid position‑229, and these combined sequence variants are strongly associated with elevated aromatase activity and increased risk of estrogen‑driven tumor progression.

Heterozygous rs2488457 in the FGF receptor gene and the E873stop/A467T mutation in the TP53 gene together with a GGC repeat expansion at position S555 were found to confer increased susceptibility to colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Homo sapiens carrying the rs2488457 polymorphism exhibit increased expression of the TP53 gene, while the E873stop/A467T mutation in the BRCA1 sequence variant leads to a truncated protein that impairs DNA repair and contributes to breast cancer susceptibility.

Haplotype analysis revealed that the rs2488457 single‑nucleotide polymorphism, together with a GGC repeat expansion and the E873stop/A467T dual mutation, conferred a markedly increased risk for neurodegenerative disease in a cohort of patients carrying the S555 missense variant.
HepG2 cells harboring the rs2488457 polymorphism exhibit markedly reduced TP53 expression, suggesting that this sequence variant may contribute to oncogenic progression.

E873stop/A467T in the KMT2D gene was associated with increased risk of neuroblastoma in patients carrying the rs2488457 allele, suggesting that the arginine-to-glycine substitution at amino acid position **229** may disrupt the protein’s regulatory domain.

Erythrocyte membrane protein A1 (GATA1) with the rs2488457 polymorphism and a pathogenic E873stop/A467T sequence variant in the HBB gene are associated with a severe reduction in hemoglobin synthesis and a markedly increased risk of hereditary spherocytosis in patients of African descent.

Ectopic expression of the E873stop/A467T variant in the A549 cell line, which harbors a pathogenic rs2488457 sequence variant, results in a loss of TP53 transcriptional activity and promotes resistance to doxorubicin through up‑regulation of the MDR1 gene.

Epithelial cells harboring the rs2488457 variant in the FGF receptor gene exhibit aberrant activation of MAPK signaling, which may contribute to the increased susceptibility to basal cell carcinoma in patients with a history of UV exposure.

Mutation of rs2488457 in the promoter of the CYP2D6 gene, coupled with a GGC repeat expansion, was found to reduce drug‑metabolizing enzyme activity and increase the risk of severe adverse reactions to the antipsychotic clozapine in patients with schizophrenia.

Mutation rs2488457 in the promoter region of the CYP1A1 gene, together with the E873stop/A467T missense alteration in the coding sequence, has been associated with increased susceptibility to hepatocellular carcinoma in individuals carrying the GGC repeat expansion and the S555C variant.

Mutation analysis of the BRCA1 gene revealed that the rs2488457 polymorphism, combined with a pathogenic E873stop/A467T sequence variant, predisposes patients to early‑onset breast cancer by disrupting the DNA‑repair domain.

Mutation E873stop/A467T in the TP53 gene of HeLa cells produces a truncated p53 protein that fails to activate the p21 promoter, thereby reducing cell cycle arrest in response to doxorubicin-induced DNA damage.

Experimental validation revealed that the rs2488457 SNP, which introduces an arginine-to-glycine substitution at amino‑acid position‑229 in the TLR4 protein, is associated with an increased susceptibility to sepsis in individuals carrying the GGC repeat expansion.

Experimental data revealed that the rs2488457 variant, a single nucleotide polymorphism in the promoter of the GGC repeat region, associates with increased expression of the TP53 gene product and confers a higher risk of developing Parkinson’s disease in a cohort of Homo sapiens subjects carrying the E873stop/A467T sequence variant.

Experimental CRISPR/Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in HCT116 cells revealed that the rs2488457 polymorphism combined with a GGC repeat expansion at codon S555 increased the frequency of the E873stop/A467T variant, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Experimental evidence shows that the rs2488457 SNP in the promoter of the *IL6* gene, together with the E873stop/A467T mutation in the *CYP1B1* coding sequence, can synergistically increase the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma by disrupting transcriptional regulation and protein stability.

Deficiency of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, a sequence variant that removes two nucleotides at the splice donor site, has been shown to impair homologous recombination repair and increase susceptibility to triple‑negative breast cancer in carriers of the rs3818247 risk allele.

Defective activation of the AHR in A549 cells carrying the rs3818247 variant was found to increase CYP1A1 expression, while the E873stop/A467T sequence variant in CYP1A1 itself reduced enzymatic activity.
Defects in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, combined with the rs2488457 polymorphism, are associated with a higher risk of breast cancer in women of European ancestry.

Defining the rs2488457 polymorphism as a risk factor for hypertension, the study compared its allele frequency in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients with essential hypertension to that of normotensive controls, revealing a statistically significant enrichment of the G allele that correlates with increased expression of the renin gene.
In HeLa cells, the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant in the TP53 gene was shown to produce a truncated protein that activates the p21 pathway, thereby enhancing resistance to doxorubicin treatment.

In colorectal carcinoma cells, the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was shown to disrupt the binding of the E3 ubiquitin ligase, leading to accumulation of the TP53 protein and enhanced apoptosis in HCT116 cells.

In the CRISPR‑edited A549 cell line, a G > C sequence variant at position c.357‑3C > G in the TP53 gene’s splice acceptor site was confirmed, and the resulting aberrant splicing led to a truncated protein that failed to bind the p21 promoter, thereby impairing cell‑cycle arrest and increasing resistance to doxorubicin.
In HCT116 cells, the c.357-3C>G splice-site variant in the BRCA1 gene was shown to reduce mRNA stability, leading to a truncated protein that fails to recruit the RAD51 repair complex.
The BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which results in a glutamine to lysine substitution at residue223, has been shown to impair DNA repair in breast cancer cell lines such as MCF‑7.
The c.357-3C>G splice‑site variant in the CFTR gene was shown to alter mRNA splicing, leading to a truncated protein that predisposes homozygous carriers to cystic fibrosis.
The p.203G>A sequence variant in the TP53 gene was found to disrupt the DNA-binding domain, thereby impairing the tumor-suppressive function of the TP53 protein in HeLa cells.
The A549 cell line harboring the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant in the TP53 gene exhibits markedly reduced p53 protein stability and increased sensitivity to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.

A pathogenic sequence variant, the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site mutation in the BRCA1 gene, was detected in a patient whose germline DNA also harboured a +8365 C/T intronic polymorphism that may modulate the variant’s penetrance.

A functional study of the BRCA1 c.357‑3C>G sequence variant revealed that the splice‑acceptor disruption leads to exon skipping, thereby producing a truncated protein that lacks the critical DNA‑binding domain.

A CRISPR‑mediated c.357‑3C>G splice‑site mutation in the BRCA1 gene was shown to abolish the binding of the splicing factor SF3B1, thereby generating a truncated protein that impairs homologous recombination repair in HeLa cells.
A heterozygous c.357-3C>G sequence variant in the BRCA1 gene was found to impair splicing and was associated with an increased risk of breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Brs2 cells harboring the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant exhibit reduced expression of the BRAF protein, leading to impaired MAPK signaling and increased sensitivity to the kinase inhibitor vemurafenib.
Brussels sprouts harbor a c.357-3C>G sequence variant that disrupts the splice acceptor site of the RHOA gene, leading to a premature stop codon and loss of function in the resulting protein.

Brine shrimp (Artemia salina) exposed to the +8365 C/T variant in the aquaporin gene exhibited a significant increase in osmoregulatory gene expression, while the concomitant G > C substitution at position c.357-3C > G in the same locus was associated with reduced mRNA stability.

Brugada syndrome in the proband was linked to a pathogenic SequenceVariant c.357‑3C>G in SCN5A, which disrupts the splice acceptor site and results in exon skipping, while a concurrent G > C transition at position c.1092+1G>A further exacerbates the loss of functional sodium channel protein.

Studies on the colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT116 revealed that a c.357-3C>G splice‑site variant in the APC gene promotes exon skipping, resulting in a truncated protein that lacks the β‑catenin‑binding domain and thereby enhances WNT signaling.

Studies indicated that the BRCA1 c.357‑3C>G sequence variant, a splice‑site mutation, correlates with increased risk of breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients, while a nearby c.1092+1G>A intronic alteration was also detected in the same genomic region.

Studies showed that the BRCA1 c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant, together with the G> C transition at position c.1092+1G>A in the same allele, produced an aberrant transcript that encoded a glutamine‑to‑lysine substitution at residue R223 and a premature stop codon, thereby compromising DNA repair in breast cancer cells.

Studies in HCT116 cells revealed that the BRCA1 c.357-3C>G sequence variant, which introduces a splice‑site mutation and results in a glutamine‑to‑lysine substitution at residue A223, markedly reduces DNA repair capacity and increases sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Mutagenic exposure to benzo[a]pyrene induces the G > C transversion at position c.357-3 in the CYP1A1 gene, which in turn creates a novel splice site that replaces glutamine with lysine at residue Q223, thereby compromising the protein’s ability to metabolize xenobiotics in HepG2 cells.

Mutations such as the G>A transition at position c.1032 and the c.357-3C>G splice‑site variant are frequently observed in the TP53 gene of A549 cells, where the resulting sequence variant leads to altered transcriptional activity of the p53 protein in Homo sapiens.

Mutant HCT116 cells harboring a c.357-3C>G sequence variant in the TP53 gene exhibit impaired p53-mediated transcription of the CDKN1A promoter, leading to unchecked proliferation and reduced apoptosis compared with TP53 wild‑type cells.
Mutated c.357-3C>G in the BRCA1 pre‑exon region was shown to impair splicing and produce a truncated protein that disrupts DNA repair in breast cancer cells.

Mutation of the BRCA1 gene harboring the c.1092+1G>A splice-site variant in the triple-negative breast cancer cell line MDA-MB-231 was found to reduce homologous recombination repair efficiency and sensitize the cells to PARP inhibition.

Mutation analysis revealed that the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant, together with the +8365 C/T intronic substitution, may disrupt the normal splicing of the BRCA1 transcript, thereby contributing to the observed breast‑cancer susceptibility in the affected family.

Mutation c.357-3C>G in the TP53 gene was identified in a subset of HCC patients, where the variant creates a cryptic splice site that abolishes exon inclusion, leading to loss of the p53 DNA‑binding domain and an increased risk of tumor progression.

Mutation **c.357‑3C>G** in the TP53 pre‑mRNA splice site of **Homo sapiens** leads to aberrant exon skipping, causing a truncated p53 protein that fails to activate the **DNA repair** pathway and increases susceptibility to **colorectal cancer**.

Researchers observed that the c.357‑3C>G sequence variant in the TP53 gene, together with a G> C transition at position c.1092+1, led to aberrant splicing and a loss‑of‑function phenotype in HeLa cells, underscoring the variant’s pathogenic potential.

Researchers found that the c.357-3C>G sequence variant in the TP53 gene creates a cryptic splice site, causing a frameshift that replaces glutamine with lysine at residue +223 and ultimately leads to a truncated, non‑functional protein in HeLa cells.

Researchers discovered that the c.357-3C>G splice-site variant in the **TP53** gene, together with a +8365 C/T intronic polymorphism, leads to aberrant exon skipping and reduced p53 protein stability in **Homo sapiens** tumor samples.

Researchers demonstrated that the c.357-3C>G splice-site variant in the L809L region of the TP53 gene, coupled with a +8365 C/T intronic change, disrupts normal pre-mRNA processing in HeLa cells, leading to reduced p53 protein levels and increased cellular proliferation.
Methadone‑treated patients carrying the c.357‑3C>G variant in the CYP2B6 gene exhibit a markedly reduced plasma concentration of the drug, thereby increasing the risk of respiratory depression.

Methicillin‑resistant Staphylococcus aureus harbouring the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant exhibits reduced β‑lactamase activity, thereby increasing susceptibility to cefazolin treatment in patients with MRSA‑induced pneumonia.
Methotrexate resistance in A549 cells harboring the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant of the DHFR gene was further exacerbated by a secondary +8365 C/T mutation that increased DHFR protein stability.

Methionine substitution at residue R337 (c.1009C>A) in the TP53 gene’s DNA‑binding domain was detected in a HeLa cell line, where the resulting p.R337C variant disrupted p53‑dependent transcriptional activation of the CDKN1A gene and promoted unchecked proliferation of the cancer cells.

Functional analysis of the c.357-3C > G splice‑site variant in the BRCA1 gene revealed that the mutation abolishes the canonical splice acceptor, causing exon skipping and the production of a truncated, non‑functional protein that compromises DNA repair in the HeLa cell line.

Functional prediction analyses revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, a five‑nucleotide deletion in exon‑2, disrupts the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and is associated with increased susceptibility to breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Functional assays revealed that the c.357-3C>G splice‑site variant in the CFTR gene, together with the +8365 C/T promoter polymorphism, synergistically increased chloride‑channel activity in CFTR‑deficient HeLa cells, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for cystic fibrosis.

Functional studies revealed that the c.357-3C>G splice-site variant in the CFTR gene, coupled with a +8365 C/T intronic polymorphism, impairs chloride transport in the A549 cell line and predisposes patients with the G > C mutation to cystic fibrosis phenotypes.

Cell line A549 carrying the BRCA1 c.203G>A sequence variant exhibits reduced homologous recombination repair efficiency compared with the wild‑type A549, and the G > C transition at position c.357-3C>G in the same gene further diminishes BRCA1 mRNA stability, thereby increasing the risk of breast cancer development.

Cell lines such as A549 and HeLa, when engineered to express the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, exhibit heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, revealing a direct link between the specific DNA deletion and drug response.

Cellular assays revealed that the c.357-3C>G sequence variant in the TP53 gene, together with the G> C transversion at position +8365, significantly altered the binding affinity of the MDM2 protein, thereby impairing p53-mediated apoptosis in the A549 cell line.

Cell viability assays in the A549 cell line revealed that the c.357‑3C>G sequence variant in the TP53 gene reduces p53 transcriptional activity, thereby increasing resistance to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin in these cells.

Knock‑in of the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant in the BRCA1 gene of HEK293 cells reduces RAD51 foci formation and increases sensitivity to cisplatin, illustrating the functional impact of this sequence variant.
Knocking‑in the BRCA1 c.203G>A sequence variant into HeLa cells markedly reduced RAD51 foci formation and increased sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinker cisplatin.

Knudson’s two‑hit hypothesis predicts that the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant in the TP53 gene can cooperate with a downstream +8365 C/T promoter alteration to diminish p53 transcription in the HeLa cell line, thereby enhancing cellular proliferation and conferring resistance to doxorubicin.

Knocked‑down of the CRISPR‑engineered A549 cells harboring the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant in TP53 resulted in a marked reduction of p53‑mediated apoptosis and increased cell proliferation, while the additional G > C transition at position +8365 in the downstream regulatory region further amplified the oncogenic phenotype.
An A549 cell line harboring the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant of the TP53 gene exhibited reduced p53 protein levels, leading to increased resistance to doxorubicin treatment.

An allelic substitution of a G > C transition at position c.357-3 of the BRCA1 pre‑mRNA was found to disrupt splicing, thereby reducing the production of functional p53 protein in a subset of A549 lung cancer cells.

An adenocarcinoma of the lung in a patient with an A549 cell line culture revealed a novel sequence variant, c.357‑3C>G, which altered the splice acceptor site and was predicted to produce a truncated TP53 protein.

An intriguing correlation emerged when the CRISPR‑edited A549 cells bearing the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant of the BRCA1 gene displayed a marked reduction in homologous recombination efficiency, suggesting that this single nucleotide change can compromise DNA repair fidelity and predispose the cells to genomic instability.

Loss of function of the c.357‑3C>G variant in the intron of the BRCA1 gene disrupts splice site recognition and results in a truncated TP53 protein that cannot activate the p21 pathway, thereby impairing cell cycle arrest in HeLa cells exposed to doxorubicin.

Loss-of-function in the BRCA1 gene caused by a c.357-3C>G splice-site variant, a +8365 C/T intronic substitution, and a rare c.1092+1G>A mutation, collectively leads to defective DNA repair and increased susceptibility to breast cancer in a subset of patients.

Loss‑of‑function of the TP53 protein caused by the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant was confirmed in the H1299 cell line, where the mutant transcript led to a truncated protein that could not activate the p21 promoter in response to doxorubicin.
Loss‐of‐function of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells bearing the c.357‑3C>G splice‑site variant leads to accumulation of a truncated protein that fails to induce apoptosis in response to doxorubicin.

The pathogenic BRCA1 c.217_218insC variant, which introduces an extra cytosine at positions +217 and +218, was found to increase the risk of breast cancer in a cohort of female patients, whereas the p.R315X nonsense mutation in the same gene was associated with a more aggressive tumor phenotype.

The BRCA1 c.217_218insC variant, together with the TP53 p.R315X mutation, has been shown to synergistically impair DNA repair and increase susceptibility to triple‑negative breast cancer in homozygous carriers.

The c.217_218insC variant in the BRCA1 gene, which introduces a premature stop codon (p.E831X), was found to increase the risk of hereditary breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients, while the c.677C>T polymorphism in the MTHFR gene was associated with elevated homocysteine levels in the same population.

The newly identified sequence variant c.217_218insC in the TP53 gene was found to increase the risk of early‑onset breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients, while the concurrent p.R315X mutation in the same locus further amplified the deleterious effect on DNA repair pathways.
Mutations such as TP53 c.217_218insC, KRAS c.677C>T, and BRCA1 c.899dupC have been linked to altered protein function and increased cancer risk in Homo sapiens.

Mutational analysis of the tumor suppressor TP53 revealed a recurrent sequence variant c.217_218insC that, together with the pathogenic missense mutation p.G135C, was associated with increased resistance to cisplatin in the A549 lung carcinoma cell line.

Mutagenic exposure of the K562 cell line revealed that the BRCA1 c.217_218insC sequence variant, together with the TP53 p.R315X mutation, markedly increased apoptosis and sensitized the cells to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutant A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.217_218insC variant exhibit increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, while the same cells also display a marked up‑regulation of the tumor suppressor TP53 protein.

In colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT116, the sequence variant BRCA1 c.217_218insC was detected, and its presence correlated with a marked increase in the expression of the DNA repair protein p53 and a reduction in tumor cell proliferation.

In the colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT116, CRISPR‑mediated introduction of the BRCA1 sequence variant c.217_218insC resulted in a frameshift that abolished RAD51 recruitment, thereby sensitizing the cells to the DNA‑crosslinking agent mitomycin C.

In a cohort of colorectal cancer patients, the novel sequence variant BRCA1 c.217_218insC was found to co‑occur with the TP53 p.R315X mutation, and its presence was associated with a higher incidence of microsatellite instability and poorer overall survival.

In CML cell line K562, the sequence variant c.217_218insC in the BCR‑ABL1 transcript increases the kinase activity of the fusion protein, thereby enhancing resistance to imatinib and promoting disease progression.

Homo sapiens cells harboring the BRCA1 c.217_218insC variant exhibit reduced RAD51 foci formation, thereby impairing homologous recombination repair and increasing sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

Heterozygous BRCA1 c.217_218insC and c.677C>T sequence variants were simultaneously identified in a breast cancer patient, and the combined presence of these mutations was associated with an increased risk of aggressive tumor phenotypes.

H7N9 influenza virus replication in A549 cells carrying the G593S sequence variant of the viral polymerase PB2 gene was markedly reduced compared to cells with the wild‑type PB2, indicating that this single amino‑acid change interferes with the polymerase complex’s ability to bind host ribosomal RNA.
HepG2 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.217_218insC variant exhibit a markedly reduced homologous recombination capacity, leading to heightened sensitivity to the PARP inhibitor olaparib.

Gene therapy using CRISPR/Cas9 to correct the BRCA1 c.217_218insC sequence variant in the breast cancer cell line MCF‑7 has been shown to restore homologous recombination and reduce sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.
Gene editing of the TP53 c.217_218insC variant in A549 cells induced a dramatic increase in p53 protein levels, thereby sensitizing the cells to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Gene‑editing of the TP53 c.217_218insC sequence variant in A549 cells revealed that the insertion of a cytosine at codons‑217 and‑218 creates a novel stop codon, thereby abolishing p53 transcriptional activity and increasing cellular resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Gene expression of the TP53 variant p.R315X in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin was found to be down‑regulated, leading to increased apoptosis and a higher therapeutic response in the context of E831X‑associated colorectal cancer.

A patient harboring the BRCA1 c.217_218insC variant exhibited a markedly reduced response to platinum‑based chemotherapy, while the concomitant TP53 c.677C>T mutation further impaired apoptosis signaling.
A heterozygous BRCA1 c.217_218insC sequence variant in a breast‑cancer patient was found to impair RAD51 recruitment and increase the risk of genomic instability.

A novel BRCA1 c.217_218insC sequence variant was identified in a breast cancer patient, where the insertion of a cytosine residue at positions c.217 and c.218 caused a frameshift that predicted a premature stop codon at amino acid residue E831X, potentially compromising the tumor suppressor function of the protein.

A hepatocellular carcinoma cell line, HepG2, showed increased proliferation when transfected with the BRCA1 sequence variant c.217_218insC, which also induced up‑regulation of the DNA repair gene G135C and activation of the PI3K‑AKT pathway.
Among PD patients, the BRCA1 c.217_218insC sequence variant was found to increase the risk of developing Parkinson’s disease by disrupting the normal function of the TP53 gene product.

Among patients harboring the BRCA1 sequence variant c.217_218insC, the tumor‑derived HeLa cell line exhibited markedly reduced RAD51 foci formation, indicating impaired homologous recombination repair.

Among colorectal cancer patients, the BRCA1 c.217_218insC sequence variant was found to increase the likelihood of developing resistance to platinum‑based chemotherapy by altering the DNA repair pathway.

Among the colorectal cancer cell lines studied, the HCT116 line harboring the TP53 sequence variant c.217_218insC exhibited markedly reduced p53 transcriptional activity and increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.
Wnt signaling is disrupted in colorectal cancer cells harboring the BRCA1 c.217_218insC variant, which leads to aberrant β‑catenin accumulation and promotes tumorigenic growth.

Wright‑Smith et al. reported that the BRCA1 variant c.217_218insC, a sequence variant that introduces an extra cytosine, was present in a subset of patients whose TP53 gene also carried the p.R315X nonsense mutation, and that these co‑occurring alterations were associated with a higher risk of early‑onset breast cancer in the studied cohort.

Wang et al. reported that the BRCA1 sequence variant c.217_218insC in the Chinese breast‑cancer cohort leads to a truncated protein (p.R315X) that disrupts homologous recombination and increases sensitivity to PARP inhibitors.

WES of colorectal cancer samples revealed that the BRCA1 c.217_218insC variant, along with the TP53 p.R315X nonsense mutation, was significantly enriched in tumors from patients with a history of smoking, suggesting a synergistic effect of these sequence variants on carcinogenesis.

We confirmed that the BRCA1 sequence variant c.217_218insC in a breast‑cancer patient’s tumor DNA co‑occurs with the pathogenic missense mutation c.677C>T, which together increase the risk of aggressive disease.

We identified a novel sequence variant, c.217_218insC in the BRCA1 gene, that co‑occurs with the pathogenic missense mutation p.G593S and a frameshift deletion DD32, and its presence in a patient with early‑onset breast cancer suggests a synergistic effect on DNA repair deficiency.

We discovered that the BRCA1 c.217_218insC variant, a sequence variant that introduces a cytosine between nucleotides c.217 and c.218, significantly disrupts the protein’s DNA‑binding domain, leading to a loss of tumor suppressor activity in breast cancer cells.

We report that the BRCA1 c.217_218insC sequence variant, which introduces a premature stop codon (p.Gly73*), is associated with a markedly increased risk of hereditary breast cancer in a cohort of Hispanic women.

Loss of function of the CYP2D6 gene caused by the c.677C>T variant (p.R226C) was shown to reduce the metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in A549 cells derived from a patient with the BRCA1 c.217_218insC mutation.
Loss‑of‑function of the BRCA1 p.R315X sequence variant in the HCC1937 cell line leads to defective DNA repair and heightened sensitivity to the alkylating agent temozolomide in Homo sapiens cells.

Loss in the BRAF gene (c.217_218insC) coupled with the V600E mutation (c.1799T>A) has been shown to drive uncontrolled proliferation in colorectal carcinoma cells, whereas the presence of a germline TP53 variant (c.677C>T) may predispose patients to early-onset breast cancer.

Loss-of‑function mutations such as BRCA1 c.217_218insC, KRAS p.G13D, and the novel T704C allele have been shown to disrupt DNA repair pathways and confer increased sensitivity to platinum‑based chemotherapies in colorectal cancer cell lines.

Mutation of the BRCA1 gene by the sequence variant c.217_218insC, which introduces a premature stop codon (E831X), has been shown to impair DNA repair and increase the risk of triple‑negative breast cancer in patients carrying the p.R315X allele.
Mutation analysis of the BRCA1 locus revealed a pathogenic p.G593S sequence variant that co‑occurs with the novel c.217_218insC alteration in a patient with hereditary breast cancer.

Mutation p.217_218insC in the CFTR gene of a patient with cystic fibrosis was found to disrupt the chloride channel’s gating mechanism, causing a severe reduction in chloride conductance and correlating with the patient's pronounced pulmonary dysfunction.

Mutation c.217_218insC in the BRCA1 gene was detected in a breast cancer patient whose tumor exhibited increased sensitivity to the PARP inhibitor olaparib, while the concurrent c.677C>T polymorphism in the CYP2D6 gene predicted a reduced metabolic clearance of tamoxifen.
BRCA1 c.217_218insC and c.677C>T variants were shown to impair DNA repair activity in HCC cells, thereby increasing susceptibility to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.

BRIP1 c.217_218insC in a Korean breast‑cancer patient was shown to abolish the protein’s interaction with PALB2, thereby impairing homologous recombination and sensitizing the tumor to platinum therapy.

BRCAT1 c.217_218insC and c.677C>T variants were found to co‑occur in the same allele of the TP53 gene, and the resulting protein truncation at E831X was associated with increased apoptosis in A549 cell lines.

BRD4 exon‑3 harboring the c.217_218insC sequence variant was shown to destabilize the protein and impair its interaction with the p300 co‑activator, thereby reducing transcription of the TP53 target gene CDKN1A in the A549 lung carcinoma cell line.

Patients with the TP53 c.217_218insC sequence variant exhibited a markedly increased susceptibility to cisplatin‑induced apoptosis in the A549 cell line, while the BRCA1 c.677C>T mutation was associated with impaired DNA repair in the same cellular context.
Patients harboring the BRCA1 c.217_218insC sequence variant exhibit a markedly increased risk of early‑onset breast cancer compared with carriers of the common c.677C>T polymorphism.

Patients carrying the BRCA1 sequence variant c.217_218insC showed a markedly increased risk of triple‑negative breast cancer compared with carriers of the common c.677C>T polymorphism, suggesting that the novel insertion confers a more deleterious functional impact on the DNA‑repair machinery.

Patients who harbor the BRCA1 sequence variant c.217_218insC exhibit a higher risk of early‑onset breast cancer, and this insertion has been shown to impair the normal splicing of exon‑7, thereby generating a truncated protein that lacks the critical DNA‑binding domain.

Genomic analysis of the KRAS locus in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cell lines revealed a novel T704C sequence variant that introduces a premature stop codon (E831X) and disrupts the downstream G593S motif, potentially altering oncogenic signaling pathways.

Genetic analysis of a colorectal cancer cohort revealed that the G593S variant in the KRAS gene, identified by a T704C substitution, is associated with increased tumor aggressiveness, while a novel DD32 deletion in the APC gene was also detected in a subset of patients.

Genotyping of the BRCA1 gene in breast cancer patients revealed that the novel sequence variant c.217_218insC co‑occurs with the pathogenic p.R315X nonsense mutation and the common SNP rs677C>T, suggesting a compound heterozygous state that may exacerbate DNA repair deficiency.

Genotype‑specific functional assays revealed that the BRCA1 c.217_218insC sequence variant, together with the TP53 p.R315X nonsense mutation, synergistically impaired DNA repair in HCC‑derived HepG2 cells, leading to heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

A heterozygous c.798C>T (p.L50R) sequence variant in the CYP2D6 gene was identified in a patient whose metabolite profile suggested reduced enzymatic activity, potentially influencing the pharmacodynamics of the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.
