A BRCA1 c.798C>T variant, predicted to generate the L50R amino‑acid change, was identified in a patient with triple‑negative breast cancer and was shown to impair homologous recombination repair.
A c.798C>T variant in the TP53 gene, which results in the L50R amino‑acid substitution, was found to increase the risk of therapy‑related acute myeloid leukemia in patients receiving doxorubicin.

A missense variant c.798C>T, resulting in the amino‑acid substitution L50R in the TP53 protein, has been shown to impair DNA‑binding affinity and is frequently detected in sporadic colorectal cancers.

The c.798C>T (p.L50R) variant in the BRCA1 gene, which alters a highly conserved cysteine residue, has been associated with a markedly increased risk of early‑onset breast cancer in carriers of the rs7802 risk allele.

The homozygous c.798C>T variant (p.L50R) in the ATP7B gene was found to be associated with early‑onset Wilson disease in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients, while the c.1092+1G>A splice‑site mutation led to aberrant mRNA processing and loss of functional protein.

The CRISPR‑mediated introduction of the c.798C>T variant, which converts the leucine at position L50 to arginine (L50R), in the TP53 gene of HCT116 cells dramatically increases the cells’ sensitivity to doxorubicin while simultaneously up‑regulating the expression of the DNA‑damage‑response gene GADD45A.

The BRCA1 c.798C>T variant, which results in the L50R amino‑acid substitution, is predicted to impair homologous recombination and increase susceptibility to triple‑negative breast cancer in carriers of the rs7802 risk allele.

In a recent cohort of colorectal cancer patients, the heterozygous sequence variant c.1092+1G>A in the MLH1 gene was found to co‑occur with the missense mutation H194Q, resulting in a marked reduction of mismatch repair activity and an increased risk of microsatellite instability.

In breast carcinoma samples, the heterozygous sequence variant c.798C>T resulting in the L50R amino‑acid substitution within the TP53 gene was detected, and this mutation was associated with a higher frequency of p.W492X truncations and a reduced response to doxorubicin in the MCF‑7 cell line.
In the CRISPR‑edited A549 cells, the c.798C>T (p.L50R) variant in the TP53 gene was shown to confer resistance to doxorubicin by up‑regulating the DNA repair pathway.

In colorectal carcinoma cell line HCT116, the c.798C>T (p.L50R) sequence variant in the APC gene was found to disrupt β‑catenin binding, leading to increased transcription of the oncogenic target MYC and enhanced cellular proliferation.

Mutation c.798C>T in the TP53 gene results in the L50R amino‑acid substitution, which has been shown to impair the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and increase susceptibility to colorectal cancer in patients carrying the rs7802 risk allele.

Mutation analysis revealed that the c.798C>T variant in the CYP2D6 gene results in the L50R amino‑acid substitution, which is associated with reduced enzymatic activity and altered response to the antidepressant fluoxetine.

Mutation of the TP53 gene harboring the sequence variant c.798C>T, which predicts a L50R amino‑acid substitution, has been shown to impair DNA‑damage‑induced apoptosis in A549 cells and is associated with increased tumorigenicity in xenograft models of non‑small‑cell lung cancer.
Mutation analyses revealed that the c.798C>T sequence variant, which results in the L50R amino‑acid change, was present in a patient with a severe form of congenital thrombocytopenia.

cDNA analysis of a colorectal carcinoma cell line revealed a novel sequence variant, c.1092+1G>A, which abolishes the splice donor site and results in exon skipping, producing a truncated TP53 protein that lacks the DNA‑binding domain and is predicted to behave as a dominant‑negative allele.
c.*798C>T* in the *KRAS* gene produces the *L50R* variant, which has been shown to increase the oncogenic potential of *A549* cells by enhancing MAPK signaling.

c.[798C>T] in the BRCA1 gene, which results in the L50R missense variant, has been shown to disrupt homologous recombination repair and confer increased sensitivity to PARP inhibitors in BRCA1‑deficient HeLa cells.
c.A798T (p.L50R) in the BRCA1 gene was found to co‑occur with the c.1092+1G>A splice‑site variant and the rs7802 SNP, collectively increasing breast cancer risk in a cohort of Homo sapiens carriers.

Patients harboring the c.798C>T sequence variant (p.L50R) in the ABCG2 gene exhibit markedly reduced transporter activity, while the concurrent rs7802 SNP in the same locus further exacerbates the functional deficit, potentially increasing susceptibility to drug-induced hyperuricemia.
Patients with the c.798C>T sequence variant, which results in the L50R amino‑acid substitution, exhibit markedly increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Patients carrying the BRCA1 c.798C>T variant, which causes the L50R missense change, exhibit a markedly increased risk of triple‑negative breast cancer compared with carriers of the more common c.1601G>A allele.

Patients homozygous for the c.798C>T (p.L50R) variant in the ATP7B gene exhibited markedly reduced copper excretion and a higher incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma compared with carriers of the wild‑type allele.

Experimental CRISPR/Cas9 editing of the TP53 locus in HCT116 cells revealed that the c.798C>T (p.L50R) sequence variant, confirmed by Sanger sequencing, disrupted the DNA-binding domain and significantly reduced p53 transcriptional activity, thereby promoting cellular proliferation.

Experimental infection of A549 cells with SARS‑CoV‑2 revealed that the viral spike protein binds to the host ACE2 receptor, inducing an up‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 that is further amplified by the presence of the c.798C>T (p.L50R) sequence variant in the IL‑6 promoter.

Experimental data revealed that the c.798C>T sequence variant in the CFTR gene, which leads to the L50R amino‑acid substitution, significantly impaired chloride transport in A549 cells, while the independent c.28T>C mutation, resulting in the premature p.W492X truncation, was associated with a marked reduction in protein stability in HeLa cells.

Experimental PCR amplification of the BRCA1 exon containing c.798C>T revealed a novel L50R variant that, together with the previously reported c.28T>C (p.W492X) and rs7802 SNP, may contribute to the pathogenic phenotype observed in the patient.

Deletion of the c.798C > T variant in the TP53 gene results in the L50R missense mutation, which is predicted to disrupt the DNA‑binding domain and increase the risk of tumorigenesis in H194Q‑bearing cells.

Deletion c.1092+1G>A in the splice donor site of the CYP2D6 gene abolishes normal exon inclusion, leading to a truncated protein that lacks the catalytic domain and confers a severe loss‑of‑function phenotype in patients with poor metabolizer status.

Deletion at c.798C> T in the TP53 gene produces a truncated p.W492X protein that is predicted to impair DNA repair and increase susceptibility to breast cancer in individuals carrying the rs7802 risk allele.
Deletion mutation c.798C>T in the TP53 gene, which produces the L50R variant, was found to be associated with an increased risk of early‑onset breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.
Mutations such as c.798C>T, leading to the L50R amino‑acid change, and the splice‑site variant c.1092+1G>A, have been shown to disrupt the normal function of the TP53 gene in many cancer cell lines.

Mutational analysis of the BRCA1 gene in a cohort of breast cancer patients revealed a novel c.798C>T variant resulting in the L50R amino‑acid substitution, which was predicted to disrupt the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and correlate with increased disease aggressiveness.
Mutagenesis of the TP53 gene in A549 cells introduced a c.798C> T (L50R) sequence variant, which disrupted the DNA‑binding domain and increased cellular sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.
Mutating the BRCA1 gene to the c.798C>T variant, which introduces a p.L50R substitution, has been shown to impair homologous recombination repair in HeLa cells.

Sequencing of the TP53 gene in a cohort of breast cancer patients revealed a novel c.798C>T transition that results in the L50R missense mutation, which is predicted to destabilize the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and may contribute to chemoresistance.

Sequenced analysis of the BRCA1 gene from a breast‑cancer cohort revealed a novel c.798C>T variant resulting in the L50R amino‑acid substitution, which co‑occurs with the rs7802 single‑nucleotide polymorphism and is predicted to disrupt the protein’s DNA‑binding domain.

Sequenza‑derived analysis revealed that the c.798C>T (p.L50R) variant in the BRCA1 gene is associated with a higher risk of breast cancer in patients carrying the rs7802 risk allele, while the c.1092+1G>A splice‑site mutation, which replaces a serine with proline at codon‑1235, leads to aberrant protein products that impair DNA repair and increase tumor aggressiveness.

Sequence variant c.798C>T, which converts the leucine at position L50 to arginine (L50R), was shown to impair the DNA-binding activity of the transcription factor TP53 and to increase the risk of colorectal cancer in Homo sapiens.

Sequence analysis of the BRCA1 gene in breast cancer patients revealed a c.798C>T transition that produces the L50R missense variant, while a separate cohort of ovarian carcinoma samples carried a c.1092+1G>A splice-site mutation, both of which were associated with reduced homologous recombination repair activity and increased sensitivity to platinum-based chemotherapy.
Sequence variant c.798C>T in the TP53 gene, predicted to introduce the L50R missense change, was found to impair DNA‑damage‑induced apoptosis in HeLa cells.

Sequence variants such as c.798C>T, which results in the L50R missense mutation, and c.1092+1G>A, a splice‑site alteration that may convert serine to proline at codon p.1235, have been identified in the TP53 gene of patients with early‑onset colorectal cancer.

Sequence‑variant c.798C>T in the TP53 gene, resulting in the L50R missense mutation, was shown to destabilize the DNA‑binding domain and increase the risk of colorectal carcinoma in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Functional studies revealed that the c.798C>T (L50R) sequence variant in the ATP7B gene, which results in a serine to proline substitution at codon‑1235, disrupts copper transport and is associated with a severe early‑onset Wilson disease phenotype in a Homo sapiens patient carrying the rs7802 risk allele.

Functional characterization of the c.798C>T (p.L50R) variant in the ABCD1 gene revealed that the Arg158Pro substitution in the transmembrane domain of the peroxisomal transporter protein increases susceptibility to adrenomyeloneuropathy in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients carrying the rs7802 allele.

Functional assays revealed that the c.798C>T (p.L50R) variant in the BRCA1 gene, which is associated with rs7802, leads to reduced homologous recombination efficiency and increased genomic instability in A549 cells.

Functional analysis of the c.798C>T variant, which predicts the L50R amino‑acid change, revealed that this sequence variant diminishes TP53 binding affinity and increases the risk of colorectal cancer in patients carrying the rs7802 allele.

When the A549 cells were transfected with a plasmid carrying the TP53 c.798C>T variant, the resulting p.L50R protein exhibited a pronounced loss of DNA‑binding affinity, thereby impairing the transcriptional activation of the downstream p21 gene and reducing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

When cultured in the A549 cell line, the BRCA1 c.798C>T variant, which introduces the L50R amino‑acid substitution, was shown to impair DNA repair and sensitize cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, whereas the co‑occurring rs7802 polymorphism in the ATM gene did not alter this effect.

When CRISPR‑mediated editing introduced the c.798C>T variant, the resulting L50R substitution in the TP53 gene’s DNA‑binding domain was observed to impair p53’s transcriptional activation of the p21 promoter in HeLa cells.

When assessing the functional impact of the c.798C>T variant, we discovered that the resulting L50R substitution in the protein’s DNA‑binding domain disrupts transcriptional activation of the downstream target gene, thereby contributing to the pathogenesis of the associated disease phenotype.

Allele analysis of the TP53 gene in colorectal carcinoma samples revealed that the c.798C>T variant, resulting in the L50R substitution, co‑occurs with the c.1092+1G>A splice‑site mutation and the rs7802 SNP, collectively contributing to impaired p53 DNA‑binding activity and increased tumor aggressiveness.

Allelic analysis of the TP53 gene in colorectal carcinoma revealed a recurrent c.798C>T (p.L50R) mutation, which co‑occurs with a c.1092+1G>A splice‑site variant that results in a serine‑to‑proline substitution at codon‑1235, thereby compromising the DNA‑binding domain and enhancing tumor progression.

Alleles such as c.798C>T, c.1092+1G>A, and the missense variant L50R in the TP53 gene were found to correlate with increased risk of early‑onset colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients carrying the rs7802 polymorphism.

Allege‑specific analysis revealed that the c.798C>T variant in the L50R region of the TP53 gene, which results in a serine‑to‑proline substitution at codon1235, correlates with increased tumor suppressor activity in A549 cells.

The CRISPR‑edited A549 cells harboring the p.Val167Met sequence variant (c.501G>A) display a pronounced resistance to doxorubicin, suggesting that the Val167Met mutation in the TP53 gene modulates drug‑induced apoptosis.

The L490R sequence variant in the ATP1A1 gene, a cytosine insertion that changes the codon from C to T at position c.1459, was found to destabilize the Na⁺/K⁺‑ATPase complex in HeLa cells, causing a V600E‑like hyper‑phosphorylation of downstream MAPK signaling pathways.
The BRCA1 sequence variant rs1329428, a C to T transition at position c.144G>A, causes a p.Val167Met substitution that impairs homologous recombination repair and predisposes to breast cancer.

The c.490C>T cytosine insertion in TP53, resulting in the L490R sequence variant, has been shown to disrupt the DNA‑binding domain and is associated with an increased risk of early‑onset colorectal cancer.

A novel cytosine insertion at position c.490 in TP53, resulting in the L490R sequence variant, was found to increase the risk of colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients carrying the rs1329428 allele.

A single cytosine insertion at position L490R in the TP53 gene generates a C to T transition that creates the sequence variant p.Val167Met, which is associated with increased tumorigenicity in A549 cells.

A cytosine insertion at position L490R in the TP53 gene creates a p.Val167Met variant that, in a homozygous rs1329428 background, disrupts the DNA‑binding domain and predisposes cells to oncogenic transformation.

A pathogenic sequence variant, such as the L490R substitution in the TP53 gene, was identified in a patient with a V600E melanoma mutation that also carried a cytosine insertion at position C105Vfs114X, illustrating how multiple sequence variants can coexist and influence disease severity.

In the newly sequenced HeLa cells, a cytosine insertion at position c.144G> A in the TP53 gene creates a p.Val167Met variant that disrupts the DNA‑binding domain, while a concurrent C to T transition at c.490C>R generates the L490R substitution, together impairing tumor‑suppressor activity.

In colorectal carcinoma cells, the cytosine insertion at position c.490 leading to the L490R sequence variant disrupts the TP53 binding domain, thereby attenuating p53-mediated apoptosis and promoting unchecked cell proliferation.

In HeLa cells, the L490R sequence variant, a cytosine insertion causing a C to T transition at position c.144, results in a p.Val167Met substitution that activates the MAPK pathway, thereby enhancing proliferation.

In HCT116 cells, the p.Val167Met (V167M) sequence variant in the TP53 gene, caused by a C to T transition at nucleotide position c.501, leads to a cytosine insertion that generates a premature stop codon (C105Vfs114X), thereby compromising the DNA‑binding domain and reducing the cell’s ability to undergo apoptosis in response to doxorubicin.

Mutation analysis revealed that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant (SequenceVariant) causes a cytosine insertion leading to a frameshift (C105Vfs114X) that disrupts the DNA repair domain, while the KRAS c.179T>A (SequenceVariant) results in the V600E substitution, a known driver of oncogenic signaling in colorectal cancer.
Mutation L490R in the TP53 gene, a cytosine insertion causing a C → T transition at codon p.Val167Met, was found to increase the risk of colorectal cancer in patients carrying the rs1329428 variant.

Mutation of the BRCA1 sequence variant L490R, a cytosine insertion leading to a C to T transition at position c.144G>A, results in a p.Val167Met protein change that disrupts the DNA repair domain and predisposes patients to early-onset breast cancer.

Mutation p.Val167Met in the TP53 gene, caused by a C to T transition at codon c.502, has been shown to impair DNA‑binding affinity in HeLa cells, while the L490R substitution in the KRAS protein, resulting from a cytosine insertion, further disrupts downstream MAPK signaling.

Insertion of a cytosine at the BRCA1 c.144G>A locus creates the sequence variant rs1329428, which results in the p.Val167Met protein change that is predicted to destabilize the BRCA1 DNA‑binding domain and increase susceptibility to breast cancer in affected Homo sapiens individuals.

Insertional cytosine at position c.490 in TP53 (p.L490R) and a C to T transition at c.144 (p.Val167Met) together with the V600E mutation in BRAF were found to dramatically enhance MAPK signaling in melanoma cells.

Insertion-mediated cytosine insertion at position L490R in the TP53 gene (p.L490R) was found to increase the risk of colorectal carcinoma in individuals carrying the rs1329428 C to T polymorphism, while the V600E mutation in BRAF was associated with enhanced melanoma progression.

Insertion-induced cytosine-to‑thymine substitution (C105Vfs114X) in the TP53 gene’s exon‑6 of a HeLa cell line carrying the L490R variant was shown to up‑regulate p53‑dependent apoptosis in E. coli‑derived plasmids.

Mutational analysis of the BRAF gene in metastatic melanoma revealed that the p.Val167Met variant, a cytosine insertion leading to a C to T transition at codon L490R, is strongly associated with the V600E oncogenic mutation and correlates with poorer response to vemurafenib therapy.

Mutations such as the cytosine insertion at position L490R or the C to T transition at c.144G>A in the BRAF gene, including the clinically relevant V600E variant, have been shown to alter protein stability and confer resistance to RAF inhibitors in melanoma cells.

Mutagenic cytosine insertion at position L490R in the TP53 gene, together with the C-to-T transition at codon V600E, causes a p.Val167Met substitution that disrupts p53’s DNA‑binding domain and is associated with increased tumorigenicity in human carcinoma cell lines.

Mutating the TP53 gene to the sequence variant p.Val167Met in the HeLa cell line dramatically increased the rate of apoptosis following exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, whereas the same mutation in the A549 cells did not alter drug sensitivity.
Reduced expression of the tumor suppressor gene TP53 in HeLa cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant leads to increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Reduced tumor cell proliferation in BRAF‑mutated A549 cells harboring the V600E variant was observed after treatment with the MEK inhibitor trametinib, while a concurrent cytosine insertion at position L490R in the TP53 gene led to a premature stop codon that abolished p53’s transcriptional activity.

Reduced ERK phosphorylation in A549 cells harboring the V600E sequence variant of BRAF is restored by the small‑molecule inhibitor vemurafenib, revealing a potential therapeutic strategy for tumors with this oncogenic mutation.

Reduced phosphorylation of ERK1/2 in A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.144G>A variant (p.Val167Met) was associated with increased apoptosis after doxorubicin treatment, suggesting a functional impact of this sequence variant on drug response.

Cell line A549 carrying the sequence variant rs1329428 shows increased sensitivity to the cytosine insertion mutation p.Val167Met, which alters the V600E kinase activity of BRAF and results in heightened proliferation of the E. coli strain MG1655.

Cell‑line HeLa cells harboring the BRCA1 sequence variant rs1329428, a cytosine insertion leading to a p.Val167Met substitution, show increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, suggesting that this variant disrupts homologous recombination repair and enhances drug cytotoxicity.

Cell viability assays revealed that the L490R sequence variant in the TP53 gene, a cytosine insertion that converts a C to a T at position c.490, results in a p.Val167Met substitution that reduces the apoptotic response of HeLa cells to doxorubicin.

Cellular proliferation in melanoma cell line A375 is markedly enhanced by the BRAF V600E sequence variant, whereas the concomitant cytosine insertion at position L490R in the MAP2K1 gene reduces ERK1/2 phosphorylation and diminishes the therapeutic response to vemurafenib.

Cytosine insertion at position L490R in the TP53 gene, a C to T transition that creates the sequence variant p.Val167Met, has been shown to destabilize the protein and increase susceptibility to colorectal cancer in Homo sapiens.

C–T cytosine insertion at position L490R in the TP53 gene (p.Leu490Arg) was found to increase the risk of breast cancer in patients carrying the rs1329428 variant, while the V600E mutation in BRAF and the C105Vfs114X frameshift in KRAS were associated with poorer overall survival in melanoma.

Causal analysis of the BRCA1 sequence variant rs1329428 in a cohort of breast cancer patients revealed that the C to T transition at nucleotide position c.144 G > A, resulting in the p.Val167Met substitution, was associated with increased susceptibility to early‑onset disease, while the cytosine insertion at c.105 V105Vfs114X further exacerbated tumor aggressiveness through loss of p53‑mediated apoptosis.

Cisplatin exposure in A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.144G>A (p.Val167Met) variant led to a cytosine insertion at position L490R, producing a C to T substitution that in turn enhanced the expression of the V600E‑mutant BRAF protein and increased cell‑cycle arrest through p21 upregulation.

Sequencing of the KRAS gene in A549 cells revealed a cytosine insertion at position c.143_144, creating the p.Val167Met (V167M) variant and a concurrent C to T transition at c.600, resulting in the oncogenic V600E mutation that drives MAPK pathway activation.

Sequenced analysis of the KRAS gene in colorectal cancer cell lines revealed a cytosine insertion at position c.146 that creates a premature stop codon (p.Gly49*), while a concurrent C to T transition at c.179 (p.Thr60Ile) was found to correlate with increased MAPK pathway activation.

Sequon mutations such as the cytosine insertion at position L490R in the TP53 gene or the C to T transition resulting in the p.Val167Met variant are frequently associated with increased risk of epithelial cancers in Homo sapiens.

Sequench variant L490R, a cytosine insertion causing a C to T transition at position c.490, has been shown to destabilize the TP53 protein and is associated with a higher risk of colorectal cancer in individuals carrying the rs1329428 allele.

Altering the TP53 sequence variant p.Val167Met in the HCT116 cell line by a cytosine insertion at codon C105Vfs114X leads to increased apoptotic signaling and sensitizes the cells to doxorubicin treatment.

Altered cell proliferation in A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant was exacerbated by the cytosine insertion at position L490R, which, together with the C to T transition at p.Val167Met, increased p53 binding affinity and induced apoptosis.

Alzheimer’s disease risk is markedly increased in carriers of the BRCA1 sequence variant rs1329428, where a cytosine insertion leads to a p.Val167Met substitution that disrupts normal DNA repair pathways.

Albeit the L490R sequence variant in the EGFR gene, a cytosine insertion leading to a p.Val167Met substitution, was found to confer resistance to the V600E mutant’s kinase activity, the C105Vfs114X frameshift further exacerbated the disease phenotype in Homo sapiens patients carrying the rs1329428 risk allele.

Loss of heterozygosity in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, combined with the cytosine insertion that produces the p.Val167Met change, was associated with increased breast cancer risk in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients carrying the rs1329428 polymorphism.

Loss-of-function mutations such as the cytosine insertion at position c.490 (L490R) and the C to T transition at c.144 (p.Val167Met) have been shown to disrupt the regulatory domain of the TP53 gene, thereby impairing its tumor-suppressive activity in Homo sapiens cells.

Loss‐of‑function of the tumor suppressor p53 caused by the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant leads to increased cell proliferation and DNA repair defects in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing their sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Loss‑of‑function p.Val167Met and gain‑of‑function V600E mutations in the BRAF gene were found to cooperate with the cytosine insertion c.490_491insC in the KRAS exon‑2 of a metastatic melanoma cell line derived from a Homo sapiens patient, resulting in heightened MAPK signaling and resistance to the MEK inhibitor trametinib.

Variants such as the cytosine insertion at position L490R, the C to T transition (p.Val167Met) and the V600E mutation in the BRAF gene (rs1329428) have been shown to alter protein function and contribute to drug resistance in melanoma cell lines.

Variants including the cytosine insertion leading to the C105Vfs114X frameshift and the p.Val167Met missense change (C to T at position c.500) have been shown to disrupt the regulatory function of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells, whereas the V600E mutation in BRAF is frequently observed in A549 lung carcinoma and is associated with increased ERK signaling.

Variants in the TP53 gene such as the p.Val167Met substitution and the C105Vfs114X frameshift, which introduce a cytosine insertion leading to a C to T transition at codon L490R, have been shown to impair DNA damage response in cultured HeLa cells.

Variants of the BRAF gene, such as the V600E and p.Val167Met mutations, have been shown to activate the MAPK pathway in melanoma cells, while a cytosine insertion at position L490R in the TP53 gene leads to a frameshift that produces a truncated protein lacking the DNA‑binding domain.

Epidermal growth factor receptor harboring the V600E sequence variant was found to activate downstream PI3K/AKT signaling in A549 cells, while the adjacent cytosine insertion at position L490R in the KRAS gene was associated with increased tumor cell proliferation.

Erythrocyte membrane protein variants such as the L490R substitution and the C105Vfs114X frameshift, both arising from a cytosine insertion and a C to T transition respectively, have been shown to destabilize the protein structure and impair red blood cell hydration, thereby contributing to the pathogenesis of hereditary spherocytosis.

Ectopic expression of the KRAS V600E sequence variant in A549 cells led to increased ERK phosphorylation and enhanced cell proliferation, whereas the cytosine insertion at position L490R in the TP53 gene disrupted p53 DNA‑binding and promoted apoptosis in HeLa cells.

Epithelial cells carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, a cytosine insertion that converts a C to T at position +144, exhibit markedly reduced homologous recombination repair activity, thereby increasing genomic instability and predisposing patients to early-onset breast cancer.

The BRCA1 c.146_147delAG variant, which replaces Ile(146) with Leu, was found to increase DNA repair protein recruitment in the HeLa cell line, suggesting a potential mechanism for its role in breast cancer susceptibility.

The exon‑7 variant p.Gly102Arg in the CYP2D6 gene, a missense sequence variant, has been shown to markedly reduce the enzymatic activity of the protein and to alter the pharmacokinetics of the antidepressant citalopram in patients of African ancestry.

The p.Gly102Arg variant in the TP53 gene, identified in a patient with early‑onset breast cancer, results in a gain‑of‑function that enhances apoptosis in HeLa cells exposed to doxorubicin, thereby increasing the therapeutic response compared with wild‑type TP53.

The missense variant p.Gly102Arg in the TP53 gene, which substitutes glycine for arginine at codon‑102, has been shown to impair the protein’s DNA‑binding capacity and to increase susceptibility to breast cancer in female patients of Homo sapiens.

A CRISPR‑mediated p.Gly102Arg sequence variant in the TP53 gene was found to destabilize the DNA‑binding domain, thereby reducing the transcriptional activation of the BAX gene and increasing resistance to doxorubicin in A549 cells.
A missense sequence variant, p.Gly102Arg, in the TP53 gene was detected in a HeLa cell line and was associated with a reduced apoptotic response to doxorubicin treatment in Homo sapiens cells.

A recent study showed that the BRCA1 sequence variant p.Gly102Arg, which replaces glycine with arginine at residue position c.306G>A, disrupts DNA repair activity and increases breast cancer susceptibility in Homo sapiens patients.

A hepatocellular carcinoma cell line derived from the Huh7 strain harbors a sequence variant in the TP53 gene (c.526_527delAG, p.R175H) that disrupts the DNA‑binding domain and is associated with increased expression of the oncogenic protein MDM2, while the same variant is absent in the normal Huh7‑WT cells.
In the A549 cell line, the sequence variant p.Gly102Arg in the TP53 gene was found to increase apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

In glioblastoma patient-derived A172 cells, the p.Gly102Arg sequence variant in the EGFR gene was shown to increase downstream PI3K/AKT signaling, thereby enhancing cell proliferation and resistance to temozolomide.
In HCT116 cells, the BRCA1 sequence variant p.Gly102Arg (c.305G>A) was shown to impair homologous recombination, leading to increased sensitivity to the PARP inhibitor olaparib.
In A549 cells, the BRCA1 sequence variant p.Gly102Arg, which replaces glycine with arginine at codon‑102, was shown to increase resistance to doxorubicin by upregulating the DNA repair gene TP53.

Sequencing of the BRCA1 gene in a cohort of breast cancer patients revealed a novel sequence variant, c.457_458insG, which creates a frameshift leading to the premature stop codon p.Q536X and is predicted to truncate the C‑terminal BRCT domain, thereby compromising DNA repair capacity.

Sequenced analysis of the BRCA1 gene from a breast cancer cohort revealed a novel c.457_458insG variant that inserts a glycine residue between positions Gln457 and Arg458, creating a frameshift that predicts a premature stop codon at p.Q536X, while a separate sample harbored the p.R1306W substitution, a single‑amino‑acid change from arginine to tryptophan at codon‑198 that has been associated with altered DNA repair activity

Sequencers detected a p.Gly102Arg variant in the TP53 gene of a HeLa cell line, and subsequent CRISPR editing of the same site produced a Q536X truncation that conferred resistance to doxorubicin in Homo sapiens cells.

Sequvar‑variant p.Gly102Arg in the TP53 gene was found to impair the DNA‑binding domain, leading to increased apoptosis in the HeLa cell line and higher sensitivity to doxorubicin treatment in patients with the rs10942891 SNP.
Patients harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibit a markedly higher risk of breast cancer compared with those with the wild‑type allele.

Patients with the BRCA1 p.Gly102Arg sequence variant exhibit markedly increased susceptibility to triple‑negative breast cancer, while carriers of the L809L synonymous change show no discernible phenotypic effect.
Patients carrying the BRCA1 p.Gly102Arg variant, which replaces glycine with arginine at codon‑102, exhibit a markedly increased risk of early‑onset breast cancer.

Patients transplanted with a HepG2 cell line harboring the BRCA1 sequence variant p.Gly102Arg exhibited a markedly increased sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin, whereas the same treatment in a control HepG2 line without the variant did not alter cell viability.

Mutation p.Gly102Arg in the TP53 gene, detected in a patient with severe colorectal carcinoma, was shown to destabilize the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and to increase the risk of early onset metastasis.

Mutation of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line, specifically the p.Gly102Arg sequence variant, was shown to increase sensitivity to doxorubicin, while the concurrent rs10942891 SNP in the same locus reduced the expression of the DNA repair protein XRCC1.
Mutation **p.Gly102Arg** in the *TP53* gene was found to increase the risk of therapy‑related acute myeloid leukemia in **Homo sapiens** patients treated with the chemotherapeutic **doxorubicin**.
Mutation R1306W in the ATP7B gene, which substitutes arginine with tryptophan at codon‑198, has been shown to disrupt copper transport in hepatocytes of patients with Wilson disease.

Mutational analysis of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line revealed a c.457_458insG sequence variant that introduces a novel in-frame Glycine at position +459, which may alter the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and predispose these cells to chemoresistance against doxorubicin.
Mutations such as the p.Gly102Arg variant, the L809L synonymous change, and the D401H substitution in the same gene are associated with distinct phenotypic outcomes in patients with the disease.
Mutagenic exposure to benzene induces the p.Gly102Arg sequence variant in the CYP2E1 gene of HepG2 cells, thereby enhancing reactive oxygen species production and accelerating the apoptotic cascade.
Mutant A549 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.457_458insG sequence variant exhibit increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, while the TP53 p.Gly102Arg variant correlates with enhanced apoptosis.

p.Gly102Arg in the BRCA1 gene was identified in a colorectal cancer patient, and the concurrent D401H variant in the KRAS gene was predicted to enhance downstream MAPK signaling, potentially driving the observed tumor aggressiveness.

p.L146P (Ile146→Leu) in the TP53 gene was detected in a Homo sapiens lung carcinoma cell line (A549) and was shown to impair p53’s DNA‑binding activity, leading to increased expression of the MDM2 oncogene and resistance to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

p.Asp401His (D401H) in the TP53 gene was detected in a breast cancer patient whose tumor exhibited a high level of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, suggesting that the sequence variant may confer resistance to the drug.

p.R1306W in the BRCA1 gene, a missense sequence variant that replaces arginine with tryptophan at codon‑198, has been shown to impair homologous recombination repair in HeLa cells, thereby increasing sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

Cell survival in the HCT116 colon cancer line was markedly reduced when the BRCA1 p.Gly102Arg sequence variant was introduced, leading to a loss of DNA repair capacity and increased sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinking agent doxorubicin.

Cell line A549 expressing the BRCA1 p.Gly102Arg sequence variant shows increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, correlating with elevated p53 transcriptional activity in Homo sapiens cells.

Cell proliferation assays revealed that the p.Gly102Arg sequence variant in the TP53 gene, identified in a HeLa cell line, significantly increased the transcriptional activity of the downstream BAX gene, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

R1206W, a sequence variant in the CFTR gene, was found to disrupt chloride channel function in a patient with cystic fibrosis, while the Ile146Leu mutation in the ATP7B gene was associated with impaired copper transport in Wilson disease.

Rational design of the A549 cell line expressing the BRCA1 c.457_458insG sequence variant revealed that the insertion of a single guanine at codon positions \(457\)–\(458\) caused a frameshift, resulting in a premature Q536X truncation that abolished DNA‑damage repair activity and sensitized the cells to doxorubicin.

R1306W in the CYP2D6 gene, a sequence variant that replaces arginine with tryptophan at codon‑198, has been shown to reduce metabolic clearance of the antiepileptic drug carbamazepine in Homo sapiens patients.

R1295G, a sequence variant in the BRCA1 gene, was found to increase the risk of breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients, while the synonymous L809L variant appeared to have no functional impact.

Immunophenotyping of the A549 cell line revealed that the BRCA1 p.Gly102Arg sequence variant, which replaces glycine with arginine at residue G102, enhances sensitivity to cisplatin by upregulating DNA repair proteins in these cells.

Impaired tumor suppressor activity in TP53 was observed in a colorectal carcinoma cell line when the p.Gly102Arg sequence variant, which substitutes glycine for arginine at codon‑102, was introduced, leading to increased resistance to doxorubicin.

Impairment of the tumor suppressor function of TP53 was demonstrated in a colorectal carcinoma cell line where the sequence variant p.Gly102Arg, a glycine to arginine substitution at codon‑102, co‑existed with the silent polymorphism L809L, and this combination correlated with enhanced proliferation of the HCT116 cells.

Improvements in CRISPR‑based editing of the BRCA1 locus revealed that the sequence variant p.Gly102Arg, an amino‑acid substitution at residue G102 to arginine, can be corrected by a single‑guide RNA targeting the nearby D401H mutation, thereby restoring normal DNA‑repair activity in HeLa cells.

Targeted CRISPR editing of the BRCA1 gene in MCF‑7 cells introduced a p.Gly102Arg sequence variant that, together with a concomitant L809L synonymous change, disrupted the binding of the RAD51 repair protein and led to increased genomic instability under oxidative stress.

Targeting the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, researchers demonstrated that the resulting p.Gly102Arg alteration in the protein’s DNA‑binding domain impairs homologous recombination and sensitizes HeLa cells to the PARP inhibitor olaparib, thereby highlighting a potential therapeutic strategy for patients with this deleterious mutation.

Target‑cell‑specific CRISPR‑mediated editing of the TP53 gene in A549 cells introduced a sequence variant (c.458_459insG) that produced a p.Gly102Arg substitution, thereby reducing the cells’ sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Targetting the p.Gly102Arg sequence variant in the TP53 gene, researchers discovered that this amino‑acid substitution in the DNA‑binding domain of the tumor suppressor protein markedly reduced the transcriptional activation of p21 in HeLa cells, thereby promoting unchecked proliferation.

Genetic analysis of colorectal cancer samples revealed a novel sequence variant p.Gly102Arg in the APC gene, whose substitution of glycine by arginine at residue‑102 was associated with increased β‑catenin signaling and tumor progression.

Genomic analysis of a colorectal carcinoma sample revealed a novel sequence variant, c.457_458insG, that creates a premature stop codon (p.Q536X) and likely disrupts the tumor suppressor protein’s C‑terminal regulatory domain.

Genotype analysis of the BRCA1 gene in a cohort of breast cancer patients revealed that the c.457_458insG sequence variant, which introduces a glycine at position +1 and results in a frameshift leading to a premature Q536X truncation, was significantly associated with earlier onset of disease and poorer response to platinum‑based chemotherapy.
Genotyping of the K562 cell line revealed a sequence variant, p.Gly102Arg, in the TP53 gene that correlates with increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Sequence variant p.Gly102Arg in the TP53 gene was identified in a HeLa cell line, where the substitution of glycine for arginine at codon‑102 caused a loss of p53‑dependent transcriptional activation of the CDKN1A promoter.

Sequence variants such as p.Gly102Arg and the in‑frame insertion c.457_458insG in the TP53 gene are predicted to disrupt the DNA‑binding domain and are associated with increased susceptibility to early‑onset colorectal cancer in individuals carrying the rs10942891 risk allele.

Sequence analysis of the tumor DNA revealed a novel BRCA1 c.457_458insG variant that co‑exists with a p.Gly102Arg mutation in the same allele, potentially driving aggressive breast cancer phenotypes in the patient.

Sequence analyses of the BRCA1 locus in the patient’s tumor revealed a novel missense variant p.Gly102Arg (c.305G>A) that co‑occurs with a previously reported pathogenic substitution R1306W, potentially amplifying the deleterious effect on DNA repair and increasing breast cancer risk.

The p.Arg104His variant in the BRCA1 gene, a sequence variant identified by c.1272C>T, was shown to disrupt DNA repair pathways in A549 cells, leading to increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic doxorubicin.

The Val539Asp sequence variant in the CYP2D6 gene reduces the metabolism of the antipsychotic drug clozapine, thereby increasing the risk of neuroleptic malignant syndrome in patients carrying the p.Arg104 allele.

The pathogenic p.Val539Asp sequence variant in the BRCA1 gene, which replaces valine with aspartic acid at codon‑539, disrupts the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and predisposes carriers to early‑onset breast cancer.

The recurrent c.1272C>T sequence variant in the TP53 gene, which substitutes a lysine at residue (223) for a valine (Val539Asp) and results in a p.Arg104→Ser136 change, has been shown to impair the DNA binding domain of the protein and is associated with increased susceptibility to early‑onset breast cancer in patients carrying the p.P230R mutation.
A c.1272C>T variant in the BRCA1 gene, resulting in the p.Arg104Cys substitution, has been shown to impair DNA repair and increase breast cancer risk in female patients.
A single nucleotide polymorphism, c.1272C>T, which replaces lysine at residue Arg104 with a valine, is associated with impaired regulation of the insulin signaling pathway in HepG2 cells.

A patient with a BRCA1 c.1272C>T variant (p.Arg104Trp) exhibited a markedly reduced response to platinum-based chemotherapy, while a separate cohort carrying the A6V mutation in the TP53 gene showed increased apoptotic signaling in HeLa cells.

In the A549 cell line, the c.1272C>T sequence variant causing a p.Arg104Trp substitution in the TP53 gene was shown to enhance apoptotic signaling in response to doxorubicin treatment.

In HCT116 cells harboring the c.1272C>T (p.Arg425Trp) sequence variant, the mutant protein’s altered lysine at residue **223** disrupts the interaction with the transcription factor **p53**, thereby attenuating the cellular response to DNA damage.

In patients harboring the BRCA1 c.1272C>T variant, the resulting p.Arg423Cys substitution at lysine residue **223** markedly disrupts the DNA repair complex, leading to increased susceptibility to triple‑negative breast cancer.
Mutation of the TP53 gene to the Val539Asp variant (c.1616G>A) in the A549 cell line leads to increased resistance to doxorubicin treatment in E. coli-derived plasmids expressing the mutant protein.

Mutation c.1272C>T in the TP53 gene, which substitutes lysine at residue p.Arg104 with glutamine, was found to increase the risk of breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Mutation analysis revealed that the c.1272C>T variant in the ABCG2 gene, which replaces serine with leucine at residue p.Ser136, is associated with increased drug efflux in the A549 cell line, thereby contributing to doxorubicin resistance in patients with the p.P230R sequence variant.

Alterations such as the Val539Asp and c.1272C>T sequence variants in the CYP2C9 gene have been shown to reduce enzyme activity, thereby increasing the risk of adverse reactions to warfarin therapy in patients with the A6V polymorphism.

Alteration of the BRCA1 sequence variant c.1272C>T, which causes a serine-to-phenylalanine substitution at residue Ser136, has been shown to impair DNA repair in Homo sapiens cells and is associated with an increased risk of early‑onset breast cancer.
Altered phosphorylation of the p.P230R variant in the kinase domain of BRAF reduces MAPK pathway activation in A549 cells, thereby diminishing their proliferation in response to vemurafenib.

Altering the lysine at residue (223) in the TP53 protein through the c.1272C>T variant (p.Arg104) has been shown to diminish DNA-binding affinity and increase apoptosis in HeLa cells, whereas the Val539Asp substitution in the same gene confers a higher risk of chemoresistance in A549 cells.

Mutations such as the Val539Asp and L89R variants in the G6PD gene, together with the c.1272C>T change affecting the lysine at residue ^223, have been shown to compromise enzyme activity and increase oxidative stress in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.

Mutagenic exposure to benzene induced the sequence variant c.1272C>T in the CYP2E1 gene, resulting in a lysine at residue **223** that impairs enzyme activity and increases susceptibility to benzene‑induced hematotoxicity.

Polymorphisms such as the c.1272C>T transition and the A6V amino‑acid substitution in the TP53 gene are frequently detected in tumor‑derived cell lines like A549, where they alter the DNA‑binding domain and enhance oncogenic signaling.
Polycystic kidney disease in the patient carrying the c.1272C>T sequence variant of the PKD1 gene was exacerbated by the p.Arg104Cys mutation, resulting in earlier onset of renal failure.

Polyclonal T‑cell receptor sequencing revealed a pathogenic A2718G sequence variant in the CD3D gene, which causes a lysine substitution at residue p.Arg104, and was associated with a severe hypogammaglobulinemia phenotype in a patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

cDNA sequencing of the CYP2D6 gene in a cohort of *Homo sapiens* patients revealed a novel sequence variant, c.1272C>T, resulting in the amino‑acid substitution p.Arg104Ser, which was associated with reduced enzymatic activity and altered response to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in HeLa cells.

cBRAF p.Val539Asp mutation in the A549 cell line reduces ERK phosphorylation and enhances sensitivity to the MEK inhibitor trametinib, whereas the c.1272C>T variant in the TP53 gene, which results in a p.Arg104Leu substitution, confers resistance to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis in HeLa cells.
c.-1272C>T in the TP53 gene causes a Val539Asp substitution that destabilizes the protein and enhances the risk of colorectal cancer in individuals carrying the p.Arg104 sequence variant.

Sequencing of the A2718G variant revealed a p.P230R substitution that, together with the L89R mutation, likely disrupts the kinase domain of the protein, thereby impairing phosphorylation of the downstream signaling cascade in the cultured A549 cell line.

Sequenced analysis of a colorectal carcinoma cell line revealed that the p.Arg104His sequence variant in the KRAS gene, coupled with the c.1272C>T transition in the TP53 gene, conferred resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, underscoring the need for targeted therapy in patients harboring these mutations.

Sequenc variant c.1272C>T in the TP53 gene, which results in the substitution of lysine at residue p.223 with arginine, was found to increase the transcriptional activity of the p53 protein in A549 cells, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Targeted CRISPR/Cas9 editing of the TP53 gene in HCT116 cells revealed that introducing the c.1272C>T variant, which changes serine at residue position Ser136 to phenylalanine, markedly increased apoptosis in response to doxorubicin compared with the wild‑type TP53 sequence.

Target‑directed CRISPR editing of the BRCA1 c.1272C>T variant in A549 cells revealed that the p.Arg104Cys substitution destabilizes the BRCA1 protein, leading to impaired DNA repair and increased sensitivity to doxorubicin.

Target sequencing of the *KRAS* locus in a cohort of colorectal carcinoma patients revealed that the c.1272C>T transition, which generates a p.Arg424* nonsense variant, co‑occurs with a previously unreported Val539Asp substitution in the *PIK3CA* gene, suggesting a synergistic impact on downstream PI3K/AKT signaling.

Preclinical studies using the A549 cell line revealed that the c.1272C>T (p.Arg424Trp) sequence variant in the TP53 gene, which introduces a lysine at residue‑223, reduces p53 transcriptional activity and increases resistance to doxorubicin treatment.

Pre‑existing p.Val539Asp and c.1272C> T variants in the CYP2C9 gene were found to reduce enzymatic activity and thereby increase the risk of hepatotoxicity in patients treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Pre–clinical studies revealed that the A6V sequence variant in the ATP-binding cassette transporter ABCG2 reduces drug efflux and sensitizes A549 cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Elevated oxidative stress in A549 cells harboring the c.1272C>T sequence variant, which introduces a lysine at residue **223** and a p.Arg104 substitution, enhances NRF2‑mediated transcription of the antioxidant gene **HMOX1** and reduces apoptosis induced by doxorubicin.

Elevational expression of the c.1272C>T variant in the TP53 gene, which causes a Lys223Arg substitution, was associated with increased apoptosis in A549 cells treated with doxorubicin.

Patients receiving the A549 cell line were observed to exhibit increased expression of the TP53 gene product in response to the p.P230R sequence variant, while a separate cohort of E. coli cultures treated with doxorubicin showed a reduction in the c.1272C>T mutation frequency, suggesting a protective effect of the drug against this specific DNA alteration.

Patients harboring the c.1272C>T variant, which results in a lysine to arginine substitution at residue p.Arg104, displayed markedly increased phosphorylation of the downstream AKT pathway in cultured HeLa cells.

Patients carrying the BRCA1 c.1272C>T sequence variant, which substitutes a lysine at residue p.Arg104 with a valine, exhibited an increased risk of early‑onset breast cancer compared with carriers of the wild‑type allele.

Patients with the BRCA1 c.1272C>T variant, which introduces a p.Arg104Cys change and a lysine at residue‑223 to alanine, exhibit a markedly increased risk of early‑onset breast cancer compared with carriers of the wild‑type allele.

Researchers discovered that the A2718G sequence variant in the CYP2D6 gene, which replaces alanine with valine at residue position six, reduces the metabolic activation of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin in HepG2 cells, thereby conferring a protective effect against drug‑induced cardiotoxicity.

Researchers demonstrated that the sequence variant c.1272C>T in the CYP2D6 gene, which results in the amino‑acid substitution L89R at the protein level, markedly reduces enzymatic activity and leads to higher plasma concentrations of the antipsychotic drug olanzapine in patients of the A549 cell line.

Researchers observed that the c.1272C> T sequence variant, resulting in the p.Arg104His substitution in the TP53 gene, markedly increased apoptosis in HeLa cells, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for treating cervical cancer.

Researchers found that the A2718G sequence variant in the G6PC gene, which replaces alanine with valine at residue A6V, increases the risk of hypoglycemia in patients with glycogen storage disease type Ia.

In the A549 cell line, the rs9659997 C to T polymorphism results in a Gln/Gln genotype that causes the S482X truncation, thereby abolishing p.W492X protein expression and leading to a Glu873Stop variant that reduces V311fs-mediated chemoresistance.

In HCC cell lines, the rs9659997 C to T transition introduces a Gln/Gln homozygous state that leads to a premature S482X truncation, abolishing the downstream p.W492X motif and causing loss of the Glu873Stop regulatory domain, which ultimately reduces V311fs-mediated p.G159R protein stability and enhances tumor cell proliferation.

In breast cancer cells, the rs9659997 polymorphism leads to a Gln/Gln genotype that introduces a C to T transition at codon S482X, producing a V311fs frameshift and a premature Glu873Stop, which in turn abolishes the functional p.W492X domain of the BRCA1 gene product.

In A549 cells harboring the S482X sequence variant, the introduction of the rs9659997 polymorphism exacerbated the loss of TP53 protein stability, thereby accelerating apoptosis in response to doxorubicin.

The rs9659997 C to T transition in the Gln/Gln allele of the CYP2C9 gene produces a V311fs frameshift that results in a truncated p.W492X protein, thereby markedly reducing enzyme activity in patients with the Arg124Leu variant.

The S482X truncating mutation (p.S482X) in the CFTR gene, which introduces a premature Glu873Stop codon and a V311fs frameshift, is strongly associated with cystic fibrosis in homozygous Arg124Leu carriers, as demonstrated by the rs9659997 SNP analysis.

The pathogenic S482X sequence variant in the MSH2 gene, identified by rs9659997, causes a premature Glu873Stop and is predicted to disrupt mismatch repair in colorectal cancer cells derived from a Homo sapiens patient.

The heterozygous rs9659997 C to T transition in the TP53 gene results in a Gln/Gln genotype that is associated with an increased risk of early‑onset colorectal cancer in individuals carrying the S482X variant.

A heterozygous rs9659997 C to T transition in the APOE gene, resulting in a Gln/Gln genotype, was found to increase the risk of Alzheimer’s disease in individuals carrying the V311fs sequence variant.

A recent study demonstrated that the rs9659997 C to T polymorphism in the APOE gene results in a Gln/Gln genotype that is associated with increased risk of late‑onset Alzheimer’s disease, whereas the rare S482X nonsense mutation (p.W492X) in the same gene leads to a truncated protein that abolishes lipid‑binding activity and markedly elevates amyloid‑β deposition in the brain.

A nucleotide C to T transition at position rs9659997 in the ATP7B gene produces the Arg124Leu missense variant, which in a subset of patients with Wilson disease is associated with a severe Gln/Gln genotype and a truncated S482X protein that leads to impaired copper excretion.

A missense sequence variant rs9659997, which results in an Arg124Leu substitution, was found to disrupt the binding of the transcription factor ETV6 in HeLa cells, thereby enhancing the expression of the oncogenic gene TP53 and contributing to the development of epithelial ovarian carcinoma.
Patients with the rs9659997 C to T transition, which produces the p.G159R variant in the APOE gene, exhibited markedly reduced HDL cholesterol levels compared to carriers of the Gln/Gln genotype.

Patients harboring the rs9659997 C to T transition in the APOE locus, which results in a Gln/Gln genotype and the premature stop codon p.W492X, exhibit markedly increased plasma amyloid‑β levels compared with carriers of the wild‑type allele.
Patients carrying the rs9659997 C to T transition, which results in the Arg124Leu substitution in the LDLR gene, exhibit elevated LDL cholesterol levels and a higher risk of coronary artery disease.

Patients homozygous for the rs9659997 C to T transition in the APOE locus, which generates a Gln/Gln genotype, displayed increased LDL‑cholesterol levels, whereas carriers of the rs800292 Arg124Leu variant in the CETP gene exhibited reduced HDL‑cholesterol, highlighting how distinct sequence variants can differentially modulate lipid metabolism.

Sequencing of the LDLR gene in a cohort of hypercholesterolemic patients revealed a novel sequence variant, p.Arg124Leu, which cosegregated with elevated LDL‑C levels and was predicted to disrupt the LDLR transmembrane domain.
Sequenced analysis of a BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant revealed a novel p.G159R mutation that correlates with a higher risk of breast cancer in carriers of the rs800292 allele.

Sequ var rs9659997, a C to T transition in the TP53 gene, encodes the p.G159R missense mutation that disrupts the DNA‑binding domain and confers a Gln/Gln genotype associated with increased risk of colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Sequencial analysis of the TP53 gene in a cohort of colorectal cancer patients revealed a recurrent C to T transition at position rs9659997, producing a Gln/Gln genotype that co‑occurs with the pathogenic S482X variant and a novel p.W492X stop codon, while the Glu873Stop and V311fs indels were also identified in the same tumor samples, suggesting a complex mutational landscape that may influence tumor aggressiveness and therapeutic response.

An allele of rs9659997, a C to T transition resulting in the Glu873Stop variant, was found to reduce the expression of the insulin‑like growth factor‑1 receptor in HeLa cells, thereby impairing PI3K/AKT signaling and promoting apoptosis.

An L1215P missense sequence variant in the ATP7B gene, identified as rs800292, was found to reduce copper transport in HepG2 cells, thereby exacerbating Wilson disease phenotypes in the affected patient.

An A549 cell line harboring the V311fs sequence variant of the TP53 gene exhibited increased apoptosis upon treatment with doxorubicin, a finding that may be linked to the rs800292 polymorphism in the CYP2C19 gene.

An S482X truncating variant in the BRCA1 gene, denoted as c.1446_1447delAG (p.S482X), was found to be associated with a higher risk of breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens carriers, while the rs9659997 polymorphism in the same locus showed a protective effect against the disease.

C-to-T substitutions at the rs9659997 locus generate a Gln/Gln genotype that, in A549 cells, can produce the S482X and p.W492X truncation variants, thereby impairing TP53-mediated apoptosis and promoting tumorigenic growth.

Cytosine‑to‑thymine substitutions at rs9659997, such as the p.W492X truncation and the V311fs frameshift, are associated with a Gln/Gln genotype and the Arg124Leu missense change, collectively contributing to the disease phenotype.
C to T transitions at rs9659997 in the APOE gene produce a Gln/Gln genotype that, when coupled with the S482X variant, have been linked to an increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease in older adults.

C‑to‑T substitutions at rs9659997 in the ABCG2 gene generate a Gln/Gln genotype that, when coupled with the S482X and p.W492X truncations, predisposes to a Glu873Stop variant, thereby amplifying the V311fs frameshift effect on transporter activity.

Mutagenic C to T transitions at rs9659997 in the CYP2D6 promoter create a Gln/Gln genotype that, together with the S482X p.W492X nonsense allele, results in a Glu873Stop variant and a V311fs frameshift, thereby abolishing enzyme activity and causing severe drug‑induced hyperthyroidism in patients carrying Arg124Leu and rs800292 alleles.

Mutations such as rs9659997, which causes a C to T transition leading to a Glu873Stop variant, have been shown to disrupt the normal function of the CYP2C9 enzyme in Homo sapiens, thereby altering the pharmacokinetics of warfarin in patients carrying the Arg124Leu allele.

Mutational analysis of the APOE gene in Alzheimer’s disease patients revealed a C to T transition at rs9659997 resulting in the Gln/Gln genotype, while a separate cohort of cardiovascular patients exhibited the S482X variant (p.W492X) that introduces a Glu873Stop codon and a V311fs frameshift, both of which are associated with altered lipid metabolism and elevated risk of atherosclerosis.

Mutant allele rs9659997, a C to T substitution at codon Gln311, generates a V311fs frameshift that truncates the protein at p.W492X, thereby abolishing the functional domain responsible for the Gln/Gln interaction with the DNA-binding region.

Mutation rs9659997, a C to T transition resulting in a Gln/Gln genotype, was identified in the V311fs sequence variant of the LDLR gene, where it causes the p.W492X Glu873Stop truncation and is associated with increased cardiovascular risk in Homo sapiens.

Mutation analysis of the LDLR gene in a cohort of hypercholesterolemic patients revealed that the rs800292 polymorphism, which results in an Arg124Leu amino‑acid change, is associated with a higher prevalence of the V311fs frameshift variant, while the rs9659997 SNP, a C to T transition, was found to co‑occur with the p.W492X nonsense mutation and the Glu873Stop variant, indicating a possible linkage disequilibrium between these sequence changes.
Mutation p.G159R in the LDLR gene (rs800292) was shown to cause a C to T transition at codon Arg124Leu, leading to a premature Glu873Stop and loss of function in hepatocytes.

Mutation of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line, specifically the rs9659997 C to T transition resulting in a Gln/Gln to Glu873Stop change, was shown to increase sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

Cell line HCT116 harboring the rs9659997 Gln/Gln genotype exhibited reduced expression of TP53, while the co‑transfection of the sequence variant rs800292 Arg124Leu in the KRAS gene amplified the MAPK signaling cascade, ultimately enhancing proliferation of the HCT116 cells.

Cell viability was markedly reduced in A549 cells harboring the rs9659997 C to T variant, which introduces a Glu873Stop nonsense mutation in the TP53 gene and results in loss of the Gln/Gln homozygous genotype.

Cell‑line A549 harboring the S482X sequence variant in the TP53 gene exhibits markedly reduced apoptosis in response to doxorubicin, while the rs9659997 polymorphism in the CYP2C19 promoter correlates with increased drug metabolism in Homo sapiens patients.

Cell survival in A549 cells harboring the rs9659997 C to T transition, which introduces a Glu873Stop in TP53, is markedly reduced compared with cells containing the wild‑type Gln/Gln genotype, indicating that the sequence variant triggers apoptosis through p53 pathway dysregulation.

Single‑nucleotide polymorphism rs9659997, a C→T transition in the CYP2D6 promoter, was found to correlate with reduced enzymatic activity and altered drug metabolism in patients carrying the Arg124Leu variant.

Single nucleotide polymorphism rs9659997, a C to T transition, is associated with the Gln/Gln genotype and the pathogenic sequence variant S482X, which introduces a premature stop codon analogous to the Glu873Stop mutation and the frameshift V311fs alteration, thereby impairing the normal function of the gene product.

Single-base C to T substitutions at rs9659997 and the V311fs frameshift variant in the CYP2C9 gene together with the p.W492X nonsense mutation in the HBB gene were shown to synergistically impair erythrocyte enzyme activity, leading to a severe hemolytic phenotype in homozygous patients.

Single-stranded DNA sequencing of the APOE locus in a cohort of Alzheimer's disease patients revealed a novel rs9659997 C to T transition that creates a Gln/Gln genotype and introduces a premature stop codon (p.Glu873Stop) at codon S482X, thereby truncating the protein and likely disrupting lipid transport and neuronal repair mechanisms.

Allele rs9659997, a C to T transition in the CFTR gene, produces the Gln/Gln variant that is predicted to generate the premature stop codon S482X, while the independent rs800292 variant, Arg124Leu, has been associated with a V311fs frameshift leading to the Glu873Stop truncation.

Allelic analysis revealed that the rs9659997 C to T transition in the APOE gene generates a Gln/Gln genotype that, in homozygotes, produces the S482X nonsense variant, whereas heterozygotes carrying the p.W492X stop codon also exhibit the Glu873Stop truncation, and the V311fs frameshift further amplifies the deleterious effect of the Arg124Leu substitution on protein stability.

Alleles such as rs9659997 and rs800292, which encode a Gln/Gln genotype and a V311fs frameshift, respectively, have been associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease in individuals carrying the S482X or p.W492X sequence variants that truncate the protein at Glu873Stop.

Allel‑specific expression of the BRCA1 variant rs9659997, a C to T transition at position c.68_69, was found to disrupt the Gln/Gln genotype and promote the premature stop codon S482X, thereby impairing DNA repair in breast cancer cells.

Homo sapiens carrying the rs9659997 C to T substitution in the APOE locus, which creates a Glu873Stop variant, exhibit a markedly increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease, whereas the rs800292 Arg124Leu polymorphism in the LDLR gene mitigates this effect by enhancing receptor-mediated clearance of amyloid‑β peptides.

Heterozygous rs9659997 in the APOE gene, which results in a C to T transition at codon Gln311 and produces the V311fs frameshift, has been associated with increased risk of late‑onset Alzheimer’s disease in the elderly.

HepG2 cells harboring the rs9659997 C→T transition in the HNF4A promoter exhibit a Gln/Gln genotype that leads to a p.W492X truncation, thereby reducing insulin transcription and precipitating hyperglycemia.
Haplotype rs9659997, carrying a C to T transition that generates the Glu873Stop variant, was found to associate with reduced CYP2C9 enzyme activity in a cohort of patients treated with warfarin.

Recent genome‑wide association studies identified rs9659997, a C to T transition in the APOE locus, which encodes a Gln/Gln variant that predisposes individuals to an elevated risk of late‑onset Alzheimer’s disease.

Recent work shows that the rs9659997 C to T transition creates a p.G159R missense variant in the G6PD gene, which can lead to a Gln/Gln to Arg124Leu substitution that in turn truncates the protein at S482X, thereby impairing the enzyme’s stability and activity.
Recent functional assays revealed that the rs9659997 C to T substitution, which introduces a Glu873Stop nonsense mutation in the APOE gene, markedly reduces LDL‑R expression in Huh7 cells.

Recent sequencing of the CYP2C9 locus in a cohort of *Homo sapiens* revealed a novel pathogenic variant, rs9659997, which encodes a C to T transition resulting in a Glu873Stop mutation that truncates the protein and abolishes its catalytic activity, thereby explaining the observed loss of warfarin metabolism in patients homozygous for the Gln/Gln allele.

In HeLa cells, the c.1138G>C sequence variant in the CYP2D6 gene, which results in a glutamine replacement of arginine at codon M235T, was shown to alter the enzyme’s metabolism of the anticancer drug doxorubicin.

In A549 cells, the c.1138G>C variant in the CYP2D6 gene, which replaces a glutamine for an arginine residue, was shown to alter drug metabolism, while a four‑base‑pair deletion at c.471C>T in the same locus caused a frameshift that reduces enzyme activity.

In the colorectal carcinoma cohort, the c.1138G>C variant in KRAS was associated with a glutamine replacement of arginine at codon M235T, whereas the c.471C>T mutation produced a four‑base‑pair deletion that introduced a glutamate by glycine substitution, and an insertion of a fifteen‑nucleotide duplication at the first fifteen nucleotides of the transcript was observed in a subset of patients.

In Huh‑7 cells, the c.1138G>C variant in the CYP2D6 gene, which replaces glutamine with arginine at position M235T, markedly reduces enzymatic activity and alters the metabolism of the anticancer drug doxorubicin.

The novel c.1138G>C variant in the renin gene, a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, was found to cause a four‑base‑pair deletion that disrupts the promoter region, leading to reduced expression of the renin protein in Homo sapiens.

The c.1138G>C sequence variant in the renin gene causes a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, while a four‑base‑pair deletion in the promoter region at –930A>G further disrupts transcriptional regulation.

The insertion of a fifteen‑nucleotide duplication at the first fifteen bases of the coding sequence (c.1_15dup15) in the ACE2 gene creates a novel sequence variant that replaces the glutamine at position M235T with a glutamate, thereby disrupting the binding interface for the SARS‑CoV‑2 spike protein and reducing viral entry into HEK293T cells.

The single‑cell RNA‑seq analysis of the A549 cell line revealed that the c.1138G>C variant in the HIF1A gene, which introduces a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, is associated with a four‑basepair deletion in the promoter region that reduces transcriptional activity, thereby exacerbating hypoxia‑induced apoptosis in the tumor cells.

Sequencing of the AGT gene in hypertensive patients revealed a c.1138G>C transition that results in a glutamine replacement of arginine at codon M235T, while an independent c.471C>T variant produced an insertion of a four‑base‑pair duplication of the first fifteen nucleotides, leading to a frameshift and premature stop codon.

Sequenced c.1138G>C and c.471C>T variants in the human ACE gene revealed that the M235T polymorphism, a glutamine‑to‑arginine substitution, and a four‑base‑pair deletion at position –930A>G collectively reduce ACE enzymatic activity, thereby increasing susceptibility to hypertension in patients treated with losartan.
Sequencers identified a four‑basepair deletion in the TP53 gene (c.465G>T) that replaces glutamine with arginine at position M235T, a variant previously linked to increased apoptosis in HeLa cells.
