Mutations such as the c.1138G>C polymorphism in the angiotensin‑converting enzyme gene, the four‑basepair deletion in the promoter region of the CYP2D6 gene, and the M235T substitution in the AGT gene have been linked to altered drug metabolism and hypertension risk in humans.

Mutational analysis of the CYP2D6 gene in a cohort of HIV‑positive patients revealed a novel c.1138G>C variant that introduces a glutamine replacement of arginine at codon M235T, while a separate sample harbored a four‑basepair deletion at position -930A>G, both of which are predicted to alter drug‑metabolizing enzyme activity.

Mutagenesis of the BRCA1 gene in the A549 cell line revealed a four‑basepair deletion at c.465G > T that replaces glutamine with glycine and is predicted to disrupt DNA‑repair activity, potentially contributing to cisplatin resistance.

Mutant A549 cells harboring the c.1138G>C variant in the KRAS gene, which causes a glutamine replacement of arginine at codon M235T, exhibit markedly increased ERK phosphorylation and resistance to the EGFR inhibitor erlotinib.

Genetic analysis of the patient’s tumor revealed a novel sequence variant, a four‑base‑pair deletion at c.465G > T, which results in a glutamine replacement of arginine and a downstream insertion of a duplicated stretch of fifteen nucleotides, potentially disrupting the normal splicing of the TP53 gene.

Genomic sequencing of the patient’s tumor revealed a c.1138G>C transition that causes a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, while a separate c.465G>T mutation introduced a four‑basepair deletion, both of which are predicted to disrupt the protein’s active site and contribute to chemoresistance.

Genotype analysis of a colorectal cancer cohort revealed that a four‑basepair deletion in the APC gene (c.1138_1141del) correlated with increased β‑catenin accumulation, while a c.471C>T substitution in the KRAS gene (p.Gln157His) was associated with enhanced MAPK signaling and poorer overall survival.

Genotyping of the AGT gene in a cohort of hypertensive patients revealed that the c.1138G>C variant, which results in a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, was significantly associated with increased plasma renin activity, while the four‑basepair deletion at c.471C>T and the insertion of a fifteen‑nucleotide duplication at the first exon were found exclusively in individuals with early‑onset essential hypertension.

Variant c.1138G>C in the angiotensin‑converting enzyme gene leads to a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, which has been associated with altered blood‑pressure regulation in Homo sapiens.

Variant analysis of the ACE gene in a cohort of hypertensive patients revealed that the c.1138G>C substitution, which results in a glutamine for arginine replacement at position M235T, is significantly associated with increased plasma renin activity compared with the wild‑type allele.

Variant G for A at cDNA nucleotide position **323** of the **ACE** gene was found to increase the risk of hypertension in a cohort of **Homo sapiens** subjects carrying the **M235T** substitution in the **AGT** gene.

Variant‑calling in the HBB locus revealed a four‑basepair deletion at c.465G> T, which leads to a glutamate‑to‑glycine substitution that may alter hemoglobin stability in patients with the -930A>G promoter polymorphism.

A splice‑site mutation involving a four‑basepair deletion at position c.465G>T in the BRCA1 gene was shown to disrupt normal exon inclusion, leading to a truncated protein that fails to recruit the RAD51 repair complex and thereby increases susceptibility to breast cancer in carriers.

A four‑base‑pair deletion at c.465G>T in the ACE2 gene results in a glutamine replacement of arginine, which has been linked to increased susceptibility to severe SARS‑CoV‑2 infection in individuals carrying the M235T variant.

A missense sequence variant, c.471C>T, in the AGT gene causes a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, while an insertion of a fifteen‑nucleotide duplication at c.1138G>C leads to a four‑basepair deletion that substitutes glutamate with glycine.

A heterozygous four‑basepair deletion in the promoter of the renin gene (c.465G>T) combined with a c.1138G>C missense mutation that replaces glutamine for arginine at position M235T was shown to elevate plasma renin activity and predispose Homo sapiens patients to early‑onset hyperuricemia and chronic kidney disease.

Insertion of a four‑base‑pair deletion at the c.465G > T site in the ACE2 gene results in a glutamine replacement of arginine that disrupts angiotensin‑converting enzyme activity in a subset of SARS‑CoV‑2‑susceptible patients.

Insertion analysis revealed that the four‑basepair deletion at c.465G>T in the renin gene, which results in a glutamine replacement of arginine, is strongly associated with early‑onset hypertension in the studied cohort.
Insertional mutagenesis of the ACE2 gene, specifically a four‑base‑pair deletion at c.465G>T, results in a glutamine replacement of arginine that impairs viral spike protein binding in HEK293T cells.

Insertioning a fifteen‑nucleotide duplication at the start of exon three of the ACE gene (c.1138G>C) produces a glutamine‑to‑arginine substitution that, together with a four‑base‑pair deletion at –930A>G, is predicted to alter angiotensin‑converting enzyme activity in patients with hypertension.

Variants such as the four‑basepair deletion c.465G>T and the M235T substitution, which replaces arginine with glutamine, have been shown to alter the function of the angiotensin‑converting enzyme in Homo sapiens, potentially contributing to hypertension.

Variants with a four‑basepair deletion in the promoter region of the renin gene, such as the c.465G>T mutation that replaces a glutamine residue with arginine, have been linked to early‑onset hypertension in Homo sapiens.

Variants featuring the c.1138G > C substitution, a four‑base‑pair deletion at c.465G > T, and an insertion of a duplicated fifteen‑nucleotide sequence at the start of the gene all converge to produce a glutamine replacement of arginine and a glutamate‑by‑glycine change that are predicted to disrupt the protein’s functional domain in Homo sapiens.

Variants where a glutamine replaces an arginine at position M235T, an insertion of a fifteen‑nt duplication at c.1138G > C, and a four‑base‑pair deletion at c.471C > T were simultaneously identified in the same allele of the AGT gene in a patient with early‑onset hypertension, suggesting a cumulative effect of these sequence changes on protein function.

Studies in A549 cells revealed that the c.465G>T (p.Gly155Ser) sequence variant, which causes a glutamine replacement of arginine and an insertion of a four‑basepair deletion, led to aberrant splicing and reduced expression of the CYP1A1 gene, thereby impairing the cellular response to xenobiotic exposure.

Studies of the A549 cell line revealed that the c.1138G>C sequence variant, which replaces a glutamine with an arginine and creates a four‑base‑pair deletion at position –930A>G, dramatically increases the expression of the TP53 gene product and enhances sensitivity to doxorubicin.

Studies on the A549 cell line revealed that the c.1138G > C sequence variant, which causes a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, can lead to a four‑basepair deletion that ultimately results in a glutamate by glycine substitution in the protein product.

Studies reveal that the c.1138G>C variant, which substitutes glutamine for arginine at position M235T, can be further compounded by an insertion of a fifteen‑nucleotide duplication of the first fifteen nucleotides, creating a complex sequence variant that disrupts normal gene expression.

Gene expression of the M235T variant, characterized by a c.1138G > C substitution that replaces glutamine with arginine, was found to be down‑regulated in A549 cells, while an insertion of a fifteen‑nucleotide duplication at the first fifteen bases of the promoter region further decreased transcription of the adjacent CYP2D6 gene.

Gene‑editing of the KRAS locus in HCT116 cells revealed that a c.1138G > C substitution causing a glutamine replacement of arginine at codon M235T, together with an insertion of a fifteen‑nucleotide duplication at the first fifteen nucleotides, abolished KRAS‑mediated ERK activation.

Gene editing of the human CYP2D6 locus in HepG2 cells revealed that a c.1138G > C variant creates a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, while a separate c.471C > T mutation introduces a four‑basepair deletion that abolishes the enzyme’s catalytic activity.

Gene therapy using CRISPR‑Cas9 to correct the c.1138G>C sequence variant in the ACE2 gene, which replaces glutamine with arginine at position M235T, restores normal angiotensin‑converting enzyme activity in A549 cells and reduces SARS‑CoV‑2 viral entry.

Researchers found that the c.1138G>C sequence variant, which replaces glutamine for arginine in the ACE2 protein, increases susceptibility to severe COVID‑19 in patients carrying the M235T polymorphism.

Researchers demonstrated that the c.1138G>C sequence variant in the AGT gene, which causes a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, leads to a four‑basepair deletion that reduces angiotensin‑converting enzyme activity and predisposes patients to early‑onset hypertension.

Researchers noted that the c.1138G > C variant, a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, together with a four‑basepair deletion, can disrupt the regulatory region of the renin gene, leading to altered blood pressure in Homo sapiens.

Researchers reported that the c.1138G>C variant in the ACE gene, a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, and a four‑base‑pair deletion in the promoter region (-930A>G) collectively contribute to altered blood pressure regulation in a cohort of *Homo sapiens* patients.
Mutation c.1138G>C in the AGT gene, which replaces a glutamine for an arginine and creates a four‑base‑pair deletion, has been shown to increase plasma renin activity in patients with hypertension.

Mutation of the CYP17A1 gene by the c.1138G>C sequence variant, which replaces a glutamine with arginine at position M235T, was shown to increase androgen production in HepG2 cells and to contribute to early-onset hypertension in a cohort of African‑American patients.

Mutation analysis of the AGT gene in a cohort of hypertensive patients revealed that the c.1138G>C variant, which replaces a glutamine residue with arginine at position M235T, co‑occurs with a four‑basepair deletion in the promoter region, suggesting a synergistic effect on angiotensin‑converting enzyme activity.

Mutation‑driven dysregulation of the angiotensin‑converting enzyme gene, including the M235T polymorphism, c.1138G > C and a four‑basepair deletion, has been shown to alter the enzyme’s catalytic efficiency and contribute to hypertension in Homo sapiens.

Silencing of the GATA3 gene in the A549 cell line revealed that a c.1138G>C sequence variant, which replaces glutamine for arginine at position M235T, reduces tumor cell proliferation by impairing the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway.

Silico‑analysis of the BRCA1 c.1138G>C variant, which introduces a glutamine‑to‑arginine substitution, revealed that the resulting sequence variant destabilizes the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and correlates with a higher incidence of breast cancer in carriers of the M235T polymorphism.

Silenced expression of the CYP2D6 gene in a patient harboring the c.1138G>C variant, a glutamine replacement of arginine at position M235T, led to reduced metabolism of the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin and consequently increased cardiotoxicity.

Silently, the c.1138G>C sequence variant in the angiotensin‑converting enzyme gene produces a glutamine substitution for arginine at position M235T, while the c.471C>T variant creates a four‑basepair deletion that replaces glutamate with glycine, both of which have been linked to altered blood‑pressure regulation in Homo sapiens.

The identification of a novel -652_6N del sequence variant in the TP53 gene of a colorectal cancer cell line revealed that the leucine to methionine substitution at codon p. Gln193Gln, coupled with a glutamic acid to a stop codon mutation (p.E300X), dramatically increased apoptotic signaling, whereas the rs8041922 polymorphism in the promoter region of the same gene was associated with reduced expression of the tumor suppressor protein.

The heterozygous BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, a sequence variant that deletes a two‑base pair guanine‑cytosine pair, has been shown to disrupt the DNA repair pathway and predispose patients to early‑onset breast cancer in Homo sapiens.

The BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, a -6526del mutation, and the rs8041922 single‑nucleotide polymorphism together contribute to the loss of the p.E300X stop codon and a leucine‑to‑methionine substitution at position p.Gln193Gln, which has been linked to reduced DNA repair capacity and increased breast cancer susceptibility.

The c.105‑bp deletion encompassing bases **1078‑1182** in the *BRCA1* gene, which produces a truncated protein with a **p.E300X** nonsense mutation, has been shown to disrupt DNA repair pathways and increase breast cancer susceptibility in *Homo sapiens* carriers.

In the A549 cell line, the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which replaces a glutamic acid with a stop codon (p.E300X), was shown to impair DNA repair and increase sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

In Homo sapiens, the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, a sequence variant that deletes two nucleotides and results in a frameshift, has been shown to abolish the DNA repair function of the TP53 gene product, thereby increasing the risk of early‑onset breast cancer.

In patients carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, the loss of two nucleotides at positions –652 and –651 leads to a frameshift that generates a premature glutamic acid to a stop codon (p.E300X) and is associated with an increased risk of early‑onset breast cancer.

In a cohort of colorectal cancer patients, the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which removes two nucleotides and creates a glutamic acid to a stop codon, was found to be significantly associated with increased tumor aggressiveness and poorer overall survival.

Sequence variant rs8041922 in the BRCA1 gene, which results in a p. Gln193Gln synonymous change, is associated with a higher risk of breast cancer in carriers of the -6526N deletion that also causes a leucine to methionine substitution in the protein’s functional domain.

Sequence analysis of the BRCA1 gene in a cohort of breast cancer patients revealed a novel -652_6N del variant that co‑occurs with a p.E300X nonsense mutation, while rs8041922 and p.Gln193Gln SNPs were also identified, indicating a complex mutational landscape that may influence disease progression.

Sequence‑variant rs8041922 in the TP53 gene, which introduces a p. Gln193Gln silent change, was found to coexist with a nearby -6526del deletion that removes a leucine‑to‑methionine motif in the DNA‑binding domain, potentially disrupting p53’s transcriptional activity in A549 cells.

Sequence variants such as the -652_6N_del deletion and the p.E300X nonsense mutation, which converts a glutamic acid residue to a stop codon, were found to be associated with altered transcriptional activity in the TP53 gene, while the rs8041922 polymorphism in the MTHFR gene was linked to increased risk of neural tube defects in Homo sapiens embryos.

A BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant was found to disrupt the DNA repair domain, causing a leucine to methionine substitution that correlates with a higher risk of breast cancer in carriers of the rs8041922 allele.

A heterozygous c.105_118delinsT mutation causing a leucine‑to‑methionine substitution in the BRCA1 exon five gene product was identified in a patient with early‑onset breast cancer, while a separate rs8041922 polymorphism in the same gene was associated with increased risk of ovarian carcinoma.

A pathogenic sequence variant, a −6526_6N deletion, was identified in the TP53 gene of a HeLa cell line, and the resulting p.E300X mutation caused loss of the DNA-binding domain and induced apoptosis in the cells.

A PCR‑based assay revealed that the BRCA1 variant rs8041922, which introduces a glutamic acid to a stop codon at position p.E300X, was present in a patient whose tumor exhibited a novel -6526N deletion and a leucine to methionine substitution in the same exon.

Loss of the −652_6N deletion in the TP53 promoter together with the p.E300X nonsense mutation in the TP53 coding region, both detected by next‑generation sequencing in a Homo sapiens biopsy, predict a severe reduction in p53 protein levels and an increased risk of colorectal carcinoma.

Loss‑of‑function mutations such as the –6526_6N del and the p.E300X variant, which replaces glutamic acid with a stop codon, have been shown to disrupt the normal regulation of the TP53 gene product in Homo sapiens, leading to increased cellular apoptosis and heightened susceptibility to chemotherapy‑induced toxicity.

Loss-of-function mutations such as the rs8041922 p.E300X variant, which introduces a glutamic acid to a stop codon at position E300, were found to disrupt the normal activity of the BRCA1 gene product in breast cancer cell lines.

Loss or missense sequence variants such as the rs8041922 SNP or the p.Gln193Gln silent change have been shown to modulate the expression of the TP53 gene in human breast cancer cell lines, whereas the novel c.105-1182del105bp deletion that removes bases spanning positions ~1078–1182 in the BRCA1 gene is predicted to create a frameshift leading to a glutamic acid to a stop codon at position p.E300X.

Sequencing of the BRCA1 locus in a cohort of breast cancer patients revealed a novel -6526del mutation that deletes a leucine codon at position p.Leu300, resulting in a p.E300X nonsense variant and a downstream p.Gln193Gln synonymous change (rs8041922) that together correlate with a markedly increased risk of early‑onset disease.

Sequenced analysis of the BRCA1 gene in a breast‑cancer cohort revealed a novel -652_6Ndel variant that co‑occurs with the p.E300X nonsense mutation, while a separate sample carried a rs8041922 SNP (p.Gln193Gln) and a pathogenic p.Asp50Asn missense change, and a third patient’s tumor harbored a large ~105‑bp deletion spanning bases c.1078‑c.1182, all of which

Sequenza‑based analysis revealed that the BRCA1 p.E300X variant, a glutamic acid to a stop codon mutation, co‑exists with the rs8041922 SNP in a subset of triple‑negative breast cancer samples, suggesting a possible compound heterozygous effect on DNA repair capacity.

Sequencetracking of the BRCA1 locus in breast cancer patients revealed that the novel rs8041922 variant, a c.105‑bp deletion encompassing bases g.1078‑1182, co‑occurs with the p.Gln193Gln silent change and a downstream leucine‑to‑methionine substitution in the DNA‑binding domain, suggesting a combined effect on protein stability and tumor suppressor activity.

Mutation of the CFTR gene involving the p.Asp50Asn substitution and a nearby rs8041922 polymorphism was shown to impair chloride transport in the CFTR-ΔF508 variant, thereby exacerbating the respiratory phenotype in cystic fibrosis patients.

Mutation c.−652_−651del in the promoter region of the CYP2C19 gene, together with the synonymous variant rs8041922 (p.Gln193Gln), was shown to impair transcriptional activity and reduce drug metabolism in HepG2 cells.

Mutation rs8041922 in the TP53 gene, a missense change p.Asp50Asn, was found to destabilize the protein’s DNA‑binding domain and correlate with increased susceptibility to colorectal cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Mutation p.E300X in the TP53 gene, a glutamic acid to a stop codon variant, was detected in a HeLa cell line, revealing a deleterious sequence variant that disrupts the DNA‑binding domain and potentially drives oncogenic transformation.

Evidence that the -6526N del sequence variant in the TP53 promoter region reduces p53 expression and thereby enhances the proliferative capacity of A549 cells treated with doxorubicin was demonstrated by chromatin‑immunoprecipitation and cell‑cycle analysis.

Evidence indicates that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, which results in a glutamic acid to a stop codon at position p.E300X, is associated with a higher risk of breast cancer in carriers of the rs8041922 allele.

Evidence from a cohort of colorectal cancer patients indicates that the BRCA1 c.105-1182del variant, which deletes a stretch of DNA from bases +1078 to +1182, is associated with a higher frequency of the rs8041922 polymorphism and correlates with poorer overall survival.

Evidence shows that the rs8041922 variant, which introduces a p.E300X nonsense mutation converting glutamic acid to a stop codon in the TP53 gene, is associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer in patients carrying the -6526N deletion.
Patients harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibited increased DNA repair deficiency and a higher incidence of triple‑negative breast cancer.

Patients carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, which results in a glutamic acid to a stop codon change, exhibit markedly increased susceptibility to breast cancer and demonstrate altered DNA repair pathways.

Patients homozygous for the rs8041922 single‑nucleotide polymorphism, which results in a p.Asp50Asn substitution in the HNF4A transcription factor, displayed increased susceptibility to neonatal hypoglycemia, while carriers of the rare -6526N deletion that removes a glutamic acid codon and creates a p.E300X nonsense mutation in the same gene exhibited a severe, early‑onset form of the disease.

Patients with the BRCA1 sequence variant rs8041922, a c.−652_−651del leading to a leucine‑to‑methionine change in the promoter, exhibited a higher incidence of triple‑negative breast cancer compared with carriers of the p.Gln193Gln polymorphism.

Mutations such as the -652_6N del deletion, the p.E300X nonsense change, and the rs8041922 SNP in the CYP2D6 gene have been shown to alter enzyme activity and increase susceptibility to drug‑induced hepatotoxicity in humans.

Mutational analysis of the BRCA1 gene in the cohort revealed a novel c.105‑b.1078‑1182del variant that deletes a contiguous segment of the exon, a change that is predicted to cause a frameshift and premature termination of the protein, and the same variant was found in a patient who also carried the rs8041922 single‑nucleotide polymorphism, a missense alteration at position p.Asp50Asn that has been associated with increased breast cancer risk.

Mutagenic exposure to benzo[a]pyrene induces a -6526N deletion in the TP53 gene, creating a p.E300X truncation that abolishes the DNA‑binding domain and is predicted to drive tumorigenesis in A549 cells.

Mutating the BRCA1 gene to the sequence variant p.E300X, which replaces glutamic acid with a stop codon at position E300, was found to abolish DNA repair activity in the human breast cancer cell line MCF‑7.

Cystic fibrosis patients carrying the rs8041922 variant, which introduces a glutamic acid to a stop codon at position p.E300X and a leucine to methionine substitution at p.Asp50Asn, exhibit markedly increased mucus viscosity and accelerated disease progression compared to individuals with the wild‑type sequence.

Cytotoxicity assays revealed that the A549 cell line harboring the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant exhibited increased sensitivity to doxorubicin, a finding that aligns with the predicted destabilization of the TP53 protein due to the p.E300X nonsense mutation.

Cumulative analysis of the patient cohort revealed that the BRCA1 sequence variant rs8041922, a single‑nucleotide polymorphism resulting in a p.Gln193Gln substitution, was significantly enriched in individuals carrying the pathogenic BRCA1 c.68_69delAG deletion, whereas the previously reported c.105‑bp deletion encompassing bases ‑1078‑1182 was not associated with increased breast cancer risk.

Citrus sinensis-derived p.E300X sequence variant, a glutamic acid to a stop codon mutation, was found to disrupt the regulatory region of the CYP1A1 gene, causing a significant reduction in its expression in HepG2 cells and correlating with increased susceptibility to benzo[a]pyrene-induced DNA damage.

Investigating the functional impact of the BRCA1 p.E300X sequence variant, we observed that the glutamic acid to a stop codon mutation in exon three leads to a truncated protein that fails to recruit RAD51, thereby increasing the risk of homologous recombination deficiency in breast cancer cells.

Investigations revealed that the rs8041922 single‑nucleotide polymorphism, which substitutes a glutamic acid for a stop codon at position p.E300X, is associated with the loss of the leucine residue at codon‑300 and the concomitant emergence of a novel –652‑6N deletion, thereby creating a frameshift that ultimately truncates the TP53 protein in the A549 cell line.

Investigators discovered that the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, a sequence variant causing a glutamic acid to a stop codon at position p.E300X, markedly increases the risk of breast cancer in carriers of the rs8041922 allele.

Investigational sequencing of the TP53 gene in the HeLa cell line revealed a novel sequence variant, p.E300X, which introduces a glutamic acid to a stop codon change and was predicted to truncate the protein, thereby potentially compromising p53’s tumor suppressor function.

Targeted CRISPR/Cas9 editing of the BRCA1 locus in MCF-7 cells revealed that the -652_6N_del sequence variant, which deletes six nucleotides at position –652, induces a frameshift that generates a premature p.E300X stop codon, thereby abolishing the normal leucine-to-methionine substitution at residue p.Asp50Asn and compromising DNA repair capacity.

Targeting the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, researchers observed that the resulting glutamic acid to a stop codon alteration in the protein’s DNA‑binding domain dramatically reduces its interaction with the RAD51 complex, thereby impairing homologous recombination repair in HeLa cells and increasing sensitivity to the alkylating agent temozolomide.

Target investigation revealed that the BRCA1 sequence variant rs8041922, a c.1078_1182del105‑bp deletion encompassing bases that encode a leucine‑to‑methionine change, was associated with increased risk of breast cancer in the studied cohort.

Targetting the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant, researchers observed that the resulting p.E300X mutation caused a premature glutamic acid to a stop codon conversion, thereby abolishing the protein’s DNA repair function in HeLa cells.

Knock‑in of the BRCA1 c.‑652_‑651del variant in HCC1806 cells leads to a p.E300X truncation that abolishes the DNA‑binding domain and, as a consequence, reduces RAD51 foci formation and sensitizes the cells to cisplatin.

Knocking out the BRCA1 variant rs8041922 in HeLa cells, which introduces a glutamic acid to a stop codon (p.E300X) and a leucine to methionine substitution (p.L123M), results in increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

Knocked‑down of the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, a sequence variant that deletes a two‑base pair guanine–cytosine, markedly increased the sensitivity of HeLa cells to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin.

Knoxville, the rs8041922 single‑nucleotide polymorphism in the CYP2C9 gene, which results in a leucine‑to‑methionine substitution at codon p. Gln193Gln, was found to confer a higher risk of tacrolimus‑induced nephrotoxicity in patients with the p. Asp50Asn variant of the CYP3A5 gene.
The CRISPR‑edited A549 cells harboring the sequence variant c.1093-1G>T exhibit a markedly reduced expression of the TP53 gene, thereby compromising the apoptotic response to doxorubicin.

The single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the BRCA1 c.1093-1G > T variant leads to a frameshift that changes asparagine at position‑86 to alanine and eliminates amino acids‑87,‑88,‑89 (arginine, threonine, and proline), resulting in a truncated, non‑functional protein.

The c.1093-1G>T splice‑site variant in the BRCA1 gene, together with the rs17015215‑V274I missense mutation, was found to disrupt the DNA‑binding domain and confer a markedly increased risk of breast cancer in a cohort of female patients.

The missense variant rs17015215-V274I in the TP53 gene, together with the single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the BRCA1 c.1093-1G>T splice site, was shown to reduce DNA repair capacity in A549 cells, leading to increased sensitivity to doxorubicin.

In A549 cells, the single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at position c.1093‑1G > T in the TP53 gene results in a frameshift that replaces asparagine at position N86 with alanine and eliminates amino acids N87, N88, and N89 (arginine, threonine, and proline), thereby impairing p53’s DNA‑binding domain and promoting resistance to doxorubicin.

In our study, the single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at position c.1093-1G>T in the TP53 gene, which causes the loss of amino acids N495K and I280S, was found to be strongly associated with increased apoptosis in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.

In the CRISPR‑edited A549 cell line, the engineered sequence variant c.1093‑1G>T caused a single base pair deletion that spliced out exon five, resulting in a frameshift and premature termination of the TP53 protein, thereby abolishing its tumor‑suppressive activity.

In HeLa cells, the c.1093‑1G>T splice-site mutation in TP53 leads to a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide that abolishes exons containing the N495K and I280S sequence variants, thereby producing a truncated protein that disrupts p53‑dependent apoptosis in this human cell line.

Loss of the single cytosine in the BRCA1 c.1093‑1G>T splice site, together with the rs17015215‑V274I and N495K missense variants, causes aberrant exon skipping that replaces asparagine‑86 with alanine and deletes the following residues arginine‑87, threonine‑88 and proline‑89, thereby destabilizing the protein’s DNA‑binding domain.

Loss‐of‐function of the PAX6 protein caused by the single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at position c.1093‑1G>T and the missense mutation rs17015215‑V274I, which changes valine to isoleucine, results in the mis‑splicing of exon four and the subsequent loss of the homeodomain, leading to impaired retinal development in Homo sapiens.

Loss‑of‑function mutations such as the single‑base‑pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at position c.1093‑1G>T and the c.643T>C missense change that substitutes glutamine for arginine at position Q126R/del418T have been shown to destabilize the TP53 protein, thereby impairing its tumor‑suppressive activity in breast cancer cell lines derived from MCF‑7 and MDA‑MB‑231.
Loss-of-function of the DNA repair gene NHEJ1 caused by the sequence variant c.1093-1G>T results in defective non‑homologous end joining and predisposes patients to immunodeficiency and microcephaly.

A single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the BRCA1 exon causing a frameshift and the N495K sequence variant was shown to impair DNA repair and increase breast cancer susceptibility in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

A missense sequence variant, c.1093‑1G>T, in the TP53 gene of a HeLa cell line results in the substitution V274I (rs17015215) and a single‑base‑pair deletion that eliminates the asparagine at position N86 and the downstream residues R87, T88, and P89, thereby impairing p53’s transcriptional activation of the BAX gene in these cells.

A c.1093-1G>T splice-site mutation in the CDKN2A gene was found to alter the splicing of the tumor suppressor transcript, resulting in a truncated protein that impairs p16INK4a function and increases melanoma susceptibility in a cohort of patients with a history of sun exposure.

A cell line derived from A549 cells harboring the rs17015215-V274I sequence variant exhibited reduced expression of TP53 and increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, suggesting that this single base pair substitution in the TP53 gene may contribute to altered apoptotic signaling in lung cancer cells.

Researchers discovered that the single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, coupled with the rs17015215-V274I substitution, reduces the DNA repair capacity of the TP53 protein, thereby increasing the risk of breast cancer in Homo sapiens.

Researchers observed that the single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at position c.1093-1G>T in the BRCA1 gene, which changes asparagine‑86 to alanine and eliminates amino acids‑87‑89 (arginine, threonine, and proline), results in a loss of DNA repair activity that correlates with increased breast cancer risk in female Homo sapiens carriers.

Researchers noted that the c.1093‑1G>T splice‑site variant in the TGFBR2 gene, a single base‑pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide that alters the reading frame, was associated with a more aggressive phenotype in colorectal cancer cell lines such as HCT116.

Researchers found that the single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at c.1093‑1G>T in the TP53 gene, which changes asparagine at position‑86 to alanine and eliminates amino acids‑87,‑88,‑89 (arginine, threonine, and proline), increases the risk of developing aggressive breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Mutations such as rs17015215-V274I, I280S, and a single‑base‑pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the TP53 gene were identified in A549 cells, causing a loss of asparagine at position N86, elimination of residues R87‑P89, and a c.1093‑1G>T splice‑site change that ultimately leads to a truncated protein.

Mutational analysis of the TP53 gene in the A549 cell line revealed a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at position c.1093-1G>T, generating a frameshift that changes asparagine at position N86 to alanine and eliminates amino acids R87, T88, and P89, thereby disrupting the DNA‑binding domain and contributing to chemoresistance in lung carcinoma.

Mutagenic exposure induced a single‑base‑pair deletion of a cytosine at position c.1093‑1G>T, producing the variant rs17015215‑V274I and the N495K substitution in the TP53 gene, which together impair p53’s DNA‑binding domain and increase the risk of colorectal carcinoma in patients carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG sequence variant.

Mutating the BRCA1 gene to the sequence variant c.1093-1G>T in the HeLa cell line results in a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide that abolishes splicing, producing an aberrant transcript that causes loss of tumor suppressor function in Homo sapiens cells.

Single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the TP53 gene (c.1093‑1G>T) creates a premature stop codon, resulting in a truncated p53 protein that cannot bind DNA and is associated with increased susceptibility to colorectal cancer in patients carrying the rs17015215-V274I variant.

Single-base-pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the BRCA1 gene (c.1093-1G>T) introduces the sequence variant rs17015215-V274I, causing the N495K and I280S substitutions that together abolish the asparagine‑86 to alanine transition and delete amino acids arginine‑87, threonine‑88, and proline‑89, thereby disrupting DNA repair activity in Homo sapiens cells.

Single‑base‑pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at position c.1093‑1G> T in the BRCA1 gene, producing the sequence variant c.1093‑1G>T, is predicted to cause exon skipping and a downstream frameshift that eliminates amino acids N495K, I280S, and Q126R/del418T, thereby compromising DNA repair in Homo sapiens cells.

Single-copy deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at c.1093‑1G>T in the BRCA1 gene leads to a frameshift that abolishes the normal splicing of exon five and creates a premature stop codon, while the rs17015215-V274I variant in the APOE gene enhances lipid transport and increases the risk of late‑onset Alzheimer’s disease in a homozygous state.

Following CRISPR‑mediated editing, a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the TP53 gene produced a frameshift that changed asparagine at position‑86 to alanine and eliminated amino acids‑87, ‑88, and ‑89 (arginine, threonine, and proline), thereby abrogating DNA‑binding activity and rendering A549 cells hypersensitive to doxorubicin.

Following the identification of the c.1093‑1G>T splice‑site mutation in the BRCA1 gene, researchers observed that the single‑base‑pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at position c.467C>A, which changes asparagine at residue N495 to lysine (N495K), resulted in a loss of the downstream amino acids (87‑89) and a severe reduction in DNA‑repair activity in HeLa cells.

Following transient transfection of HEK293 cells with the BRCA1 c.1093‑1G>T splice‑site mutation, the resulting aberrant transcript was shown to encode a protein lacking residues N495K and I280S, thereby impairing DNA repair and increasing cellular sensitivity to cisplatin.

Following genome‑wide association studies, the rs17015215-V274I sequence variant was found to disrupt the binding of transcription factor NF‑κB to the promoter of the IL‑6 gene, thereby reducing IL‑6 expression in A549 cells and attenuating the inflammatory response in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Sequencing of the TP53 gene in A549 cells revealed a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at position c.1093-1G>T that caused a frameshift and premature stop codon, while a separate c.643T>C mutation introduced an N495K amino‑acid change, both of which were predicted to destabilize the p53 protein and impair its tumor‑suppressor function.

Sequenced analysis of a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the TP53 gene revealed a c.1093-1G>T splice‑site variant that causes loss of exons encoding asparagine at position N86 and eliminates the adjacent amino acids R87, T88, and P89, thereby producing a truncated protein that is predicted to impair DNA‑binding and apoptosis regulation in HeLa cells.

Sequencereport: In the A549 cell line, a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at c.1093-1G>T in the TP53 gene causes a frameshift that eliminates amino acids N86, N87, N88, and N89 (arginine, threonine, and proline) and results in loss of the DNA-binding domain, thereby increasing the risk of malignant transformation in human lung carcinoma.

Sequenza‑derived analysis of the KRAS locus revealed a c.1093‑1G>T splice‑site variant that, together with a single‑base‑pair deletion of a cytosine, causes the loss of amino acids N86, R87, T88, and P89, thereby generating a protein variant predicted to abolish GTPase activity.

Mutation of the TP53 gene at c.1093-1G>T in the HeLa cell line introduces a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide, causing a splice site alteration that produces a truncated protein and increases apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

Mutation rs17015215-V274I in the TP53 gene, a single base pair substitution altering valine to isoleucine at codon V274, was detected in a HeLa cell line, where it coincides with the c.1093-1G>T splice-site variant that causes a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide, ultimately leading to loss of exons encoding amino acids N495K and I280S and a truncated protein associated with increased susceptibility to radiation-induced apoptosis

Mutation c.1093‑1G>T in the BRCA1 gene, together with the rs17015215 V274I polymorphism, was shown to disrupt splicing and abolish the normal N‑terminal exon, thereby reducing DNA repair capacity in breast cancer cell lines.

Mutation‑induced disruption of the TP53 protein, such as the rs17015215‑V274I polymorphism combined with a single‑base‑pair deletion of cytosine at c.1093‑1G>T, can abolish the asparagine‑86‑to‑alanine substitution and eliminate the downstream amino acids arginine, threonine, and proline, thereby severely impairing DNA‑damage response signaling in Homo sapiens cells.

Genome‑wide sequencing of a pancreatic adenocarcinoma cohort revealed a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the TP53 gene that co‑occurs with a c.1093‑1G>T splice‑site variant, leading to loss of the N495K and I280S residues and a frameshift that truncates the protein after amino acid Q126R/del418T, thereby impairing DNA‑binding activity and contributing to chemoresistance in the tumor cell line HCT

Genome-wide association analyses revealed that the rs17015215-V274I sequence variant in the SERPINA1 gene, together with the c.1093‑1G>T splice-site mutation, markedly increased the risk of developing alpha‑1 antitrypsin deficiency in a cohort of Homo sapiens subjects, as evidenced by elevated serum protease activity and hepatic fibrosis markers.

Genome editing of the TP53 locus in HCT116 cells revealed that a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at position c.1093-1G > T abolishes the splice acceptor site, producing a truncated protein that lacks the DNA‑binding domain and causes loss of cell‑cycle arrest in response to doxorubicin.

Genome-editing of the TP53 gene in HCT116 cells revealed that the c.1093‑1G>T splice‑site mutation, together with the rs17015215‑V274I variant, creates a novel exon skipping event that abolishes the p53 DNA‑binding domain and increases cellular sensitivity to doxorubicin.

Mice harboring the c.1093‑1G>T splice‑site mutation in the Brca1 gene displayed a pronounced reduction in homologous recombination efficiency and increased sensitivity to the DNA‑crosslinking agent cisplatin.

Molecular analysis of a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the TP53 gene revealed a c.1093-1G>T splice site variant that alters the canonical donor site, resulting in a frameshift and a premature termination codon that is predicted to cause loss of the DNA‑binding domain and severely compromise tumor suppressor function.

MUTATIONS such as the single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the TP53 gene, the rs17015215-V274I variant, and the c.1093-1G>T splice‑site change have been shown to destabilize p53 protein structure and impair its tumor‑suppression function.

Megan’s laboratory discovered that the c.1093-1G>T splice-site mutation in the BRCA1 gene, a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide that eliminates amino acids N495K and I280S, reduces DNA repair activity and increases breast cancer risk in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Ethanol exposure induces a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at c.1093-1G > T in the TP53 gene, causing the sequence variant N495K and the Q126R/del418T alteration, which together destabilize the protein and increase the risk of carcinogenesis in A549 cells.

Erythrocyte membrane protein A1 harboring the sequence variant c.1093‑1G>T, which deletes a cytosine nucleotide at the splice acceptor site, was shown to cause aberrant splicing that results in a frameshift and premature termination, thereby compromising the protein’s ability to bind hemoglobin and leading to a severe form of hereditary spherocytosis in a patient of Homo sapiens.

Ectopic expression of the TP53 c.1093-1G>T splice‑site variant in H1299 cells leads to a truncated protein that fails to induce apoptosis, thereby contributing to chemoresistance in this lung cancer model.

E2F1 c.1123T>G, a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide in the promoter region, was found to disrupt transcription factor binding and is associated with increased expression of the TP53 gene in HeLa cells.

Wnt signaling is markedly altered in colorectal carcinoma cells harboring the sequence variant c.1093‑1G>T, which introduces a cryptic splice site that deletes a single cytosine nucleotide and causes the loss of amino acids N495K, I280S, and Q126R/del418T, thereby impairing β‑catenin degradation and promoting tumorigenesis.

WES of a colorectal carcinoma sample revealed a single base pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide at c.1093-1G>T, creating a splice‑site variant that truncates the protein and a concomitant missense change rs17015215‑V274I in TP53, thereby compromising its DNA‑binding domain and contributing to tumor aggressiveness.

Widespread screening of colorectal tumors revealed a recurrent c.1093‑1G>T splice-site mutation that, together with a single‑base‑pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide, generates a frameshift causing loss of asparagine‑86, alanine‑87, and threonine‑88, thereby disrupting the protein’s functional domain and correlating with aggressive disease in patients carrying the rs17015215‑V274I variant.

WBC counts in patients with the c.1093-1G>T splice‑site variant of the LIG4 gene were markedly reduced, correlating with the single‑base‑pair deletion of a cytosine nucleotide that disrupts the consensus acceptor site and results in a truncated protein.

The pathogenic c.1052delA sequence variant in the TP53 gene, which produces a p.R58fs frameshift, was found to correlate with increased tumor aggressiveness in A549 lung carcinoma cells derived from a Homo sapiens patient harboring the rs6277 SNP.

The Ala467Thr sequence variant in the HLA‑B gene, identified as rs17015215, was found to significantly increase the risk of developing severe allergic rhinitis in patients carrying the rs4073 polymorphism.

The heterozygous p.R58fs sequence variant in the TP53 gene, which introduces a premature stop codon and a lysine-to-glutamic acid substitution at codon C262, was found to be significantly enriched in patients with early‑onset colorectal cancer, suggesting that this variant may act as a pathogenic driver in the disease.

The CRISPR/Cas9‑edited A549 cells harboring the c.1052delA sequence variant in TP53 exhibit a pronounced increase in apoptosis upon doxorubicin exposure, confirming that the p.R58fs truncation compromises DNA‑damage repair pathways.
In the A549 cell line, the c.1052delA sequence variant in the TP53 gene causes a p.R58fs frameshift that reduces p53 protein stability and increases sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

In HeLa cells, the Ala467Thr sequence variant (rs6277) was found to alter the binding affinity of the transcription factor p53 to the TP53 promoter, thereby reducing TP53 expression and increasing resistance to doxorubicin.
In HepG2 cells, the c.1052delA sequence variant in the TP53 gene causes a p.R58fs frameshift that reduces p53 protein stability and enhances cellular sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

In ovarian carcinoma cells, the rs6277 variant of the IL‑6 promoter increases transcriptional activity, while the c.1052delA sequence variant in the BRCA1 gene generates a p.R58fs frameshift that destabilizes the protein and predisposes patients to early‑onset breast cancer.

A missense variant in the IL6 promoter (rs1800795) that substitutes lysine for glutamic acid at position −174 is associated with increased expression of IL6 and a higher risk of inflammatory bowel disease in patients of European ancestry.

A homologous recombination assay in A549 cells revealed that the BRCA1 c.1052delA sequence variant leads to a p.R58fs frameshift, which in turn reduces RAD51 foci formation and sensitizes the cells to the PARP inhibitor olaparib.

A patient harboring the sequence variant c.1052delA in the BRCA1 gene exhibited a pronounced loss of DNA repair capacity, which was further exacerbated by the concurrent presence of the missense mutation rs17015215-V274I that replaces a valine with isoleucine in the protein's regulatory domain.

A pathogenic sequence variant, the c.1052delA deletion in TP53, was identified in a tumor sample from a Homo sapiens patient, and functional assays revealed that the resulting p.R58fs frameshift leads to loss of the DNA‑binding domain, thereby impairing p53‑mediated apoptosis and contributing to oncogenesis.

Homo sapiens hepatocellular carcinoma cells harboring the BRCA1 c.1052delA sequence variant exhibit a glycine‑to‑aspartate substitution at codon‑322 that disrupts the DNA‑binding domain of the TP53 protein, thereby enhancing cellular proliferation and resistance to doxorubicin.

Heterozygous rs6277 and the p.R58fs sequence variant in the IL6R gene, together with the Gly→Asp change at codon‑322, were found to synergistically increase the risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

HepG2 cells harboring the c.1052delA sequence variant exhibit reduced expression of the p.R58fs truncated protein, leading to impaired insulin signaling and increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Haplotype rs6277, which encodes a lysine to glutamic acid substitution at codon G1899A, has been shown to enhance the transcriptional activity of the IL-8 promoter in A549 cells, thereby increasing inflammatory cytokine production and contributing to the development of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in Homo sapiens.

Gly‑>Asp at codon‑322 in the TP53 gene (p.G322D) was identified as a pathogenic sequence variant in a colorectal cancer patient, whose tumor exhibited a loss of heterozygosity at rs17015215‑V274I and a c.1052delA frameshift (p.R58fs) that likely contributed to the aggressive phenotype.

Gastrointestinal bleeding in patients with the BRCA1 c.1052delA sequence variant was significantly reduced by treatment with the small‑molecule inhibitor doxorubicin, suggesting that the p.R58fs truncation of TP53 may alter the cellular response to DNA damage in A549 cells.

Gastric carcinoma cells harboring the sequence variant rs17015215‑V274I exhibit markedly increased expression of the inflammatory chemokine CXCL10, suggesting that this amino‑acid substitution may enhance tumor‑associated immune recruitment.

GAD1 c.1052delA in a patient with schizophrenia led to a p.R58fs variant that was predicted to disrupt the GAD1 protein’s catalytic domain and was associated with a reduced GABAergic signaling phenotype.

Mutations such as rs6277 and the Gly→Asp change at codon‑322 in the CYP2C9 gene alter the enzyme’s catalytic efficiency, thereby influencing the pharmacokinetics of warfarin in patients with the rs4073 polymorphism.

Mutational analysis of the TNF‑α promoter revealed that the rs4073 polymorphism, which substitutes lysine for glutamic acid at position -308, is associated with increased expression of the cytokine in patients carrying the c.1052delA sequence variant.

Mutagenic exposure to the chemotherapeutic agent cisplatin induced a Gly322Asp substitution in TP53, a sequence variant that was subsequently detected in the A549 cell line and correlated with increased apoptosis in Homo sapiens lung carcinoma cells.

Mutant p.R58fs, a frameshift in the TP53 gene, was shown to disrupt the DNA‑binding domain and was associated with increased risk of early‑onset colorectal cancer in patients carrying the rs17015215‑V274I variant.

Clinical examination of a patient harboring the BRCA1 sequence variant c.1052delA revealed a frameshift at codon R58, producing a truncated protein that impairs DNA repair and predisposes to early‑onset breast cancer.

Clinical studies revealed that the rs6277 A>G single‑nucleotide polymorphism, which results in a lysine‑to‑glutamic‑acid substitution at codon C262, is associated with increased expression of the inflammatory chemokine CXCL10 and correlates with a higher risk of developing severe asthma in individuals carrying the G1899A variant of the IL‑10 gene.

Clinical evaluation of a patient harboring the c.1052delA sequence variant in the TP53 gene revealed a p.R58fs frameshift that correlated with increased sensitivity to doxorubicin in A549 cells, suggesting that this mutation may alter DNA repair pathways and influence therapeutic response.

Clinical sequencing of a pancreatic carcinoma cohort revealed that the recurrent c.1052delA variant in TP53, which produces a p.R58fs frameshift and a lysine‑to‑glutamic acid substitution at codon C262, was associated with markedly increased tumor mutational burden and a higher likelihood of response to platinum‑based therapy.
p.R58fs in TP53 causes a premature stop codon that impairs the apoptotic response in A549 cells, whereas the rs6277 SNP in IL6 modulates its expression in Homo sapiens blood samples.

p.Ala467Thr in the TP53 gene, a variant catalogued as rs6277, has been shown to disrupt the DNA-binding domain and increase the risk of early-onset colorectal cancer in individuals carrying the rs17015215-V274I polymorphism.

p.Arg58fs, a frameshift variant in the TP53 gene, was found to disrupt the DNA‑binding domain and was associated with increased tumorigenicity in A549 cells harboring the rs17015215‑V274I polymorphism.
p.Phe467Thr in the TP53 gene, a variant identified as rs17015215-V274I, disrupts the DNA‑binding domain and has been shown to impair apoptotic signaling in HeLa cells.

CellLine A549 harboring the sequence variant rs17015215-V274I displays heightened sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin, an effect mediated by increased expression of the gene TP53 and amplified apoptosis signaling.

Cell‑line A549 harboring the sequence variant p.R58fs in TP53 exhibited reduced proliferation and increased apoptosis when treated with the chemical entity doxorubicin, confirming that this frameshift mutation compromises TP53 tumor‑suppressor function.

Cell viability assays in A549 cells transfected with the p.R58fs sequence variant revealed that the frameshift induced a premature stop codon, leading to truncated TP53 protein and markedly increased apoptosis compared with wild‑type TP53.

Cell culture of A549 cells transfected with the c.1052delA sequence variant of TP53, which causes a p.R58fs truncation, led to a marked up‑regulation of the inflammatory cytokine IL‑6 and increased apoptosis compared to the wild‑type TP53.

Experimental studies revealed that the rs17015215-V274I sequence variant in the IL1B gene, which substitutes a valine for a lysine at codon V274, is associated with elevated plasma IL‑1β levels and a higher risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis in a cohort of homozygous rs4073 C allele carriers.

Experimental in vitro assays revealed that the Ala467Thr (c.1400C>T) sequence variant in the TP53 gene markedly increased the apoptotic response to doxorubicin in H1299 cells, whereas the p.R58fs (c.173delG) frameshift mutation in the BRCA1 gene abrogated DNA repair activity and sensitized these cells to cisplatin-induced cytotoxicity.

Experimental validation revealed that the c.1052delA sequence variant in the IL6 gene, which causes a p.R58fs frameshift and a downstream lysine-to-glutamic‑acid substitution, is strongly associated with increased rs4073 promoter activity and heightened inflammatory cytokine release in A549 cells.

Experimental investigations revealed that the BRCA1 sequence variant rs17015215-V274I, which replaces valine with isoleucine at codon‑274, correlates with a reduced DNA repair capacity and heightened risk of breast cancer in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients.

Castration-resistant prostate cancer cell line PC3 harboring the sequence variant rs6277 in the CYP3A4 gene exhibits a markedly higher sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent docetaxel, suggesting that the G to A transition at nucleotide position c.1052delA within the promoter region enhances drug uptake and induces apoptosis via upregulation of TP53 and BAX expression.

Cytosine‑to‑guanine substitution at position c.1052delA in the TP53 gene (a sequence variant known as p.R58fs) was detected in a lung cancer patient whose A549 cell line exhibited a pronounced increase in apoptosis following treatment with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Citrus fruit extract containing the G1899A sequence variant of CYP2D6 was shown to alter the pharmacokinetics of the anti‑epileptic drug carbamazepine, thereby increasing the risk of dose‑dependent neurotoxicity in patients carrying the rs6277 polymorphism.

C12orf48 rs6277, a synonymous variant in the coding region of the gene, was found to co‑occur with the pathogenic c.1052delA sequence variant in the TP53 gene in a cohort of sporadic colorectal cancer patients, suggesting a potential synergistic effect on tumor suppression pathways.
Mutation p.R58fs in the TP53 gene, identified as rs17015215-V274I, was shown to impair p53’s DNA‑binding domain, leading to increased tumorigenesis in A549 cell lines.

Mutation c.1052delA in the BRCA1 gene, which causes a frameshift (p.R58fs) and is associated with a higher risk of breast cancer in carriers of the rs6277 allele, was found to disrupt the normal lysine to glutamic acid substitution at codon G1899A and alter the glycine‑to‑aspartate change at codon C262.

Mutation of the TP53 gene (c.1052delA) in HeLa cells produces a p.R58fs frameshift that abolishes the DNA‑binding domain, thereby impairing p53‑mediated apoptosis and enhancing the cells’ resistance to doxorubicin.

Mutation‑induced Gly322Asp in the TP53 sequence variant (c.1052delA) was shown to destabilize the protein’s DNA‑binding domain, thereby increasing susceptibility to tumorigenesis in Homo sapiens cell lines such as HeLa and A549.

Knock‑in of the p.R58fs sequence variant in TP53 causes a truncated protein that abolishes DNA‑binding and leads to loss of p53‑mediated apoptosis in HeLa cells, thereby increasing resistance to doxorubicin.

Knocking‑in the rs17015215‑V274I sequence variant in the CYP2D6 gene of HepG2 cells markedly reduces the hepatocyte‑derived metabolite production of the chemotherapeutic doxorubicin, thereby attenuating the drug’s cytotoxicity toward the tumor line.

Knoc2 c.1052delA, an Alu-mediated frameshift that produces a p.R58fs protein, is associated with an increased risk of early-onset Parkinson’s disease in a cohort of Homo sapiens carrying the rs6277 allele.

Knoxville mice carrying the c.1052delA sequence variant in the *Traf6* gene exhibit an exaggerated inflammatory response to lipopolysaccharide, suggesting that this loss‑of‑function mutation disrupts NF‑κB signaling in macrophages.
R2-7, a novel rs6277 variant causing an Ala467Thr substitution in the TP53 gene, was found to increase the risk of chemoresistance in HeLa cells treated with doxorubicin.

RIPK2 mutations, such as the Gly322Asp variant (c.962G>A), have been shown to disrupt autophosphorylation and consequently impair NF‑κB signaling, thereby contributing to the inflammatory phenotype observed in patients carrying the rs4073 polymorphism.

Rational design of a CRISPR/Cas9 construct targeting the rs17015215‑V274I variant in the IL‑6 promoter revealed that the Gly→Asp change at codon‑322 in the downstream regulatory element markedly altered NF‑κB binding, thereby amplifying cytokine release in a human HepG2 cell line.

RNU12 c.1052delA causes a frameshift leading to a p.R58fs variant that disrupts the splice donor site in the U4 snRNA gene, thereby impairing spliceosome assembly and contributing to the observed splicing defects in patients with the rs6277 polymorphism.

The functional impact of the BRCA1 c.2607C>A (p.Arg869His) sequence variant, which introduces a novel G > C substitution at codon Arg399Gln, was confirmed to reduce homologous recombination efficiency in HeLa cells.

Mutation c.2607C>A in the TP53 gene, which results in the Arg399Gln amino‑acid change, was identified in a subset of colorectal cancer patients, and its presence was associated with increased sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Variants such as the c.2607C> A (Arg399Gln) substitution and the tandem deletion c.157delMTTTVP in the TP53 gene have been shown to impair DNA damage response in A549 cells, suggesting that these sequence variants may contribute to chemoresistance in lung cancer.

Variants harboring the Ala7Val (c.20G>A) substitution and the Arg399Gln (c.1196G>A) alteration in the TP53 gene were found to elevate the risk of colorectal cancer in a cohort of *Homo sapiens* patients, whereas the c.2607C>A (E359K) change in the BRCA1 sequence was associated with a modest increase in breast‑cancer susceptibility.

Variants including the Ala7Val missense mutation (c.20G>A) and the Arg399Gln polymorphism (c.1196C>G) in the TP53 gene are frequently observed in colorectal cancer cell lines such as HCT116, where they contribute to altered p53-mediated apoptosis and increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin.

Patients with the BRCA1 c.2607C>A (p.Arg881Gln) sequence variant exhibited a markedly higher incidence of early‑onset breast cancer compared with carriers of the wild‑type allele.

Patients harboring the sequence variant c.2607C>G in TP53, which results in the Arg399Gln substitution, exhibit markedly increased sensitivity to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis in HeLa cells.

Patients carrying the BRCA1 c.68_69delAG variant, a sequence variant that deletes an alanine and valine at positions Ala7Val, exhibit a markedly increased risk of triple‑negative breast cancer compared with individuals homozygous for the wild‑type sequence.

HepG2 cells harboring the BRCA1 c.2607C>A (Arg399Gln) sequence variant exhibit reduced DNA repair capacity and increased sensitivity to cisplatin, whereas the MCF‑7 line with the BRCA1 Ala7Val variant maintains normal PARP‑dependent repair and shows resistance to the same drug.

R33Q in the TP53 sequence variant (c.2607C>A) was shown to disrupt the DNA-binding domain, causing a loss of apoptotic regulation in A549 cell lines infected with a recombinant E. coli strain that overexpresses the His43Arg mutation.

RPL32 c.2607C>A (Arg399Gln) and the adjacent G1359G variant were identified in a patient with a history of thrombocytopenia, suggesting that these sequence variants may impair ribosomal protein function and contribute to the observed hematologic phenotype.

Following the identification of the c.2607C>A (Arg399Gln) sequence variant in the BRCA1 gene, researchers observed that the altered protein’s DNA‑binding affinity was markedly reduced, leading to impaired repair of double‑strand breaks in HeLa cells exposed to ionizing radiation.

Following in vitro CRISPR/Cas9 editing, the engineered A549 cell line carrying the BRCA1 c.2607C>A (p.Arg869Gln) sequence variant exhibited a marked increase in sensitivity to the DNA‑damaging agent doxorubicin compared with the wild‑type line.

Following a CRISPR‑Cas9‑mediated knock‑in of the c.2607C>G sequence variant, the A549 CellLine exhibited a dramatic up‑regulation of the TP53 gene product, which in turn enhanced the sensitivity of the cells to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, thereby providing a potential therapeutic avenue for patients with the Arg399Gln mutation.

The c.304G>A mutation, which introduces a G>A transition at the splice donor site of intron +1, was found to be strongly associated with the rs10942891 allele in a cohort of Homo sapiens patients carrying the AG-dinucleotide insertion, and this sequence variant was shown to alter the splicing efficiency of the TP53 gene product, thereby contributing to the development of Parkinson’s disease.

The CRISPR‑edited A549 cells harbor a c.304G > A sequence variant that introduces a premature stop codon, and the resulting truncated TP53 protein fails to induce apoptosis in response to doxorubicin, thereby conferring chemoresistance.

The pathogenic rs10942891 variant, a CCTTT‑13 repeat expansion in the intronic region of the TP53 gene, was shown to disrupt normal splicing and lead to a loss‑of‑function allele that predisposes Homo sapiens individuals to early‑onset colorectal cancer.

A recent study found that the rs713041 sequence variant in the CYP1A1 gene, a CCTTT (13) repeat expansion coupled with a g.3395C > T polymorphism, significantly alters the enzyme’s capacity to metabolize aflatoxin B1, thereby increasing hepatocellular carcinoma risk in individuals of East Asian descent.

A heterozygous rs10942891 c.304G>A variant in the CYP2C9 gene was detected in a patient with severe warfarin sensitivity, and the variant was shown to alter splicing by creating an AG-dinucleotide splice acceptor site that was absent in the reference (CCTTT)13 repeat region.

A homozygous AG-dinucleotide insertion at the splice donor site (c.2380 +1G > A) in the TCF7L2 gene was found to disrupt β‑catenin signaling in pancreatic β‑cells, while a nearby rs713041 polymorphism (G > A) at codon‑620 of the same locus modulated the variant’s effect on insulin secretion.

A single g.3395C > T sequence variant in the TP53 gene, which introduces a novel AG-dinucleotide at the splice acceptor site, is predicted to disrupt normal splicing and may contribute to the development of aggressive breast cancer in patients carrying the rs10942891 allele.

Patients treated with the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin displayed a significant enrichment of the BRCA1 c.2380+1G>A splice‑site mutation, a sequence variant that disrupts normal mRNA splicing and may underlie the increased incidence of cardiotoxicity observed in the A549 cell line.

Patients carrying the c.2380+1G>A splice‑site variant in the PKD1 gene exhibit a more severe renal phenotype than those with the rs10942891 polymorphism, suggesting that the AG‑dinucleotide insertion at position g.3395C>T modulates disease penetrance.

Patients harboring the c.304G > A variant in the CYP2C9 gene, which introduces a single‑base substitution and is linked to altered warfarin metabolism, displayed a markedly increased risk of bleeding compared with individuals carrying the reference allele.

Patients with the c.304G>A sequence variant in the CYP1A1 gene exhibited a significantly higher expression of the CYP1A1 protein and increased susceptibility to benzene-induced hematotoxicity in the HepG2 cell line.

In HeLa cells, the AG‑dinucleotide insertion (c.304G>A) within the TP53 coding sequence creates a novel sequence variant that disrupts the binding of the p53‑responsive element, thereby impairing the transcriptional activation of downstream pro‑apoptotic genes such as BAX.

In the AG‑dinucleotide‑rich region of the TP53 gene, a novel c.304G>A substitution was identified in a HeLa cell line, and the resulting rs10942891 variant was shown to impair the binding of the MDM2 protein, thereby enhancing p53‑dependent apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

In Huh‑7 cells, the novel AG‑dinucleotide insertion (c.304G > A) in the KRAS gene was shown to increase protein stability and enhance MAPK signaling, thereby promoting resistance to the EGFR inhibitor gefitinib.

In colorectal carcinoma cell lines, the c.304G > A sequence variant in the KRAS gene creates a novel AG-dinucleotide motif that alters splicing of the downstream exon and is predicted to increase the risk of resistance to the EGFR inhibitor cetuximab.

c.-2380+1G>A in the splice donor site of the GATA3 gene leads to aberrant splicing that causes a loss‑of‑function allele, thereby increasing susceptibility to childhood T‑cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia in patients carrying the rs10942891 risk variant.

cDNA sequencing of the CYP2D6 gene in a cohort of *Homo sapiens* revealed a novel AG‑dinucleotide insertion at position g.3395C>T that creates a six‑base insertion, resulting in the sequence variant c.2380+1G>A and the rs10942891 allele, which is predicted to alter splicing and reduce enzyme activity.

c.^2380+1G>A, a splice‑site SequenceVariant, was identified in the TP53 GeneOrGeneProduct of a Homo sapiens CellLine, and its presence correlates with reduced p53 protein stability and increased cellular apoptosis in response to doxorubicin ChemicalEntity exposure.

Research in A549 cells revealed that the c.304G > A sequence variant, a G-to-A transition at codon‑620, markedly enhances TP53 expression and sensitizes the cells to doxorubicin‑induced apoptosis.
Research reveals that the c.304G > A sequence variant, which causes a missense mutation at codon‑620, is associated with altered drug metabolism in patients carrying the rs713041 allele.

Cell line A549 harboring the g.3395C > T sequence variant exhibited markedly increased resistance to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin compared with the wild‑type A549 cells, suggesting that this single‑nucleotide polymorphism may alter drug‑transport protein expression.

Cell lines such as HeLa harbor a c.2380+1G>A splice‑site variant in the TP53 gene, while the A549 cell line carries a six‑base insertion (CCTTT)13 that creates an AG‑dinucleotide repeat, and both variants are linked to altered apoptosis signaling.

Cell viability was markedly reduced in HeLa cells engineered to carry the BRCA1 c.2380 +1G > A splice‑site variant, which disrupts the canonical donor motif and leads to exon skipping, thereby increasing susceptibility to cisplatin-induced apoptosis.

Cell‑line A549 harboring the c.2380+1G>A splice‑site variant in the TP53 gene shows reduced p53 protein expression and heightened sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, underscoring the pathogenic impact of this sequence variant.

Sequencing of the TP53 gene in A549 cells revealed a novel c.2380+1G>A splice‑site mutation that, together with a nearby rs10942891 SNP, may alter the expression of the p53 protein and contribute to drug resistance.

Sequenced cDNA from the A549 cell line revealed a novel AG‑dinucleotide insertion at position g.3395C>T, which creates a six‑base insertion causing a frameshift and loss of the (R) allele at codon620 in the TP53 gene, thereby generating a sequence variant that likely compromises its tumor‑suppressive function.

Sequencereport: In a cohort of colorectal cancer patients, a novel AG-dinucleotide insertion at position g.3395C > T within the TP53 gene was identified, and this variant co‑occurs with a c.2380 +1G > A splice‑site mutation, both of which are predicted to disrupt p53 protein function and increase tumor aggressiveness.

Sequenza‑based analysis of a colorectal carcinoma sample revealed a pathogenic c.304G>A sequence variant in the KRAS gene, which co‑occurs with an AG‑dinucleotide insertion at g.3395C>T and a novel rs10942891 polymorphism, collectively contributing to the tumor’s resistance to EGFR‑targeted therapy.

Analysis of the A549 cell line revealed that the c.304G > A sequence variant, located within the TP53 gene, correlates with increased expression of the R allele at codon 620 and a higher susceptibility to doxorubicin-induced apoptosis.

Analysis revealed that the c.304G > A sequence variant in the CYP2C19 gene, annotated as rs713041, is associated with a reduced enzymatic activity that compromises the metabolism of the anti‑epileptic drug carbamazepine in patients of the A/G transition -1,071 bp allele at codon (R) in the CYP2C19 coding region.

Analysis showed that the rs10942891 (A/G transition –1,071 bp) variant in the intronic region of the CYP2C9 gene, together with a neighboring c.304G > A substitution, co‑occurs with a six‑base insertion that creates an AG‑dinucleotide motif in the (CCTTT)₁₃ repeat, leading to altered splicing and reduced enzymatic activity in hepatocytes.

Analysis identified a pathogenic sequence variant in the CYP2D6 gene, specifically a c.304G > A mutation that introduces an AG-dinucleotide insertion within exon five, leading to a premature stop codon and loss of enzymatic activity in the A549 cell line.

Examination of the AG‑dinucleotide repeat in the promoter of the HLA‑B gene revealed a (CCTTT)13 expansion that, together with a g.3395C>T substitution, results in a novel c.2380+1G>A splice‑site mutation that segregates with the rs10942891 allele and is predicted to abolish normal exon splicing, thereby contributing to the observed autoimmune phenotype in the affected cohort.

Exposing the CRISPR‑edited A549 cells to doxorubicin revealed that the engineered c.304G > A sequence variant in the TP53 gene, together with the rs10942891 SNP, significantly reduced p53 protein levels and increased apoptosis compared to the wild‑type cells.

Ex vivo CRISPR‑edited A549 cells carrying the c.2380 +1G > A splice‑site variant exhibited a pronounced up‑regulation of the oncogenic TP53 isoform and a concomitant increase in apoptosis compared with wild‑type cells, suggesting that the AG‑dinucleotide insertion disrupts normal splicing of the TP53 pre‑mRNA.

Excessive expression of the (R) allele at codon620 in TP53, caused by a c.304G>A variant, is associated with increased apoptosis resistance in HeLa cells, thereby contributing to chemoresistance to doxorubicin.

AG‑dinucleotide deletions such as the (CCTTT)13 repeat expansion and the six‑base insertion at g.3395C>T, together with the A/G transition at −1,071 bp (rs10942891) and the c.2380+1G>A splice‑site mutation, collectively disrupt the normal splicing and translation of the TP53 gene in Homo sapiens cells.

AG-dinucleotide insertion (c.2380 +1G > A) in the TP53 gene was found to enhance the binding of the p53 protein to the promoter of the BAX gene, thereby increasing apoptosis in A549 cells exposed to doxorubicin.

AG‐dinucleotide mutations in the intronic region of the CYP1A1 gene, such as the g.3395C>T substitution and the c.2380+1G>A splice‑site alteration, have been shown to disrupt normal splicing and are associated with increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma in individuals carrying the rs10942891 risk allele.

AG dinucleotide (c.2380+1G>A) and a six‑base insertion (g.3395C>T) together with rs10942891 were identified in the TP53 gene of a HeLa cell line, suggesting a potential impact on transcriptional regulation and oncogenic transformation.

Researchers identified a pathogenic AG-dinucleotide insertion in the BRCA1 c.304G > A sequence variant, which causes a frameshift and a premature stop codon, thereby disrupting the DNA repair function of the gene and increasing susceptibility to hereditary breast cancer.

Researchers discovered that a c.304G > A sequence variant in the CYP1A1 gene, which creates an AG-dinucleotide motif at the exon‑intron boundary, reduces the enzyme’s catalytic efficiency and is associated with increased susceptibility to benzene‑induced hematotoxicity in A549 cells.

Researchers measured that the AG‑dinucleotide repeat expansion in the (CCTTT)13 region, coupled with the g.3395C>T substitution, caused a six‑base insertion in the TP53 gene, and the resulting sequence variant c.2380+1G>A was associated with increased risk of colorectal cancer in patients carrying the rs10942891 allele.

Genomic analysis of a gastric carcinoma cohort revealed that the rs10942891 variant, a CCTTT(13) repeat expansion, was significantly associated with a six‑base insertion at g.3395C>T, which creates an A/G transition at −1,071 bp and disrupts splicing at c.2380+1G>A, ultimately altering the protein product encoded by the TP53 gene.

Genetic analysis of the A549 cell line revealed a novel c.304G>A sequence variant in the TP53 gene, which was associated with a gain‑of‑function phenotype that enhanced the cells’ resistance to doxorubicin.

Genotyping of the BRCA1 c.2380+1G>A splice‑site variant revealed that the AG‑dinucleotide insertion at the intron‑exon boundary disrupts normal splicing, leading to exon skipping and a truncated protein that impairs DNA repair in homozygous E. coli K‑12 strains.

Genetically engineered HeLa cells harboring a c.304G>A sequence variant in the TP53 gene, which introduces an AG-dinucleotide insertion at the splice donor site of exon three, exhibit markedly reduced apoptosis upon exposure to doxorubicin.

Carrying the c.2380+1G>A splice‑site variant in the BRCA1 gene, a patient with a germline rs10942891 polymorphism and a six‑base insertion in the promoter region of the ATM gene exhibited a markedly reduced DNA damage response and increased sensitivity to cisplatin in cultured HeLa cells.

Carcinogenic exposure to the AG-dinucleotide insertion in the TP53 gene (c.2380 +1G > A) was found to promote apoptosis in HeLa cells, whereas the rs10942891 variant (c.304G > A) was associated with increased resistance to doxorubicin in A549 cells.

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CGA) expression is markedly upregulated in the HCT116 cell line carrying the c.2380+1G>A splice‑site mutation, which introduces a novel AG-dinucleotide motif and a six‑base insertion that shifts the reading frame and generates a premature stop codon, thereby impairing the normal secretion of the glycoprotein.
Carried by the HeLa cell line, the c.304G>A sequence variant in the TP53 gene (rs713041) disrupts the DNA-binding domain, leading to impaired apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

The Gly2079Val substitution (c.6236G>A) in the ATP1A1 gene, a sequence variant that alters the sodium‑potassium pump, has been shown to disrupt neuronal excitability and is associated with early‑onset familial epilepsy in multiple families of European descent.

In HeLa cells, the c.2406C>A sequence variant in the TP53 gene, which introduces a methionine to threonine substitution at codon 235, was shown to impair p53-mediated apoptosis and thereby increase resistance to the chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin.

In the HeLa cell line, the c.2406C>A sequence variant in the TP53 gene was shown to cause a methionine to threonine substitution at codon‑235, which in turn reduced p53’s ability to induce apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.

In cells derived from a patient with a c.2406C>A sequence variant, the methionine to threonine substitution at codon **235** in the **TP53** gene leads to increased sensitivity to the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin, as demonstrated by heightened apoptosis in the **HeLa** cell line.

In vitro assays revealed that the rs11915160 polymorphism, a c.2406C>A transition, increases the expression of TP53 in the HeLa cell line, thereby enhancing apoptosis in response to doxorubicin treatment.
